As an immediate measure, the Parliament requests the government to implement a ban on the hiring of labor from businesses that are not production companies, at construction sites, in the counties of Oslo, Akershus, Østfold, Buskerud, and Vestfold, cf. the Working Environment Act § 14-12 (5) by July 1, 2019.
Make the necessary regulatory changes and present proposals for the necessary appropriations to strengthen employment services as a public task in connection with the state budget for 2020.
Promote a proposal for an amendment to the Working Environment Act § 14-12 (1) that ensures that hiring under this paragraph is limited to temporary replacements.
Promote a proposal to remove the general access to temporary employment.
Ensure that staffing agencies do not become training companies.

Initiate the work on a new living conditions survey for students at universities, colleges, and vocational schools to ensure a good and updated data foundation regarding, among other things, students' living conditions, finances, and housing situation.

Present a mapping of the students' learning environment at universities, colleges, and vocational schools, and request that this work be viewed in connection with the work on the new university and college law.
Adjust the absence limit for undocumented absence in such a way that the negative consequences of the absence limit are reduced, for example by increasing the principal's discretion.
Give parents the authority to certify absences, and additionally investigate whether certifying absences is a task that can be assigned to school nurses.
Ensure that upper secondary schools have the opportunity to implement local arrangements for a flexible school day where desired by the school, and where it does not cause significant disadvantages.

Amend the regulations to the Education Act so that self-certification from parents/guardians, or adult students, is accepted as valid documentation for absence due to illness and other welfare reasons for up to three days.
Investigate the possibility of granting school health nurses the right to certify absences in school.

Come back to the Parliament with an account of how the evaluation report "In the Blind Spot of the Absence Limit" (Fafo 2018:41) will be followed up, and present proposals for measures that can support students who are at increased risk of dropping out, both in the short and long term.

Define criteria for extension for those who need the benefit beyond three years. The proposed changes must allow for discretionary assessments of each individual's need for an extension of the benefit period. Extensions should be granted, among other reasons, when the recipient has not been fully assessed, or when Nav and the public health service have not fulfilled their obligations. The authority for decisions and any extensions of the AAP period must reside with the local Nav office.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals that create a demand in the labor market that leads to real equality for people with reduced work capacity.

Instruct Nav to review all cases where individuals have lost their right to AAP due to reduced duration or as a result of tightening of the exception provisions, so that the AAP benefit is continued to prevent these individuals from becoming dependent on social assistance.

Propose an amendment to the law that sets the benefit period for work assessment allowance to up to four years, and that defines criteria for a genuine possibility of extension for those who need the benefit beyond four years. The amendment must allow for discretionary assessments of the individual's need for an extension of the benefit period. Extensions should be granted, among other reasons, when the recipient has not completed their assessment, or when Nav and the public health service have not fulfilled their obligations. This authority should reside with the local Nav office.

Come back with a proposal to expand the possibility of using the exception provision in the National Insurance Act § 11-12 second and third paragraphs, so that the AAP period can be extended after an individual assessment of needs, in line with the goal of enabling as many as possible to return to work, either fully or partially.

Ensure that recipients of work assessment allowance have the right to an extension if Nav and/or the healthcare system have not managed to clarify the user's situation by the end of the period during which they can receive work assessment allowance.

Introduce increased requirements for Nav in the form of an obligation for the agency to closely follow up on recipients of work assessment allowance, so that the reciprocity in the relationship between the user and the administration is restored, as anticipated when the Nav reform was enacted.
Ensure that decisions regarding temporary benefits, including AAP, are made at the front line, as intended when the Nav reform was adopted.

Take the initiative for concrete poverty prevention measures that can be implemented for those who have experienced and those who are currently experiencing loss of income due to the tightening of AAP (Work Assessment Allowance).

Take the initiative to introduce a right to activities for individuals who need measures and follow-up from Nav. This right should ensure that each person is regularly followed up with measures that are individually assessed for them. Nav's obligation to provide follow-up must be strengthened.

Promote a proposal to remove the introduced waiting period in the AAP scheme and to reverse the tightening of the National Insurance Act § 11-5, where considerations other than illness were downplayed.

Review the consequences of the tightening of the work assessment allowance and return to the Parliament with a comprehensive report on this. The review should, among other things, provide answers to how many have been pushed onto social assistance or have fallen outside the system without municipal or state income security due to the changes.

Investigate how the BPA scheme can be directly financed by the state, and how the right to BPA hours can be granted directly by the state, with the aim of providing an equal and continuous service offer regardless of where in Norway the user lives, and in a way that ensures the intentions of the scheme are upheld.
Promote proposals to amend anti-discrimination legislation to include the right to information, goods, and services for people with disabilities.

Establish a tax and duty committee that will promote concrete proposals for a comprehensive restructuring of the current tax and duty system with the aim of helping Norway achieve its national Paris goals. The proposals should collectively also contribute to reducing economic inequality in Norwegian society.

Investigate how a model for climate rewards (carbon tax for distribution) can best be introduced in Norway. It is assumed that the government, in addition to defining which sectors will be included, also indicates the progressivity of the tax rates necessary to achieve the climate goals set through the Paris Agreement.
Consider a support scheme for shorter working hours in municipal workplaces, especially in demanding professions such as caregiving.

Initiate a power investigation for the labor market that maps the power balance between employers and employees. The investigation should examine, among other things, the level of organization and barriers to organizing, co-determination, the responsibility of the client, management styles, ownership structure, corporate democracy, and the control and surveillance of employees. The investigation should shed light on the consequences of the EEA agreement for the power balance in Norwegian working life.

Present a comprehensive mapping of the actual distribution of wealth in Norway, which includes shares in non-listed companies and other assets that are currently undervalued in the wealth statistics, with their real market value included.

Present calculations for the development of the Gini index and other measures of income inequality where retained earnings are attributed to the owners of the companies, in order to gain a better understanding of income inequality in Norway.

Present an account of the overall effect that the government's policies have on the disposable income of various income groups, including estimated effects of changes in taxes, co-payments, benefits, and welfare schemes, following the model of the "Fördelningspolitisk redogörelse" in Sweden.

Initiate a power investigation for the labor market that maps the power balance between employers and employees. The investigation should, among other things, examine the level of organization and barriers to organizing, co-determination, the responsibility of the client, management styles, ownership structure, workplace democracy, and the control and surveillance of employees.
Implement a stronger area-focused initiative in the major cities to ensure good neighborhoods and reduce disparities.

Investigate the distributional consequences of cuts in benefits and welfare schemes, including cuts in housing support, cuts in child benefits for the disabled, cuts in purchasing power for pensioners, cuts in free legal aid, cuts in transition benefits for single parents, cuts in support for transportation for those who depend on it to get to the store or the doctor, cuts in maternity care, cuts in work assessment allowance, and cuts in the criminal justice system and courts. The results of the investigation shall be presented to the Parliament no later than together with the proposal for the state budget for 2020.
Increase control to uncover illegal export of fish.
Ensure that the penalty level for illegal export of fish is at a level that provides a real preventive effect.
Come back with a separate case with measures to ensure serious recreational fishing and to combat resource crime related to leisure fishing.

Investigate how to prohibit dividends, group contributions, or other ways to transfer rental income from municipal housing to other parts of the municipality's operations, and return to the Parliament with proposals for necessary legislative changes.
Promote a proposal for a law that ensures funding for and a municipal obligation to provide housing for the homeless and other disadvantaged individuals who cannot secure housing on their own.

Propose amendments to the Tenancy Act so that municipalities cannot demand market rent or prevailing rent for social housing or care homes owned by the municipality, as well as investigate a new mechanism for long-term and predictable pricing based on income, among other factors.
Review the Tenancy Act and propose changes to strengthen tenants' rights, including participation in decision-making and regulation of rent.
Ensure that grant schemes through the Norwegian State Housing Bank are strengthened to realize more rent-to-own models.
Investigate the limits of the possibility to use dividends from municipal housing for other parts of the municipality's operations.

Investigate and initiate a pilot scheme where the public sector can become a co-owner of homes with up to 15% of the purchase price upon application from individuals who can service a mortgage but do not have equity.

Amend the regulation regarding start loans from the Norwegian State Housing Bank, so that applicants who are young or first-time homebuyers with payment ability, but without equity, are included in the target group for receiving start loans. It should be up to each municipality to manage this scheme based on local discretionary assessments, so that all municipalities can use the scheme to ensure that young people and first-time homebuyers have the opportunity to settle in the municipalities.
Divide the Start Loan scheme into two, one for the current target group and one for young first-time home buyers.
Continue the current professional environments and regional structure at the Veterinary Institute, so that autopsies can be carried out as they are today.
Investigate how Norwegian technical language can be maintained and secured in the transition to open publishing.
Involve the research sector in the concretization of the implementation of Plan S.
Ensure that all academic fields will still have relevant channels to publish their research results in.
Ensure that quality, not resources, determines who has the opportunity to publish research results.
Assess the need for, and investigate possible transition arrangements for the implementation of Plan S.
Ensure that Plan S is not in conflict with Norwegian copyright law.

Promote proposals for necessary legal changes that ensure that wage provisions in collective agreements with a wage level lower than 80% of the average industrial worker's wage are automatically made universally applicable.
Promote proposals to improve the generalization scheme and make it easier to use by simplifying the documentation requirements.
Review the regulations on the marketing of non-medical cosmetic procedures with the aim of introducing a ban on cosmetic surgery that is not part of medical treatment.
Ensure stricter enforcement of rules for marketing aimed at children under 18 years old and consider a ban on advertising targeted at this age group.

Revise the regulations on environmental health protection in schools and kindergartens with the aim of mandating advertising-free zones around schools and ensuring that schools and kindergartens are free from product advertising.
Review the regulations on the marketing of cosmetic procedures with the aim of introducing a ban on the marketing of cosmetic surgery.
Consider a ban on the marketing of weight loss products.
Give the Consumer Authority the mandate to take stronger action against violations of the Marketing Act Chapter 4 regarding special protection for children.
Give the Consumer Authority the mandate to crack down on the use of mannequins with medically irresponsible body proportions.
Gather more knowledge about children and young people's vulnerability to advertising influence.
Promote proposals for necessary changes to the Education Act § 1-1 to provide the law with a norm-critical starting point.
Investigate the possibility of regulating targeted advertising on social media for Norwegian users, including considering a ban on targeting and filtering advertisements based on age.

Promote a proposal to amend the crisis center law so that women in active substance abuse who experience violence receive their own free, low-threshold crisis center services that are individually tailored.
Promote a proposal that the definition of close relationships in the crisis center law should include the women's own definition of close relationships.

Consider whether the definition of "close relationships" in the crisis center law is sufficiently comprehensive, and whether it should be clarified in the purpose paragraph of the law what is meant by close relationships.
Ensure that substance-dependent individuals can start or maintain substitution medication at the crisis centers.

Ensure that the professional guidelines for crisis centers emphasize collaboration between the crisis centers and the specialist health services so that those who wish to can be directed into interdisciplinary specialized substance abuse treatment (TSB).
Introduce information programs for women in substance abuse environments about the fact that violence is not acceptable, and that there are places that offer help for free.
Investigate whether a second opinion assessment of emergency decisions can be introduced with the aim of ensuring the quality of emergency decisions made by the child welfare service.
Investigate how to appropriately grant the press access to cases in the county boards to ensure transparency and insight, while also safeguarding the involved parties' right to privacy.

Initiate a quality reform for a better child welfare system by promoting the necessary legislative proposals and ensuring that the following initiatives and changes are implemented: 

Legal security 
a) All county boards shall have the option for dialogue/discussions prior to the processing of cases in the county board. 
b) Expert witnesses shall be appointed through an application-based system in the county boards. 
c) Emergency decisions shall always be subject to a second opinion assessment. The decision must also always be sanctioned by an external body. 
d) The appeal options regarding custody transfers should be changed, and clearer criteria must be developed for how often an appeal can be filed. The interests of children must be better safeguarded than today. 
e) Transparency for the press in cases in the county boards must be ensured. 
f) The possibility of setting quality requirements for lawyers handling child welfare cases must be investigated. 
g) The political responsibility for child welfare must be clarified and firmly anchored through separate, annual quality-based reports to the municipal councils.

Initiate a quality reform for a better child welfare system by promoting the necessary legislative proposals and ensuring that the following initiatives and changes are implemented: 

Children and parents 
a) The best interests of the child shall be the foundation for all measures and assistance throughout the entire contact with the child welfare services, and the provision regarding this in the Child Welfare Act must be moved from § 4 to § 1, the purpose. 
b) The user perspective from the children themselves and the parents should permeate the practice and must be included in the digital platforms that are developed. 
c) In meetings with families and children, the children's parents should have their own, independent voice and be heard throughout the entire process. 
d) The situation of parents and children should be assessed both collectively and individually. Parents who are deprived of their children should be offered follow-up support after a decision on custody transfer has been made. 
e) The position of foster parents should be reviewed, and follow-up and guidance should be improved. 
f) The service must address the needs for cultural understanding and take into account the language challenges faced by indigenous peoples, immigrants, and national minorities. 
g) Aftercare should be extended to age 25.

Initiate a quality reform for a better child welfare system by promoting the necessary legislative proposals and ensuring that the following initiatives and changes are implemented: Organization, collaboration, and means of action a) Services aimed at children and young people and their families should be organized in co-located low-threshold measures with interdisciplinary competence. Midwives, public health nurses, psychologists, social workers, and child welfare educators should be the minimum staffing. The service may include other professional groups such as doctors, family therapists, educators, preschool teachers, etc. b) Formal, practical collaboration between child welfare services, schools, and voluntary actors in the municipality working with measures for children and young people should be enshrined in law. c) The term "acute decision" should be replaced with "emergency decision." d) The means of action in Nav/social services must be expanded; home help, homework support, support contacts, etc., must be available quickly and without bureaucratic arrangements. e) Guiding criteria for staffing norms in child welfare services should be investigated.

Implement a survey of the working environment in child welfare services to determine whether a lack of time, threats/violence/cyberbullying, etc., can explain high turnover. The work will be carried out in collaboration with employee organizations, and the results will be continuously presented to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Initiate a quality reform for a better child welfare system by promoting the necessary legislative proposals and ensuring that the following initiatives and changes are implemented: Education a) Relevant educational programs must place greater emphasis on relational competence and enhanced knowledge of family relationships and practical low-threshold family work. b) Practical experience and social work content should constitute a larger proportion of relevant educational programs. c) Guidance competence must be strengthened, internal supervision should become part of the practice, and the support work for foster families must be improved. d) The class perspective should be emphasized more strongly in education to provide students with a better understanding of how social background, living condition stress in poor families, and language barriers affect the interaction between child welfare services and families. e) There should be provisions for more practice-oriented career paths for child welfare educators, social workers, and other staff, and more individuals with practical experience should be given the opportunity to pursue a master's degree and doctoral degree (PhD) and bring that knowledge back into their work in child welfare. f) A plan should be presented for the scaling up of doctoral positions in social work and child welfare education to contribute to more knowledge-based development of the professions.

Ensure that the next agricultural settlement prioritizes measures to strengthen the biodiversity of insects, for example by: a. introducing a support scheme for designated organic agricultural land (such as flower meadows, buffer zones, and other biologically valuable areas) b. shifting subsidies towards management and area instead of volume c. supporting organic farming as a spearhead for more sustainable agriculture by reintroducing transition support and increasing subsidies d. strengthening the subsidy scheme "Special Environmental Measures in Agriculture" (SMIL) e. establishing a support scheme for operational difficulties for unfertilized and untilled areas such as harvesting forests, mowing fields, and natural grazing lands.

Ensure the protection of habitats for insects and other species by: a. strengthening voluntary forest protection and all stakeholders working on it, which is essential to achieve the goal of 10% protection of productive forests b. establishing a plan for the protection and restoration of natural and cultural landscapes in coastal areas to better safeguard biodiversity c. expanding the scheme for protected watercourses, especially coastal watercourses d. protecting and restoring more peatlands and other wetlands e. expanding the program that Innovation Norway has, so that smaller farms can also receive support for loose housing systems f. expanding the "Selected Cultural Landscapes" program to 100 areas by 2020 g. increasing the number of prioritized species and selected natural types and allocating funds to implement action plans to improve their status h. investigating a system where the state pays landowners for particularly important ecosystem services that require active management, or that restrict opportunities for other income, including transitioning to selective logging aimed at re-establishing species-rich multi-aged forests, maintaining and increasing biodiversity in cultural landscapes, and re-establishing rare or threatened species.

Strengthen environmental protection considerations in development cases by: a. strengthening the County Governor's authority and capacity for guidance and supervision of the municipalities b. reviewing the laws that regulate development and land use interventions, and proposing changes to ensure a more integrated management and prevent piecemeal degradation c. allocating funds for climate and environmental advisors in the municipalities.

Require municipalities, counties, and state enterprises to establish and maintain flower meadows/wildflower meadows with native plants on their properties, including rooftop areas, to ensure the biodiversity of plants and insects.
Facilitate public research and development of necessary local seed mixtures for the entire country.

Implement a national program with incentives to establish and maintain flower meadows/wildflower meadows with native plants on private properties, including rooftops, to ensure the biodiversity of plants and insects.
Propose and implement a turnaround for Norwegian nature conservation, land use management, and agriculture to stop Norwegian and global insect decline.

Establish a research program for the development and testing of agroecological cultivation methods, focusing on improved soil quality, utilization of local resources, and reduced consumption of synthetic fertilizers and pesticides.
Establish a program for full-scale monitoring of insects to have a better knowledge base regarding the status of insects in Norway and to prioritize various measures to prevent insect mortality.
Introduce a support scheme for testing autonomous agricultural robots for more efficient and targeted use of fertilizers and pesticides.
Strengthen and develop the work with regional seed mixtures by establishing regional centers for the production and sale of native seeds for flower meadows.
Prioritize research in the field to further understand the causal relationships and promote evidence-based measures to counteract insect mortality.
Ensure that Norway receives an exemption from any potential EU regulations that allow for the free movement of bees within the EEA area.

Implement an agricultural policy that facilitates a diverse usage structure, active use of grazing resources, and preservation of cultural landscapes throughout the country, while contributing to the strengthening of biodiversity and ensuring environments and habitats for pollinating insects.

Present a case where warranty periods and complaint deadlines for clothing, white goods, brown goods, and electronics are at least doubled to pressure manufacturers to create products with increased lifespan and quality, thereby contributing to reduced consumption.

To ramp up climate financing for emission reductions, adaptation, and support for loss and damage to countries in the Global South based on Norway's fair share of global climate costs, and existing proposals for a scaling-up plan for Norwegian climate financing from several Norwegian environmental and development organizations based on the report "Norway’s Fair Share of meeting the Paris Agreement" by the Stockholm Environmental Institute.

Come up with suggestions for revised purpose clauses for Norwegian state-owned enterprises that manage natural resources, so that the purpose clauses emphasize the enterprises' responsibility to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and loss of biodiversity, and that this is highlighted over the goal of economic return.

Introduce a climate percentage where up to two percent of the national income is transferred annually from the Oil Fund to climate initiatives in developing countries, to contribute to Norway's fair share of the global climate costs.
Propose to transfer 65 billion kroner from the Government Pension Fund Global to the UN Green Climate Fund.

Halt the allocation and opening of new oil and gas fields on the Norwegian continental shelf while simultaneously starting a gradual and planned phase-out of petroleum activities over a 15-year period.
Withdraw the announcement of TFO 2019.
Investigate and propose the introduction of a youth card for public transport in Norway. The card should be valid for everyone under 20 years old.
Present a plan for reduced car traffic in urban areas and that all growth in passenger transport in metropolitan areas is to be accommodated by public transport, cycling, and walking.
Present a plan in connection with the state budget for 2020 that ensures 100 percent of new car sales in 2025 are zero-emission vehicles.
Present a plan to the Storting that reduces Norwegian emissions every year until Norway achieves zero emissions by 2050.
Propose increased CO2 taxes in the state budget for 2020.

Come up with a plan to significantly reduce travel time by train between the cities in Southern Norway. The goal should be a travel time of 4 hours between Oslo and Bergen, Stavanger, and Trondheim, respectively.
Remove subsidies to the oil industry.
Come up with a plan for carbon capture and storage at all major point sources of emissions in Norway.
Change the flight seat fee so that it is also charged for empty seats.

Present a report on Norway's historical responsibility for the climate crisis and propose a plan for how Norway should take its historical responsibility to finance climate adaptation and emissions reductions in other countries.
Ensure that no new exploration or extraction permits are granted to oil companies in Norway.

Promote a proposal for permanent protection against petroleum activities in particularly valuable and vulnerable marine areas, such as Lofoten, Vesterålen and Senja, the ice edge zone, the polar front in the Barents Sea and the Norwegian Sea, the marine area around Jan Mayen, the Mørebanken, the Iver Ridge, as well as the Skagerrak.
Increase Norway's climate targets to a 60% reduction by 2030 compared to emissions in 1990 and provide a plan for how Norway will achieve these cuts domestically during the first half of 2020.

Conduct a concept choice study and subsequent external quality assurance for a third runway at Gardermoen and other major airport developments, as is done for other large transportation projects. The study must, among other things, consider the development of a third runway in light of Norway's climate goals and objectives for the preservation of arable land.

Develop proposals for annual sector-specific climate budgets that commit Norwegian authorities to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from Norwegian territory by 60% by 2030 compared to 1990, and by 95% by 2050.

Investigate what Norway's fair share of the global climate costs is, and in the proposal for the state budget for 2020, explain a model for determining annual contributions and how these can be used for climate measures in developing countries.
Head towards a third runway at Oslo Airport Gardermoen.
Develop proposals for annual sector-specific climate budgets.
Come up with proposals for a new climate agreement that can serve as a basis for ambitious cooperation on emission reductions across party lines.
Present a plan for an annual increase in assistance from Norway for emission reductions and climate adaptation in developing countries.
Present a plan for an annual increase in Norway's contributions to the UN Green Climate Fund.

Prioritize assistance measures that contribute to sustainable and climate-smart agriculture in developing countries, and return to the Parliament with a plan for how this can be achieved in connection with the state budget for 2020.
Grant permission for the removal of all predators, including otters and sea eagles, that threaten the eider duck population in the traditional egg and down habitats.
Facilitate the protection of the eider duck population through a scheme that encourages more active eider duck guardians on the Vega Islands.
Investigate the establishment of a separate environmental complaints board, with the aim of creating one.
Establish an expert committee to assess the non-editorial social media and measures to improve the climate for free expression.

Further investigate and return to the Storting with a proposal for a designated personal tax model for financing NRK, with increased social progression, greater independence, and more predictability, for example through the establishment of a fund.
Investigate various models for time-limited exemptions from employer's social security contributions for the media industry.

Take the initiative to engage in a dialogue with non-editorial social media platforms to improve the climate for expression, moderation of hate speech, threats, and harmful content, as well as to ensure transparency regarding the moderation that takes place.

Present a new and more thorough media statement, with a solid review of overarching goals, important developments and trends, and a long-term strategy for a strong, good, and diverse media sector and an informed and participatory population.

Review the list of major events of national significance that should be publicly accessible, to see if media developments suggest that more such events, such as the Ski World Cup, should be included on this list.
Extend today's FM licenses for local radio until 2031, corresponding to the expiration date for local radio's digital licenses.
Ensure that the Storting's compensation scheme for justice is better known and better informed about as a compensation scheme.

Come back to the Parliament with a comprehensive review of the compensation scheme for justice, which particularly examines which groups are not covered by the scheme, and assess how these should be included or covered by other schemes.
Return to the Parliament with a proposal to clarify how Norwegian regulations on arms exports should be implemented, in order to avoid violations of international law and humanitarian law.
Establish a committee to ensure that the Penal Execution Act better protects inmates' rights against inhumane treatment and their right to necessary healthcare.
Come to the Parliament with a comprehensive presentation on how the recommendations put forward in NIM's annual report for 2018 are being followed up.
Develop an action plan against violence and abuse, with particular emphasis on the Sami community.

Develop a comprehensive, cross-sectoral action plan against violence in close relationships based on the obligations arising from the Istanbul Convention. The action plan should reflect the specific needs of vulnerable groups.
To ensure an overview of the extent of coercive measures due to suicide risk, self-harm, and mental disorders.

Follow up and implement the necessary recommendations from the Norwegian Correctional Service Directorate and the Directorate of Health's report from 2016 "Follow-up of inmates with mental disorders and/or substance abuse problems."

To present an annual report to the Parliament regarding weapon permits granted to both borrowed and loaned personnel as a result of the agreement of September 4, 2018, between Norway and Sweden on mutual assistance between the police's special intervention units in crisis situations.
Facilitate that the entire eastern line of the Østfold Line can be trafficked by passenger trains and freight trains, and that the Parliament is informed about this.
Require Telenor to maintain and upkeep the copper network in areas that do not have alternative broadband connections.
Come back to the Storting with a report on existing plans for property, buildings, and facilities in Indre Troms in relation to the actual need for accommodation of Norwegian and allied soldiers.
Present a separate case to the Storting that clarifies all costs and new factors resulting from the establishment of MPA at Evenes, before the work begins.
Present a case with all ongoing projects for military activity at Andøya.
Wait with all ongoing projects at Evenes related to MPA until the report on allied reception has been addressed by the Storting.

Ensure that the planned efficiency improvements in maintenance within the Armed Forces do not lead to further privatization, downsizing, poorer working conditions, or loss of maintenance expertise in the Armed Forces.
To organize cleaning services in the defense sector under the Defense's own management when the current contract with the external private provider expires in January 2020.
Ensure that the statute of limitations is not used as a basis for rejecting applications or appeals for compensation for veterans with mental injuries from overseas operations.
Review Norway's cooperation with the EU in the field of statistics and propose bureaucratic reduction measures within the current regulations.
Review Norway's cooperation with the EU in the field of statistics and propose changes to the current regulations, including agreements with the EU, to reduce bureaucracy.

Propose a plan for how a complete or partial divestment of fossil energy stocks in the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG) can be best implemented with the aim of further reducing the GPFG's holdings of assets exposed to oil and gas activities.
Propose a tightening of the coal criteria with the aim of divesting from all coal investments in the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG).

Propose a framework for how the Government Pension Fund Global (SPU) can exercise more active ownership with the aim of shifting the integrated energy companies' own investments towards a higher share of renewable energy.
Develop guidelines that ensure that the largest possible portion of the fund's activities is carried out from Norway.
Investigate whether the activities of the oil fund in Norway can be more widely distributed so that the entire country benefits.
Increase the framework for the environmental mandate.
Evaluate the mandate for investments in unlisted infrastructure every other year, with the aim of expanding the size of the mandate.

Present an overview of the oil fund's investments in arms companies, including end producers of weapons and weapon systems as well as manufacturers of key components for weapons, in connection with next year's management report.
Propose an amendment to the coal criteria that includes companies that are building or planning to build new coal power plants.
Come back in connection with next year's management report with a proposal for a final phase-out date for all coal investments.
That a product criterion is established in the guidelines regarding the observation and exclusion of gambling companies that operate in a manner that is illegal in Norway.

Investigate whether it is appropriate to implement pre-filtering in the Government Pension Fund Global, where companies are assessed with particular emphasis on ethical risk assessments and climate risk evaluations before investment decisions are made.
Conduct a new and more thorough review of the possibility of developing ethical guidelines for the oil fund's investments in government bonds, based on transparency criteria in the issuing countries.

Return to the Parliament with a proposal for a strategy to strengthen human rights in the fund's responsible management, with a particular focus on investments in conflict areas, including occupied territories. The strategy should be anchored in the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGP) and the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises.

Consider how the arrangement with shadow ratings can be reintroduced, and what measures the Parliament and the government can take to achieve this, and return to the Parliament with this no later than spring 2020.
Give Kommunalbanken status as a so-called promotional bank and provide loans to the municipal sector with a so-called zero weight in the weighted capital adequacy requirements.
Ensure that the contracting obligation is followed up, and that any violations of this are addressed and sanctioned.

Investigate whether the Financial Complaints Board can have its mandate expanded, for example, to also handle complaints from organizations, businesses, and companies, possibly organizations and companies below a certain size.

Establish a committee to produce a public report to assess the need for new solutions and regulations to ensure access to cash as a comprehensive emergency solution in the event of prolonged failures in digital payment systems.
Come back to the Storting no later than spring 2020 with a concrete proposal for a system for easy transfer of services such as eInvoice and Direct Debit between accounts.

Ensure that the Financial Supervisory Authority maps and analyzes the consequences of climate change for financial risk in Norway, and that the assessment of climate risk becomes part of the mandate of the Financial Supervisory Authority.
Require the Financial Supervisory Authority to conduct a stress test of climate risk in Norwegian financial institutions.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to expand the investment universe of the Government Pension Fund Norway to, for example, also include unlisted shares.
Promote proposals that further reduce banks' access to take risks outside their core business.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to ban return commissions.
Present a proposal for the introduction of a rent cap in Norway at approximately the same level as the Finnish rent cap.

Establish a committee to assess how to increase the market shares of banks and financial institutions based in Norway and report back to the Parliament with a message on this by spring 2021 at the latest.
Come back to the Storting no later than spring 2020 with a proposal to ban the marketing of consumer loans.
Map the causes of the significant wage differences between genders in the same type of position in the financial sector, and report back to the Parliament in next year's financial market report.
Propose a regulatory framework that ensures that holders of free policies receive their pension rights.
Come back with a comprehensive industrial policy for the financial sector.

Come back to the Parliament with a bill that ensures that consumer loan banks cannot sell overdue consumer loans and also cannot use the public collection apparatus if they cannot document that the requirements for granting loans were met.
Propose to the Parliament a cost cap that protects consumers in financial difficulties from unreasonably high costs and uncontrolled debt growth.
Return to the Storting no later than spring 2020 with a concrete proposal on how account number portability in Norway can be implemented.
Come back to the Parliament with a concrete proposal to expand the debt register in connection with the state budget for 2020.

Ensure that the compensation schemes for the fur farming industry are designed in such a way that they provide incentives for a rapid phase-out and discontinuation of fur farming rather than full operation until 2025.
Provide fur farmers with compensation for the real value of their facilities by using the estimated residual value of real capital as a basis instead of the book value.
Compensate all expenses related to the demolition and cleanup of facilities that have been used for fur farming, where there are requirements for sorting the waste before delivery.
Ensure fur farmers who cannot find other work receive compensation for lost income for up to three years.
Ensure that fur farmers who will be over 62 years old in 2025, and who will not find other work, are compensated for lost income until retirement age of 67 years.

Come back with a case in the fall of 2020 that outlines the social and economic consequences of the decision to phase out the fur farming industry, along with proposals for measures that can address negative impacts. The case should also highlight the consequences for the breeders' pensions.
Ensure that no fur farmers are left with debt related to the facility after its closure.

Ensure the completion of the compensation scheme for fur farmers and make it available during the fall of 2019, so that the farmers can start the transition. The government must also follow up on its promise to contact the municipalities where fur farming is most prevalent, to contribute to additional transition measures for the areas most affected by the phase-out.
Conduct an investigation with the aim of introducing a ban on the import of fur after the ban on fur farming has been implemented.
Assuming that the keeping of fur animals will still be legal in Norway in accordance with the decision made by the Storting in January 2017.
Ensure that fur breeders and other stakeholders affected by the business ban receive full compensation, and that the compensation is determined based on expropriation law principles.
Implement the measures to strengthen animal welfare in the fur farming industry that the Parliament approved in January 2017.

Promote a new bill that introduces a ban on fur farming starting from February 1, 2025, along with a proposal for a compensation provision based on the premise that compensation is provided as if it were an expropriation-type intervention.

Follow the compensation scheme closely and expect that the scheme will be adjusted if there are unreasonable outcomes in the overall assessment of compensation, including compensation for the book value of non-realizable capital, to individual operators related to the winding down of business operations. The Parliament will be kept informed about how the scheme will be adjusted in light of this.
Promote a proposal to clarify the school's responsibility for children's safety on the way to school in the Education Act.
Make traffic education a mandatory part of the framework plan for kindergartens.
Develop a national map of school routes as a basis for land use planning in municipalities and counties.
Promote a proposal to introduce a national requirement that all children should be able to cycle safely to school, as a guideline for municipal and county planning.
Propose to reduce the default speed limit in built-up areas from the current 50 km/h to 40 km/h, and to 30 km/h in urban areas with mixed traffic and around schools and kindergartens.

Give the Children's Transport Plan an updated national action plan with new, concrete measures and initiatives that prioritize the needs of children and young people in the transport system over car traffic and the construction of new motorways. The lack of pedestrian and cycling paths, sidewalks, and crosswalks must be prioritized over the construction of new motorways.
Establish an action program for safe school routes with a dedicated grant scheme for safe school routes in the municipality.
Establish a national standard for car-free zones around all schools.
Promote a proposal to require three-point seat belts in all school transportation purchased by county municipalities.
Take the initiative to develop and promote arrangements for activity transport with emission-free transportation after school for children and young people.

Stimulate and reward cities and municipalities with towns that convert roads with street parking into playgrounds and sports fields, remove street parking in city centers and residential areas, and transform former street areas into green oases.
Propose to extend the age limit for children's tickets on public transport from 16 to 18 years.

Promote a proposal to reduce the speed limit in cities and densely populated areas to 30 km/h with mixed traffic, while simultaneously increasing the assistance limit from the motor for unregistered electric bicycles from 25 km/h to 30 km/h.
Promote a proposal to increase state funding for large public transport projects in urban areas to 80 percent.
Promote a proposal to replace the zero growth target in transportation policy with a goal of a 5 percent annual reduction in car traffic in urban areas from the current level.
Revise today's road standards and traffic regulations to prioritize walking, cycling, and micromobility.
Promote a set of measures for electric micromobility for personal transport and freight transport.

Come back to the parliament with a downsizing of all major tunnel and bridge projects in the national transport plan from four-lane roads to two- and three-lane roads with passing lanes and electric ferries instead of bridges, in order to avoid significant environmental impacts, increased traffic and emissions, and enormous toll costs.

Promote a proposal to give municipalities the authority to regulate parking on private property and introduce a reward scheme for municipalities that reduce street parking spaces in cities and densely populated areas.

Prioritize micromobility in a transition to a significantly larger share of more energy-efficient, electrified, traffic-safe, space- and resource-efficient personal transport and freight transport in Norway.

Introduce sustainable mobility freedom as a guiding principle in the current and upcoming national transport plan, to prioritize public transport, walking, cycling, and micromobility over car traffic in urban areas.
Cancel capacity-increasing highway projects that contribute to an increase in passenger car transport in areas where there is a goal of zero growth in passenger car traffic.
Promote a proposal to set a target of a five percent annual reduction in car traffic in urban areas during the revision of urban environment agreements/urban growth agreements.
Promote a proposal to establish a reward scheme for large municipalities that reduce car traffic.

Promote a comprehensive national policy for the rental, sharing, and parking of electric scooters on public land, which encourages such sharing services without creating conflicts or insecurity in traffic.

Take the initiative to develop and promote arrangements for on-demand buses with zero-emission transport to meet passengers' real door-to-door transport needs in a timely manner, and continuously stitch together optimal driving routes.

Promote a proposal for a legal basis in the Road Traffic Act so that municipalities can regulate the rental of electric scooters on public land. Municipalities must be given the authority to set requirements for where electric scooters can be parked/left, to require municipal permission to use municipal land, and to impose standards for the quality, safety, and durability of the scooters.
Promote a proposal to increase state funding for large public transport projects in urban areas to 70%.
Come up with a proposal for an interest compensation scheme in the state budget for 2020 that enables municipalities to accelerate the replacement of drinking water and sewage systems in Norway.

Conduct a comprehensive assessment of drinking water quality in Norway to gain an overview of how many people become ill from drinking water and how many are at risk of becoming ill if the replacement rate of the pipeline network does not increase.
Investigate how orthodontics can be transferred to public management in order to reduce significant, unsocial expenses for individual families.

Regulate that the public sector shall take nutritional considerations into account in accordance with dietary guidelines in tender announcements for food and beverages, by following the nutritional criteria from the Norwegian Directorate of Health.
Introduce a ban on flavoring in snus and e-cigarettes.
Investigate a legal basis that ensures that parents with unvaccinated children can be denied the right to take their child to countries where the risk of infection is high.
Introduce mandatory vaccination for kindergarten staff.
Open for the school nurse to refer to Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services (BUP).
Remove the restriction that prevents public health nurses and midwives from having prescribing rights for all types of contraception for young people under 16 years old.
Promote a bill that ensures that companies based abroad must pay value-added tax from the first krone sold in Norway.
Intensify the controls of foreign tour buses, among other things to ensure that the companies that own the buses are registered for value-added tax.

To wait for the EEA incorporation of CRR and CRD IV to take the necessary steps so that the SME discount in the capital adequacy requirements can be implemented, and so that the Basel I floor, which was intended as a transitional rule in the capital adequacy framework, can be removed as soon as possible and preferably immediately.

Come back to the Parliament with an assessment from the Legal Department of the Ministry of Justice and Public Security regarding whether MiFIR entails a transfer of sovereignty to the EU or ESA that is more than "slightly intrusive."
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for necessary legislative changes as a result of potential EEA incorporation of the CRR and CRD IV regulations.

Come back to the Storting with a new proposal for consent to the incorporation of the regulations MiFIR, CRR, CRD IV, and MiFID II into the EEA Agreement, where (1) a thorough cost-benefit analysis of such incorporation based on Norwegian interests is provided, (2) an account of Norwegian sovereignty and room for maneuver in the short and long term regarding the incorporation of each of the regulations and the regulations collectively is given, and (3) EEA adaptations are provided that ensure Norwegian sovereignty.

Propose to introduce a new environmental tax on clothing, shoes, tools, sports and outdoor equipment, and other consumer goods that have a high environmental footprint and are suitable for sharing and renting.

Promote proposals to completely remove value-added tax on the reuse and repair of consumer electronics, white goods, brown goods, furniture, clothing, and shoes, as well as on parts needed for repairs.
Propose that funds be allocated to municipalities for the establishment of sharing schemes for tools, sports and outdoor equipment, and other products suitable for sharing.

Promote a parliamentary report that follows up on the recommendations from the UN's International Panel on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services on how to break the link between a good, meaningful life and the ever-increasing material consumption that destroys nature and the environment and threatens the well-being of humanity.

Develop a plan for how Norway can become the best in resource efficiency within the OECD by 2030, with the overarching goal of reducing the material footprint to eight tons per person by 2050, while maintaining and increasing quality of life. The plan should include an action program that is revised every three years.
Investigate how a tax differentiated according to the material footprint of various goods and services can be designed and implemented.
Propose the introduction of a right to repair, and work to ensure that this right applies to all goods imported to Norway, while also demanding that products be recyclable.

Promote a proposal to reintroduce a ban on tying in marketing, so that, for example, it would not be possible to offer customers a free bicycle if they purchase a washing machine or a new flat-screen TV.
Present a parliamentary report on Urban Mining, which maps out the potential for increased recycling of metals in Norway, and propose measures to recover minerals and metals that are not in use.
Investigate and present proposals for changes to natural resource legislation to ensure that it takes into account environmental considerations and requirements for sustainable resource management.

To investigate and propose a system where goods and services must have a product declaration that quantifies greenhouse gas emissions and resource consumption, enabling consumers to make environmentally friendly choices.
Investigate further whether it can be required that products imported to Norway must be repairable or recyclable, and suggest how such a requirement can be enforced.
Promote a proposal to replace the current packaging tax with a differentiated material tax that rewards the use of renewable and recycled materials.
Promote a proposal for a legal basis for a municipal resource fee on the extraction of minerals.
Promote proposals to ban products with built-in planned obsolescence, making it impossible to intentionally incorporate mechanisms and features in products and goods that shorten their lifespan.

Establish a committee to propose how material consumption can be reduced, within a distributional and social framework, where, among other things, taxes, the creation of more lending schemes for consumer goods suitable for lending, strengthening the consumer purchase law, and systems for reuse and recycling are viewed in conjunction and contribute to lower consumption.

Promote concrete measures to strengthen the culture school as a type of school, for example by establishing a national framework plan through regulations, and consider whether the introduction of a maximum price could be a suitable measure to ensure increased participation and accessibility for all children.

Promote a parliamentary report that safeguards the culture school as a distinct type of school and ensures that all children, regardless of their place of residence and their parents' financial situation, have access to an equal and high-quality cultural school offer.

Propose suggestions on how the cultural school offerings can be strengthened and further developed, as well as propose specific measures to: ensure increased participation and accessibility for all children, for example by introducing free cultural school lessons; ensure good framework conditions, for example by establishing a predictable funding scheme and introducing searchable incentive funds; strengthen the practical and aesthetic subjects in schools through enhanced and systematic collaboration between primary education and the cultural school, for example by facilitating more combined positions and introducing competence requirements for teaching in practical and aesthetic subjects; and increase collaboration with the voluntary sector, for example by establishing municipal cultural forums with representatives from kindergartens, primary education, cultural schools, and the voluntary sector.
Ensure that contractors working for the public sector have a collective bargaining agreement.
Ensure that the public sector refrains from purchasing Israeli goods produced in occupied Palestinian territories in violation of international law.
Ensure that when outsourcing public services, pension requirements should be at the same level as in the public sector.
Develop a system for labeling Israeli goods produced in occupied territories in violation of international law.
Promote a proposal to amend the Public Procurement Act so that the environmental requirement is weighted at 50%.
Set requirements in public procurement for the use of concrete with such low emissions that it necessitates the use of carbon capture and storage.
Set requirements for public procurement for fossil-free construction sites where, as far as possible, zero-emission technology is used in construction projects.
Design requirements for public procurement that contribute to increased public demand for hydrogen in purchases where this is relevant.
Implement measures that ensure requirements are included in the tenders for the use of low- and zero-emission technology on the short-haul network when the technology is available.

Evaluate the current threshold values for procurement with a special focus on socio-economic consequences such as the prevention of labor market crime, environmental impact, the intake of apprentices, resource utilization, and opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises to participate in tender competitions.

Amend the regulations on public procurement to establish a real requirement for a 30% environmental weighting in all public tenders where relevant, and not just something the contracting authority can choose to do, in accordance with the Parliament's previous decision from December 2016.
Develop better statistics for climate requirements and environmental impact in public procurement.

Conduct an evaluation of whether the legal and regulatory requirements for emphasizing environmental considerations in public procurement are functioning as intended, such as the rule that environmental factors should generally be weighted with at least 30% where relevant as award criteria.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals on how the procurement regulations can potentially be improved to contribute to real market change.
Investigate a free and easily accessible advisory service for municipalities and other public purchasers.
Present a financing plan that can strengthen the Procurement Academy in the years to come.
Ensure that public actors use real-time control systems, such as HMS-Reg or alternative systems, to strengthen the oversight of compliance with the requirements of the procurement regulations.
Ensure that seriousness requirements equivalent to the Oslo Model are applied in all public procurements.

Present a case to ensure that elected representatives in public enterprises that purchase services have access to contracts and wage and working conditions of the supplier in accordance with the General Application Act and regulations.
Investigate the reintroduction of the anti-contractor clause.
Set requirements for linguistic accessibility and quality in the regulations for public procurement, in line with the proposal from the Language Council's Future Committee.
Implement necessary measures to identify and retrieve all children who are Norwegian citizens from the war zones in Syria and Iraq to Norway.
Implement necessary measures to ensure good child welfare follow-up, rehabilitation, and reintegration of returning children from Syria and Iraq.

Report a national emission target to cut Norway's emissions by 60% by 2030 compared to emissions in 1990, and submit a proposal to the Storting for a climate agreement that achieves this goal through national emission reductions, during the spring of 2020.
Submit a case to the Storting regarding Norway's fair share of the global emissions reductions that need to be made, as well as Norway's fair contribution to global climate adaptation efforts.
Not taking advantage of the opportunity to credit emission reductions from forestry and other land use.
Postpone the treatment and conclusion of a climate agreement with the EU until all consequences related to Norwegian forestry and agriculture are clarified.

Include Article 3 (Integrated National Energy and Climate Plans) and Article 13 (Assessment of the Integrated National Energy and Climate Plans) in Norway's incorporation of the Governance Regulation (EU) 2018/1999.
Not taking the opportunity to carry out the one-time transfer of approximately 6 million tons of emission units from the regulated sector to the non-regulated sector.
Refrain from utilizing bilateral agreements for the purchase of emission units for the non-ETS sector in EU countries as a substitute for emission reductions in Norway.
Report an enhanced national emission target to be submitted to the UN within the year.

To enter into bilateral agreements for the purchase of emission units for the non-ETS sector in other EU countries, as a substitute for emission reductions in Norway, the government must document that these funds are used for new climate measures that actually reduce emissions in those countries, and ensure that double counting of emission reductions in those countries is avoided.
To include the quota-regulated sector in climate plans and reporting.

Ensure that the goals and measures in a ten-year climate and energy plan for 2030 are developed with the 2050 target in mind, so that decisions made during the ten-year period are sustainable over a longer timeframe where emissions are to be reduced to near zero.
Return to the Parliament with a case regarding the entire governance system regulation (EU) 2018/1999 once the EEA relevance has been assessed.
Introduce a scheme for free fruit and vegetables daily for all students in primary school.

Present a plan aimed at a gradual implementation of a school meal program in primary schools with the following conditions: a) The school owner shall design the program in collaboration with families, students, schools, and the municipality. b) Municipalities shall be compensated for additional expenses, and a co-payment may be required. c) Municipalities shall ensure that all students are included in the program.

Present a plan aimed at a gradual implementation of a free school meal in primary schools. The school meal program will be financed through the budget of the Ministry of Health and Care Services as part of public health efforts.
Take the initiative for a binding agreement with the parties in the labor market regarding the implementation of a broad skills reform for the workforce.
Promote a proposal for a national, stakeholder-driven competence fund to enable skills enhancement for individual employees.
Review the funding systems for vocational schools, universities, and colleges, and assess adjustments to encourage the development of more continuing education and professional development programs.

Facilitate a pilot scheme that allows vocational schools, upon application, to receive funding to develop national modules for continuing education in areas where there is a significant need for competence.

Review the role and mandate of the Council for Cooperation with Working Life (RSA), with the aim of clarifying the central role of educational institutions in providing further and continuing education.

Investigate how the Norwegian State Educational Loan Fund (Lånekassen) can be organized to provide better opportunities for educational support for adults in need of upper secondary education or further and continuing education on a full-time or part-time basis. In this context, the government is particularly encouraged to explore: changing the requirement of 50% study load to qualify for educational support, so that education of a smaller scope can also provide eligibility for educational support; extending the maximum limit of eight years for study support in special cases; raising the age limit for reduced study support from the current maximum limit of 45 years; and establishing specific arrangements for grants, additional loans, and repayment for adults.

Implement a broad competence reform for the labor market based on a framework that includes: proposing changes to the laws and agreements to give employees the opportunity to acquire a right to skills development through their work, ensuring that union representatives are involved in discussions about the skills development that businesses need, introducing a "long-term plan for lifelong learning" that is regularly revised, reforming the education sector to adapt universities, colleges, and vocational schools to lifelong learning, including a closer connection between education and the labor market and facilitating more tailored educational offerings, reviewing the system for prior learning assessment to enable employees to have their skills documented so they can carry them forward, establishing more industry programs for sectors that are particularly vulnerable to change and restructuring, initially focusing on the retail and transport industries, and eventually expanding to more sectors.
Increase the growth in the total revenues of the municipal sector by between 8 and 9 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in Prop. 113 S (2018-2019).

Ensure that the transfer of financial resources to the county municipalities in 2020 for the administration of county roads is based on what has actually been used for joint road administration in total by the Norwegian Public Roads Administration, as well as covering the necessary restructuring costs incurred by the county municipalities.
Investigate a new model for municipal property tax based on the property's assessed value, with mandatory exemptions and shielding arrangements such as deferred tax upon transfer of ownership.
To strengthen the funding of cultural schools and promote proposals on how a maximum price scheme can be implemented.
To increase the growth of the total revenues in the municipal sector by between 5 and 5.5 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in Prop. 113 S (2018–2019).

Assume that tenders for county municipal ferry and boat traffic hereafter will be based on zero-emission technology, and that the income system for the counties will henceforth ensure financing for the necessary transition to zero-emission solutions in all public transport.
Change the funding scheme for crisis centers so that the grant once again becomes a model with 80% state funding and 20% municipal funding.
Designate funding for psychologists in municipal health and care services to ensure an adequate offer, as well as funding for day activity programs for home-dwelling individuals with dementia.

Maintain grants for training apprentices, candidates for practice certificates, and candidates with special needs, grants for career guidance, and grants for early intervention in schools through increased teacher efforts in grades 1-10.
Present various models to increase the state's co-financing of the scheme for particularly resource-intensive services and to expand the scheme to include residents over 67 years old.
Ensure secure e-voting solutions in polling places for the blind and visually impaired during the upcoming municipal/county council elections and parliamentary elections.

Increase the municipal sector's revenues by 4.2 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in the Municipal Proposition 2020. Within the increased framework, at least 1 billion kroner should be allocated to a maintenance program for county roads.
Ensure that the regional grant is discontinued, as it is not in line with the Parliament's decision that the income system should not be used to continue the municipal reform.

Change the arrangement of the urban and growth municipality grants so that they are added as a surcharge to the municipalities that qualify for the grant, without any deductions from the framework for all municipalities.
Increase the funding for decentralized higher education both within the sector itself and through direct financial transfers to the county municipalities.
Ensure that all relevant costs associated with resource-intensive services are included as part of the municipal contribution.
Increase the municipal sector's revenues by between 2.5 and 3 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in the Municipal Proposition 2020.
Ensure e-voting solutions for the blind and visually impaired in the upcoming municipal/regional elections and parliamentary elections.
Establish a new and larger trial with voting rights for 16-year-olds and include the largest cities in the trial scheme.
Maintain funding for regional initiatives for the development of business environments and access to expertise outside the municipal framework.
Abolish the pilot scheme with state funding for elderly care.

Present a model that ensures a faster integration of new teaching materials in line with the new curricula starting from the school year 2020, and follow up with proposals for funding that covers the additional expenses of the municipal sector in accordance with this.
Maintain the current funding model for clinical veterinary emergency services outside regular working hours. The arrangement will not be included in the block grant to municipalities.
Base Oslo municipality's compromise regarding the Y-block as the foundation for the further work on the government quarter.
Ensure that the new government quarter project meets the BREEAM Excellent certification requirements.
Increase the area standard to ensure a permanent office space for all employees and to provide a sufficient number of individual offices in the new government quarter.
Come up with suggestions on how the new government quarter should become a model project for larger buildings, both in terms of material selection, energy use, and energy production.
Ensure that Statsbygg applies the Oslo model or equally strict seriousness requirements when announcing its tenders.
Present a climate budget and emission targets for the construction, operation, and demolition phases to the Storting before the preliminary project for the new government quarter is completed.
Ensure that as much as possible of the 22nd of July Center, as it stands today, should be preserved and become an important element in the new government quarter.
Set requirements for reduced climate impact from building materials in the upcoming building technical regulations.
Consider setting requirements for reduced climate impact from building materials in the upcoming building technical regulations.
Return to the Parliament by the end of 2019 with proposals for economic incentives for the use of climate-friendly materials such as wood in larger construction projects.
Return to the Storting by the end of 2019 with proposals for economic incentives for the use of wood in larger construction projects.

Follow up on the strategy for the forestry and timber industry – a driver for green transition, including ensuring better documentation of the properties and environmental advantages of wood-based products.

Carry out the wage settlement in the state so that the result is four identical main collective agreements – so that there is one main collective agreement applicable to all employees in the state tariff area regardless of organizational affiliation.

Promote a proposal to amend § 11 of the Student Welfare Organization Act so that the welfare organizations are subject to the Language Act, or in some other way ensure that the student welfare organizations are required to use both Nynorsk and Bokmål.
Change the categorization of teacher education programs in the funding system so that the funding covers the costs associated with the scope and content of the practical training.

Facilitate a better and more effective teacher education by ensuring that greater expectations are placed on teaching quality and study intensity in teacher education programs, through: a. increased study intensity by allocating more hours to studies overall, distributed across organized learning activities and independent study, with the goal of raising the average time spent on studies in teacher education to at least the average for other students, b. ensuring that educational institutions provide teacher students with training in practical teaching work and the tasks teachers face in the classroom throughout their education, c. ensuring that educational institutions continuously work on measures to improve collaboration with the labor market for teacher students during their education, d. strengthening the competence of students, teacher education programs, and practice schools in the use of digital tools and digital learning methods.
Follow up that teacher education programs take the lead in developing a good national system for sharing quality-assured and research-based teaching and learning arrangements for students.

Change the regulations for primary school teacher education so that the scope of the pedagogy and student knowledge subject shall constitute at least 60 credits, excluding the module in religion, life stance, and ethics.
Investigate – with the aim of introducing – national frameworks for practice in teacher education, in close dialogue with the sector and the field of practice.
Establish a national prioritization council based on the model from Sweden to broaden the prioritization debate and ensure that it addresses more than just access to new medications.
Complaining that the Decision Forum's decision on confidentiality is reversed, and that the conclusions from the Norwegian Medicines Agency's cost-effectiveness assessments are made public.

Ensure full transparency regarding the decision-making basis for prioritizations in the healthcare service – including the additional cost per quality-adjusted life year of implementing a measure, the budgetary consequences of implementing a measure, and the application of the seriousness criterion.

To promote the necessary legislative changes to ensure that all nurses and pharmacy staff, as well as all state employees, are covered by the occupational pension scheme regardless of their percentage of employment.

Investigate and promote a legislative proposal to replace the Health Enterprises Act with a new Health Administration Act, which examines how the counties can take over the operation of hospitals, introduce elected governance, local and practice-oriented management, and co-determination for the employees.

Investigate and propose a new financing model for hospitals, where large hospital investments are prioritized by the Parliament in the National Health and Hospital Plan and fully funded through the national budget, and where hospitals are included in the same budget and accounting system as municipalities and county municipalities.

Ensure that the action plan for the general practitioner service, which was announced to be presented in 2020, also becomes an action plan to strengthen the emergency medical service as an acute medical emergency service.
Promote measures that encourage municipalities to a greater extent to facilitate that emergency care work is planned and included in regulated working hours.
Introduce a maximum travel time to the emergency room in line with the proposal in NOU 2015:17.

Summarize the experiences with the challenges of serving sentences related to inmates convicted of ideological terrorism, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner with the results of the review.
Contribute to the identification of individuals with Norwegian citizenship who may be suspected of war crimes, or complicity in war crimes, in Syria/Iraq.
Facilitate the follow-up on the request from the UN regional coordinator that suspected war criminals should be prosecuted in the respective countries where they hold citizenship.
Ensure that the prosecution has sufficient resources to prioritize the prosecution of Norwegian citizens suspected of war crimes in Syria/Iraq.
Present a case that highlights the challenges of the current apprenticeship system in reindeer herding, along with suggestions for a fairer model.
Create maps that show the status of reindeer grazing areas and make it possible to have an ongoing overview of the loss of areas in development cases.
To initiate an independent investigation of the Norwegian Food Safety Authority's supervisory activities within both the green and blue sectors.
Establish effective control measures and requirements for NUF companies (Norwegian branch of a foreign enterprise) and for contractor operations.
Prepare a report on the establishment of sole proprietorships among labor immigrants.
Introduce a register of foreign service providers in Norway based on the model of the Danish RUT register.
Develop a national overview of the need for VTA placements and use this as a basis for a scaling-up plan to increase the number of VTA placements.
Develop models that ensure a seamless transition from high school to VTA placement for youth who need it.
Make a new assessment of the allocation criteria for VTA places that ensures that the allocation of places reflects the actual needs in the various counties.

Ensure that the increased production is used to replace fossil energy consumption domestically, increase access to affordable and clean energy as a competitive advantage for Norwegian industry, and maintain supply security for consumers. There should be no facilitation for the export of new power production from offshore wind.
Take the initiative for a North Sea collaboration to develop a long-term management plan for offshore wind, with a view to exporting to Europe.
Ensure that the Norwegian continental shelf has a capacity of 3 GW by 2030.
Set a goal for Norway to achieve a 10% market share of the global offshore wind market, with a revenue of 50 billion kroner by 2030, and facilitate this.

Come up with proposals for an initiative focused on power production based on solar cells and other renewable technologies, such as geothermal energy and wave power, with the goal of achieving a total production of 15 TWh by 2030.
Present a national strategy for offshore wind, with specific measures.
