Open more areas for offshore wind production so that Norway can become a major producer of floating offshore wind with competitive players throughout the value chain.
Facilitate emission reductions in the oil and gas industry by replacing electricity production with gas turbines offshore with offshore wind.
Give Statnett the responsibility to develop and operate a future offshore power grid in the North Sea.
Facilitate a Norwegian market for new maritime energy technology, including offshore wind power, with test centers and energy parks at sea.
Propose changes to the concession legislation for wind power, so that the same requirements for public ownership apply to wind power as for hydropower.
Ensure that decisions regarding the development of wind power align with local wishes and municipal council resolutions. A concession cannot be granted in conflict with municipal council resolutions.
Investigate and come back with proposals for a reversion scheme for wind power similar to that for hydropower.
Investigate and come back with proposals for a natural resource tax on wind power that will benefit the municipalities.

Ensure that no permits are granted for the commencement of construction activities for power developments until all required environmental studies have been conducted and the necessary considerations have been addressed through the requirements imposed on the work.
To increase the investment in train services between Norway and Scandinavian and European cities.
To facilitate continuous express trains between Oslo and Copenhagen, with good transfer options to night trains to the continent, which Swedish authorities are now working to establish.
To ensure better route information and ticket booking solutions for train travel between Norway and Europe.
Ensure that night trains are established between Oslo and Berlin.
Ensure that Swedish SJ's wishes for more and faster train departures between Stockholm and Oslo, without increased public subsidies, can be realized.

Ensure that more sleeping cars are procured for the existing night trains in Norway. Some of the cars should have a simpler standard with more sleeping places in each compartment, which is beneficial for groups and families traveling together, and makes it easier for the train to compete in the low-price segment.
Ensure that it becomes possible to purchase tickets in shared compartments on night trains in Norway.

Strengthen the night train service by offering passengers the opportunity to sleep in as long as possible before leaving the train upon early morning arrival, and likewise allowing passengers to board carriages that are attached to the train during the night.
Restore the offer of night trains also on Saturdays.
Ensure that any potential cost savings in the project benefit motorists through reduced toll fees.
Come back with a proposal that downsizes the planned expansion of E18 Langangen–Dørdal to a 2/3-lane road.
Assess how large a total guarantee sum for toll projects it is reasonable for Telemark County Municipality to bear.
Ensure that any potential cost savings in the project benefit motorists through reduced toll fees.
Come back with a proposal that downsizes the planned development of Ulsberg–Melhus to a 2/3-lane road to reduce costs, emissions, and environmental impact.
Assess how large a total guarantee sum for toll projects it is reasonable for Trøndelag County Municipality to bear.
Clarify on a principled basis how large a guarantee a county municipality can provide in connection with the financing of state roads.
Ensure that any potential cost savings in the project benefit motorists through reduced toll fees.

Come back with a proposal that downsizes the planned expansion of the E6 on the stretch Moelv–Øyer in Hedmark and Oppland to a two-/three-lane road in order to reduce costs, emissions, and environmental impact.
Consider what economic savings can be achieved and how much less agricultural land can be reduced by changing from the planned four-lane road to a 2/3-lane road from Lillehammer and northward.
Assess how large a total guarantee sum for toll road projects it is reasonable for Oppland County Municipality to bear.
To introduce a temporary suspension of cabotage rules for road-based freight transport in Norway.
Review and propose improvements before the cabotage arrangement under the regulations must be reintroduced.
Introduce necessary round-the-clock monitoring of truck combinations at border crossings in Norway, without compromising domestic inspections.

Ensure that transport buyers who violate the obligation to monitor drivers' pay and working conditions during cabotage operations face severe sanctions, and increase the penalty level to at least 10 kroner per kilogram of goods for freight transport by road and at least 1,000 kroner per passenger for passenger transport by road.
Review the penalties/sanction frameworks for the professional transport sector and assess whether they are strict enough, and report back to the Parliament on the matter.
Reduce the number of possible cabotage assignments from three to two.
Introduce requirements for electronic waybills for the transport industry.
Introduce prepayment or other guarantee solutions that ensure all foreign trucks pay tolls.
Ensure that the fines related to the illegal use of duty-free diesel are made equal for Norwegian and foreign carriers.
Introduce a mandatory course at the same level as for Norwegian drivers to master Norwegian winter roads and set stricter standards for the vehicles' winter equipment.
Develop an environmental support scheme for freight transport by rail. The environmental support scheme must facilitate a larger share of goods being transferred from road to rail.

Withdraw circular N-1/2013 or amend its content so that Norwegian authorities comply with EU regulations related to international transport in this area, thereby registering both the tractor and the trailer's registration numbers, and using the same definitions as those used in both cabotage legislation and the road freight law, where the tractor and the coupled trailer are defined as one vehicle.

Investigate the possibility of introducing a legal basis for Norwegian authorities such as the Norwegian Public Roads Administration, the Labour Inspection Authority, and others to stop and prevent further operation of trucks that have outstanding debts related to tolls, fines, or other obligations to the Norwegian state, before the state's receivables are settled, either through local credit card deductions, bank transfers, or other means.

Investigate whether vehicles under 3.5 tons that engage in freight transport on roads should be subject to the same regulations as commercial vehicles over 3.5 tons, both in terms of driving and rest times, licensing requirements, collectively agreed wages, and other requirements that apply to heavy vehicles.

Develop and present to the Parliament measures to stop the development of social dumping, crime, and increased security risks in the transport sector, including proposals that: 

1. All foreign coach operators are required to register in the VAT register, meaning that the threshold is lowered from 50,000 NOK to 1 NOK in turnover for VAT registration for this business group, which will simplify control measures. Additionally, electronic registration of all cabotage driving in Norway will be introduced. 

2. The Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority will increase its control activities. The agency will be strengthened financially and increase staffing, and a special unit for inspections in the transport industry will be established. The Norwegian Public Roads Administration will increase control activities at the border and along domestic roads. The Norwegian Public Roads Administration will be granted enforcement rights to stop vehicles based on decisions from the Labour Inspection Authority. An electronic freight document system for the transport of goods by road will be introduced. 

3. It will be investigated whether commercial vehicles under 3.5 tons can be legally included under the driving and rest time regulations, or if other regulations can be introduced that have a similar effect. 

4. A point deduction system will be introduced for holders of national transport licenses for violations of the Working Environment Act and the Road Traffic Act. 

5. Increased and certified requirements for equipment and competence for drivers in winter conditions will be established. It will be required that all drivers on Norwegian roads have completed and passed a skid driving course. It will be required that trucks on Norwegian winter roads can only use winter tires that are 3PMSF marked according to EU legislation, which have strict requirements for friction and performance in cold weather. 

6. The obligation to provide information, the duty to ensure compliance, and the right to access publicly available collective agreements for employees in road freight transport and the coach industry will be further strengthened. Government control measures will increase in scope, and violations will lead to reactions with a deterrent effect. 

7. Legal, financial, and insurance-related joint liability will be imposed on clients purchasing transport services, in addition to the solidarity responsibility that applies in all industries where there is a legally regulated minimum wage (publicly available collective agreements). 

8. State ownership will be actively used to promote a serious working life with equal competitive conditions in the transport sector. State-owned companies and enterprises must comply with seriousness requirements. 

9. Payment must be made on the mandatory toll tags before foreign trucks and coaches cross the border into Norway. 

10. The coordination of the agencies' efforts against unscrupulous actors in the transport industry will be strengthened. Customs, prosecuting authorities, the Norwegian Public Roads Administration, the Labour Inspection Authority, and tax authorities' measures are important counterforces to the emergence of unscrupulous actors in the transport industry, and efforts must therefore be better coordinated.

Contact the Swedish and Finnish authorities to improve and strengthen the control cooperation so that heavy vehicles that do not meet traffic safety requirements are stopped by Norwegian inspectors even where border control is on foreign ground. There must also be the possibility to stop vehicles where the owner has not paid outstanding claims for tolls, fines, or other debts, until this is settled.

Develop a program to reduce the maintenance backlog on county roads. The program should outline a ramp-up plan for county road maintenance with proposals for financing models and organization that will lead to increased maintenance and a reduction of the backlog on the county road network.
Come back to the Storting with a comprehensive proposal on the future organization of the Norwegian Public Roads Administration.
Stop further tendering of passenger traffic by train until an external evaluation of the tendering of Traffic Package 1 South and Traffic Package 2 North has been conducted.

Ensure that no contract is signed with the winning bidder for Traffic Package 2 North before an external evaluation has been conducted. If the evaluation reveals that price has been weighted higher than quality, the tender will be canceled, and a new tender process will be initiated where quality is weighted significantly higher than price.
Include assessment criteria for employee job security and working conditions.

Initiate a government pilot project for electricity production from deep geothermal energy in 2020, based on geological knowledge and drilling technology from the petroleum sector, as a collaboration between parties in the oil industry, public research institutions, and the Research Council.

Strengthen the regional development funds, with measures particularly aimed at expanding existing industrial clusters, building new industrial clusters, extending product and value chains, ensuring resource utilization of by-products, and creating locally anchored jobs, in collaboration with relevant trade unions in the region.

Present a proposal that allows for a portion of the Government Pension Fund Global (SPU) to be used as a national green industrial fund that makes strategic investments in domestic industrial production, with the aim of ensuring technological development, increased export of goods, more industrial jobs, increased value creation, and more processing in Norway.

Present a proposal that allows for a portion of the Government Pension Fund Global (SPU) to be used as a green infrastructure fund that invests in the development of climate-friendly infrastructure such as railways, public transport, charging networks, ports, and broadband across Norway.

Present a plan for large-scale industrial construction across the country - based on the further processing of the country's natural resources, the knowledge of industrial workers, technology, and competence environments - so that professional groups and local communities that have contributed significant value to the community do not have to bear the costs of the necessary restructuring of Norway's petroleum-oriented industry in the face of global climate change.
Work to ensure that hydrogen is safe and commercially available as fuel in shipping within 5 years.

Present a case on how to establish new and maintain existing industrial production throughout the country by developing and facilitating various forms of ownership, including regional and county ownership, ownership through employee funds, as well as employee-owned companies.

Ensure that assignments related to large investments in public enterprises, state-owned companies, and businesses are awarded to shipyards and manufacturing companies in Norway, with requirements for good cooperation between parties regarding business development, permanent employment, limitations on contract chains, and strict demands for health, safety, and environmental standards.

Ensure updated guidelines for ENOVA and other national support schemes, so that grants for larger investments and projects within the purpose are conditioned on a high proportion of the value chain for the projects being located in Norway, and enable the re-establishment of production that has previously been moved out of the country.

Present a case on how Statnett and Statkraft should be given expanded responsibilities to ensure that Norwegian electricity and power production are used as an industrial policy and environmental tool, including ensuring that the industry has access to long-term reasonable power contracts, with strict requirements for environmental standards and active production, and to say no to new power connections to foreign countries.

Present proposals on how to actively use existing and new establishment of fully or partially state ownership to retain industrial production in Norway, as well as proposals to increase the degree of further processing and ensure longer value chains in Norwegian industry, especially related to forestry and wood processing, aquaculture, fisheries, agriculture, and the food industry, as well as process industry and further processing of metals and minerals.

Establish a support scheme for projects in the process industry that replaces fossil input factors with hydrogen or other solutions that contribute to a significant reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from chemical processes.
Allocate funds to establish Bionova, modeled after Enova, to systematize innovation and increase the commercialization of biobased value creation.
To cut emissions by 60% by 2030 and halt the loss of biodiversity, present a plan that increases the share of the green mainland industry in value creation to 10% by 2025, and to 20% by 2040.
Come up with proposals for a large-scale investment in the development of offshore wind power in Norway.

We should refrain from pursuing more interconnectors until we have gained experience from the two ongoing cables to Germany and the United Kingdom. The societal benefits must be documented before any additional interconnectors can be built.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to establish a green investment company for the development of technology companies based on green, renewable carbon.

Ensure the launch of a government pilot project for offshore wind in 2020, through collaboration between stakeholders in the oil sector supply industry, public research institutions, and the Research Council.
Investigate the potential for energy production from geothermal energy in Norway, both offshore and on land.
Contribute to the development of new production methods and applications for hydrogen based on Norwegian natural gas.
Facilitate fleet renewal in the coastal shipping fleet, including by establishing a top financing scheme in GIEK and a scrapping incentive scheme that is effective.
Continue the CO2 compensation scheme at the current level, with at least 75% compensation also after 2020.
Ensure an ambitious and climate-friendly domestic market for the maritime industry through environmental requirements in public procurement.
Contribute to the development of new industrial production and new value chains based on bioresources from the sea, land, and forest.
Come back with proposals in the state budget for 2020 to strengthen the regional development funds.

Amend the regulation for the use of motor vehicles in uncultivated land and on frozen waterways so that municipalities are granted the authority to exercise discretion regarding the measurement of the 2.5 km boundary according to the regulation § 5 first paragraph letter c. Considerations of actual driving distance and topography should carry more weight than the distance of 2.5 km measured in a straight line.
Initiate a pilot project on the management of golden eagles in Troms and Trøndelag during 2019.
To fly the rainbow flag on state buildings where possible in connection with the Pride festival, and the Parliament will do the same.

Investigate the consequences of treating individuals admitted to psychiatric hospital departments equally with those admitted to somatic hospital departments, so that both patient groups are exempt from reductions in their benefits from the National Insurance Scheme. The government is requested to return to the Storting in an appropriate manner, with an assessment of full, or possibly partial, equal treatment.

Propose changes to the regulatory principles for ongoing pensions so that pensioners do not lose purchasing power during years when wage earners experience positive purchasing power development. Additionally, present a case regarding the right to negotiate in the social security settlement, including assessments of the opportunities for reprioritization within the current framework of the social security settlement, and what changes can be implemented to allow pensioners' organizations to have increased opportunities to influence the priorities within the constraints set by the social security settlement through the right to negotiate.
Ensure that the earmarking of 3 million kroner for the Psychology Students' information work for youth (POFU) is continued in the budget for 2019.

Introduce trials with activity rights for all social assistance recipients, where qualitatively good content is also offered to prepare individuals for the labor market, and establish a government support scheme for such trials in selected municipalities. The trials should preferably take place in municipalities that offer qualification programs and be linked to this.
Investigate and propose changes to the Working Environment Act that clarify the concepts of employee and employer.
Initiate an independent investigation into the Police Immigration Unit's use of coercive measures in light of the forced return of families and minors to Afghanistan.

Ensure that Andøya Air Station is preserved as a base for the Norwegian Armed Forces' maritime surveillance, in light of new information suggesting that the choice of Evenes as a base for maritime surveillance was made on flawed grounds or incorrect assumptions.

Reallocate the increased funding for the capacity-increasing motorway project E18 Lysaker–Ramstadsletta, which will further increase an already high toll burden, to collective development projects and railway projects.
Ensure that the oil and gas found through the exploration well Snadd Outer Outer/Black Vulture southwest of the Norne field off the Helgeland coast are not extracted.
Stop the expansion of wind farms in untouched nature on land in Norway.

Ensure air ambulance preparedness with necessary measures in the short and long term, and ensure that the contract between the Air Ambulance Service HF and Babcock Scandinavian Air Ambulance AB is annulled if the new operator is unable to deliver in accordance with the signed contract, and ensure proper operation and maintenance during the operator transition on July 1st.
Withdraw its assessment that the concession processing for NorthConnect should be postponed and reject the concession application.

To ensure that the Ullevål team, which provides services to pregnant women and those giving birth with complex issues such as mental health problems, substance abuse, and/or difficult life situations, does not lose one of its two midwife positions, and that maternity care and midwife positions are not removed from the ABC unit at Ullevål.

Ensure staffing in the maternity wards and other necessary services for expectant mothers during the summer months, considering that the number of births is often higher in the summer than at other times of the year.
Propose a change in the regulatory principles from 2020 onwards to reflect the actual average of wage and price development.

Propose a change to the AAP scheme so that extensions beyond three years are granted when the applicant's medical situation is unclear. Furthermore, extensions should be granted for young people under 25 years old who need more work training. The decision-making authority for decisions and any extensions of the AAP period must lie with the local Nav office.
Complaining that any potential cost reductions in the E39 Klett-Bårdshaug project will benefit motorists through reduced toll fees.
Review the E18 West Corridor project with the aim of significant cost reductions and lower toll fees for motorists.
Complaining that any potential cost reductions in the project rv. 3/rv. 25 Ommangsvollen-Grundset/Basthjørnet will benefit motorists through reduced toll fees.

Provide an account of any consequences for the security situation and urban development projects as a result of plans for allied reception in Andøya and Bodø, and present these to the Storting in connection with the state budget for 2020.
Amend the regulation on country-by-country reporting to ensure that where extended information is to be provided, it shall be given regardless of materiality threshold.

Investigate the costs, benefits, and drawbacks of (1) tightening the wording regarding the requirement that figures must be sourced from the annual accounts in the LLR regulation § 4, and (2) requiring that the key figures in country-by-country reporting be included as a note in the financial statements.

Ensure that pension adjustments do not lead to a sustained negative development in purchasing power for retirees, and investigate a model for calculations that secures retirees' income even in years with low wage growth.

Come back in the state budget for 2020 with a proposal for a significant increase in funding for the conservation of prioritized species under the Nature Diversity Act, so that efforts can be greatly intensified in line with the wishes of the Parliament.
Investigate and propose changes to taxes in connection with the state budget for 2020, which make it profitable for owners of recreational boats to switch to zero-emission technology.

Review the regulations and rates for social assistance, living expenses, and other means-tested benefits, and return to the Parliament in the state budget for 2020 with proposals that ensure recipients a dignified standard of living and that the amounts paid out increase.

Promote the issue of the social security settlement to the Parliament so that the matter receives a thorough examination, and the organizations participating in the social security settlement must be granted negotiation rights.

Conduct a new assessment of the regulations related to the payment of benefits for stays in state and county institutions, and by the end of 2019, return to the Parliament with a legislative proposal that addresses this imbalance in the regulations, effective from January 1, 2020.
Investigate and propose a tax exemption for electric buses in the state budget for 2020.
Take the initiative to reopen a direct train route between Oslo and Copenhagen, and start the process of acquiring new night train sets to operate the direct route between the two cities.

Ensure that the work assessment allowance scheme operates in accordance with the National Insurance Act § 1-1 (Purpose), so that no one loses the right to work assessment allowance before they are fully assessed for work or benefits.
To amend the regulations on country-by-country reporting so that extended information shall be provided in accordance with the annual accounts and regardless of materiality threshold.
Prepare a separate parliamentary report on climate risk, among other things based on NOU 2018:17, and return to the Parliament with such a report no later than during the spring session of 2020.
Propose suggestions on how we can achieve the goal of 100% of new car sales being zero-emission vehicles by 2025.

Give an additional task to the working group assigned to assess and review the compensation schemes for veterans, to investigate the reasons why the rejection rate in compensation cases for personnel who have incurred psychological stress injuries in overseas operations is increasing.

Ensure that the allocation for the OPS project rv. 3/rv. 25 Ommangsvollen–Grundset/Basthjørnet in Hedmark, 150 million kroner, is used to increase the state's share in the project, so that the cost reduction benefits motorists by reducing the toll fee portion.

Promote a proposal to introduce a registration requirement for foreign service providers, posted workers, and self-employed individuals who perform work in Norway. The proposal should include information about the work location, time period, and the individuals performing the work.
Maintain the earmarked support for Physicians Against Nuclear Weapons of 2 million kroner for 2019.
Ensure that there are no tightening of the compensation schemes for personnel who have incurred psychological stress injuries in overseas operations.
Ensure that the conditions for the merger of Nord University are respected and followed up.

Make adjustments to the funding model for the short course scheme at folk high schools in line with the input from the Folk High School Council, and that the funding for the short courses continues in accordance with this also after January 1, 2021.

Provide the Parliament with a decision-making basis on alternative financing models for the capture, transport, and storage of CO2, which can create profitability for new projects, as well as how the alternative financing models can also contribute to the financing of the relevant full-scale project.

Amend the broadcasting regulation so that the Women's World Cup and Women's European Championship are considered events of significant social importance, in line with other similar sports events, and ensure free viewing rights.
To reduce toll fees by up to 200 million kroner during the entire financing period for the PPP project.

Ensure that the Norwegian four-year-old in al-Hol is brought to Norway as quickly as possible due to humanitarian reasons, as it is a matter of life and death for a seriously ill child. This also involves bringing to Norway the three-year-old sister and the children's 29-year-old Norwegian mother, who is being investigated by the Police Security Service for participation in the terrorist organization IS.
Suspend the construction of licensed wind power plants pending political processing of the national framework for wind power.

Ensure the air ambulance preparedness with necessary measures in the short and long term, and ensure that the availability at all of the country's public air ambulance bases is immediately brought up to 98.4% as stipulated in the contract. If the operator is unable to deliver in accordance with the signed contract, the contract between the Air Ambulance Service HF and Babcock Scandinavian Air Ambulance will be canceled.

Develop sector-specific action plans for emission reductions leading up to 2030, and ensure that the emission cuts are made in a socially just manner, for example through progressive environmental taxes based on economic factors, environmental impact, and regional considerations.
Take the initiative to ask EFTA to resume negotiations on the free trade agreement with Mercosur, and do not conclude any final agreement until sufficient protection of the rainforest is ensured.

Establish a public committee – a Green New Deal Commission – to investigate how Norwegian society can transition in a fair manner from a fossil economy to a zero-emission society. The committee will review the societal structures that hinder the necessary green transition and climate cuts. The committee will propose concrete measures to achieve Norway's climate goals, to develop and preserve jobs and industry, and to implement the green shift with low social inequality.
Present the proposals necessary to reverse cuts and deteriorations in the scheme for work assessment allowance.

Ensure that thorough analyses of the consequences for nature have been conducted in all granted wind power cases before MTA/detailed plans are processed. These investigations must address any changes to the plans compared to how they were when the concession was granted.
Maintain disability protection against age adjustment.

Present the government's proposal for a national framework for wind power to the Parliament, so that affected parties and interest groups have the opportunity to express their views and be heard in a proper and thorough manner.
Give the Parliament access to the content of the free trade agreement that the government has finalized with Mercosur.

Ensure that an immediate, indefinite hunting permit is granted for wolves that have caused damage east of the E6 in Trøndelag and for wolves that have caused damage in Hægebostad, Lyngdal, Kvinesdal, and Åseral in Vest-Agder.
Maintain the current management regions for large carnivores.
Ensure that any potential cost savings in toll-financed road projects benefit motorists through reduced tolls.
Present a report on Norway's relationship with the EU in the energy sector.
Conduct a public inquiry into alternatives to the EEA based on WTO regulations, our free trade agreement, and the trade agreement that exists between Canada and the EU.
Stop the planning of a third runway at Gardermoen.
Present a parliamentary report on tax policy.
Present a case in the Storting regarding the specific model for compensation to fur farmers before the compensation is finally determined.
Facilitate the possibility of reversing the merger of counties if the counties request it.

Contribute to climate financing for energy transition in emerging economies. The goal must be for Norway to become a central contributor in the effort to phase out new coal power plants in emerging economies.
To initiate a renegotiation of the Chicago Convention of 1944 on international civil aviation, so that international air travel can take its share of climate commitments.
Present a plan to increase the long-term carbon uptake in Norwegian forest areas.

Conduct a public inquiry on how the scope for the design and implementation of regulations in the EEA Agreement can be utilized to safeguard Norwegian interests in the areas of energy, transport, and labor.
Ensure that the rule stating that each municipality must have its own conciliation board is followed in practice.
Ensure that none of today's maternity wards or other birthing services are closed down.
Present an evaluation of the tender process in the air ambulance service to the Parliament as a separate matter, cf. decision no. 865 (2017-2018).
Follow up on the settlement regarding the local police reform (Innst. 306 S (2014-2015)) by promptly strengthening the staffing in the local police and the frontline preparedness in the police.

To register the development of hiring from staffing agencies and create statistics by industry and county, including the proportion of short-term stays from EU member states, and to present proposals for measures that prevent the development we have seen in, among others, the construction industry from spreading to other sectors.
Take the initiative with families in Norway for children who have Norwegian parents and are located in Syria, to assist in a safe transportation of the children to Norway.
Ensure that higher education institutions emphasize their regional responsibility and decentralized education throughout the country.

Explain how to ensure that children with Norwegian parents who are in Syria can return home as quickly as possible, as well as the situation regarding Norwegians who have joined or worked with ISIS, the status of efforts for legal accountability in the region, and the basis for arrest and prosecution of these individuals if they come to Norwegian territory.
Intensify the efforts to strengthen the public production of means of payment and establish a digital legal tender for the public, issued by the Central Bank of Norway.
Investigate the possibility of digital account and payment solutions provided by the public sector, and whether blockchain technology may be suitable in this context.

Investigate the role and position of cash, including assessing the right to pay in cash against the desire of businesses to operate cashless, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Restore the educational offerings in Helgeland by transferring responsibility to another university.
Halt the downsizing process at the Nesna campus, and ensure that students who have been admitted to Nesna can continue their education at Nesna without interruption.
To present a comprehensive plan for the future structure of higher education in Norway.
Change the funding system and introduce incentives for decentralized study programs that are in demand by regional labor and business sectors.
Present to the Storting an analysis of the financing system's impact on the structure of the sector in terms of both study locations and subject offerings.
To stop the approved change of the study location structure, at the Nesna campus and the nursing education in Sandnessjøen, at Nord University.
Secure teacher education in Nesna, among other things by ensuring financial flexibility for the education through study places, recruitment positions, and a strengthened budget.
To ensure that the goals of regional responsibility and equal access to higher education throughout the country are strengthened and followed up by educational institutions.

To follow up on the structural message for higher education with a plan for how to strengthen the regional role of educational institutions, describing how broad professional education and practice-oriented research will be enhanced to ensure access to decentralized education across the country. Future higher education in Nesna should be part of the plan.
Promote proposals with rules and frameworks for introducing the right to strike for school students, so that student councils and student organizations can organize and encourage political strikes.

Change the absence rules in schools so that documented participation in political strikes organized by student councils, student organizations, or other civil society organizations is considered political absence.
Present concrete proposals and a timeline for making all Norwegian schools dyslexia-friendly, with a focus on specific learning difficulties, so that all students receive the appropriate support.

Investigate and promote the necessary proposals to ban commercial school operations, through new organizational forms that facilitate non-profit activities while ensuring transparency in the schools' financial expenditures.

Present a proposal that approved private primary and secondary schools can be included in a municipal/county school utilization plan. If there is a need to reduce the number of school places due to changes in student enrollment, the reduction in the total number of school places must not weaken the public school offering.

Present a proposal for a legislative amendment that allows for the reduction of the number of approved private student places in a municipality or county municipality if the situation is such that the quality of the overall public school offering is threatened.

Promote a proposal for a legislative change that ensures municipalities and county municipalities have full authority over the school structure, so that the interests of the public school offering are safeguarded when establishing and expanding private school offerings.
Investigate new organizational forms for operating private schools that facilitate non-profit activities while ensuring public transparency in the use of public funds.

Review the legislation for private schools to ensure that the intention that all state funding benefits students is better upheld than it is today. Such a review should aim to reduce the need for oversight, introduce stricter sanctions for violations, and prevent the resale of schools and colleges receiving state funding from allowing private profit to be extracted from school operations.

Propose to increase the value-added tax on meat from 15 percent to 20 percent, with the exception of organic meat and meat production where the share of concentrated feed does not exceed 10 percent of the feed measured in energy.
Promote a proposal to amend the Sales Act § 1, so that the purpose is expanded to also take health and the environment into account.

Increase the target price for grain without increasing the price reduction for concentrated feed, in order to encourage more sustainable animal husbandry with less use of concentrated feed, and more use of roughage and pasture grazing.
Promote a proposal to remove the value-added tax on fruits and vegetables.
Promote a proposal to remove the value-added tax on plant-based meat alternatives.

Promote a proposal to amend the Sales Act § 11, so that the share of funds transferred to the information offices via the Sales Council is not tied to the product type from which the fees have been collected.

Promote a proposal to introduce requirements for a neutral educational curriculum in food and health subjects in schools to prevent commercial interests from having too strong an influence on children's knowledge about food.
Promote proposals to strengthen customs protection on meat, with the aim of reducing the import of especially beef.
Prioritize increased support for grazing in uncultivated land over the agricultural agreement.
Increase support for the information offices for grains, fruits, and vegetables to stimulate increased demand for Norwegian-produced plant-based food.
Present a case that demonstrates the climate impact of increasing the share of meat, fruits, and vegetables produced in Norway.
Present a case with a proposal for strengthened customs protection for meat, fruit, and vegetables produced in Norway, in order to safeguard Norwegian jobs and reduce emissions from food production.
Propose to reduce the normal speed limit in built-up areas from the current 50 km/h to 40 km/h, and to 30 km/h in urban areas with mixed traffic and around schools and kindergartens.

Lower the limit values for particulate matter in the pollution regulations from the current level, so that they align with national environmental goals: a. The annual limit value for PM10 is reduced to 20 µg/m3. b. The annual limit value for PM2.5 is reduced to 8 µg/m3.
Promote proposals to introduce sanctions for municipalities that exceed the air quality limit values in the pollution regulations.
Promote a proposal to introduce a reward system for municipalities that implement measures to improve air quality.

Promote a proposal for a national support scheme for individuals in areas with air pollution problems who wish to replace their old wood stoves with new, clean-burning stoves. The scheme should prioritize low-income households.

Investigate and return to the Storting with concrete proposals to use environmental speed limits to a greater extent in and around Norwegian cities and towns, in order to achieve societal benefits in the form of better health and reduced fuel consumption, particulate matter, and exhaust emissions, as well as changes in traffic congestion, noise, and accidents.
Present a plan for increased planting along national roads in and around major Norwegian cities, with the aim of reducing air pollution and noise from road traffic.

Come back to the Parliament with a case that describes the status of air quality regulation in cities and towns, and that specifies how the pollution regulations, the recommendations from the Norwegian Institute of Public Health, and national environmental councils can be coordinated and harmonized so that air quality in cities and towns is regulated based on a comprehensive legal framework and system for limit values.

Promote a proposal to give municipalities the authority to impose restrictions on wood burning on heavily polluted days. The restrictions must be able to differentiate between clean-burning and non-clean-burning stoves, as well as take social considerations into account to protect low-income households.

Come back with a national plan with stronger measures against particulate matter, and better harmonization between national environmental goals and the legal framework, to ensure that the national target for particulate matter of the type PM10 is not exceeded in the coming years.
Report annually to the Storting on the overall efforts to improve air quality in cities and towns, including goal achievement and the need for new measures.
Promote a proposal to introduce a requirement that all public construction sites must be emission-free.
Promote a proposal to amend the climate law to establish that Norway should be emission-free by 2040.
Present a realistic and binding plan for domestic cuts in greenhouse gas emissions by 60 percent by 2030 compared to 1990. The plan must be presented no later than January 1, 2020.
Present a realistic and binding plan to prevent the loss of biodiversity and nature by no later than January 1, 2020.

Come back to the Parliament with a new proposal regarding the EU's reference value regulation, where thorough assessments of Norway's interests in the matter are made, and where changes and adjustments are proposed that can alleviate the burdens for Norwegian actors and otherwise provide a regulatory framework adapted to Norwegian conditions.

Establish a state production of pharmaceuticals, StatMed, which through agreements with the regional health authorities ensures the production of important medications, and strengthen research and development of new, necessary medicines.

Establish a support scheme where pharmaceutical manufacturers can enter into a binding collaboration with the state, where the state can cover part of the costs for research and development of medicines based on certain criteria, in exchange for the public gaining access to necessary medications at an agreed, low price for a defined period afterwards.
Create a program to secure funding for mature health clusters, and ask the government to revisit the issue in the Revised National Budget (RNB) on how this can be implemented.
Ensure the establishment of a national center for clinical studies.
Present a scheme that facilitates toll discounts for those with low income.

Investigate the social effects of tolls and various social moderation schemes, including road pricing models that take income into account, and reimbursement through lower taxes for those with average and low incomes, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Stop large road construction projects funded by tolls.
Initiate a pilot project with free public transport for children up to and including the year they turn 13, in areas with high toll charges.
Promote proposals for a significant increase in state funding for urban environment packages and urban growth agreements, as well as the special grants for large public transport projects.

Develop a new system for financing transportation projects where funding for large public road projects through tolls is not possible, and where projects that enhance traffic safety, ensure safe transport in rural areas, and reduce total emissions from the transportation sector are prioritized over capacity-increasing highway projects. This will be presented in connection with the next update of the National Transport Plan.
Investigate road pricing as a replacement for current tolls and other usage-related vehicle taxes.
Have an explicit assessment criterion regarding better social and geographical profiling in user payments in the ongoing investigation of new technology that can replace the current toll system.
Remove the condition of reducing toll fees and ticket prices for public transport in order to increase the state's contribution to large public transport projects.
Present a report on tax policy that includes an assessment of the social consequences of toll fees.

Review the rules for business transfers and propose amendments to the law that ensure employees do not lose their jobs when a contract expires, and that strengthen employees' rights in the event of a business transfer. The review should cover both the private and public sectors, with particular attention to services such as cleaning, waste management, security, and road maintenance.

Review the rules for business transfers and promote legislative proposals that strengthen workers' rights in business transfers in both the public and private sectors, as well as when contract tenders expire. In particular, attention should be given to the sectors of cleaning, waste management, security, janitorial services, and road maintenance.

Review the effects of the right of reservation in the Working Environment Act § 16-2 second paragraph, including the consequences for salary and working conditions, and promote legislative proposals that strengthen employees' conditions in the event of business transfers.
Promote proposals that ensure that wage and working conditions are not weakened as a result of outsourcing.

Investigate the consequences of outsourcing in various industries, with particular emphasis on the effects of competition outsourcing on employees and their working conditions, and propose amendments to laws that strengthen the position of workers.

Ensure that all plans for outsourcing cleaning services in government agencies are halted, and that cleaning services that have already been put out to tender are brought back in-house as soon as it is practically possible.

Ensure that government agencies in the competition basis set stricter requirements for salary and pension conditions and working conditions for employees in companies that perform assignments for the public sector.

Ensure that public enterprises do not design the competition basis in such a way that lower wage and pension conditions or poorer working conditions are the reasons why the public sector chooses not to carry out the work in-house.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a funding scheme for municipal midwives that ensures that municipalities do not lose money by using municipal midwives instead of general practitioners in the follow-up of pregnant women.

Establish a committee to prepare a white paper that examines the overall maternity services and how to best ensure qualitative and safe prenatal, childbirth, and postnatal care. The investigation must particularly address proximity to maternity services, quality and staffing in the delivery ward, and follow-up before and after childbirth, as well as the financing system for midwives and the transitions between specialist healthcare services and municipal healthcare services.

Introduce a fundamental principle for maternity care that families must be ensured a close and accessible high-quality birthing service, regardless of their place of residence, and ensure that health enterprises operate according to this.
Investigate whether the enhanced birthing room, as mentioned in St.meld. no. 12 (2008–2009) A Joyful Event, can be utilized to a greater extent than it is today.
Promote a case for funding maternity care through a capitation model, so that quality is rewarded and that adequate staffing is ensured as an emergency service.

Ensure that pregnant women who are entitled to companion services receive them by ensuring that healthcare enterprises have the necessary agreements with midwives in place, and by expanding access to pay according to the tariff.
Ensure that a new national inspection of the country's maternity departments is conducted.

Conduct a comprehensive review of the staffing situation at the country's maternity wards to ensure that the staffing is adequate so that each woman actually has access to one-on-one care from a midwife during the active phase of labor.

Ensure that Helse Nord RHF expands the mandate for Helgeland Hospital 2025, so that the mandate also includes an investigation of a hospital structure with two local hospitals with full emergency functions and up to two district medical centers. The hospitals must at least have round-the-clock preparedness in emergency medicine, emergency surgery, anesthesia, and access to radiology and laboratory services, as well as a maternity ward.

Ensure that there is a comprehensive plan for pre-hospital services in the various alternatives outlined for the structure and location of Helgeland Hospital 2025, as well as that the content of the district medical centers is defined before a decision is made in the matter.

Ensure the restoration of child benefits as a universal entitlement by ensuring that municipalities exclude the entire child benefit from the calculation of social assistance, and allocate funds for compensation for this in the revised national budget for 2020.
Acquire zero-emission vehicles that meet the safety requirements for the ministers' car service, and eventually replace all fossil fuel cars with zero-emission vehicles.
Reverse the introduction of the road usage tax for biofuels outside the sales requirement.

Deliver a binding, sector-specific climate budget and climate accounts in accordance with the Climate Act, no later than in connection with the state budget for 2021, with open and verifiable sources. The climate budget should outline annual cuts to achieve the 2030 target.
Ensure that biofuels with a high deforestation risk cannot be counted towards meeting the blending requirement for biofuels.

Investigate a new and more social model for municipal property tax based on the same revenue potential, the assessed value of properties, mandatory basic deductions, and social shielding arrangements such as deferred tax upon property transfer.
To investigate possible compensation schemes, including differentiated rates, for the air passenger tax for the short-haul network in Northern Norway.
Ensure the continuation of tax exemption for biofuels beyond the blending requirement.
Continue the distribution of grants to volunteer centers according to Table C-k – cases with special distribution for the municipalities.
Promote a legal case for the Storting to lift the ban on fur farming in Norway.
Present a message about tax policy that addresses, among other things, the social and geographical distribution effects of various taxes.
Present a proposal for a climate fund for agriculture based on the model of the forestry fund.
Ensure that no tax exemptions are granted for biofuels with a high deforestation risk, either within or outside the blending mandate.

Initiate an investigation into the consequences of implementing a full road usage tax on all liquid biofuels, in consultation with users and suppliers. Such an investigation should also include a proposal for a long-term plan for the tax treatment of alternative fuels to ensure the desired predictability.
Develop a climate account for all government entities from 2020 – including scope 3 from 2021.
Resume dialogue and negotiations with the business transport sector regarding the establishment and organization of a CO2 fund for business transport.
Not to implement full road usage tax on all liquid biofuels from 2020, so that the exemption for biodiesel sold outside the blending requirement is maintained until further notice.
Propose to abolish the system of neutral VAT in healthcare services in connection with the state budget for 2021.
Present the matter of Norway's accession to the EU's third energy market package for new consideration in the Storting.

Negotiate a joint declaration with the EU in line with the Norwegian position as expressed in the agreement between the Labour Party, the Conservative Party, the Progress Party, the Liberal Party, and the Green Party regarding adherence to the EU's third energy market package, for decision in the EEA Committee.
Amend the regulation on country-by-country reporting to ensure that where extended information is to be provided, it shall be given regardless of the materiality threshold.

Investigate the costs, benefits, and drawbacks of (1) tightening the wording regarding the requirement that figures must be sourced from the annual accounts in the regulation for country-by-country reporting § 4, and (2) requiring that the key figures in the country-by-country reporting be included as a note in the financial statements.

Present concrete proposals that uphold the intention of Document 8:160 S (2018–2019) to reduce tax evasion while also taking into account other considerations such as ensuring the competitiveness of Norwegian businesses, safeguarding Norwegian jobs, and avoiding unnecessary bureaucracy.

Amend the regulation on country-by-country reporting to ensure that where extended information is to be provided, it shall be given in accordance with the annual accounts and independent of the materiality threshold.

Investigate alternatives for adjustments and changes to the Norwegian tax system aimed at preventing a decline in tax revenue to Norway, as a result of new corporate structures and business models that are minimally captured by current tax regulations.
Renegotiate existing tax treaties with the aim of being able to introduce withholding tax on royalties and interest.
Present a proposal to introduce withholding tax on royalties and interest no later than in connection with the presentation of the revised national budget for 2020.
Strengthen the requirements for transparency regarding ownership and taxes in public procurement.

Gather experiences from other countries with similar ownership registers and the use of various threshold values, and investigate a lower threshold value than 25% to ensure that Norway is a frontrunner in terms of transparency, as well as to follow up on both the Storting's decision in Innst. 298 S (2014–2015) and the EU's fourth anti-money laundering directive.

Take the necessary steps, including promoting any necessary legislative proposals, to include actual tax payments in the procurement regulations, and stipulate that in order to participate in a tender process, a company must report how much tax it has paid in recent years, as well as report revenue, actual owners, and cost structure.

Investigate the Norwegian scope of action while awaiting an agreement on an international framework for fairer taxation. The investigation must include the introduction of a specific sales tax on digital businesses, as many EU countries have done or plan to do, and a reverse credit deduction to combat profit shifting.
Promote a proposal that au pairs are protected by the Working Environment Act or other protective regulations during the hours they work.
Promote the proposal that the au pair's residence permit should be tied to the au pair and not to the host family.
Consider a lower upper age limit for au pairs.
Remove the requirement for a fee to change host families or impose the fee on the host family that has breached the contract.
Promote proposals that require host families to document participation in mandatory courses.
Tighten the rules so that violations by the host family result in exclusion from the program.
Propose changes to the legislation that require there to be minor children in the host family.
Start the work of phasing out the current au pair scheme and establishing a new scheme that ensures the purpose is cultural exchange and protects participants from exploitation.
Establish a sector agreement for offshore wind based on the British Offshore Wind Sector Deal model, with the goal of 100 TWh annual production by 2030.
Implement necessary measures to prevent the use of biofuels with a high deforestation risk in the Norwegian fuel market. The measures must be in place by January 1, 2020.

Establish the following basis for development projects on the Norwegian continental shelf: The Storting (Norwegian Parliament) agrees that the Ministry of Petroleum and Energy may approve projects (plans for development/facilities and operations) on the Norwegian continental shelf in 2020 under the following conditions: 1. The project must not have significant principled or societal implications. 2. The upper limit for total investments per project is 7 billion kroner. 3. Each individual project must demonstrate acceptable socio-economic profitability and be reasonably robust against changes in the price development of oil and natural gas.
Consider measures such as organized state hunting and shooting premiums in the implementation of the Action Plan against wild boar 2020–2024.

Come back to the Parliament with a concrete action plan with new and modified measures that will achieve a minimum of 6 TWh reduced energy consumption in existing buildings by 2030, in addition to the 4 TWh expected to be realized with existing measures.
Report on the profitability development of all individual fields under development, as well as on the state's prospects for revenue from the fields.
Set requirements for offshore supply vessels regarding low-emission solutions from 2025 and zero emissions from 2030.

Establish a commission to conduct a review of the governance systems for Norwegian climate policy, why the emission target for 2020 is not being met, and what needs to be changed to ensure better goal management of climate efforts in Norwegian administration leading up to 2030.
Ensure that the restoration of nature and biodiversity in and along waterways is secured through the upcoming conditions revisions for waterways.

Implement the protection of the areas Innervisten, Nordfjorden, Karlsøyvær, Kaldvågfjorden and Innhavet, Ytre Karlsøy, Rossfjordstraumen, Rystraumen, Ytre Hardangerfjorden, Lurefjorden and Lindåsosane, Krossfjorden, Børgin and Skarnsundet as planned in the fall of 2019.
Develop a climate account for all government agencies from 2020 – including Scope 3 from 2021.
Ensure that the state leases equipment instead of purchasing it where it results in a lower carbon footprint and where there are no significant differences in costs.
Introduce a basic deduction for the electricity tax for fast chargers of 5,000 kWh per month.
Investigate various tax models for the extraction of virgin natural resources during 2020 and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Investigate various tax models for fossil plastics and plastic packaging during 2020 and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Reject the license application from NorthConnect for the construction of a new cable between Norway and the United Kingdom.
Investigate how employers can be required to ensure that employees who are labor immigrants receive Norwegian language training.
Conduct a living conditions survey for elderly non-returnable asylum seekers.
Review the ban on temporary work permits for non-returnable asylum seekers and consider a differentiation of the regulations, including for stateless individuals and older asylum seekers.
Ensure that arrangements are made for the introduction scheme to be linked to vocational training and adult education, so that upper secondary vocational training can be started and completed.

Ensure that the university and college sector offers relevant and genuinely qualifying supplementary education programs for immigrants with completed or started higher education, in accordance with the recommendations in NOU 2017:2.

Promote proposals for a revised housing support framework that ensures that new disability recipients also receive housing support at the same level as before, so that housing support as a social housing tool is significantly strengthened.
Compensate the municipalities for the expenses they incur when the fire service has to perform tasks that are the responsibility of state emergency services.
Establish a government interest compensation scheme for necessary investments in infrastructure in the municipal sector as a result of extreme weather.

Change the arrangement of the urban and growth municipality grants so that they are added as a surcharge to the municipalities that qualify for the grant, without any deductions from the framework for all municipalities.

Suggest changes to the integration scheme or the municipalities' income system that compensate for permanent expenses so that refugees with significant health issues or disabilities can be settled quickly.
Establish a permanent compensation scheme for the loss of income resulting from changes in property tax on businesses and facilities, ensuring nearly full compensation.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals for necessary appropriations for fast ferries as soon as possible.

Conduct a comprehensive review of the scheme for resource-intensive services and ensure that relevant costs incurred by municipalities, such as those arising from the quality regulations and early discharge of patients, are included in the basis for the municipal co-payment.

Change the direction of the district-specific funds so that they contribute to the transition to a zero-emission society and economy. Within such frameworks, the county municipalities should have greater freedom to decide how the funds should be used.
Ensure e-voting solutions for the blind and visually impaired in the upcoming municipal/county council elections and parliamentary elections.
Initiate an external evaluation of the government's handling of the refugee crisis in 2015, as recommended in the Emergency Preparedness Committee's report.
Come to the Parliament with full funding for the transfer of the county road administration from the state to the county municipalities.
Abolish the pilot scheme with state funding for elderly care.

Ensure that the work to clarify the recipients of work assessment allowance is not adversely affected by the cleanup related to the so-called Nav scandal, and return to the Parliament if there is a need for increased funding.

Present a case to the Parliament regarding the reorganization of the Labor Inspection Authority, which will take effect from January 1, 2020. The reorganization involves centralizing the management of the various inspection sections, with no local management. This will lead to more remote management, poorer collaboration across sections, and increased travel. It will result in higher costs for the agency. The number of inspections may decline significantly in the future. The report must document how this reorganization will strengthen the Labor Inspection Authority's main task, which is inspection and control.

Maintain the current regulations regarding support for the increased cost of a gluten-free diet for those who require it, until a better professionally grounded proposal can be presented in consultation with the user organization, effective from July 1, 2020.

Ensure that assistive devices for individuals over 26 years old are treated equally to other assistive devices and converted into a preliminary grant. The change should be made in connection with the announced evaluation of the scheme.
Establish a framework that grants young people in need of permanent adapted work (VTA) the right to such state-funded positions.
Consider whether optometrists can be used for vision examinations of children over 5 years old, and that the examination is covered by the state.

Engage in dialogue with the Celiac Association well in advance of the proposed implementation date of April 1, 2020, for further cuts to the basic allowance for celiac disease/non-celiac gluten intolerance, in order to reach a consensus on what the actual additional expenses are, and report back with the results of these discussions in the revised national budget for 2020.
Come back to the Storting with an assessment of the establishment of a Nav ombudsman.
Implement an activity reform with a job guarantee for young people with disabilities who can work fully or partially.

Implement a project to map out which internal mechanisms in the Labor and Welfare Administration have slowed down or hindered the expected implementation of the Nav reform, so that progress can be made in the execution.
Ensure that all municipalities in the country adopt a strategy for full-time culture, and establish a government financial grant scheme for projects promoting full-time and against part-time.
Ensure that the organizations that are currently exempt from paying the employer's share to the National Pension Fund continue to have this exemption.
Facilitate that the difference between the government's regulation of old-age pensions and an average of wage and price growth is allocated to increase the level of the minimum pension.
"Promote the necessary proposals to ensure that the organizations participating in the social security settlement have the right to negotiate in 2020."

Present the social security settlement as a separate issue in the Storting during the spring session after the social security discussions, while also reinstating the previous budget practice, where costs were grouped under the item for miscellaneous expenses.
Present a case for changing the regulatory principles for ongoing pensions from wage development minus 0.75% to the actual average of wages and prices.
Consider the possibilities for reprioritization within the framework set by the right to negotiate in the social security settlement.

Promote proposals for necessary legislative changes and make the necessary regulatory amendments so that the time frame used for assessing victim compensation in reopening cases shifts from the time of the harmful act to the time of the conviction. In assessing the allocation of victim compensation in reopening cases, the time of the last conviction should be the basis. The regulatory changes should have retroactive effect.

Promote a proposal for a new law on victim compensation that ensures the victim compensation scheme includes victims of violence from older cases and reopening cases, and present this to the Parliament during the spring of 2020.
Promote a proposal for a new law on victim compensation and present it to the Parliament during 2020.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal on how sustainable development can be incorporated into the continuing education and professional development programs for teachers.
To return to the Parliament with a plan for a new and improved quota program for students from the Global South, as well as an assessment of whether the Panorama strategy needs adjustment.

Conduct an evaluation of the effects of the conversion scheme for student support that was introduced with the state budget for 2019, to investigate whether and to what extent the scheme affects study progression and completion rates.
Abolish the system of quality-based funding in health enterprises.
To return the loan application for the New Oslo University Hospital to Helse Sør-Øst RHF.
Ensure that Ullevål Hospital is not sold.
Develop a binding plan and goal that all home-dwelling individuals with dementia who have such a need will have access to a day activity program by 2025.

Support for orthodontic treatment is based on the report from the Norwegian Directorate of Health, which has been prepared in collaboration with professional environments, in order to ensure that children who have a clear need for treatment will continue to receive funding.
Ensure that manual therapists are included on par with chiropractors in the work to establish a five-year master's program.
Initiate an evaluation of the Norwegian Patient Injury Compensation, Health Complaint Board, and the boards within the Health Complaint Board.

Investigate whether the increased costs of obtaining authorization result in an economic loss for society due to foreign-educated healthcare professionals not utilizing their skills and labor resources in our shared healthcare service, and further assess the profitability of reducing the costs associated with obtaining authorization.
Reintroduce the reporting system in the specialist health service, which was discontinued in the spring of 2019.
Abolish free treatment choice and return to free hospital choice as well as the use of agreements with non-profit and commercial actors.

Ensure that the state takes over the air ambulance service and that the contract between the Air Ambulance Service HF and Babcock Scandinavian AirAmbulance is terminated due to the company's inability to provide air ambulance readiness in accordance with the contract.

Ensure the preparedness of the air ambulance service in accordance with the quality requirements the operator is obligated to deliver under the signed contract, until the state can take over the operation. The government is requested to provide the necessary resources for hiring services from other operators in addition to assistance from the Armed Forces to ensure the service maintains an adequate level of preparedness.

Ensure air ambulance preparedness across the country, with necessary short- and long-term measures to create stability and predictability in the service. The five ambulance planes belonging to the previous operator must, if necessary, be deployed in service along with the military's helicopter as an immediate measure.

To conduct an external independent investigation of the entire process regarding the air ambulance tender and the operator change. In particular, the investigation must examine the risk that Babcock Scandinavian AirAmbulance would not be able to provide the necessary preparedness in accordance with the contract.

Propose the necessary funds in the revised state budget for 2020 so that the new Kirkenes hospital can be completed, and ensure that Helse Nord HF guarantees that Kirkenes hospital has intensive care preparedness at level 2.

Conduct a comprehensive investigation of the preparedness across Northern Norway, particularly in Finnmark, and implement all necessary measures to ensure safe emergency services for the population. The delivery to Babcock should be a central part of the investigation.
Ensure that the five ambulance aircraft belonging to the former operator are put into service.
Implement measures to reduce violations of the Working Environment Act in hospitals, and report back to the Parliament on which measures have been implemented and the effects of these.
Ensure proper reporting of violations of the Working Environment Act in hospitals.

Ensure the continued operation and follow-up of the Center for Dignity, which offers further education for healthcare personnel in emergency medical care for the elderly, palliative elderly care, and volunteer coordination to ensure ongoing competence in this area.

Present an investment plan for the Parliament that highlights the planned investments in hospital construction in Health South-East and ensures that the hospital development in Oslo does not come at the expense of necessary hospital buildings within Health South-East or in the rest of the country.

Conduct a comprehensive investigation into the preservation of Ullevål Hospital, so that the decision regarding the future hospital being located at Ullevål or Gaustad is well-founded and sufficiently researched.

Reverse the decision made at the corporate meeting of Helse Sør-Øst RHF on June 24, 2016, and through a new corporate meeting ensure that the hospital expansion in Oslo is planned based on the following hospital structure: - Radiumhospitalet is maintained as a specialized cancer hospital. - Ullevål Hospital is expanded as a large acute hospital with a trauma center. - Aker Hospital becomes the new local hospital for the entire Groruddalen. - Rikshospitalet is maintained unchanged for national and regional functions. - In later phases, the functions of Rikshospitalet will be consolidated at Ullevål.

Investigate a new scrapping scheme for shipping with the aim of reducing greenhouse gas emissions as much as possible. The scheme should not require the purchase of a new ship, and a differentiated subsidy should be considered based on the ship's scrap value and whether the scrapping takes place in Norway. The new scheme should be implemented from January 1, 2021.

Set requirements for offshore supply vessels regarding zero or low-emission solutions from 2025 and zero emissions from 2030. It should be required that the first hydrogen-powered vessel in the supply fleet is put into operation no later than 2022.
Ensure that all unallocated funds under Innovation Norway's schemes in 2019 are redirected from petroleum to other industries.
Set guidelines for the export credit scheme, so that support for projects in renewable energy and other industries is prioritized over support for oil and gas projects.

Establish a public committee to assess the consequences of the introduction and use of new genetic technology methods in connection with food production. The committee must be broadly composed to ensure that as many perspectives as possible are highlighted, existing knowledge is discussed, and the need for new knowledge is mapped out.
Enter into a binding agreement with the aquaculture industry for a minimum 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions from the industry by 2030.

Engage in dialogue with the fishing industry to clarify further guidelines for the compensation scheme for CO2 tax in fisheries, and ensure that the structure of the scheme provides predictability and does not violate the assumptions that were established. The scheme must not hinder the landing of fish along the coast for processing.
Stop the land consolidation sale of Statskog.
Present a case to the Storting regarding the introduction of emergency storage of food grains in Norway.
Reintroduce the condemnation scheme for older ships in Norwegian waters – with requirements for the vessel's climate and environmental profile.

Promote proposals for amendments to the property tax law that exempt all owners of buildings that are either protected under the Cultural Heritage Act or designated for preservation under the Planning and Building Act from municipal property tax.

Investigate and propose alternative models for tax and fee reductions that can contribute to consistent and good maintenance of buildings that are either protected under the Cultural Heritage Act or designated for preservation under the Planning and Building Act.
Create a plan for how all counties/regions can have their own building preservation center under the auspices of local museums and/or volunteer cultural heritage organizations.
Initiate a government preservation program for medieval stone churches aimed at restoring all Norwegian medieval churches by 2030, the 1000th anniversary of the Battle of Stiklestad.
Initiate a government conservation program for the protected wooden churches built before 1650 that are not included in the stave church program.
Initiate a government conservation program for historically significant churches built between 1650 and 1850.
Come back with a proposal for a scaling-up plan for the Norwegian Cultural Heritage Fund, so that the fund eventually has 300 million kroner available for distribution annually.

Ensure that the Norwegian Cultural Heritage Fund establishes a dedicated program for climate measures in heritage buildings from before 1950, and request that the government, in the revised budget for 2020, returns to the Storting with a proposal for funding for the project.
Consider the one-time benefit in terms of the risk of women being "locked" into a poverty trap, and its relationship to the work-oriented approach.
Consider a division of the disbursement of the one-time grant.

To amend the regulation on the state's grants and guaranteed incomes for artists, so that work grants, long-term grants, and guaranteed incomes are at a minimum adjusted with an index equal to the framework for wage negotiations in the state.
Transform the incentive scheme for international film and TV productions into a rule-based system and place it under the Ministry of Trade and Fisheries.
Develop a set of criteria for applying for funds from chapter 315 item 86, so that this becomes an open and searchable scheme in the future.
Present a case on how economic policy can help strengthen economic equality between women and men.
To restore the previous allocation for volunteer centers in the Ministry of Culture's budget.
To make the arrangement for value-added tax compensation for the construction of sports facilities rule-based.
Investigate and promote an application-based fund for operational and long-term support for the established performing arts companies under the Norwegian Arts Council, outside the cultural fund.
Start the work to implement the EU Copyright Directive ((EU) 2019/790).
Present a parliamentary report on film distribution.
Come back to the Storting with proposals for any changes to the advertising rules for local radio on FM.
Reassess the content of request resolution no. 694 (2017–2018) in connection with the ongoing legislative work, to ensure a responsible, comprehensive, and consistent gambling policy.

Implement an immediate halt to all forced returns of asylum seekers to Afghanistan until the Parliament has reviewed and made a decision regarding amendments to the Immigration Act (introduction of a reasonableness requirement for internal flight).
Establish an expert committee to ensure greater transparency and verifiability in decisions regarding changes to security assessments of return countries in the immigration administration.
Give the Supervisory Council for Trandum its own budget and necessary secretarial function, independent of the Police Immigration Unit.

Establish an independent external review group to assess the relevant forced return, including the medical and child welfare assessments that were made before and during the implementation of the forced return.
Halt all further planning of ferry-free alternatives for crossing the Bjørnafjord in the Ferry-Free E39 project.
