Start the work of establishing the national TT scheme as a legal right and that the scheme is placed under Nav.
Establish a new high-speed rail investigation with the premise that high-speed railways should be a multi-use concept for freight and passenger transport, and that considers a varied stop pattern.
That the concept choice report for transport in Northern Norway exclusively addresses the Nord-Norge Line and not comprehensive transport solutions.

Consider possible solutions such as toll caps or hourly regulations in coordination with other toll projects in the Kristiansand area/Vest-Agder, for commercial transport that faces an unreasonably high toll fee burden.
Investigate possible compensation schemes for the passenger tax on flights in the short-haul network.
Develop a plan for universal design of all Norwegian train stations by 2025.
Ensure that the cost reductions related to the PPP project rv. 3/rv. 25 Ommangsvollen–Grundset/Basthjørnet in Hedmark are partially used to reduce the toll fees for the project.

Prepare and return to the Parliament with a proposal to introduce a specific action plan to map, prevent, and address Islamophobia and anti-Muslim attitudes. The plan must include prioritized, concrete, measurable, and new measures with funding to finance the work, inspired by the action plan against anti-Semitism.
Promote proposals to include asexuality, BDSM, and fetishism in the Equality and Anti-Discrimination Act.

Review the basic and further education for teachers and child welfare educators with the aim of including the topics of norm criticism, minority stress, sexual health, and gender and sexuality diversity as a mandatory part of the public education offerings.
Include competence goals on norm criticism, minority stress, sexual health, and gender, relationship, and sexuality diversity where relevant, especially in the subject of KRLE.
Include competence goals regarding what constitutes positive sexual relationships, setting boundaries, prevention of rape, and acceptance and understanding of sexual minorities.

Come back to the Parliament with an action plan for a competence boost on transgender issues, sexual minorities, and relational minorities in the school system, school health services, child and adolescent psychiatric outpatient clinics, healthcare, the police, the Directorate of Immigration, and child welfare services.

Gather knowledge about living conditions and mental health for asexuals, aromantics, BDSM practitioners/fetishists, relationship minorities, non-binary individuals, and transgender people in Norway, and propose measures to reduce the challenges faced by these groups.
Promote a proposal to introduce a third legal gender category.
Develop necessary proposals for amendments to the Penal Code that strengthen the legal protection of transgender individuals.
Promote proposals for necessary legislative changes to make gender-neutral toilets and changing rooms available in all new school buildings and public institutions.

Promote a proposal to prohibit so-called gender-normalizing cosmetic procedures (that are not medically necessary) from being performed before the child is able to consent. The Parliament requests the government to strengthen the police's resources in the fight against hate crime. The Parliament requests the government to increase funding for LGBTQI work through organizations in the field, the "LGBTQI fund," in future budget proposals. The Parliament requests the government to ensure that all municipalities establish concrete LGBTQI action plans. The Parliament requests the government to initiate a study on the introduction of a third gender category in Norway.

Promote a proposal to ban conversion therapy. The Parliament requests the government to strengthen the regional professional environments' expertise on gender dysphoria and ensure measures for better access to treatment options for this patient group. The Parliament asks the government to enhance the work with Rosa competence in the workplace, healthcare, schools, kindergartens, the police, and asylum reception centers, and to ensure that it is done systematically and nationwide. The Parliament requests the government to secure the continued operation of Skeivt Arkiv in Bergen in future proposals for the state budget. The Parliament asks the government to ensure the continued operation of the magazine Blikk and the opportunity for further dissemination through school libraries.
Inform each individual Norwegian citizen concerned that their personal data related to air travel has been unlawfully identified by the PST.
Ensure that those potentially affected by the Nav scandal are offered free assistance from an independent lawyer before any further processing of their cases in Nav.
Ensure the development of police resources and expertise on honor-based violence so that this serious form of crime can be better identified and combat.
Ensure that each individual prison has an offer for a substance abuse treatment unit.
Allocate sufficient funds for the police districts' investigation of domestic violence and rape.

Expand the mandate of the legal aid committee, in light of the Nav scandal, with the aim of strengthening the legal aid system, as well as ensuring that the lack of legal security and incorrect application of the law in the welfare system, which has been revealed by the Nav scandal, is addressed with proposals for legal aid measures that can help prevent this from happening again.
Come back to the Storting with an assessment of whether the police education in Kongsvinger should be reinstated.
Ensure that Molde courthouse has safe courtrooms.
Facilitate the expansion of Vik and Hustad prisons, as well as the planning of the Sunnmøre Correctional Center and Ilseng prison.

Present an alternative to the current subscription model that ensures that small and medium-sized municipalities are no longer disproportionately disadvantaged financially. State co-financing should be considered.
Consider the arrangement for occupational injury compensation for employees in the correctional services on par with employees in the police force.
Facilitate that duplication is not used in the criminal justice system.

Initiate an economic escalation plan for the correctional services, aimed at providing the necessary resources to the correctional and probation services to effectively implement sentences that have an impact on inmates across the country. The escalation plan should be developed in close collaboration with employee organizations, relevant professional environments, and relevant voluntary organizations associated with the correctional services. The escalation plan must include concrete and binding measures in the following areas: A specific, comprehensive, and future-oriented plan for the further development of all aspects of the correctional services. New methods in criminal procedure. Analysis and assessment of the future need for various forms of sentence execution, including so-called open and closed placements, probation services, and alternative forms of serving sentences such as electronic monitoring. Measures to strengthen the content of the sentence so that it has an effect, including an assessment of welfare services for inmates, the principles of proximity and normality, collaboration with victims and relatives, living conditions for inmates, educational offerings, and program activities, so that convicted individuals can return to society as good neighbors after serving their sentences. A particular focus on female offenders serving time in prison. A particular focus on young offenders and youth units. Measures that reduce the use of isolation.
Ensure that if children are sentenced to serve their time in prison, this should take place in specialized youth units within the correctional system.
Facilitate the maintenance of the current number of student places at the Police University College.
Recognize Palestine as an independent state.
Ensure that agreements on the return of individuals without legal residence in Norway are not used as a condition for receiving assistance from Norway.

Ensure that organizations that have expressed support for the BDS campaign (boycott, divestment, and sanctions) against Israel's violations of international law are not excluded from development support programs in Palestine.
Cancel the planned order of six new fighter jets.

Postpone the implementation of the restructuring of the 2nd Battalion in the Brigade in Northern Norway from a conscription-based battalion to a mobilization battalion by one year, from 2021 to 2022, thereby maintaining the same level of establishment that the 2nd Battalion currently has.
Initiate the work on a public evaluation of integrated strategic management within the defense sector.
Introduce an instruction that ensures the committee has access to the information that employees in the civil service and underlying agencies may have.
Promote a proposal for a progressive inheritance tax with a basic deduction of 5 million kroner and a lowest rate of 10%, gradually increasing to a 50% tax on inheritances over 100 million kroner.
Investigate the possibility of converting all or parts of the Skattefunn scheme into an Environmental Fund scheme.
Promote a proposal to change the basic fee on beverage packaging for plastic bottles to an environmental tax on material use, graded according to the amount of recycled or renewable material.

Investigate how a progressive inheritance tax with a high exemption threshold can be designed. The results of the investigation should be presented along with the proposal for the state budget for 2021.

Promote a proposal that it should be mandatory to report inheritance settlements to the tax authorities, so that the collection and publication of statistics on received inheritances can be reintroduced as it was done until 2014.
Investigate a fee for the use of peat where the costs for the climate are made visible.
Investigate how the tax-free scheme can be abolished while still taking into account the interests of regional airports.

Make a new assessment of the regulations for taxation and reporting of non-cash benefits and return to the Parliament with a new proposal that takes into account the need for broad tax bases, reduced bureaucracy, and simplification of reporting.
Come back to the Parliament in connection with the revised national budget 2020 with a proposal to reintroduce tax exemption for reasonable employee discounts.
Reduce the capitalization rate in property tax for hydropower plants from 4.5% to 3% effective from 2020 until a new calculation system for this rate is in place.

Come back to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2021 with a predictable calculation system for the capitalization rate in property tax for hydropower plants, which takes into account market interest rates and ensures that the rate under current conditions will be lower than the existing rate.
Come back to the Parliament in connection with the revised national budget 2020 with a proposal to abolish the maximum and minimum rules for property tax on power plants.

Evaluate the increased depreciation rate for electric vehicles and consider higher depreciation rates for low- and zero-emission vessels in coastal shipping, as well as investigate how this can be implemented in practice.
Ensure that tax exemption for benefits that are retained by retirees, such as free travel cards from train and bus companies, can be reintroduced.
Investigate changes to the Value Added Tax Act that ensure healthcare professionals must include value added tax if they provide alternative treatment.

Investigate whether any of the members in the organizations currently registered in the register for alternative practitioners can be considered to provide health care, and return to the Parliament with a legislative proposal that allows them to be exempt from the Value Added Tax Act.

Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner, no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2020, to investigate and present measures for a revenue-neutral restructuring of the financial tax, where the increased employer's contribution is removed.

Come back with an assessment of the tax burden for companies with quota-restricted emissions that are subject to a reduced rate for CO2 tax on natural gas and possible measures to improve their framework conditions.
Come back with an assessment of the tax burden for non-ETS industries with power needs under 20 MW and possible measures to improve their framework conditions.
Continue the previous practice of tax exemption for benefits in kind that one has received as a pensioner or as a family member of a former employee.

Make a new assessment of the transfer of tax collection from the municipalities to the Tax Administration, and return to the Parliament with a new proposal no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2020 that safeguards local expertise, the revenue from tax collection, and strengthens the work against labor market crime.

Come back to the Parliament with a report on the EEA legal framework regarding the taxation of individuals residing in another EEA state, who receive income from work, pensions, disability benefits, or business activities in Norway.

Consider how to ensure equal treatment of publicly listed and non-publicly listed companies in wealth tax, i.e., that their valuation does not systematically favor non-publicly listed companies as it does in the current system.

Conduct a comprehensive evaluation of the system for new methods, and based on the evaluation, present a separate case to the Parliament with proposals for changes to the system. The evaluation must, among other things, highlight how the system can ensure legitimacy, openness, and transparency, how the system can allow for appeals against errors in the Decision Forum's case processing, how the system can be better adapted to methods that are not pharmaceuticals, how the system can be better suited to implement personalized medicine, and possible exceptions that ensure an individual assessment for patients who differ significantly from the majority in the patient group.

To - in line with the prioritization message and the adopted goals for pharmaceutical policy, as well as the premises in Prop. 55 L (2018-2019) - ensure an evaluation of the current organization and processing in the system for new methods, with the aim of further developing a system for equitable and rapid introduction of new methods in specialist health services.
Present a plan to the Storting for the escalation of safe food production based on Norwegian resources.

Present to the Storting a thorough risk and vulnerability analysis of Norwegian supply security that addresses the recognition that the global food market may be affected by a more unpredictable geopolitical development and by climate change.
Work to increase the self-sufficiency rate, adjusted for feed imports, for Norwegian agricultural food products to 50% by the end of 2026.
Ensure competency goals that guarantee students learn about and reflect on different sexual orientations and variations in gender identity and gender expression.
Incorporate the interdisciplinary theme of "sustainable development" into the curricula for English and Mathematics, in line with the curriculum group's proposal.
Ensure that competence goals that contribute to increased knowledge about organized working life are included in relevant curricula.

Establish a public committee to examine the entire preparedness situation regarding the increasing cruise traffic in Norwegian waters. The goal of the investigation should be to map out the preparedness challenges in light of the growing cruise tourism and to explore possible models for how cruise lines can contribute financially to the development of standing preparedness in Norway (and whether the industry can contribute to covering the costs of incidents, accidents, and disasters through funds, insurance, or other means).

Establish a public committee to review the preparedness situation for increasing cruise traffic in Norwegian waters. The aim of the investigation should be to identify any weaknesses in the current arrangement as well as to propose measures to improve preparedness in light of the increasing cruise tourism that may occur in Norwegian waters.
Use the same estimates for price and wage growth for the Sámi Parliament as for the rest of the administration.
Impose stricter requirements and ensure, through proposals for appropriations, sufficient climate and environmental expertise in the municipalities.

Require municipalities to prepare land accounts that provide an overview of land use changes, the need for mapping, the status of ecological conditions, the need for restoration, and trends in biodiversity within the municipalities.
Require that all municipalities develop a municipal sub-plan for biodiversity and map and assess their outdoor recreation areas.

Withdraw the tightening of the objection institution that has occurred through steering signals as pointed out in the National Audit Office's report Document 3:7 (2018–2019) Investigation of the handling of objections in planning cases.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to amend the legislation so that the department is legally obligated in its written justifications for objection decisions to specify how the consideration for local self-government is weighed in relation to natural values, agricultural land protection, and climate emissions.
Accelerate the work on developing a methodology for assessing what constitutes "the overall burden" under the Nature Diversity Act § 10.
Promote a proposal for a tax shift with increased taxation on property and reduced income tax.
Develop a national housing plan for residential development across the country in the long term, which includes a plan for the role of the Housing Bank in ensuring a fairer housing market.

Investigate models for municipal property tax based on the property's assessed value, with mandatory exemptions and/or potential shielding arrangements such as deferred tax upon transfer of ownership.

Investigate the possibility of differentiating between taxation of primary residences and secondary residences, where a higher property tax is introduced for secondary residences compared to primary residences.

Investigate how social infrastructure can become part of development agreements, and expand development agreements so that the planning authority can impose requirements for financing and costs for the completed housing.
Present a proposal for a law on non-commercial housing organizations – community housing – based on the Danish law on public housing.
Promote a proposal to amend the Planning and Building Act so that the planning authority can require a proportion of affordable and social housing in all new projects to be built.

Ensure a study on how the adaptation of regulations and any support schemes for housing construction can promote housing development throughout the country. The study should address the following: Special solutions for housing construction in rural areas and areas where construction costs may exceed the mortgage value of the property. Special solutions for housing construction in high-demand areas. Possible measures to ensure housing for those in long-term difficult situations and for individuals with special needs. Possible measures to ensure that first-time buyers and single individuals have the opportunity to purchase a home. An assessment of non-profit housing organizations, community housing, based on the Danish law on public housing. Evaluations of the challenges and benefits of the model, measures to prevent area-related issues, as well as what tools and legal changes are needed to establish the model. The role of the Housing Bank and the alignment of its measures.
That the quotas that are converted and deposited into a separate, closed account should not be used for domestic emission reductions in the non-ETS sector.

Come to the Storting with a proposal for a business fund for the municipalities affected by the Johan Castberg development. The proposal for the business fund should be presented no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2020.
Demand that oil from the Johan Castberg field be landed in Finnmark to trigger local ripple effects.
Set requirements for Equinor regarding the use of local suppliers in connection with the development and operation of the Johan Castberg field.
Use saved EEA funds from chapter 117 EEA financing schemes items 77 and 78 for humanitarian aid in refugee camps on the Greek islands and other urgent situations.
Conduct a review of the condition of the road surface on the national road network, and in this context, consider increased funding for the maintenance of road surfaces.
Require Telenor to maintain and preserve the copper network until an impact assessment has been conducted.
Investigate the significance of both national and state ownership of the infrastructure for digital electronic communication in Norway.
Investigate how the state's ownership in Telenor can best contribute to achieving Norway's security and preparedness policy goals.
Conduct a consequence assessment of the phase-out of the copper network.
Require Telenor to maintain and uphold the copper network everywhere until a suitable alternative is in place.

1. To require the police to log all checks for this purpose. The statistics must be made publicly available and searchable so that others outside the police can also verify this. Such statistics should at least include age, nationality, and, if possible, any remarks related to the check. 2. To require the police to implement a pilot project where individuals who are checked in connection with an extended knife ban receive a receipt indicating that they have been checked.
Develop a binding action plan against knife violence in broad collaboration with all stakeholders who can contribute.

Ensure that the action plan against knife violence includes better enforcement of the ban on carrying knives in public places, the use of punitive measures, an expansion of the list of prohibited items in the weapons regulations, reduced availability of dangerous knives, a specific statistic for knife stabbings and threats with knives, collaboration with schools, and preventive services for children and young people, among other things.
Present the action plan against knife violence by the summer of 2020.

Consider how the customs authorities can obtain better legal grounds to confiscate knives that appear to be products of violence, including whether a requirement for a permit from the police or an age limit for the importation of certain types of knives can be introduced, and whether provisions can be established that result in import bans for individuals who repeatedly violate the weapons law.
Promote a proposal to ban the marketing of knives as self-defense products.
Reintroduce the registration of bodily injuries resulting from knife attacks and threats with a knife in the STRASAK report.

Establish a public committee to investigate the frameworks for public debate online and in social media, particularly considering where the boundaries should be set for anonymous participation in public debate, and how to better hold facilitators of public debate accountable. The committee should examine the legal developments in other countries and assess whether these have transferable value to Norway. In addition to the above, the committee shall have a mandate that includes the following points: Ensure follow-up on decision no. 698 (2017–2018), where the government is asked to propose an extension of the Penal Code's provisions on hate speech, hate crime, and discrimination so that they also encompass hate speech made, or discrimination exercised, based on a person's gender expression or gender identity. Assess the relationship between gender, gender identity, and gender expression as grounds for discrimination in the Penal Code § 185 and the Gender Equality and Anti-Discrimination Act § 39. Consider measures to strengthen the content and marketing of the police's reporting service for hate speech online and evaluate to what extent tips should be followed up by Kripos. Develop a clear mandate for the police, police districts, and state prosecutors to prioritize work against hate speech, and review what resources and expertise are necessary to prevent and stop hate speech online as well. Review the police's ability to streamline the national registration of reports of hate crime and hate speech and systematize ongoing data collection on such crimes, and ensure that the recommendations of the UN Human Rights Committee in the concluding remarks on Norway's seventh periodic report are followed up. Identify measures that will increase knowledge about online harassment and hate crime among the police, state prosecutors, and in the courts. Assess the possibilities and what is required to establish a pilot scheme in the conflict resolution councils, where victims of online harassment should have the opportunity to bring the harasser to mediation in the conflict resolution council, and where the harasser could be required to attend. Facilitate the police's authority to impose fines or other administrative sanctions for online harassment. Investigate how individuals threatened due to their opinions and expressions can be given better protection. Editors and journalists should have special protection. Review how the police can ensure investigations in these cases, and consider a potential need for designated contact persons for this group within the police. Review the training currently provided in online safety and the use of social media in primary schools and assess at what stage of education this should be integrated with a view to further developing curricula in this area. Review research related to online harassment, its extent, the role of technology, and what has so far proven to be effective measures, and provide recommendations for further research in the field.

Come back to the Parliament with an assessment of whether it would be appropriate and proportionate to grant the police the authority to impose fines or other administrative sanctions for online harassment. A weighing of various considerations must be made, including – but not limited to – the right to freedom of expression and the presumption of innocence.
Investigate and propose a new tax on inheritance of large fortunes.
Prepare the recognition of Palestine as an independent state.
Promote a case to the Parliament with proposals that contribute to increasing the level of organization, as an acknowledgment that it is important for many workers to choose to be unionized.
Change the practice in bear management so that the threshold for removing bears that harm livestock and reindeer is lowered.
Consider reducing the population target for the number of bear litters, especially in regions 6 and 7.
To grant municipalities the right to a local veto against onshore wind power development.
Present a message about the tax policy.
Instruct the Police Directorate to halt all downsizing and cuts at police stations until the police reform has been evaluated.
Present a report on Norway's relationship with the EU in the energy sector.
Ensure that none of today's maternity wards or other birthing services are closed down.
Promote the necessary legislative proposals that ensure pensions from the first krone for everyone no later than in connection with the state budget for 2021.

Ensure that individuals on work assessment allowance are given the necessary time for clarification regarding work or benefits, without losing their support before they are fully clarified, through a flexible and individually tailored application of the provisions regarding exceptions to the general time limit.
Maintain the shielding supplement for disability pensioners born in 1954 or later.

To present a proposal for funding to the county municipalities to reduce ferry fares and ensure the transition to low-/zero-emission ferries in a way that does not burden ordinary travelers' expenses.
Investigate with the aim of introducing a guarantee that all students who are qualified will be offered an apprenticeship.
Reverse the cuts in the scheme for support for glasses for children, "Glasses for children/youth under 18 years old."
Present a new comprehensive and binding action plan for the mental health of children and young people.
Ensure that all children undergo a mandatory test of Norwegian language skills during the four-year check-up.
Ensure that municipalities follow up on children who miss age-specific health checks.
Suggest measures to tighten the use of substitutes in case of absence.
Introduce a specific staffing requirement for kindergartens with particularly long opening hours, for example, opening hours of over 10.5 hours per day.
Review the existing factual basis to assess the overall impact of school tests on students' mental health.
Investigate and implement attractive parenting courses as an offer to all families with children.
Establish a coordination model that offers youth a comprehensive, digital pathway from health-promoting information services with low thresholds to complete digital health care.
Strengthen the funding of the school health service and health stations, including earmarking the funds for the service for the entire school period during a ramp-up phase.

Ensure that low-threshold mental health services are established for children, young people, and families in all municipalities. The measures can be realized through the establishment of Family Houses and/or other easily accessible services. The services must be multidisciplinary and cross-sectoral to ensure that children, young people, and families receive good and comprehensive services.
To prepare a public inquiry on the rights of children and young people as relatives.

Promote a new proposal for a concrete, binding, and comprehensive escalation plan aimed at reducing the incidence of violence in close relationships, as well as strengthening the protection of children exposed to violence and abuse, modeled after the escalation plan for mental health. The plan should ensure a multidisciplinary approach to the measures, good coordination, and a long-term commitment to increased funding and earmarked resources.
Conduct a pilot project where school nurses can refer children and adolescents to Child and Adolescent Psychiatry (BUP).
Propose 80% government funding for crisis center services through earmarked funds.

Promote a proposal to amend § 2 of the crisis center law to introduce a requirement for sufficient proximity to the nearest crisis center service, so that geographical coverage aligns with the fact that crisis center services should be easily accessible, and to regulate this further in regulations.
Promote a proposal to amend § 2 of the crisis center law to introduce a requirement for round-the-clock staffing.

Promote a proposal to introduce a general regulatory authority in the crisis center law and to establish a quality standard through regulation to further regulate a. the implementation of the requirement for physical separation b. requirements for competence, including child-related expertise c. that the length of stay at the crisis centers must be adapted to the time it takes to provide support and necessary assistance for the victim's re-establishment d. the content of the follow-up during the re-establishment phase.
Conduct an evaluation of the crisis center services for men and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Ensure that the crisis center services for the Sami indigenous population are improved, and inform the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Come back to the Parliament with a comprehensive review of the crisis center services.
Ensure that the regional health authorities provide accompaniment services to all birthing individuals who have more than 60 minutes of travel time from their residence to the place of birth.
Promote a proposal to legislate the obligation of health enterprises to offer accompaniment services for birthing individuals.

Ensure to meet the requirement for escort services when the travel time is more than 90 minutes from the place of residence to the place of birth, and further, promptly investigate the introduction of a 60-minute requirement.
Ensure that the maternity follow-up service becomes part of the legally mandated cooperation agreements between municipalities and health enterprises, cf. the Health and Care Services Act § 6-2.

To prioritize more funding for climate cuts in municipalities by emphasizing the municipalities' ambitions and potential for climate cuts in the distribution of revenues and block grants among the municipalities.
Work to promote the announced parliamentary report on the follow-up of Climate Plan 2030 before Easter, so that the Parliament has a reasonable opportunity to address it before the summer.
Investigate a climate reward scheme for businesses. The revenues from the CO2 tax can go to a climate fund and climate consulting for companies.

Come back to the Parliament with a plan for the implementation of measures and initiatives for local climate work and real emission reductions in the municipalities. The plan will be developed in collaboration between the state and the municipal sector.
Investigate a climate reward scheme for businesses.

Map the extent of unreasonable compensation outcomes for the phasing out of fur farming in individual cases in connection with the revised national budget 2020 and allocate funds to address this starting from the revised national budget 2020. It should be ensured that no fur farmers are left with debt related to the facility after the closure.

To change the compensation scheme for fur farmers who kept fur animals on January 15, 2018, and who are affected by the decision of the Storting on June 13, 2019, regarding the ban on keeping fur animals, so that compensation is provided as if it were an expropriation-like intervention.
To replace the current compensation based on book value and/or the number of breeding sows, with financial compensation to fur breeders based on the valuation of each individual fur farming facility.
To design a framework for the valuation of fur animal facilities based on professional assessments of value that are grounded in expropriation law principles.
To continue the other arrangements related to the phasing out of the fur farming industry as established in the current regulations.
Establish flexibility within the compensation scheme so that full or partial payments can occur simultaneously with the potential start of other production/business activities.
Promote a proposal for a ban on the hiring of labor from companies that are not production companies.

Return to the Parliament with immediate measures to ban all hiring from staffing agencies in the construction industry in the Oslofjord area and other pressured areas and industries where the use of staffing agencies is extensive.
Make the necessary regulatory changes and present proposals for the necessary appropriations to strengthen employment services as a public task.
Map the extent of hiring across industries throughout the country and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Promote proposals that limit hiring under § 14-12 first paragraph to only cover pure temporary positions, cf. the Working Environment Act § 14-9 second paragraph letter b.
Return to the Parliament with measures to counteract companies that use staffing agencies to circumvent the requirement of a maximum of two subcontractors in public contracts.
Return to the Storting with measures to exclude actors who have repeatedly violated the hiring regulations from future public contracts.

Ensure that the structure of the large carnivore committees remains unchanged, and that the proposal to transfer the final decision-making authority in appeals cases related to large carnivores to an independent national appeals board is set aside.
Use high inbreeding levels as an independent criterion for the selection of wolves, and significantly tighten the access to shield wolves from management due to "genetic importance."
Consider the possibility of changes to the large carnivore regulation regarding regular quota hunting of wolves when the population target has been reached and the population is viable.
Change the population target for wolves so that individual wolves, pairs, and family groups that have not bred are included, so that the overall predation pressure is reflected and a limit is set.

Ensure to investigate a system for the administration to monitor the development in all established wolf territories, as well as the societal consequences of these, so that all necessary documentation is available as a basis for the decisions of the large carnivore committees.
Set a deadline for when the department's complaint processing should be completed, so that the complaint processing is finished at least one month before the start of the hunting season.

Follow up on the decisions made by the large carnivore committees to grant licensed hunting of the wolves in the territories of Mangen and Rømskog, so that the hunting can take place during the current licensed hunting period. The licensed hunting period will be extended if necessary, so that the mentioned wolf packs can be removed.

Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner with a review of how Norwegian development and aid policy can best be effective and function in the changed global landscape, also as a tool for influence in multilateral organizations and in relation to private investments.
Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner with an updated definition of the term "Norwegian interests" in foreign policy.
Ensure that NBTS at the National Hospital does not have a monopoly on the treatment of individuals with gender incongruence.
Ensure that a new regional investigation team is developed in collaboration with other professional environments with expertise in gender dysphoria/gender incongruence, independent of NBTS.
Ensure that patients with gender incongruence are guaranteed the right to a new assessment by an independent body, in accordance with the Patient and User Rights Act.
Investigate measures to reduce waiting times in public hospitals and in municipalities for treatment options for individuals with gender incongruence.
Consider a Scandinavian collaboration for the coordination of surgical services for genital surgery, with the aim of ensuring good quality through a larger treatment volume.

Ensure that the treatment options for individuals with gender incongruence are made more accessible and decentralized to relevant professional environments, and that hormonal treatment and breast surgery are offered in more locations.
Initiate a long-term study to investigate and provide recommendations for evidence-based and effective treatment for individuals who identify as non-binary.

Conduct a living conditions and quality of life survey for individuals with gender incongruence who have been treated, are undergoing treatment, are under assessment, or have been denied treatment. The Parliament requests the government to propose measures to improve living conditions and quality of life for these groups.
Follow up on the National Health and Hospital Plan (Report St. 11 (2015–2016)) and increase bed capacity at Norwegian hospitals to meet the needs of elderly patients.

Conduct an evaluation of the discharge practices in public hospitals following the implementation of the coordination reform, promote concrete measures to ensure that all patients have safe discharges and dignified transport from hospitals, and inform the Parliament in an appropriate manner and no later than in the state budget for 2021.
Ensure that night transports do not occur unless the patient requests it themselves, or there are very special circumstances that justify it.
Ensure that patients, relatives, and municipal health services are given genuine participation in the discharge of patients from the hospital.

Ensure that the health enterprises follow up on the specialist health service's requirements to appoint a coordinator and offer an individual plan to all patients in need of long-term and coordinated services.

Ensure financial frameworks that guarantee a real strengthening of the care allowance scheme in the municipalities, and introduce national guidelines for the allocation and assessment of care allowances.

Ensure that all home-dwelling users/patients with special care needs and their relatives are offered a collaboration agreement that can provide a predictable partnership and dialogue with the healthcare service, which addresses the relatives' needs for and rights to respite, training, days off, guidance, and measures to safeguard their own health, and similar.
Ensure a national escalation plan for the development of day activity places and short-term stays, also to provide relief and security for the relatives.

Promote a case to the Parliament regarding improving the leave options for caregivers in the workforce to ensure equality and the ability to combine work and caregiving, cf. the Kaasa Committee's proposals.

Present a case to the Storting where a requirement is introduced for the aquaculture industry to replace the soy proteins currently used in feed with sustainable feed by 2028. The case should include a clear definition of sustainability that ensures the sustainable feed has a significantly lower environmental footprint than today's soybeans.

Promote a case for the introduction of a mandatory sales requirement for sustainable fish feed in the aquaculture industry, starting low, with a phased plan that gradually increases to 100% sustainable feed by 2035. The case should include a clear definition of sustainability that ensures the sustainable feed has a significantly lower environmental footprint than current soybeans.
Introduce a requirement that by 2020, all farmed salmon must be double-tagged in a way that allows escaped fish to be easily identified and traced.
Present a parliamentary report on framework conditions and sustainability in the aquaculture industry.
Investigate and establish a registration system for all entities involved in the breeding of dogs, cats, and rabbits for commercial purposes.

Ensure that all relevant health data about dogs, cats, and rabbits from veterinary visits is recorded in a database, that the data benefits the animals in breeding, and that the Food Safety Authority utilizes the database in its supervision.
Ensure that pedigrees are established for purebred and mixed-breed dogs for use in dog breeding.
Promote proposals for regulating dog breeding that ensures animal welfare by requiring certification for breeders with two or more litters per year.

Develop the market opportunities that mountain farming has by utilizing grass, outfield, and grazing resources, as well as through agricultural and nature-based experiences, by facilitating the establishment of a national center for mountain farming.
Ensure the further development of the Løken research station in Valdres for research and development in mountain agriculture.
Come to the Parliament with an assessment of the findings from the external investigation of the Norwegian Food Safety Authority and a plan for how these findings are intended to be followed up.

Investigate the possibility that origin guarantees can only be sold from new renewable energy production, and only for a limited period after production starts, for example until the power plants are depreciated.

Return to the Parliament within the first half of 2020 with the announced case that follows up on how changes can make the system for renewable energy with guarantees of origin and product declaration for electricity function better than today.

Initiate an investigation into how the system of origin guarantees has functioned in accordance with the purpose for its establishment, and what concrete results have been achieved for increased production of renewable energy.
Ensure that Statnett's tariff model is designed so that the industry's cost share objectively and reliably reflects the costs it actually imposes on the grid.

Investigate and present to the Storting a model that provides an equal tariff level for large consumers with high usage time, regardless of whether electricity is sourced from the regional or transmission grid.
Ensure that Statnett withdraws from the Association of Issuing Bodies (AIB).

Ensure that origin guarantees do not have any impact on energy consumers' climate reporting. Electricity consumption in Norway, regardless of origin guarantees, must be able to be documented as renewable.

Ensure that NVE updates its origin guarantee pages to include a pie chart with physical power consumption and to clearly describe the difference between Norwegian power consumption based on origin guarantees and actual physical consumption, as well as to present CO2 intensity per power supply source, not an overall CO2 intensity for the residual mix.
Ensure a clear geographical differentiation between predators and grazing animals.
Follow up on the wildlife agreement's point that the realization of population levels for bears should not require land beyond the current breeding areas.
Follow up on the wildlife agreement's point that there should be no predators that represent a damage potential in prioritized grazing areas or calving areas for reindeer.

To ensure that the bear population, including female bears, is managed based on the dual objectives, so that the distinction and management between predator-prioritized areas and grazing-prioritized areas remains unchanged from the decisions in the predator agreement.
Ensure that individuals over 70 years old have the right to sick pay.

Extend the maximum layoff period from 26 to 52 weeks. Layoff days and unemployment benefits used before the corona crisis should not be deducted from the rights that employees are entitled to during the crisis.

Give students the right to unemployment benefits, or otherwise ensure that students receive a corresponding compensation similar to unemployment benefit payments, as unemployment benefits are calculated for other employees. This is a temporary arrangement until further notice. The change takes effect immediately, and payments will be made as soon as a technical solution is in place.
Implement necessary measures to ensure that banks and other credit institutions grant periods of repayment relief on their loans to all who need it.
Impose on the banks that have now had their capital buffer requirements reduced, not to distribute dividends for the time being.
Provide additional grants to all students equivalent to the extra grant that is normally intended for students who cannot work alongside their education due to reduced functional ability.
Ensure that the public's own debt collectors stop forced collections, freeze late payment interest, put claims on hold, and implement other similar measures while the crisis is ongoing.
Ensure that private debt collection agencies stop forced collections, freeze late payment interest, put claims on hold, and implement other similar measures while the crisis is ongoing.
Ensure equal coverage for all who receive unemployment benefits, whether they are laid off or unemployed.

Enter into an agreement with business organizations regarding a crisis package for the business sector, which includes an absolute requirement for zero dividends until further notice for companies receiving state guarantees for loans, offers of state bond financing, or liquidity relief under state loan schemes during the loan term.
Exempt airlines from all airport fees from January 1, 2020, and until further notice, and that the government proposes necessary compensation for Avinor in the revised national budget for 2020.

Clarify that the compensation scheme includes all businesses, including subcontractors, that are losing income due to government mandates, and request that the government ensure in an appropriate manner that actual losses are covered for cultural actors if the extraordinary situation related to the coronavirus persists.
Ensure national and distributed ownership through loan and support schemes.
Expand the growth guarantee scheme by having the state cover a sufficiently large share of the banks' risk for liquidity loans to small and medium-sized enterprises.
Secure guarantee schemes for extended credit for businesses in the travel industry.
Facilitate a temporary freeze on all loans from Innovation Norway. This means that companies should be able to receive a payment holiday on their loans without incurring interest and costs for this.

Ensure that the loan and grant frameworks in Innovation Norway are strengthened, and that they can contribute more significantly to meeting companies' needs for improved liquidity through risk loans and enhanced grant schemes, based on the current situation. This should, to the greatest extent possible, be done in collaboration with banks/financial institutions.

To promote proposals where companies receiving government guarantees for loans, offers of government bond financing, or liquidity relief under government loan schemes are required to commit to setting a maximum limit on compensation for employees in group management and other senior executives in 2020 and 2021, for example through a requirement for zero growth.

To promote proposals that set a limit on dividend payments for companies that receive government guarantees for loans, offers of government bond financing, or liquidity relief under government loan schemes during the loan's term.
Facilitate compensation for cultural institutions with more than 50% public funding that have been affected by cancellations due to the coronavirus and health authorities' advice.

Come back to the Parliament as soon as possible with a concrete proposal that self-employed individuals and freelancers should have access to temporary income support through financial social assistance, until a new scheme is in place.

Come back to the Parliament as soon as possible with a compensation scheme for the cultural sector and a scheme for sports and volunteer work. The schemes should be designed as application-based arrangements for compensation for a portion of net lost income in connection with the cancellation of a cultural or sports event, or the postponement of a cultural event, due to government-mandated closure of an event that was planned before the government order. Applicants will need to document their losses, as well as demonstrate that the losses are not covered in any other way. Public entities or companies whose main source of income consists of public operating grants and events with fewer than 50 participants should not be included in the scheme. The government is requested to prepare a regulation with more detailed guidelines for the schemes and how the funds should be distributed.
Come back with a temporary arrangement through the Norwegian State Educational Loan Fund for students experiencing loss of income due to the corona pandemic as soon as possible.
Facilitate the state's entry into ownership in particularly significant Norwegian companies if necessary, in order to ensure national ownership.

Compensate the airlines operating FOT routes for the difference between the loss of revenue and the loss of costs on the FOT routes due to the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as advance payments for subsidies to the FOT routes each month until further notice.

Ensure that the banks promptly reduce the interest rates on loans to individuals and businesses, in a similar magnitude to the extraordinary cuts in the policy rate carried out by Norges Bank and any potential future cuts.
Prohibit the distribution of dividends and bonuses to executives for companies receiving loans under the aviation guarantee scheme.
Ensure the state has the right to a proportional share of the banks' profits from loans that are repaid under the government guarantee scheme.
Open up for companies to receive grants for internal training for employees who are completely laid off.

Come back with an entrepreneurship package in the next proposal presented to the Storting, and that the government consciously adapts the instruments under Innovation Norway, Siva, and Investinor to the current situation.
Require that companies receiving state loan guarantees or state bond financing shall not distribute dividends for the time being.
Ensure that loans provided through the State Bond Fund do not contribute to new investments in fossil energy or infrastructure.
Ensure that loans provided through the State Bond Fund contribute to the green transition, thereby making both our economy and society less dependent on petroleum and better prepared for the future.
Ensure that loans provided with government guarantees do not contribute to new investments in fossil energy or infrastructure.

Ensure that loans provided with a guarantee from the state contribute to the green transition and thereby make both our economy and society less dependent on petroleum and better prepared for the future.
Investigate and propose a digital transport register for all international freight traffic, combined transport, and cabotage trips in Norway.
Ensure that the new electronic waybills planned in the CRM directive are made mandatory.

Promote proposals for necessary regulatory changes that can ensure the ability to impose fines for violations of technical requirements for vehicles and cabotage regulations when the violation is detected.

To use the Tenancy Act § 4-6 to set maximum rates for certain rental agreements at a 50% reduction from the level on March 1, 2020, for rental companies and landlords with more than 2 secondary residences.

To ensure that all municipalities grant deferrals on the payment of municipal fees for those who request it. The state guarantees for lost revenue and ensures liquidity through increased discretionary funds.

To use Section 4-6 of the Tenancy Act to set maximum rates for certain rental agreements at a 50% reduction from the level on March 1, 2020, for businesses covered by the government's crisis packages.
Come back with suggestions that ensure commercial property owners contribute to alleviating the expenses for the businesses involved.

Come back no later than the end of April with a proposal to reinstate the previous exemption for CO2. The Parliament asks the government to return no later than the end of April with a proposal to reinstate the previous exemption from the CO2 tax for non-ETS sectors for electrolysis and metallurgical processes for industry, and to enter into an agreement where the industry agrees to a gradual ramp-up over a four-year period.
Come back, at the latest in the state budget for 2021, with a report and possible financing models that can ensure the development and realization of projects within floating offshore wind.

Present proposals for additional climate measures on the Norwegian continental shelf, no later than the revised national budget for 2020, which also have the potential to create more opportunities for the Norwegian supplier industry.

Ensure that the county governors grant grocery stores and pharmacies exemptions from the main rule of remaining closed on Sundays and public holidays, where municipalities request this to reduce the risk of infection from the coronavirus. This also means that the decision that Oslo will not receive an exemption from the law on holiday peace for grocery stores and pharmacies before the upcoming Easter should be reversed so that those grocery stores and pharmacies that wish to open during Easter can do so.
Do not require parental payment for kindergarten and after-school care services for children with special care needs until June 30, 2020.

Compensate the municipalities for additional expenses related to providing children with special care needs an offer of kindergarten or after-school care during the coronavirus crisis, and return to the Parliament with a proposal for such compensation.
Strengthen efforts to safeguard the interests of vulnerable children during the virus outbreak, ensuring their participation in, among other things, kindergarten and after-school care.
Come back with a proposal on how non-governmental airports can ensure continued operation.
It is stipulated as a condition that landlords grant a certain percentage of reduced rent in order to receive payments from businesses that receive support under the compensation scheme.

It is stipulated as a condition that the disbursed support benefits the affected company and is not transferred to holding companies or otherwise ends up enriching the owner, beyond any regular salary.
Require a special certification from the auditor that the support the companies receive is used according to the purpose of the scheme and as described in the application.

Ensure that a public and searchable database is established, which is continuously updated with information about which companies receive support through the compensation scheme and how much they have received.

It is stipulated as a condition that companies, upon request, can document that they comply with Norwegian and industry-specific standards for health, safety, and working conditions, as well as wages.

Ensure that characteristics of the company applying that indicate unprofessional operations lead to the company being automatically denied approval, for example, if the company has a high number of payment remarks, tax debt, wage debt to employees, claims to the tax collector, or decisions on forced collection.

Ensure that multinational enterprises receiving support must publish country-by-country reports that show their entire corporate structure, including the distribution of income and costs within this structure, including subsidiaries in so-called third-country jurisdictions.
Consider using risk-based sampling controls with audits of companies that have received large sums in compensation.

Create a public and searchable database that includes information related to which companies receive support through the compensation scheme, how much they have received, and the actual owners of the companies.
Ensure that fixed costs to related parties and businesses within the same group are not covered by the temporary compensation scheme for companies in connection with the coronavirus crisis.
It is stipulated as a condition that one commits, through a self-declaration for receiving compensation funds, to not lay off any employees during the period in which one receives compensation funds.

It is stipulated as a condition that one, through a self-declaration for receiving compensation funds, commits to not distributing dividends for the income years 2020 and 2021, unless the dividends are used for investments in one's own business, contributions to socially beneficial purposes, or where dividends are taken out as ordinary salary, meaning not higher than the average for the last two years.

Closely monitor the development of the allocation of compensation and actively use the powers granted in case the compensation scheme results in an disproportionately large share of the support going to rent, and if necessary, use the provisions of the rent law to regulate directly.
Ensure that cash transfers to businesses from the temporary compensation scheme for businesses related to the coronavirus crisis are not taken out of the country.

Ensure that the temporary compensation scheme for businesses in connection with the coronavirus crisis is limited to companies that have parent companies in low-tax countries, as defined by the EU's blacklist and the Tax Administration's list of low-tax countries.
Ensure that a searchable publicly available overview is made available, which at a minimum includes information about which companies have received support and how much each company has received.
It is stipulated as a condition that one commits, through a self-declaration for receiving compensation funds, to not increase executive salaries or board fees beyond the average wage growth.
Remove the deductible of 10,000 kroner for fixed costs in the compensation scheme.

Ensure that the compensation scheme for businesses in connection with the coronavirus crisis benefits the legitimate part of the labor market, among other things by requiring that the companies primarily employ permanent staff and that the companies do not have final decisions or enforceable judgments against them related to, for example, labor market crime, social dumping, and also not for violations of the Immigration Act.

Present an assessment of whether dividends in businesses receiving support for fixed costs can be limited, through a temporary amendment to the Companies Act and the Public Companies Act, where the support amount is deducted before arriving at the final dividend basis, for example, by including "received compensation" in another paragraph, and return to this in a reasonable time before other disbursements of the support.
Consider a compensation scheme better suited to the media's specific income structure and quickly return to the Parliament with proposals on this.
Consider various measures that can help viable businesses continue operations instead of shutting down.

Ensure a tight and well-defined regulatory framework to prevent cash transfers to businesses from the temporary compensation scheme from moving money out of the country in violation of the scheme's intent.
Monitor the situation for startups and growth companies closely, and continuously assess how the various measures affect them.

Consider whether relevant costs in the compensation scheme can be accrued in accordance with the "matching principle" in the Accounting Act § 4-1, so that costs incurred to generate income are attributed to the same period (month) as the income.

Ensure that businesses with extensive economic operations, but which do not have "profit as a purpose" and therefore do not pay taxes, are provided with financial compensation, such as companies for permanently adapted work, foundations, non-profit organizations, and a number of enterprises in areas including culture and museum operations, are taken care of.
Consider how private and non-profit actors providing welfare services can be compensated for the extra costs they have incurred due to the virus outbreak.

Investigate and return to the Storting with a proposal for a reflection of the current cemetery responsibility, so that it is the municipalities that have the responsibility, but have the right to transfer this to the parish.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a change in the law that ensures that the legal marriage must be sanctioned by the public authorities.
Return to the Storting with proposals that uphold the provisions of the Division Act regarding financial settlements in the case of municipal mergers or changes to municipal boundaries.

Investigate whether state grants can be revoked or denied to a specific congregation – regardless of its affiliation with a larger faith or belief community and regardless of whether state funding is sought from the central body of that particular faith or belief community – if/when the congregation violates the conditions for receiving grants.
Investigate and return to the Storting with a separate case regarding sanctioning options related to the reporting obligation.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals to strengthen the legal status of the parish and to continue the legislation of the joint council, including tasks, organization, and financial responsibility for this moving forward.

Strengthen the oversight of faith and belief communities that receive state funding – including inspections and unannounced visits – to ensure that their activities are not in violation of the conditions for state funding.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a clarification of the placement of employer responsibility for locally employed church staff.
Propose a model where faith and belief communities do not receive public funding.
Develop a social contract in collaboration with organizations representing faith and life stance communities.

Promote proposals for conditions under which independent religious or belief communities can come together in an organizational framework and obtain exemption from the membership requirement. This should be formulated in accordance with the government's proposal in the consultation document.
Come back to the Parliament with a separate case regarding the status and evaluation of faith and belief communities after the introduction of new guidelines for receiving state funding.
Require at at least 40% representation of women in governing bodies that manage public funding.

Set requirements for individuals coming to Norway to practice as religious leaders, that they should have or acquire knowledge about the role of religious counseling in dealing with violence in close relationships, experiences of exile, and key values in Norwegian society.
Require that representatives in governing bodies managing state support for faith and life communities are democratically elected.

Promote a case with a proposal for a framework that protects children who are at risk of being sent to or left in foreign countries against their will under arranged and organized unsafe conditions, which may contribute to children and young people being exposed to violence and torture, negative social control, or radicalization.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for necessary legislative changes aimed at prohibiting fixed after-school programs with overnight stays for extended periods in order to prevent segregation, parallel societies, negative social control, or radicalization.

Ensure that after-school programs with overnight stays are reported through the annual operational reporting of faith and belief communities. If there are concerns about activities that violate children's rights, or that may seem to have a negative effect on children's integration, contribute to segregation, negative social control, or radicalization, supervision should be conducted.

Investigate a right of reversion for properties transferred to the Church of Norway, and return to the Storting with proposals in connection with the legislative bill that follows Report No. St. 29 (2018–2019).
Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner with a proposal for a long-term financing plan for the preservation of culturally and historically significant church buildings.
Take the opportunity presented by the clarification of rights related to the Information Fund, so that the current approximately 6,400 lease agreements are offered for redemption.
Facilitate a collaboration with the municipalities that ensures broader societal considerations are taken into account beyond just the need for profitability.

The following should be ensured: 1. The state and the church shall be equal parties in the process that will clarify which buildings the church will take over, and it is assumed that the state will reach an agreement with the Church of Norway on this matter. 2. The church's values will be separated first, after which the state should make its own assessments regarding the management of the values that remain in the fund. 3. The condition for the division of the fund is that the state increases its efforts to preserve the culturally and historically significant church buildings to a degree that corresponds to the values that the state will own at a specific time. Once the assets in the Enlightenment Fund are finally distributed between the state and the church, a calculation of the real value must be made. The real value should benefit the culturally and historically significant church buildings through restoration and securing of the churches. The state's increased efforts for the preservation of the churches must, over time, at least correspond to this value (adjusted for inflation). 4. The state's increased efforts regarding the church buildings shall not replace the municipalities' financial responsibility for the church buildings or serve as a substitute for other measures or arrangements that exist in the area. 5. In consultation with church authorities, heritage authorities, and others, work will be initiated on preservation programs for various categories of culturally and historically significant church buildings, for example, by categorizing the church buildings by age, conservation value, or maintenance condition.

Return to the Parliament with a case regarding the property assets that the state will take over after the division of the Enlightenment Fund. It is requested that the government sheds light on questions concerning the purpose of the state fund, its social responsibility, organization, conditions for the sale of properties, security issues related to potential sales to foreign actors, as well as other matters that are significant for the management of the remaining fund that the state will take over.
Develop a plan for the improvement of heritage church buildings.

Investigate and return to the Parliament with proposals for necessary legal amendments to ensure that various organizations – particularly different religious and belief communities – cannot legally conduct extensive and closed educational programs with overnight stays over longer periods, such as Quran schools, which may involve segregation, negative social control, or have other harmful consequences for children under the guise of leisure activities.

Return to the Parliament with a new proposal regarding medical devices. The proposal must ensure that neither the law on medical devices nor the incorporation of the EEA Agreement regarding the regulation on medical devices and the regulation on in vitro diagnostic medical devices limits the public health service's ability to utilize custom-made medical devices compared to today, nor restricts the national scope to regulate genetic self-tests.

Investigate and propose quality- and competence-based staffing standards in elderly care. A staffing standard must take into account all relevant professional groups, where doctors, nurses, health care professionals, and other relevant occupations are part of the assessment. It should also highlight how task shifting, education, and competence development can contribute to achieving the staffing standard.

Initiate a mapping of the human rights situation in Norwegian nursing homes, home care services, and other municipal care services, where residents and users themselves, as well as their relatives, are also sources. The government is requested to report to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Investigate and return to the Parliament with a proposal for necessary competence-enhancing measures for employees and leaders in elderly care, which can prevent and reduce violence and abuse against the elderly and staff in elderly care.

Ensure that there is sufficient capacity in relevant vocational education programs and offerings for continuing education in geriatrics for healthcare workers, occupational therapists, physiotherapists, and porters.

Propose to abolish corporate fines as a punitive measure against health enterprises and suggest another suitable punitive measure against management that has systematically and grossly neglected its management responsibilities.
Design a template for user and relative surveys in care services, and ensure that all municipalities conduct this annually.

Introduce a standard practice for removing doctors and other healthcare personnel from operational duty while they are under investigation for systematic, gross, and serious malpractice against patients.

Ensure that all cases where the Health Inspectorate concludes that healthcare personnel have violated the law and committed systematic, serious, and grossly negligent malpractice are followed up by the prosecuting authorities.

Propose to extend the penalty framework for healthcare professionals who are convicted of gross and systematic malpractice against patients, aiming for an increase from the current maximum sentence of three months.
Ensure increased self-sufficiency of protective equipment for the healthcare service through national production and emergency storage, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Promote a new, overarching parliamentary report on quality and patient safety in health and care services, with specific goals and measures that are followed up with annual status reports.

Change the overarching goal for ownership management in state-owned companies to read: "Companies in category 1 and 2 deliver the highest possible return over time and actively contribute to achieving the goals of the Paris Agreement."
Transform the state's "expectations" of companies regarding sustainability, due diligence, human rights, labor rights, tax policy, etc., into "requirements."
Establish concrete measurement indicators for companies' due diligence assessments and management of both risks and actual harm to people, communities, and the environment.

Develop clear guidelines for the tax policy of state-owned companies, in line with the expectations of the Government Pension Fund regarding the companies in which the fund invests. The boards of companies that do not comply with the guidelines, and where the state is the majority owner, shall be replaced.

Update the state's guidelines for salaries and other compensation for senior executives in enterprises and companies with state ownership, so that one of the main principles for salary formation is that executive salaries should not exceed the salary of the Prime Minister.

Ensure that the use of variable pay and bonus schemes is tightened, and that the size of pension schemes and severance packages for senior executives in companies and enterprises with state ownership is reviewed with the aim of reducing total compensation. There should be feedback on the developments in the annual state budgets.

Review the board fees in state-owned companies with the aim of reducing the fees. The annual growth in compensation should not exceed the general wage growth in Norway, measured in absolute monetary value.
Require sustainability reporting from state-owned companies in accordance with the TCFD framework. The reporting should be audited by an independent third party.
Introduce a goal of at least 40% women on the boards of all companies in which the state has an ownership stake.

Change the guidelines for salary and other compensation for senior executives in enterprises and companies with state ownership, so that it is established that companies where the state is the majority owner shall follow the state's guidelines for executive pay.

Change the guidelines for salary and other compensation for senior executives in enterprises and companies with a state ownership stake in a way that ensures that total compensation over time does not grow faster than the general wage development.
Ensure that the total compensation for executives in enterprises and companies with state ownership is reduced.

Ensure that the use of variable pay and bonus schemes is limited, and that the size of pension schemes and severance packages for senior executives in companies with state ownership is reviewed with the aim of reducing total compensation.

Following the Covid-19 outbreak and the economic consequences the virus has caused, measures must be implemented to address the increased potential risk of foreign takeover of strategically important industries for Norway. In this context, an action plan must be developed to ensure the protection of companies that have societal security or strategic significance, should they be threatened by acquisitions from third countries. In this regard, state ownership should be actively utilized to prevent strategically important interests from being subject to foreign takeover.
Strengthen state ownership so that it becomes a strategic tool to contribute to the transformation of the Norwegian economy.

Investigate and, during the autumn of 2020, return to the Parliament with a separate case containing concrete proposals on how the state can take strategic measures to ensure national anchoring and long-term industrial capital for companies or industries that could have national significance in order to: ensure the development of Norwegian natural resources, contribute to restructuring with a focus on climate and environmental impact, develop strategic competence environments, contribute to technology development of international interest, and strengthen export revenues.

Develop a new review of state ownership that assesses how state ownership can actively contribute to strengthening national value creation and achieving the goals of the Paris Agreement. This review should include: a strategy to increase the share of the land-based industry in GDP; a strategy to strengthen national ownership of companies listed on the Oslo Stock Exchange; an assessment of how state and national ownership can contribute to achieving preparedness and security policy goals; a strategy for how state ownership can help strengthen Norway's competitive advantages in the low- and zero-emission economy, as well as contribute to low- and zero-emission solutions abroad.
Promote proposals to increase, not reduce, state ownership.

Create a new ownership instrument aimed at establishing national ownership in strategically important companies of national significance, as well as increasing the value of these ownership stakes in the long term. The company should also be able to receive funding through the national budget.

Ensure that the state uses its position as a majority owner to ensure that salaries and other compensation for senior executives in the relevant companies comply with the state's guidelines for executive pay. Furthermore, the state should strive to ensure that the state's guidelines for executive pay apply to all companies in which the state has an ownership stake.

Use its ownership power to ensure that the state's guidelines for executive compensation and expectations for board fees are adhered to, and vote to replace members of the boards of state-owned companies that do not follow these guidelines and expectations.

Ensure that companies integrate climate risk into their regular operations and report on this in accordance with the TCFD framework, as is already done for financial investments through Norges Bank and the Government Pension Fund.

Use their ownership power to ensure that the guidelines are followed, and to replace board members who do not adhere to the state's guidelines for executive compensation in companies where the state expects them to be followed.
Strengthen the municipalities' ability to regulate cruise ships and cruise tourism.
Present a comprehensive assessment of the preparedness related to cruise traffic, with particular emphasis on the Arctic regions.
Ensure increased control over cabotage bus operations in Norway.
Present a comprehensive case for sustainability in the cruise industry.

Establish a joint committee to assess measures that can strengthen Norwegian maritime competence, ensure Norwegian seafarers on Norwegian ships, and secure the competitiveness of Norwegian shipping companies.
