Establish a tripartite committee that will propose legislative changes and arrangements to implement Norwegian wage and working conditions for shipping activities taking place in Norwegian waters and on the Norwegian continental shelf. The committee's proposals will be presented in the announced white paper on the maritime industry.
Change the current blood alcohol limit for operating a recreational boat under 15 meters from 0.8 per mille to 0.2 per mille.
Introduce a high-speed certificate that requires both a theoretical and a practical exam.
Propose stricter regulations for operating fast leisure boats, such as a separate certification, requirements for practical training and testing, and a reduced blood alcohol limit of 0.2 promille.
Promote a proposal to amend the second-hand trade law by removing the requirement for a police license to engage in second-hand sales.
Establish a complaints board in connection with the sale of new homes, to which representatives of developers and contractors should be affiliated.

Review the Consumer Purchase Act and suggest how durability and access to spare parts can be incorporated as part of the basis for assessing whether the goods comply with the purchase agreement. The review must also include an assessment of what requirements should be set for spare parts to be available during the expected lifespan of the product, and how information about durability and access to spare parts can be made available to consumers.

Investigate and propose to the Parliament changes to the right of complaint and the seller's burden of proof that more strongly encourage the offering of products with longer shelf life in the market.
Propose to the Parliament a law on ethical information, including suggestions on how violations of the law can be sanctioned.
Return to the Storting no later than spring 2021 with a proposal to ban the marketing of consumer loans and consumer credit.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to introduce an interest rate cap on consumer loans and credit.
Ensure that circular solutions and waste reduction are required in all public tenders.

Come back to the Storting with a proposal to introduce a requirement for the inclusion of recycled plastic in all relevant products sold in the Norwegian market, for example, based on the model of the inclusion of advanced biofuels.

Appoint a public committee to investigate changes in the consumer role and the consequences this may have for the work on consumer rights. The committee shall particularly examine how consumer protection can be maintained in light of a development where consumers are increasingly involved in production, and where there is a rapidly accelerating shift from purchasing goods to purchasing services.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for measures to limit advertising in public spaces, for example by establishing advertising-free zones in the vicinity of schools.
Review the regulations on the marketing of non-medical cosmetic procedures with the aim of introducing a ban on the marketing of cosmetic surgery that is not part of medical treatment.
Promote a proposal for a regulation that allows goods to be repaired by all professional repairers without affecting the warranty.
Assess whether the tax policy in Norway promotes or hinders a climate- and environmentally friendly consumer policy.
Investigate measures and present a proposal to the Parliament with actions to limit children's consumption of energy drinks.
Review the legislation in the consumer area to assess the need for changes that ensure that consumer policy as a whole becomes more sustainable.
Come back to the Storting with a review of public services from a consumer perspective.
Consider expanding the debt information scheme to include more types of debt, such as housing debt and student loans, in connection with the planned evaluation in 2021.
Investigate whether the complaint period for newly constructed homes should be extended from five to ten years, as well as the consequences of a possible extension.
Promote a proposal to introduce mandatory ID tagging for cats.
Promote a proposal to introduce mandatory ID tagging of dogs.
Investigate a mandatory system for general ID marking of other pets in Norway.

Present a case to the Storting that demonstrates how Statskog SF can invest in further processing forestry industry in Norway and contribute to more industrial development and economic growth, also locally in the areas where Statskog SF owns properties.

Propose changes to the provisions of the National Insurance Act regarding the right to unemployment benefits, § 4-10, or clarify in regulations or in another way that victims of human trafficking and labor market crime are exempt from the waiting period provisions in the National Insurance Act regarding the right to unemployment benefits in § 4-10.

Take the initiative to establish a certification scheme for petroleum producers based on best practices in the market, in line with the emission reduction targets that the Norwegian petroleum industry has already set.
Take an international initiative for an agreement with other oil-producing countries to promote transition and limit the production of oil and gas.

Come back to the Storting with a proposal to amend the Petroleum Act so that there is no rights-based access to extensions beyond the timeframe of the extraction permit, and that when assessing extensions, an evaluation of greenhouse gas emissions should be the basis, rather than solely economic considerations.
Halt the development of the Johan Castberg field in the Barents Sea.
Ensure that Equinor ASA reduces its greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% by 2030 compared to 1990 levels.

Demand that Equinor ASA has similar targets for reducing the company's own greenhouse gas emissions for operations outside Norway, as they do for reducing emissions on the Norwegian continental shelf.

Present a plan that leads to zero emissions from the petroleum sector by 2035, at the latest by 2040. The Parliament requests that the plan be presented to the Parliament in an appropriate manner no later than the end of 2020.
Not granting any more permits to search for fossil energy on the Norwegian continental shelf.
Come to the Storting with a plan to supply the Johan Castberg field with renewable energy. The plan should be presented no later than in connection with the state budget for 2021.
Follow up on the recommendations and assessments from the Climate Risk Committee and present a parliamentary report on the matter during 2020.
Present a case for the landing of oil from the Johan Castberg field to the Storting. The case must be presented no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2020.
To halt the planned development of NorthConnect.

Ensure that Statnett takes over the ownership of NorthConnect, as the current owners have requested, in order to ensure that the cable can be built as quickly as possible and thereby contribute to emission reductions, increased power exchange, and market development for renewable energy.
Present a constitutional assessment of potential accession to the EU's fourth energy market package.
Reject applications for licenses to build foreign cables that will contribute to higher electricity prices for people and industry in Norway.
Take the initiative with the EU to ensure that NorthConnect is removed from the EU's list of projects of common interest (PCI list).
Reject the application from NorthConnect for a facility license, foreign license, and exemption from EEA regulations to build a power cable between Norway and the United Kingdom.
Replace homework with schoolwork.
Make a new assessment of the competence goals for 2nd grade based on the announced evaluation of the six-year reform.
Open up for the possibility that kindergarten teachers can be used in schools.
Start a few pilot projects with delayed school start to gain insights into whether the measure has the desired effects.

Facilitate a better and more effective teacher education by ensuring that there are higher expectations for teaching quality and study intensity in teacher education programs, through: a. increased study intensity by allocating more hours to studies overall, distributed across organized learning activities and independent study, with the goal of raising the average time spent on studies in teacher education programs to at least the average for other students b. ensuring that educational institutions provide teacher students with training in practical teaching work and the tasks teachers face in the classroom c. ensuring that educational institutions continuously work on measures for better collaboration with the labor market for teacher students in their education d. strengthening the competence of students, teacher education programs, and practice schools in the use of digital tools and digital learning methods.
Establish a public committee to investigate the proposal for a new joint collaboration law to ensure that children and young people receive comprehensive and interdisciplinary services.
Consider how the measures can be better aligned to support the school owners' work in ensuring a good and equitable offer.

Ensure that the county municipalities are obligated to ensure that all students applying for upper secondary school have a genuine free choice of school, either throughout the county or in intake regions, and that the changes take effect in the autumn of 2021.
Promote a proposal to the Parliament that the counties' right to decide on their own admission model for upper secondary education be included in the Education Act.

Investigate various models for non-commercial housing, both in the ownership and rental sectors, and return to the Parliament with proposals for necessary legislative changes and appropriations to establish such arrangements.

Promote a proposal that the cap on total compensation for employees in the state, including any allowances and pensions, should not be at a higher level than the arrangements that apply at any given time for the Prime Minister.
Do not increase salaries or compensation for state secretaries and political advisors in the government apparatus until a new system with a cap on leadership salaries in the state is in place.
Introduce a salary cap for state leaders at 15 G, and a salary freeze for current leaders with salaries above this level.

Establish a salary commission for state executive salaries, executive salaries in state-owned companies and companies where the state is the majority owner, as well as the salaries of politicians at the national and local levels. The commission will examine state executive salaries, bonus schemes, and compensations in context and analyze why salary development at the top level has gained a foothold, despite previously adopted guidelines. The commission will also conduct a thorough assessment of what constitutes genuine societal considerations in salary determination, and what cannot be justified by this. The commission should have strong representation from the parties involved. The salaries of political and administrative leaders in the state with a salary of 9.8 G or more will be nominally put on hold until the salary commission presents its conclusions in the fall of 2020.

Establish a salary commission for state executive salaries, executive salaries in state-owned companies, and companies where the state is the majority owner, as well as the salaries of politicians at the national and local levels. The commission will examine state executive salaries, bonus schemes, and compensations in context and analyze why the salary development at the top level has continued, despite previously adopted guidelines. The commission will also conduct a thorough assessment of what constitutes genuine societal considerations in salary determination, and what cannot be justified by this. The commission should have strong representation from the parties involved. The salaries of the Prime Minister, ministers, and members of parliament will be nominally put on hold until the salary commission has presented its conclusions.

Establish a practice where leaders in the state and wholly-owned state companies who leave their positions, regardless of whether it is voluntary or involuntary, as a general rule do not retain their leadership salary if they are reassigned to lower positions.

Ensure that the responsible minister reports annually to the Parliament on the development of executive salaries within their area of responsibility. Ministers responsible for state-owned companies shall submit a report to the Parliament on how they have promoted the state's principles for moderation in executive pay. There should also be a report on what has been done to ensure an equalized executive salary profile.
Ensure that the salary development for leaders in the public sector does not exceed the average salary development in society.

Ensure that bonus agreements are limited and used only in exceptional cases. Bonus agreements must be justified and must be approved by the responsible minister in state-owned companies and in the government. Bonuses are to be considered part of a leader's overall compensation package and should be subject to the same criteria of moderation.
Conduct national tests as sample tests.
Ensure that the presentation of the results from the national tests provides more precise and accurate information than is currently the case.
Ensure that the overall requirements for reporting and documentation in schools are reduced.

Prepare and return to the Parliament with a proposal that ensures state operation of the air ambulance service, and that the state can acquire companies with the relevant approvals, rights, and expertise for operating ambulance aircraft in Norway, and begin the integration of the service at the earliest opportunity. Services in Northern Norway are prioritized in the integration process.

Initiate a controlled termination of the contract with Babcock and secure an agreement where Babcock contributes the necessary aircraft and personnel until the state fully operates the air ambulance, and where Babcock bears its share of the costs incurred by the breach of contract to the state.

Prepare for the public operation of the air ambulance service so that it becomes an integrated part of the health enterprises' other ambulance services and emergency medical preparedness, and return to the Storting with this as a separate matter.
Include the expenses for the health enterprises' extra measures in the air ambulance case in the proposal for the revised national budget 2020.
Ensure that the expert group's mandate is expanded to also investigate how a public takeover of the air ambulance service can be carried out.
Present an overview of the economic, preparedness, and health consequences and deviations resulting from the tendering process in the air ambulance service and the operator change in 2019.
Ensure that a standby arrangement for pilots is immediately established, which can be called upon in case of illness and absence in the air ambulance service.

To engage in dialogue with the parties in the labor market about wage development in socially critical professions, especially female-dominated and low-paid jobs, in order to determine what the state can contribute in terms of funding to ensure a wage increase.

Promote proposals for increased funding to strengthen staffing in kindergartens and schools, as well as to ensure sufficient cleaning personnel in connection with the gradual reopening of schools and kindergartens.

Follow the call from the UN Secretary-General to include the protection of women as part of measures against the COVID-19 pandemic, and ensure additional funding for work against violence in close relationships.

Propose measures for female-dominated professions that are particularly affected by the consequences of the coronavirus situation on the economy and labor market in a separate case for the Parliament, including measures for increased full-time employment, initiating long-term trials with reduced working hours, increasing staffing levels, and starting a dialogue with the parties about wage increases for female-dominated professions in the public sector, as well as specific measures within female-dominated industries in the private sector, such as service industries.
Promote a proposal to incorporate the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities into the Human Rights Act, in order to give the convention precedence in Norwegian law.

Ensure that the work against violence in close relationships is prioritized by the police and other relevant actors by earmarking funds for the police's work on violence in close relationships, implementing the tools PATRIARK and SARA in all police districts, and that a portion of the new positions in the police resulting from the coronavirus crisis should be allocated to the police's work against violence in close relationships, and if necessary, return to the Parliament with a case on this matter.

Implement an extraordinary cross-sector effort against violence in close relationships as a result of the coronavirus situation, particularly to improve collaboration between relevant actors such as the police, crisis centers, child welfare services, schools, and health services.
Include evaluation and gathering of knowledge about the consequences for gender equality, including violence in close relationships and equality in the labor market.

Ensure that Norway takes on a leading role internationally to prevent the coronavirus situation from being used to hinder sexual and reproductive health and rights, such as abortion, and that development policy takes into account that women are particularly affected by the economic consequences of the pandemic.
Map the effects of the coronavirus crisis on the equality field, and report back to the Parliament with results and findings in an appropriate manner.

Amend the regulation of May 15, 1988, no. 356 regarding the use of motor vehicles in uncultivated land and on frozen waterways as follows: § 5c shall read: owner of a cabin for the transport of luggage and equipment between the road and the cabin when the cabin is not connected to a plowed road.
Ensure that the amendment to the regulation of May 15, 1988, no. 356 regarding the use of motor vehicles in uncultivated land and on frozen waterways takes effect from October 1, 2020.
Ensure that the regulatory change leads to simplifications in the regulations and increased municipal self-governance.

Establish a public committee that will: propose how to most effectively analyze and present natural risk at the national level; investigate and suggest measures such as changes in framework conditions, regulations, and modifications in tax and fee policies, which ensure that private and public enterprises, including financial institutions, have a basis for analyzing and reducing natural risk in the best possible way.

Present a parliamentary report that includes a plan for large-scale restoration of wilder nature, intact ecosystems, and greater recreational opportunities in Norwegian nature in line with Norway's Aichi commitment to restore 15 percent of our degraded ecosystems.
Require all Norwegian municipalities to implement their own nature budgets, with national limits for biodiversity loss and targets for restoration, which are tightened annually.
Establish a public committee to assess how to most effectively analyze and present natural risks at the national level.

Establish a public committee to assess potential methodologies for private and public enterprises, including financial institutions, to have a professional basis for analyzing and managing natural risks in the best possible way.
Establish a public committee to identify presumed important global, nature-related risk factors and assess their significance for the Norwegian economy and financial stability.

Halt all planned exploratory drilling in marine areas that are intended to be included as particularly valuable areas in the upcoming comprehensive national plan for marine protected areas, in the revision of the management plan for the Barents Sea and the areas off Lofoten, as well as in the update of the management plans for the Norwegian Sea and the North Sea-Skagerrak.

Include the updated particularly valuable and vulnerable areas (SVO) in the management plan for the Barents Sea and the marine areas outside Lofoten, as well as in the management plans for the Norwegian Sea and the North Sea-Skagerrak, in accordance with the recommendations in the scientific basis "Particularly Valuable and Vulnerable Areas | M-1303," and protect these areas from oil activities in the upcoming national plan for marine protected areas.

Prepare license holders that it will not be relevant to allow the development of oil and gas fields in the area around Trænarevet or other marine areas planned to be included as particularly valuable areas in the upcoming comprehensive national plan for marine protected areas, in the revision of the management plan for the Barents Sea and the areas off Lofoten, or in the update of the management plans for the Norwegian Sea and the North Sea-Skagerrak.
Protect the marine area around Trænarevet from petroleum activities in the upcoming national plan for marine protected areas.
Develop a new counting method for bear cubs that reflects the actual population level.
Conduct a survey to assess the actual level of the bear population through a count.

Investigate the consequences of Norwegian fisheries policy based on the criticism from the Office of the Auditor General, and return to the Parliament with a new white paper that takes this into account.
Propose to reduce the value-added tax on locally processed seafood to ensure more sustainable use of resources and increase employment and value creation in the rural areas.

Ensure a reduction through structuring by 50 percent and return to the Storting with a proposal for an arrangement where the reduction in the coastal groups goes to non-transferable recruitment quotas, while in other groups it goes back to the group.

Present a proposal for a gradual phasing out of the obligation scheme for cod trawlers, with the exception of the activity requirement. The phasing out should occur gradually in accordance with the legal considerations from the obligation commission or more quickly. The phasing out should result in a transfer of quotas to the part of the coastal fleet that supplies raw materials to the industry, where requirements for catch patterns that are seasonally identical to the current cod trawler fleet should be considered during allocation.
Ensure the reintroduction of the 28-meter limit in the coastal fishing fleet.

Come back to the Storting with a proposal for a tax on frozen fish exported from Norway for further processing in other countries. The revenues from the scheme should go towards quality-enhancing measures, for example in the fish sales organizations.
Ensure to implement a structural halt until new regulations are in place in areas pointed out by the National Audit Office.

Investigate a scheme where the current system of buying and selling vessels with quotas is replaced by a concession system where proximity to resources and expertise determines access to rights. The investigation should also include a transition solution, so that those who have invested within the current system do not suffer unacceptable losses.
Investigate and propose measures that reduce the use of plastic and measures that replace plastic in fishing gear.
Investigate and propose incentives in fisheries to adopt fishing gear that does not contribute to marine litter.
Present a case for measures to prevent plastic from ending up in the ocean due to fishing and other maritime activities.
Conduct an evaluation of how the changes in the duty system have affected the arrangement in 2022, and present a case to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Continue the joint fishing scheme, but require local delivery.
Consider whether it is possible to impose requirements for fishing for species other than cod under the joint fishing scheme.
Ensure that the distribution of quotas between the fleet groups does not change significantly.

Ensure that upon the expiration of the time limit for structural quotas, the structural gain is allocated to the vessel group to which the vessel belongs when the time limit occurs, and is distributed relatively according to the basic quota. When establishing a structural quota, the structural gain that arises from reductions is allocated to the vessel group to which the vessel belongs, and is distributed relatively according to the basic quota. For the purse seine group and pelagic trawl, the structural gain is allocated when the time limit occurs according to the current group affiliation.

Return to the Storting (as soon as possible, possibly from 2021) with a proposal for a fiscal fee on fisheries (wild fish) amounting to approximately 100 million kroner annually. In this context, it is being considered whether it can be modeled after the fisheries research fee. The model must be compatible with Norway's obligations under the EFTA Convention and EFTA free trade agreements.

Facilitate the establishment of quota flexibility at the vessel level for the fishing of cod, haddock, and saithe north of 62°N across the year-end, so that a vessel can make the best use of its quota basis within a quota year, similar to what is done in pelagic fisheries.
Ensure that the existing arrangement of "fishing with oneself" in the cod fishery is discontinued by December 31, 2025.
Do not establish a government quota stock/community quota stock.
Ensure that there is no opportunity to extend the time limit in the structural quota scheme.
Develop a strategy for better gender equality in fisheries.
Conduct an impact assessment of any elements in the decisions made during the consideration of Innst. 243 S (2019-2020) that have not been assessed through the report.

Promote proposals for a concrete action package to ensure greater seriousness in the fishing industry. Important measures that must be included to ensure competence, seriousness, and decent wage and working conditions are: Good training programs to ensure the industry has access to skilled labor. Continuation of special arrangements for layoffs in the fishing industry. Mapping the use of hiring and temp agencies in the sector. Measures to encourage full-time permanent positions and to limit hiring. More active use of the Labor Inspection Authority and a-krim centers in relation to the fishing industry. Stricter sanctions for violations of the Working Environment Act.

Investigate whether the scope of the Media Responsibility Act can be expanded to include news agencies that provide quality-controlled content, and how this can be done without undermining the goal of ensuring a clear point of accountability in the media, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner by the spring session of 2021.
Ensure that the state and public authorities treat editor-controlled journalistic media equally in their access to arenas of public interest.

Introduce a labeling system for goods, so that products coming from areas occupied by Israel must be labeled with their country of origin, following the model of the EU Court's ruling on such labeling.
Clarify the responsibility for labeling goods that come from areas occupied by Israel before they reach Norwegian consumers.
Investigate control mechanisms and any sanctions against responsible actors who violate the new regulation on labeling of goods from areas occupied by Israel.
Promote a proposal to reverse the cuts in disability benefits that occurred due to the government's unfair recalculation model from the old to the new disability scheme.
Promote a proposal to reverse the cuts to the disability child allowance.
Promote proposals to rectify the cuts in purchasing power for many elderly pensioners in recent years.
Promote a proposal to reverse the cuts in work assessment allowance.
Promote a proposal to reverse the cuts to the transition allowance for single parents.
Increase housing support significantly and facilitate that more low-income individuals can be enabled to own their own homes through increased housing support and increased start loans.

Come back to the Parliament with an overview of how the various cuts and reforms in welfare benefits that have been implemented since the Solberg government took office have affected the living conditions of the most vulnerable in society, and what consequences this has had for social inequality in Norway.
Promote a proposal to abolish the cap on the sum of disability benefits and child allowances equivalent to 99% of income before disability.
Promote proposals to ensure that the disabled continue to be protected from age-related adjustments.
Promote the necessary proposals to ensure that the organizations participating in the social security settlement have the right to negotiate.
Propose necessary legislative changes so that recipients of work assessment allowance can retain the benefit until they are actually assessed for work or other benefits.
Promote a proposal to reverse the reduction in the minimum benefit for recipients of work assessment allowance under 25 years old.
Promote a proposal to reverse the cuts in eyewear support for children.
Promote a proposal to reverse the cut in the car support scheme for individuals in group 1 who need a car to break an isolated existence and improve daily life functions.
Implement measures that collectively will contribute to eliminating the effect of annual under-regulation of pensions.

Come back to the Parliament with a review of how the unfair cuts they have implemented have weakened the living conditions for the most vulnerable in society and increased social inequality in Norway.
Promote a proposal for the establishment of a Nav ombudsman based on the model of the patient and user ombudsman.

Investigate the establishment of a Nav ombudsman. The investigation must include the ombudsman's function/mandate, organization in relation to state and municipal Nav, a model for the ombudsman including how the ombudsman will operate, location, costs, and possibly coordination with patient and user ombudsmen.
Present a proposal for the establishment of a Nav ombud, including suggestions for its mandate and organization.
Consider measures to improve guidance and follow-up for each individual user in Nav.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to amend the Social Security Act that interrupts the appeal deadline to the Court of Appeal when appealing the decisions of the Social Security Court to the Parliamentary Ombudsman.
Establish a model for effective mass vaccination, with an efficient logistics system for inviting prioritized vaccination of known risk groups first.
Dissolve the regional health authorities and distribute the tasks between a national governing body and the individual health enterprises.
Ensure that the outsourcing and operation of critical national ICT services and systems in the healthcare sector is terminated, and that new agreements cannot be made.

Ensure increased use of individual plans for patients who require long-term and coordinated services, and ensure that patients' statutory rights to a coordinator and contact physician are upheld in the health enterprises.
Ensure that the regional health authorities do not pass on activity-based financing to the hospital level or department level.
Ensure that information related to national security interests is managed and stored in Norway.

Investigate and promote a legislative proposal to replace the Health Enterprises Act with a new Health Administration Act, where the counties can take over the operation of hospitals with the introduction of elected governance, local and practice-oriented management, and employee participation.

Require the regional health authorities to implement local management at all hospitals and larger hospital departments, and that the local manager shall be responsible for the entire operation, including professional responsibility, financial responsibility, and personnel responsibility.

Expand the specialist health service offerings in Alta with a maternity department and necessary emergency functions. It must be assumed that a new hospital will be built in Hammerfest, and that the hospitals in Finnmark will collaborate in a network model to provide the entire population with an equitable health service of good quality.
Ensure a permanent ambulance helicopter in Kirkenes and a jet stationed permanently in Tromsø.
Stop the closure of the maternity department in Kristiansund and ensure that a fully functional maternity department in Kristiansund becomes part of the future hospital structure in Møre and Romsdal.
Follow up on request resolution 750 (2017–2018), and ensure that the maternity ward in Kristiansund remains operational until the maternity ward in the new hospital at Hjelset is in operation.
Ensure that local management becomes the norm at Norwegian hospitals.
Establish a contingency model for Norwegian production of essential medicines, including antibiotics, and return to the Parliament with a proposal on this matter.
Establish a public/private partnership with production environments, aimed at increasing self-sufficiency in protective equipment for the healthcare service.
Define the hospital in Kirkenes as intensive activity level 2.

Investigate what production capacity exists in Norway, and which essential medicines and medical equipment can and should be produced nationally to ensure supply and preparedness, and return to the Parliament with a proposal on this matter.

Bring a separate case to the Storting regarding the base structure for air ambulances in Norway, which must include Innlandet and Bykle/Vinje, no later than in connection with the state budget for 2021.
Ensure that non-profit hospitals and non-profit specialized outpatient clinics (DPS) are included in the health communities.

Ensure that it is safe for children to share painful experiences, and that the child has control over their own information. There should be good routines in place to ensure that parts of the child's journal can easily be restricted from access. Adequate training should be provided for healthcare personnel, and there must be time and space to make these assessments.

Review health legislation to ensure that it aligns with the principles of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child regarding children's right to be heard, decisions made in the best interest of the child, and children's right to privacy.

Place decisive emphasis on local political desires and the perspective of residents, and therefore open up for the possibility that newly merged municipalities can have shared solutions among multiple health enterprises.
Introduce a system where all visit denials until October 1st are logged with the possibility for verification.

Facilitate that, as far as possible, no interruption of the sentence is implemented against the inmate's wishes. Other measures should always be considered before an interruption of the sentence is initiated.
Facilitate that inmates who are in an established treatment program with the start of treatment within two months should not be considered for parole.
Review all the closed prisons and assess the possibility of reopening them in order to address the ever-increasing prison queue.
Facilitate that the condition of an ankle monitor should only be applicable if parole would otherwise have been denied.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to extend the duration of the entire or parts of the temporary law on adjustments to the regulations for child welfare services and the county board to alleviate the consequences of the outbreak of COVID-19 beyond October 22, 2020, if the government deems this necessary to ensure that child welfare services can fulfill their responsibilities.

Review the existing plans for the changed hospital structure in the capital region to clarify whether infection control considerations are addressed and whether the division of tasks between hospitals and the sizing of new buildings are suitable to ensure the health services for the population during future pandemics and other extraordinary events that place special demands on hospitals. The scenarios developed by the Norwegian Institute of Public Health for the COVID-19 pandemic should be emphasized in the work. As part of this effort, a risk and vulnerability analysis of infection control and functionality during epidemics/pandemics for the plans for the New Oslo University Hospital should be conducted, and the work should help clarify the claims that compact high-rise buildings are less suitable for limiting the spread of infection in hospitals than other building solutions. Representatives from the infection control environment at Oslo University Hospital and employee organizations should participate in the work.

Investigate the continued operation of Ullevål Hospital, in accordance with the city council's decision from the City of Oslo that the Gaustad plans are to be put on hold until the continued operation of Ullevål is sufficiently investigated, and present the investigation to the Parliament by the end of 2020. The investigation must address the objections raised by the Oslo City Council.
Ensure that no state regulation is adopted if the City of Oslo does not approve a rezoning in accordance with the hospital plans of Helse Sør-Øst.
Present a proposal for the establishment of a green investment company for the development of businesses based on green (renewable) carbon.

Present a plan for increasing the long-term carbon uptake in Norwegian forest areas. The plan must, in addition to including a more detailed plan for tree planting, contain knowledge-based value creation measures and concrete climate actions that will enable the forestry sector to contribute to achieving emission targets.

Ensure that foreign tourists can only take fish out of the country if it has been caught in collaboration with a registered tourist fishing company, in order to limit exports that do not create value in local communities and to gain stronger control over how much fish is caught and exported.
Ensure that the export requirement applies to whole fish, not fillets.
Change the export requirement so that the limit in kilograms applies per year, not per border crossing.
To map the food waste from tourist fishing and propose measures to reduce food waste to a minimum.

Propose an amendment to the Marine Resources Act that provides the legal basis for imposing conditions on permits for the establishment of tourist fishing businesses, and return to the Parliament with such a legislative proposal. The amendment should ensure that all tourist fishing enterprises must be registered and approved before they can commence business activities. Requirements may include safety, boat, and equipment standards, similar to those for professional fishing.
Investigate the introduction of fishing permits for foreign tourists, where the revenues will be used for fishing control, and return to the Storting with a proposal on this matter.
Present a plan of action to prevent illegal tourist fishing.
Investigate a scheme where tourist anglers can be required to deliver fish to local fish receiving stations.
Move away from the use of PPP (public-private partnership) for the Sotra connection.
Move away from the use of PPP (public-private partnership) for the Hålogalandsveien.

Ensure that the Norwegian Public Roads Administration, the Norwegian Railway Directorate, Bane NOR, Nye Veier, the county municipalities, and other relevant actors in connection with public procurement prioritize the development of capacity and competence in local, regional, and national businesses.
Ensure that there is a procurement strategy in public purchases that facilitates local, regional, and national jobs.
Ensure that knowledge of, and experience with, Norwegian conditions, such as climate and topography, is emphasized in public procurement.
Ensure that large contracts following market dialogue are divided into subcontracts, in accordance with the Public Procurement Regulations § 19-4. Division of procurements.

Utilize the procurement strategy adopted on March 31, 2020, in Innst. 216 S (2019–2020) and ensure that Hålogalandsvegen is divided into smaller subcontracts, so that Norwegian actors have a real opportunity to compete for the projects.

Utilize the procurement strategy adopted on March 31, 2020, in Innst. 216 S (2019–2020) and ensure that the Sotrasambandet is divided into smaller sub-contracts, so that Norwegian actors have a real opportunity to compete for the projects.

Ensure that requirements for vocational certificates, apprentices, and permanent employment on construction sites are stipulated in public procurement to ensure that the seriousness provisions between the Norwegian Construction Industry Association, the United Federation of Trade Unions, and the Norwegian Labor Union are adhered to in practice.
Investigate the scope within the Competition Act with the aim of clarifying the possibilities for collaboration among Norwegian contractors in the construction industry.

Take the initiative to establish an industrial competence center in Western Norway for maritime zero-emission technology and autonomous maritime transport systems, in close contact with both research environments, relevant industries and clusters, and the Norwegian Public Roads Administration.

Investigate a solution with frequent departures using zero-emission ferries (Mortavika–Arsvågen) as an alternative to a ferry-free crossing of Boknafjorden. The investigation should include an assessment of both cost/benefit and climate/environmental effects of crossing with zero-emission ferries compared to the ferry-free E39. Until the investigation is completed, all planning for the crossing is put on hold.

Investigate a solution with frequent departures using zero-emission ferries (Halhjem–Sandvikvåg) as an alternative to a ferry-free crossing of the Bjørnafjord. The investigation should include an assessment of both cost/benefit and climate/environmental effects of crossing with zero-emission ferries compared to the ferry-free E39. Until the investigation is completed, all planning for the crossing is put on hold.

Investigate a solution with frequent departures using zero-emission ferries (Lavik–Oppedal) as an alternative to a ferry-free crossing of the Sognefjord. The investigation should include an assessment of both cost/benefit and climate/environmental effects of crossing with zero-emission ferries compared to the ferry-free E39. Until the investigation is completed, all planning for the crossing is to be put on hold.

Investigate a solution with frequent departures using zero-emission ferries (Lote–Anda) as an alternative to a ferry-free crossing of the Nordfjord. The investigation should include an assessment of both cost/benefit and climate/environmental effects of crossing with zero-emission ferries compared to the ferry-free E39. Until the investigation is completed, all planning for the crossing is put on hold.

Investigate a solution with frequent departures using zero-emission ferries (Festøya–Solavågen) as an alternative to a ferry-free crossing of Vartdalsfjorden. The investigation should include an assessment of both cost/benefit and climate/environmental effects of crossing with zero-emission ferries compared to the ferry-free E39. Until the investigation is completed, all planning for the crossing is to be put on hold.

Investigate a solution with frequent departures using zero-emission ferries (Hareid–Sulasundet) as an alternative to a ferry-free crossing of the Sulafjord. The investigation should include an assessment of both cost/benefit and climate/environmental effects of crossing with zero-emission ferries compared to the ferry-free E39. Until the investigation is completed, all planning for the crossing is put on hold.

Investigate a solution with frequent departures using zero-emission ferries (Molde–Vestnes) as an alternative to a ferry-free crossing of the Romsdalsfjord. The investigation should include an assessment of both cost/benefit and climate/environmental effects of crossing with zero-emission ferries compared to the ferry-free E39. Until the investigation is completed, all planning for the crossing is put on hold.

Investigate a solution with frequent departures using zero-emission ferries (Halsa–Kanestraum) as an alternative to a ferry-free crossing of the Halsafjord. The investigation should include an assessment of both cost/benefit and climate/environmental effects of crossing with zero-emission ferries compared to the ferry-free E39. Until the investigation is completed, all planning for the crossing is put on hold.

Halt all projects for the construction of four-lane highways with an average daily traffic (ÅDT) below 15,000 at the start of construction, and instead focus on two- and three-lane roads, preferably with a median barrier.
Investigate the upgrading or construction of a new railway before a new four-lane motorway if the new road is planned in a corridor with an old, single-track railway.

Adapt future road development based on Average Daily Traffic (ÅDT), normalized road standards, costs, existing road capital, land conservation, topographical conditions, and what other transportation alternatives are available in the area. Distribution considerations must be taken into account in the same way as socio-economic analyses.

Consider climate, environmental, and land use considerations when constructing new roads, and request the government to develop new guidelines that take these factors into greater account throughout the entire project phase, from the concept phase to completion.
Initiate the work to realize the North Norway Railway.
Conduct a concept choice study (KVU) for transport solutions in Northern Norway in such a way that the Northern Norway Railway can be considered in the next revision of the National Transport Plan.

Investigate the possibilities for more cost-effective development of infrastructure for cyclists and pedestrians while strengthening considerations for goals related to cycling traffic, life-cycle costs, traffic safety, accessibility, and the perception of safety. The use of economic incentives and changes to regulations for cyclists should be included in the assessment.

Ensure that the Norwegian Public Roads Administration's road standards related to the planning and construction of pedestrian and bicycle paths develop more flexible standards that take into account the varying traffic volumes and thus different needs in different parts of the country.
Maintain the property authority so that the self-governing institutions in the university and college sector can continue to manage their own properties and buildings.
Promote measures that can help restrict the opportunities Norwegians have to use surrogacy services abroad, and continue the national ban on surrogacy.

To investigate how punitive measures against individuals who enter into agreements for commercial surrogacy with a surrogate mother, or against a business that facilitates surrogacy services, can be designed so as not to affect the children born.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to allow egg donation from women undergoing IVF treatment, who consent to donation, with the same strict regulations as for sperm donation. The donor should be unknown and non-anonymous.
Ensure that Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is allowed in Norway from July 1, 2020.
Work to change the Biomedicine Convention or the understanding of it, to ensure that mitochondrial donation can be allowed in Norway when the method is safe and scientifically sound.

Develop guidelines for compensation for the donation of gametes, reflecting the burden and time commitment for the donor. The compensation is set at a moderate level that does not drive up the overall compensation levels in Nordic countries. Documented travel expenses are covered in addition.
Ensure that employers are exempt from the obligation to cover sick pay for women who wish to donate eggs.
Design a prioritization guide for egg donation that largely harmonizes with the prioritization guide for sperm donation.
Ensure that ultrasound with additional examinations that can reveal serious illness or injury in the fetus is offered to all women in the first trimester through the public maternity care system.

Ensure that Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is offered to all women who are entitled to prenatal diagnostics, or in cases of findings during early ultrasound with additional examinations, regardless of the woman's age.
Ensure that Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is allowed to be performed in Norway for all pregnant women.
Ensure that Norway actively works in international contexts to combat the exploitation of women in the international surrogacy industry.
Ensure that the biotechnology law can be evaluated more dynamically and continuously in the future to keep pace with the rapid developments in biotechnology.
Amend the Medical Birth Registry Regulations with the aim of registering all treatments involving assisted reproduction in the Medical Birth Registry, regardless of outcome.

Ensure a review of the terms and guidelines for preimplantation diagnosis and prenatal diagnosis, so that these can be viewed in context and provide a comprehensive and coherent offer for women and families at particular risk of serious illness or injury to the fetus. The review should emphasize suffering and lost quality of life associated with palliative and life-prolonging treatment in the assessment of the conditions for granting PGD. The government is requested to present proposals for the necessary legal amendments resulting from this review.
Ensure that the age limit for being offered prenatal diagnostics is lowered from women who are >38 years at term, to women who are >35 years at term.
Incorporate the economic consequences of the changes in the Biotechnology Act into the state budget for 2021.

Return to the Parliament with a report on the market for genetic self-testing, which will serve as the basis for legal regulation of this market. The report must, among other things, take into account considerations of privacy, the right to one's own health data, and health consequences of misleading test results.
Promote legislation that ensures genetic testing of children outside the healthcare system is prohibited.

Promote a proposal to reverse the cuts to free physiotherapy for burn victims, people with developmental disabilities, amputees, and all the other groups who now have to pay for this important treatment.
Promote a proposal to reintroduce a good offer for seniors over 75 years old for free dental check-ups.

Implement a continuous investigation of the effects that the ABE cuts have on hospitals across the country, and present the results to the Parliament in the annual parliamentary report on quality and patient safety.

Promote a proposal to reverse the weakening of the coverage scheme for orthodontic expenses for children and young people, and ensure that the returned funds are used to strengthen the scheme for those with genuine needs for orthodontics.

Conduct an evaluation of the escalation plan for habilitation and rehabilitation 2017–2019, including the consequences of abolishing the diagnosis list for physiotherapy, and inform the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Shield the healthcare sector from ABE cuts.
Investigate and propose a new grant scheme to establish more day activity services for the elderly in the municipalities.
Reintroduce the grant scheme for day care services for people with dementia.
Come back to the Parliament with a binding escalation plan to strengthen staffing and competence in elderly care in the municipalities.
Present a plan to the Parliament for activity offerings for the elderly.
Investigate a separate grant scheme for positions that can ensure increased interdisciplinary competence and more volunteer work in Norwegian nursing homes and home care services.
Develop a scheme with specialized shielding services for particularly aggressive dementia patients.
Do not invite additional municipalities to join the project with state funding for municipal health and care services.

Establish a national program for increased basic staffing and recruitment for the municipal health and care services. The program must include concrete measures to facilitate locally anchored projects for increased basic staffing and reduced use of temporary workers in the health and care services.

Investigate the introduction of an objective legal and economic joint liability for transport buyers/transport orderers and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner. The objective liability must include joint responsibility for ensuring that the wage and working conditions in the sector are met. The investigation must also include an assessment of the need for a register of businesses that meet the requirements to provide transport services, modeled after, for example, the Cleaning Register. Additionally, the investigation must consider a limitation of the clients that should be covered by the joint liability.

Prepare and present to the Parliament a proposal that imposes legal, economic, and insurance-related joint liability on the client when purchasing transport services, in addition to the solidarity responsibility that applies in all industries where there is a legally regulated minimum wage (general collective agreements).

Investigate and propose the introduction of an objective legal and economic joint liability for transport buyers/transport orderers and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner. The objective liability must include joint responsibility for ensuring that the wage and working conditions in the sector are met. The investigation must also include an assessment of the establishment of a register of businesses that meet the requirements to provide transport services, based on models such as the Cleaning Register. Additionally, the investigation must consider a limitation of the clients that should be covered by the joint liability.
Introduce a limitation on cabotage driving for coach buses, so that it is not possible to perform cabotage driving for more than seven days per month.

Prepare and present to the Storting a proposal that the Norwegian Public Roads Administration should be granted enforcement rights to stop vehicles based on decisions from the Labour Inspection Authority.
Implement a process to dissolve the county municipality as an administrative level.

Facilitate so that the county municipalities that wish to reverse the forced mergers quickly have the opportunity to hold new elections for the county councils at the same time as the parliamentary elections in 2021.

Promote a proposal to fully compensate the expenses incurred by the county municipalities in connection with the forced mergers, including expenses that arise in connection with a possible repeal of the forced decisions. This must be done without cutting the block grants to municipalities and county municipalities.
Offer Greece relief by accepting unaccompanied minor asylum seekers and families with children from the refugee camps.
Work for a European cooperation that relieves Greece by distributing refugees to other countries.
Ensure that Norway joins the German initiative for the evacuation of vulnerable individuals and children from refugee camps in Greece now.

Say yes to evacuating a total of 1500 unaccompanied minors and other vulnerable asylum seekers from Moria and other refugee camps in Greece, and that at least 500 of these should be evacuated as quickly as possible.
Utilize the exception clause in the Dublin Regulation regarding Greece, so that no applicants are returned there.
To defend the Refugee Convention and Article 14 of the UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights of 1948, which establishes the right to seek asylum.
Work to include Kurdish self-governing authorities in the peace talks, including the ongoing constitutional process.

Facilitate that Norway, within this year's quota of 3,000 refugees, can receive some of the most vulnerable children from camps in Greece, under the following conditions: A range of European countries agree on an arrangement for reception. Distribution is calculated based on the population of the receiving countries. Norway receives a request from Greece to contribute to relocation. Norway accepts unaccompanied minors under 15 years old without guardians in the camps, preferably girls. Norway engages in dialogue with the UN to assess who are the most vulnerable within this group.

To engage in dialogue with the UN to assess who the most vulnerable individuals are that we should prioritize bringing to Norway, and how this can include the most vulnerable with protection needs from Greece.
Come back to the Parliament as soon as possible with a proposal for changes to the state budget for 2020, so that Norway increases the number of quota refugees for 2020 from 3,000 to 3,500.
Engage in dialogue with the UN to find solutions and implement a plan for the resettlement of quota refugees for 2020.

Present and implement a concrete plan for what Norway's international contribution should be to establish dignified and rights-based reception conditions in transit countries such as Greece. This involves quality assurance of asylum case processing, free legal aid for vulnerable groups of asylum seekers, voluntary assisted return, and reintegration of vulnerable groups.

Come to the Storting with a separate case before the merger of district courts in Østfold and Romerike is potentially carried out, and that the merger of these district courts is put on hold until the case has been processed.

Ensure that the healthcare services follow up on children in a regular manner, so that everyone is guaranteed the health care, treatment, and clarification that each child needs when child welfare services initiate a case.
Promote a proposal to legislate that health assessments of children's somatic and mental health should be conducted in connection with all custody transfers.
Promote a proposal to introduce quality requirements for lawyers who will handle cases in child welfare in collaboration with the Bar Association.
Review the appeal options in cases of custody takeover and assess the criteria for how often a case can be appealed, in light of the best interests of the child.
Promote a proposal to introduce a system where all emergency decisions are subject to a secondary assessment by an external entity.
Promote a proposal to change the arrangement of expert assessments in the child welfare service so that the county boards manage and organize the expert assessment system.
Introduce a system for user participation similar to the system for user participation in health enterprises, for all parts of the child welfare service.

Establish an expert committee that will, based on specific grounds in cases that are/have been processed by the European Court of Human Rights, review Norwegian child welfare services with the aim of improving legal security at all levels of the service.

Ensure that the proposals for the new child welfare law and the new child law are in line with the principles of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child regarding children's right to information, to be heard, decisions made in the best interest of the child, and children's right to privacy.
Ensure that the maintenance requirement also includes refugees and asylum seekers in accordance with the guidelines in Prop. 90 L (2015–2016).
Instruct the Immigration Directorate to reject the substantive processing of asylum applications from individuals who have resided in Turkey or another country where they were not persecuted.
Implement strengthened border control to stop asylum seekers who do not have the right to have their application processed.
Investigate and propose a physically and economically scaled-down project for the government quarter RKV, as the Oslo City Council unanimously requested in its council decision on April 22, 2020.
Ensure that the demolition of the Y-block is put on hold until the Parliament has considered a proposal for a physically and economically scaled-down project for the government quarter RKV.
Instruct Statsbygg to suspend the demolition decision regarding Y-block until the case has been processed in the Oslo District Court.
Investigate the establishment of an independent environmental complaints board with the aim of creating such a board.
Come back to the Parliament with a bill that lowers the threshold for what is considered self-defense under the Nature Diversity Act § 17, compared to the current practice.
Maintain the current complaint system with a clear political anchoring with the responsible minister.
Maintain the current division into 8 regional large carnivore committees.
Ensure that exemptions from the protection of cultivated and arable land can only be granted by a national planning authority.

Propose changes to the Agricultural Act that provide real protection for cultivated and arable land through a significant tightening of the possibilities for exemptions from the general requirement that cultivated and arable land should not be used for purposes other than food production.
Present a new land protection strategy with measures to achieve the new land protection goal.
Formulate a goal for the reallocation of arable land, as well as measures that will reduce agriculture's own consumption of topsoil.

Investigate changing the conditions for participation in the king crab fishery in the quota-regulated area in East Finnmark (east of 26° E), so that vessels registered in West Finnmark can also participate on the same terms as vessels from East Finnmark. The investigation must be conducted quickly, so that the change can be implemented from the quota year 2021.
Maintain the current activity requirements in the king crab fishery.
Consider increasing efforts to tackle unregistered king crab fishing.

Investigate both a model that allows for the expansion of the quota-regulated fishery to also include West Finnmark, and a scheme that provides fishing vessels registered in West Finnmark with quotas for fishing in East Finnmark.

Change the conditions for participating in the king crab fishery in the quota-regulated area in East Finnmark (east of 26°E), so that vessels registered in West Finnmark can also participate on the same terms as vessels from East Finnmark. The change will take effect from the next quota year (2021).

Consider a scaling model for the requirements to participate in king crab fishing, in order to ensure that this right is granted to active fishermen, and request the government to return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Establish a broadly composed committee tasked with evaluating all aspects of the Follo Line project.

Come back to the Parliament with an overview of the consequences of the cost overruns mentioned in Meld. St. 17 (2019–2020) for the progress and start-up of other projects, and what measures the government will initiate to reduce the cost overruns.

Evaluate the governance structure between the Norwegian Railway Directorate, Bane NOR, and the Ministry of Transport. It is important that Bane NOR can carry out expansion projects and work related to operations, maintenance, and renewal in a way that ensures optimal resource utilization, good cost control, and efficient project execution. In this work, assessments should also be made regarding whether the Nye Veier model can be applied in the development of railway projects.

Investigate the introduction of a progressive air passenger tax. The investigation should include an assessment of how such a tax could be higher for first-class/business travel, for those with many international trips annually, and for travel between the major cities in Norway where alternative, more environmentally friendly modes of transport are available. It should also be assumed that necessary flights on the short-haul network and in rural areas are exempt from the tax.

Investigate the possibility of introducing a "frequent flyer levy" or "air miles duty" in Norwegian aviation. The investigation should include an assessment of how such a fee can be differentiated between international flights, domestic flights, and flights on the short-haul network.
Demand the use of electric and hybrid aircraft (with advanced biojet fuel) in public service obligation routes as soon as the technology is available.
Set a goal for full electrification of the short-haul network by 2030.
Promote a proposal for a temporary compensation scheme for the aviation industry that compensates the sector for parts of the revenue loss.
Adjust the tax structure to stimulate demand for zero-emission aircraft and begin the work of adapting the infrastructure at Avinor's airports for zero-emission aircraft.
Introduce a duty to report between public agencies that become aware of human trafficking, including as part of the collaboration within the a-crime centers.
Ensure that situations where the employer intentionally misleads employees are treated equally to encouraging or pressuring the employee to consciously commit an illegal act.
Consider a duty to notify the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority when employees apply for unemployment benefits and claim to be victims of human trafficking or labor market crime.

Promote proposals for specific penal provisions for companies and business leaders who encourage, pressure, or influence laid-off employees to commit offenses by working for the company without registering it, while simultaneously receiving unemployment benefits.
Contact the parties in the labor market to discuss how to ensure that employers and employees receive sufficient and accurate information about their rights and obligations during layoffs.

Ensure that all employees with needs due to shorter opening hours in kindergartens and after-school care have the right to care benefits for individual hours and half days, as well as impose an obligation on employers to facilitate this.

Promote necessary proposals to ensure that parents who need to take care days due to lack of childcare continue to have the right to salary, initially by increasing the temporary quota by an additional 20 days.

Promote a proposal for a legislative amendment that clarifies the possibility of taking care leave days as individual hours, for example, based on the model of the National Insurance Act § 8-24 fourth paragraph. The withdrawal of care leave days as individual hours should be decided locally after discussions with the elected representatives in the organization.
Consider introducing care benefits graded down to 50%, for parents who need to be away from work for part of the day.

Ensure that in the subjects where vocational certificates are the relevant education, only active training companies receive public procurement contracts, and that these contracts require a higher intake of apprentices than the company usually has.
Investigate the requirements for competence among employers and leaders in the construction industry.

Promote a case for stricter seriousness requirements in public tenders that ensure that serious craft businesses with apprentices, their own employees, and skilled workers actually gain access to the market. For construction work that requires a building permit and liability, there must be requirements for professional competence for the executing party.

To allow municipalities to assign maintenance tasks to training companies that are at risk of having to lay off apprentices and skilled workers, based on a pre-agreed hourly rate. The allocation should be done in collaboration with the parties in the labor market.

Promote a case for stricter seriousness requirements in public tenders, including requirements for professional competence in the execution phase. For public procurements below the threshold value of 1.3 million kroner, criteria for seriousness must be developed. This can be referred to as "Little Doffin." The criteria must apply to both sole proprietorships without employees and companies with their own employees. For sole proprietorships without employees, there should be a requirement for a vocational certificate or equivalent in the area for which the tender is being submitted. For companies with their own employees, there should be requirements for a certain percentage of skilled workers in the relevant area, a percentage of permanent positions, as well as requirements for the number of apprentices depending on the size of the business. Companies that meet these requirements will be pre-qualified for a certain period.

Introduce state seriousness requirements equivalent to the Oslo Model and guidelines from the Construction Industry Association and the United Federation of Trade Unions, in Statsbygg, the Norwegian Public Roads Administration, and all state-owned companies that issue tenders to craft businesses.
To present a cost overview of incurred and upcoming expenses for the establishment of the base for maritime surveillance aircraft at Evenes Air Station.
Promote a case to the Parliament that ensures public-private collaboration for the establishment of a national cluster for the development and production of vaccines for humans, animals, and fish.
Investigate a top price system for concentrated feed for livestock in Norwegian agriculture, based on the model of the previous scheme with 'concentrated feed discount' that was discontinued in 1981.
Present a package of measures for agriculture to ensure increased Norwegian self-sufficiency.
Present financing and a plan for the implementation of emergency storage of food grains in connection with the state budget for 2021.

Investigate the consequences that the realization of Andøya SpacePort has for the fishing industry and engage in dialogue with the industry to develop mitigating measures that ensure a continued strong fishing industry in Andøya and the surrounding areas.
Ensure that Andøya Spaceport is realized as quickly as possible.
Investigate the need for a national center for space-based activities, and what could potentially be a suitable location for such a center.
Promote a proposal for the allocation of necessary funds through a dedicated crime package as soon as possible.
Promote necessary legislative proposals to ensure that relevant registry information is shared between public administrative bodies to uncover and prevent crime.
To review Økokrim's threat assessment for 2020 and promptly return to the Storting with proposals for measures to combat the increased threat of economic crime.

Propose amendments to the Intelligence Service Act that strengthen source protection and the public's trust in the state, and that prevent interventions that have a chilling effect on freedom of expression. Chapters 7 and 8 of the Act will not come into force until these proposals have been considered by the Parliament.
Investigate other measures that strengthen our defense against digital and hybrid threats without mass storage of data from electronic communication.
Ensure that the mandate of the announced privacy commission includes the consequences of tailored data collection for privacy.

Come back to the Parliament within five years with the most open evaluation possible of the effects that facilitated intelligence gathering has had on combating foreign intelligence activities and terrorism in Norway, and how facilitated intelligence gathering may have affected freedom of expression through chilling effects, whether mission drift has occurred, and any negative impact on source protection.
Propose amendments to the Intelligence Services Act that strengthen source protection through ongoing judicial oversight.
Promote a proposal for judicial review in § 9-6 third paragraph, which entails strengthened source protection.

Ensure an independent evaluation of the new intelligence service law from the date of full implementation. The evaluation should be public and completed no later than four years after the law has come into force. The evaluation should address the law's effectiveness and the possibility of oversight of its provisions, including the resource situation, competence, and tools available to the EOS Committee and the courts.
Ensure that the Oslo District Court has sufficient resources, accessibility, and expertise to fulfill the tasks assigned to them under the new intelligence law.

Ensure a swift progress in the E39 Rogfast project and that it is primarily continued based on the current decisions made by the Parliament. If the cost review of the project shows that it is necessary to change the management and cost framework, the government shall present it to the Parliament as soon as possible, so that the progress of the project is not unnecessarily delayed.

Ensure a quick start and continued progress in the E39 Rogfast project, primarily based on the current decisions made by the Parliament. If the cost review of the project indicates that it is necessary to change the management and cost framework, the government shall present this to the Parliament as soon as possible and without delay in the project's progress.

Join forces with the industry and labor movement to sign a common social contract that will serve as the foundation for powerful crisis measures and public funding. Such a social contract should be based on the following assumptions: The state commits to investments that replace lost oil investments, job guarantees, and income security for everyone in oil-related industries, as well as the active use of state ownership to maintain and bring back domestic industrial operations throughout Norway. Companies commit to suspending dividends for private investors, prioritizing environmentally friendly and long-term investments, and ensuring that contracts go to Norwegian subcontractors and adhere to Norwegian and industry-specific standards for wages and working conditions.

Propose to allocate 500 billion kroner from the Government Pension Fund Global (SPU) as a national green industrial fund for long-term strategic investments in Norwegian industrial production, with the aim of ensuring technological development, increased export of goods, more industrial jobs, enhanced value creation, and more processing in Norway.

Conduct a share buyback in Equinor with the aim of achieving full ownership of the company, discontinue foreign investments in oil and gas projects, and develop the company as an industrial locomotive for value creation in Norway.
Extend the layoff period to 52 weeks to preserve skills in the supplier industry and other sectors.
Ensure that the decision to close the production facility at Strendene in Sandnessjøen is reversed.
Investigate whether the petroleum tax regime should be converted to a pure cash flow taxation on a permanent basis.
Present a case for the landing of oil from the Johan Castberg field to the Storting no later than in connection with the state budget for 2021.

Ensure that oil companies can be provided with liquidity through one of the existing loan schemes established in the spring of 2020, or otherwise provide loans on market terms. The state should assess the climate risk associated with this.

Introduce stricter oversight to avoid scandalous projects, particularly ensuring that overly risky solutions are not chosen that the community has to pay for, and return to the Parliament with this no later than the state budget for 2021.

Design proposals that involve a positive differentiation of climate-friendly investments in the petroleum tax, for example, by granting the free income allowance only to projects that result in real emissions reductions. It should also be considered whether well plugging can benefit from the same differentiation.

Ensure a binding agreement that emissions from oil and gas production on the Norwegian continental shelf are reduced by 50% by 2030 compared to 1990, and return to the Storting with this no later than the revised national budget for 2021.

Engage in dialogue with operators on the Norwegian continental shelf to define a year as a deadline for when all new fields with PUD should have technology with net zero emissions, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Make it a requirement for electrification in the decisions of the PUD. Electrification should be made profitable through an increased CO2 tax. A CO2 fund will be established to which the increased CO2 tax is paid, and which will be used to finance projects aimed at reducing emissions.

Ensure that the rights holders, in light of the improved tax regime for investments and activities, choose contract strategies that emphasize delivery reliability, proximity, Norwegian health, safety, and environment standards, as well as the use of skilled workers and apprentices.

Draft a proposal for a legislative amendment aimed at removing the deductibility of communication work in the special tax for petroleum, and return with this in connection with the state budget for 2021.
Remove the tax-free allowance as long as there is an opportunity for immediate expense deduction.
Investigate the establishment of hydrogen production in Finnmark.
Introduce options for direct expense accounting of investments in offshore wind in 2020 and for five years thereafter.
Introduce an option to receive the tax value of any losses from investments in offshore wind in 2020 and for five years thereafter.

Lower the threshold for when PUDs and PADs should be processed in the Parliament, from 20 billion kroner to 10 billion kroner, and return to the Parliament with this no later than the end of June. The reduced threshold for submissions to the Parliament shall apply for the same duration as the temporary changes to the petroleum tax law.

Ensure that oil companies integrate climate risk into their regular operations and report on this in accordance with the TCFD framework, as is already done for financial investments through the Norwegian Bank and the Government Pension Fund, by the end of 2021.
Map oil wells with unknown positions and return to the Parliament with a focus on developing new technology and commercialization for well plugging.

Present a program for plugging oil wells, managed by the Research Council of Norway. An allocation of 200 million Norwegian kroner will be granted for this purpose in the state budget each year for the next 5 years.

Set requirements for offshore supply vessels regarding low-emission solutions from 2025, zero emissions from 2030, and that the first hydrogen-powered vessel is to be put into operation no later than 2022.
Ensure that oil companies do not pay out dividends as long as a temporary change in the petroleum tax is in effect.
Ensure that oil companies do not buy back their own shares as long as a temporary change in the petroleum tax is in effect.

Enter into an agreement with the industry organization of petroleum companies for 2020 and 2021 to freeze bonus payments and salary growth for senior executives, as long as the temporary change in petroleum tax is in effect.
