Promote a proposal to temporarily amend the Companies Act and the Public Companies Act so that the basis for dividends for 2020 and 2021 is adjusted for the liquidity relief that oil companies receive according to the temporary amendment in the Petroleum Tax Act § 11, first paragraph.

Promote a proposal to limit access for share buybacks for petroleum companies for 2020 and 2021 equivalent to the amount of liquidity relief that petroleum companies receive according to the temporary amendment in the Petroleum Tax Act § 11 first paragraph.
Present a legislative proposal for a solution to secure the landing terminal at Veidnes, which is related to the temporary changes in the petroleum tax law or other similar measures.
To ensure that further prioritization of well plugging is emphasized when the OG21 strategy is to be updated.
Present proposals that ensure zero and low-emission solutions for offshore vessels in petroleum production.

Present a plan for how emissions from oil and gas production on the Norwegian continental shelf are to be reduced by 50% by 2030, compared to 2005, within the framework of current measures. Furthermore, the plan must take into account cost-effective emission reductions, including further electrification of existing fields and low- and zero-emission technology for new fields, as well as considerations for the power system on the mainland. This work is to be completed by the end of 2021.

Establish a committee to investigate the overall framework conditions, including the tax and duty system, to promote climate-friendly investments and long value chains based on renewable resources in Norway. Such investments may include forestry and wood processing, fish and fish processing, carbon capture and storage, hydrogen, offshore wind, and green shipping. The committee's work will be presented to the public within the first half of 2022. The committee will draw on the expertise of the NTNU/Sintef environment in Trondheim.

Clarify to the rights holders that, in light of the improved petroleum tax regime for investments and activities, they should choose contract strategies that emphasize supply security, health and safety standards at least at the Norwegian level, and the use of skilled workers and apprentices.

Ensure that the ripple effects on the mainland are assessed for new developments, and conduct an evaluation of local, regional, and net national ripple effects/employment from new projects covered by the temporary changes in petroleum tax, as well as the use of zero and low-emission technology, and present this to the Parliament in an assessment during the first half of 2023.

Promote a proposal for increased funding for the Labour Inspection Authority and the Petroleum Safety Authority beyond the regular budget adjustment for a total of at least 20 million kroner in the state budget for 2021.

Take the initiative to collaborate with the parties in the labor market for more permanent employees, requirements for the recruitment of apprentices, as well as the further development of strong competence environments based on the oil, gas, and supplier industries, with transferable value to renewable industries.
Investigate whether the banks' credit granting is economically beneficial for society and assess whether a quota system (credit guidance) for the banks' lending to different sectors is appropriate.
Make a new assessment of whether the requirement for an increased systemic risk buffer should be postponed and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Consider how the arrangement with shadow ratings can be reintroduced, and what measures the Parliament and the government can take to achieve this, and return to Parliament with a case on this by spring 2021 at the latest.
Investigate the experiences with the guarantee scheme for loans to small and medium-sized enterprises, and assess similar schemes as part of the business policy.

To adjust the Guarantee Scheme for loans to small and medium-sized enterprises so that it does not exclude businesses contrary to the original intention of the scheme, for example, businesses that have undergone a restructuring and consolidation process to make the company more solid, and additionally to give banks greater discretion in their decision-making.

Ensure that any potential connection to an EU supervisory structure for anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing preserves Norway's room for action and does not involve the relinquishment of sovereignty to EU or EEA bodies.
Investigate the introduction of differentiated system risk buffer requirements and report back to the Storting no later than in connection with the Financial Market Report 2021.

Establish a committee to assess how to increase the market shares of banks and financial institutions based in Norway, and report back to the Parliament with a message on this by spring 2022 at the latest.
Investigate the risks associated with outsourcing the operation of IT systems to foreign entities, and how central ICT providers and data centers can best be subjected to oversight.
Ensure that critical financial IT infrastructure is operated from Norway.
Promote proposals that further reduce banks' ability to take risks outside their core business.
Investigate the establishment of a state green investment bank and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Return to the Storting no later than spring 2021 with a proposal to ban the marketing of consumer loans.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to ban return commissions.
Present a proposal for the introduction of a rent cap in Norway.
Consider a special loan program for banks organized by Norges Bank, as well as an extended maturity for F-loans.
Introduce comprehensive reporting on climate risk, tailored to the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD).
Report on climate risk in the Norwegian economy in each national budget.

Task the Financial Supervisory Authority with conducting stress tests on climate risk in Norwegian financial institutions. The Financial Supervisory Authority must map and analyze the consequences of climate change for financial risk in Norway.

Investigate how the framework conditions and regulation of the financial industry can be changed to promote restructuring and climate cuts, and how climate and climate risk can be given more weight in the credit process.
Come back to the Parliament with a concrete proposal to expand the debt register in connection with the state budget for 2021.

Come back to the Storting no later than spring 2021 with a concrete proposal on how to ensure account number portability in Norway, as well as a proposal for a system for easy transfer of services such as eInvoice and Direct Debit between accounts.
Present a more detailed assessment of the issue of central bank digital currencies.

Investigate whether the Financial Complaints Board can have its mandate expanded, for example, to also handle complaints from organizations, businesses, and companies, possibly organizations and companies below a certain size.
Present a plan that meets the requirements from the business sector that 10% of the workforce should have vocational education by 2030.
Introduce a climate job guarantee to provide relevant work for everyone tailored to the work capacity of selected groups.
Investigate a scheme with a competence account where the company or the public employer commits to setting aside a certain amount earmarked for skills enhancement or climate measures.
Conduct a comprehensive review of the financing system in collaboration with representatives from the sector.
Expand the right to upper secondary education by amending the current law regarding the number of years of upper secondary education, to become a right to complete it.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for changes to the funding system for higher education that strengthen basic funding, rectify the historical imbalances in basic funding between new and old institutions, and provide institutions with incentives to establish study programs in line with regional competence needs.

Suggest how the governance and financing of the sector can contribute to achieving goals such as: better labor market relevance in higher education, improved offerings of further education that meet the demands of the labor market, and more flexible study options that can be combined with work.

Come back to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2021 with proposals that ensure predictable basic funding for the infrastructure and the work on facilitating study programs that take place through local study and education centers.
Create an industry program for the oil and gas industry, and one for the maritime sector.
Investigate a new incentive scheme, Competence Discovery Digital, so that small and medium-sized enterprises can invest in increased digital/technology competence for their employees.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to extend the right to competence assessment to also include adults without the right to upper secondary education.

Establish a joint committee to investigate how employees can acquire a right to skills development throughout their working life, and ensure that union representatives are included in discussions about the skills development that the organization needs.

Establish up to 1,000 new study places in higher vocational education starting from autumn 2020, in addition to making the 1,000 study places that the government announced in Prop. 117 S (2019–2020) permanent, and further develop a binding escalation plan with 1,000 new study places annually over five years.

To present a proposal for a new funding system for universities and colleges. The proposal must be developed in close collaboration with the education sector and the labor market. Incentives/factors in the proposal for the new funding system should include relevant employment after graduation and the relevance of the study to the labor market. Various arrangements for continuing education and professional development. Establishment of smaller and more flexible courses and modules that the labor market demands, which can be taken in combination with work.
Take the initiative to restore a flight service on the route Stord–Oslo.

Compensate Ørland Airport for the loss of income due to the COVID-19 outbreak, with deductions for reduced operating costs, and engage in dialogue with the municipality with the aim of financing the operations of Ørland Airport.

Continue the following previously approved investment projects: E18 Riksgrensen–Ørje in Viken within a revised cost framework of 1,090 million NOK. E18 Knapstad–Retvet in Viken within a revised cost framework of 1,820 million NOK. Rv. 4 Lunner border–Jaren and Lygna south in Innlandet within a revised cost framework of 3,420 million NOK.

Establish the following principles for toll collection on E16 Kongsvinger–Slomarka in Innlandet: The current toll placements at Fulu (county road 250) and Galterud (county road 175) will be maintained. Reduced rates for vehicles in toll group 1 (passenger cars) and toll group 2 (trucks) will continue on county road 175, and for vehicles in toll group 1 (passenger cars) on county road 250. The reduced rate will be half of the rate on E16. The current exemption arrangement for residents in defined areas at Galterud and Fulu will continue. The government will engage in dialogue with Innlandet County Municipality with the intention of signage on the county road over Edsberg indicating No Through Traffic.
Compensate Torp Airport for the loss of income resulting from the COVID-19 outbreak, with deductions for reduced operating costs during the same period.
Not to charge rent for terminals and cranes at Bane NOR's terminals from January 1, 2020, until the end of the year, including reimbursement of rent that has already been paid.
Develop a compensation scheme for the ports for lost user payments (such as quay fees) based on the model of the cash support scheme for businesses.
Remove the requirement for track fees for freight trains during the period from January 1, 2020, until the end of the year, including refunds of track fees that have already been paid.

Establish a guarantee scheme for an additional daily train service for freight transport to and from Malmö, or for other routes where it is assessed that a guarantee scheme could trigger new freight transport by rail.
Remove the requirement for payment of the taxi meter fee for 2020. Those who have already paid must be refunded.

Create a plan for how all counties can have at least one dedicated building preservation center managed by local museums and/or volunteer heritage organizations, and return with proposals for state operational support for these when the government's proposals for preservation strategies are presented to the Parliament.

To develop more detailed guidelines for "special reasons" under the Cultural Heritage Act § 10, assuming that extensions and new constructions of operational buildings on ordinary farms always constitute special reasons for the state to cover the costs of archaeological excavations.

Explain how a large transfer of responsibilities from the Directorate for Cultural Heritage to the county municipalities does not involve a significant transfer of funds from the former to the latter.
Consider whether there would be synergies to be gained by consolidating the sectors in the state that work with cultural heritage, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Establish a permanent protection boundary for the cultural heritage of national minorities, including the cultural heritage of the Kvens, based on the model of the permanent protection boundary for Sámi cultural heritage.

Present a parliamentary report on archaeology in Norway, where the government establishes a stronger focus on research and dissemination, while also considering whether the state should more actively facilitate so-called research excavations and enhance the state funding for such activities.
Consider which measures can be implemented to strengthen the focus on post-Reformation archaeology.

To follow up on the national goal of engagement by ensuring that all member organizations in the Cultural Heritage Federation receive basic support under chapter 1400 item 70 in the national budget or in another suitable manner.
To maintain conservation programs in the field of cultural heritage to achieve the established goals and to promote proposals for deadlines for this.
Promote proposals for goals for cultural heritage policy with specific outcome targets and deadlines, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Present a separate case to the Parliament regarding new conservation strategies in the cultural heritage field (including theme selection, outcome goals, and indicators) while also explaining how it will coordinate and strengthen the relevant economic instruments.
Present a scheduled escalation plan for the funds managed by the Cultural Heritage Fund in Røros.
Promote proposals that ensure the transfer of responsibilities from the Directorate for Cultural Heritage to the county municipalities is fully funded.

Explain how Norway can resume collaboration with other countries to get cultural heritage sites and cultural environments from the Viking Age onto UNESCO's World Heritage List, including an account of which Norwegian sites – including the burial mounds in Borre, Oseberg and Gokstad, as well as the grindstone quarries in Hyllestad – could be relevant as Norway's new contributions.
Promote proposals on how the state can encourage private owners of cultural heritage sites and cultural environments to maintain them consistently and well through tax and fee incentives.

Assuming that one of the new conservation strategies will focus on churches, and that in this context, a goal is set for all stone churches from the Middle Ages to have a standard level of maintenance by the 1,000th anniversary of the Battle of Stiklestad in 2030.
Withdraw the Smittestopp application and ensure that the application is only used for contact tracing and complies with privacy legislation.
Change the Smittestopp application and ensure that those who download the app have the option for shared consent. One for infection tracking and one for data collection.
Promote the necessary proposals to extend the limit for self-determined abortion to include up to and including the 16th week of pregnancy.

Investigate and establish advisory teams across the country, with qualified healthcare personnel who support and guide women and ensure real self-determination for women, as a replacement for the current committee system for abortions after week 12.
Present a case with a proposal to repeal § 2a of the Act of June 13, 1975, No. 50 on abortion.
Present an evaluation of how the current abortion committees function, as well as explore alternative solutions that ensure women's autonomy.
Ensure that women who are to undergo a planned abortion are offered the opportunity to do so at the hospital, if the woman herself wishes it.
Ensure that everyone who experiences a miscarriage is offered follow-up care from healthcare professionals.

Promote a comprehensive plan with short-term and long-term measures to increase the use of non-profit actors across the entire spectrum of health and care services, and present it to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Ensure that the regional health authorities do not acquire or take over the specialist health service offerings of non-profit actors, and that any proposals regarding this must be addressed in corporate meetings.

Promote a comprehensive plan with short-term and long-term measures to increase the use of non-profit actors, as a replacement for commercial actors, across the entire spectrum of health and care services, and present it to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Assign the regional health authorities the task of rotating their strategic plans for sustainable growth, with the requirement that at least 10% of their services should be operated by non-profit actors by 2030.

Ensure that non-profit hospitals receive long-term agreements, and that the health enterprises are tasked with assessing the possibility of expanding the catchment area and new service volume for non-profit hospitals in their development plans.
Ensure that the internal financing models in the regional health enterprises do not provide the health enterprises with financial incentives to exclude non-profit actors.

Ensure that the regional health authorities, when entering into contracts with non-profit actors, require that the service provider cannot change its operational form from non-profit to commercial during the contract period.
Abolish the requirement for increased competition and more purchases of private services through tenders, which was introduced through the reform of free treatment choice.
Promote a proposal to halt the system of activity-based funding (ISF) for 2020, so that all funds allocated under ISF in the national budget are provided as block funding.

Promote the proposals necessary to ensure that politicians at all levels, when receiving severance pay, must adhere to the same rules regarding information obligations, control, activity, and other requirements that the general public faces when receiving benefits from Nav.
Increase the municipal sector's revenues by a minimum of 10-12 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in the Municipal Proposition 2021.
Promote proposals for legislative changes to the Storting that allow municipalities to impose a lower property tax rate for primary residences compared to secondary and vacation homes.
Promote proposals for stricter income equalization in the income system for municipalities.
Increase the growth of the total revenues in the municipal sector by between 7 and 9 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in Prop. 105 S (2019–2020).

Propose suggestions on how the cultural school offerings can be strengthened and further developed, as well as put forward specific measures to: ensure increased participation and accessibility for all children, for example by introducing free cultural school lessons and a maximum price, ensure good framework conditions, for example by establishing a predictable funding scheme and introducing searchable incentive funds, strengthen the practical and aesthetic subjects in schools through enhanced and systematic collaboration between primary education and the cultural school, for example by facilitating more combined positions and introducing competence requirements for teaching in practical and aesthetic subjects, and increase collaboration with the voluntary sector, for example by establishing municipal cultural forums with representatives from kindergartens, primary education, cultural schools, and the voluntary sector.
Reduce the municipalities' own contribution in the scheme for particularly resource-intensive services, so that the state's share increases by approximately 1 billion kroner.

Propose the establishment of incentive funds to create more municipal services based on the model of Stangehjelpa, along with follow-up research that, in addition to mapping quality and accessibility for users, can uncover possible simplifications in reporting and bureaucracy.

Promote proposals for necessary legislative changes that ensure municipalities and county municipalities have full access to the financial flows in companies that perform municipal/county welfare tasks or legally mandated services.
Establish a stable core funding for the coordination function of decentralized higher education, which is currently operated through the study centers.

Increase the municipal sector's revenues by a minimum of 4 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in the Municipal Proposition 2021, of which 1 billion is justified by the maintenance of county roads.
Follow up on the decision from the processing of the state budget for 2020 to expand the pilot program with state funding for elderly care to include six new municipalities.
Change the framework grants to the same model as before 2015, where all municipalities receive an equal basic grant and the small municipality grant is reintroduced.
Propose changes to the income system so that urban grants and growth grants are financed as an addition to the framework without deductions from all municipalities.

Conduct a review of the arrangement for resource-intensive services and ensure that all relevant costs incurred by municipalities in the scheme are included as the basis for the municipal co-payment. Further investigate and present a step 2 in the top financing scheme with a maximum amount per inhabitant, and return to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2021.
Increase the municipal sector's revenues by 3 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in the Municipal Proposition 2021.
Ensure that the reduced wage and price growth from 2020 does not affect the income framework for 2021.
Ensure that there is full compensation at the municipal and county level for the loss of expected tax revenue in the state budget for 2020.
Define crisis centers as national critical societal infrastructure.

Ensure that municipalities and county municipalities are compensated for the effects of tax shortfalls, loss of income, including compensation for the loss of parental fees, and additional expenses related to the coronavirus pandemic.

To ensure that this allocation is distributed such that one third is allocated according to the ferry criteria in the cost key, and two thirds based on ferry connections that have adopted electric ferries as of 2020.

Make new assessments of the need for compensation to the municipal sector in light of new information regarding both additional expenses and loss of income in the municipal sector, developments in tax revenue, and wage/price developments, and return to the Storting in connection with the new adjustment of the state budget for 2020, and if possible, provide an update in the proposal for the state budget for 2021.
Present an analysis of the overall economic consequences of the coronavirus pandemic for the municipal sector in 2020 in the Revised National Budget 2021/municipal proposition 2022.

Review the arrangements for maintenance and investment in the county road network, and consider strengthening these so that the county municipalities can make more investments and maintain the road network to a greater extent than they do today.
Provide an update on the situation for public transport and how the county municipalities are compensated for reduced income due to infection control measures that limit capacity.
Ensure that the funding for volunteer centers continues with a special allocation also after 2021 to secure financing for volunteer centers in both small and large municipalities.

Ensure that the funding for volunteer centers is transferred to a designated grant in the Ministry of Culture's budget from 2021 to secure financing for volunteer centers in both small and large municipalities.
Ensure that there is full compensation for lost income and increased expenses related to the coronavirus situation in municipalities and county municipalities.

Ensure that the municipalities' and county municipalities' unforeseen extra expenses in 2021 related to the COVID-19 situation are addressed through proposals for special appropriations beyond the regular municipal framework.
Ensure that the regional center grant is discontinued, as it is not in line with the Parliament's decision that the income system should not be used to continue the municipal reform.
Postpone changes to the cost-sharing keys for primary education until the follow-up of the expert committee's review of the municipal income system.
Ensure secure e-voting solutions in polling places for the blind and visually impaired in the upcoming municipal/county council elections and parliamentary elections.
Abolish the pilot scheme with state funding for care services.
Facilitate mechanisms in the top funding scheme for resource-intensive services in municipalities that support smaller municipalities with a large number of users of resource-intensive services.

Update the guidelines for the ferry replacement scheme so that ferry connections consisting of multiple routes, where only parts of the connection are relevant for replacement, are calculated as if the entire ferry connection is being replaced, as long as the entire connection is discontinued.
Come back with the proposed changes to the draft budget proposal for 2021.
To quickly assess how to best safeguard Norwegian interests, including the need to initiate an opening process for relevant areas.
Ensure the removal of predators in, and in connection with, the calving areas of domestic reindeer.
Ensure that in connection with the agricultural settlement of 2021, a plan for escalation is developed to strengthen preparedness, self-sufficiency, and rural agriculture.
Increase the grants and investment support for smaller vegetable producers.

Increase the target price for grain without increasing the price reduction for concentrated feed, in order to encourage more sustainable animal husbandry with less use of concentrated feed, and more use of roughage and pasture grazing.
To increase the grazing and grass subsidy in order to shift the feed from concentrated feed to Norwegian-produced grass.
Increase support for the information offices for grains, fruits, and vegetables to stimulate increased demand for Norwegian-produced plant-based food.

Review the customs protection for potatoes, fruits, and vegetables, and consider proposing to change from specific duties to ad valorem duties for fruits and vegetables that can be grown in Norway, as well as for potatoes.

Return to the Storting in 2020 with a new case regarding the cultivation of wetlands, which establishes that conditions for new cultivation should take into account climate, food production, and biodiversity.
To accept the county municipality as a guarantor for the project in Prop. 38 S (2019–2020), as is standard practice for large road projects, and that further progress depends on this.
Engage in dialogue with Viken County Municipality and Oslo Municipality to find agreed solutions to the transportation challenges in the West Corridor.
Review the project with the aim of significant cost reductions and reduced toll fees for motorists.
Review the project with the aim of reducing costs, without leading to reduced road capacity or other disadvantages for motorists.
Evaluate new technologies and alternative solutions that can reduce the cost requirements related to public transport solutions, for example between Fornebu and Lysaker.
Extend the temporary arrangement with full wage compensation (up to 6 G) for a minimum of 20 days in case of layoffs until the end of the year.
Establish a state investment company with the aim of ensuring public ownership in pharmaceutical production.
Extend the improvements in the unemployment benefit regulations through the budget year.
Reintroduce the holiday supplement in the unemployment benefit scheme, with earnings starting from the income year 2020.
Ensure that income from the full wage compensation scheme (up to 6 G) for 20 days during layoffs counts towards the accrual of holiday pay to be paid out in 2021.

Remove the limit of 25,000 kroner in lost income to qualify for support through the compensation scheme for voluntary organizations and sports. This is to include small organizations or organizations with low income in the scheme.

Implement the necessary changes to ensure that the work assessment allowance scheme operates in accordance with the National Insurance Act § 1-1 (Purpose), so that no one loses the right to work assessment allowance before they have been fully assessed for work or benefits.
Return to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2021 with proposals for permanent increases in the rates for social benefits and allowances from the National Insurance Scheme.
Ensure that municipalities exclude the entire child benefit from the income basis in the calculation of social assistance, and allocate funds for compensation for this in the state budget for 2021.
Ensure that the soldiers from the Home Guard's operational units receive the holiday pay they have earned from 2005 onwards.

Ensure that individuals who do not meet the requirements for other income support schemes are provided with financial social assistance regardless of means testing, according to the provision in § 18 of the Social Services Act.

Present a case for the establishment of a six-hour workday fund for the implementation of pilot projects with shorter working hours in municipal management as a measure for increased employment and better working conditions.
To ensure that the price of dental treatment does not increase due to additional costs for infection control.
To ensure that the depot system for washing and issuing of body-close clothing in the Army in Northern Norway is restored.

Expand the scheme so that unemployment benefits are increased to 80% of the benefit basis up to 3 G, and then 62.4% of the benefit basis over 3 G and up to 6 G, to apply to all unemployment benefit recipients. The change will take effect immediately.
To organize cleaning services in the defense sector under the Defense's own management.

Come back in connection with the state budget for 2021 with a proposal to reintroduce a CO2 tax on natural gas and LPG for chemical reduction or electrolysis, metallurgical and mineralogical processes, while also promoting a proposal for CO2 compensation for the industries that will be subject to the tax. The compensation scheme is assumed to be designed in such a way that companies will still have an incentive to reduce their emissions.

Propose a scheme that involves converting the entire additional loan for students who can document loss of income due to the pandemic into a grant, cf. the decision on additional loans with partial conversion to grants for students as addressed in Innst. 233 S (2019–2020).

Expand the number of resettled refugees in 2020 by 1,500 and as quickly as possible, preferably in 2020, bring 1,500 individuals among unaccompanied minors, families with children, and other vulnerable groups from Moria and other refugee camps in Greece.

Reorganize the entire new chapter 576 Maintenance and Rehabilitation, new item 60 Maintenance and Rehabilitation so that the maintenance, rehabilitation, and upgrading of buildings and facilities contribute to environmental upgrading, energy efficiency, and market growth for green buildings and environmental rehabilitation that exceed the current regulatory requirements.
Investigate and assess the right of reversion for access to the community's natural resources, both for quotas on wild populations and for concessions for aquaculture sites.
Expand the organizer support scheme to also compensate the entire supply chain for concerts and performing arts events.

Ensure that the working group responsible for providing professional assessments of the economic consequences that the coronavirus outbreak has had for the municipalities delivers interim reports until they submit their final report by April 1, 2021, including updated data in connection with the processing of the state budget for 2021.
Ensure that municipalities and county municipalities are fully compensated for the total effects of tax shortfalls, loss of income, and additional expenses related to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Make new assessments of the need for compensation to the municipal sector in light of new information regarding both additional expenses and loss of income in the municipal sector, developments in tax revenue, and wage/price developments, and submit proposals for this to the Parliament early in the autumn of 2020, as well as in connection with the reallocation of the state budget for 2020.

Investigate the appropriateness of a change to § 11-7 of the Local Government Act to map the potential and consequences of increased digital implementation of meetings in elected bodies at the municipal and county level.

Change the terms of the government's compensation scheme so that it better meets the needs of children's and youth organizations, allowing significantly more of LNU's member organizations than today to apply for compensation for lost income due to the coronavirus outbreak.

Change the rules for receiving compensation as a seasonal business in the cultural sector, so that the scheme is more effective, including by removing the requirement that the activity takes place outdoors, and by lowering the 80% requirement for the share of revenue within a period of a maximum of six months.
Increase the sub-requirement for advanced biofuels from July 1, 2020, beyond the proposed requirement of 6.1%, in order to reduce the risk of blending biofuels with a high deforestation risk.
Present a final analysis of the overall economic consequences of the coronavirus pandemic for the municipal sector in 2020 in the revised national budget 2021/municipal proposition 2022.

Develop a scheme with a basic salary based on an annual income of 2 G, which can be paid out immediately during periods of long processing times and delayed benefit payments. Once the application has been fully processed and the benefit has been calculated, the applicant should receive any outstanding amount for the period as a retroactive payment.

Increase the requirement for the share of advanced biofuels within the blending mandate to a level that ensures that conventional biofuels make up a maximum of 6%, in order to avoid the use of biofuels with a high deforestation risk.

Come back with a proposal for a new model for option taxation for startups where qualifying businesses have up to 50 full-time equivalents, a maximum revenue of 70 million kroner, and where companies up to 12 years old are included.
Ensure that the local developer's negotiated contract is executed with a start in the fall of 2020.

Start planning the construction of a bypass in Kongsvinger and propose funding to realize the construction project in connection with the state budget for 2021. In this context, a strategy will be developed to establish an international freight corridor through Kongsvinger.
Develop a plan for the expansion of high-speed broadband and return with this in connection with the state budget for 2021.
Ensure that all laid-off and unemployed individuals maintain the temporary conditions and unemployment benefit rates throughout 2020.
Change the regulations for Jobbsjansen so that women who are dependent on social assistance can also participate in the program.
Ensure that supplier costs are also covered in the compensation scheme for events, so that the entire value chain of the event is taken care of.
Remove the requirement for a minimum income of 25,000 kroner in the compensation scheme for events.
Establish a targeted grant scheme that ensures that literature houses and similar institutions and foundations are compensated for the loss of income they depend on, which is currently absent.
Ensure a separate compensation scheme for non-profit organizations that have lost income due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Take the initiative for a new high-speed rail study for the most relevant routes in Norway and abroad, towards Stockholm and Gothenburg.

Propose a government-funded job creation program in the state budget for 2021. The program should create new climate-friendly jobs, for example, in climate adaptation in municipalities, in agriculture, and in nature restoration.
Ensure that those who were laid off or unemployed before the coronavirus outbreak receive the same terms and unemployment benefit rates as those who were laid off after March 2020.
Investigate the possibility of a state-owned green hydrogen company.
Task Enova with establishing a national support scheme for charging in housing cooperatives, condominiums, and garage associations.
Create an application pool for immediate development for pedestrian and cycling facilitation in municipalities and county municipalities.
Ensure that the funding intended to cover 80% of sales revenue for pre-approved action organizers is made into a provisional grant so that everyone is guaranteed compensation of 80%.
Extend the scheme for work assessment allowance to apply until the end of 2020.

Come back to the Parliament with a review of the backlog and increased health queues that have arisen as a consequence of COVID-19, where they account for the extra costs incurred by the healthcare service if this is to be addressed, and to what extent all parts of the healthcare service have contributed to solving any capacity shortages, including private actors.

Utilize the exception provision in the law on the Government Pension Fund § 7 third paragraph and make temporary borrowings to cover the extraordinary budget expenses related to COVID-19, at least to avoid selling assets in the Government Pension Fund Global.

Present permanent legal and regulatory changes that ensure that people who need financial social assistance do not have to sell necessary assets that are common in society, deplete their children's savings accounts, or face demands that exacerbate the crisis and make the path back to work or normal daily life more difficult.
Accelerate the construction of state ships that are already planned, including five mine countermeasure vessels for the Navy.

Consider various models for the allocation of areas and subsidies for floating offshore wind and return to the Storting with proposals for necessary legislative changes no later than in its proposal for the state budget for 2021.
Make the arrangement for a start depreciation of 30% for asset group d permanent.
Extend the layoff period to 52 weeks.
Ensure that the rules regarding the extension of the period for work assessment allowance are followed up by Nav locally.
Establish pediatric palliative care teams across the country to ensure that seriously ill children and their families have more time together.
Ensure that Nordland School of Art and Film is incorporated into one of the country's universities.
Investigate an increase in the natural resource tax to ensure greater local returns from hydropower.
Establish a state acquisition fund aimed at securing national ownership in companies of strategic importance for the future business landscape in Norway.
Set a target of at least 2 GW of installed capacity in floating offshore wind by 2025 and 30 GW by 2040.
Return to the Storting with a proposal for favorable depreciation rules for all offshore wind projects until 2030.

Investigate the need for a state-owned floating offshore wind company, Statvind, and report back to the Parliament with proposals for its establishment and structure in an appropriate manner no later than the proposal for the state budget for 2021.
Raise the VTA rates to correspond to the average salary, 5,200 kroner per month per VTA position, and that this applies as long as the temporary rates for unemployment benefits are in effect.

Investigate the possibility of establishing new state-owned companies in renewable industries, with the aim of ensuring national and strategic ownership and long-term capital for green business and industrial projects, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Ensure that the funds under chapter 560 item 60 can also be used for landslide protection of county roads.
Establish a grant scheme to trigger investments in water and sewage in municipalities with significant needs for improvements.
Make the compensation scheme for the cultural sector a provisional grant, so that all organizers entitled to compensation receive it.
Develop a plan for the maintenance of water and sewage systems and return with this in connection with the state budget for 2021.
Return to the state budget for 2021 with a plan for full financing of Mo i Rana Airport until completion in 2023.
Set a goal that unemployment in Norway should be at least as low at the end of 2021 as it was at the end of 2019.

Ensure a compensation scheme for Norwegian domestic aviation, either by including aviation in the compensation scheme established for businesses, or by establishing a separate equivalent scheme for aviation. When granting support to airlines, conditions must be set that they pay out outstanding amounts to package tour operators and passengers as soon as possible.

Withdraw the proposal to introduce a tax on biofuels beyond the blending requirement, and present a new case to the Parliament that effectively contributes to stopping the use of palm oil in the production of biodiesel.

Return to the Parliament in connection with the new budget adjustments for 2020 with compensation for the additional expenses incurred due to the delays in the co-location in the new veterinary building in Ås.
Make an assessment of which additional flight routes should be part of the FOT routes, so that the flight service is maintained throughout the country.
Remove the deductible in the compensation scheme for the application months of March and April.
Ensure financial compensation to companies for permanently adapted work.
Ensure financial compensation for businesses that do not have "profit as a purpose" and that are not sufficiently covered by other compensation schemes.

Draft requirements stating that businesses that have received support under the compensation scheme must, upon request, be able to document that the fixed costs included in the application for and the calculation basis for the allocation of support to the individual business have actually been paid.
Include all government-mandated maintenance costs for businesses that have an operating license in accordance with the Act on Amusement Devices and the Act on Cable Cars.
Come back with an update on the work to strengthen the local Nav offices in the state budget for 2021.

Ensure the presence of a military multi-role helicopter stationed in Kirkenes from July 16, 2020, which combines military capacity with support for the police and ambulance services for the population in East Finnmark, in order to strengthen preparedness in Northern Norway and in the border area with Russia.
Ensure appropriate security measures for the Police University College's education center in Kongsvinger (including fences and barriers for access control).

To enter into an agreement with the national industry for the completion of the Vanguard concept with the aim of starting construction of the first vessel in 2021, and to request the government to return with a proposal for the financial framework for the project and funding for the start of construction in the proposed state budget for 2021.
Propose to exempt the police from VAT and one-time fees on specially equipped vehicles.
Consider measures to ensure better continuity in investments in police vehicles.
Establish a risk mitigation scheme for payment guarantees similar to the scheme with credit insurance for GIEK.
Exempt tax-free from the compensation scheme starting from the application month of May.

Ensure that no funds are allocated in the spring of 2020 to establish a children's hospice, but that this is postponed until the Parliament has addressed Report No. St. 24 (2019–2020) on Palliative Treatment and Care in the fall of 2020.

Extend the temporary exemption from airport fees until the end of the year and ask the government to return with a more detailed assessment of the need for compensation for Avinor in connection with the state budget for 2021.

Investigate a rights-based wage subsidy scheme for employers who hire individuals with partial work capacity, which includes new or previously employed individuals who have been assessed through the AAP scheme.

Change the compensation scheme to be an event compensation, and not just organizer compensation, so that it includes all businesses, including subcontractors, that are directly affected by the authorities' event bans and restrictions.
Ensure that it is the actual activity and not the organizational form that determines whether an organizer can apply for compensation for organizers in the cultural sector.
Ensure that today's distribution key for compensation from aquaculture licenses remains in place until a new distribution key comes into effect in 2022.

Conduct a review of the system and principles for the sale and auction of production capacity in the aquaculture industry, analyzing and proposing measures to maintain and further develop a strong and diverse ownership in the aquaculture sector.

Change the compensation scheme for media companies as follows: The media will receive coverage for up to 80% of the loss of advertising revenue during the period from March 1 to July 1, 2020, compared to the same period in 2019. Media companies that experience a decline in advertising of less than 20% during this period will not receive compensation. The maximum support amount per media company is set at 15 million kroner.
Consider an expansion and strengthening of the government contribution to the travel guarantee fund to ensure that trust in the scheme is maintained.
Continue the 400 temporary police positions that were added to the agency as a consequence of the coronavirus pandemic, and make these permanent in connection with the state budget for 2021.

Investigate and propose changes to laws and/or regulations that ensure the industry stable framework conditions that utilize the flexibility within the EEA Agreement, including tariff models that reflect the value that large, stable consumers have for the grid. Tariffing of industry based on the same principles, regardless of network level, must also be included.
Reestablish the housing establishment grant scheme in the districts as a new three-year initiative and return to the Storting with a proposal in the state budget for 2021.
Present a proposal for more places in the youth unit in the correctional service in Eidsvoll in the upcoming state budget.
Present a proposal for an exit program from criminal environments, based on collaboration with volunteers, in the upcoming state budget.
Compensate the municipal sector for lost tax revenues in 2020 compared to estimated revenues in the national budget for 2020.

Ensure that more small actors receive compensation by lowering the minimum payout threshold and removing the deductible. If necessary, this could be financed by a lower maximum compensation limit for regular businesses and corporations.

Develop standards that facilitate the certification of the reuse of existing building materials, as well as assess measures that make it more difficult to demolish buildings and support the reuse of existing building stock.
Create a special program for circular economy, a Pilot S, based on the model of Pilot E.

Ensure that Gassnova/ClimitDemo can provide investment support for the realization of full-scale CO2 capture, utilization, and storage beyond the projects that are currently part of Northern Lights. Hydrogen from natural gas should be able to be included in the program.

Facilitate the use of the local developer's negotiated contract for the construction of a new airport in Mo i Rana, where Rana municipality's contribution of 450 million kroner is included in the financing of the first phase. The government is requested to return to the financing of the airport in the state budget for 2021.

Determine the tax-free income in the resource rent taxation as the sum of a risk-free interest rate equivalent to the government bond rate with a 10-year maturity plus a risk premium, so that the normal return is shielded and the extraordinary earnings are taxed.

To withdraw the loan allocation to the New Oslo University Hospital until the group that is to examine emergency medical preparedness at the new Oslo University Hospital has completed its work, and a financial assessment of additional orders after the concept study has been made.
Support the initiative for the X-Games 2021 with plans for summer sports in Håkons Hall and winter sports in Hafjell, and present a proposal for funding for this in the state budget for 2021.

Change the mandate for Enova so that Enova can provide support for technologies that have existed for a long time but are commercially immature and where the volumes are still small, such as investment support for technology used in the production and application of renewable hydrogen.

Change the requirements related to § 3-1 fifth paragraph in the regulations on the compensation scheme for businesses with significant revenue decline, so that the requirement for additional control actions is exempted in cases where an external authorized accountant has performed ongoing bookkeeping and/or prepared mandatory financial reports for the period.

Exempt companies that own fishing vessels registered in the Register of Marked Norwegian Fishing Vessels (the marking register) from the requirement to have employees in the compensation scheme for businesses with significant revenue decline.

Facilitate the use of the local developer's negotiated contract for the construction of a new airport in Mo i Rana, with Rana municipality's contribution of 450 million kroner included in the financing of the first phase. The government is requested to return to the financing of the airport in the state budget for 2021, which should also consider how to ensure the viability of other airports in the area.
Work quickly and make the necessary clarifications needed to realize the planned airport in Mo i Rana.
Establish a interest compensation scheme for the necessary development and maintenance of water and sewage facilities.

Come back to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2021 regarding the expansion with six new municipalities into the trial of state funding for the care and nursing sector, so that the Parliament can then decide which six municipalities will be offered to participate in the scheme.

Come back in the state budget for 2021 with an assessment of whether the ship guarantee scheme should be extended beyond the three-year trial period 2018–2020, including considering an increased duration.

Come back in an appropriate manner with a plan, including financial and administrative consequences, for establishing a joint police station with the Swedish police at Magnormoen. The expenses for both Swedish and Norwegian police must be outlined. The Parliament requests the government to collaborate with Swedish authorities on the plan for the building, the organization of police cooperation, and the distribution of costs.

Include subcontractors within the technical field in the compensation scheme for canceled cultural events, so that they can apply for compensation for lost income due to the cancellation or closure of events in the cultural sector. The government will establish further terms and conditions for inclusion in the scheme.
Keep track of the situation for top football and grassroots sports, and continuously assess whether there is a need for adjustments to existing arrangements.

Monitor the situation, including assessing the need to extend the loan and grant scheme, and consider additional measures if a situation arises where many travelers do not have their claims covered in the event of the tour operator's bankruptcy.

Come back with an assessment of the situation for the tourism industry, proposals for measures tailored to the situation, and the management of any new schemes no later than in connection with the state budget for 2021. Measures must comply with the rules of the EEA Agreement. It is assumed that the measures are considered in conjunction with the already proposed restructuring measures for the tourism industry amounting to 250 million kroner.

Assess whether there is a need for supplementary arrangements for solid, large companies that initially have a healthy operation but lack the necessary liquidity due to the virus outbreak. All arrangements of this type must comply with EEA regulations and be approved by ESA.

Investigate and assess changes to the shipping tax scheme so that companies within the scheme, in addition to activities that qualify for shipping taxation, can also engage in activities that are not eligible for support and will be taxed normally. The status of the matter should be addressed in connection with the state budget for 2021.

Send out for consultation proposals for changes to the value-added tax regulations for contracts so that during the period until the work is completed, the obligation to issue sales documents only arises if partial payments are received for completed work or materials supplied to the contract object. There should be room for the parties to arrange themselves so that the contractor does not need to report and pay value-added tax on disputed claims along the way, that is, until the project is completed. The Parliament requests the government to submit proposals in line with this in connection with the presentation of the state budget for 2021.

Present changes to the regulations for camper vans that allow the number of seating places to exceed the number of sleeping places. The other criteria will be adjusted as needed. The Parliament requests the government to return with proposals for changes as soon as possible and no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.
Ensure a revenue-neutral restructuring of the one-time fee for motorhomes in connection with the transition to WLTP as the measurement method for CO2 emissions starting in 2021.

Ensure that the regional health authorities utilize the combined capacity in the health region, including that of private providers, to address the healthcare queues and backlog that have arisen due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Ensure that the municipal sector is allocated 2.25 billion kroner for the capacity adjustment in 2020 and 1 billion kroner in 2021. Furthermore, the Storting requests that starting from 2022, a distribution of 40 percent to the municipal sector and 60 percent to the state is established.
Remove the minimum payout amount in the compensation scheme.

Create a model for calculating the compensation basis that better accommodates businesses with significant seasonal variations. The calculation should, as far as possible, be based on the following principles: Calculate the company's average monthly revenue from March 1, 2019, to March 1, 2020, as the total revenue divided by 12. Then calculate a monthly factor for how much revenue each of the months of March, April, and May in 2019 represented of the total revenue for the last 12 months. It is then calculated what percentage of the revenue each of these months represents compared to the corresponding months in 2019. The compensation for fixed costs per month in March, April, and May is calculated as a factor x total fixed costs for the period from March 1, 2019, to March 1, 2020, x 90%. The scheme should ensure that if, for example, 40% of the annual revenue is generated in April, 90% of 40% of the annual fixed costs should be covered in that month.

Introduce a general and industry-independent model for businesses with significant seasonal variations in revenue, based on the calculation model for determining support that the government has outlined, but where the requirement for the business to be conducted entirely or partially outdoors is removed, and where the proportion of revenue in the peak season to qualify for the scheme is reduced to 70%.
Include depreciation in the compensation scheme from the application month of May.
Include installments in the compensation scheme from the application month of May.
Remove the requirement that sole proprietorships must be the main source of income in order to receive support.

Include costs for a certain minimum staffing or key personnel in areas such as finance, payroll and HR, legally required maintenance, security, and cleaning as fixed unavoidable costs in the compensation scheme for the benefit month of May.
Define independent businesses within the same sole proprietorship as separate entities if separate accounts are maintained.
Define separate business areas within the same limited company as independent entities if separate accounts are maintained.

Clarify the scope of the compensation scheme, including the extent and consequences of having, through correspondence with ESA, moved away from the requirement that the revenue decline must be linked to the virus outbreak and the infection control measures implemented in Norway, and limited to companies' activities in Norway, and report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner.
Maintain towards ESA that it is important to compensate for income loss for companies' activities in Norway, and that any coverage beyond this should be determined by Norwegian authorities.
Notify the continuation of the low VAT rate of 6% until the end of 2021.
Design arrangements that support the tourism industry, initially until the end of 2020.
Ensure that changes are made to the compensation scheme for the application month of May that better support small businesses.
Expand the definition of fixed costs to ensure that more businesses fall under the compensation scheme, thereby helping to avoid job losses.

Introduce a general and industry-independent model for covering government-mandated maintenance costs based on the current limitations of the compensation scheme, which includes both maintenance services that are purchased/leased and documented necessary labor costs for businesses that carry out maintenance in-house.
Consider special measures to reach newly established businesses that fall outside the current compensation scheme.

Ensure that all unemployed individuals who have not been granted wage compensation or unemployment benefits by July 1 receive an immediate advance of 20,000 kroner. This advance should not result in deductions from other benefits from Nav other than wage compensation and unemployment benefits, nor should it be required to be repaid.
Ensure that individuals who still do not have a decision on wage compensation or unemployment benefits by June 30 have access to an advance scheme until their applications are processed.
Suspend the construction of licensed wind power plants until the Parliament has addressed a new licensing system for onshore wind power.

Revoke granted land-based wind power concessions where one or more of the following conditions are met, in developments that have not been initiated: a) that the concession has been granted in an area free from intervention and/or destroys important natural values, as is the case on Haramsøya b) that the affected municipalities have opposed the relevant project during the concession processing before the MTA plan was approved c) that a given concession conflicts with the rights of indigenous peoples as defined in the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples.
Stop the construction of the wind power plant on Haramsøya.

Assess whether the handling of the given wind power concessions has followed the energy legislation and the requirements of the Administrative Act. If there are errors or deficiencies in the concession that are in conflict with the requirements of the legislation, the administration must halt the decision.
Do not grant an extension for commissioning beyond December 31, 2021, for onshore wind farms that currently have a valid license.
Refrain from processing new applications for wind power concessions until the Parliament has addressed the announced white paper on changes to the concession processing for onshore wind power.
Propose a ban on the chartering of private jets and the use of private aircraft for transportation that is not justified by considerations of life, health, and safety.
Investigate tax deductions for tenants' rental costs for their own housing purposes.
Promote a proposal to introduce a redistributive upper limit on the tax deduction for interest on mortgage loans.
Make Norway a leading country that stands up against an international race to the bottom in taxation and gradually increase the tax on corporate profits.
Ensure that tax-funded welfare services are operated by public and non-profit actors, and present a plan for the gradual increase of public and non-profit ownership and operation.
Investigate the introduction of a fair and progressive tax on luxury inheritances, to prevent the formation of dynasties, where power and enormous fortunes are passed down tax-free.
Remove the possibility of taking tax-free dividends by eliminating the shielding deduction.
Ensure that Equinor permanently halts its share buyback program.
Present a parliamentary report on tax policy, which assesses several differentiated and progressive taxes based on economy and geography.
Ensure that municipalities exclude the entire child benefit from the income basis in the calculation of social assistance, and allocate funds for compensation for this.
Present an annual parliamentary report on the development of union membership and measures to strengthen organized labor.
Ensure that Norwegian collective agreements and Norwegian labor legislation take precedence over EU regulations.
Conduct a power investigation with particular emphasis on structures and the balance of power in the labor market.
Promote a proposal to introduce a more progressive wealth tax with an increased rate for large fortunes and a higher basic deduction.
Investigate alternatives to the exemption method that ensure that owner income is taxed continuously.
Present concrete measures aimed at reducing inequality, as a consequence of the fact that inequality in Norway is too high.
Present a comprehensive review of the distributional effects of changes in the tax and duty system since 2013.
Present comprehensive assessments of the development of inequality and the actual distribution of wealth and income in Norway.
Maintain the arrangement for supplementary pensions for survivors ("widow's pension").
Reverse the cut in glasses support for children and young people under 18 years old.

Present changes to the tax system that uphold the Parliament's historical intention of a progressive tax system where the average tax rate increases with rising income, including for the wealthiest 1%, in order to ensure that all taxpayers pay taxes according to their ability.
Investigate the effect that the use of tenders has on working conditions and wage formation, both for employees and managers, especially in public transport and railways.
Ensure that the tax regime for the petroleum industry prevents socio-economically unprofitable investments, and as quickly as possible present proposals for changes that ensure this is upheld.
Present a parliamentary report with a binding action plan for the restoration of 15 percent of degraded ecosystems in Norway.
Carry out the relocation of asylum seekers from Greece to Norway as quickly as possible, and increase the number to significantly more than 50 in 2020.

Give the health enterprises a clearer instruction to increase the proportion of full-time positions in the health enterprises, and as a consequence, to not appeal the case against the nurses in Østfold who wish for full-time positions, but instead accept the decision of the dispute resolution board.
To follow the request of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees regarding how many quota refugees Norway should accept.
Follow the recommendations of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees in shaping Norwegian asylum and refugee policy.

Not to award any new oil or gas fields to the oil companies, either through the 25th licensing round or in any other way, until the Supreme Court has addressed the climate lawsuit from Nature and Youth, Greenpeace, the Norwegian Society for the Conservation of Nature, and the Grandparents' Climate Action.
Promote proposals to eliminate the under-regulation of pensions.

Implement measures to ensure that irreversible interventions in nature are not made where the construction of wind power plants has already begun, or where such constructions will be initiated, before the review requested by the Parliament on June 19 of the granted wind power concessions has been completed.

Investigate the consequences for those affected by the cuts in disability benefits that resulted from the government's unfair recalculation model from the old to the new disability scheme. The results of the investigation shall be presented to the Parliament no later than together with the proposal for the revised national budget in 2021.

Instruct Health South-East to promptly carry out a comprehensive and genuine investigation of the Ullevål alternative during the period when responses are awaited from the Planning and Building Agency in Oslo regarding the plans that have so far been approved. Particular attention must be given to infection control, potential new pandemics, and the sufficient future need for hospital bed capacity in the assessment.
Stop the planning of a third runway at Gardermoen.
To initiate a renegotiation of the Chicago Convention of 1944 on international civil aviation, so that international air travel can take its share of climate commitments.
Implement a project on the transfer of tasks from the county governor to the county municipalities that do not involve control, complaints, or supervision.
Stop the reduction in service offerings at the Norwegian Public Roads Administration's traffic stations.
To ensure that all healthcare institutions provide adequate support services to all women who have more than 1.5 hours of travel time to a maternity facility.
Present a plan to increase CO2 uptake in Norwegian forest areas.
Promote a case for the Storting where the state takes over the guarantee responsibility for toll road loans on national roads, both for current and future projects.
Facilitate the possibility of reversing the merger of counties if the counties request it.
Strengthen the staffing of the local police and the frontline emergency response in the police.
Extend the contract with Lufttransport RW for the continuation of the covid19 helicopter service in Tromsø.
Present a report on Norway's relationship with the EU in the energy sector.
Ensure that the shared municipal journal solution Akson is quality assured through a public hearing.
Compensate municipalities and county municipalities fully for the effects of tax shortfalls, loss of income, and additional expenses related to the coronavirus pandemic.
Ensure that higher education institutions emphasize their regional responsibility and decentralized education throughout the country.

Ensure a mapping of public authorities' handling of visiting restrictions and visiting bans in homes for the elderly and disabled during the coronavirus pandemic, either as a separate investigation or by clarifying the mandate of the coronavirus commission to include this.

Develop proposals for economic models for the development of new, effective antibiotics that reward drug development, not sales and use, where both reward mechanisms and fees/taxes are considered as tools.

Promote a proposal to cap the self-cost of building application fees, based on the most efficient municipalities, to ensure that residents receive cost- and time-effective services in building matters.
Implement measures that will collectively contribute to eliminating the effects of annual under-regulation of pensions.

Implement a comprehensive review of Norwegian aid funds that have been allocated to countries that are at a red level (38 points and below) on Transparency International's corruption index, in order to uncover how much aid money is being misused. The Parliament further requests that the government return with the results of the review, and at the same time present proposals on how the Ministry of Foreign Affairs can better ensure that aid funds do not disappear into or contribute to corruption.
"To 'Investigate a certification scheme for teachers and possible protection of the teacher title during the period'."

Promote the necessary legal amendment that establishes that no municipalities can place individuals between the ages of 0 and fifty in nursing homes against their will. For children, the wishes of the closest relatives must apply.
Propose amendments to the law to ensure that old-age pensions in payment are adjusted according to the actual average of price and wage growth.

Promote a case to the Parliament with concrete proposals that will increase the level of organization in the labor market, including closer and more binding tripartite cooperation and a doubling of the union deduction.
Propose to regulate ongoing pensions with the average of wages and prices, while simultaneously reversing the wealth tax cut that was enacted in June of this year.

Promote proposals for amendments to the pension schemes in the private sector that ensure pension accrual starts from the first kroner earned in salary, that accrual is granted for lower working percentages than 20 percent, and that membership in pension schemes is also provided for individuals under 20 years of age.
Propose changes to the National Insurance Act that involve reintroducing the holiday supplement for those receiving unemployment benefits.

Promote a proposal to remove the introduced waiting period in the AAP scheme and ensure that individuals who have not been fully assessed by NAV and/or the healthcare system by the end of the period during which they can receive work assessment allowance are granted the right to an extension.

Extend the temporary changes to the unemployment benefit regulations, as well as the income security schemes for apprentices and self-employed individuals that were adopted in March, until March 31, 2021.
Create guidelines for the proper use of emergency shifts in connection with COVID-19.
Ensure national guidelines for how non-profit actors with agreements with health enterprises should be compensated for loss of income and any additional costs related to COVID-19.

Continue to take national responsibility for coordinating the procurement and control of infection control equipment throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, to ensure that hospitals and municipalities have sufficient infection control equipment.
Promote proposals to prevent individuals who have to stay home from work to care for children as a consequence of national or local infection control measures from losing income.
Present a proposal to increase the minimum pensions.
Establish a national plan for the rehabilitation of individuals who have undergone COVID-19 and require retraining.

Develop clear guidelines for how vulnerable children and youth, individuals with substance abuse issues, people with disabilities, those with severe mental health disorders, and other at-risk groups should be supported in the event of a new lockdown.
Make concrete assessments of increased public access when requesting insight into the total patient numbers for each health region in connection with COVID-19.

Establish an expert committee to review the Norwegian child welfare system with the aim of improving legal security at all levels of the service, where the consideration of the child's best interests shall be the foundation of the committee's work.
To ensure that engineering programs, teacher education programs, and other in-demand fields of study in the labor market have the appropriate funding.
Make the scientific basis for new infection control measures publicly available before they are announced.
Change the conditions for unemployment benefits so that they only cease when the workload exceeds 80% of normal working hours.
Increase companies' wage obligation during layoffs to 15 days, effective from July 1, 2021.
Ensure that all unemployment benefit recipients receive a compensation rate of 80% of income up to 3 G, effective from October 1, 2020.

Continue the arrangement with full wage compensation for 20 days until the end of the year, so that the state from September 1, 2020, covers full wages for 10 days in addition to the companies' wage obligation for 10 days.

Extend the temporary compensation benefit for apprentices to new cases for the rest of the year, and from November 1, 2020, provide full compensation for all laid-off apprentices for income up to 3 G.

Establish production facilities for ship hulls over 75 meters, in connection with the existing shipbuilding industry, to reclaim a larger share of the maritime value creation that takes place in Norway.
Ensure that extraordinary maintenance is carried out on all ships in public ownership, with the condition that the work is conducted at Norwegian shipyards.
To extend the temporary extensions of the benefit periods for recipients of work assessment allowance until the end of the year.
Allocate funds to the Institute of Marine Research to build the 'coastal research vessel South' on the condition that the contract is awarded to Norwegian shipyards.
Establish a support scheme for county municipal investment in electric ferries, where construction contracts are awarded to shipyards and manufacturing companies in Norway.
Continue the reduced minimum income requirement to qualify for unemployment benefits until the end of the year.
Extend the benefit period until the end of the year for unemployment benefit recipients who had 19 weeks or fewer left in their benefit period at the end of June 2020.
Extend the temporary compensation benefit for self-employed individuals and freelancers until the end of the year with an 80% compensation rate.
Establish a decommissioning scheme for retired offshore vessels, with the condition that the recycling takes place at Norwegian shipyards.
Increase Enova's grants for climate measures in the industry.
Establish a system of unemployment benefits for students based on the model for individuals who have recently graduated from military service.

Return to the Parliament with a scheme that ensures that students who experienced a loss of income between June 16 and December 31, 2020, can benefit from the same arrangement of extra loans and conversion to grants that applied to students in the spring of 2020.
Ensure that new, clear projects that fall under the decentralized scheme for cultural buildings receive support, in accordance with the new framework for the scheme for 2020.
Extend the temporary rules for graded unemployment benefits in agriculture, etc., and the temporary rules for laid-off skilled workers from third countries.
Set conditions for increasing the blending requirement from 0.5% to 1% advanced biofuels.
Extend the reduced requirement for lost working hours to 40% also for new cases.

Continue the measures in the temporary regulation regarding exceptions from the National Insurance Act and the Working Environment Act in connection with COVID-19, which concerns recipients of work assessment allowance.

Change the model for businesses with significant seasonal variations in revenue retroactively, so that the requirement for the business to be conducted entirely or partially outdoors is removed, and the percentage of revenue during peak season required to qualify for the scheme is reduced to 70%.
Extend the scheme to maintain logging activity in forestry until July 1, 2021.
Change the support scheme for public events so that applications for funding can be made regardless of whether the event was planned to be open to the public or not.
Abolish the requirement that events must have been canceled in order to receive support under the compensation scheme for cultural events.
Abolish the requirement that assignments and events must have been planned before March 12, 2020, in order to receive support under the compensation scheme for cultural events.
Reduce the lower limit in the compensation scheme for culture, volunteering, and sports from 25,000 kroner to 10,000 kroner.

Adjust the model for coverage of government-mandated maintenance costs so that it includes all government-mandated maintenance, including maintenance services that are purchased/leased, and documented necessary labor costs for businesses that carry out the maintenance in-house.
Extend the period used for calculating statutory maintenance costs to the period from March 12 to October 31, 2020.
Extend the period for when seasonal businesses can carry out maintenance to March 31, 2021.

Follow up that the grant for refund obligations for canceled and canceled package trips during the period from March 14 to June 14, 2020, as decided in connection with the revised national budget 2020, can amount to up to 80% of the refunds, and that the next distribution round will be implemented as soon as possible.
Adjust the guarantee scheme for loans to small and medium-sized enterprises by increasing the maximum loan term from 3 to 6 years.
Ensure that all unemployment benefit recipients receive a compensation rate of 80% of income up to 3 G, effective from October 1, 2020, and until further notice.

Transform the proposed grant scheme for municipalities that aims to compensate businesses affected by extensive local infection control measures into an application-based grant scheme for businesses impacted by such measures, where the businesses can receive support based on the same model that is applied in the new compensation scheme for the tourism industry.
