Come back by the end of 2020 with a proposal for a stabilization package for aviation, with economic framework conditions that safeguard airlines based in Norway, including measures that ensure seriousness and orderly wage and working conditions in aviation.
Set conditions that there should be permanent positions with direct employment in the airline.
Set conditions for compliance with home-based rules that clearly define employer responsibility, social responsibility, and Norwegian labor law legislation.
Set conditions that convenience flags or subsidization of foreign subsidiaries will not be accepted.
Ensure income security schemes for students who can demonstrate loss of income in the fall of 2020, within the framework of the Parliament's allocation.
Ensure that recipients of grants from the compensation scheme for organizers and subcontractors cannot pay bonuses to senior executives for the remainder of 2020 and in 2021.
Ensure that recipients of grants from the compensation scheme for organizers and subcontractors commit to not increasing executive salaries or board fees for the remainder of 2020 and in 2021.

Ensure that recipients of grants from the compensation scheme for organizers and subcontractors cannot have parent companies in third-country jurisdictions that are on the EU's blacklist of non-cooperative jurisdictions.
Ensure that recipients of grants from the compensation scheme for organizers and subcontractors cannot pay out dividends or conduct share buybacks for the remainder of 2020 and in 2021.
Compensate the municipal sector for lost tax revenues in 2020 compared to estimated revenues in the national budget for 2020.
Compensate each municipality for direct additional expenses incurred as a result of the outbreak of COVID-19.
Ensure predictability for the entire winter season 2020–2021 in the compensation scheme for the travel industry. Monthly payments of support should be arranged.
Introduce a fast track for processing applications for the approval of foreign education.
Remove the upper age limit for training in Norwegian and social studies under the Integration Act.
Ensure that healthcare personnel and other public employees are obligated to report to the police and child welfare services in cases of suspected female genital mutilation.
Ensure that initiated qualification paths can be completed within the introduction program, and that the regulations are adjusted to provide the necessary flexibility regarding duration.

Ensure that NOKUT has the primary responsibility for developing methods to be used for skills mapping of refugees, as well as the responsibility for training personnel who will carry out the skills mapping.
Introduce a pilot project with remote teaching of Norwegian in the country from which the transfer refugees are being sourced.

Ensure that the municipalities are compensated for the additional expenses that the proposed changes to the integration law entail, including funds for tasks that are transferred from IMDI to the county municipalities.

Facilitate closer collaboration between adult education and work practice, including increasing the use of and removing barriers to establishing vocational training models such as the Helsfyr and Gloppen models, and developing this to apply to more trades.
To increase the number of Norwegian lessons in reception from 175 hours to 250 hours.
Ensure that arrangements are made for the introduction scheme to be linked to vocational training and adult education, so that upper secondary vocational training can be started and completed.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to transfer the employer responsibility for minority advisors from IMDi to the county municipalities. At the same time, a three-year escalation plan for the county municipalities' financing of the service should be presented.
Ensure that training on the Norwegian labor model and workers' rights is included in the curriculum for Norwegian and social studies.

Take the initiative for a scholarship and/or loan scheme, for example through the Norwegian State Educational Loan Fund, to cover necessary courses and professional exams to achieve authorization for healthcare personnel.

Return to the Parliament with a new action plan for the care of personnel before, during, and after foreign service. The plan should help clarify which measures from the government's action plan (2011) and follow-up plan (2014) will be continued. Furthermore, the plan should include specific goals, sub-goals, and measures for the three prioritized policy areas presented in the report: (1) care for personnel's children and families, (2) further development of competence and collaboration in the civilian support system, and (3) research. In addition, the plan should specify goals, sub-goals, and measures for a fourth area: (4) openness and culture around mental health in the Armed Forces.

Engage in dialogue with the Armed Forces, employee organizations, and veteran organizations to ensure the possibility of equal parental leave and financial stability for the families of military personnel on overseas missions.
Present a mapping of prioritized research areas related to defense personnel in foreign service. This will lay the foundation for a strategy for Norwegian veteran research.

Promote a proposal that veterans entitled to compensation for psychological stress injuries from foreign operations are not subject to statutes of limitations until at least 3 years after a decision on disability benefits and granted occupational injury based on psychological stress injury. The government is requested to draft the proposal so that the change is given retroactive effect, so that it also includes veterans injured before 2010, and so that veterans who have already been denied compensation on the grounds of statutes of limitations are given the opportunity to reapply.
Ensure that the outer twenty-year statute of limitations is not used to deny compensation to veterans who otherwise meet the criteria for compensation.

Ensure that the specialist statement regarding permanent psychological strain injury is not dismissed by the National Insurance Scheme or the appeals body of the compensation schemes without first sending the statement back to the relevant specialist for a comment or additional statement. If the National Insurance Scheme or the appeals body believes that the statement is still unsatisfactory, a new medical assessment must be obtained.
Ensure that veterans can reopen their cases where decisions from the National Insurance Scheme and/or the Appeals Board may be in conflict with applicable law.
Ensure that the current arrangement for financing legal assistance for veterans, including legal aid and travel expenses, is maintained.
Consider exempting more groups, such as employees at hospital pharmacies, from the reduction in old-age pensions and return to the Storting in an appropriate manner.

Ensure that personnel who are called to ordered service under the Act of June 23, 2000 No. 56 on health and social preparedness § 1-3 first paragraph letter h, are included in the exceptions regarding pension reduction.

Open up for the possibility of applying for visas at multiple foreign missions, and allow for visits to close family, partners, or significant others where quarantine can be carried out in suitable housing.
Facilitate that visits to Norway for close family, partners, or significant others can take place within the framework of infection control guidelines.
Stop all exports of weapons and defense materials to Turkey until the armed conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan has ceased.

Present a proposal for an amendment to the export control regulations that ensures that Norwegian digital surveillance technology is not exported to countries where there is a risk that the technology will be used in violation of human rights.

Ensure that first and second line services within the healthcare system and schools have sufficient cross-cultural competence, especially knowledge about negative social control, honor-related violence, guidance on family establishment, and other family-related issues.

Ensure that the family welfare services have sufficient cross-cultural competence, especially expertise in social control and honor-related violence, and make sure that parents and families who wish to, or where there are reports of a need for help, are offered tailored parenting courses on various phases of childhood and youth that facilitate intergenerational dialogue.

Strengthen the cross-cultural competence in child welfare services, particularly knowledge about honor-related violence and negative social control, and ensure that child welfare services have good routines for working on these issues.

Expand the mandate of crisis centers to also include follow-up during a re-establishment phase for those who have escaped situations involving negative social control, violence, and honor-related violence, where this is necessary and appropriate. This must entail changes in the funding arrangement.

Initiate an investigation to assess the need for a new penal provision that protects all citizens against particularly hateful expressions, given a significantly higher threshold than under the current Penal Code § 185.
Present a bill to prohibit cousin marriage.

Investigate whether the duty to avert in the Penal Code § 196 should be expanded to also include more criminal offenses, particularly Penal Code §§ 257, 260, 261, 272 b, 292, 293, 294, 300, 301, 302, 304, and 305.
Investigate sanctions against religious communities that violate the specific criminal provision against forced marriage.

Conduct a comprehensive review of the statutes of limitations for sexual offenses and violent crimes against minors, and return to the Parliament with proposals for legislative changes that raise the general level of limitation periods for this type of crime.
To ensure reliable and publicly available data on the extent of isolation in Norwegian prisons.
To propose changes to the provisions of the Penal Execution Act that ensure that isolation is only used in extraordinary cases, as a last resort, and for the shortest time possible.
To propose changes that prohibit isolation for a defined number of hours in a row.

To expand the mandate of the supervisory councils to include oversight and monitoring of coercive decisions, prison record-keeping, and the use of isolation, also on their own initiative and without the requirement of consent from the inmate.

To propose changes to the mandates of the supervisory councils to include a reporting obligation to the Ministry of Justice and Public Security via the Directorate of Correctional Services, and to the Attorney General, in cases of suspected illegal use of coercion and isolation.
To propose a scheme for free legal aid for inmates who file complaints against their prison for illegal isolation.
Follow up on the recommendations in the Parliamentary Ombudsman's Document 4:3 (2018–19) and report back on the status in an appropriate manner.

Promote proposals for a legally guaranteed right to family support for families with special caregiving challenges, such as single parents with twins, families with triplets, families with children who have serious illnesses or disabilities, or families where there is a serious illness among the parents.

Map the collaboration between municipalities and specialist health services and promote the necessary proposals to ensure routines that secure cooperation with parents of children with special care needs before or shortly after birth.

Investigate whether too much emphasis is placed on diagnosis as a gateway to services, instead of basing it on holistic needs and the families' wishes. The Parliament also asks the government to present the necessary legislative proposals to ensure that a much more comprehensive understanding is established.

Promote a proposal for a municipal obligation to offer family support to families with special caregiving challenges, such as single parents with twins, families with triplets, families with children who have serious illnesses or disabilities, or families where there is a serious illness among the parents.

Investigate new practices that involve guidance in the family's home, instead of at the specialist healthcare service's office, when there are large geographical distances. This applies to guidance for families with children who have severe disabilities.

Ensure that all home-dwelling users/patients with special care needs and their relatives are offered a collaboration agreement that can provide a predictable partnership and dialogue with the healthcare service, which addresses the relatives' needs for and rights to respite, training, days off, guidance, and measures to safeguard their own health, and similar.
Propose legislative changes that ensure families who have a child with a disability have the right to quick and effective financial support to adapt their homes to their new life situation.
Implement "Roadmap. Universally Designed Local Schools 2030," so that all schools are open to all students.

Simplify and strengthen the rights of families with children, including developing the system of family support for parents of young children who have particular needs for assistance in acute and special situations.

Ensure that parents have the right and municipalities have the obligation to provide a designated contact person/coordinator/rights coordinator as early as possible, who will assist with guidance in the system, any applications, and practical and emotional support.
Develop a guide that clarifies the responsibilities of the rights coordinator, including the provision of outreach services to those in need.
Ensure competence development so that kindergartens have fundamental knowledge of functional variation.
Ensure that schools have interdisciplinary competence to provide more comprehensive support for students.
Gather knowledge and build a comprehensive offer for siblings in families where a child, for example, has severe disabilities.
Ensure that parents of children with special care needs can receive the guidance they need at home from mobile services, instead of having to meet at an office.

Map the situation for respite care arrangements for parents of children with special care needs, and present proposals that clarify that flexible and safe respite care arrangements are a fundamental part of families' rights, which municipalities must ensure are maintained, even in times like this with the coronavirus pandemic.
Ensure updated and balanced information for families who are informed that the child they are expecting has trisomy 21 or other diseases or disabilities.

Ensure that the statutory cooperation agreements between health enterprises and municipalities include services for children and young people, individuals with severe mental illnesses and substance abuse issues, frail elderly people, and individuals with multiple chronic conditions.
Investigate whether too much emphasis is placed on diagnosis as a gateway to services, instead of focusing on holistic needs and the family's wishes.

Propose legal changes that grant all parents who have been informed of a fetus with Down syndrome or other variations or conditions the right to close follow-up and guidance. Parents who have a child with an illness, injury, or other congenital condition that requires follow-up must have a legally guaranteed right to training and support before birth.

Promote a proposal that the Housing Bank's schemes for grants and loans for housing adaptations for families with significant care needs should, to a greater extent than today, be adjusted to the family's financial situation, both in terms of the size of the grants and loans and the conditions for loan repayment.

Facilitate that families in need of assistance can avoid difficult application processes, and instead be invited into collaborative decision-making processes based on the trust that authorities have in parents' understanding of their family's situation.
Facilitate that assessments with functional mapping and potential diagnosis must be available without long waiting times.
Ensure a national escalation plan for the development of activity schemes and short-term stays, also to ensure relief and security for the relatives of children with special care needs.

Promote a case to the Parliament regarding improving the leave options for relatives of children with special care needs in the workplace to ensure equality and the ability to combine work and care, cf. the Kaasa Committee's proposal.

Promote proposals that ensure that the holiday pay belonging to each employee is set aside in a separate account, so that the employer can never use up the holiday pay that belongs to the individual employee.
Tighten the conditions under which disproportionate burden can be used as an argument for business owners to be exempt from ensuring universal design of their own operations.
Ensure e-voting solutions for the blind and visually impaired in the upcoming municipal and county council elections, parliamentary elections, church elections, and elections to the Sámi Parliament.

Consider introducing a requirement for universal design in the cultural sector, and that individuals in need of a companion can use a companion pass as a prerequisite for public funding for cultural events.
Provide an assessment of the conditions under which disproportionate burden can be used as an argument for exempting a business owner from ensuring universal design of their own business.
Set a deadline for Norway to be universally designed by 2035.
Incorporate "Roadmap. Universally Designed Local School 2030" into the upcoming action plan for universal design, and allocate sufficient incentive funds.
Ensure that universal design in the transport sector is incorporated as a fundamental principle in the new National Transport Plan to achieve that Norway becomes universally designed by 2035.
Promote proposals to amend anti-discrimination legislation to include the right to information, goods, and services for people with disabilities.
Require municipalities to ensure that all polling places and meetings in municipal and city councils take place in venues that are universally designed.
Ensure that all buildings and means of transportation have evacuation equipment that ensures safe evacuation for individuals with disabilities.
Ensure that disaster preparedness plans also take into account the needs of people with disabilities.
Assess whether the central bank governor in the case of the employment of Nicolai Tangen has fulfilled his duties as outlined in the central bank law § 2-12 letters c and/or e.
Ensure that the Oil Fund is managed from Norway.

Change the mandate of the committee "Norway towards 2025" so that the committee will also specifically analyze and describe the social and geographical distributional consequences of the pandemic and crisis measures, as well as that proposed measures should support long-term goals of reduced inequality and high levels of organization.
Change the composition of the committee "Norway towards 2025" so that the committee becomes a broad and representative committee, rather than an expert committee.

Present proposals on how the savings from changes in the tax exemption for electric cars can be used for better and cheaper public transport and environmentally friendly transport infrastructure throughout the country.
Investigate a ban on the sale of new fossil fuel cars in 2025 if the goal set by the Parliament is not achieved through the tax system as a measure.

Investigate how the tax system should be structured to achieve the 2025 goal, including how value-added tax on electric vehicles can be phased in while simultaneously strengthening competitiveness against fossil fuel vehicles in all segments.
Investigate how the market share for electric cars can be increased in the leasing market through changes in the tax system.
Investigate various models that reduce the tax exemption for the most expensive and heaviest electric cars, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Consider how information in criminal cases involving doping according to WADA's prohibited list can also be made available to anti-doping organizations, including any potential need for changes in legislation.

Consider the possibilities for new provisions in the Penal Code to enable the prosecution of illicit use of doping in sports, including those who profit from athletic performances as a result of doping, with the possibility of financial confiscation. Clear penal provisions for those who attempt to manipulate sports competitions must also be thoroughly considered.
Investigate which criteria should be met for government support for international sports events that comply with the WADA code regarding anti-doping efforts, to be held in Norway.

Consider how information about athletes and support personnel who are punished for doping offenses can also be made available to anti-doping organizations, including any potential need for changes in legislation.
Consider the possibilities for new provisions in the Penal Code to prosecute those who profit from athletic performances as a result of doping, and the possibility of confiscation.
Investigate which criteria should be met for government support for international sports events to be held in Norway.
Initiate an evaluation of the Court Administration (DA) with a focus on assessing DA's role in ensuring the independent position of the courts, and DA's role as a legal policy actor.
Initiate an external evaluation of the Court Administration (DA) to assess whether DA has functioned as intended and exercised its mandate in a satisfactory manner for all courts.
Introduce a two-part process in the Immigration Appeals Board to ensure full contradiction and oral hearings.

Amend § 14-1 of the regulation on foreigners' access to the realm and their residence here (the Immigration Regulations) to specify which factors should be investigated and emphasized in the assessment of the child's best interests in expulsion cases, and to clarify that decisions regarding expulsion must be made in a manner that is responsible in light of the child's best interests.
Investigate whether the Norwegian Directorate of Immigration and the Immigration Appeals Board, in expulsion cases involving children, should as a general rule obtain an external expert assessment.

Amend the regulation on fees from the public to lawyers, etc., according to fixed rates (unit prices) for free legal aid and in criminal cases, so that each child affected in expulsion cases is granted three hours of legal assistance on an independent basis upon prior notice, with an additional two hours in case of appeal.
Ensure that children affected by deportation cases have the right to be heard, and ensure that children are heard directly and orally to a much greater extent than today.

Ensure that when processing an appeal against a decision to expel a foreign national who has children in Norway, the individual concerned, as well as the affected children, are granted the opportunity to appear in person and express their views at the committee meeting.

Ensure that in expulsion cases involving children, there is always an investigation and assessment of the real possibility for the child to be reunited with their mother or father after the entry ban expires, that the time perspective is examined, and that this is taken into account in the consideration of the child's best interests.

Ensure that when children are born or granted residence permits after a deportation decision, the deportation case should be re-evaluated in two instances, and the child should be provided with legal assistance on an independent basis.

Conduct a review of the complaint system in the immigration field with the expectation that this will involve a strengthening of legal security, including increased use of contradiction and oral proceedings in the complaint system.

Consider facilitating budgeting and organizing railway development in Norway so that Bane NOR has portfolio management over all or parts of the annual allocation, and report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner.

Conduct a review of the responsibilities among the actors in the railway sector, with particular emphasis on the relationship between the Norwegian Railway Authority, Bane NOR, and the Ministry of Transport.
Assign Nye Veier AS the task of developing railway projects in the same way as on the road side.
Ensure that necessary personnel and goods transportation in Northern Norway is secured.
Ensure that the coastal route is maintained with six ships and calls at all ports between Bergen and Kirkenes.
Allocate funds for the coastal route as a measure in connection with the COVID-19 outbreak. Up to 3 additional ships will be deployed between Trondheim and Kirkenes to ensure calls every other day.
To initiate the work of allowing temporary leasing of aquaculture licenses for self-production in the fishing industry and to promote a case to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
To highlight how the introduction of a rental scheme could affect municipalities' revenues from the Aquaculture Fund, and to ensure that these revenues do not change negatively.
Ensure that a scheme for leasing time-limited aquaculture licenses contributes to increased value creation in the fishing industry and does not allow for the trading or subleasing of licenses.
To investigate a scheme for leasing time-limited aquaculture licenses to ensure domestic production in the fishing industry.

Introduce a system with rolling Maximum Allowed Biomass (MTB) in the aquaculture industry as soon as possible, based on experiences from the pilot program with variable MTB. The system will be evaluated after five years.

Investigate a scheme with rolling MTB and present a case to the Storting by the deadline for processing in the spring session of 2021, with the aim of introducing a pilot scheme that will contribute to increased processing and value creation.

Establish a salary commission for state executive salaries, executive salaries in state-owned companies, and companies where the state is the majority owner, as well as the salaries of politicians at the national and local levels. The commission will examine state executive salaries, bonus schemes, and compensations in context and analyze why salary development at the top level has gained a foothold, despite previously adopted guidelines. The commission will further conduct a thorough assessment of what constitutes genuine societal considerations in salary determination, and what cannot be justified by this. The commission will have strong representation from the parties involved. The salaries of political and administrative leaders in the state with a salary of 9.8 G or more will be nominally put on hold until the salary commission has presented its conclusions.

Establish a practice where leaders in the state and wholly owned state companies who leave their positions, regardless of whether it is voluntary or involuntary, as a general rule do not retain their leadership salary if they are reassigned to lower positions.

Establish a salary commission for state executive salaries, executive salaries in state-owned companies and companies where the state is the majority owner, as well as the salaries of politicians at the national and local levels and severance pay schemes. The commission shall examine state executive salaries, bonus schemes, and compensations in context and analyze why the salary development at the top level has continued, despite previously adopted guidelines. Furthermore, the commission shall conduct a thorough assessment of what constitutes genuine societal considerations in salary determination, and what cannot be justified by this. The commission shall have strong representation from the parties involved. The compensation for the Prime Minister, ministers, and members of parliament shall be nominally suspended until the salary commission has presented its conclusions.
Promote a separate case for the Parliament regarding new guidelines for executive salaries and other types of compensation for leaders in the state, which contribute to reduced salary disparities.
Ensure that the responsible minister reports annually to the Storting on the development of executive salaries within their area of responsibility.
Conduct the wage settlement in the state so that there is one main collective agreement applicable to all employees in the state tariff area, regardless of organizational affiliation.

To propose necessary regulatory changes so that the police certificate provides a complete picture of the applicant and shows all relevant offenses in cases related to employment in schools, kindergartens, or other places where contact with children is an important part of the position.

Return to the Parliament with a comprehensive kindergarten law by the end of 2020, which follows up on the Parliament's previous decisions and ensures that all state support and parental payments for kindergarten benefit the children.

Clarify how municipalities in the land use plan of the municipal plan for kindergartens can regulate the function of kindergarten properties for public purposes, in order to prevent property speculation.
Propose legislative changes to ensure that kindergarten properties built on inexpensive or free municipal land or with public capital grants are not sold for profit to commercial actors.

Review the expenses of commercial kindergartens for rent and the profits of commercial companies from publicly funded kindergartens through property purchases and sales, and propose legislative changes that clarify the limitations on rent for publicly funded kindergartens.
Propose legal amendments so that rental agreements for kindergartens must be approved by the municipality to be valid.
Present a plan for the escalation of public and non-profit ownership and operation of kindergartens to ensure that kindergartens are run by public or non-profit entities.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for changes to the legislation that ensures the municipality has the authority over the distribution of the number of places between private and municipal kindergartens if the municipality experiences a reduction in the number of children.

Come back with a proposal to amend the Kindergarten Act § 53 first paragraph, so that the municipality shall continue to conduct financial supervision of the private kindergartens in its own municipality.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how the government will ensure adequate oversight of an increasingly commercialized childcare sector.
Promote proposals for changes in legislation that ensure public access to the accounts of businesses receiving public funding for kindergarten operations.
Introduce or promote necessary proposals to implement a requirement that when a kindergarten is sold, the new owner must reapply for funding.

Promote proposals that give the municipality the opportunity to make a balanced allocation of places between municipal and private kindergartens, ensuring that the considerations for predictability and the operational basis for both municipal and private kindergartens in the municipality are secured in accordance with parents' wishes and the need for a decentralized kindergarten structure.
Propose changes to the Kindergarten Act so that public funding solely benefits the children, and that this money cannot be withdrawn as dividends for private kindergarten owners.

Promote necessary legislative proposals that, regardless of municipal or non-municipal management of public tasks, ensure transparency and access to accounts, quality indicators, staffing situations, and cash flows, as well as that the changes in central parts of the legislation that are necessary for real insight into public operations are also applicable to private providers with whom the municipality has contracted, so that the municipal sector can effectively control any misuse of public subsidies.

Introduce a reporting obligation and preemptive right for the municipality in the sale of kindergartens and promote any proposals for necessary legal amendments to establish such rights and obligations.

Present a legislative proposal corresponding to the regulations in the Independent School Act, which ensures that employees in private kindergartens shall have salary and working conditions that are at least equivalent to those in municipal kindergartens.

Ensure the entire population in the country has access to fast broadband (minimum 100 Mbit/s) by increasing the state's allocations for broadband development and introducing a public delivery obligation in areas where there is no basis for commercial development.

Continue the National Welfare Technology Program with the goal of making welfare technology an integrated part of health and care services by 2025, and present such a plan to the Parliament. The program must include grant schemes and measures to ensure that welfare technology can be rolled out in all municipalities, increase digital communication between patients and health services, involve volunteerism and non-profit organizations, and implement measures to strengthen digital competence in the population and prevent digital class divides.
Ensure that laid-off employees with low digital skills have access to courses and relevant training during the layoff period.
Intensify the work on rolling out digital communication between patients and healthcare services and ensure necessary user competence.

Establish a grant scheme to ensure the digital transformation of health volunteering, so that digital tools are put in place to facilitate the planning and execution of activities and social networks that provide quality of life and a sense of achievement.

Set the goal that all households and businesses in the country should have satisfactory broadband capacity. The government is requested to create a development plan and propose an increase in state funding for broadband expansion to achieve this goal.
Ramp up the rollout of welfare technology in municipalities, including the purchase of tablets or other solutions for volunteer organizations that have visitor friend arrangements.

Continue to roll out and strengthen training programs for digital skills enhancement for the elderly and others in need, for example in collaboration with the Pensioners' Association, Senior Network, and local volunteer centers.

Establish a state-owned company, StatMed, which will ensure national self-production of pharmaceuticals in Norway and collaborate with the rest of the pharmaceutical industry and the public healthcare system on national development and production of medicines.

Establish R&D collaboration with the pharmaceutical industry, where the public healthcare system can access medications at acceptable prices when the drugs are developed based on publicly funded studies.
Take the initiative for a broad Nordic collaboration on the production and storage of pharmaceuticals and protective equipment in the Nordic region.
Take the initiative for a broad Nordic and European collaboration on the production and storage of pharmaceuticals and infection control equipment.

Facilitate public tenders for pharmaceuticals where agreements can be made with more than one provider, in cases where this is deemed beneficial, with the aim of reducing vulnerability related to delivery reliability.

Ensure the security of supply of critical medicines in Norway by splitting contracts for the procurement of medicines into two parts, with one of these parts reserved for Norwegian actors. This is to ensure emergency production.

Investigate and present a case to the Storting regarding the establishment of a national pharmaceutical company that can stimulate Norwegian drug and vaccine production, either independently or in collaboration with the Norwegian pharmaceutical industry. The company must have the capital to strengthen both existing production capacity in Norway and encourage new production capacity. It should also be able to establish long-term agreements to ensure both the import and national emergency production of necessary medications.
Ensure that all hospitals, both existing and new constructions, have space to establish local emergency stockpiles.
Expand the use of emergency stockpiles for medical equipment and promote the necessary proposals to ensure progress in this work.
Present necessary proposals to ensure that medical emergency stockpiles are financed outside of regular operating budgets.

Strengthen the R&D collaboration with the pharmaceutical industry, so that public research funds can help increase the opportunities for participation in clinical trials for Norwegian patients, as well as improve access to medications.

Promote the necessary proposals to ensure that decisions or regulations based on the Infection Control Act § 4-1 shall have a limited duration of one month. If the decision or regulation is to be extended, the government may decide to do so and immediately submit a proposition to the Parliament.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to introduce a temporary parliamentary review of national measures based on the Infection Control Act.

Promote necessary proposals for amendments to the Infection Control Act that stipulate that particularly intrusive national measures, introduced under the authority of the law, shall be presented as a proposition for consideration in the Storting as soon as possible.

Promote the necessary proposals for amendments to the Infection Control Act that stipulate that the Parliament, with at least one-third of the votes, may at any time request that national measures introduced under the authority of the law be presented as a proposition to the Parliament.

Promote the necessary proposals to legislate an obligation for the government to publicly disclose the scientific basis at the same time as national decisions and regulations based on the Infection Control Act are implemented, as long as it does not conflict with national security or cause significant societal harm.

Promote the necessary proposals to ensure that the second paragraph of Section 37 of the Public Administration Act regarding consultation applies to national decisions or regulations based on the Infection Control Act if it is timely feasible. A consultation deadline may be set to 24 hours.
Assess the need for guidelines that ensure a practice where the municipal council is involved and held accountable for municipal decisions implemented under the Infection Control Act § 4-1.

Ensure a practice where decisions regarding particularly intrusive national measures that have significant societal consequences, enacted under the Infection Control Act, are presented as a matter and debated in the Parliament as soon as possible.
Conduct a comprehensive review of the Infection Control Act after the Corona Commission has submitted its report.

Return to the Parliament with a bill that protects drug users from prosecution and legal action for their own use doses when they contact authorities for help for themselves or others – a so-called "Good Samaritan Law."

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal on how the public sector can offer more choices in the final phase of life within the services currently used across the country. This must include training, the need for delegated authority, and an increase in resources.

Follow up on the recommendation in NOU 2017:16 On Life and Death, and not prioritize funds for the establishment of a children's hospice in Norway, but instead ensure the rapid development of pediatric palliative centers and mobile pediatric palliative teams in all health regions to provide all seriously ill children with care at home or close to where they live.

Draft a proposal for a new law on a freedom of choice system, based on the model of Sweden. The law should ensure that those who have been granted care services from the public sector can choose which provider will perform the service.

Establish a committee to examine practices and legislation in other countries related to assisted dying and pain relief at the end of life, and the consequences that legislation granting more rights in the final phase of life would have.

Promote measures to develop municipal palliative care work and ensure that all municipalities have their own palliative teams, possibly inter-municipal teams, and strengthen the role of general practitioners in this work.
Ensure that comprehensive palliative centers are established at regional hospitals, and that local hospitals have at least palliative teams.
Ensure that the regional competence services in palliative care are strengthened and given new tasks.
Ensure that pediatric palliative teams are established at all regional hospitals in Norway, and that these are funded through earmarked funds during a development phase.
Ensure funding for further education in palliative care and nursing, and the development of more master's programs in palliative care for various professional groups.

Strengthen the vocational school offerings in palliative care while simultaneously enhancing in-house training to promote skill development in palliative care for both qualified and unqualified care and nursing personnel.
Establish a dedicated research program in the Research Council focused on palliative care.

Establish palliative medicine as a medical specialty, or a subspecialty that formalizes competence in palliative medicine with the status of a medical specialty. The opportunity to build on learning objectives/content from various specialties should be included in the establishment of the new specialty. As a result, clinical training positions must be created.

Review the funding arrangement so that the way guidance and mobile services are financed for the specialist health service's palliative teams does not become an obstacle to achieving good follow-up processes.
Ensure that Lukas Hospice in Malvik is secured predictable funding during the project period.

Develop a binding action plan for palliative care and present it to the Parliament in an appropriate manner. The plan should, among other things, ensure: that hospitals have a plan to prevent overtreatment at the end of life; that health enterprises have a plan for how they can, in collaboration with municipalities, prevent undignified transport of patients in the final phase of life; that no one receiving assistance from the healthcare service – to the extent possible – should die alone or be alone in the final phase of life. This goal also applies during pandemics and similar crises; improved collaboration regarding seriously ill patients by establishing cooperation agreements between municipalities and hospitals for the joint development and use of patient-centered pathways in palliative care, and by involving patient organizations in the work; a plan to strengthen the competence to address people's spiritual and existential needs, ensuring that patients and their relatives receive holistic treatment and care.
Establish Health Data Service in Tynset and co-locate Health Data Service with the Norwegian Health Archive.

Consult the Sámediggi before the regulation under § 20 of the Health Register Act, which will regulate which health registers will be made available in the health analysis platform, is sent out for consultation, with the aim of achieving agreement on ensuring indigenous peoples' control over the collection, access to, analysis, and interpretation of health-related data.
Come back to the Storting with this before October 2021.
Tighten the legislation and the municipalities' exemption options to prevent construction in the coastal zone.
Come back with a proposal for increased funding for the work on environmental crime in the police districts and ØKOKRIM, in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.

Establish a permanent grant scheme for the county municipalities, so that they can ensure access to decentralized higher education in line with the needs of the business sector, the public sector, and the population throughout the country.

Change the orientation of the regional district and industry-targeted instruments so that they contribute to the transition to a zero-emission society and economy. Within such frameworks, the county municipalities should have greater freedom to decide how the funds should be used.
Promote proposals to increase the municipal business funds.
Revise state guidelines that hinder local self-governance and development opportunities in rural areas.
Develop a differentiated regulatory framework for construction in coastal areas based on region and area.
Ensure arrangements that guarantee the distribution of all local newspapers in the country every weekday, including Saturday.

Consider how the MERKUR scheme can be expanded to also include those who do not have equity and will not be able to generate sufficient profit, and therefore do not have the means to co-finance measures.

Ensure that the entire population of the country has access to fast broadband (minimum 100 Mbit/s symmetrical broadband capacity) and introduce a public delivery obligation for broadband in areas where there is no basis for commercial development.
Consider how the proposal affects the settlement pattern.

Develop "regional agreements" between the state, municipalities, and regions, which will ensure development and growth throughout the country and provide long-term frameworks for business, transportation, settlement, education, and welfare.

Present a parliamentary report on a new initiative for the mineral industry, addressing the following elements: An evaluation of the mineral law. A plan to complete the mapping of mineral deposits, at least in line with the goal from the mineral strategy that 75% of the country should be mapped with advanced equipment. Concrete measures to strengthen predictability in case processing and reduce processing times. Strengthening of management to uphold environmental requirements, Sami rights, and guidance for municipalities. Measures for R&D to reduce environmental impact. A strategy for increased utilization and processing of minerals in Norway. A review of the current situation and proposals for necessary measures to strengthen recruitment and education for the industry. A strategy for stricter international environmental requirements for the extraction of mineral resources.
Promote a proposal to increase the commuter deduction for ordinary people.
Strengthen the basic geological mapping conducted by the Norwegian Geological Survey (NGU).
Promote proposals to significantly increase funding for broadband expansion.
Promote proposals to increase regional development funds to the county municipalities.
Investigate the establishment of a green investment company for the development of businesses based on green (renewable) carbon and present the proposal to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Return to the Parliament with an assessment of the future possibilities for changing the wealth tax, highlighting both the state's revenues and the municipalities' room for maneuver in competing for tax conditions between municipalities.
Clarify to the county governors that local self-government should be given greater emphasis than it is today when processing municipal plans and dispensations.
Develop a guide on how to preserve older buildings through adaptive reuse for new activities.

Investigate and promote necessary proposals to ensure non-profit school operations, through new organizational forms that facilitate non-profit activities while also ensuring transparency in the schools' financial expenditures.

Present a proposal that approved private primary and secondary schools can be included in a municipal/county school utilization plan. If there is a need to reduce the number of school places due to changes in student enrollment, the reduction in the total number of school places must not weaken the public school offering.
To propose changes to the Independent School Act so that approval under Section 2-1 of the Act shall not be granted if the relevant host municipality or host county opposes such approval.

Review the legislation for private schools to ensure that the intention that all state funding benefits the students is better upheld than it is today. Such a review should aim to prevent the resale of state-funded schools from allowing private profits to be extracted from school operations, as well as to introduce stricter sanctions and reduce the need for oversight.
Ensure a regulatory framework that requires private schools to report in the event of sale, merger, demerger, and closure of private schools.
Investigate new organizational forms for operating private schools that facilitate non-profit activities while ensuring public transparency in the use of public funds.

Develop and implement a comprehensive plan to ensure oversight and coordinated follow-up from the individual ministries regarding the recommendations from international monitoring bodies to Norway in the field of human rights.
Facilitate reduced use of isolation in prisons so that Article 92 of the Constitution is followed.

Review the recommendations in the annual reports from Norway's National Institution for Human Rights from 2015, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner on how this has been followed up.

Ensure that there is equal access to compensation for failures of the public sector towards a person who was a child when the failure occurred, regardless of where the person lives in the country, and if necessary, establish a national compensation scheme or a national framework for municipal schemes.
Return to the Storting with a review of the various municipal and county compensation and restitution schemes to gain an overview of potentially problematic discriminatory treatment.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to coordinate the regulations for compensation with the rules for statute of limitations in the Penal Code, so that claims for compensation do not expire before any potential prosecution.

Return to the Storting with a comprehensive review of public compensation schemes, which specifically examines which groups are not covered by the schemes, and assesses how these should be included in or covered by other arrangements.
Ensure that the Storting's compensation scheme for justice is better known and better informed about as a compensation scheme.
Establish a review committee to map and examine all cases where individuals may have been unjustly sentenced as a result of a misinterpretation of the Refugee Convention Article 31(1).
Ensure that the Attorney General has sufficient resources to follow up on cases where individuals have been wrongfully sentenced, also as a result of misinterpretation of the Refugee Convention.
Establish a suitable legal aid scheme so that individuals who believe they have been wrongly convicted due to misinterpretation of the Refugee Convention receive free legal assistance.

Investigate various models for a tourist tax in Norway, and return to the Storting with a proposal in connection with the revised national budget for 2021. The Storting requests the government to consider both a state-set tax and a municipal rate, a flat rate and a percentage of the accommodation price, differentiated rates depending on the season and destination, as well as whether the municipalities' tourist tax revenues should be earmarked for tourism purposes.

Ensure that the base policy is maintained by rejecting any proposals for Expeditionary Advanced Base (EAB) operations on Norwegian territory, and ensure the withdrawal of American soldiers stationed in Norway for an extended period.

Present a withdrawal plan for Norwegian forces in ongoing NATO operations and US-led operations. The case should include a plan for the final withdrawal of Norwegian military engagement in Iraq and Afghanistan.
Decline the invitation to participate in the Cooperative Deployment concept.
Come back to the Storting with a separate case about the future of compulsory military service.

Investigate a two-part recruit school structure based on Terningmoen and Drevjamoen, and return to the Storting with a proposal on this during 2021. The proposal should also examine the use/rental of Haslemoen's resources as a sub-department of Terningmoen, including shooting and training areas and any other relieving capacity, if this can save funds and space.
Practice a much greater degree of transparency towards the Storting regarding Norwegian military cooperation with third countries and Norwegian operations abroad.

Present a climate and environmental plan for the defense sector with clear goals and measures for emission reductions and reduction of environmental impact for the period leading up to 2030, and report annually on goal achievement in the budget proposal.
Return to the Parliament with a revised proposal for the defense-specific efficiency cuts in the long-term plan, where they are explained and justified individually.

Establish an external committee with a mandate to investigate all aspects of the procurement of the F-35 in light of the updated cost picture from Prop. 1 S (2020–2021) and the latest reports from the U.S. Government Accountability Office regarding the program, including whether the Parliament has been sufficiently and timely informed about challenges related to and anticipated additional costs resulting from the procurement.
Come back with a case to the Storting regarding possible measures to reduce the total costs of the fighter aircraft acquisition, including the possibility of a reduction in the number of aircraft.
Come back with a report that outlines the extent of outsourcing and the establishment of so-called "strategic partnerships" aimed at a reintegration into the Armed Forces.
Plan for the phased introduction of tanks from no later than 2023.
Start the establishment of a new cadre-based Brigade South from 2021. Brigade South will be a light brigade built on reservists and conscripts.
Increase the staffing in the Home Guard to the approved structure, cf. Innst. 50 S (2017–2018), and ensure further escalation to 45,000 soldiers.
Ensure that the Home Guard is provided with increased resources to secure annual training of six days for soldiers and nine days for officers.
Develop a possible Recruit School North at Drevjamoen with increased recruitment intake.
Present a status report for EBA in the Armed Forces, as well as a needs analysis with a cost estimate leading up to 2028.
Start the establishment of the fourth battalion before 2026.

Come back in the revised national budget for 2021 with an overview of the actual costs of participation in the EU's defense fund and what consequences participation will have for the export-based national defense industry.

Strengthen air defense through the acquisition of new air defense systems with long-range air defense missiles and sensors that will be capable of protecting the airbase at Ørland, the allied reception area, and the base at Evenes.
Expand the purchase with dedicated helicopters for the Army, which will be stationed in their own squadron based in Bardufoss.
Come back with an assessment of possible investments and upgrades that can be carried out independently of the ongoing investigation into future surface structure.
Start the procurement process for new long-range air defense, in accordance with the government's long-term plan proposal from 2016.
Continue to maintain Andøya Air Station as a base for maritime surveillance aircraft.
Establish a committee to assess how Norway can strengthen its digital autonomy.
Take the initiative for a Norwegian or joint Nordic public cloud solution.
To present a budget where the operating budgets of the branches of the armed forces are distributed across different chapters.
To complain about the restoration of a national grain storage system in Norway.

Come back to the Parliament with concrete proposals for accelerating investments and/or procurements in the Navy. This is to strengthen the Navy's operational capability and ensure predictability for the Norwegian shipbuilding industry.
Ensure that cleaning in the Armed Forces is carried out by employees in the defense sector or DSS.

Freeze all processes for outsourcing and entering into so-called 'strategic partnerships' in the defense sector until the Parliament has been presented with a report on the use of non-military personnel and issues related to the law of armed conflict and non-military personnel as legitimate military targets.
Exempt the Armed Forces from ABE cuts during the long-term planning period.
Ensure that the Armed Forces museums are co-financed by the Ministry of Culture following the same model as the Armed Forces music starting from the state budget for 2022.

Increase the number of man-years in the Armed Forces by 500 in 2021, assume an increase of 1,100 man-years by 2024, and return no later than in the revised national budget for 2021 with the necessary measures to realize this.
Ensure that the savings from the ABE cuts are reinvested in the defense sector.

Follow up on the transformation of the Andøy community in accordance with the guidelines that formed the basis for the decision and the majority's remarks in Innst. 62 S (2016–2017), and conclude by February 1, 2021, regarding the designation and use of areas related to Andøya Air Station.

Promote a case for the replacement of the current coast guard and support vessels, including an assessment of a future standardized vessel class, and return with possible accelerations in Prop. 1 S (2021-2022).

Accelerate an increase in the number of full-time positions in the Armed Forces to 300 in 2021, and align the increase with the recommendations in the Chief of Defence's military professional advice (FMR).

Acquire new helicopters for dedicated helicopter support for the Army. The new helicopters will be organized into a squadron at Rygge and a squadron at Bardufoss to support and cooperate with the Army. The Parliament requests the government to return to the Parliament with a separate case regarding the acquisition of the helicopters, including the number.
Clarify the consequences related to the economy, work environment, and preparedness as a result of the outsourcing of cleaning services in the Armed Forces.

Consider ways to reduce the defense budget's exposure to currency fluctuations in connection with the procurement of defense materials, and report back to the Parliament with an assessment in the revised national budget for 2021.

Come back to the Storting with a complete plan for the relocation of maritime surveillance activities from Andøya to Evenes, detailing solutions for phasing in, hangar issues, de-icing, storage of ammunition and fuel, as well as staffing, including support functions and finances.
Provide insight into the process surrounding the military professional recommendation regarding the phasing in of the P-8 to prevent speculation about interference from the Ministry of Defence.
Present calculations that form the basis for operating costs for MPA activities at Andøya and Evenes.
Present analyses and calculations that form the basis for the placement of the hangar for the Norwegian P-8 aircraft.
Present a staffing plan that ensures full operational capacity of the base at Evenes.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals for amendments to the law that expand the possibility for billing cards as a product to be offered in Norway.

Consider whether the deductible in the Financial Contracts Act § 3-20 third paragraph should be increased to account for inflation in recent years and to ensure that the amount provides a sufficient incentive for rights holders to use their electronic signature in a responsible manner. The government is also asked to consider whether the amount should be linked to the basic amount in the National Insurance Scheme so that it is automatically adjusted for price changes. These assessments should also be made for the amount in § 4-30 third paragraph.
Ensure that a requirement for prior consent from the debtor is introduced in accordance with the General Data Protection Regulation Article 6(1)(a) for the transfer of overdue or defaulted loans.
Consider the need for a ban on the marketing of unsecured credit on social media, and return to the Parliament with a legislative proposal.
Review the practice of private noise agreements in connection with wind power developments, and consider banning such agreements.
Change the regulations so that municipalities and local communities have a real veto power against development, through binding referendums and municipal council decisions.

Ensure that the Norwegian Environment Agency or another public institution with expertise in nature mapping conducts the nature mapping that is to be carried out as part of the impact assessments for wind power plants, and create regulations that make the developer responsible for the costs of the mapping.
Prioritize the upgrade of existing hydropower plants, ensure energy efficiency in buildings, and do not increase the export capacity of electricity to other countries.
Review all ongoing wind power projects and assess the scope for tightening regulations under the new concession system.

Ensure that no concessions are granted for wind power developments where the needs of reindeer husbandry, such as grazing areas, migration routes, and calving sites, are not met by the developer in the concession process. Concessions should not be granted with conditions that clarifications with reindeer husbandry will be made afterwards.

Ensure the necessary regulatory changes that make the Norwegian Environment Agency an active part of the work of assessing the environmental impact assessments, and return to the Parliament with proposals that ensure this.
Ensure that wind power is not developed in large contiguous natural areas with an untouched character.
Ensure that wind power is not developed in nationally and regionally important outdoor recreation areas.
Ensure that wind power is not developed in landscapes of national and significant regional interest.

Initiate an independent investigation of all contentious onshore wind power projects, both completed and those under construction, to assess whether the regulations, including the regulations on impact assessments and EU regulations on impact assessments, have been followed.
Ensure that no new onshore wind power plants are built.
Ensure that all ongoing wind power projects with environmental impact assessments older than five years prepare new environmental impact assessments.
Review the use of state land use planning in power concession cases, propose tightening of practices if they are not in accordance with the legislation, and return to the Parliament with proposals.
Ensure that wind power is not developed in areas on the fringes of protected areas.

Present a proposal to the Storting for the introduction of an environmental fee of between 1.5 and 2 øre per kWh of produced power, which will be allocated to the host municipality of the wind power plant, based on the Energy Act, as part of the wind power plant's concession conditions.
Ensure that decisions regarding the development of wind power align with local wishes and municipal council decisions. A concession cannot be granted in conflict with municipal council decisions.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to repeal the provision in the Planning and Building Act § 6-4, third paragraph, which concerns concessions and state land use planning.
Return to the Parliament with proposals for changes to the concession legislation for wind power, so that the same requirements for public ownership apply to wind power as for hydropower.
Present to the Storting a case regarding the taxation of foreign companies' value creation in Norway, including the need for tightening the rules on profit shifting.
Ensure that strong restrictions are implemented on foreign ownership in the exploitation of concession-granted natural resources in Norway.

Establish an energy commission that develops proposals for a comprehensive energy and climate plan that considers the expected energy needs of businesses and society, energy efficiency, and the need for various forms of new energy production in relation to Norwegian climate policy. The plan must clarify the needs at both the national and regional levels and should result in a separate case for the Parliament.

Ensure that no permits are granted for the commencement of construction activities for power developments until all required environmental studies have been conducted and the necessary considerations have been addressed through the requirements imposed on the work.
Ensure that residents and interest organizations are notified when negotiations between municipalities and developers of wind power or hydropower begin.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for an amendment to the Energy Act § 2-1 regarding the application requirement, so that it only includes conditions for the production and distribution of electrical energy. The proposal must include a clarification that the processing of the concession application cannot take place until there is land clarification in the municipal plan, and possibly a zoning plan, in accordance with the provisions of the Planning and Building Act.

Come back to the Storting with a proposal to amend the Planning and Building Act § 12-1, which means that energy facilities subject to concession are no longer exempt from the requirement for regulation.

Require that the license holder sets aside funds in a blocked account from the first year of operation, with annual amounts sufficient to cover the costs of removing wind turbines and infrastructure when the license expires.
Investigate and return to the Storting with a proposal for a reversion scheme for wind power, similar to that of hydropower.

Ensure that the traditional livelihoods of indigenous peoples receive stronger protection in the processes surrounding energy development by consulting representatives of Sámi reindeer herding in advance when proposed interventions that may affect their operations are being considered.

Ensure that the county municipalities responsible for business and community development, climate, nature, and outdoor life play an active role in the regional assessment of the need for and location of wind power plants.

Develop clear knowledge-based guidelines for the Planning and Building Act regarding methods for weighting the loss of nature, habitats for wildlife species, and interventions in important outdoor recreation areas.
Return to the Storting with a proposal for a ban on the degradation of wetlands.

Propose to amend the Planning and Building Act § 12-1 third paragraph last sentence to: "Requirements for zoning plans do not apply to facilities subject to concession for energy production under the Energy Act, the Water Resources Act, or the Water Regulation Act; this exception does not apply to onshore wind power plants."

Come back to the Parliament with a concrete tax and fee proposal that investigates a natural resource tax similar to what is in place for hydropower, environmental fees, and resource rent, and provides the industry with assurance that economically viable development projects will remain profitable even after such a potential tax.

Initiate a mapping of the potential for smaller wind power developments such as farm windmills, small facilities near existing industry and other infrastructure, and present such a mapping no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.

Look at the requirements for distance restrictions for wind turbines of lower height, built in cultural landscapes or already industrialized areas, and ensure that the rules for distance based on the height of the turbines do not create unnecessary obstacles for such installations, and return to the Parliament with the matter in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.
Consider changes in wind power taxation, including an assessment of how an appropriate design and timeline for increasing the tax burden on wind power producers can be implemented.

Come back to the Parliament in connection with the revised national budget for 2021 with an assessment of how local compensation and predictable framework conditions for wind power can be ensured, for example through natural resource tax, a production fee, or another appropriate arrangement for all parties involved.
Set a deadline of up to 5 years from the final approval of a project until the wind power facility must be operational.
That the concession specifies the number and height of wind turbines and that a buffer zone is established around buildings or other activities.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to include the planning and construction of wind power plants in the Planning and Building Act.
Ensure that both the joint Swedish-Norwegian electricity certificate scheme and the special depreciation schemes for wind power plants are phased out by no later than December 31, 2021.
Investigate and present to the Storting alternatives for how a guarantee for cleanup can be provided at the start of the wind power facility.
Establish an independent review committee with a broad mandate to conduct a comprehensive assessment of child welfare services and propose improvements.
Establish a branding scheme for more grass-based milk and meat production.

Promote a proposal to amend § 5 of the law on the Government Pension Fund to allow direct transfers from the fund to the UN Green Fund for climate initiatives abroad following a decision by the Storting.

Change the traffic agreement with Flytoget for the first half of 2021, so that Flytoget is only allowed to operate the route Oslo S–Gardermoen–Oslo S and the number of departures on the route is halved.

Investigate a scheme for electric mobility support to enable leasing of electric cars or electric cargo bikes, based on the housing support scheme that municipalities and the Norwegian State Housing Bank collaborate on to provide more individuals with limited means and a need for a vehicle the opportunity to purchase or lease an electric car or electric cargo bike, so that they can save money, benefit from the advantages of electric vehicles, and contribute to reducing emissions.
Design a model for a tax on salmon lice in the aquaculture industry that provides an estimated revenue effect of 900 million kroner.

Allocate a portion of the additional funding under chapter 571 item 64 (discretionary grants) to the municipalities that have been hardest hit by the pandemic for local measures to ensure that the most vulnerable and at-risk groups (such as refugees, beggars, the homeless, migrant workers, undocumented individuals, sex workers, and children in violent homes) have their vital needs met, such as food, a place to sleep, healthcare, and a safe everyday life.
Replace the one-time grant with parental benefits of 2 G for everyone who currently receives a one-time grant and is not a student.
Return to the Parliament with a proposal for a separate quota for climate refugees, with the same reception and integration services as quota refugees, and promote such arrangements internationally.
Come back with a proposal for government support for psychological services for students, which is currently funded through the semester fee.
Move the Norwegian Space Center and related government jobs to Tromsø.

To ensure that the proposed additional allocation is distributed such that one third is allocated according to the ferry criteria in the cost key, and two thirds based on ferry routes that have adopted electric ferries as of 2021.

Make the animal police a nationwide unit under the Police Directorate by expanding from the current situation with established animal police in six of the country's twelve police districts to all twelve.

Establish a grant scheme aimed at helping the most vulnerable groups in society when society is shut down; such as refugees, beggars, homeless individuals, migrant workers, undocumented people, sex workers, and children in violent homes are all extremely vulnerable groups.
Increase support for Matsentralen Norway to enable them to redistribute more food and reduce food waste.

Consider extending the layoff period to 60 weeks for employees who were laid off before July 1, 2020, so that employees at businesses that are seriously getting started in the summer, such as in tourism and hospitality, do not have to terminate their employees.
Come back with a proposal to implement the UN Sustainable Development Goals as a framework in all municipalities, municipal agencies, and counties.
Develop better collaboration and investigate a shared electronic journal between specialist and primary healthcare services.
Investigate an increase in occupancy at Norwegian hospitals to 85% in line with OECD recommendations.

Investigate and return to the Storting with proposals on how Norway can increase the number of permanent intensive care beds in Norwegian hospitals by 100 and the number of monitoring beds by 300, while also training enough qualified healthcare personnel for this.

Present a proposal for a caregiver account in connection with the overall caregiver strategy and action plan that was announced in December 2020. The caregiver account should be coordinated with the ongoing work on a national caregiver survey.
Implement a reform that ensures that coercive fines and fees resulting from administrative errors or delays adhere to a principle of proportionality and do not unduly burden small businesses.

Evaluate how Norway during the coronavirus crisis has ensured that the most vulnerable groups (such as refugees, beggars, homeless individuals, migrant workers, undocumented individuals, sex workers, and children in violent homes) have access to vital needs such as food, a place to sleep, healthcare, and a safe everyday life, and come back with suggestions for improvements in emergency preparedness in the form of, for example, financial support schemes and emergency solutions such as health-safe accommodations and public food distribution.
Design a model for a tax on salmon lice in the aquaculture industry, and return with a proposal in connection with the revised national budget 2021.

Report on how the budget proposal aligns with Norway's climate commitments under the Paris Agreement. The costs of climate measures should, to the extent possible, be quantified in the budget proposal.

Present a special crisis package for Groruddalen and South Oslo, as well as for districts with similar challenges in other cities, with a particular emphasis on employment measures for youth/young adults, and return to the Parliament no later than the revised budget 2021.

Expand the specialist healthcare services in Alta with a maternity department and necessary emergency functions. It must be assumed that a new hospital will be built in Hammerfest, and that the hospitals in Finnmark will collaborate in a network model to provide the entire population with an equitable healthcare offer of good quality.

Postpone the introduction of value-added tax for alternative treatment until a comprehensive review of the alternative register and the law on alternative treatment has been conducted, in order to arrive at a better model to ensure patient safety and criteria that can qualify for exemption from value-added tax.

Adjust the compensation scheme for companies with significant revenue decline so that the employer period during layoffs is included in the definition of unavoidable costs, applicable for the months where the employer period during layoffs is 10 days.
Inform the Storting about which groups are being considered for authorization under the Health Personnel Act, and what assessments and criteria apply.
Present a message about tax policy that addresses the social and geographical distribution effects of various taxes.
Consider relocating the Norwegian Space Agency and related government jobs to Tromsø, and report back to the Storting no later than the presentation of the revised national budget for 2021.
Ensure that public procurement is used to increase the demand for Norwegian goods and services.
Notify of a further extension of the layoff period beyond 52 weeks and present a case for this to the Storting no later than January 2021, aiming for an extension until August 1, 2021.
Allocate 30 million kroner to Lukas Hospice, Malvik for the entire pilot period.
Ensure that the elderly living in institutions or receiving home care receive the dental treatment they are entitled to.
Come back with suggestions for the RNB 2021 on how the mountain boards' economy can be strengthened in 2021.
Facilitate increased use of joint initiatives for skills development for employees.

Ensure that businesses with extensive economic operations, but which do not have "profit as a purpose" and therefore do not pay taxes, are provided with financial compensation, such as companies for permanently adapted work, foundations, non-profit organizations, and a number of enterprises in areas including culture and museum operations.
Ensure that circular economy becomes part of Enova's mandate.

Task Statkraft with developing a national development plan for hydrogen infrastructure leading up to 2030. The plan should describe the needs for production, transport, and demand given various scenarios.
Utilize the flexibility within the state aid regulations and facilitate the ability of the support system to contribute a higher share of funding for larger industrial projects.
Develop a scaling plan for the turnover of advanced biofuels to 40% by 2030 without double counting.
Develop a national strategy for charging infrastructure, both on land and at sea.
Plan crisis support for students for the spring semester of 2021, so that the arrangements are ready when needed, and no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.

To strengthen Norwegian export promotion efforts and formalize the role of the foreign service, develop a strategy for economic diplomatic work based on the model of the Danish government's strategy. The strategy should place particular emphasis on how to create good incentives for increased work on export promotion at foreign missions, and what activities they should be responsible for.

Conduct a comprehensive review of the financing system for private kindergartens, including mapping the consequences for employees' pension conditions in private kindergartens, as well as investigating a system where the pension costs of private kindergartens are covered based on actual expenses. The government is requested to return to the Parliament with a report and proposals in the revised national budget for 2021.
Plan for students for the spring semester of 2021, so that the arrangements are ready when needed, and no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.
Allocate 30 million kroner to Hospice Malvik and 30 million kroner to the children's hospice in Kristiansand for the entire pilot period.
Ensure that persecuted Christians, Ahmadiyya, and Yazidi refugees are also prioritized as a group and as individuals in the selection of resettled refugees.
