Change the income requirement (both the requirement for future and past income) in family immigration cases so that benefits under the Introduction Act are not included (from January 1, 2021: benefits under the Integration Act).

To maintain the capital grant for private kindergartens at the 2020 level, initially for the first half of 2021, and to establish a fast-working committee that includes, among others, KS and PBL, to investigate the financing of private kindergartens, including the possibility of loans from the Norwegian State Housing Bank. The Parliament requests the government to submit a proposal for the determination of the capital grant for private kindergartens for the second half of 2021 in connection with the revised national budget.

Present an overview of all measures in the budget that have the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions as the main justification, and as far as possible, an overview of the effect of each individual measure measured in kroner per ton reduction or increased binding, as well as account for the status of the work in the Technical Calculation Committee for Climate.

Take the initiative to negotiate entering into the transport and storage partnership with state ownership stakes in the event of an expansion of the infrastructure to more than 1.5 million tons of CO2 per year.

Come back to the Parliament on how the state can take a portion of the revenues from future exploitation permits for CO2 storage. The assessment should include taxation and alternatives for state ownership, including the SDØE model.

Closely monitor cost and risk control in Langskip, in such a way that potential significant negative deviations in the projects are identified early, and that the government utilizes the agreement's flexibility to keep the state's costs as low as possible.

Assuming that the Norwegian language is primarily used for planned state investments or maintenance that will be put on the market in 2021 in the maritime sector, but will consider whether it is necessary to allow for English in certain cases.
Come back to the Parliament with an efficiency strategy for the public sector.
Consider changes to the value-added tax regulations for contracts so that the contractor does not need to report and pay value-added tax on disputed claims until the dispute is finally resolved.
Allow the sale of e-cigarettes with nicotine and tobacco-free nicotine pouches.

Grant public authorization to naprapaths and osteopaths, and conduct a new assessment of whether acupuncturists should be authorized as healthcare professionals. Until the assessment of acupuncturists is completed, the VAT exemption should be continued.
Submit proposals no later than in the revised national budget for 2021 that further improve the ferry replacement scheme so that even more ferry replacement projects can be realized.
Ensure progress in the work on the planning of the Glomma crossing on rv. 22 in Lillestrøm.
Ensure progress in the E16 Bjørum-Skaret project.

Take the initiative with the Swedish authorities in the first half of 2021 with the aim of entering into an agreement for a joint Norwegian-Swedish border station at Magnormoen with the Swedish authorities before the revised national budget. The Storting requests the government to return in the revised national budget with a report, so that the realization of the police station at the border/Magnormoen can be carried out once the financing of the entire project is clarified.
Ensure progress in the planning of rv. 19-E6 Moss harbor when quality assurance is completed.
To expand the construction loan guarantee scheme in GIEK to also include advance guarantees, so that GIEK can provide advance guarantees of up to 50%.

Follow up on the mineral law committee by proposing improvements and simplifications to the mineral law, including in the delineations against other regulations, among other things to ensure that coordination is good and that the time spent is as low as possible. The government is requested to return to the Storting in an appropriate manner.

Review the regulations for motorhomes/campers with European type approval to be automatically approved for registration in Norway without the need for individual approval at the traffic station, and present proposals for how this can be done no later than in connection with the revised national budget in 2021.
Establish an approval system for private actors who wish to offer NIPT, in accordance with the guidelines from the majority of the Storting in Innst. 296 L (2019-2020).

To expand Innovation Norway's scheme for the scrapping of vessels in coastal shipping to also include offshore vessels. Final criteria for the scheme will be developed in accordance with state aid regulations.
Develop a proposal for a differentiated coercive fine scheme, and return with an assessment of such a proposal to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Come back in the revised national budget with a proposal that pregnant women can be offered NIPT testing also in the public sector during 2021, in accordance with the guidelines from the majority of the Storting in Innst. 296 L (2019-2020).
Consider solutions to stop patient overload at Skaidi for patient transport between Alta and Hammerfest.
Strengthen the regional pediatric palliative teams to ensure that a good and equitable service is provided to children and their families.
Ensure that criminals convicted of offenses against children are prioritized in the sentencing queue, so that they can go directly from conviction to serving their sentence.
Ensure that the grant to volunteer centers and the current distribution is continued in 2021 with a special allocation, so that the funds are distributed per volunteer center and not per inhabitant.

Investigate the Østfold model for learners with special needs, developed by ASVL (The National Association of Work Cooperatives), and assess whether this can be made into a national scheme, as recommended in NIFU report 18: 2018.

Make a new assessment of whether the current government buildings can still be used, as an alternative to building phases 2 and/or 3 in the new government quarter. The assessment will be presented to the Parliament in the state budget for 2022.

Come back to the Parliament with an account of how Langskip is organized, who owns the technology that is being developed and demonstrated, and how it can be facilitated for society to get the most benefit from the technology being developed and demonstrated through government support.
Facilitate the utilization of as much of the technology developed and demonstrated in Langskip, as well as other learnings from the project, in Norway.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals for measures for aviation, including an assessment of the need for a compensation scheme for the aviation industry and the framework for route purchases.
Come back with a proposal on how non-governmental airports, including Torp and Haugesund, can be ensured continued operation in 2021.
Come back with proposals for measures, for example through a scheme organized by GIEK, to help ensure that the guarantee market for tour operators functions in 2021.
Assess the need for an additional extension of the tax payment deferral scheme.
Continue the guidelines on the disposal of housing or other assets to be granted social assistance.
Propose a new compensation model for businesses for the period after February 2021 and, if the infection situation warrants it, submit proposals by the end of January 2021.
Investigate a national maximum price for boat and ferry tickets, where the state fully compensates the counties for their loss of income due to the implementation of such a scheme.
Reduce the advance payment amount for AutoPASS for ferries to the same amount as the cost of the deposit for the AutoPASS toll tag.
Adjust the criteria for the funding of boat and ferry operations so that counties responsible for this part of the infrastructure can develop good services based on reasonable ticket prices.

Present a proposal for a financing scheme that involves the state fully covering the additional costs associated with the climate transition of the counties' fast ferry and ferry traffic. The scheme must account for both implemented and upcoming measures.
Reduce the advance payment amount for AutoPASS for ferries to 1,000 kroner.
Consider lower advance payment amounts for AutoPASS for ferries, and that this is assessed for all fare groups.
Present a parliamentary report on a national cycling strategy.
Ensure that a cycling strategy is developed in connection with the revision of the National Transport Plan.
Develop guidelines that ensure that the largest possible portion of the Government Pension Fund Global's operations is conducted from Norway.
Investigate whether the activities of the Government Pension Fund Global in Norway can be more widely distributed so that the entire country benefits.
Follow up on the management principles adopted in Innst. 330 S (2015-2016), where only the Parliament has the authority to make decisions regarding changes to the nationally designated wolf zone.

Follow up on a clear management of the wolf population by not allowing areas outside the wolf zone to be exempt from licensed hunting as long as the population targets for wolves set by the Parliament are met.

Stop any expansion of the wolf zone, including temporary expansion. Temporary expansion refers to protected zones/buffer zones that protect a limited area in a grazing-prioritized area outside the wolf zone where licensed hunting can usually take place. The existing expansion of the zone is revoked as of December 15, 2020.

Present a plan for determining the total number of refugees Norway will integrate over time. The plan should be based on the principle that the number of asylum arrivals, quota refugees, and family reunifications with refugees should be considered in conjunction, and family reunification with quota refugees should be clarified before they arrive in Norway. The number should be established based on negotiations between the municipalities and the state, with the Parliament setting the total number. Recommendations from the UN High Commissioner for Refugees should be emphasized throughout the process.

Facilitate the implementation of intensive courses in democracy, gender equality, and Norwegian working life, as well as initiate a pilot program for Norwegian language training for quota refugees before they arrive in Norway.

Establish a dedicated solidarity fund for refugees within the development budget that will contribute to the protection and dignified humanitarian conditions for people on the run, while also providing poor host countries in the surrounding areas with better opportunities to meet the long-term needs of refugees.

Come back with proposals for legal amendments that, within the framework of international obligations, provide a clearer distinction between convention status (asylum) and subsidiary protection, by limiting the right to family reunification and expanding the use of temporary permits in cases of subsidiary protection.

Develop a plan for how Norway can contribute to a more effective fight against irregular migration, including ensuring that the current legal basis for referring asylum seekers to safe third countries outside the EU is actively utilized. This requires cooperation agreements with third countries that ensure the asylum seekers' need for protection is well taken care of.
Impose the same requirements for identity clarification for permanent residence permits and family establishment as for citizenship.

Present proposals for changes to the regulations that ensure self-sufficiency through a tightening of the maintenance requirement, as well as consider a possible tightening of the provision regarding the connection requirement in family establishment cases.
Reduce the number of possible cabotage assignments from three to two.

Investigate a legal basis that allows provisions in the Act on General Application, such as the information and oversight obligations for clients, to be included in the Road Traffic Act, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Facilitate that outstanding fees and other defaults, including breaches of generalization provisions, are included as part of the risk classification system in the transport industry, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Prepare and promote proposals for limiting foreign truck transport in Norway, in accordance with the decisions made during the processing of the EU's mobility package.
Draft a proposal for a legal basis that allows Norwegian authorities to withhold vehicles that owe toll fees, and return to the Storting in an appropriate manner.
Change the national regulations for ferry fares so that all recreational vehicles, such as motorhomes, pay fare group B2.
Change the AutoPass regulations for ferry fares so that all recreational vehicles, such as motorhomes, pay tariff group AP1.
Make the necessary changes so that vehicle group M1 is included in prepayment class 1 for AutoPass ferry accounts.

Amend the regulation on the one-time tax on motor vehicles § 2-5. The new main rule for the definition of a motorhome for the calculation of the one-time tax shall be that all vehicles delivered as motorhomes from the factory and have type approval as motorhomes shall be subject to this tax calculation. A separate rule will be established for vehicles registered in other vehicle classes that are later converted into motorhomes. Here, standard requirements and individual approval must be assumed to obtain such reclassification.

Facilitate the possibility for motorhomes to increase the permitted total weight through the retrofitting of parts carried out by entities other than the final manufacturer. Documentation from the equipment manufacturer and an independent body should be sufficient to approve the increased permitted total weight.
Work to allow driving motorhomes up to 4.25 tons with a Class B driver's license.
Ensure an arrangement so that Norwegian-registered motorhomes can undergo approval for the Danish Tempo 100 scheme in Norway.
Facilitate more disposal options for wastewater from motorhomes and caravans along the roads.

Investigate how all 32 port terminals and central cargo ports can provide shore power to larger vessels by 2025. In the long term, the ports must also be able to offer other green energy carriers such as ammonia and hydrogen.
Facilitate the electrification of port infrastructure in combination with other developments of renewable energy, such as wind, hydro, and solar power, both on land and at sea.
Ensure progress in the work of developing standards for shore power and charging power for all vessel groups to reduce costs and streamline port stay times.
Facilitate the introduction of a disconnectable tariff as part of the new tariff model and require the grid company to provide such an offer.

Present a specific number of how many asylum seekers Norway will accept from Greece in 2021, based on the fundamental principle that Norway should be a leader in the coalition of European countries that contribute to the rule of law for the approximately 50,000 asylum seekers who are prevented from traveling onward from Greece.
Ensure that the relocation of asylum seekers in Europe does not result in Norway accepting fewer quota refugees through the UN, but rather that it is in addition.

Withdraw the Instruction on the interpretation of the Immigration Act § 32 – transfer of asylum seekers to Greece in accordance with the Dublin III Regulation (GI-07/2017) and process the asylum applications of those individuals who have Greece as their first country of arrival, in Norway.

Facilitate that Norway, within this year's quota of 3,000 refugees, can receive some of the most vulnerable children and vulnerable families with minor children from camps in Greece, under the following conditions: A range of European countries agree on an arrangement for reception. Distribution is calculated based on the population of the receiving countries. Norway will accept unaccompanied minors under 15 years old in the camps, preferably girls. Norway will accept vulnerable families with minor children. Norway will engage in dialogue with the UN to assess who are the most vulnerable within these groups.

Present and implement a concrete plan for what Norway's international contribution should be to establish dignified and rights-based reception conditions and asylum processing procedures in transit countries such as Greece. This involves quality assurance of asylum processing, free legal aid to vulnerable groups of asylum seekers, return work, and reintegration of vulnerable groups.

Promote a proposal to increase the number of quota refugees in 2021 by 500 and quickly develop a plan for how this will include the relocation of vulnerable asylum seekers in need of protection from Greece, as well as present a concrete plan for how many asylum seekers Norway will accept from Greece in 2021.

Come back with a proposal that clarifies the possibilities in the Courts Act for more flexibility, collaboration, and case sharing between the current judicial districts, including a clarification and amendment of § 55 e, so that it becomes possible to summon judges from other district courts and judicial districts also in individual cases.

Ensure that all courts will remain operational and staffed. For courts that currently have four or fewer permanent judge positions, the current level of positions related to core activities should be maintained.

To return to the Storting with a final proposal for changes in the court structure and changes in the judicial districts in accordance with the practice that minor changes should be presented to the Storting and larger changes should be presented as a separate case, where the consequences of decisions made in the Storting related to Innst. 134 L (2020-2021) regarding Prop. 11 L (2020-2021) have been previously assessed and sent out for consultation.
Promote a proposal to reverse the tightening of the National Insurance Act § 11-5, where considerations other than illness were downplayed.

Propose an amendment to the law that sets the benefit period for work assessment allowance to up to four years, and defines criteria for a genuine possibility of extension for those who need the benefit beyond four years. The amendment must allow for discretionary assessments of the individual’s need for an extension of the benefit period. Extensions should be granted, among other reasons, when the recipient has not completed their assessment or when Nav and the public health service have not fulfilled their obligations.
Come back with a proposal to reverse the cut in work assessment allowance for young people under 25 years old that was introduced in 2020.

Introduce increased requirements for Nav in the form of an obligation for the agency to closely follow up on recipients of work assessment allowance to ensure that the relationship between the user and the administration is established and maintained as intended when the Nav reform was adopted.

Promote proposals that expand the possibility of using the exception provisions in the National Insurance Act § 11-12 second and third paragraphs, so that the period for work assessment allowance can be extended based on an individual assessment of needs, in line with the goal of enabling as many as possible to return to work, either fully or partially.
Ensure that decisions regarding temporary benefits, including work assessment allowance, are made at the front line, as anticipated when the Nav reform was enacted.
Investigate the consequences of the introduced waiting period in the scheme for work assessment allowance.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan to abolish the staffing industry.
Promote a proposal for a ban on the hiring of labor from private companies that are not production companies.
Promote a proposal to repeal the Working Environment Act § 14-12 second paragraph. Necessary time must be given for restructuring, so that companies can recruit their own skilled professionals.

Promote proposals for changes to the Working Environment Act that ensure the law's purpose of safe working conditions by: ensuring that those who actually have decisive influence over an employment relationship have rights and obligations as an employer; clarifying the main rule regarding permanent and direct employment relationships in Norwegian working life; preventing employers from organizing themselves away from employer liability; ensuring that wage and working conditions are not weakened by tender processes, splitting of companies, and other changes in corporate structure.
Strengthen employees' rights in the Civil Service Act, particularly related to permanent positions and job security.
Reintroduce the right to minority appeal in hiring.
Ensure that employment services are a public responsibility.
Promote a legislative proposal to abolish the general access to temporary employment in the Working Environment Act § 14-9 second paragraph letter f.

Introduce a ban on the hiring of labor from private companies that are not production companies at construction sites in the counties of Oslo, Viken, and Vestfold, cf. the Working Environment Act § 14-12 fifth paragraph.

To present a proposal where the following is included in the Working Environment Act: If a business employs labor that does not have the status of an employee, the person performing the work shall be considered an employee if a) the relationship indicates that the purpose has wholly or partially been to circumvent the protection an employee has under this law, or b) the individual, after a comprehensive assessment, has a need for protection as an employee.
Strengthen the labor market competence at the Nav offices in municipalities and districts, and Nav's role as an employment intermediary.

Adopt a regulation to immediately lower the requirement for reduced working hours to receive unemployment benefits during layoffs from 50 to 20 percent until further notice, or promptly return to the Parliament with a proposal for a legislative amendment on the same matter.

Adopt a regulation to immediately ensure full salary (up to 6 G) for a minimum of 20 days from the time of layoff, or as soon as possible return to the Parliament with a proposal for a legislative amendment on the same matter.

Adopt a regulation to immediately reduce the income threshold for entitlement to unemployment benefits from 1.5 G to 0.75 G until further notice, or as soon as possible return to the Parliament with a proposal for a legislative amendment to the same effect.

Adopt a regulation to abolish the waiting days in the unemployment benefit scheme from the New Year and until further notice, or promptly return to the Storting with a proposal for a legislative amendment on the same matter.
Come back with suggestions for better income security for recipients of unemployment benefits and work assessment allowance who have reached the maximum benefit period.
Come back with suggestions for better income security for the long-term unemployed on unemployment benefits.
Hold an annual report to the Storting on freedom of expression and press freedom, as well as the current situation and goal achievement in media policy in Norway.
Grant exemption from quarantine obligation if one has tested negative for covid-19 on two tests.
Create a plan for mandatory testing in government administration at important border crossings, in combination with a quarantine regulation developed by health authorities.
Come back to the Storting with a plan for the introduction of mandatory testing for covid-19 upon entry to Norway.

Consider a model for increased testing for covid-19 at the border, which, along with entry quarantine, can contribute to lower infection rates in Norway, taking into account the experiences from Iceland.
Come back to the Parliament with an updated plan for how to ensure increased testing capacity throughout the country.

Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how to ensure increased testing and increased testing capacity for at-risk groups, and immediately facilitate testing for COVID-19 among employees and asymptomatic individuals in healthcare institutions, if the health authorities recommend this.

Ensure that a sufficient number of nurses and healthcare workers are trained to increase intensive care capacity across the country, and that better provisions are made for full educational programs offering bachelor's and master's degrees for specialized nurses.

Develop a national overview and a binding escalation plan for the education of specialized nurses and doctors specializing in intensive care medicine, as well as other healthcare personnel with intensive care expertise.

Increase the intensive care capacity in Norway and set requirements for intensive care capacity at the hospital trust (HF) level and regional health authority (RHF) level that ensure preparedness in normal situations and during future pandemics and other health crises, and inform the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Review the funding scheme for hospitals and ensure that it does not provide incentives to reduce intensive care capacity.
Ensure that the ability to quickly increase intensive care capacity is taken into account when constructing new hospital buildings.
Ensure updated and accessible information on national intensive care capacity and preparedness, and that the Parliament receives an annual update on this in an appropriate manner.

Investigate a unified organization of intensive care medicine in Norwegian hospitals, taking into account local geography and weather conditions, to ensure patient safety, consistent guidelines, coordinated professional development, and coordinated research activities, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Review all aspects related to the hospitals' intensive care capacity and preparedness in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, including private hospitals, so that the healthcare system is prepared for crisis situations that involve increased patient influx.

Ensure that an independent investigation is conducted into the environmental and health consequences of Equinor's investments in the USA and other countries, and report back to the Parliament before the summer of 2021.
Conduct a concept choice study (KVU) for the construction of an arm to Bergen from E134. The work on the concept choice study is to be initiated by the end of 2020.
Ensure that loss limits for gambling at Norsk Rikstoto are not introduced.

Wait to implement loss limits until after the Parliament has been appropriately informed about whether it is possible to introduce an additional individual adjustment of loss limits within the framework of socially responsible gaming.

Ensure that the state takes over the funding of the Norwegian Horse Center from January 1, 2022, as well as tasks related to doping control, event veterinarians, stable inspections, and preventive doping work.

Conduct a review of whether it is possible, within the framework of socially responsible gaming, to introduce further individual adjustments to loss limits based on an assessment of each player according to specific criteria, and appropriately inform the Parliament about the results of the review.
Make the abolition of the totalisator tax permanent.

Ensure that in connection with structural changes to police stations in Oslo, a comprehensive and long-term plan is established that involves a continuous presence of police based on police stations or police posts in the outer districts of Oslo South and Oslo East.

Ensure that an independent impact assessment of the plans is prepared in connection with the planning work for structural changes of police stations in Oslo. The impact assessment must examine how the merger will affect the service offerings, changes in police work methods and methodologies, crime prevention efforts, and changes in response times. The analysis must also evaluate how the changes will affect the police's collaboration with the municipality, child welfare services, and schools, as well as the economic consequences.

Promote necessary proposals to ensure that no one with a gross pension scheme receives less than the guaranteed pension at the age of 67, even if they choose to work longer. It is assumed that this can be implemented in a revenue-neutral manner. If this is not possible, the recommendation of the pension commission will be awaited.

Ensure that individuals covered by the applicable gross pension scheme in the public sector receive good information about the overall consequences for their total annual pension with various combinations of withdrawals from the National Insurance pension and public service pension.

Conduct a review of the current rules for the recalculation of occupational pensions for retirees who re-enter work in the public sector for a period, to ensure that short periods of work or small positions in situations where critical or important societal functions must be maintained do not lead to an unreasonable reduction in the occupational pension when the individual resumes drawing their pension.

Investigate legislative changes to reduce the requirement for premium payments from members in SPK, municipal pension funds, and other public gross occupational pension schemes from the time the individual has compensated for the longevity adjustment.
Come back to the Parliament with assessments of how to further strengthen the work line for public employees born in the years 1944–1962.

Base the following on development projects on the Norwegian continental shelf: The Storting agrees that the Ministry of Petroleum and Energy may approve projects (plans for development/facilities and operations) on the Norwegian continental shelf in 2021 under the following conditions: The project must not have significant principled or societal aspects. The upper limit for total investments per project is 7 billion kroner. Each individual project must demonstrate high socio-economic profitability and be robust against climate risk and changes in the price development of oil and gas.
Set requirements for electrification on all development projects on the Norwegian continental shelf during 2021 and report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner.

Present a plan for a significant increase in the long-term carbon uptake of Norwegian forest areas. The plan must, in addition to including a more detailed plan for tree planting on new areas, investigate which value creation measures and specific climate actions will enable the forestry sector to contribute to achieving emission targets.

Allocate more of the funds for Nature Information Centers directly to the centers based on the dimension of their authorization, so that the allocated funds reflect the 5-year plan developed during the authorization and correspond to the total responsibility of each visitor center. This must be designed in a way that redistributes resource use from project writing and application processing to direct activities as neutral knowledge disseminators, in line with the brand of Norway's national parks.

Provide municipalities and county municipalities with sufficient financial flexibility to address complex needs and challenges arising from demographic changes and climate change, and return to the Storting with proposals regarding this in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.
Implement measures to increase the use of performance-based procurement instead of price-based procurement during 2021 and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Investigate and implement requirements for higher sales targets for advanced biofuels during 2021 and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Give municipalities the opportunity to say no to cruise traffic calls and report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner during 2021.
Investigate how a scheme for the development of fast chargers can be established to compensate for installation costs beyond a 'normal' cost.
Investigate a ban on the use of fossil fuels in industry during 2021 and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Increase conditional co-financing for Fortum Oslo Varme (OFV) its capture facility to 4.5 billion kroner.
Consider whether additional incentive schemes for biogas production can be established in Norway.
Promote a proposal for basic support to the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters for Polar Research to maintain the academy's activities no later than in the revised national budget for 2021.

Secure a grant of 100 million kroner for Sikre Sjunkhatten Folk High School across various departments for a universally designed new building that is to be completed by autumn 2024. It should also be considered whether Statsbygg can be responsible for the construction.
Propose a start grant to UiT The Arctic University Museum of Norway no later than in the state budget for 2022.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal for financing ViteMeir in the revised national budget for 2021.

Ensure that the announcement and allocation of continuing education funds do not favor certain theoretical subjects, but instead address the actual need for continuing education across a wide range of subjects.
Allocate 500 million kroner of the total funds for further education for teachers to school-based competence enhancement related to the implementation of the curriculum renewal.
Ensure that manual therapists are included on par with chiropractors in the work to establish a five-year master's program.

Present proposals that strengthen the working conditions of technology transfer offices and ensure flexible financing in the earliest stages of a commercialization process. If this financing disappears, the pace of innovations will slow down, and Norway will see less commercialization from the research conducted at the country's public research institutions. This must be viewed in connection with the government's review of the business-oriented support system.

To map out the plans for the initiative Free Digital Arena (FriDA) in primary education, and what consequences this will have for the diversity and quality of the provision of digital learning resources.

Present a comprehensive plan for competence development for employees in SFO (School Age Care) no later than in the revised national budget for 2021, including an overview of the competencies of SFO employees. The plan should ensure that skilled workers in SFO receive access to vocational school offerings similar to what skilled workers in kindergartens receive through "Competence for the Future Kindergarten," and include a plan for financing vocational education in childhood studies, as well as ensure that more individuals have the opportunity to obtain vocational certificates while working.

Ensure that funding is provided for training on the school ship at Maritime High School Sørlandet from the fall of 2021 in the revised national budget for 2021, provided that a new school ship is put in place to replace the previous school ship MS Sjøkurs.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for funding the underfinanced fifth year of the primary school teacher education, no later than in the revised national budget for 2021.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that special education funding can follow the student during the time of training in a company.
Ensure progress in the work to establish talent centers in the natural sciences nationally.
Ensure that UiB is given the opportunity to use its allocated funds to continue the planning of new facilities for the Grieg Academy in collaboration with Statsbygg.
Engage in dialogue with the Student Society in Trondheim about the plans for new construction and return to the Storting in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.

Ensure that Statsbygg does not use subcontractors in labor disputes, including companies that use dismissal as a means against union representatives, and that suppliers respect the special protection against dismissal for union representatives.

Await further progress on the new government quarter until a proposal for a decision has been presented to the Storting, including a comprehensive, complete, and cost-estimated plan for the new government quarter, where alternative solutions are also cost-estimated and assessed based on security and timeline for completion.
Investigate how employers can be required to ensure that employees who are labor immigrants receive Norwegian language training.
Propose amendments to the law so that non-returnable asylum seekers are granted temporary work permits as long as they cannot be returned.
Return to the Parliament with a proposal to enshrine the right to kindergarten placement for all children in asylum reception centers.
Present proposals for and funding of more pilot projects with low-threshold services within the psychiatric and addiction fields in the municipal sector.

Assume that tenders for county municipal ferry and boat traffic hereafter will be based on zero-emission technology, and that the income system for the counties will henceforth ensure financing for the necessary transition to zero-emission solutions in all public transport.
Establish the necessary competence requirements in the municipal sector regarding the environment, biodiversity, and climate.
Expand the funding scheme for resource-intensive services for residents over 67 years old.
"Initiate work aimed at establishing a government operation of cloud services for public entities."

Promote proposals for a revised housing support framework that ensures that new disability recipients also receive housing support at the same level as before, so that housing support as a social housing tool is significantly strengthened.

Change the arrangement of the urban and growth municipality grants so that they are added as a surcharge to the municipalities that qualify for the grant, without any deductions from the framework for all municipalities.
Present proposals for different models to increase the state's share of co-financing for the scheme for particularly resource-intensive services.
Not compensating Bø municipality and possibly other municipalities, either through the income system or in any other way, for lost revenues related to local municipal decisions to reduce wealth tax.

Assuming that the cost framework for phase 1 of the new government quarter is not approved, but that the work can continue on a reduced scale until the Parliament is presented with an adjusted cost framework in connection with the Revised National Budget (RNB) 2021, where alternative solutions have been costed.

Investigate and report back to the Storting with alternatives for scaling down the project for a new government quarter, in all construction phases, and additional projects. It should be specifically examined how costs can be reduced, for example by reusing the current government buildings and modifying related projects.
Ensure that initiated qualification paths can be completed within the introduction program, and that the regulations are adjusted to provide the necessary flexibility regarding duration.
Propose changes to the regulations so that Norwegian citizens are not automatically registered as emigrated in the National Population Register after two years.
Implement a temporary halt to the closure of asylum reception centers until the pandemic is under control.
Establish a government interest compensation scheme for necessary investments in infrastructure in the municipal sector as a result of extreme weather.
Present a proposal for stronger income redistribution in the municipal sector.
Investigate and present a proposal for a step 2 in the top financing scheme with a maximum amount per resident, and return to the Parliament in connection with the municipal proposition for 2022.
Ensure an e-voting solution for the blind and visually impaired in polling places for the upcoming elections.
Ensure that only voluntary organizations registered in the Brønnøysund Register with an organization number can receive state funding under chapter 291 item 71.

Present a legislative proposal that ensures municipalities have the necessary authority for zero-emission zones/environmental zones for the sake of the climate, e.g., a zone where only zero-emission vehicles are allowed.
Propose a revised and more accurate method for calculating grants for the smallest municipalities with the greatest need for resource-intensive services.
Remove the tax exemption for stock dividends and return to the Parliament with the necessary proposals in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.

Introduce a temporary special tax of 3 percentage points on the profits of companies engaged in the rental of commercial real estate, based on the model of the special tax on the profits of financial companies, and promptly return to the Storting with a proposal for such a special tax.

Introduce a temporary extra tax on dividends from companies that have received state crisis aid during the coronavirus pandemic, and return to the Parliament as soon as possible with a proposal for such a tax.

Establish in regulation that landlords shall grant a 10-30% reduction in rent in order to receive payments from businesses that receive support through the grant scheme for companies with significant revenue decline after August 2020.

Investigate a production fee that provides both breeders and municipalities with incentives to use environmentally friendly zero-emission technology, where open facilities pay a high fee to the state, while closed facilities pay a lower fee that goes to the municipalities.

Remove the 30-day limitation to exempt leasing and rental of electric vehicles and the sale of electric car batteries from value-added tax, and return to the Storting with a proposal in the revised national budget for 2021.
Promote a proposal for a progressive inheritance tax with a basic deduction of 5 million kroner and a lowest rate of 10%, gradually increasing to a 50% tax on inheritances over 100 million kroner.
Propose tightening of tax expenditures on gains from the sale of one's own home and vacation property, as well as rental of one's own home, in connection with the state budget for 2022.
Establish models that make it possible to separate fixed assets such as machinery, inventory, etc. on the balance sheet when determining the asset value of unlisted limited companies.

Investigate whether and how the air passenger tax can be differentiated in favor of flights on the short-haul network and between Northern Norway and Southern Norway, and report back on this in connection with the state budget for 2022. The criteria may include the weight of the aircraft, geography, duration of travel with alternative public transport, or other criteria that ensure protection for the short-haul network and flights between Northern Norway and Southern Norway.

Postpone the implementation of the waste incineration tax until it is ensured that it does not lead to the export of emissions, and it has been investigated which businesses will be affected by the tax, and what effects the tax will have on the affected facilities.

Clarify with ESA whether newly acquired machinery and other operating assets in depreciation group d can still be granted an increased initial depreciation of 10%, and return to the Parliament with a proposal on this as soon as possible.
Investigate a fee on nitrogen in mineral fertilizers to price emissions of nitrous oxide, and return to the Parliament with a proposal for this in the state budget for 2022.
Investigate the reintroduction of the boat engine tax with exemptions for electric motors and batteries, and return to the Storting with a proposal for reintroduction in the state budget for 2022.
Investigate a turnover tax on the Oslo Stock Exchange or other forms of taxation on financial transactions, and report back to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2022.
Investigate the extent of adjustments to the shareholder model and the exemption method, and report back to the Storting during 2021 with a proposal aimed at countering unintended adjustments.

Investigate value-added tax on the residual value of cars sold in the used market that have previously had all value-added tax deducted in the VAT accounts, in order to improve the competitiveness of electric vehicles in leasing, and present a proposal regarding this in connection with the state budget for 2022.
Investigate and implement a one-time fee for heavy trucks during 2021 and return with a proposal for this in the national budget for 2022.

Investigate a restructuring of the document fee that ensures that the reuse of parts of existing buildings is favored in the fee system, and return to the Storting with a proposal for changes in connection with the state budget for 2022.
Investigate taxes or other measures to reduce emissions of methane and NMVOC and other emissions from the petroleum sector, and return to the Storting with proposals in the state budget for 2022.
Investigate a fee for the use of peat during 2021 and return to the Storting with a proposal for this in the state budget for 2022.

Investigate how the value-added tax system can be changed to ensure that the tax advantage of electric cars compared to fossil fuel cars at the time of purchase is replicated for car leasing, and report back to the Parliament with proposals in the revised national budget for 2021.
Investigate tax exemptions for zero-emission goods and freight vehicles during 2021 and return with proposals on this in the state budget for 2022.

Investigate measures to increase the material recycling of textiles, such as deposit systems or pricing for textiles, and return to the Parliament with proposals for measures in the state budget for 2022.
Investigate a material fee on the extraction of virgin natural resources and return to the Parliament with a proposal for this in the state budget for 2022.
Investigate various tax models for fossil plastics and plastic packaging and report back to the Parliament with proposals on this in the state budget for 2022.

Evaluate the effect of the proposed tax on waste incineration in connection with the presentation of the state budget for 2022. The evaluation should include the climate impact of the tax and whether the tax supports the transition to a more circular economy, as well as its effect on jobs and value creation.

Design a material fee that rewards the use of renewable and recycled materials, replacing the current packaging fee, and return with a proposal no later than in connection with the state budget for 2022. The competitiveness of products that currently have an exemption from the fee must not be reduced.

Promote a proposal for improvements in the tax on incineration plants so that the climate effect is enhanced. This could, for example, involve a material tax or an export tax, similar to what is done in the Netherlands.

Promote a proposal to remove the additional tax on wages in the financial sector while simultaneously increasing the tax on profits from financial institutions by an equivalent amount to offset the revenue loss.

Investigate a public health tax or other measures that create incentives for reduced sugar content in products, and that do not create undesirable competition distortion or come at the expense of revenue in Norway and Norwegian businesses.

Investigate the extent of adjustments to the shareholder model and the exemption method, and report back to the Storting during 2021 with a proposal aimed at eliminating unintended adjustments. The investigation must also consider alternatives to the exemption method.

Ensure that the exemption provisions established in nationwide collective agreements for employees and pensioners in public transport continue to be tax-free. The same applies to employee tickets for employees and pensioners in the railway sector.
Propose a cash flow taxation for hydropower that is limited to the refurbishment of existing hydropower plants.
Propose to increase the maximum property tax rate for residential and vacation homes to 7 per thousand.
Investigate changes to the Value Added Tax Act that ensure healthcare professionals must include value added tax if they provide alternative treatment.
Renegotiate existing tax treaties with the aim of being able to introduce withholding tax on royalties and interest.

Investigate whether any of the members in the organizations currently registered in the register for alternative practitioners can be considered to provide health care, and return to the Parliament with the necessary changes that would allow them to be exempt from the Value Added Tax Act.

Present a proposal for a tax on non-alcoholic beverages that is more differentiated based on the sugar content of the product, including considering exempting sugar-free drinks entirely from the tax, and return with a proposal for such a model in the revised national budget for 2021.

Investigate the differentiation of various taxes such as value-added tax, taking into account the effects on Norwegian jobs and the product's climate footprint and health impact, and present proposals for the introduction of such differentiated taxes in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.
Present a proposal to reduce or eliminate the value-added tax on Norwegian-produced food, including Norwegian-produced fruits and vegetables, in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.
Present an assessment of the situation regarding cross-border shopping, and an evaluation of whether a cross-border shopping barometer should be established as an annual survey.
Ensure that a survey on Norwegians' physical cross-border shopping is conducted regularly, at least annually, following a model similar to Statistics Norway's pilot survey.
Present an overview of how relevant taxes and cross-border shopping affect Norwegian jobs, and a strategy to preserve jobs in the Norwegian food industry and retail sector.
Ensure that Norfund withdraws its investments from commercially driven school chains.
Investigate and create an action plan for how Norway can achieve the goal of increasing annual climate financing to 65 billion kroner.
Evaluate the new budget structure for the defense budget for 2021 and present the evaluation in the revised national budget for 2022.
Reverse the proposed restructuring of the chapter structure for the defense budget.

Facilitate that the protected property Tollbugata 10, as it currently appears, is given as a gift to the Foundation The Old War School for a symbolic amount. The condition shall be that the foundation develops this property, which is particularly rich in historical and cultural values, so that it becomes accessible to the public and can thus convey the significance it has had for Norwegian societal development.

Inform the Parliament about the purposes (procurements) for which the additional allocation of 50 million kroner to expedite planned purchases of products and services from small and medium-sized technology companies was utilized, which companies have been awarded contracts, and how the scheme has contributed to ensuring the survival of small and medium-sized technology companies that deliver their own products/services directly to the defense sector.

Support the proposal from South Africa and India for temporary waivers from the patent provisions of the TRIPS agreement to combat COVID-19 ("Waiver from certain provisions of the TRIPS agreement for the prevention, containment and treatment of COVID-19"), and escalate multilateral efforts to prevent patent restrictions from becoming a barrier to a rapid and cost-effective response to the global pandemic.

Present a case to the Storting that provides a broader and better factual basis for making an informed decision regarding the easing of patent rights concerning vaccines and medical equipment for combating COVID-19, as well as outlining possible initiatives such as compulsory licensing and how this can be used as a measure during a global pandemic to ensure fair access to vaccines and medicines for countries around the world.
Reverse the cuts in support for children's glasses.

Ensure that students who receive loans or grants from the Norwegian State Educational Loan Fund and experience a loss of income due to the COVID-19 pandemic can receive unemployment benefits according to the National Insurance Act § 4-6, and request the government to return to the Parliament as soon as possible with a proposal for this in 2021.
Extend the maximum period for receiving work assessment allowance as a job seeker to December 31, 2021.
Ensure that the scheme for permanent and temporary wage subsidies is provided to 10,000 more people in 2021.
Ensure that all municipalities in the country adopt a full-time culture, and establish a government financial grant scheme for projects promoting full-time work and against part-time work.

Ensure that the National Association for Public Health can receive grants from the state budget's chapter 352 item 70, in line with other user and relative organizations, for its advocacy and peer support work for people with dementia.

Ensure that every business and participant in the permanent adapted work in ordinary enterprises (VTO) receives proper follow-up at a level comparable to the follow-up established by the HELT MED project, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner on how this will be implemented.

Take the initiative for a pilot project with the right to permanent adapted work for individuals under 30 years old, for example in the form of a pilot project in one county, with the goal of a 100% job guarantee for people with developmental disabilities after completing their education.
Strengthen the right to full-time work in the Working Environment Act by requiring employers to demonstrate their need for part-time positions.
Extend the maximum period for receiving work assessment allowance as a job seeker to July 1, 2021.

Submit a proposal to the Parliament that provides a compilation and discussion of intersecting measures within Nav and the specialist health services that are currently being implemented to reduce the increase in the number of young people on disability benefits. In particular, the unique collaboration model for young people in exclusion (the Saltdal model) must be reviewed. This model involves 24/7 support with simultaneous focus on work and health, as well as an emphasis on the young people's coping abilities and opportunities.
Suggest measures for parents of home-dwelling disabled individuals over 18 years old who, for infection control reasons, must stay home during the day during the pandemic.

Extend the maximum period for receiving unemployment benefits until July 1, 2021. Individuals who have been excluded from the scheme as a result of the government's decision not to extend the maximum period for receiving unemployment benefits beyond November 1, 2020, should be able to resume receiving unemployment benefits from January 1, 2021.
Reduce the income requirement for entitlement to unemployment benefits to 0.75 G for new cases from January 1 to July 1, 2021.
Propose changes to the National Insurance Act that involve reintroducing the holiday supplement for those receiving unemployment benefits.
Establish a new temporary arrangement that ensures laid-off skilled workers from third countries receive an income equivalent to unemployment benefits.
Promote measures to ensure that infection control regulations related to labor immigration are followed.
Come back with suggestions for the time being to ensure that employees on reduced working hours who occasionally have the opportunity to work more do not lose their right to unemployment benefits.
Come back with a package of measures for income security, skills development, and employment for the long-term unemployed.

Review the regulations and rates for social assistance, living expenses, and other means-tested benefits, and return to the Parliament in the revised national budget for 2021 with proposals that ensure recipients a dignified standard of living and that the amounts paid out increase.
Propose amendments to the National Insurance Act that introduce holiday pay for those who have been unemployed, including those who received unemployment benefits for less than 8 weeks in 2020.
Review the arrangement for glasses support for children and return in the revised national budget with a scheme that protects families with high eyewear expenses for children.
Establish a scheme to refund 8 of the 10 days in the employer period during layoffs, initially for layoffs implemented between September 1, 2020, and March 1, 2021.

Implement a temporary grant scheme for businesses with significant loss of income as a consequence of the coronavirus crisis and otherwise sound operations. The scheme will be established under the auspices of Innovation Norway, which is responsible for a number of other loan and grant schemes and has a presence throughout the country.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to scale up the frameworks for Innovation Norway's loan and guarantee schemes in line with the business community's need for support due to infection control measures and the pandemic in general.
Come back with a case that assesses how the business-oriented support measures can be used to ensure liquidity in times of crisis.
Consider in the next crisis package a temporary reduced VAT rate of 15% for catering services until July 1, 2021.
Consideration of the deletion of tax and fee claims.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a grant fund for municipalities with unemployment above the national average.
Assuming that extensions and new constructions of operational buildings on ordinary farms always constitute "special grounds" for the state to cover the costs of archaeological excavations.

Consider changes to the property tax law that exempts all owners of buildings that are either protected under the Cultural Heritage Act or designated for preservation under the Planning and Building Act from municipal property tax.
Propose a plan for the escalation of the Norwegian Cultural Heritage Fund in Røros, with the goal of building up the fund to have 300 million kroner available for annual distribution.

Consider arrangements for tax and fee incentives that scale the incentives for private owners in accordance with the conservation value. The goal is for those owners who manage the most valuable cultural heritage sites and cultural environments to receive the strongest incentives.
Consider exemption or a lower rate of value-added tax for the maintenance of protected cultural heritage sites and cultural environments, or a compensation scheme with a similar structure.

Explain how Norway – when our country is no longer a member of the World Heritage Committee – will resume efforts to have Norwegian cultural heritage sites and cultural environments from the Viking Age included on the World Heritage List. It is particularly requested that the government outlines how Norway can collaborate with other countries in the North Atlantic and the Baltic Sea in this context.

Investigate the establishment of a dedicated church heritage fund linked to increased state efforts regarding the maintenance of culturally and historically valuable church buildings. The purpose should be for both the state and municipalities to share responsibility, thereby triggering a greater overall conservation effort.
Ensure that the Cultural Heritage Fund's pilot project with grants for movable cultural heritage is extended to the same extent in 2022.
Promote a proposal for a permanent grant scheme for movable cultural heritage, either in the budget of the Ministry of Transport or in another suitable manner.
Return to the Storting in 2021 with a plan for the implementation of health assessments for children in child welfare services across the country.

Create a plan for how all counties can have at least one dedicated building preservation center managed by local museums and/or volunteer heritage organizations, and return with proposals for state operational support for these centers. Where appropriate, two or more counties can collaborate on a building preservation center, but in a way that ensures the service reaches all parts of the relevant counties.

Emphasize the need for craftsmen with specialized knowledge of lime and stone buildings, and consider how the projects being carried out can build up expertise and knowledge while also recruiting new craftsmen with specialized knowledge of older Norwegian stone churches.
Come back in the revised national budget for 2021 with proposals on how the state can contribute to the realization of the new World Heritage Center at Urnes Stave Church.
Consider distributing the one-time grant over several payments.
Promote a proposal for a change in the law that abolishes the cash support scheme from August 1, 2021. Cash support/waiting support can be provided until a kindergarten place is offered.
Transform the incentive scheme for international film and TV productions into a rule-based system and place it under the Ministry of Trade and Fisheries.

Implement sufficient and relevant control over the organizations by reducing the number of registered religious communities or in other ways, and that the Parliament is presented with a case on this no later than in the revised national budget for 2021.
Include measures against social control in closed religious communities in the upcoming action plan against social control.
Ensure that the Religious Communities Act § 6 second paragraph comes into force as soon as possible and no later than April 1, 2021.

Ensure that the Health Library will be a community solution that provides good access to necessary knowledge resources for healthcare personnel, and if necessary, return to the Parliament in the revised national budget.

Facilitate access for women in countries where abortion is illegal to safe and secure abortions in Norway, both by ensuring that health enterprises are aware that abortion is considered emergency healthcare and should be provided free of charge, and by initiating a European collaboration to ensure safe abortion services for women in countries where abortion is illegal.
Remove the bureaucratic system of performance-based funding and return to the Parliament with a proposal for a new funding arrangement for hospitals.

Investigate measures and return to the Parliament with proposals to ensure that we have more organ donors, with the goal of increasing the number of organ donors, and consider a system where organ donation is the norm and individuals must actively opt out of organ transplantation.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to establish a fixed salary scheme for general practitioners, midwives, speech therapists, and orthoptists with full and permanent positions.

Start an investigation into the establishment of a permanent government inquiry commission for large fires or expand the mandate of the Norwegian Accident Investigation Board to include major building fires.

Take the initiative for a financial escalation plan for the correctional services, aimed at providing the necessary resources to the correctional system and probation services to effectively implement sentences that have an impact on inmates across the country. The escalation plan should be developed in close collaboration with employee organizations, the correctional services, relevant professional environments, and relevant volunteer organizations associated with the agency.
Evaluate whether the establishment of closed institutions in child welfare, including movement restrictions, is in accordance with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.
Investigate whether a residence ban interferes with the person's constitutionally and conventionally guaranteed rights, including the freedom of movement, cf. the Constitution § 106 and the ECHR.

Propose amendments to the law that lower the threshold for the use of imprisonment as a sanction for criminals under 18 years old, as well as abolishing youth sentences as a sanction for criminals over 15 years old, thereby reversing the legislative changes made by the Parliament in 2011, cf. Prop. 135 L (2010–2011), cf. Innst. 83 L (2011–2012).
Propose amendments to the Police Act that allow for the general arming of the police.
Propose amendments to the law that eliminate the current reduction in sentences for multiple offenses.
Propose amendments to the law that ensure that criminals who have committed offenses in the past receive stricter penalties for new offenses.
Propose amendments to the law that impose stricter penalties for crimes committed in crime-prone areas.
Investigate a reversal of the criminal age of responsibility from 15 years to 14 years, as it was until 1987.
Add machetes to the weapons regulation § 9 regarding which types of knives are prohibited to acquire, own, and possess in Norway.

Change the practices in child welfare services to prevent children under 15 years old who commit repeated crimes, and for whom the child welfare services are unable to provide treatment, from being permanently discharged and sent back to their home community in some cases.
Prepare and present to the Storting an overview of sentencing in cases where offenders are charged with committing new offenses after having been convicted and served time for similar offenses.

Allocate funds for upgrading security equipment and access control in the correctional system, so that it can prevent gang members from smuggling in equipment to continue their criminal activities while serving their sentences.
Strengthen and expand the youth units in the correctional system with more places.

Report to the Parliament on the extent to which the new legal provisions for data collection from spring 2016 have been utilized in the fight against organized crime and criminal gangs, and what resources and expertise are needed for them to be used effectively.
Develop a binding action plan against knife violence in broad collaboration with all stakeholders who can contribute.

Ensure that the action plan against knife violence includes better enforcement of the ban on carrying knives in public places, the use of punitive measures, an expansion of the list of prohibited items in the weapons regulations, reduced availability of dangerous knives, a specific statistic for stabbings and threats with knives, collaboration with schools and preventive services for children and youth, among other things.
Present the action plan against knife violence by the summer of 2021.
Prepare and present to the Storting an overview of sentencing in cases where offenders are charged with having committed multiple repeated offenses.
Come up with suggestions for strengthening collaboration between the police, child welfare services, and vulnerable families, with the aim of improving the situation for the child.

Promote a proposal to amend the provisions of the Penal Code regarding the confiscation of economic gains, so that a duty of care is introduced with criminal liability for those who allow gang criminals' assets, cars, apartments, etc., to be registered in their name.

Investigate a proposal to amend the provisions of the Penal Code regarding the confiscation of economic gains, so that a duty of care with criminal liability can be introduced for those who allow gang criminals' assets, cars, apartments, etc., to remain in their name.
Prepare proposals for legal provisions that prohibit participation in criminal gangs and recruitment to these, and submit them to the Parliament so they can be processed by June 2021.

Propose to amend the provisions of the Criminal Procedure Act regarding restraining and stay-away orders, so that those who commit crimes in specific areas can be prohibited from residing within a larger radius and for a significant period of time, as well as consider the use of electronic monitoring to enforce this.
Develop proposals for legal provisions that prohibit participation in criminal gangs and recruitment to these.
Consider how parents can be more involved and held accountable for repeated offenses committed by their children who are below the criminal age, and propose suggestions for this.
Investigate whether, in special cases, it is possible to allow for increased penalties for new offenses of the same kind for repeat offenders under 18 years of age.

Ensure that suitable institutions are established in child welfare that can implement the provisions of § 4-24 of the Child Welfare Act regarding placement and detention for up to twelve months without the child's own consent or the consent of the person who has parental responsibility for the child.

Present measures and proposals for legislative changes to increase the scope of confiscations and make it easier for the police to seize assets acquired through criminal activities, both through civil confiscation and in criminal cases.
Ensure that a separate exit program is established for gang criminals that provides them with better opportunities to permanently break away from the criminal environment.
Ensure that bodily harm with a knife is recorded again in the STRASAK report.

Implement measures that provide immediate noise reduction for residents along Trondheimsveien between Sinsen and Grorud, including a lower speed limit with average speed monitoring, accelerating the work on replacing windows at Sletteløkka, dedicated bus lanes, and new noise barriers along the stretch.
Contribute to the establishment of zero-emission zones in major cities.

Introduce requirements for electric aircraft in future tender announcements, reductions in Avinor fees, exemptions from value-added tax, and the facilitation of infrastructure at airports so that Norway can be a leader in the transition to emission-free aviation.

Investigate alternative financing models for large railway investments other than the ordinary ones, for example, through the establishment of an infrastructure fund aimed at also financing larger railway projects, direct borrowing, or other methods. The government is requested to return to the Parliament with a proposal, no later than in the revised national budget for 2021.

Establish a new high-speed rail study prepared by an external expert environment with the premise that high-speed railways should be a multi-use concept for freight and passenger transport, and which considers a varied stop pattern.
Stop the planning of a third runway at Gardermoen.

Contribute to the introduction of geographically divided contracts regardless of whether it is Nye Veier, the Norwegian Public Roads Administration, or the county municipalities that have the overall responsibility, so that operating costs are kept as low as possible.
Implement work to establish a night train service to Copenhagen and Germany.
Ensure that the construction of the Stad ship tunnel begins in 2021.
Investigate possible compensation schemes for the passenger tax on flights in the short-haul network, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Establish a TT scheme in Nav that is based on the principles that apply to the state support for TT in the counties, with 200 trips per user per year.
Ensure that there is a sufficient flight service to Stord Airport and Ørland Airport as well.
Promote a proposal for an investment decision regarding a new airport in Mo i Rana in the revised national budget for 2021.
Prepare a complete and detailed climate budget for the Rogfast development and report back to the Storting no later than March 1, 2021.
Ensure that all unallocated funds under Innovation Norway's schemes in 2019 are redirected from petroleum to other industries.
Introduce a turnover requirement for advanced biofuels for shipping.

Come back with a proposal for a new model for the allocation of aquaculture licenses where the price is removed or reduced, and where competition is instead based on sustainability. In this context, there will be requirements for emission-free facilities and electrification.
Reintroduce the criterion that organizations receiving state support from the budget of the Ministry of Agriculture and Food must promote positive attitudes towards the agriculture and food sector.
Present proposals for changes to the Skattefunn scheme to free up funds for a scaling program for larger investments.
Allocate funds for a national campaign for better maritime safety where volunteers are mobilized along the entire coast.
Stop the land consolidation sale of Statskog.

Evaluate the CO2 compensation scheme for the fishing fleet and, in connection with the proposal for the state budget for 2022, present an assessment and an impact study on how a potential phasing out of the scheme would affect climate goals and fisheries policy issues.
Consider expanding GIEK's power guarantee scheme to include battery production and other energy-intensive industries.

Take the initiative to facilitate dialogue between the parties to find good solutions that can accelerate the conversion of the offshore fleet. Special consideration should be given to stricter requirements for the use of low- and zero-emission technology.
Task Enova with creating a plan for the use of battery packs on as many offshore vessels as possible by the end of 2022.
Consider whether Norway can participate in IPCEI Hydrogen.

Investigate how much needs to be invested in the Norwegian economy for Norway to meet its obligations by 2030 according to the Paris Agreement, including the extent of the additional need compared to the current level of public and private green investments, and report back on this no later than in connection with the state budget for 2022.
Propose a change in the mandate of the Government Bond Fund aimed at promoting capital for green investments, and report back to the Parliament during the first quarter of 2021.

Investigate various compositions of loan transactions and transfers from the Government Pension Fund Global (SPU) in the national budget with regard to the consequences for the state's wealth, the exchange rate, monetary policy, a well-functioning market for government bonds, and financial stability.

Report on how many and what type of businesses have received loans based on the loan guarantee scheme in connection with the revised national budget 2021. The report should include an evaluation of the banks' profit margins on the state-guaranteed loans.

Ensure that ongoing old-age pensions in 2020 are increased by the average of wage and price growth for 2020 from May 1, 2020, following a similar arrangement as in the budget agreement between the Progress Party and the governing parties for 2021. The government is requested to return to the Storting with how this will be implemented and retroactively paid. The payment is a one-time payment; any continuation of the increase in pensions must be decided in 2021.

Ensure that single minimum pensioners also receive an increased benefit in 2020 in the form of a tax-free one-time payment of 4,000 kroner, and request the government to return to the Storting with this. Any continuation of this allocation as a permanent addition to the minimum pension must be decided in 2021.

Submit a proposal as soon as possible and no later than the end of the first quarter of 2021 for a one-time increase of 4,000 kroner in the minimum pension level for single individuals for those who are pensioners in 2020. This should not have a permanent effect.

Introduce a low-threshold service with counselors in middle schools, with a preventive mandate aimed at implementing long-term attitude-changing measures in anticipation of conflicts between youth and parents.
Change the term minority advisor to a job title that is more neutral, in order to encompass all aspects of negative social control in various environments.
Introduce a pilot program with diversity contacts in child welfare services.

Develop a plan for increasing the number of minority advisors and establishing a national contact point, so that high school and middle school students can seek advice from this service regardless of which school they attend.

Present a bill proposing that health checks for children aged zero to ten years become mandatory, and that the checks are conducted with weighing and examination taking place without clothing. Unless the child is regularly monitored by the healthcare system for other reasons, all children and families must attend the scheduled health checks.
Clarify the need for further specifications of the duty to provide information in this and other laws.

Develop a guide on the duty to inform and the duty to avert, as well as the rules for exceptions to confidentiality, in order to strengthen collaboration across agencies in the work against negative social control and violence in close relationships. In this context, a broad information campaign must be carried out regarding the duty to inform, report, and avert, to ensure that everyone working with children, as well as the general population, is well acquainted with this.

Introduce reporting routines where relevant agencies such as schools, kindergartens, child welfare services, municipalities, county municipalities, Nav, etc., collaborate to create concrete overviews of children who have been left behind in their family's country of origin, so that the embassies can investigate the situation of the Norwegian children in the countries they are responsible for.

Propose a change in the law or clarify in the form of regulations that negative social control can also trigger the duty to report to child welfare services, cf. the Child Welfare Act § 6-4, and the duty to avert, cf. the Penal Code § 196.
Expand the mandate of the follow-up service to map and report suspicions of involuntary placement abroad.
Return to the Parliament with a proposal for a new system for pre-approval of primary education abroad to ensure that the child has access to adequate teaching quality.

Return to the Parliament with a plan for increasing the number of minority advisors, so that high school students can seek advice from this service regardless of which school they attend. The Parliament also asks the government to consider whether dedicated minority advisors should be employed at certain junior high schools.
Introduce guidelines that ensure resource teams are quickly involved when children have undocumented absences from school, to safeguard the child's right to education.
Propose changes to the legislation that ensure that the authorities can better follow up and assist children who are left behind abroad, regardless of which country the child is in.

Take the initiative to develop an accurate methodology and coordination among public authorities in international cases concerning children left behind abroad, to ensure that these cases are handled in a cross-agency and integrated manner.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for amendments to the law that ensure that parents who systematically and deliberately prevent their children from attending compulsory schooling are financially sanctioned through daily fines and deductions in child benefits for the entire period they have undocumented school absenteeism for their child.
