Consider how all municipalities can ensure a common coordination point for the various support measures against negative social control, where anyone seeking help or guidance can turn to.

Ensure offers of competence enhancement that provide basic knowledge about negative social control for teachers and counselors from elementary school to high school, as well as guidelines for how schools should systematically work with this issue.
Initiate an investigation aimed at strengthening reporting on how many children are left behind abroad, and explain how the scope for follow-up can be enhanced.

Prepare a comprehensive overview of the social work directed towards families affected by negative social control, including an assessment of whether the work is targeted and sufficient, and present it to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Implement an information campaign about the duty to inform, report, and intervene related to negative social control and violence in close relationships.
Take the initiative to develop a program to support children and youth who have been left behind abroad, even after returning to Norway, so that they receive the necessary assistance to start anew.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals that ensure that the unemployed do not bear the cost of layoffs through waiting days or a reduced employer period.
Consider lifting the exception from the requirement to undergo the quarantine period at a quarantine hotel for workers and contractors in cases where the employer or client provides accommodation.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that lowers the requirement for reduced working hours to receive unemployment benefits during layoffs, so that those who occasionally work more than 50 percent do not lose their right to unemployment benefits.
Ensure that employers are fined if employees show up for work during the quarantine period, in cases where the employer is aware that the employee has been in a red-listed country.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that ensures that everyone who has been unemployed receives holiday pay for the period they have received unemployment benefits.

Gather assessments from the municipal chief medical officers in northern Norwegian municipalities and take these into account when evaluating measures to prevent import infection from foreign soldiers. Planned exercises and training should be modified, adapted, or canceled if necessary to avoid local spread of import infection and overburdening of the civilian healthcare system.
Reduce the maximum cap for support payments in the compensation scheme for businesses to 10 million kroner per company per month.
Suspend activity requirements for social benefits as long as the coronavirus crisis persists.
Increase the rate of unemployment benefits to 80 percent for the first 4 G until October 1, 2021, for all unemployment benefit recipients.
Include closed events organized by the event industry in the support scheme for public events.
Include costs related to lost inventory due to expired dates as a result of infection control measures in the compensation scheme for unavoidable costs.
Work for a temporary easing of international patent regimes, so that low- and middle-income countries can increase their production of medicines, vaccines, and other technology to combat COVID-19.
Promote proposals to increase funding for municipal business funds.
Promote a proposal for a temporarily reduced value-added tax rate for catering services to 15 percent for a minimum of 2 terms in 2021.
Define independent businesses within the same sole proprietorship as separate enterprises if separate accounts are maintained.
Promote proposals that ensure that stores that wish to do so can remain open every day.
Introduce temporary tightening of the entry regulations to Norway and limit the purposes that grant the right to enter Norway.
Ensure round-the-clock staffing of all border stations.
Ensure that gyms that maintain adequate infection control measures can remain open.
Ensure that mandatory COVID-19 testing is implemented upon entry to Norway and that foreign COVID-19 test certificates are rejected.
Ensure that everyone arriving at Norwegian border stations registers.
Ensure income security for newly graduated individuals who become unemployed after completing their education during the coronavirus crisis.
Strengthen Nav's support and services for newly graduated individuals who are unemployed.
Demand that the compensation schemes require businesses receiving support to repay if they proceed with layoffs.
Impose requirements in the compensation schemes that businesses receiving support must repay the support if they distribute dividends.
Impose requirements in the compensation schemes that businesses receiving support must repay the support if they buy back their own shares.
Reduce the requirement for lost working hours to receive unemployment benefits during layoffs to 40 percent until October 1, 2021.
Ensure that municipalities with low infection rates are allowed to serve alcohol in connection with food service.
Strengthen control at border crossings, including tailored solutions for less trafficked border crossings.

Establish a compensation scheme for airlines with Norwegian operating licenses that have been operating in Norway over time. The purpose of the scheme should be to ensure the Norwegian route offer, secure Norwegian jobs in aviation, and impose requirements that ensure the support does not go to the companies' creditors and shareholders. The support should help ensure permanent and direct employment with Norwegian wages and working conditions in aviation.

Present a binding escalation plan for phasing out the tendering system in child welfare, ensuring that when current contracts with commercial companies expire, they will not be renewed, and individual purchases will be terminated. The escalation plan should ensure that ownership and operation in child welfare are public and involve long-term collaboration with non-profit actors.

Present a binding escalation plan for phasing out the current tender system in child welfare, as children should not be subject to tenders. 2. Avoid consolidation and excessive market shares for large commercial providers upon the expiration of contracts with private companies, and increase the share of non-profit and small, independent service providers when entering into new contracts. 3. Present an escalation plan that ensures ownership and operation in child welfare is public or in long-term collaboration with non-profit actors.

Investigate various ways to secure the remaining financing for Fortum Oslo Varme's carbon capture through the use of innovative financing mechanisms, public procurement policies, or requirements for the use of waste management with energy recovery and carbon capture, and promote proposals for such financing in the draft revised national budget for 2021.
Set goals for testing CO2 capture from the air in Norway and secure funding for such pilot plants.
Clarify the further regime for support to Norwegian companies that wish to implement carbon capture, and propose this in the proposal for the revised national budget for 2021.
Investigate various ways to ensure strong enough incentives to implement CCS in energy recovery from waste, with the goal that all energy recovery from waste occurs with carbon capture.

Investigate which industries have process emissions that are difficult to replace, and propose measures that are strong enough to implement carbon capture in these industries, and return with suggestions on this in the proposal for the national budget for 2022.

Open up for power companies to apply for power development even in protected waterways where the nature and environmental impacts are limited, while also providing benefits in the form of increased power production and profitability.
Come back with proposals for tightening the concession law and other legislation with the aim of strengthening local Norwegian ownership of forests and land in Norway.
Come back with a proposal for a legislative amendment that means that the sale of limited companies that own concession-required areas also requires a concession.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a change in the law to introduce price control on pure forest properties, in order to ensure dispersed ownership and the possibility for comprehensive management.
Return to the Parliament with the necessary proposals to amend the Public Procurement Act so that environmental and climate considerations are weighted at 50% in public procurements.

Present a proposal for changes to the Public Procurement Act § 4. The proposal should ensure that the principle of safeguarding environmental, social, and labor rights is given equal importance to the existing principles of competition, equal treatment, predictability, verifiability, and proportionality in public procurement.
Initiate the cleanup work at Folldal mines and return to the Storting in connection with the revised national budget for 2021 with a concrete plan on how this will be carried out and financed.
Implement measures to separate the wholesale, distribution, and retail sectors in Norwegian grocery trade to ensure competition within each sector, and if necessary, return to the Parliament.
Create a digital sales data register for sales data of goods traded in the grocery market, and ensure access for all producers and suppliers.

Present to the Parliament a proposal for amending the Working Environment Act that clarifies the employer's responsibility in franchises, corporate groups, and similar organizations. The proposal should ensure that those who have decisive influence, and thereby are effectively the employer, also receive rights and obligations as an employer in accordance with the Working Environment Act.
Investigate models to limit the differences in purchasing prices in the grocery industry.
Abolish the alcohol regulation § 3-4, which prohibits kiosks and gas stations from applying for a sales license on the same terms as the grocery industry.
Investigate a ban on private label products (PLP) in the grocery industry and report back in an appropriate manner in connection with the revised national budget 2021.
Discuss various models for making distribution and supply chains less integrated in the grocery industry.
Map and propose measures to limit cross-subsidization between independent brands and private label brands (PLB) in the grocery industry.

Investigate a ban on discriminating between own and independent brands in a way that puts independent brands at a disadvantage in competition in the grocery industry, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Clarify to the Competition Authority that the grocery chains' overall purchasing conditions should be the same, unless suppliers can document cost differences in production or distribution related to each individual chain.
Provision in the regulation that the Grocery Supervision Authority is granted the authority to supervise the logistics area and the use of private label products (PLP) in the grocery market.
Present a separate white paper to the Parliament on the food industry.

Investigate measures to ensure competition and greater transparency within the wholesale and distribution sector of the grocery trade, including oversight of the pricing calculations for distribution services.
Investigate measures to limit the spread of private label brands (PLB).
Introduce a reporting obligation to the Competition Authority for the purchase or lease of production capacity in the supplier chain of the grocery industry.

Map the lack of enforcement of intellectual property rights and return to the Parliament with proposals for measures that more effectively protect producers' ownership of their own brands, product development, and innovation activities against the private labels of grocery chains.
Ensure that the Grocery Supervision Authority collaborates with the industry on a common labeling system that better distinguishes the chains' private labels from independent brands.

Map the usage and pricing of private label brands (PLB) compared to corresponding prices for branded products from the industry. Requirements for justification will be introduced for grocery retailers if significant differences in margin markups are discovered.
Investigate various models to take into account the competition in the grocery industry regarding lease agreements related to both existing premises and new constructions.

Clarify to the Competition Authority that in its work, the authority must assume that suppliers with a dominant position have a particular responsibility to demonstrate that differences in purchasing terms are objectively justified and do not harm competition. It must be assumed that differences in purchase prices from dominant suppliers, which do not have an objective justification through differences between the chains in production or distribution costs, or differing values of specific counter-performances, harm competition between the chains. It should be communicated to the various actors in the industry, both at the supplier and chain levels, that although the burden of proof lies with the suppliers, the chains are equally responsible for complying with the regulations.
Demand an accounting and functional separation between the links in the value chain in the grocery industry.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal on how the grocery industry can facilitate that discounts achieved in negotiations between suppliers and chains more closely follow the product.
Investigate and propose measures to ensure greater transparency in the food supply chain.
Clarify to the Competition Authority that guidance for businesses must be strengthened in the grocery sector.
Ensure that the Competition Authority has closer oversight of vertical integration and vertical restraints that may harm competition in the grocery industry.

Prepare to inform the Competition Authority that they must be particularly attentive to vertical integration and concentration of chain power. Private labels must not attain such a dominant position that they push out other players and hinder innovation.
Develop a cross-border trade barometer as a permanent arrangement by July 1, 2021.
Present a separate case to the Storting regarding border trade, where measures are discussed and proposed to reduce border trade and ensure the competitiveness of Norwegian businesses.

Postpone planned closures or reductions of service offerings at traffic stations. Any structural changes should not be implemented until effective solutions are in place that ensure a lasting reduction in the need for physical presence, for example as a result of digitalization, and that do not have significant negative consequences for people and businesses.
Allocate resources to government agencies and the municipal sector that are earmarked for innovation.
Make visible how this has been calculated.
Assess the need to make necessary changes to the regulations for telecommunications to reduce costs for the development of fiber networks.
Investigate a national cloud solution for public enterprises.
End the so-called ABE reform.

To investigate solutions with a reduced scope of statutory tasks, staffing norms, regulations and rights establishment, state goals, and objections in order to facilitate greater municipal self-governance with a higher degree of innovation.

Present a strategy for the public sector that involves user organizations, elected representatives, and management in all major public enterprises in a binding process on how the trust reform should be shaped in each area with the following objectives: Reduce the use of market mechanisms in all parts of the welfare state, such as purchaser-provider models, outsourcing, internal billing, competitive tendering, privatization, and market-based financing of welfare services. Ensure that the parliament, government, and ministries, in collaboration with the parties in the labor market, govern the public sector based on fewer and better quality goals. Strengthen tripartite cooperation and the rights of employees to be involved in all important processes, both in the state and in municipalities. Collaborative partnerships should become an important part of the work of public leaders at all levels in the public sector. Use digital technology as a tool for trust management and ensure that large ICT projects in the public sector are managed in a new and better way based on close involvement of users and employees, and by building up expertise within the organization rather than purchasing consulting services. Contribute to establishing leadership training in the public sector based on the Norwegian labor model. The public sector must have its own in-house digital competence.
Come back with proposals for startup funds for several trials to develop new and more user-friendly working methods and approaches in various welfare services based on the model of Stanghjelpa.
Strengthen research in and for the municipal sector.

Ensure good broadband/5G coverage across the country, so that there are no technological barriers to business establishment and operation, and that innovations such as digital health services are made available even in rural areas.

Investigate whether and how a potential obligation for network companies to explore the possibility of installing fiber in collaboration with other actors when power lines are replaced can be introduced, and present this to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Present a political total account of the vote exchange agreements and other types of commitments or understandings that have accrued in connection with the campaign for Norway's seat on the Security Council.

Inform the Storting about the vote exchange agreements and other types of intergovernmental commitments or understandings that have been made in connection with the campaign for Norway's seat on the Security Council.

To hold an open briefing regarding Norwegian focus areas and key issues that have been and are expected to be addressed in the Security Council during Norway's membership in the council. It is also requested that these topics be included in the regular annual foreign policy briefing.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal for the ratification of the Rome Statute's amendment on the crime of aggression (Kampala amendment).
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a new provision in the Penal Code chapter 16 that criminalizes acts of aggression, in line with the Kampala amendment to the Rome Statute.
To require Wizz Air to cease its domestic flights in Norway, because they violate ILO Convention No. 87 on freedom of association and protection of the right to organize.
Use ownership in Avinor to deny Wizz Air access to Avinor's airports as long as Wizz Air does not allow employees to organize and enter into a collective agreement.
Exclude Wizz Air as a provider of business travel for state employees.
To use state ownership to work for the exclusion of Wizz Air as a provider of business travel services for employees in state-owned companies.
Engage in dialogue with Lufthavndrift AS with the aim of buying them out of the agreement for the operation of Haugesund Airport Karmøy.

Include serious or systematic violations of workers' rights as a criterion for observation and exclusion from the Government Pension Fund Global, and incorporate the right to engage in collective bargaining and reference to ILO Convention No. 87 on Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organize as the basis for the ethical guidelines for investments of the Government Pension Fund Global.
Ensure that the requirement for Norwegian wage and working conditions and the right to enter into a Norwegian collective agreement are upheld for Wizz Air's employees on domestic flights in Norway.

Investigate solutions to shield the short-haul network and routes between Northern and Southern Norway from price increases on flight tickets, and report back to the Storting with a proposal no later than in the revised national budget for 2021, where it should be considered: to require Avinor to remove the take-off fee at airports that currently have a 30% discount and compensate for the loss of income through corresponding increased fees at other airports; to eliminate the air passenger tax for flights with aircraft types under 20 tons and cover the revenue loss by increasing the tax on other flights.

Secure Norwegian jobs, expertise, and critical societal infrastructure in Norwegian aviation through state ownership. The ownership should be purposefully used to ensure Norwegian jobs and seriousness in Norwegian aviation, as well as to reduce carbon emissions and build a green aviation industry. Additionally, the ownership should aim to secure air traffic in those parts of the country where there are no environmentally friendly alternatives.

Investigate the possibility of introducing a "frequent flyer levy" or "air miles duty" in Norwegian aviation. The investigation should include an assessment of how such a tax can be differentiated between international flights, domestic flights, and flights on the short-haul network.

Present a plan to secure the necessary investments to reduce emissions in Norwegian aviation in general through a focus on zero-emission technologies. The plan must describe how this can help position Norway as a leading industrial player in the development of zero-emission solutions for the aviation of the future.
Align all measures related to airport infrastructure, fees, incentives, and other aspects with the goal of making the short-haul network's aircraft emissions-free by 2030.
Support setting conditions for greenhouse gas emission reductions and that the Norwegian model for the labor market is followed.

Initiate the work of establishing competence transfer programs and job security programs, for example based on models from previously established industry programs, for employees in Norwegian aviation, and actively involve the trade unions in this work.

Present a national aviation strategy in the form of a parliamentary report based on the recommendations of the Aviation Committee in NOU 2019:22 From Status Symbol to Common Ownership – Norwegian Aviation in Transition.

Investigate whether a minimum price for airline tickets can be established based on the model from Austria, which should at least cover the company's costs for transporting a passenger, and return to the Parliament with a proposal in an appropriate manner.
Present a compensation scheme for airlines with a Norwegian operating license.
Engage in dialogue with Norwegian with the aim of finding solutions that can save the company's Norwegian jobs and ensure the company's route offerings to and from Norway.
Ensure that Avinor is compensated for the loss of income from air traffic due to travel restrictions related to the virus outbreak.

Present measures that ensure a good flight service throughout Norway, and that contribute to airlines with Norwegian operating licenses being able to continue responsible operations. A compensation scheme for airlines with Norwegian operating licenses must help secure Norwegian jobs and operations with Norwegian wage and working conditions.
Ensure that the Avinor model is continued for the operation and further development of airports throughout the country.
Promote a proposal for a crisis plan for Norwegian aviation that will last until the end of 2021.
Present a parliamentary report on a national aviation strategy, where the ambitions are to outline the framework for a comprehensive and sustainable development in Norwegian aviation.

Ensure flight route offerings Oslo–Stord round trip and Oslo–Ørland round trip, either through a temporary solution via the FOT route arrangement or through direct purchases or other agreements with the airlines.

Amend the regulation on fees for the use of studded tires and additional fees so that a studded tire fee cannot be introduced for through traffic outside the city center in a municipality with a studded tire fee.
Amend the regulation on fees for the use of studded tires and additional fees so that a studded tire fee cannot be introduced on national roads.
Clarify in the Driver's License Guide that the cognitive tests should only be used when there is suspicion of cognitive impairment.

Conduct a review of how the current system for mandatory health tests for driver's license renewal works, and investigate whether it is reasonable to raise the age limit for mandatory health tests to 85 years.
Ensure that there are good control mechanisms in place so that those who are not fit to drive are stripped of their driver's license, and that this is done regardless of age.
Remove the requirement for mandatory, age-specific health certificates for the elderly as a basis for driver's licenses.

Look into the possibilities for how those who have already had their driver's licenses revoked as a result of the cognitive tests can have the opportunity for a new assessment of their suitability to drive, and that the government returns to the Storting in an appropriate manner with proposals for a solution during the spring of 2021.
Investigate and propose an extension of the calculation basis for disability benefits, based on the average income of the three best years out of the last ten.
Facilitate that people with disabilities receive the same income limit as those who have a VTA position.

Investigate and propose an expansion of the calculation basis for disability benefits, where, for example, the average income from the best five of the last ten years is used, in order to provide incentives to attempt reduced working hours before considering a transition to disability benefits.
Investigate models to provide better incentives to try reduced working hours before considering a transition to disability benefits.
Investigate the possibility of having a disability pension of less than 50 percent.

Clarify the regulations, in accordance with request resolution 927(2015–2016), for both state and municipal benefits, so that there is no right to refuse work for religious or ideological reasons without interruption or reduction in benefits.

Ensure that users who are registered as new recipients of municipal and/or state benefits are informed early that a suspension or reduction of benefits will be a consequence of reserving against work or activities for religious or ideological reasons.
Promote the legislative proposals necessary in the Working Environment Act to ensure a genuine right to full-time employment.
Promote necessary legislative proposals to ensure that children under 18 years old are not deducted from basic or assistance benefits as a result of long-term hospital stays.
Develop a national digital on-call system for available sign language interpreters year-round, at least for healthcare institutions both nationally and locally.

Promote a comprehensive plan for the health services for the hearing impaired, which maps the needs within hearing care and proposes measures for assessment, diagnosis, allocation of hearing aids, follow-up, rehabilitation, and coping.

Ensure that Sykehusbygg HF develops a new model for projecting activity and capacity needs. The model must ensure that the health enterprises plan new hospital buildings based on needs and expected demographic and epidemiological developments, and not based on expectations of efficiency improvements, further cuts in inpatient care, and task transfers to the municipalities.
Change the financing model for hospitals so that hospitals are included in the same budget and accounting system as municipalities and county municipalities.

Investigate and return to the Parliament with a proposal to abolish the health enterprise model and establish a governance system with independent hospitals under regional management. Such a change must ensure elected governance, local and practice-oriented leadership, and employee participation.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to change the organization of healthcare services by abolishing the regional health authorities and distributing the tasks between a national governing body and the individual health enterprises.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to increase the share of performance-based funding to 60% in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.
Ensure that all of the country's current and future hospital buildings have adequate parking capacity.

Investigate and propose a new financing model for hospitals, where investment and operations are separated, and where large hospital investments are prioritized by the Parliament and fully funded through the national budget.
Ensure that all new hospital buildings are planned with a maximum occupancy rate of 85%, in line with the recommendation from the OECD.

Make the necessary changes to the governing documents for the implementation of hospital construction projects to ensure that infection control and preparedness for epidemics and pandemics are emphasized in the planning of new hospital buildings.
Ensure the involvement of employee representatives in the planning and evaluation of new hospitals, and that crucial emphasis is placed on the employees' input and perspectives.
Ensure that hospital projects are built according to actual capacity needs and not scaled down to meet a politically conceived budget limit.
Ensure that employees are involved in the planning and evaluation of new hospital buildings.
Ensure measures that can contribute to increased use of agreement specialists in health enterprises, and inform the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Consider allowing microbreweries to sell beer with slightly over 4.7 percent alcohol directly from their own production.
Investigate and propose a differentiation of the alcohol tax, so that alcoholic beverages are cheaper in licensed establishments and more expensive in retail stores.

Establish that establishments that violate the Working Environment Act or offer wages below the universally applicable tariff may have their liquor licenses revoked, and inform the Parliament about this.

Return to the Storting with the necessary proposals to allow the sale of cider in one's own production facilities without the requirement that the raw materials are sourced from one's own production or farming operations.
Investigate a solution where local distilleries and breweries can sell their own produced goods in their own production facilities, in collaboration with Vinmonopolet.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals that can ensure that entrepreneurs and businesses can hold tastings of alcoholic beverages of class 3 before 1:00 PM.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to amend the Alcohol Act to allow labeling of alcohol packaging with any awards and/or prizes.
Ensure that Vinmonopolet can choose which accessories they want to sell, and return to the Parliament with any necessary proposals to ensure this.

Investigate changes to the procurement regulations for Vinmonopolet with the aim of increasing the selection of locally produced goods at each individual outlet. The starting point can be the model used by Systembolaget in Sweden, but the criteria must be adapted to Norwegian conditions, and they must be objective.
Ensure that municipalities do not have the opportunity to oppose the introduction of free user choice in elderly care.
Elaborate and implement guidelines for systematic coronavirus testing of staff and residents in health institutions for the elderly and in home care services.

Ensure a review of the consequences of the coronavirus measures implemented after March 2020 for the elderly in institutions or receiving home care, and ensure that this is presented to the Parliament.

Ensure that all nursing homes and home care services have sufficient infection control equipment and are provided with opportunities for necessary minor renovations (establishment of visiting rooms, isolation rooms, etc.).
Promote a national program for more full-time positions, increased basic staffing, and recruitment for the municipal health and care services, with measures both in the short and long term.
Introduce the system of free user choice in elderly care.
Ensure that medical and palliative treatment of elderly individuals with COVID-19 infection is assessed individually and based on need.
Ensure that no elderly individuals in healthcare institutions have to die alone during the pandemic. Close relatives must be given the opportunity to be present during the final phase of life.
Ensure that municipalities and hospitals report cases where elderly individuals die alone in healthcare institutions, and why relatives could not be present.
Suggest measures to ensure better infection control and dignified care for the elderly during the coronavirus pandemic, and to promptly report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Change their communication practices during the pandemic in such a way that municipalities and municipal chief physicians are directly notified of national changes and measures.
Create a regulation that ensures that individuals with disabilities from occupational groups with special age limits do not have large sums coordinated away from the special age limit to 67 years.
Promote proposals to repeal the legal provisions for establishing special age limits for pensions.
Resume negotiations with employee organizations regarding future regulations for special age limits, including the issues raised in Representative Proposal 45 S (2020–2021).

Ensure that the pension committee, which is to evaluate the pension reform, including the relationship between the new old-age pension and other schemes, with a clarification of its mandate, is tasked with assessing the issue raised in Representative Proposal 45 S (2020–2021).
Propose to change the pension accrual for recipients of disability benefits, so that disabled individuals earn pension credits up to and including the calendar year in which they turn 66 years old.
Facilitate that the pensioners' settlement is financed through the Miscellaneous item in the state budget, as it has been done up to and including 2015.
Present your own case for changing the regulatory principles for ongoing pensions from wage development minus 0.75% to the average of wage and price growth.
Ensure that the Pensioners' Association is allowed to participate in the meetings of the government's contact committee.

Promote the necessary proposals to ensure that the country's pensioners do not lose purchasing power as long as wage earners do not either. The necessary decisions will be made in the spring session of 2021. The principle is based on regulating the social security adjustments as an average of wage and price growth. The social security adjustment in 2021 must also take into account the lost purchasing power in 2020, so that this is compensated for.

Include a ramp-up plan for the minimum pension in the annual pension settlements so that the level is increased by 7,500 kroner annually, effective from May 1 each year, until the minimum pension reaches the poverty target EU60.
Grant negotiation rights to the pensioners' organizations in the welfare settlement. The Pensioners' Association/SAKO will represent the pensioners in the negotiations.
Ensure that the Pensioners' Association is given a place in the Technical Calculation Committee for income settlements (TBU).

Present a proposal for a regulation that allows organizations, in connection with the annual social security negotiations, to negotiate on other issues of significance for retirees, outside the framework set by the pension agreement, and where any budgetary consequences are assumed to be incorporated into the revised budget.

Ensure that the impact of the life expectancy adjustment is investigated for different income and occupational groups, and provide suggestions that ensure that the economic differences between the various groups of pensioners are reduced, not increased.
Promote a proposal for the reintroduction of partial protection against age adjustment for former disability pensioners.
To inform the Storting in an appropriate manner about the Pension Committee's assessments regarding minimum levels, as well as how the Pension Committee's recommendations will be followed up.

In the annual report to the Storting regarding the regulation of pensions and the income situation of pensioners, it is reported on the development in the number of recipients of the minimum pension level, as well as the development of low income among elderly pensioners.

The Pension Committee should consider what constitutes a reasonable minimum level in the National Insurance Scheme for different benefit groups, including an assessment in relation to the interests of those who have worked hard to be able to retire at the age of 62, and what is reasonable in relation to the legitimate expectations of the working population to receive something in return for their contributions to social security.
Present a proposal for regulation stating that organizations, in connection with the annual social security negotiations, can negotiate other issues that are significant for pensioners.

Include a compensation for the social security settlement of 2020, corresponding to the difference between the then-current regulatory principles and the regulation that actually reflects the average of wage and price growth.

Ensure that the amount of 4,000 kroner approved in December 2020 is continued as a permanent increase in the minimum pension for singles, starting from January 1, 2021, and add this on top of the social security settlement for 2021.

Propose necessary legislative changes to introduce pension from the first krone, aiming for implementation from January 1, 2023. The Parliament requests the government to consider temporary, compensatory economic measures for employers and transitional rules that allow for the introduction of pension from the first krone to be phased in over a period of time, for example, 3 years after the effective date.
Take the initiative to introduce pension accrual from the first krone in the private sector and for employees in the public sector with a working percentage below 20%, effective from January 1, 2022.
To present a bill to the Storting to regulate ongoing pensions with the average of price and wage growth, effective from 2022.
Reintroduce the practice of presenting the social security settlements as a separate matter for the Storting in the spring session, starting with the social security settlement for 2021.

Engage in dialogue with pensioners' organizations with the aim of establishing quarterly meetings between the government and the pensioners' organizations, where issues of significance to pensioners can be discussed.

Consider the possibilities for negotiating market access for selected agricultural products, so that Norwegian consumers have access to a cheaper and wider variety of food, and so that Norwegian farmers have a freer food market and greater opportunities for trade.
Use the negotiations on the EEA funds to improve areas covered by the EEA Agreement that are not functioning, including the limitation of welfare export.
Establish a requirement that Norway's financial support to the EU should be reduced.

Investigate and propose to expand the system of child care certificates, so that criminal convictions under the Penal Code §§ 271, 272, and 273 regarding bodily harm, aggravated bodily harm, and bodily injury result in a notation on the police certificate.
Conduct a thorough review of the child care certificate and return to the Parliament with proposals for any changes.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to reintroduce a renewal scheme for childcare certificates.

Conduct a review of the child care certificate scheme, which also includes an investigation of digital simplification opportunities, an assessment of the possibility for information sharing regarding relevant offenses in other countries, and an evaluation of whether sections 272 and 273 of the Penal Code should be included in the police certificate.
Ensure that the request resolution no. 182 of December 12, 2017, cf. Innst. 43 S (2017–2018) and Document 8:19 S (2017–2018), is followed up in accordance with the Parliament's original decision.
Come back with a proposal for a ban on selling imported products of meat, milk, fruits, and vegetables in the same type of packaging as Norwegian products.
Come back with suggestions for requirements regarding the labeling of antibiotic use in the production of meat and dairy products.
Come back with suggestions for origin labeling on processed products.
Come back with suggestions on how labeling can be improved in the restaurant and catering market.
Come back with proposals for a labeling scheme for food and beverages within grocery retail that corresponds to the consumer-friendly and clear origin labeling that has been used at Vinmonopolet.
Reintroduce full wage compensation (up to 6 G) for a minimum of 20 days for new layoffs until October 1st.

Reintroduce holiday pay on unemployment benefits, without the requirement of at least 8 weeks of unemployment, effective from January 1, 2020, so that unemployment benefits earned in 2020 entitle the recipient to holiday pay in 2021.

Make the necessary changes to the temporary regulation of March 20, 2020, no. 368 regarding exceptions from the National Insurance Act and the Working Environment Act in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic, in order to extend the increased rate of unemployment benefits, 80% of the unemployment benefit basis up to 4.5 G, until December 31, 2021.
Increase the compensation rate for support to self-employed individuals and freelancers to 80% with a duration until October 1st.

Retroactive payment of benefits to recipients of work assessment allowance who are job seekers and have their benefits resumed from March 1, 2021, should have been paid for the months of November 2020 to February 2021.

The retroactive payment that recipients of work assessment allowance under § 11-12 should have received for the months of November 2020 to February 2021 upon the resumption of the allowance from March 1, 2021.
Extend the maximum benefit period for recipients of work assessment allowance who are job seekers (§ 11-17) until October 1st.

Give recipients of work assessment allowance under § 11-12 who lost the benefit from November 1, 2020, the right to apply for reinstatement of the benefit from March 1, with a duration until October 1.

Make the necessary changes to the temporary regulation of March 20, 2020, no. 368 regarding exceptions from the National Insurance Act and the Working Environment Act in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic, in order to extend the income security scheme for apprentices (including new cases) until October 1, 2021, with full compensation for income up to 3 G.

Ensure that a retroactive payment is calculated and paid out to all individuals who have received unemployment benefits based on the standard rate from March 20, 2020, until February 1, 2021, despite the fact that the benefit has been increased for new recipients during the same period.
Increase the rate in the compensation scheme for self-employed individuals and freelancers to 80% up to 4 G, and then 60%.
Halve the income requirement to receive compensation as self-employed and freelancers.

Propose amendments to the Working Environment Act § 14-2 (4) to ensure a temporary extension of the priority provision by 12 months in order to strengthen job security for employees who have had their employment terminated due to the effects of the pandemic.

Ensure that the employer's wage obligation period during layoffs for the period from January 1, 2021, until the Parliament's decision on changes includes 8 days of wage costs in the employer period I as a separate cost component in the general compensation scheme, and is refunded according to the rules applicable to this scheme.

Make the necessary changes to the temporary regulation of March 20, 2020, no. 368 regarding exceptions from the National Insurance Act and the Working Environment Act in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic, in order to extend the increased rate of unemployment benefits, 80% of the unemployment benefit basis up to 4 G, until October 1, 2021.
Extend the employer period II (30 weeks) from June 1, 2021, to July 1, 2021.
Change the employer period I from 10 days to 5 days plus 5 days of wage compensation for employees until October 1, 2021, or as long as the pandemic lasts.
Ensure that those on furlough are not subjected to extended waiting periods due to having changed jobs while they were furloughed during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Reduce the requirement for lost working hours to receive unemployment benefits during layoffs to 40% until October 1, 2021.
Postpone employer period II to June 1, 2021.

Make the necessary changes to the temporary regulation of March 20, 2020, no. 368 regarding exceptions from the National Insurance Act and the Working Environment Act in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic, in order to lift the three-day waiting period for receiving unemployment benefits until October 1, 2021.
Make changes to the regulations to extend the layoff period to October 1, 2021.

Make the necessary changes to the temporary regulation of March 20, 2020, no. 368 regarding exceptions from the National Insurance Act and the Working Environment Act in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic, in order to extend the increased rate of unemployment benefits, 80% of the unemployment benefit basis up to 3 G, until October 1, 2021.

Make the necessary changes to the temporary regulation of March 20, 2020, no. 368 regarding exceptions from the National Insurance Act and the Working Environment Act in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic, in order to extend the maximum period for receiving unemployment benefits to October 1, 2021, also for those cases that exceeded the maximum period from November 1, 2020, until the date the change is implemented.

Make the necessary changes to the temporary regulation of March 20, 2020, no. 368 regarding exceptions from the National Insurance Act and the Working Environment Act in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic, in order to extend the income security scheme for apprentices (including new cases) until October 1, 2021.

Extend the scheme with lower income requirements for receiving unemployment benefits (0.75 G in the last 12 months or 2.25 G in the last 36 months) for new cases as long as the crisis lasts, now until October 1, 2021.

Change the unemployment benefit rules so that individuals who were granted unemployment benefits before March 20, 2020, will receive increased rates similar to the temporarily raised unemployment benefit rate starting from February 1, 2021.

Introduce a temporary right to holiday pay for unemployment benefits received in 2020 and 2021 for payment in the summer of 2021 and 2022, respectively. This will apply to those who do not have the right to continue receiving unemployment benefits while also taking vacation.
Ensure that the booster vaccine against diphtheria, tetanus, and whooping cough is free of charge.

Promote a proposal for the introduction of a program offering basic vaccinations for all adults who have not received all the vaccines in the childhood vaccination program. The program must include a plan for invitations and ensure that the vaccinations and vaccines are free of charge.

Review the vaccines that have been introduced in the childhood vaccination program in recent years, such as the pneumococcal vaccine, and propose a program for a booster dose against pneumococci. The vaccination and the vaccine should be free of charge. Everyone who needs a booster dose should receive an invitation. Those who have not received the pneumococcal vaccine should be offered both the vaccination and the vaccine for free.
Establish a differentiated influenza vaccination program with high-dose influenza vaccine for the elderly in nursing homes and other groups that the government is authorized to determine.
Investigate whether the co-payment for the adult vaccination program can be included in the blue prescription scheme.
Promote a proposal for the gradual implementation of a vaccination program for adults based on the recommendations of the Norwegian Institute of Public Health regarding prioritized vaccines.
Investigate how an adult vaccination program can be implemented, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Consider the possibility of establishing an automatic information system for residents regarding when a booster vaccine for diphtheria, tetanus, and whooping cough is needed. This service could be organized as part of helsenorge.no and could also include the option to unsubscribe from such a system.
Consider introducing labeling for treatment methods and medications that do not have documented efficacy, but are claimed to treat various conditions.
Establish a working group that will develop proposals for approval schemes and discussions on what the alternative treatment industry can provide in terms of health care.

Ensure a comprehensive review of the entire registration scheme for alternative treatment, with a focus on changes that can enhance patient safety and consumer protection, as well as set quality requirements for the services offered. An exemption from value-added tax for registered practitioners of alternative treatment who meet new quality standards will be considered in such a review of the registration scheme.

Promote a parliamentary report on quackery, proposing stricter measures against actors who deliberately promise health benefits that are not sufficiently proven, and reviewing the level of penalties for violations of the legislation.

Ensure that healthcare personnel employed in public hospitals do not have private side jobs that target the same type of treatment and the same patients for whom they are responsible in the public sector.

Investigate whether private healthcare providers are more likely to perform overtreatment, and whether these providers should bear a greater share of the risk for complications and injuries from procedures that are not prioritized in the public healthcare system, and return to the Parliament with a case on this matter.
Review the practices of fully private providers regarding prescription of medications and referrals, and propose stricter regulations if the practices indicate that there are systematic differences.

Review the practices of private actors in reserving spots for paying customers, and propose regulations that ensure health priorities, rather than willingness to pay, determine the speed of treatment.
Investigate a sales tax on private health insurance to strengthen the public healthcare system.
Establish a public committee to review the development of private healthcare providers and private health insurance in Norway, and propose measures to prevent a dual healthcare system.
Introduce price caps on dental services in cases where public subsidy schemes are to cover all or part of the dental treatment.
Ensure that all health enterprises comply with today's requirements for escort services, and in the long term, change the limit for escort services to a 60-minute travel time.
Ensure that a fully-fledged maternity department in Kristiansund becomes part of the future hospital structure in Møre and Romsdal.
Ensure that rapid tests can be used in hospitals so that it is better facilitated for the partner to be involved in pregnancy follow-up and during labor and postpartum.
Instruct Health Mid-Norway RHF to ensure the continued operation of the maternity department in Kristiansund in accordance with the Storting's resolution no. 574 (2019–2020).

Ensure that Helse Møre og Romsdal HF is provided with the necessary professional and financial resources to ensure the safe operation of the maternity department in Kristiansund, and inform the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Ensure that when tendering for patient transport, quality should weigh more than price, and ensure that health enterprises prepare tenders with fixed prices to ensure that different providers compete on quality, such as waiting times.
Ensure that patients who need to travel to and from institutions if they close, for example on weekends, are covered by the regulations for patient travel.

Incorporate the following changes to the regulations for patient travel: 1. The patient's total travel time should be emphasized, prioritizing the most appropriate means of transportation. 2. Introduce a fixed rate for travel reimbursements that are automatically paid for urgent and planned appointments at hospitals. 3. Allow patients to pay a supplement if they prefer to travel with more expensive means of transportation. 4. Set the rate based on actual expenses, meaning an increase from the current driving rate of 2.7 NOK/km. 5. Ensure greater flexibility in the regulations.

Promote a case to the Storting regarding simplifications and improvements in the regulations for patient travel and the organization of services by the regional health authorities, cf. the Storting's request resolution of April 19, 2018, cf. Innst. 196 S (2017–2018).

Specify the regional health authorities' obligation to provide patient transport and require all health enterprises to have agreements with taxi companies so that patients entitled to have their patient travel covered do not have to pay for the journey themselves.
Engage in negotiations with the EU with the aim of reducing tariff-free quotas for the import of agricultural products from the EU to Norway as a result of Brexit.
Reject new negotiations aimed at further liberalization of trade in agricultural products under Article 19 or other provisions of the EEA Agreement.
Reject the application to build the foreign cable NorthConnect.
That a decision is made regarding the application for the conversion of the Røldal-Suldal concessions to indefinite concessions, to decide on the opening of a revision of the concession terms.

Treat the position of the host municipalities in the audit case equally with the treatment of the municipalities that have previously had water rights that have been renewed, also regarding the concession terms for the establishment of business funds.
The review of the conditions for the Røldal-Suldal facilities will be prioritized after the license for these facilities has been converted to a license for an unlimited period.

Ensure that the licensing authorities assess whether there are specific conditions that warrant the establishment of a business fund or other financial terms based on existing practices and guidelines.

Ensure that the municipal compensation scheme provides accurate coverage of expenses for legitimate businesses that have been shut down, including compensation for inventory that is lost due to local infection control measures, or come back with proposals for an expanded and more precise scheme that ensures this.
Reduce the maximum payout from the compensation scheme, so that each company can receive a maximum of 20 million kroner for each of the two grant periods in the months of March–June 2021.
Set a cap of 10 million kroner per company per grant period for distribution through the compensation scheme for businesses.
Ensure that the calculation of grants is based on the total loss of revenue, and not just fixed costs in the compensation scheme for businesses.
Develop a description of 'Green Shipping' in GIEK's ship financing offer with an extended repayment period of 18 years.
Establish a scheme for unemployment benefits for recent graduates without regular earnings, based on the model of the scheme for recently discharged conscripts.

Assess the prospects for public transport companies' ticket revenues in the period following the easing of infection control measures, and propose measures that prevent route cuts and encourage passengers to return to public transport when the infection is under control.

Include costs related to lost inventory in the compensation scheme or promptly present other proposals that ensure that industries with significant costs related to inventory loss receive increased support.
Adjust the arrangement of additional loans so that it is possible to receive the grant portion without receiving the loan portion that cannot be converted.
Ensure municipalities compensation to strengthen staffing in municipal welfare services such as elderly care, schools, and kindergartens.

Propose necessary legal amendments to ensure that the owners of companies receiving grants through the compensation scheme for businesses cannot distribute dividends unless the received grant is first repaid.
Lower the ceiling in the compensation scheme for businesses for the maximum cash support paid out per month per company to 10 million kroner per month. Amounts above this can be paid out as loans.
Ensure that recipients of grants from the compensation scheme for businesses cannot pay out dividends or conduct share buybacks for the remainder of 2021 and in 2022.
Include tax balance depreciation for asset group C and asset group D in the compensation basis starting from the benefit month of March 2021.

Present a compensation scheme for the aviation industry as soon as possible and no later than mid-March, in accordance with the clear frameworks and requirements outlined in the request decision no. 553 from the Parliament on January 19, 2021, which also helps to compensate for the significant losses the aviation sector has experienced during the pandemic.
Consider a scheme to ensure language and workplace training for laid-off and unemployed labor immigrants.

Make the necessary changes to ensure that individuals who have lost their income completely or partially as a result of the pandemic, and thus do not meet the maintenance requirement for family reunification, are exempt from the requirement for current and future income. Exceptions must also be made from the income requirement for other grounds of residence, such as self-employed individuals and freelancers, in cases where income has been completely or partially lost due to the pandemic.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal on how green transition requirements can be included in the COVID-19 support through the compensation scheme, the loan guarantee scheme, the State Bond Fund, or a new hybrid scheme that combines the compensation scheme with a loan scheme beyond the maximum amount.

Take the necessary measures to ensure that property owners provide a rent reduction of 10-30% for the months of March to June 2021 for businesses receiving support through the compensation scheme for the business sector.
Reduce the advance payment for AutoPASS for the ferry to 800 kroner.
Include lost inventory in the compensation scheme for businesses.
Design a proposal for how the compensation scheme for businesses can be made progressive so that the subsidy becomes relatively larger the smaller the company is.
Come back with a proposal for a temporary reduction of the serving VAT from 25% to 15% for the last four terms of 2021.
Change the government support schemes for the cultural sector so that they are based on the same conditions as the general compensation scheme for other businesses (cost coverage).
Consider how stores and shopping centers that can demonstrate strict infection control measures and contact tracing can remain open.
Include fixed, regular common costs that the property owner invoices their tenants in the concept of fixed unavoidable costs in the compensation scheme for businesses.
Establish an application-based scheme to cover documented lost inventory for industries that are directly or indirectly closed due to central or local infection control measures.

Promote a proposal for a necessary supplementary grant to ensure that everyone receiving Nav benefits such as work assessment allowance, disability pension, housing support, social assistance, minimum pension, unemployment benefits, and similar, receives a one-time support payment to compensate for high electricity prices. The payment should not result in deductions from other benefits.
Facilitate access to information on payment deferrals for tax and fee claims to the state according to the special rules established in connection with the coronavirus pandemic.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to include government-mandated maintenance in the general compensation scheme for businesses.
Propose changes to the Alcohol Act so that municipalities can easily allow establishments to temporarily sell alcohol for takeout, in the same way as grocery stores.

Present a proposal for a financing scheme that involves the state fully covering the additional costs of climate transition for the counties' fast ferry and ferry traffic. The scheme must account for both implemented and upcoming measures.

Include government-mandated maintenance and supervision costs in the compensation scheme for businesses starting from the benefit month of March 2021, for example, by allowing applications for compensation for maintenance and supervision costs equivalent to 1/6 of the average annual maintenance cost calculated over the last 2 or 3 years.
Include costs for infection control measures in the compensation scheme for businesses starting from the support month of March.

Ensure that the limit is set to 30,000 Norwegian kroner when the requirements for the content of the application for compensation from the compensation scheme must be certified/confirmed by an auditor or accountant, as it was in the old scheme, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Reopen the grant scheme from 2020 that pertains to subsidies for refunds of package trips that were originally scheduled to take place between March 14 and June 14, 2020, so that the trips that were eligible for subsidies but for which no application for funding was submitted in the previous round can be included.
Incorporate membership fees in tourism destination companies as fixed unavoidable costs in the compensation scheme.
Suggest measures that can alleviate the situation with extraordinarily high electricity costs, and quickly return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Propose arrangements that can benefit the smallest businesses, such as hybrid loan schemes/loan schemes where the state guarantees 100% of the amount, and return to the Parliament with this as soon as possible.
Incorporate layoff costs for January and February into the compensation scheme for fixed costs.
Promote proposals that ensure companies owning their own operating assets are treated equally with companies that lease and rent equipment.
Come back in the revised national budget 2021 with a binding plan for the phasing out of ferry prices, on both national and county roads.

Include closed events organized by the event industry in the support scheme for public events, where this extension is particularly intended to target Norwegian event agencies and companies with the following NACE codes: 77.39-40 Rental and leasing of other machinery and equipment and materials not mentioned elsewhere, 82.300 Congress, fair, and exhibition activities, 82.990 Other business support services not mentioned elsewhere. Businesses registered under other NACE codes where at least 60% of revenue comes from closed business events as an organizer or subcontractor. The support amount is set to a maximum of 10% of documented revenue loss per month compared to 2019. The decline must be more than 50% to qualify for support, and there is a cap of 500,000 Norwegian kroner per month per applicant.
Monitor the situation for the event industry and others in the organizing sector closely and return to the Parliament with proposals for additional funding if necessary.
Ensure that the trade unions in the hardest-hit sectors have decisive influence over at least 50 million kroner of the competence and education offerings funded under chapter 257 item 70.

Regulate that businesses receiving support from the compensation scheme for the business sector are obligated not to make layoffs as long as they receive support, replace permanent employees and laid-off workers with hired and temporary staff, pay out dividends in or for 2021, pay out bonuses in or for 2021, buy back their own shares in 2021, or increase executive salaries or board fees in 2021.

Reduce the threshold for the reduction of support amounts to 10 million kroner per month and lower the maximum payout limit to 30 million kroner per month in the temporary grant scheme for companies with significant revenue decline.
Ensure that infection control measures are included as a separate cost element in the compensation scheme, and return to the Storting in an appropriate manner.

Change the arrangement regarding the coverage of 'fixed, unavoidable costs' (§ 3-2 second paragraph) and include common costs and fixed marketing contributions for commercial premises in the basis for cost coverage in connection with the compensation scheme for businesses, where these are included in the lease agreement for commercial premises.

Ensure that the allocations to the municipalities are also used to enforce strict infection control in schools and kindergartens, so that the expenses do not have to be covered by the regular budgets of the institutions.
Based on the criteria in the Oslo model for public procurement, set similar conditions regarding orderly conditions for companies to be eligible for support in the compensation scheme for businesses.
Ensure that Sandefjord Airport Torp is secured for operation even after the month of April.
Monitor the development of the public transport companies' finances and, if necessary, return to the Storting with proposals for additional appropriations in the revised national budget for 2021.

Ensure that grants under the cultural life stimulation scheme are allocated in a way that is broad and fair, and ensure that grants to beneficiaries are reduced, in accordance with the guidelines of the scheme, if the net cost of the requested activity appears disproportionately high.
Consider a grant or loan scheme, or a combination of these, for tour operators that have had to cancel postponed trips.
Promote a proposal for a separate grant to reduce the income loss for Norwegian destination companies.

Promote proposals for mitigating measures within the COVID-19 support schemes for the industries and actors that are particularly affected by the fact that different forms of financing for operating assets yield different results in the COVID-19 support schemes.
Make an exception to the entry ban for cross-border commuters who are border residents and who commute daily from Sweden or Finland to Norway for work.

Establish an exception for the business codes 'L - Sale and operation of real estate, 68.1 - Purchase and sale of own real estate, and 68.2 - Rental of own or leased real estate' in the compensation schemes for businesses.
Ensure 100% compensation for lost inventory due to infection control restrictions for the period from November 1, 2020, to February 28, 2021.

Ensure income security for newly graduated individuals who become unemployed after completing their education, covering both upper secondary school students and higher education students. The scheme(s) should last as long as other temporary income security measures are in place.

To use the Tenancy Act § 4-6 to set maximum rates for certain rental agreements at a 20% reduction from the level on March 1, 2021, for rental companies and landlords with more than 2 secondary residences.
Ensure that the compensation scheme for businesses does not provide support to companies engaged in property rental that leave rental apartments vacant instead of renting them out at a reduced price.

Ensure the repayment of support from businesses that have not acted diligently and loyally towards the purpose of the compensation scheme, including businesses that have reduced their revenue to achieve increased payments of support under the compensation scheme and businesses where the decline in revenue is not primarily due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Ensure that the criteria in the compensation scheme for subcontractors that applied from May to August 2020 are continued for the rest of 2020 and for allocations in 2021.
Assess the situation for Norwegian students abroad and return to the Parliament with proposals for compensatory measures.

Promote a proposal for a solution to reduce the income loss for the Norwegian destination companies, either by incorporating membership fees/partner contributions as fixed unavoidable costs in the compensation scheme or as a separate grant to the destination companies.

Promote a proposal for a solution to reduce the income loss for the Norwegian destination companies, either by incorporating membership fees/partner contributions as fixed unavoidable costs in the compensation scheme or as a separate grant to the destination companies.

Come back in the revised national budget for 2021 with proposals for reduced ferry fares already for the current year, and a binding plan for halving ferry prices on both national and county road connections. Solutions for lower fares for commuters should be prioritized, and the reduction should be financed by the state.

Include costs for lost inventory caused by expired dates due to infection control restrictions in the compensation basis for the benefit month of March. Businesses that can document significant lost inventory as a result of infection control restrictions during the period from November to February should be able to apply for compensation for this.
Review the film incentive scheme and return in the revised national budget 2021 with proposals on how the scheme can be strengthened.
Come back in an appropriate manner with a proposal for a temporary arrangement where the state contributes to reestablishing a functioning guarantee market for package travel.
Quickly return to the Storting if there is a need for additional funds to ensure the operation of Haugesund and Torp airports.
Ensure that Flytoget is included in the public procurement scheme as compensation for lost ticket revenues, similar to other train companies.

Ensure that the Sami language is available in all public digital services developed from the outset, and that all public agencies support Sami letters, so that Sami names can be correctly written in public registers.

Investigate which remaining obstacles need to be removed in order to provide a comprehensive digital offering to users of Sámi languages in Norway, and appropriately present proposals to the Parliament that ensure this.

Ensure that the Sami perspective is included at an early stage in the development of digital services, including the need to mention the Sami offerings when allocating funds for new digitalization initiatives.
Facilitate the processing of the annual parliamentary report on Sami language, culture, and community life during the spring session.
Promote proposals that remove the right of the county governor and the Norwegian Public Roads Administration to object to municipal planning and land use decisions.
Propose that the administrative supervision for handling complaints regarding municipal planning decisions be placed under the Ministry of Local Government and Modernization.

Promote a proposal that objections in land use matters can only be raised in questions of significant national importance. Furthermore, the party affected by the objection should be able to bring this issue, if it is of significant national importance, before the Ministry of Local Government and Modernisation, with a deadline for decision within six weeks.
Promote a proposal that it should not be possible to raise objections against plans that fall within the current planning purposes of the overarching plan.

Investigate the specific needs for increased capacity and competence in the municipal sector regarding climate and biodiversity in order to implement necessary measures such as climate adaptation, environmentally friendly procurement, nature mapping, and other initiatives to reduce emissions and protect nature, which are essential to achieve Norway's nature and climate goals.

Investigate what limitations and changes can be made to the right of objection for state bodies and sector authorities regarding municipal planning and land use decisions in order to strengthen municipal self-governance, thereby providing greater opportunities to manage local development.
Conduct a comprehensive investigation into changes in government guidelines to strengthen development opportunities in rural areas and local self-governance.
Develop and implement a receipt system for use by the police during ID checks.
Ensure that all ID-checked individuals receive a receipt upon inspection.
Ensure that the statistics on ID checks under the Immigration Act are made publicly available and searchable.
Ensure the requirement for logging all ID checks, in accordance with the circular on the Police's enforcement of immigration control in the territory.
Follow up on the recommendations of the Children's Ombudsman for oversight and control of police assignments in child welfare cases and return to the Parliament in a suitable matter.
Consider the title 'Local Police Chief' as a new title for the sheriff positions as an alternative to 'Police Department Leader'.
Ensure local management at all police stations and sheriff's offices.
Initiate the planning of a new police academy and return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
To stop the Oslo police's recently submitted proposal to the Ministry of Justice and Public Security regarding the merger of police stations in Oslo.
Allow exceptions to the general arming of police when assisting the bailiff in evictions involving children and families.

Ensure local management at all police stations and sheriff's offices in the form of either a police station chief or sheriff, and that the term 'place of service' is replaced with either police station or sheriff's office.

Promote a proposal that the powers and responsibilities the sheriff had before the implementation of the local police reform in June 2015 are continued and/or reinstated, including the bailiff function, the secretariat for the conciliation council, and the issuance of passports.
Promote a proposal to reintroduce the system of appointing police chiefs as civil servants without term limits.
Ensure that all police districts are allocated sufficient funds earmarked for increasing the number of patrols and strengthening their operational police by a minimum of 30% by January 1, 2023.

Ensure that the boundary for Unit West in the Oslo Police District is moved to the Lysaker River, in order to provide accessible and present police services throughout the entire Oslo Police District.

Ensure that the Oslo police district immediately provides a more present and operational police force in areas particularly affected by gang crime, and ensures that the police's exercise of authority commands the necessary respect for them to carry out their societal mission.

Initiate the work on planning a new Police Academy to replace the current facility in Majorstua. The new school will be located within daily commuting distance to Oslo and will be constructed as a competitive building.
Promote the necessary proposals for legislative changes that grant the police the right to carry weapons while on duty.
Ensure to separate the police and the prosecution.

Establish a selection composed of strategic leaders from the police, the military, and academia to develop a top management program for strategic leadership based on the model of the military's leadership development programs, with the mandate to create a relevant and applicable program.
Take the initiative to develop a leadership platform in the police force.

Ensure that police districts with long coastlines are allocated increased resources, and at the same time ensure that these are used to strengthen the police's maritime service in the relevant district, so that the police have an increased presence and preparedness along the coast.

Promote the necessary proposals to dissolve the Police Directorate. Tasks and responsibilities related to the directorate should be partially returned to the ministry and partially transferred to the police districts. An investigation must be conducted on how such a change should be implemented.
Ensure that the process of replacing the title 'lensmann' with a gender-neutral title is halted.
Come back to the Parliament with concrete measures to strengthen the police's work against ICT crime.
Maintain the goal of 200 employees at NC3 at Kripos by the end of 2021.
Increase the number of students admitted to the Police University College to at least 550 students starting from the fall of 2021.
Preserve the current organization of the Emergency Police.
Ensure that the main statistics on homicides committed in Norway include a complete overview of all homicides.

Ensure that all police districts in the country implement immediate measures to prevent and combat gang crime, including ensuring that all police districts have sufficient operational personnel to maintain a strong presence in vulnerable areas.
Reopen the arrests where closures under the police reform have led to the police today spending disproportionately much time on the transport of prisoners.
Establish a national weapons register that is added to the Brønnøysund Register Centre and to the Nordland Police District with administration in Mosjøen.
Ensure full identity protection for police employees.
Come back to the Parliament with an assessment of how fisheries and seafood crime is part of the police's efforts against organized crime, labor market crime, and economic crime.
Ensure that prisoner transport is conducted by public authorities and not left to private entities.
Present an overview related to personnel development at all police stations and sheriff's offices during the period 2016–2020.

Stop all ongoing or proposed centralization in the police districts, including the reduction of the number of geographical operational units, merging of sheriff offices and police stations, centralization of civil justice, bailiff services, and service offices pending the evaluation of the local police reform.
Come back to the Parliament with an overview related to resource use, expenditure development, and assistance to the police from the fire service and ambulance service during the period 2016–2020.

Follow up the public prosecutors' quality survey for 2020 on prioritized rape cases with a report to the Parliament, as well as follow up with an evaluation study on how victims in rape cases experience their interactions with the police and prosecution.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that ensures that students with disabilities who wish to go on exchange are granted a temporary exemption from the rules that require them to use benefits and services within the country's borders, also outside the EEA.
Engage in dialogue with the student welfare organizations with the aim of removing the preferential rights of international students to student housing.
Prioritize Norwegian students in Norway and investigate and promote necessary proposals so that loans and grants from Lånekassen are reserved for Norwegian students.
