Prioritize Norwegian students in Norway and investigate and promote necessary proposals to introduce tuition fees for foreign students starting from the beginning of the academic year in the fall of 2022.

Investigate and promote necessary proposals so that the Norwegian State Educational Loan Fund can offer top scholarships and loans to students who qualify to study at the world's leading elite universities.
Engage in dialogue with PST and Norwegian higher education and research institutions to establish regular and formalized meeting points between the parties.
Investigate the economic costs of achieving the goals outlined in Meld. St. 7 (2020–2021) by 2030.

Evaluate the effects of credit for foreign stays graded by duration in the funding system for universities and colleges, and ensure that professional education programs are safeguarded without establishing a general incentive for shorter stays.
Ensure that a distinction is made between shorter and longer stays abroad in the student mobility statistics.
Conduct a comprehensive review of the economic and legal barriers for international students and return to the Parliament with proposals for simplifications.
Review the regulations for language scholarships through Lånekassen and ensure a practice that serves the purpose.
Implement the qualification passport for refugees systematically in Norway.
Suggest adjustments to the Panorama strategy and plan for a new quota program to ensure greater diversity in incoming and outgoing student mobility.

Initiate a research project focusing on student mobility among students with disabilities, and assign Lånekassen the responsibility of presenting annual national mobility statistics for this student group.
Continue and strengthen the "Students at Risk" program and eventually make it permanent, as well as facilitate the "Scholars at Risk" network.
Maintain and secure the principle of free education for international students in Norway.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan for more internationalization in primary education, secondary education, and higher vocational education.
Facilitate researcher exchange and internationalization in doctoral studies.
Ensure good financing mechanisms for study abroad programs to guarantee equal access regardless of economic background – including to highly ranked institutions.
Suggest effective measures to increase study mobility among students with special needs.

Investigate and return to the Storting with the necessary proposals so that Norwegian students abroad can have part-time jobs alongside their studies without losing their membership in the National Insurance Scheme.
Further develop simpler, faster, and more predictable approval processes for foreign education and qualifications.
Consider compensatory measures to contribute to a more equal competition for study places in the admission to higher education in 2021.

Investigate a step-by-step implementation of Tier II and III requirements for the entire Norwegian coast, not just the World Heritage fjords, and return to the Parliament with a proposal on this, with the aim of implementing the requirements for the entire coast by no later than 2025. The requirements should apply regardless of the ships' year of construction and for all vessels over 1000 gross tons.
Develop various proposals for support schemes for companies that impose zero-emission requirements in the transportation of goods, leading to the adoption of new technology.
Make the necessary adjustments to the regulations on environmental safety for ships and mobile installations, and ensure the transportation of stone by ship from the mineral industry.

Exempt the transportation of stone by ship from the mineral industry from the implementation of requirements and regulations regarding emissions from cruise ships and other shipping traffic in tourist fjords.
Present exceptions that still ensure the business sector dependent on activities related to shipping in the World Heritage fjords, while also safeguarding mining in the area.
Postpone the requirement for zero emissions in the World Heritage fjords until 2030.
Engage in dialogue with cruise companies and the supplier industry to identify good and innovative solutions that genuinely protect the environment in the long term.
Contribute to the implementation of measures initiated by local and regional authorities that reduce emissions in the World Heritage fjords.

Propose measures to ensure that the World Heritage fjords remain a port of call for cruise ships even after 2026, including the state ensuring the establishment of shore power in Flåm as planned by 2022.

Review the arrangement of LAR with the aim of strengthening the individual's right to tailored support, as well as increasing the focus on the rehabilitation aspect of LAR, including establishing more options for tapering off within LAR.
Propose changes regarding the funding of individuals with substance dependence that ensure that follow-up after treatment is also financed by the state.
Investigate a financing key to allocate the costs of aftercare for individuals with substance abuse issues between the state and the municipality.
Ensure that both the person with substance dependence and their relatives are provided with a substance coordinator they can turn to in the municipality.

Review the LAR arrangement with the aim of strengthening the individual's right to tailored support, including by including more medications in the program, and increasing the focus on the rehabilitation aspect of LAR, including establishing more options for tapering off within LAR.
Initiate the work on a treatment reform for substance abusers.

Ensure that providers of round-the-clock treatment within interdisciplinary specialized treatment for substance use disorders offer follow-up after treatment. The follow-up should aim for reintegration into regular working life, education, or other activities and should be conducted in collaboration with the municipality and the user themselves.

Ensure that the healthcare system is organized in such a way that patients with substance abuse and mental illness receive the necessary prevention and treatment for somatic diseases, and inform the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Ensure that individuals who have come out of active substance use are provided with housing that does not place them together with individuals who are still in active substance use.

Promote proposals for an improved and fairer funding scheme for the round-the-clock care and rehabilitation services in the substance abuse field that are not considered part of the specialist health service.

It is possible to impose involuntary detention for up to three months in a dedicated residential institution if a person is in the process of abusing substances in such a way that life and health are put in critical danger, in accordance with the Health and Care Services Act § 10-2.
Ensure that everyone with substance abuse problems in prison is offered addiction treatment. It is requested that the government establishes substance abuse management units in all prisons.
Come back to the Parliament with a binding escalation plan for mental health care.

Present a plan for the escalation of healthcare services in Norwegian prisons, which includes the establishment of area functions for mental health care and substance abuse management units/navigation units in all prisons.

Ensure that all health enterprises implement routines for notifying the municipal health services when discharging a patient who has been admitted for overdose, suicide attempt, or possible suicide attempt.

Develop and implement an information and alert system that can be used between agencies that, for shorter or longer periods, treat or follow up individuals with severe substance abuse and mental health issues (SUD/MH).

Clarify the division of tasks and responsibilities between health enterprises, municipal health services, and other municipal agencies for users and patients with severe substance abuse and mental health issues (ROP) who have frequent contact with the support system.

Ensure a mapping of what types of housing municipalities offer to people with severe substance abuse disorders and mental health issues (ROP), and what support services are provided within them. Based on this, propose good models for housing options for this group. The user perspective in the mapping must be emphasized.
Conduct a living conditions survey for individuals with severe substance abuse and mental health issues (ROP) based on the evaluation of the escalation plan for the substance abuse field.
Stop the reduction of inpatient beds in mental health care.
Review the available capacity and needs within mental health care, with the aim of increasing inpatient capacity in line with demand.
Conduct a review of discharge practices within substance abuse and mental health care.
Ensure that all quantity restrictions for stoma supplies, which were introduced on January 1, 2020, are lifted immediately.

Consider changing the practice when amendments are made to the blue prescription regulations, so that changes affecting patients' access to equipment and medications are made through regulatory amendments, rather than in circulars, in order to ensure that professionals and patient organizations have the opportunity to express their opinions.
Ensure that all patients with a stoma receive the necessary follow-up, guidance, and information, and inform the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Evaluate the overall changes that have occurred in medical consumables, and the effect they have had on users' quality of life and participation, and promote necessary changes.

Make a public apology to transgender individuals who, until July 1, 2016, could not change their legal gender unless they had the psychiatric diagnosis of transsexualism and underwent irreversible sterilization.
To establish a compensation scheme for those who have undergone an irreversible sterilization procedure in connection with a change of legal gender.
Promote a proposal to introduce a third legal gender category.
Evaluate the law on changing legal gender to ensure that the amendment does not have a design that could lead to unintended consequences.
Consider a third gender category.

Ensure that those who have undergone an irreversible sterilization procedure in connection with gender transition have their cases thoroughly addressed within the general compensation schemes that currently exist.

Come back to the Parliament in a suitable manner on how to ensure that children under 16 years old can receive eye tests for free, in the same way that it is free for children under 16 years old for examinations and treatment with general practitioners and public clinics.
Ensure a consistent practice in all healthcare institutions, where all individuals admitted after a stroke have their visual function assessed.

Evaluate the public services and professional collaboration regarding vision tests and vision assessments for children, including the need for more ophthalmology specialists and possibly the use of optometrists where appropriate as part of the public offering.
Ensure a consistent practice in all healthcare institutions, where all patients with confirmed visual impairment are referred for necessary rehabilitation.

Promote proposals for changes to the Health and Care Services Act § 4-1 first paragraph letter a, so that each patient or user is provided with a comprehensive and coordinated health and care service offer, children are not placed in nursing homes against the wishes of their families and the best interests of the child, and patients aged 18-49 are not placed in nursing homes against their own or their guardian's wishes.

Conduct a review of the arrangement for resource-intensive services and ensure that all relevant costs incurred by the municipalities in connection with the arrangement are included as the basis for the municipal co-payment.
Investigate and present a step 2 in the top financing scheme with a maximum amount per inhabitant, and return to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2022.

Promote a case for the Parliament regarding measures to strengthen speech therapy services in municipalities, including proposals for the revision of the National Insurance Act § 5-10 and the associated regulations, in line with the recommendations from the Norwegian Directorate of Health.
Promote proposals for necessary legal changes to abolish the residency requirement for residential and vacation properties.

Conduct a comprehensive review of the impact that the residency requirement has on the districts where it has been implemented, and whether municipalities can introduce more targeted measures to attract new residents without encroaching on private property.

Establish a public committee to map the inequalities in rehabilitation services in municipalities and specialist health services, and provide concrete proposals on how to deliver good rehabilitation services based on: user and family involvement, reduced disparities in services, the use of welfare technology, collaboration between primary health care, specialist health services, and other welfare actors, and equitable services throughout the country.
Establish a national development center for rehabilitation, based on the user perspective and with innovative services, that facilitates good collaboration between service levels.

Ensure an escalation of rehabilitation and habilitation services, based on the Norwegian Directorate of Health's evaluation of the Escalation Plan for habilitation and rehabilitation 2017–2019, and present this to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Ensure that employees in rehabilitation institutions who require rehabilitation have the opportunity to undergo such rehabilitation at a different institution than the one where they are employed.

Establish a long-term grant scheme for municipalities that, through innovative development work, facilitate rehabilitation services where the patient's needs are at the center, and where the patient receives a process tailored and adapted to their needs.
Implement measures to reduce the geographical differences in habilitation and rehabilitation.

Initiate trials with mobile teams in the specialist health service, which can contribute to proper follow-up and expertise in a decentralized treatment offer for individuals in need of specialized rehabilitation.

Ensure that rehabilitation services within the specialist health service are not discontinued until it has been ensured that the municipalities are capable of taking over responsibility for the relevant patient groups.

Amend § 5 letter a in the regulation on the right to health and care services for persons without permanent residence in the country, so that those who are already in the country receive primary health services on par with other citizens.
Ensure that individuals without permanent residence in the country are granted access to the general practitioner scheme.

Ensure that healthcare institutions comply with the law when dealing with undocumented pregnant women, and ensure that they receive necessary medical assistance without being asked for or required to pay before treatment, and that clear guidelines are established for the treatment and follow-up of undocumented pregnant women.

Establish a funding scheme for practitioners, so that they can be reimbursed for expenses and medications provided to patients outside the National Insurance Scheme, and return to the Parliament with the necessary proposals to ensure this.

Ensure that individuals without permanent residence in the country are granted access to preventive and curative health services in the municipal health service, including general practitioner services, and that children are given the right to be registered with a general practitioner.

Ensure that organizations are bound by the same legislation as the state apparatus, thereby ensuring that voluntary organizations have a reporting obligation when they come into contact with illegal immigrants. This must be a prerequisite for receiving financial support from the public sector.
Facilitate a national reimbursement scheme for the Health Center for the Undocumented in Bergen and Oslo that covers expenses for medications and pharmacy costs.

Ensure that the health centers for undocumented migrants in Bergen and Oslo have access to COVID-19 vaccines, so that they can vaccinate their patients in accordance with recommendations and prioritization of groups.

Evaluate the regulation on the right to health and care services for persons without permanent residence in the country, and make necessary changes so that the health services for vulnerable groups, such as children, persons with disabilities, pregnant women, and the elderly, are in line with the services offered to the rest of the population.

Ensure that all undocumented individuals residing in Norway receive necessary healthcare that cannot wait, as well as review the practice of the right to necessary healthcare, including the funding arrangements, and assess improvements to ensure that these rights are fulfilled.
Review the treatment options available in inpatient units for children and adolescents to ensure that they are services that children and young people find helpful.

Present a plan to ensure the necessary education and recruitment of medical specialists and other specialists within child and adolescent psychiatry (BUP). The necessary education should be based on summarized knowledge derived from what children say is important in terms of education and competence.

Promote measures to realize collaborative models for increased interaction between the school health service and child and adolescent psychiatry (BUP), and ensure that such collaborative models are in line with children's four fundamental rights as outlined in the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. The foundation for the models must be that the school health service, which follows the school environment and knows the students over time, is best positioned to prevent minor mental health issues and contribute to prompt treatment.
Make an assessment of which arrangements within mental health care have faced significant burdens as a result of COVID-19, and return to the Parliament with proposals to strengthen these services.

Ensure that the regional health authorities temporarily expand the use of contracted specialists in mental health care, and prioritize building up the public services with more permanent and health positions in the sector.
Investigate the introduction of a requirement for child and adolescent psychiatry to provide an assessment of all referrals and necessary follow-up actions.

Ensure equal and fair case processing practices in child and adolescent psychiatry (BUP) and that all referrals are assessed by leaders in BUP with specialist competence. The Parliament further requests the government to ensure that children and young people receive better information about their rights.
Ensure that a national overview of rejections of referrals, complaints about rejections, and the percentage of overturned decisions is prepared within child and adolescent psychiatry.
Ensure that public health nurses have referral rights to child and adolescent mental health services (BUP).
Postpone major restructuring and closures of inpatient facilities in mental health until the pandemic situation is more clarified.
Remove the co-payments for patients up to 25 years old for treatment in public mental health care.
Present a plan to ensure the necessary education and recruitment of medical specialists, clinical psychologists, and specialized nurses within child and adolescent psychiatry (BUP).
Promote measures to realize collaborative models for increased interaction between municipal health services, school health services, and child and adolescent psychiatry.
Ensure access to rapid mental health support and low-threshold services without referral in all municipalities.

Establish a public committee to review mental health services for children and adolescents, among other things based on the findings in the reports from Ukom and the Children's Ombudsman. The committee will also examine the connection between the assistance provided in municipal health services and in specialist health services.

Increase the treatment capacity in child and adolescent psychiatry (BUP) and stop the reduction of bed capacity to ensure short waiting times and provide children and young people with help close to where they live, as well as access to necessary inpatient treatment.

Ensure that children and young people under 18 years old who become acutely mentally ill are admitted to a child and adolescent psychiatric department, even on weekends and in the evenings, so that they do not have to be admitted to an adult acute psychiatric department.
Abolish performance-based funding for child and adolescent psychiatry (BUP) to ensure that children and young people have access to flexible services.
Ensure that the regional health enterprises expand the use of contracted specialists in mental health care.
Stop the Innlandet Hospital's plan to close the child and adolescent psychiatric services at Kringsjåtunet.

Conduct a review of the use of coercion in involuntary mental health care, particularly in relation to staffing. There must be a correct and compassionate use of coercion, which should only be employed when absolutely necessary.

Evaluate the changes in the Mental Health Care Act regarding the introduction of consent requirements for involuntary admission to compulsory mental health care, and promote a case to the Parliament regarding necessary legal amendments in this area to ensure the lives and health of seriously mentally ill patients.

Propose amendments to the law that ensure criminal liability with minimum penalties for individuals or organizations that contribute to children being sent abroad and left against their will under conditions where they may be subjected to violence and torture, negative social control, or radicalization.

Investigate and present proposals on which benefits should be discontinued when parents, through their own actions or arrangements, are responsible for sending children abroad or leaving them behind against their will under circumstances that may expose children and young people to violence and torture, negative social control, or radicalization.

Ensure that it has consequences for parental responsibility when parents, through their own actions or facilitation, are responsible for children being sent to or left in foreign countries against their will under conditions that may contribute to children and young people being exposed to violence and torture, negative social control, or radicalization.

Promote necessary proposals and implement changes that ensure consequences for the residence permit of parents with temporary residency when they, through their own actions or facilitation, are responsible for children being sent to or left abroad against their will under conditions that may contribute to children and young people being exposed to violence and torture, negative social control, or radicalization.

Promote a proposal for a legislative amendment that ensures the introduction of minimum penalties for parents and caregivers who, through their own actions or facilitation, are responsible for sending children to or leaving them abroad against their will under conditions that may expose children and young people to violence and torture, negative social control, or radicalization.

Map cases where child welfare services have contributed when parents have wanted to send children out of the country. The Parliament also asks the government to immediately stop the practice of child welfare services assisting in sending children abroad against their will.

Develop information and guidelines on how children and young people who find themselves abroad against their will should be followed up and provided assistance if they make contact with embassies, child welfare services, or other public authorities, in order to ensure that the children in question feel taken seriously.

Follow up on the proposals in the government-appointed expert group's report "It Was Not Just a Holiday" regarding the obligation of foreign missions and immigration authorities to notify child welfare services, similar to the obligation that passport authorities have.
Investigate and present proposals for which benefits may and should be discontinued when children are sent abroad and kept there against their will.

Investigate the prohibition against deprivation of liberty in situations where children are to be, or are already, sent abroad against their will, and propose amendments to the law that ensure that forced stays abroad can be punished.

Introduce new and stricter measures when the custodial parent obstructs visitation, as well as investigate what sanctions should apply when the non-custodial parent fails to show up for scheduled visitation.
Promote a proposal that visitation that has not been carried out due to visitation sabotage should be able to take place later, referred to as compensatory visitation.
Propose that long-term or repeated visitation interference should be grounds for transferring custody authority to the parent who will ensure the greatest possible overall parental contact.

Propose a change in the law that ensures that no one benefits financially in terms of child support due to visitation sabotage, and that all collection/payment of support is halted in cases of sabotage by the recipient.

Promote a proposal to increase the powers of family counseling offices regarding the establishment of visitation plans, which also grants the right to impose fines if the plan is violated. This is to relieve the courts and resolve cases more quickly.
Obtain an independent legal assessment of Nav's implementation of the child support regulations in cases of visitation sabotage.
Promote proposals for new and stricter reactions to visitation sabotage.
Investigate stricter measures that can counteract visitation obstruction.
Investigate whether there is a need to make adjustments to the child support regulations to ensure that financial issues do not become a driving factor for hindering visitation.

Prepare informational material about the rights that children in child welfare services have, and ensure that this informational material is distributed to all municipalities in Norway, and inform the Parliament in an appropriate manner once this is done, by the end of 2021.

Promote proposals to legislate participation at the service level, for example through municipal user councils that include children, and through the committee method, where children's experiences and knowledge are gathered.
Suggest that participation is mentioned in all relevant chapters of the new law.

Ensure that those working in welfare service sectors funded by the public sector have salary and working conditions, including occupational pension schemes, that are in line with those of the public sector, as well as ensuring greater transparency and better control of enterprises funded with public money.

Review the effects of the right of reservation in the Working Environment Act § 16-2 second paragraph, including the consequences for salary and working conditions, and promote legislative proposals that strengthen employees' conditions in the event of business transfers.
Ensure that publicly funded welfare services are primarily carried out by employees, not by self-employed individuals.

Review whether the working conditions at commercial welfare actors, including staffing, are in accordance with legal and contractual obligations. Furthermore, the Parliament requests the government to terminate tender contracts and other types of agreements where working conditions do not comply with the contractual provisions, and to report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Ensure that contractors working for the public sector have a collective bargaining agreement.
Ensure that all companies that primarily derive their income from the public sector are subject to external auditing and have extended note requirements in their annual financial statements.

Come back to the Parliament with an assessment of the developments related to the police's working conditions in relation to youth environments and gang criminals. The government is asked to consider any potential increases in penalties as well as other measures to stop the rise in harassment, obstruction, threats, and violence against police officers.

Promote a proposal for Norway to sign the additional protocol to the CRPD, so that Norwegian citizens are not excluded from filing complaints about possible rights violations based on reduced functional ability to the CRPD Committee.
Promote a proposal to incorporate the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) into the Equality and Anti-Discrimination Act.

Promote a proposal to incorporate the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) into the Human Rights Act, and to conduct a systematic review of Norwegian legislation to identify where changes may be needed.
Present an assessment of the consequences of Norway ratifying the Optional Protocol to the CRPD.
To promote a cause with necessary legislative changes that align Norwegian legislation with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD).

Investigate the consequences of incorporating the CRPD into Norwegian legislation, including the implications it will have for future legislative development, and request the government to appropriately return to the Storting with a proposal.
Promote a proposal to incorporate the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) into the Human Rights Act.
Establish response time requirements for emergency services at the municipal level.

Consider whether it may be appropriate to establish a separate Ministry of the Interior, following the model of other comparable countries, where the portfolio of the Ministry of Justice is divided between a dedicated Minister of the Interior and a Minister of Justice.
Introduce language requirements for healthcare personnel so that they can be sufficiently understood and avoid miscommunication.

Accelerate the establishment of a digital border defense by ensuring that the intelligence service is provided with sufficient funding for the capacity to facilitate the collection of cross-border data traffic.

Ensure that in the event of an armed conflict or an attack on Norway, the civilian population near civilian and military targets receives protection through rapid access to civilian protective measures, while also ensuring that exercises for the evacuation of the civilian population in vulnerable areas are conducted.

Review the organization of the fire and rescue service at the national level to strengthen the ability to carry out missions in districts where long distances hinder rapid response times and adequate preparedness.

Strengthen the fire and rescue service by introducing a new education model, including basic education at the vocational school level and leadership training at the university level, requiring full-time management in all local fire departments, and clarifying and prioritizing the task portfolio of the fire and rescue service through a separate parliamentary report.
Review the shelters, upgrade the shelters so they can provide real protection, and develop a plan to give the population access to the shelters.

Ensure that a supply reserve of critical medicines and medical supplies is established, where for non-storable medicines, public-private partnerships must facilitate the rapid establishment of domestic production capacity.

Investigate whether the Crisis Support Unit in the Ministry of Justice and Public Security can include additional areas of expertise beyond the current ones, for example, the health sector and the transport sector, in order to uncover mutual dependencies in hybrid, misguided incidents.

Further develop the Joint Cyber Coordination Center (FCKS) and the National Cyber Security Center (NCSC) through adequate funding and updating the legal framework to implement necessary protective measures.
Conduct information campaigns for the civilian population about relevant civil protection measures for various types of threats.
Ensure that volunteers who assist emergency services during crises are entitled to compensation for lost income.

Establish a permanent total preparedness committee that reports to the government every year to ensure coordinated leadership at a higher level and across sectors, as well as comprehensive and coordinated threat assessments. Both preparedness authorities, community organizations, and the business sector should be represented in the committee.
Investigate a compensation scheme for lost income for volunteers who assist public emergency services in rescue operations.

Ensure that decision 236 from December 11, 2020, is followed up and returned to the Parliament in connection with the Revised National Budget (RNB) 2021, where the plan to ensure a physical presence of police, based on police stations or police posts, in the relevant districts is presented in accordance with the Parliament's decision of December 11, 2020.
Secure funding for the further development of the Armed Forces' ability to conduct offensive cyber operations against, among other things, threats in the digital space.
Strengthen physical security of prioritized objects based on threat assessments and risk analyses.
Ensure increased competence development for employees in municipalities, the state, and companies in the field of ICT security.
Ensure that an annual self-preparedness campaign is conducted to remind the population to secure their basic needs in case of various crises.

Ensure that the police, county governor, and municipalities include voluntary organizations in emergency plans, that they participate in joint exercises, and that the police are committed to coordinating and maintaining cooperation between the various actors during incidents.

Establish a fast-working expert committee to assess the potential long-term effects of the pandemic on travel habits and other transportation relevant to Norwegian transport planning. The committee shall deliver a preliminary report early enough to be valuable for the Parliament's consideration of the National Transport Plan in the spring of 2021, while a final report should be completed by the end of the year 2021–2022.
Present a proposal that makes it legal in Norway to train suitable dogs for the purpose of hunting wolves using the method of loose, driven hounds.
Ensure that the authority for granting exemptions related to methods for damage removal is given by the same authority that makes decisions on damage removal.

Present a case to the Storting regarding more efficient removal of bears that harm livestock, where the government identifies obstacles to effective removal and proposes measures that ensure that damage-causing bears are effectively removed in grazing-prioritized areas.

Present a case to the Storting on how new technical aids can streamline the culling of predators in Norway. Technical aids such as drones, snowmobiles, helicopters, lights, thermal devices, etc., should be considered in this context.
Promote proposals for suitable measures that make the culling of predators more effective and uniform.

Implement a knowledge transfer project so that the methods and experiences gained by the wildlife culling teams in Nord-Østerdal and Engerdal are shared with wildlife culling teams in other parts of the country. A training program should be developed, and a permanent network should be established to ensure the transfer of knowledge and expertise.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals on how measures related to damage removal can also help make licensed hunting more effective.

Establish a public committee to gain knowledge and gather new research on sexual harassment in Norway and provide recommendations for measures against this, in all areas of society and sectors, with a consistent power perspective. The committee should be composed of researchers and representatives from the parties in the labor market.
Increase support for the Equality and Anti-Discrimination Ombud's work against sexual harassment, in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.

Prepare a parliamentary report with a comprehensive review of various fields and sectors in society, proposing measures that can help prevent sexual harassment in Norwegian society. The work must encompass all types of harassment, as well as threats and violence.

Take the initiative for a partnership with the parties in the labor market to deliver solutions for equal pay, including a possible multi-year equal pay fund in the public sector, measures to increase full-time employment, and measures to counteract the gender-segregated labor market.
Come back to the Parliament at the first opportunity with a binding escalation plan for equal pay in the public sector, including proposals for financing.
Strengthen the tripartite cooperation for gender equality by establishing a dedicated council for this purpose and ensuring it is accompanied by budgetary funds.

Strengthen equal pay legislation by investigating and implementing an equal pay standard, inspired by Iceland, where businesses above a certain size must prove that they pay equal wages, and where the Equality and Anti-Discrimination Ombud and the Anti-Discrimination Tribunal are given the opportunity to monitor and sanction non-compliance with the standard.
Develop a strategy against the gender-segregated labor market, including strengthening the counseling services in secondary schools to avoid gender-segregated educational choices.

Strengthen the work of the Equality and Anti-Discrimination Ombud in following up on businesses and providing guidance on the duty to promote equality and report, including referring inadequate reports to the Discrimination Tribunal.

Strengthen the Discrimination Tribunal's ability to enforce regulations and sanction businesses that do not comply with the duty to promote and report, in order to ensure good quality and efficient case processing.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to abolish the gambling monopoly and introduce a licensing system that ensures equal competitive conditions for Norwegian and international gaming companies.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to amend the Marketing Act so that all licensed gambling companies can legally advertise their products.

Promote a reading strategy that includes long-term measures to strengthen engagement and interest in reading across the entire population. The strategy must include measures to enhance access to literature and facilitate reading-promoting initiatives in schools, workplaces, and other relevant locations. It should also contain proposals for skills development to foster engagement and motivation for reading. The strategy must be financially binding and involve collaboration between the Ministry of Culture and the Ministry of Education, with industry and reading organizations included in the early stages of the strategy's development.

Come back to the Parliament with a separate case about school libraries, where they propose to require municipalities to have a plan for school libraries that ensures all children have regular access, also on their own, to a school library with a professionally trained librarian.
Present a report on which measures have the best effect on increasing reading and reading motivation.

Promote a reading strategy that includes long-term measures to strengthen engagement and interest in reading across the entire population. The strategy should include initiatives that enhance access to literature and facilitate reading promotion activities in schools, workplaces, and other relevant locations.

Develop a plan for the safe reopening of cultural life when feasible based on the infection situation, as well as an emergency plan with various scenarios in case new infection control restrictions are implemented, to provide predictability for the organizers.
Ensure that no enterprise receives more than 10 million kroner in combined monthly support from the wage support scheme and the regular compensation scheme for businesses.

Ensure that individuals who are brought in with wage support are offered the opportunity to use part of their working hours for skill development, as well as to enter into agreements with union representatives to preserve jobs and invest in employees' skills.

Facilitate that individuals who are hired with wage support and who have not completed upper secondary education are offered the opportunity to participate in the program Certificate of Competence in Work.

Make an assessment together with the parties on how the infection situation and vaccination rate affect the economic outlook, and thus the need for an extension and any other adjustments to the wage support scheme, and return to the Parliament with a separate case.
Develop a national strategy for the implementation of the decommissioning of Norwegian nuclear facilities.
Develop a strategy for business development and increased value creation based on expertise in decommissioning and waste management from nuclear operations.

Establish as a basis for the further work on the cleanup related to IFE's nuclear activities that the state takes full responsibility for the cleanup and covers all necessary costs associated with it. However, the fact that the Parliament now confirms this principle should not set a precedent for any other cleanups where the state has played an initiating role.

Investigate a future location for Export Financing Norway, where both continued location in Oslo and alternatives outside of Oslo are examined. The investigation should also include an assessment of a new structure with multiple local offices based in key export regions in the country.

Postpone the merger of GIEK and Export Credit Norway until it is deemed prudent, considering the coronavirus crisis, to choose a location for the headquarters outside Oslo in line with the placement of government jobs.

Present a plan to relocate 200 other government jobs that are currently located in Oslo to Groruddalen. This relocation should occur in parallel with the reorganization and relocation of GIEK and Export Credit Norway.

Handle the merger of GIEK and Export Credit Norway in accordance with the government guidelines for the location of state workplaces and move the activities out of Oslo by establishing the headquarters and branch offices in Ålesund and Bergen, respectively.
Investigate and choose a model and location in Western Norway for Export Financing Norway that best serves the export environments along the coast and in the rest of the country.
Promote proposals that strengthen the regions' role in economic development.
Promote proposals on how the presence of the government support system for businesses throughout the country can be strengthened.

Consider expanding the mandate of Export Financing Norway. The expansion should particularly facilitate the establishment of good export financing arrangements for green transition, commercialization, scaling up, and internationalization.

Suggest measures that make the support system for businesses more industry-oriented and customer-focused, particularly measures that can simplify and make the support system more accessible for small and medium-sized enterprises.
Investigate a stronger regional presence for Export Financing Norway based on the objective of a stronger regional presence in key export regions, and report back to the Parliament on the matter.

Return to the Storting with a proposal for a revised project for E18 Dørdal–Tvedestrand, where the current two- and three-lane road is included in the new development of E18 along the applicable stretch.

Conduct a concept choice study (KVU) for the Norwegian part of a new railway line between Oslo and Stockholm, with the goal of achieving a travel time of under three hours between the two capitals. The KVU should be viewed in conjunction with the Swedish action choice study completed by the Swedish Transport Administration in November 2017, as well as the concepts from the two private companies in Norway and Sweden working towards the same goal. The KVU should also include the Kongsvinger Line as one of the route alternatives and explore various solutions for government financing through borrowing or other means.
Create a comprehensive investigation of the possibilities for alternative state models for financing and organizing railway developments in Norway.
Take the necessary initiatives to start planning for a train service with a travel time of under three hours between Oslo and Stockholm.
Review the responsibilities between the Norwegian Railway Authority, Bane NOR, and the Ministry of Transport.
Follow up on the KVU from the Norwegian Railway Directorate regarding the Kongsvinger Line and implement upgrades for both freight and passenger transport.
Conduct a feasibility study to clarify route selection and possible financing model for the Oslo–Stockholm 2.55 project in Norway.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that allows crew members on ships, for whom diving is a limited part of their position, to still be covered by the Ship Safety Act and the Seafarers Act.

Explain the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority's follow-up of the Working Environment Act § 1-2 second paragraph letter a, and assess whether it may be appropriate to make provisions and rights, such as sick pay regulations, which currently fall under the Maritime Labour Act, applicable to the relevant employees.

Maintain close dialogue with the parties in the labor market to continuously evaluate the effects of the Working Environment Act § 1-2 second paragraph letter a and, if necessary, consider adjustments to the regulations, including ensuring that the captain's responsibilities are clarified when diving is conducted, as well as clarifying the provisions related to working and resting hours in connection with diving operations at sea.

Consider the introduction of a regulation requiring working and resting hours for self-employed individuals and contractors engaged in professional diving from vessels in business. The regulation should provide the same protection for self-employed individuals and contractors as for employees under the Working Environment Act.
Promote a new, overarching parliamentary report on quality and patient safety in health and care services, with specific goals and measures that are followed up with annual status reports.

Investigate and propose a low-threshold, sanction-free reporting system across the entire healthcare service with the aim of learning across the board, including from near-miss incidents, based on the reporting system established in § 3-3 of the Specialist Health Services Act, which was discontinued in 2018.
Present a plan for increased intensive care capacity in Norway.

Establish a dedicated gang unit within the police, based on Kripos, that will work to uncover the networks and structures of gangs throughout the country and internationally, in collaboration with the affected police districts.

Ensure that when establishing a gang unit in Kripos, there is sufficient surveillance capacity, informant handlers, data-savvy personnel, etc., to continuously monitor criminal networks and gangs 24/7/365.

Ensure that the establishment of a gang unit in Kripos includes sufficient investigators, police lawyers, and prosecution resources in the unit, as well as an associated state attorney, so that the unit can handle cases up to legal proceedings on its own.

Ensure that when establishing a gang unit in Kripos, training and equipment are provided so that the gang unit can uncover the gangs' advanced communication and utilize new tools that the Parliament has granted the police through legislative changes regarding access to data reading, etc.

Ensure that a gang unit in Kripos, in order to avoid cycles of revenge and vigilantism in gang environments, will prioritize bringing cases against gang members quickly to court and seek to use the Penal Code § 79 first paragraph letter c ("the organized crime paragraph") which can impose harsher penalties.
Ensure that the work against organized crime and gangs is prioritized and provided with resources in all police districts, so that they are able to do their part of the job.
Find a solution that prevents the police investigation from coming to a standstill and replaces the temporary directive following the ECHR ruling on December 17, 2020.

Present a proposal for the digitization of the application for permits for the storage and import of weapons, including a specific timeline for the project, no later than in the revised national budget for 2021.

Utilize selected green growth indicators as a long-term management tool for the Norwegian economy, guiding the formulation of strategic goals for energy, environmental, and industrial policy, so that the improvement in carbon productivity in the Norwegian economy is at least above the average recommended by scientific consensus, which is over 5 percent per year.

Investigate a revenue-neutral tax model for green growth. This should provide tax incentives to businesses that over time transition to real green growth (improving their carbon productivity relative to their starting point), and be balanced with a corresponding tax increase for other businesses.
Provide the same set of annually updated key indicators for green growth that are currently reported to the OECD's Green Growth Indicators in each budget proposal.
Define cultural heritage schools as schools that ensure the preservation of nationally valuable competencies in subjects that are of great importance for the safeguarding of our cultural heritage.
Establish a basic funding for schools that offer cultural heritage subjects.
Investigate the financing of school places in cultural heritage subjects that cater to adults without the right to upper secondary education.

Consider whether profits from the sale of kindergarten properties can be regarded as illegal state aid to a commercial real estate business, rather than support for a non-economic kindergarten operation. Furthermore, the Storting requests the government to clarify how any illegal state aid can be reclaimed and to report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner.
Return to the Parliament with a proposal that public funding for private kindergartens is discontinued upon sale or after a certain period of time.
Start the work on reestablishing the former Nesna University College as a fully-fledged higher education institution with primary school and kindergarten teacher education.
Require Nord University to continue teaching at Campus Nesna and to announce study places for the academic year 2021–2022 in the Coordinated Admission for 2021.
Investigate which other permanent study programs can be located at Campus Nesna to meet regional competence needs in other professional education and fields of study.
Facilitate the institution in Nesna to also offer gathering-based study programs located at other study sites in the region.

Investigate international and national experiences with legal, institutional, labor-related, and economic models for the registration and protection of traditionally sacred Sámi natural sites for future generations.

Initiate a collaboration with the Sámi Parliament to protect a selection of traditionally sacred Sámi natural sites. The enhanced protection should ensure the opportunities for continued Sámi practices related to these sites, so that experiences with the protection methods can be gathered for later investigation and continuation.

Promote the issue that the right to free interpreting services is removed for those who have resided in the country for more than five years or have Norwegian citizenship, including in the handling of civil law cases.
To reduce public spending and limit the right to free interpreting services, including in connection with the conduct of criminal cases.
To introduce optional second language in schools and return to the Parliament with a proposal regarding any necessary legal changes to implement this.

Come back to the Storting with a legislative proposal that allows each individual citizen and each public authority to choose their preferred language form. It should be up to the public employee to use the language form they wish, regardless of which municipality or other public authority they are employed in and in which language form an inquiry has been made.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals on what sanctions should apply in case of violations of the Language Act.

Ensure that the development and use of the Norwegian language in the past and present are scientifically documented, and that the documentation and standardization of the Norwegian language shall be a public mission at a Norwegian scientific institution.

Come back to the Storting with a proposal to amend the Language Act, specifying that the public sector has a responsibility to develop and use Norwegian terminology and technical language, and to make it available in both language forms within its field of expertise.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal regarding sign language, suggesting how the right to sign language can be incorporated into the language law.

Return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner with a proposal on how particularly children and young people who lack speech or sign language can be better included in society through, among other things, AAC/symbol language.

Ensure that the compensation scheme for employees affected by entry restrictions applies to workers who were outside Norway's borders on January 29, 2021, and for whom our authorities do not grant entry permits to perform their work.

Ensure that employees who, for special reasons such as illness, childbirth, or funerals of close family members, need to return to their home country, are able to re-enter Norway once the situation has been resolved.
Develop sector-specific climate plans that investigate which measures need to be implemented to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 80% by 2030 compared to 1990.

Investigate and, in connection with the state budget for 2022, return to the Storting with a proposal for a green people's bonus. It should be based on the premise that the people's bonus will be paid to people with low and average incomes, and that the total amount paid out will correspond to the increase in the CO2 tax.

Ensure that the revenues from the increase in CO2 taxes, with the exception of the increase for the petroleum sector, are matched by at least an equal amount on the expenditure side of the state budget for a green people's bonus.

Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how emissions from the continental shelf should be reduced by at least 50% compared to emissions in 1990. The plan should also include a strategy for how to develop offshore wind production that, in the long term, generates at least as much electricity as is required to electrify the continental shelf. The offshore wind production must also be connected to the onshore power grid so that it can be utilized when the platforms are phased out.
Consider compensatory measures for groups that are particularly affected by the increase in the CO2 tax.

Investigate and return to the Parliament with a proposal for a production tax for oil companies in connection with the state budget for 2022. The production tax should contribute to the financing of zero-emission technology such as offshore wind.
Introduce a model to ensure profitable development of large-scale floating offshore wind.

Contribute to risk alleviation and predictable revenues for offshore wind companies, for example based on the successful British model of contracts for difference that shares risk and reward between the industry and the state.

Open to the idea that the business sector, as an alternative to an increased CO2 tax, can enter into sector-specific agreements with the state, based on the model of the Business Sector's NOx Fund, where they commit to reducing at least as much emissions as an increase in the tax would yield.
Ensure that the increase in the CO2 tax is not offset by a lower road usage fee, as this would drastically reduce the emission reduction effect.
Ensure that no tax reliefs are granted that reduce the environmental impact of the increased CO2 tax.
Investigate a nature fee on land use to limit the development of Norwegian nature, and return to the Storting with a proposal in connection with the state budget for 2022.
Investigate and implement a ban on the use of all fossil energy in industry.

Investigate and implement a reward system for the most environmentally friendly suppliers for public contracts, and return to the Parliament with proposals in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.
Present proposals for measures to reduce the consumption of red and processed meat to the level recommended by dietary guidelines.

Investigate and propose a model for a so-called carbon tax for distribution, where the revenue from the increased CO2 tax on gasoline and diesel is paid out again to all residents as a climate reward. Geographical and social distribution considerations should be taken into account in the grading of the payments.
Elevating the role of cities as one of the main priorities in international climate efforts, alongside the conservation of rainforests and renewable energy.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to amend the Road Traffic Act § 7, so that municipalities can establish zero-emission zones for the sake of the climate.
Investigate a scheme for support for the purchase, car sharing, or leasing of electric vehicles for low-income households.
Continue to promote the advantages of electric cars in such a way that electric vehicles become increasingly competitive compared to fossil fuel cars in all categories.

Present an assessment of the consequences of Norway's goal for 2050 being a target for a "low-emission society" rather than a "climate-neutral society," as well as a proposal for how carbon uptake in forests and land areas can be included in Norway's climate targets for 2030 and 2050.

Investigate a contractual arrangement for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from Norwegian ships, where shipowners commit to halving greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 compared to emissions in 2005, and where the CO2 tax is set equal to the EU quota price when the agreement comes into effect.
Introduce calculation methods for reporting our emission obligations that differentiate between emissions of short-lived and long-lived greenhouse gases.

Develop a plan for how forests can be utilized more effectively in relation to climate, and present measures for a significant increase in the long-term carbon uptake in Norwegian forest areas, forest planting on new areas, and how raw materials from the forest can contribute to reducing greenhouse gas emissions in other sectors. The plan must include an investigation of which value creation measures and specific climate actions will ensure that forests are optimally utilized to achieve our long-term climate goals, and how these can be implemented.
Establish a grant scheme for tree planting in the context of climate change, to increase the forest's CO2 absorption.
Reject a general goal of tripling the CO2 tax by 2030. The structure and any increase of the CO2 tax and compensatory measures will be determined in the annual budgets.
Engage in dialogue with relevant industries and arrive at concrete solutions and realistic objectives based on the available tools for each sector.
To negotiate and enter into agreements with various sectors with goals and measures similar to those for agriculture, where this is appropriate.
To explain how the various changes in the structure of the EU's climate regulations may affect Norway's climate goals and their implementation.
Present a plan for the construction of 10,000 fast chargers across the country by 2030, and by the end of 2022, have a plan for the rollout of refueling stations for hydrogen and biogas.

Ensure that there is room for transitional arrangements when requirements for zero-emission solutions are imposed in public ferry and fast boat tenders, and that any additional costs in this regard are covered by the state.

Implement a climate policy that balances the goals of the Paris Agreement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions with the requirement that this does not come at the expense of food production and the objectives of food security and combating hunger.

Include measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions or increase carbon uptake in soil in the government's annual reporting to the Storting, provided that the measures have scientifically documented climate effects. This also applies to measures that do not yet have a finalized accounting methodology in Norway's official climate accounts.
Not to introduce taxation on private parking spaces or benefits of access to parking spaces at the employer's premises.
Provide suggestions on how sectors or industries that are unable to switch to alternative technology can be shielded from increased CO2 taxes.
Ensure that no ban is introduced on the import of gasoline and diesel cars, whether new or used.
Not implementing requirements for zero-emission vehicles in public procurement of passenger and commercial vehicles.
Reducing greenhouse gas emissions or increasing carbon uptake in the soil should be highlighted in the government's annual reporting to the Parliament.
Establish that increased taxation of Norwegian meat production should not be implemented as part of climate policy.

Establish a green investment company that will contribute to strategic investments and long-term loans in companies focusing on climate-friendly solutions and products, based on green renewable carbon.
Present a message on how to ensure preparedness in a society that is increasingly being electrified.

Establish a "Bionova," a climate fund of 10 billion Norwegian kroner for agriculture, where practitioners can apply for support to transition their production and operations in order to reduce greenhouse gas emissions per produced unit. The fund will also help finance measures to increase CO2 sequestration in forests and soil.
Increase the warranty period for new homes from five to ten years in the Housing Construction Act to ensure longer durability of materials.
Investigate incentives in building regulations to use heat pumps for heating and return to the Parliament with proposals.

Enter into a binding collaboration with stakeholders in the freight transport sector to establish solutions that provide opportunities within heavy transport, and resume negotiations on a CO2 fund for the freight transport industry.
Come back with a plan to electrify, introduce hydrogen trains, or hybrid solutions on all railway lines where diesel trains currently operate.

Present a plan for how we will achieve the goal of moving 30% of freight transport by truck over 300 km to sea and rail by 2030. The plan will be presented to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2022.
Take the initiative to renegotiate the Chicago Convention, so that it becomes possible to increase fees on international air travel.
Implement the approved exemption in the toll ring for heavy vehicles using biogas and report back to the Parliament in connection with the revised budget.
Reduce import quotas on agricultural products.

Work to ensure that Norwegian coastal shipping has the same competitive conditions as other countries in the EU, and request that they come back with proposals on how we can ensure that the CO2 tax does not exceed the quota price in the EU at any time.
Establish that there should be no zero-emission zones that prevent people from driving their gasoline or diesel cars in parts of Norwegian cities.
Establish and implement the decommissioning scheme for retired offshore vessels.

Facilitate the expansion of wind power in areas with good wind conditions and local acceptance, in line with our positions in the wind power report from autumn 2020, and have a major investment in floating offshore wind.
Ensure that the licensing system is designed to provide environmentally sound licenses for solar, hydro, and wind power projects in line with expected consumption trends.
Facilitate the development of more clean energy and infrastructure through a comprehensive plan for Norwegian hydropower, wind power, and other energy developments that require permits.

Facilitate in collaboration with the industry to ensure that emissions from oil and gas production on the Norwegian continental shelf are reduced by 50 percent by 2030 and to net zero by 2050, measured against 2005 levels.

Enter into binding climate partnerships with particularly vulnerable industries. These agreements should be in place early and before the CO2 tax is ramped up. These climate agreements should include a ramp-up plan that takes into account the competitiveness of the industry.

Facilitate that the measures in the climate partnerships are proportional to what the industries contribute, and take into account what is needed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, preserve jobs, and promote new technology. The measures are financed through the annual state budgets.
Continue the compensation scheme for the fishing industry until satisfactory alternative solutions or binding agreements are in place.
Develop a separate concession regime for offshore aquaculture with strict requirements for sustainability and coexistence between different industries at sea.
Reduce the benefits for the most expensive electric cars, and increase the CO2 component for new gasoline and diesel cars in order to achieve the goal of only selling zero-emission vehicles by 2025.

Reduce the road usage tax with a geographical differentiation, so that the price of gasoline and diesel has little or no increase in rural areas, but somewhat higher in urban areas where there is better developed public transport. The tax increase will not be linear, but will be lower at the beginning of the period and increase as zero-emission vehicles become more viable alternatives across the country.
To assume that the need for and effectiveness of compensation schemes for the CO2 tax will be evaluated by 2025 to measure the impact of emission reductions.

Facilitate that electrification on the Norwegian continental shelf, as far as possible, occurs with offshore wind, balanced with power from (and to) land. A long-term goal should be that as much power is produced on the shelf as the shelf itself uses. However, this must not delay the work on electrification.
Facilitate the integration of climate risk into the investment decisions and regular operations of oil companies, and ensure they report on this.
Establish a system for annual concession announcements for offshore wind under the Ocean Energy Act, based on mapping of both environmental impact and wind conditions.
Strengthen the municipalities' ability to implement their own climate measures in the transport sector, such as zero-emission zones and greater local autonomy in parking policies.

Expand and strengthen producer responsibility so that producers pay a larger share of the costs for handling plastic waste, and come back with proposals to the Parliament in connection with the state budget.
Consider measures and instruments that can increase the recycling of plastic materials and reduce the amount of plastic in residual waste.
To investigate a tax on plastic packaging that is not recycled, similar to the tax introduced in the EU. The tax should encourage the use of recycled and renewable plastic raw materials.

Investigate reward systems for increased carbon storage on individual farms in Norway, to mobilize farmers who wish to contribute, and return to the Parliament in connection with agricultural negotiations.
Present an annual report to the Storting on measures for emission reductions in the agricultural sector, which includes measures not captured by the official emissions accounts.
Introduce a temporary exemption from all airport fees for electric aircraft.
Ensure that electric aircraft are exempt from passenger fees.

Give the authority to establish and determine the size of zero-emission zones to the municipalities, regardless of whether the roads are municipal, county, or state-owned. The zones should be established in close dialogue with businesses and residents, as well as the Norwegian Public Roads Administration and county municipalities in cases where state and county road networks are affected.

Increase support for initiatives such as carbon capture and storage, offshore wind, hydrogen, battery technology, and green shipping, among other things, by implementing a tax reform to make it more attractive to invest in climate-friendly industries.

Develop an ambitious national strategy for offshore wind that includes a focus on the Norwegian supplier industry, a solid regulatory framework, attractive conditions for investments, and close cooperation between Norway and the EU.

Present a strategy with the goal that all public tenders for construction sites in all building projects should be emission-free by 2025. The strategy must address a solution for cost distribution or a financing model between the state and municipalities for any additional costs and include a set of measures that accommodates a wide range of contractors.
Present a plan for how installations on the Norwegian continental shelf can be electrified, have a system for carbon capture and storage, or other forms of carbon-neutral production.

Ensure a large-scale investment in Norwegian bioenergy and advanced biofuels in the transport sector, and present a plan for a comprehensive and industrial value chain for the use of Norwegian bioresources.

Investigate and present a plan for how to increase the focus on carbon storage in soil and forests. Active forest management, grazing, and the use of grass resources, as well as increased use of cover crops and biochar as soil improvement, must be prioritized in such a plan.
Not to introduce a tax on mineral fertilizers.
Introduce subsidies for the removal of logging waste as an incentive for the production of biodiesel and bioenergy.

Enter into a binding agreement with the seafood industry based on the model of the agricultural climate agreement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and environmental footprint, while also contributing to the creation of more jobs along the Norwegian coast.
Not introducing a tax on Norwegian meat as a climate measure.

Come back to the Parliament with an overview of the opportunities that lie in utilizing the flexibility of the EEA Agreement to ensure competitive framework conditions for new, large investments in climate-friendly industry.

Ensure that the tariff models for electricity better support Norwegian industry, and that reasonable and clean Norwegian power makes it attractive to establish new power-intensive industries in Norway.
Develop a strategy for electrification and return to the Parliament with it.

Facilitate a large-scale investment in offshore wind. A concrete offshore wind strategy and action plan must be developed for the growth of a Norwegian offshore wind industry, where the main goals should be to create Norwegian jobs, increase the export potential for Norwegian businesses, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and realize the potential of natural resources in Norway.

Establish effective and predictable arrangements that stimulate technology for the continued growth of the aquaculture industry at sea to ensure that fish is produced with the lowest possible energy consumption.
Ensure that high-blend advanced biofuels that are specifically procured do not count towards the general blending requirement.
Ensure that biofuels procured specifically do not count as part of the general blending requirement.
Present a proposal in the revised national budget for 2021 that the sale of advanced biofuels beyond the blending requirement be exempt from road use tax.
Present a scaling-up plan for biofuels in the proposed state budget for 2022, which establishes annual blending requirements leading up to 2030.
Ensure the development of a comprehensive infrastructure for zero and low-emission vehicles.
Facilitate support schemes for the establishment of necessary infrastructure for the realization of various technologies in passenger and freight transport.
Extend the agreement on the NOX fund until 2027.
To encourage reduced waste volume and to manage waste in Norway.
Ensure that the access to change the permitted total weight for vehicles without technical modification is also extended to vehicles over 7,500 kg.
Make an exception to the main rule regarding side and under-run protection for N3G vehicles.
Delegate the authority to carry out ADR inspections to approved heavy vehicle workshops.
Investigate the possibility of transferring the authority to conduct ADR inspections to approved heavy vehicle workshops.
Investigate the possibility of a regulatory change related to the modification of the permitted total weight for vehicles of 7,500 kg or more.
Ensure that the Norwegian Public Roads Administration takes over responsibility for all road development in the Kristiansand region.

Transfer the E18/E39 Gartnerløkka–Kolsdalen project to Nye Veier AS. Nye Veier is asked to downscale the project as part of an integrated transport planning in Kristiansand. It is assumed that phase 2 of the Transport Package for the Kristiansand region will be financed without the use of tolls.
Ensure comprehensive transportation planning in Kristiansand, where the development of the projects Gartnerløkka-Kolsdalen and Ytre Ringvei is viewed in context.
Postpone the plans for the development of Gartnerløkka until significant cuts have been made to the existing plans.
Ensure that the Ålgårdbanen is maintained as part of the national railway network.
Initiate planning for the reopening, construction, and re-establishment of the Ålgårdbanen.

At Gaustad Hospital is preserved as a treatment institution for patients within mental health care and interdisciplinary specialized substance abuse treatment, and that plans that prevent the use of the hospital and its areas for this patient group are halted.

Initiate an investigation into alternative development opportunities for Oslo University Hospital and return to the Storting with proposals on how an investigation of the location alternatives can be structured.

Do not allow the demolition of functional building stock at Oslo University Hospital, and postpone any demolition plans until after stage 2 of the New Oslo University Hospital has been regulated and investigated in a preliminary project, and detailed plans are in place to ensure that the entire population of Groruddalen receives their local hospital services at Aker Hospital.

Do not allow the sale of the hospital site at Ullevål, and postpone any potential sales decision until after stage 2 of the New Oslo University Hospital has been regulated and investigated in a preliminary project, and detailed plans are in place to ensure that the entire population of Groruddalen receives its local hospital services at Aker Hospital.
Ensure that Aker Hospital quickly becomes a fully-fledged local hospital for the entire Groruddalen.
Ensure that no plans are made for a reduction in the projected hospital activity in Oslo.
Ensure that the operations at Granheim Lung Hospital are maintained and expanded to meet the need for treatment and rehabilitation of lung diseases.

Ensure that the rehabilitation services at Granheim are maintained and strengthened, with sufficient staff and medical resources until the evaluation is completed, and that Granheim Lung Hospital is also equipped to handle rehabilitation for patients with long-term effects after COVID-19 illness.

Ensure that the services at Granheim Lung Hospital are maintained at least at the same level as today, until the announced evaluation of the need for rehabilitation and treatment for lung patients in the region is completed.
Present a parliamentary report on floods and landslides, with a comprehensive knowledge base and a plan for managing the future flood and landslide situation in Norway.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a state fund scheme that county municipalities can apply for when significant damage occurs as a result of unforeseen natural events.

Strengthen NVE's work on flood and landslide prevention significantly to ensure the areas that are currently known to be at risk, and return to the Parliament with a budget proposal no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2021.
Investigate the establishment of a Northern Areas Directorate, which will be located in Northern Norway.
Come back to the Storting with a separate case on how it will follow up on the recommendations from the Youth's Arctic Report: An Arctic Policy for Youth.

Come back to the Storting with a new strategy for détente and cooperation in the north. This should specifically address the need for concrete détente measures in the northern regions and a strengthening of the multilateral cooperation bodies in the Arctic.
Return to the Parliament with a national program for large-scale use of digital technology to promote knowledge and competence building throughout the country.
Present a strategy to provide greater opportunities for local vocational training in collaboration with local businesses from day one.
Present a parliamentary report on value creation in Northern Norway with initiatives and concrete measures to address the main challenges for the development of the region.

Come back to the Parliament with a research strategy to strengthen Arctic research, with an emphasis on social sciences and humanities, and to enhance the position of Northern Norwegian research environments in Arctic research.
Investigate moving the coordination work for Arctic policy to Northern Norway.
Ensure that the Barents Secretariat is granted a permanent allocation in the state budget from 2022.

Develop a program to reduce the maintenance backlog on county roads. The program should outline a ramp-up plan for county road maintenance with proposals for financing models and an organization that will lead to increased maintenance and backlog reduction on the county road network.
Initiate a pilot project in Northern Norway where a larger part of the higher education offerings from the region's universities is made available at study and college centers.

Follow up the structural message for higher education with a plan for how to strengthen the regional role of educational institutions, describing how broad professional education and practice-oriented research will be enhanced to ensure access to decentralized education across the country. Future higher education in Nesna should be part of the plan.

Establish a thorough decision-making basis for the Northern Norway Railway in the National Transport Plan - to clarify route and technology choices, climate impact, costs, and progress - so that the project can move forward with the goal of realizing the Northern Norway Railway.
