Promote proposals that ensure that all new shopping centers and department stores can only be established in areas that are already developed, not in untouched nature or agricultural land.
Establish systems for quality assurance of mapping companies and require independent mapping of biodiversity for larger development projects and land use changes.

Ensure that by 2025, national conservation plans are developed that particularly protect areas that are currently not sufficiently protected and have good representation, including cultural landscapes, forests, wetlands, and coastal areas.
Investigate and come back with proposals for a zero vision for the loss of nature.
Investigate a building ban on wetlands.
Establish systems for quality assurance of companies conducting environmental mapping in connection with development projects.

Ensure that the priorities within nature management are tightened by obtaining expert advice to a greater extent than before, and by developing a comprehensive plan with concrete proposals for prioritized species and selected natural types, based on explicit criteria for prioritizing species and selecting natural types, before further use of these measures in the Biodiversity Act.

Introduce a requirement that a consistent and clear distinction is made between knowledge producers and users of this knowledge, and that all publicly funded mapping of biodiversity is carried out according to general standards for value neutrality and quality.
Strengthen the efforts to map all nature in Norway, so that the valuable nature can be protected.
Come up with proposals that better protect cultivated land and important natural areas in connection with new developments.
Review the conservation plans and provide suggestions that quickly ensure the protection of natural areas that currently do not have adequate protection.
Introduce driver's license class B1 with a minimum age of 16 years during 2021. It is based on similar training requirements as for driver's license class A1 for light motorcycles.
Investigate the introduction of driver's license class B1 with a minimum age of 16 years.
Promote a proposal to abolish the point penalty system in traffic effective from July 1, 2021.
Ensure that the combination of driver's license class T and driver's license class B grants the right to a driver's license class BE.
To implement the Parliament's decision to abolish the requirement for a health certificate for older drivers, effective no later than August 1, 2021.
To repeal the provision in the regulation on admission to higher education regarding additional points based on gender.

Address the working conditions of employees in the new long-term plan for research and higher education, and return to the Parliament with a concrete plan on how authorities and institutions can collectively reduce the proportion of temporary employees at universities and colleges.
Conduct an investigation into the working conditions and career development of researchers across the entire research sector.

Return to the Parliament with an assessment of the need for, and possibly proposals for tightening, the access to fixed-term appointments in teaching and research positions when creative or performing artistic competence is a significant element of the competence requirement.

Come back to the Parliament with a clarification of the Universities and University Colleges Act § 3-8 second paragraph regarding the use of digital lectures and what should be understood as public lectures.
Come back with a proposal for legislating the right to receive exam questions in the Norwegian written language that students prefer.

Ensure that the new Education Act and Kindergarten Act are in line with the fundamental rights of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child regarding the procedures for children's right to information, to express themselves freely, children's right to privacy, and that all actions and decisions concerning children are made in the best interest of the child.
Come back with suggestions for distance learning in the legislative proposal for the new education law.

Promote a case for a more democratic hospital structure where hospitals are owned by the state, and regional health boards are established with political representation from the regional county councils and a minority of hospital-appointed healthcare professionals, elected union representatives, and elected representatives from patient organizations.

Present a parliamentary report on values for the Norwegian healthcare service, to ensure a professionally and value-driven healthcare service that guarantees the healthcare system's preparedness responsibilities and equal healthcare services for all regardless of background, as well as a healthcare service that is not governed by business economic principles.
Promote the case for introducing a people's democracy in specialist healthcare services, where hospitals are managed according to an administrative model.
Promote a national strategy to reduce social health disparities.
Ensure that healthcare professions are strengthened in hospitals, and that healthcare bureaucracy is reduced along with control and management levels, which are replaced by local leadership.
Ensure that food supply, cleaning, and IT functions are part of the core activities of hospitals and not outsourced, in order to avoid compromised quality, hygiene, and safety.

Propose changes to the Alcohol Act so that individuals over the age of 16 can work at the checkout in grocery stores and handle the entire range of products sold in the stores, including low-alcohol and alcoholic beverages from groups 1 and 2.

Propose amendments to the Tobacco Damage Act to allow individuals over the age of 16 to work at the checkout in grocery stores and handle the entire range of products sold in the stores, including tobacco products.
Ensure that coordinating services for fracture prevention (FLS) are established in all health enterprises, and that such services are guaranteed funding.
Develop an action plan for fall prevention and fracture prevention in osteoporosis.

Follow up on request resolution 670 (2020–2021) with a temporary arrangement for 2021 and 2022 that ensures guarantee provisions in the Travel Guarantee Fund for all package tour operators operating in Norway, regardless of size.
Expand the state guarantee scheme presented in Prop. 107 S (2020–2021) to include all package tour operators, regardless of size, revenue, and number of employees in the business.

Expand the state guarantee scheme outlined in Prop. 107 S (2020–2021) to include all package tour operators operating in Norway and establish a tiered model where the state assumes 75% of the guarantee responsibility for SMEs and 50% of the guarantee responsibility for large package tour operators.
Evaluate the effect of the risk relief scheme for guarantees to the Travel Guarantee Fund and the situation for businesses during September 2021.
Present a plan to encourage more entrepreneurial activity among youth under 18 years old.
Ensure that more students in upper secondary education have the opportunity to participate in programs through Young Entrepreneurship.

Consider quickly initiating a Tourism 21 process that can enhance knowledge about the tourism industry, identify the need for measures, and how to ensure better sustainability and more full-time permanent positions.
Present a plan to strengthen Norwegian tourism after the coronavirus pandemic and ensure Norwegian ownership of tourism businesses in Norway.
Present an adjusted compensation scheme for the taxi industry, where companies that own their own vehicles are treated equally to companies that lease/rent vehicles.
Present an adjusted compensation scheme for the Norwegian coach bus industry, where companies that own their own vehicles are treated equally to companies that lease/rent vehicles.
Present an adjusted compensation scheme for the car rental industry, where companies that own their own vehicles are treated equally to companies that lease/rent vehicles.
Work systematically towards a long-term goal of halving Norwegian meat consumption.
Promote a proposal to remove the value-added tax on plant-based meat alternatives.
Investigate and propose measures and initiatives in agriculture, the food industry, the restaurant sector, and grocery stores to promote vegan and vegetarian food based on Norwegian raw materials.

Propose to increase the value-added tax on meat from 15 percent to 20 percent, with the exception of organic meat and meat production where the share of concentrated feed does not exceed 10 percent of the feed measured in energy.
Promote a proposal to ban price promotions on meat that involve selling meat at a loss. Food that is close to its expiration date is exempt from the ban.
Introduce a requirement that public cafeterias must serve only vegetarian food at least one day a week, and always have a complete vegetarian option available.
Introduce a requirement that kindergartens with food service must always offer a complete vegetarian option.
Work systematically to reduce Norwegian meat consumption.

Replace today's information offices with a consolidated information office that promotes sustainable and health-conscious food and diet, in line with goals for self-sufficiency, nature, and climate. The industry and professionals should be represented.
Promote proposals to strengthen tariff protection on meat and negotiate the lowest possible import quotas for meat in trade agreements.
Work to increase the self-sufficiency rate, adjusted for feed imports, for Norwegian agricultural food products to 50% by the end of 2026.
Promote a proposal to reintroduce the scheme of free school fruit in primary schools. The scheme should favor Norwegian-produced and locally-produced fruits and vegetables.
Present a proposal for a food waste law.
Return to the Storting with a proposal for a ban on the degradation of wetlands.

Tighten Norway's climate goals to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from Norwegian territory by 80% by 2030 compared to 1990 levels, and present a binding plan effective from January 1, 2022, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in line with this.
Implement a gradual, predictable, and planned phase-out of petroleum activities by 2035.
Following the IEA's new report, halt the 25th licensing round and TFO 2021.
Abolish the exploration refund scheme for oil companies.
To stop all exploration activities on the continental shelf, including canceling the 25th licensing round.
To halt all allocations of new exploration licenses on the Norwegian continental shelf.
Abolish the search refund scheme from January 1, 2022.
Tighten Norway's climate goals to a 70% reduction in emissions compared to 1990 levels and return to the Parliament with a plan to achieve this goal as soon as possible.

Present a proposal to strengthen the climate law by including requirements for national climate budgets and associated action plans, and make this part of the state budget from 2022. The proposal should also expand the climate law so that municipalities and county municipalities are required to operate according to climate plans and climate budgets at least in accordance with the Paris Agreement.

Establish an oil commission where authorities, labor organizations, research and knowledge institutions, and businesses collaborate on a plan to maintain employment and create new jobs while phasing out oil activities.
Work through the Arctic Council for an international oil moratorium in the Arctic.

Present a plan for how an increased CO2 tax can avoid being socially and geographically unfair, and not generate increased revenue for the state, but instead be used for measures that ensure repayment or compensation.

Present a proposal that ensures that the revenues from the increased CO2 tax are paid out again to all residents with medium, low, or no income, with an additional amount per child and geographical differentiation. The repayment should be monthly and tax-free, similar to child benefits, and the geographical differentiation could, for example, be based on the existing map for zone division for differentiated employer contributions.

Propose a division of the electricity price, either in the form of a two-part grid fee or electricity tax, or in another way that distinguishes between regular consumption and unnecessary luxury consumption.

Present a proposal that allows for a portion of the Government Pension Fund Global (SPU) to be used as a national green industrial fund that makes strategic investments in domestic industrial production, with the aim of ensuring technological development, increased export of goods, more industrial jobs, increased value creation, and more processing in Norway.

Present a proposal that allows for a portion of the Government Pension Fund Global (SPU) to be used as a green infrastructure fund that invests in the development of climate-friendly infrastructure such as railways, public transport, charging networks, ports, and broadband across Norway.

Develop sector-specific action plans for emission reductions, including an assessment of the measures that need to be implemented to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 70% by 2030, and how the emission cuts can be achieved in an economically and geographically equitable manner.
Assume that the revenues from the increased CO2 tax should not be used to reduce taxes on wealth, corporate profits, and high incomes.

Strengthen the municipalities' ability to establish and determine the size of their own zones reserved for public transport, pedestrians, people with reduced mobility, cyclists, and freight transport, thereby reducing environmental impact, regardless of whether the roads are municipal, county, or state-owned. The zones should be established in close dialogue with businesses and residents, as well as the Norwegian Public Roads Administration and county municipalities in cases where state and county road networks are affected.

Present a proposal for a ban on passenger transport using fossil-fueled private jets. The ban should include both chartered and privately owned aircraft, but for the time being, make exceptions for all use concerning life, health, and safety, as well as for the use of small aircraft in hobby/sport contexts.

Establish a commission to examine the climate emissions associated with unnecessary luxury consumption such as private jets, first-class travel, large vacation homes, and excessive energy use, and to provide targeted proposals that reduce greenhouse gas emissions from these activities.

Transfer cod, haddock, and pollock quotas from the trawler fleet to the coastal fleet to ensure reduced climate emissions from fisheries, create more jobs in the Norwegian fishing industry, and facilitate increased processing of raw materials here at home.

Facilitate the ability of the civil service to calculate the climate impact of proposals put forward by the party groups in the Storting, in the same way that the Ministry of Finance currently responds to budget inquiries and provides economic calculations for alternative budgets, and ensure that comprehensive calculations of the distribution effects of the parties' climate policies are offered.
Reduce the import of foreign meat and dairy products by decreasing the use of reduced tariffs, renegotiating international trade agreements, and strengthening tariff protection in other ways.

Investigate the distribution effect and the impact on energy consumption of a two-tier pricing system for electricity, alternatively an increased electricity tax combined with a fixed sum reimbursement per household.

Promote a proposal to secure government co-financing through the budget of the Ministry of Climate and Environment for the work carried out by the non-profit organization Maridalens Venner in Oslo to implement the government-approved management plan for the Maridalen Landscape Protection Area.
Use its ownership in Kongsberg Group to take the initiative for the acquisition of Bergen Engines or in other ways secure jobs and national security through national ownership of Bergen Engines.

Conduct and present to the Storting in an appropriate manner: a mapping of security competence in all ministries, a review carried out by a publicly appointed expert committee of the application of the Security Act, including possible vulnerabilities, distribution of responsibilities, the status of the ministries' listing of entities that are to be fully or partially covered by the Security Act, and an evaluation of how security understanding is established in the ministries and how cooperation between the ministries is ensured.
Present a parliamentary report on how Norway can ensure national ownership and control over strategically important companies, natural resources, infrastructures, and technologies.

To relocate Oslo prison from Grønland, and that the use of the area where the prison is currently located benefits the residents of the neighborhood, in addition to the new prison at Bredtvet being dismissed as an alternative.

Ensure that Statsbygg quickly conducts a new study on the placement of a new prison to ensure good conditions for the inmates. The construction of the new prison should not come at the expense of forests and wildlife, or destroy important natural areas for the local population.
To expedite the work of finding other suitable land alternatives to Bredtvet for Oslo prison within the necessary proximity requirements.
Upgrade the existing Oslo prison and Bredtveit women's prison while awaiting a new prison.
Put the preliminary plans for a new Oslo prison at Bredtvet on hold.
Consider alternative locations for a new prison in Groruddalen that preserves green spaces while ensuring state jobs in the area.
Return to the Storting with proposals regarding the new Oslo prison.

Propose amendments to the law that ensure that the use of incendiary devices and similar very serious actions directed against the police and courts are subject to the same strict penalties as acts of terrorism.

Present a case that assesses whether the current labor protection legislation adequately safeguards employees who perform work in private homes, and propose measures that can lower the threshold for registering such employment relationships.
Promote a proposal to introduce a national minimum wage, which will ensure that every worker receives a decent level of pay.
Provide an account of the status of the establishment of the European Labour Agency (ELA), and assess to what extent the regulation will impact ELA's planned scope of activities.
Present the finally adopted regulation on ESF+/EaSI (the EU program for employment and social innovation) to the Parliament for consideration.

Halt the process of further power transfer to ACER, initiate the reversal of the power transfer to the EU's financial supervision, and do not transfer power to the EU over asylum and immigration policy in Norway.
Ensure that Norway does not participate in the EU's asylum pact, "New Pact on Migration and Asylum."

Actively work to dismantle the current failed asylum system, including initiating the following: a. Stop the possibility of obtaining residency by applying for asylum at the borders of European countries. b. Establish asylum centers outside of Europe where all asylum seekers who arrive will be sent while their applications are processed. It should not be possible to apply for asylum directly at these centers. c. Use aid funds to negotiate agreements with safe third countries to establish asylum centers. d. Use aid funds to set up care centers for unaccompanied minor asylum seekers. e. Ensure that asylum seekers who are granted refugee status are provided protection in a safe country that Norway has an agreement with.
Seek collaboration with Denmark to enter into a memorandum of understanding with Rwanda or other countries to establish asylum centers in third countries.
Present a bill proposing that children born abroad to a Norwegian mother or father must have a stable connection to and contact with the biological parent who holds Norwegian citizenship.

Present a bill that requires self-sufficiency for the last five years in order to be granted Norwegian citizenship. This means that the applicant must be self-sufficient in the sense of having an income above a certain level (above the low-income threshold) or being in education.
Present a bill that requires citizenship to be denied if the applicant has received social assistance in the last five years.

Present a bill that requires applicants for citizenship to have contributed to the integration of their spouse, partner, and children into Norwegian society. Self-segregation should be actively prevented.
Ensure that the costs of required archaeological excavations on private property are covered by the state.
Come back to the Storting with a comprehensive mapping of the protective provisions in Norway.

Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner with a mapping of Norway's many protective regulations and with proposals for a critical review of which protective regulations should be able to prevent construction, and which authority should have control over which regulations.

Come back to the Parliament with a concrete proposal regarding which public authority should pay for the required archaeological excavations on private property, as well as an assessment of which private properties are affected by such cultural heritage sites.
Take the initiative for a legislative change so that municipalities and county municipalities are not allowed to exercise local foreign policy.
Promote demands for full transparency regarding the content of negotiations and contracts for all vaccine agreements that Norway is a part of.

Facilitate a process that can lead to an international agreement on a patent exemption that is broad enough to enable a rapid and effective increase in production. In this context, the Storting requests that the government communicate that Norwegian authorities are supportive of a broad patent exemption for vaccines, medicines, and other technology to combat the pandemic in low- and middle-income countries.

Establish a committee of Norwegian and international experts to investigate how a publicly funded international research and development collaboration for vaccines and other medicines could be structured, based on principles of open information sharing and decentralized production that can make all countries in the world more self-sufficient and less dependent on the pharmaceutical industry.

Take the initiative to develop a publicly funded and operated international research and development institute for antibiotics and drugs against antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which can in turn serve as a model for a new global regime for the development of other types of medications.
Ensure that all Norwegian contributions to research and development of pharmaceuticals in the future are based on principles of knowledge sharing and open source.
Take the initiative to strengthen the WHO as the coordinating body in the fight against COVID-19, and to implement a common quality control for new COVID-19 vaccines under the WHO.
Take the initiative to ensure that all vaccine technology Norway has contributed to funding is made available in the WHO Covid-19 Technology Access Pool (C-TAP).

Take the initiative in the WTO/TRIPS to evaluate the regulations for patent exceptions, so that in the future it functions better in line with the intention of quickly increasing local and regional self-sufficiency with necessary medicines in future emergencies.
Promote demands in contexts where Norway has contributed to research and development of vaccines, for full transparency regarding clinical results.
Ensure that Norway invites to a follow-up conference on the FACTI panel's report.
Renegotiate the tax agreements that have been criticized for being harmful.
Increase support for tripartite cooperation through development cooperation, including increasing support for the ILO's work for decent work.

Come back to the Storting in connection with the state budget for 2022 with a parliamentary report on Norwegian climate financing towards 2030. The report will examine how Norway can increase its contributions to international climate financing in line with the country's rightful responsibilities.
Hold an advisory referendum on whether Norway should join the EU's fourth railway package. Prop. 101 LS (2019-2020) is sent back to the government pending the results of the referendum.

Promote a new case for the Storting, where the Supreme Court's statements in the opinion dated March 26, 2021, regarding the extent of the transfer of authority upon the incorporation of Directive 2012/34/EU on a single European railway area and the legal acts that constitute the fourth railway package, are further assessed.
Ensure that the entire country's population has access to fast broadband, with a minimum of 100 Mbit/s symmetrical broadband capacity, by 2025.

Return to the Storting with a report on improved measures that ensure effective competition where there is no basis for competition at the infrastructure level, prevent consumer lock-in, and ensure neutrality and media diversity in broadband networks.
Investigate a right to high-speed internet for all households in Norway.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that prioritizes households that currently lack all forms of basic internet, in order to ensure a swift implementation of this right.
Increase the grant schemes for the expansion of high-speed internet to achieve the goal of 100% coverage by 2025.

Ensure that the entire country has access to high-speed internet with at least 100 megabits per second through a combination of fiber and mobile technologies that together can ensure complete internet coverage.

Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how to appropriately achieve the goal of 100% internet coverage across Norway by 2025, with at least 100 megabits per second, through a combination of fiber and mobile technology.
Introduce requirements for full mobile and internet coverage in all new national road projects.

Develop a plan for the expansion of mobile and internet coverage along existing national roads, specifying coverage gaps and the costs for addressing these, and incorporate this into the revised national budget for 2022.
Ensure that no one loses their landline before they have mobile coverage or other telephone solutions with at least the same level of coverage as a landline.
Ensure the development of a good and stable mobile network so that it is available to the entire population of the country, regardless of where they live.
Develop a plan for the expansion of mobile networks along all major transportation routes both on land and at sea.
Propose to introduce a public obligation to provide fast broadband, with a minimum of 100 Mbit/s, in areas where there is no basis for commercial development.
Abolish the regulation on a ten percent absence limit in individual subjects in upper secondary education, and in dialogue with the sector, develop a new regulation for absence.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how the implementation of assessment for learning in upper secondary education can be strengthened.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how to connect the systematic work on assessment for learning to the work on curricula, especially in planning for learning.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how the quality of the assessment-related language in upper secondary education can be developed.

Come back to the Parliament with a plan to strengthen assessment competence and understanding of assessment for learning among other actors outside of schools/apprenticeships that can support the work of upper secondary schools.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how to ensure good framework conditions for student representatives to have opportunities for participation and influence in upper secondary education.

Not to introduce the future subject as a new common subject, but to return with proposals for a new distribution of subjects and hours where the current common subjects are continued with a scope that preserves the educational function of the subjects, the intrinsic value of the subjects, and without stipulating a priority for only the subjects of mathematics, Norwegian, and English.

Divide the school year into terms with instruction in a smaller number of subjects in each term, and that subjects which currently extend over more than one year are divided into smaller units with final assessments, so that the need for increased academic concentration and deep understanding is met.
Vocational education and preparatory studies are assigned their own chapters in the upcoming education law.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how to strengthen the connection between and the quality of ongoing assessments and final assessments in upper secondary education.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a review of how the structures in upper secondary education, including assessment systems and the systems for calculating points and diplomas, can be adjusted to better promote learning and good mental health for students.
Come back with a report on how the current examination system can be supplemented with alternative assessment methods, such as portfolio assessment.

Increase the housing allowance for students living away from home and adjust the educational support so that students living away from home do not face a cost disadvantage compared to students living at home.
Increase the apprenticeship grant and structure it in a way that encourages companies to offer apprenticeship contracts to students in Vg1 in the form of alternating models.

Give upper secondary students who need it the right to introductory subjects. Language training in Norwegian should be integrated into this offer, and the training should be incorporated into the student's Vg1 program.
Specify further improvements for Vg3 in schools that provide students with a final competence that meets the demands of the labor market and is trusted by industry and the workforce.
Facilitate the establishment of more production schools.

Promote proposals for amendments to the Police Act and the Police Regulations to clarify that a stricter human rights protection applies to the use of coercion against children than against adults, including, but not limited to, the introduction of qualified proportionality and necessity requirements when using coercion against minors.
Make an exception from general arming when the police assist child welfare services.
Investigate and propose the establishment of an independent complaint body for children under the care of child welfare services who are subjected to coercion by the police.
Find a solution for how to create an overview of the police's assistance to child welfare services.

Develop a child welfare guide for the police's assistance to child protective services. The guide should be created in collaboration with employee organizations, child protective services, and representatives from the children themselves.

Consider a change to the Police Act and the Police Regulations to clarify that a stricter human rights protection applies when using coercion against children compared to adults, including, but not limited to, the introduction of qualified proportionality and necessity requirements when using coercion against minors.
Come back to the Parliament with a case that further clarifies the complaint procedures where the police assist child welfare services.
Ensure a national practice for logging and statistics on the use of coercion during police operations in child welfare cases, which can be made publicly available.
Introduce stricter regulations on which coercive measures and what combination of coercive measures can be used towards children under the care of child welfare services.
Introduce a ban on the use of spit hoods on children.
Present a proposal for the abolition of leasehold for residential and vacation properties.
Promote a proposal to prohibit the establishment of new lease agreements under the Ground Lease Act for residential and vacation properties.
Propose amendments to the law that grant the police the authority to establish time-limited and geographically restricted search zones in areas particularly vulnerable to crime.
Establish procedures to ensure that thorough proportionality assessments are conducted for all measures taken during crises when those measures interfere with human rights.
Establish procedures so that the consultation institute is used as far as practically possible, even when there is urgency.
Establish procedures to ensure that special attention is given to vulnerable groups and their needs in all crisis management.
Work to appoint specific representatives for the child who can ensure the child's right to be heard in child welfare cases before the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR).
Promote a proposal to amend the Penal Execution Act to state that inmates, as a general rule, have the right to spend at least eight hours in communal activities outside their cells.

Investigate the establishment of an independent climate commission, with a legally mandated role to provide advice on emission reductions and to monitor compliance with human rights climate obligations.
Develop and implement a comprehensive plan to ensure oversight and coordinated follow-up from the individual ministries regarding the recommendations from international monitoring bodies to Norway.

Present a plan to the Parliament for a permanent solution for small aircraft activity in the Oslo area. Until such a plan is available and implemented, the government must facilitate the continuation of current small aircraft activity at Kjeller Airport.
Present a case to the Storting with a plan for how the state can contribute to preserving the national cultural historical values at Kjeller.
Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner with a cost overview of all international contributions, participations, projects, and initiatives that Norway is or has been involved in.
Ensure that the rights perspective is applied in the child coordinator scheme.

Investigate and propose a right for children to an individual plan in the Kindergarten Act and the Education Act, with a corresponding obligation for the education sector to develop an individual plan.
Ensure that the rights establishment of the child coordinator and the coordinator scheme for patients with needs for complex and coordinated services is fully funded before implementation.
Investigate and promote a case for the Parliament with proposals for necessary legal amendments to ensure that children in need are granted the right to comprehensive and coordinated services.

Investigate and promote a case to the Parliament to ensure that youth and young adults with disabilities and chronic illnesses can live free and independent lives. The measures should cover all areas of society, including education and higher education, youth health, the labor market, and interactions with support services. User organizations should be closely involved in the work.
Develop models that ensure a seamless transition from high school to VTA (permanently adapted work) for young people who need it.
Ensure that the processing time for cases at the county governor in complaints related to the health, social, and care sectors is reduced. The Parliament will be informed in an appropriate manner.

Ensure that shrimp industry companies that have been granted the right to own vessels with shrimp trawl permits may, upon application, be granted cod trawl rights equivalent to 1.5 quota units of cod/haddock per granted shrimp trawl permit. The quotas are regulated within the cod trawl group. This should serve as a supplementary contribution to ensure that the companies have a basis for activating the allocated shrimp rights and thereby secure a raw material basis for the future operation and development of a vibrant and forward-looking shrimp industry in Norway.

Design specific concession conditions that ensure that cod concessions are non-transferable, that whitefish raw materials from trawlers are subject to processing obligations in Norway, and that the concessions are initially granted for a limited time of 15 years, with the right to extension under certain conditions.

Investigate and propose measures aimed at increasing efforts in harvesting sustainable and underutilized fishery resources in Norway's areas of interest. The shrimp stock in the Barents Sea and around Svalbard is one such resource.
Investigate an activity requirement for vessels with shrimp trawling permits.
Investigate how the tax system can be used to encourage vessels with shrimp trawling permits to find it profitable to harvest shrimp and other less profitable species.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to abolish the cod trawling licenses with bidding and processing obligations, and to redistribute the associated cod and haddock quotas to the coastal fleet. The new quotas should be non-transferable and tied to a county or region. The redistribution of quotas should take a maximum of 15–30 years, in line with the obligation commission's determination that this is the duration of the current trawling licenses.

Come back with a proposal for a new quota message with a changed distribution of the resource base, where the traditional coastal fleet and open group are significantly strengthened, and with measures that provide women and youth with significantly better opportunities to establish themselves as independent fishermen.

To ensure that the obligated trawlers actually deliver fish to the designated fishing communities in accordance with the intention of the obligation system. The alternative will be, if this does not happen within two years, that quotas are returned from these companies to the coastal fleet.
Investigate and propose a scheme for quota deductions of up to 20 percent from quota-regulated catches that are exported unprocessed to foreign processing industries.

Set conditions that the catch subject to the offer must be delivered fresh or frozen to the entitled buyer at fixed minimum prices adjusted for the average first-hand prices of corresponding fresh landings in the same region.
Ensure that the intentions of the Marine Resources Act and the Participant Act regarding regional policy are implemented in practice, and promote necessary proposals to ensure this.

Present a new and updated quota message, which will contribute to building local communities along the entire coast, ensure a fair distribution of resources, and secure future-oriented jobs. The message will be developed in close dialogue with the industry.
Set a goal of reducing the business sector's administrative costs related to imposed regulations and bureaucratic burdens from the government by 11 billion Norwegian kroner by 2025.

Establish a pilot program for Industry 4.0. The program should ensure a simplified and holistic approach to new and existing measures, increase the capacity for investment in new technology, and strengthen the skills in the industry, with a focus on lifelong learning.

Use state ownership in industrial companies like Equinor to ensure that quality, environmental considerations, and the protection of Norwegian jobs carry more weight in procurement policies, so that these companies contribute more to securing activity and jobs at Norwegian shipyards and other supplier industries.
Secure guidelines and other measures that the county municipalities can implement to ensure increased activity and employment in Norway during the transition to zero-emission fast ferries.
Secure guidelines and other measures that the county municipalities can implement to ensure increased activity and employment in Norway during the transition to zero-emission ferries.
Ensure that the allocated crisis package funds are used in accordance with the Parliament's assumption that it will lead to increased activity and employment in Norway.
Develop guidelines for use in future allocations of support schemes, subsidies, crisis packages, and similar, ensuring that the allocations lead to increased activity and employment in Norway.
Investigate and propose changes to the Public Procurement Act, so that public purchases generally lead to increased activity and employment in Norway.

Establish an independent and broadly composed panel with relevant professional expertise to examine the consequences of the increased use of punishment and other coercive measures against drug-dependent individuals and other drug users from 1984 to the present day.

Ensure that minors who are required to attend a mandatory meeting with the municipal counseling unit for drug cases are mandated to have two meetings. The first meeting should be with the minor and the unit. The second meeting should involve the parents or others with parental responsibility, the minor, and the unit. Parents or others with parental responsibility should not be involved until the child has met with the unit and expressed whether it is safe for the child.

Carry this out without imposing a fee for failure to attend at the same time. The municipal advisory unit for drug cases shall work proactively in cases of non-compliance with the attendance requirement.

Come back to the Parliament with a bill that protects drug users from prosecution and legal action for the use and possession of illegal drugs when they contact the authorities for help for themselves or others.
Establish an independent police commission to examine the use of coercive measures in drug cases.
Consider expanding the scheme for removing annotations in the reaction register after a certain number of years to also apply to young people over 18 years old.
Ensure that today's practice, where almost no one serves an unconditional prison sentence for use and minor possession of drugs, is continued.
Ensure that individuals with substance abuse issues who accumulate fines are given the option of serving their fines through community service, fine payment, or treatment.

Ensure that the blocking of reactions for the use and possession of drugs for personal use after three years, provided that no further criminal offenses have been recorded during the relevant period, is given retroactive effect.

Investigate and propose necessary changes to the legislation that ensure decriminalization for the use and possession of small amounts for heavy drug users, so that this group is met with proper health care and support instead of punitive measures.
Evaluate the use and effect of arrangements with drug contracts and other types of binding agreements for youth.
Ensure that healthcare professionals' duty to inform regarding patients' substance use must be based on a concrete assessment, not on whether the substance is legal or not.

Propose legislative changes that ensure that imprisonment is no longer a punitive response for violations of the provisions of the Medicines Act regarding the use and possession of drugs for personal use. Additionally, suggest mitigating measures for the consequences of these changes in the law.

Ensure that the police do not prosecute violations of the Medicines Act § 24, first paragraph, where the offender provides assistance or calls emergency services in acute emergency situations, or where such a violation is discovered in the victim when reporting other criminal offenses.

Ensure that information in the reaction register about individuals who have been subjected to criminal sanctions for the use and possession of drugs for personal use is blocked after three years. Blocking is contingent upon no further criminal offenses being recorded during the relevant period.

Ensure that society's reactions to problematic substance use are proportionate and can be linked to the substance use. The Parliament requests the government to particularly review the practice of revoking driving licenses in cases where there is no apparent connection between the person's substance use and the operation of a motor vehicle.
Facilitate that substance users can test the purity and content of the substances, and ensure that the purchase and use of devices that enable such testing do not lead to reporting to the police.
Come back with a proposal for a pilot scheme for a publicly funded service for anonymous drug testing.
Investigate a scheme for a "social exemption card," where individuals with substance use disorders are exempt from paying co-payments in the healthcare system.
Ensure a review of the LAR scheme, including considerations for preventing overdose deaths related to LAR medication.

Ensure that each municipality has measurable measures and services related to interdisciplinary substance abuse treatment teams, mobile services, activity and housing offers, as well as low-threshold drop-in places.
Ensure that all municipalities commit to summoning youth who are caught using or possessing drugs for a conversation and follow-up within 72 hours.

Ensure that municipalities are required to have an interdisciplinary program for youth who are caught using or possessing drugs, for example based on the model from the TIUR project in Ringsaker, 'Similar Practice' through the Conflict Council in Trøndelag, or other similar offerings.
Strengthen the pharmacological rehabilitation services.
Ensure systematic prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of hepatitis C with the goal of eradicating the disease.

Return to the Parliament with a report on whether it would be beneficial for general practitioners and/or specialist healthcare services to have access to prescribe more medications for individuals with substance dependence in order to ensure better support on the path to sobriety and a better life.
Consider expanding the use of Naltrexone.
Ensure that child and adolescent psychiatry (BUP) acquires expertise in substance abuse.
Suggest measures that ensure that after detoxification, it normally does not take more than 24 hours before the patient is offered further outpatient or other treatment.

Come back to the Parliament with an aftercare reform where individuals with substance dependence are systematically followed up after treatment and prison stays, including ensuring housing conditions and support that prevent them from relapsing into substance abuse environments.
Consider expanding the use of Naloxone nasal spray to a national program for treating overdoses.

Ensure that individuals in active substance use also have access to a crisis center service with staff who have interdisciplinary expertise in substance use and violence, either in connection with existing crisis centers or as an independent service.
Transfer the responsibility for the Planning and Building Act from the Ministry of Local Government and Modernisation to the Ministry of Climate and Environment.

Ensure a reinforcement of the municipalities' planning and nature knowledge, as well as the municipalities' capacity to better ensure nature conservation, climate adaptation, agricultural land protection, and outdoor recreation.
Abolish the arrangement where the deputy county governor processes appeals regarding exemptions under the Planning and Building Act on behalf of the ministry.

Consider how complaint cases related to exemptions under the Planning and Building Act can be better managed, in terms of resources and time, in cases where the state administrator is itself the complainant or otherwise a party to the case.

Consider how to best ensure a correct and solid knowledge base to gain an overview of the types of cases in which Norwegian municipalities utilize the exemption provisions in the Planning and Building Act.

Engage in dialogue with the fur farming industry to ensure a mutual understanding of the further basis presented through NIBIO's proposal for calculating compensation based on use value. The lifespan of the facilities, calculation of labor time for the various fur productions, prices of pelts and feed, and the size of the capitalization rate are among the elements that are particularly important to reach a mutual understanding of.

Base the capacity of the fur farming operation on the regulations regarding the keeping of fur animals, applicable from January 1, 2015 (FOR-2011-03-17-296), when calculating utility value and economic loss.

Promote a proposal to establish a scheme that provides grants for the cleanup and remediation of fur farms and feed kitchens, so that the residual value of these facilities can be increased and the facilities can be reused.

Promote a proposal to establish a compensation scheme for machinery and equipment that is specialized for the operation of feed kitchens and fur farms, and which has no residual value as a result of the ban on fur farming.

Amend the regulation on compensation after the phasing out of fur farming, etc., so that in § 7, the first sentence states that for the demolition and cleanup of fur farming operations that were in operation in approved facilities according to the regulation on fur farming as of January 1, 2015, compensation will be provided to cover the actual costs, without the current requirement that resale and recycling must be taken into account.

Present a parliamentary report on a long-term plan to strengthen the most important municipal and state services and offerings for children and youth, including but not limited to education, child welfare, volunteerism, mental health for children and youth, leisure activities, and measures against violence and abuse.
Develop a four-year escalation plan with earmarked funds to increase staffing in the municipal child welfare services, and present this in the proposal for the state budget for 2022.
Introduce a guideline staffing norm where caseworkers with administrative functions (function 244) in the municipal child welfare services cannot be responsible for more than 15 children.
"Ensure that the public sector provides the basic capacity in child welfare services for all target groups."
Promote proposals to amend the Child Welfare Act to ensure that public funding does not go to profit for commercial child welfare actors.
Ensure that actors receiving public funding for the operation of child welfare measures have salary, working, and pension conditions in line with those applicable in public measures.
Introduce an even stricter interpretation of what constitutes public authority exercise, in order to limit the hiring of private consultants in child welfare services.

Promote proposals for changes to the regulations on working hours in institutions with live-in arrangements, so that they are adapted to the non-profit drug and child welfare collectives that the regulations were originally intended for, as well as establish a joint committee with representation from both parties, including children as a user group, to investigate any other changes to the live-in regulations.

Conduct an investigation aimed at clarifying the definition of the term "artificial light" in the Wildlife Act, and what principles should be established for a new provision regarding this in the Wildlife Act, in connection with the ongoing work on the modernization of the Wildlife Act.

Propose the establishment of a state-owned mining company that can conduct exploration and extraction of minerals, ensuring local jobs and value creation with a requirement for high environmental standards.
Suggest measures to increase the pace of mapping mineral resources in Norway.
Send the proposal for the introduction of order requirements to the mineral law committee for a comprehensive assessment.
Develop a Norwegian mineral strategy, where the Norwegian mineral industry is viewed in connection with the EU's efforts to secure access to critical minerals and metals.
Propose a grant of 75 million kroner for an 'artificial intelligence' fund.
Consider measures, including the use of government capital, to ensure increased access to capital for startups.

Establish an expert committee to ensure democratic control over the digitalization of society and that Norwegian data contributes to value creation in Norway. The committee shall, among other things: Analyze how the interests and control of the community are affected as new sectors of society are increasingly digitalized, with particular attention to sectors such as education, energy, health, and transport. Propose measures and strategies to prevent the formation of monopolies and concentration of power, and ensure that value creation is distributed fairly in a fully digitalized society, including assessing when the state should consider taking ownership of infrastructure, platforms, and platform development, standard development, etc. Models for profit distribution should be discussed with and without an effective tax policy for international technology companies. National measures must be proposed where international success is deemed unlikely. Promote proposals on which sectors and in which contexts the public sector should require data sharing and data ownership from the private sector to the public sector, for example in concessions, tenders, grants, etc., with the aim of safeguarding important societal concerns. Propose measures where the state facilitates that data produced in Norway is increasingly processed further in Norway, and clarify what scope the state has under the EEA agreement to impose such requirements.

Present a proposal that ensures transparency regarding algorithms that form the basis for decisions that have significant implications for individuals or society. The proposal should consider the need for and who should potentially certify and oversee such algorithms.

Investigate what role the labor movement should and can play to safeguard the interests of ordinary people in the digital economy, particularly regarding the management of personal data, the distribution of value creation from this data, and individuals' interests in relation to the large technology platforms.
Establish a pilot project for unified access to personal data that the public sector has stored about individuals, for example in the field of health.
Review how the public sector shares usage data from public websites with large technology companies and other third parties, and propose regulations for when such sharing should be permitted.
Investigate the establishment of a government cloud solution for storing public data such as health data, financial data, and detailed data points about residents and infrastructure.

Take an active role in international cooperation to ensure regulations for effective taxation of international technology companies and measures to counteract the concentration of power, and implement national measures in case of insufficient progress in this work.
Establish a safe and verifiable temporary solution that ensures that protected individuals do not need to stay at a quarantine hotel.
Return to the Parliament in future conservation processes as a result of Meld. St 29 (2020-2021).

Present a comprehensive overview of planned protection of areas on land and at sea/ocean leading up to 2030, and put forward additional conservation proposals on hold until the comprehensive overview has been addressed by the Parliament.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to expand the scope of the Nature Diversity Act so that it applies to all Norwegian marine areas, including the entire Norwegian economic zone.
Assuming that the Nature Diversity Act is the law that should be used to ensure a comprehensive protection of natural values in Norwegian marine areas.

Ensure that no new activities are initiated in areas defined as particularly valuable and vulnerable areas (SVO) in the management plans before these have been assessed against the marine conservation plan.

Ensure that mineral extraction on the seabed is not allowed until the natural values in the relevant marine areas have been mapped and a network of protected areas has been established, in accordance with recommendations from the Institute of Marine Research.
Work towards a solution in the upcoming nature agreement that involves an effective and comprehensive protection of marine areas, rather than fragmented sector-based regulations.
Ensure to initiate your own conservation processes for all the remaining areas included in the conservation plan from 2004, with the goal of having these completed by 2027.
Accelerate the work of mapping the important areas that complement the conservation plan from 2004, in order to achieve 30% protection of Norwegian marine areas by 2030.
Take the objections from Andøy and Senja municipalities into account and terminate the work on establishing a marine protected area in Andfjorden.
Restrict the proposed protected area for Lopphavet in line with considerations for fishing, economic development, and important measures for infrastructure development.
To restore ecosystems and increase harvesting potential in the associated area.

Take the objections from Inderøy and Steinkjer municipalities into account and permanently terminate the work on the establishment of a marine protected area in Børgin under the Nature Diversity Act § 39.

Develop clear and predictable guidelines for all business operators operating within protected areas and SVO areas. These guidelines should also be adapted to new business activities and indicate who can engage in commercial activities where, when, and how this should take place.
Contribute to setting realistic goals for conservation in the UN's new nature agreement, and based on this, contribute to genuine protection of nature.
Investigate whether the Nature Diversity Act should apply beyond 12 nautical miles.
Inform and involve the Storting when ambitions to protect nature are to be adopted on behalf of the nation of Norway in international negotiations.

Contribute to setting ambitious plans for the necessary protection of vulnerable nature both on land and at sea. It must be clearly stated how activities in these vulnerable areas can take place in a sustainable manner.
Ensure that supervision is conducted to verify that the driving rules are followed in the protected areas and SVO areas.
Establish an international system for the registration of protection, so that all countries commit to following up on the protection in the same way.
Ensure that the municipalities and business actors are effectively involved in all conservation processes mentioned in Meld. St. 29 (2020–2021).

Resume negotiations with the employees' organizations in accordance with the agreements made on March 3, 2018, and November 29, 2018, and prepare a new case when the agreement on future pension rules for individuals with special retirement age limits is finalized.

Present a proposal to raise the general age limit in the public sector to 72 years, as it is in the Working Environment Act. The Parliament requests the government to consider further increasing the age limits in the labor market to 75 years.

Investigate possible changes to the Working Environment Act where the current arrangement of appointing specially qualified lay judges in each case upon proposal from the parties is replaced with a random selection of lay judges from each of the specially qualified labor law panels.

Dissolve Kulturtanken, and initiate a process aimed at replacing Kulturtanken with, for example, a smaller DKS department in the Arts Council, the counties' DKS organizations, and/or an expansion of Scenekunstbruket and similar entities for other art forms. The field and the employees in Kulturtanken must be involved and taken care of. The Parliament requests the government to inform the Parliament about the process in an appropriate manner and that necessary changes are proposed at the latest in the draft state budget for 2023.

Conduct an investigation into alternative organization of the cultural school bag, including (strengthening of) the counties' DKS organizations, expansion of the Performing Arts Use and similar activities, and evaluation of Kulturtanken. The Parliament requests the government to inform the Parliament about the process in an appropriate manner and that any changes are proposed at the latest in the draft state budget for 2023, where the Parliament will make the final decision. The level of transfers to the cultural school bag shall not be changed by this.

Take the initiative for a binding collaboration between the state, municipalities, and sports to reduce the costs of participating in children's and youth sports and to work towards a principle of free participation. The government is requested to return to the Parliament with proposals for appropriations to follow up on this work.
Continue the current DKS arrangement, as well as clarify that the goal of DKS (The Cultural School Bag) should still be to contribute to students receiving a professional arts and culture offer.

Initiate an external and independent evaluation of the achievement of goals in the museum reform, which will also highlight challenges and suggestions for appropriate adjustments to the current consolidation strategy.

Conduct a consultation program with volunteers related to today's museums and then appropriately promote proposals in the Parliament regarding measures that can stimulate increased volunteer engagement in all parts of Museum Norway.

Present proposals for specific goals and measures that can strengthen the collaboration between relevant museums on one side and the Cultural Heritage Federation and its member organizations on the other.

Review the national grant schemes for the production and dissemination of audiovisual works with the aim of introducing spending requirements based on the model of other countries that have such a condition in their grant schemes, so that a specific percentage of the state grant funds is used to produce film and TV drama in Norway.

Investigate and propose a change to the cultural law that imposes requirements for cultural policy management in municipalities, including a requirement for a municipal sub-plan for culture, and where the principle of arm's length distance is enshrined in law for all levels of administration.

Investigate and return to the Parliament with a proposal regarding possible changes in cultural management, including separating the Arts Council into two functions, so that the arm's length tasks and the directorate tasks are handled by separate organizations. The goal of any potential change is to strengthen the independence, transparency, and the principle of arm's length for the Arts Council, to enhance necessary directorate functions, and to safeguard the independence of art institutions.
Investigate a significant strengthening of the Norwegian Cultural Fund, both organizationally and financially, and provide suggestions for areas that need more funding and/or expertise.
Investigate and return to the Storting with a proposal to establish a research center for cultural sector research.

Investigate the role of Kulturtanken and its future operations in accordance with a new structure for the Arts Council and a directorate, with an emphasis on strengthening the Cultural School Bag. The investigation must include an assessment of assigning national tasks related to the Cultural School Bag to the Arts Council/directorate, whether models like Scenekunstbruket can be expanded to include more cultural expressions in collaboration with the relevant fields, and how the responsibilities and resources of the counties can be increased to enhance the offerings of the school bag.
Propose amendments to the law that remove the statute of limitations for all types of sexual offenses against children.
Return to the Storting with stricter regulations if the new framework does not sufficiently prevent the establishment of international criminal gangs and mafia organizations.

Investigate specifically whether the police should be granted access to coercive measures in criminal procedure beyond what the proposed penalty framework of three years' imprisonment for participation, recruitment, or continuation of a criminal organization suggests.
Ensure that all individuals who sustain dental injuries as a result of an accident receive coverage for treatment of these injuries.
Consider an expansion of coverage for dental injuries due to accidents, in connection with the upcoming case regarding the strengthening of Norwegian dental health.
Accelerate the work on following up decision 20 (2018–2019) regarding the strengthening of Norwegian dental health, and present this matter no later than in connection with the state budget for 2022.
Introduce a requirement for liability insurance for businesses that rent out electric scooters.

Present a dental health reform to the Parliament that includes a concrete plan for the phased implementation of a universally accessible dental health service, where teeth are treated as part of the body and dental health is equated with other health services, for example through a co-payment scheme.
To investigate a gradual expansion of publicly funded dental care, so that oral diseases are regarded as a regular diagnosis, and dental health is equated with other health services.

Design a dental health reform that ensures equal social and geographical distribution of dental health services, where no one should pay more for necessary dental health services than for other necessary health services. The reform must ensure a significant expansion of the public dental health service, strengthen preventive work so that everyone regularly receives a dental check-up, establish regulated prices in the private dental health service, develop principles for the regulation of private enterprises, and strengthen the supervisory apparatus. An enhancement of dental health services should primarily occur through the strengthening of the public dental health service, and individuals with the greatest need for assistance, the elderly and the young, should be prioritized in the implementation.
Suggest measures to strengthen preventive dental health work, including training and hiring more dental hygienists, and introducing regular free dental check-ups for everyone.

Propose a strengthening of the social welfare systems and establish a separate dental health scheme through Nav that ensures that vulnerable groups in need of dental care receive an offer of necessary dental assistance, with common guidelines for the entire country.
Include more treatments and groups in the reimbursement scheme and introduce price regulation for dental services in collaboration with the industry, and propose this in the state budget for 2022.
Introduce a high-cost protection until the dental health reform is fully implemented, provided that the treatment is necessary and not priced above given reference prices.

Reintroduce the reimbursement schemes for necessary orthodontics (braces), establish fixed prices for services with reimbursement, and begin the work of facilitating orthodontics in the public sector.
Transfer the ownership of the regional dental competence centers from the county municipalities to the universities.
Present a proposal for free treatment choice for individuals who have dental care covered by the public sector.

Ensure that support is provided through the National Insurance Scheme to patients with increased dental treatment needs due to previous life traumas such as torture or abuse, as well as to patients with odontophobia.
Ensure that patients with a history of trauma such as torture or abuse, as well as patients with odontophobia, are assessed, diagnosed, and offered tailored dental treatment.
Ensure that patients with dental treatment anxiety are offered treatment for this before dental treatment is initiated, except in cases of emergency treatment.
Ensure that treatment for dental anxiety is carried out by qualified healthcare professionals.

Present a plan for a gradual expansion of publicly funded dental care, ensuring that the increased use of public funds is entirely directed towards strengthening dental services, including the consideration of implementing a maximum price for dental treatments that are fully or partially funded by the public sector.

Develop a proposal for how to establish a support scheme that ensures individuals with low income can still receive necessary dental care. The support scheme should be designed in a way that allows for easy scaling and gradual expansion.
Ensure that the public dental health service remains a county responsibility, and on that basis, discontinue further work related to trials with a municipal dental health service.

Make an assessment of the consequences that the implemented cuts to the subsidy scheme for orthodontic treatment for children and young people have had, and evaluate the need for a targeted strengthening of the subsidy scheme for individuals in need of orthodontic treatment.

Consider measures that can help prevent the centralization and closure of public dental health clinics, including examining the need for initiatives that can increase recruitment in professional and/or geographical areas where it is currently challenging to find qualified personnel. The Parliament requests the government to also look into whether measures should be introduced regarding the acquisition of dental treatment clinics by larger chains.

Start the work of expanding the public dental health service and ensure increased capacity in the county municipal services, so that all patients with rights in the public dental health service can receive the necessary follow-up.

Promote a case with proposals for measures that ensure that the regional dental competence centers become genuine decentralized services that provide people across the country with the shortest possible travel distance to specialized dental treatment.
Initiate work on the establishment of a new entry point in social security financing, to ensure these patients a predictable right to necessary dental treatment.

Conduct an evaluation of the regional dental competence centers. The evaluation must assess whether the goal of having the centers contribute to a decentralization of specialized competence in the dental health field has been achieved, whether the current structure of the state funding scheme is appropriate, and whether the use of these state funding resources should be changed to better ensure that patients have access to good specialized dental health treatment throughout the country. The results of the evaluation and proposals for measures will be presented to the Parliament.

Strengthen the tailored dental health services for victims of torture and abuse, as well as individuals with severe anxiety about dental treatment (odontophobia) (TOO), and promote proposals in the budget for 2022 to ensure necessary funding.
Reassess the absence rules in high school, with the aim of reducing the risk of antibiotic prescriptions for infections.
Limit the right to prescribe antibiotics after contact via phone/video to the patient's general practitioner and municipal emergency services.

Propose new pharmaceutical policy measures that can ensure Norwegian access to pediatric formulations of penicillin, in order to avoid children being prescribed broad-spectrum antibiotics when it is not necessary.

Include access to effective antibiotics in the work of drafting a treaty for health preparedness under the auspices of WHO. The Parliament requests the government to consider whether antibiotic resistance is suitable for treatment under this treaty, and alternatively to return to Parliament with proposals for further follow-up on antibiotic resistance within WHO.

Propose to the Parliament a change to the Patient and User Rights Act that abolishes the current distinction between clarified and unclarified conditions, while also suggesting new pathway measurements and indicators that ensure patients' right to safe patient pathways.
Conduct an evaluation of the deadline breach scheme.

Further investigate model C in the Norwegian Directorate of Health's report IS-2742 on the regulation of patient pathways and the registration of waiting times in specialist health services, where deadline breach rights are replaced by pathway plans, among other things.

Increase the limit for the environmental mandate in the Government Pension Fund Global so that it corresponds to the limit for investments in unlisted real estate, i.e., to 7% of the investment portfolio.

Add the goals of the Paris Agreement to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees, as well as a target for a net-zero investment portfolio by no later than 2050, to the mandate for the management of the Government Pension Fund Global.
Withdraw the Government Pension Fund Global from investments in animal production that do not meet Norwegian animal welfare standards.
Increase the framework for the environmental mandate in the Government Pension Fund Global.
Report on whether the investment portfolio and the benchmark index are in line with the goals of the Paris Agreement.

Change the behavioral criteria for the observation and exclusion of companies to ensure that the Government Pension Fund Global withdraws its investments from companies linked to unlawful occupation and other violations of international law.
Introduce a product-based criterion for autonomous weapons.
Develop guidelines that ensure that the largest possible portion of the Government Pension Fund Global's operations is conducted from Norway.
Investigate whether the activities of the Government Pension Fund Global in Norway can be more widely distributed so that the entire country benefits.
Remove all upstream companies from the Government Pension Fund Global index, as intended in Innst. 339 S (2018–2019).

Evaluate whether the divestment of upstream oil and gas companies in the Government Pension Fund Global has affected Norway's total exposure to the oil sector, and investigate a possible product criterion for oil and gas.
Start the work of establishing a state green investment bank.
Ensure that Norway has preparedness in public financial institutions to immediately provide credit to businesses in an acute economic crisis.
Set a goal to reduce the share of private banks in the money supply.
Investigate the effects of a monetary system that adopts digital central bank currencies, combined with increased public credit intermediation through existing or new financial institutions.

Take the initiative with relevant parties and industry organizations to investigate the establishment of a complaints body for those who fall outside the mandate of the Financial Complaints Board, for example, to handle complaints from organizations, businesses, and companies, possibly organizations and companies below a certain size.

Investigate to what extent the banks' lending is economically beneficial and assess how credit regulation can make the allocation of credit more efficient with the aim of particularly achieving the goals of the Paris Agreement and otherwise supporting the real economy.
Prohibit the marketing of 'green' financial products that are not genuinely environmentally friendly.

Investigate how the framework conditions and regulation of the financial industry can be changed to promote restructuring and climate cuts, and how climate and climate risk can be given more weight in the credit process.
Make climate transition a part of the purpose of Norges Bank.
Evaluate the effect of the crisis measures aimed at the banks and map out how much of the banks' profits in 2020 and 2021 can be attributed to the crisis measures.
Introduce comprehensive reporting on climate risk, tailored to the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD).
Report on climate risk in the Norwegian economy in each national budget.

Task the Financial Supervisory Authority with regularly conducting stress tests on climate risk in Norwegian financial institutions. The Financial Supervisory Authority must map and analyze the consequences of climate change for financial risk in Norway.
Make the necessary changes to differentiate between dividends to shareholders and dividends for charitable purposes in recommendations and regulations regarding dividends.
Engage in dialogue with Norwegian banks with the aim of making account number portability a reality or promote proposals that make switching banks even easier for consumers.

Engage in dialogue with the financial industry and assess whether a separate complaints body should be established for businesses, entrepreneurs, and organizations, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Ensure that any potential connection to an EU supervisory structure for anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing preserves Norway's room for action and does not involve the relinquishment of sovereignty to EU or EEA bodies.
Take the initiative for an international collaboration on the taxation of currency transactions and financial transactions involving securities.
Establish a public committee to assess the role of cash in society moving forward, and how the needs of different customer groups for cash services can be met in the most efficient way possible.

Investigate the overall effect on financial stability of bank financing through covered bonds (OMF) with the associated dependence on developments in the housing market, cross-ownership of OMF between banks, and the opening for securitization under the Securitization Regulation.
Present a proposal for the introduction of a rent cap in Norway.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to ban return commissions.

Work to ensure that specific Norwegian experiences and perspectives related to important renewable industries such as hydropower and the forestry industry are taken into account in the development of the EU taxonomy for sustainable economic activity.

Work to ensure that investments in important Norwegian renewable industries such as hydropower and the forestry industry can be defined as sustainable according to the EU's taxonomy for sustainable economic activity.
Introduce a duty to consult the debt register and a duty of care for creditors.

Investigate a possible introduction of bank switching services, for example based on models from the United Kingdom and the Netherlands, which do not rely on account number portability but help simplify the bank switching process for bank customers.
Investigate the risks associated with outsourcing the operation of IT systems to foreign entities, and how central ICT providers and data centers can best be subjected to oversight.
Ensure that critical financial IT infrastructure is operated from Norway.

Conduct a review of the Oslo Stock Exchange's outsourcing of critical operational functions, particularly related to the risk of weakening preparedness and expertise in Norway, and present an assessment and any proposed measures, no later than in connection with the Financial Market Report 2022.
Come back to the Parliament with a concrete proposal to expand the debt register in connection with the state budget for 2022.
Promote proposals that further reduce banks' ability to take risks outside their core business.
Return to the Storting no later than spring 2022 with a proposal to ban the marketing of consumer loans.
Come back in the Financial Market Report 2022 with proposals for tightening the regulations on supplementary benefits conditional on credit uptake.
