Establish a committee to assess how to increase the market shares of banks and financial institutions based in Norway, and report back to the Parliament with a message on this by spring 2022 at the latest.
Investigate the need for, and the possibility of, including even more types of debt in the debt registers.
Establish a public committee to assess the role of cash in society moving forward.

Adapt the implementation of capital requirements for high-risk exposures in accordance with the actual Norwegian regulations for the sale of residential properties, so that signed purchase agreements, rather than completion certificates, are used as the basis for assessing whether the loan financing is high-risk or not.
Secure and strengthen the position, framework conditions, and attractiveness of equity certificates in the capital market.

Mapping and utilizing the scope of action within the capital requirements regulations to ensure the competitiveness of Norwegian savings banks, including the relationship between standard method banks and IRB banks in the calculation of capital requirements.
Consider reducing the risk weight for commercial real estate with less than 50% leverage, from 100% to 50% for standard method banks.

Utilize the flexibility in the EU's banking package to limit capital requirements and reporting burdens for savings banks in line with the principle of proportionality, and ensure that the use of this flexibility is specifically defined in the regulations rather than left to the discretion of supervisory authorities.

Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner, no later than in connection with the state budget for 2022, with a proposal for a revenue-neutral restructuring of the financial tax where the increased employer's contribution is removed.
Ensure that savings banks have the flexibility to use common solutions in collaboration with other savings banks within responsible frameworks.
Use the leeway available in relation to the EU to ensure that the capital requirements for Norwegian savings banks are not significantly stricter than the requirements for their competitors.
Consider whether the management of the export control regulations should be transferred from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to the Ministry of Defence.
Consider entering into long-term agreements with relevant stakeholders to ensure adequate logistical support related to allied reception and readiness situations.

Come back to the Storting with a separate case regarding the F35 program and associated upgrade projects, detailing the procurement, the current cost estimates, and the challenges of the F-35 program as a whole.
Develop a long-term financing plan for the restoration work at Tollbugata 10.
Present a proposal for an initial government contribution to the Foundation of the Old War School.

Prepare a feasibility study on how the use and dissemination of the Old War School in Tollbugata 10 can be optimized, and identify what the state can contribute to maximize the opportunities for the foundation's future work.

Investigate and clarify whether any future grants and/or operating funds to the Foundation The Old War School in connection with the building complex at Tollbugata 10 in Oslo should be released through the Ministry of Culture.

Develop a comprehensive plan for the Armed Forces to achieve the objectives outlined in the UN's agenda for women, peace, and security, the Gender Equality Act, and the prohibition of discrimination, as well as the Working Environment Act. The plan must include all operational domains, HR and education, their structures, processes, and culture, and contain sub-goals and deadlines for implementation.

Elaborate on the situation regarding the NH90 with the aim of finding a solution that ensures the Coast Guard has sufficient capacity of helicopters with adequate range, and that can handle the challenging climate in the Barents Sea. The assessment must be made in a 20-year perspective, where the costs of operation and maintenance of the NH90 are evaluated against the purchase of new helicopters. The Parliament requests the government to return to the Parliament with the matter in the proposal for the state budget for 2022.

Ensure that Norwegian cooperation with the U.S. intelligence services, suspected of espionage against Norway, including the NSA, is temporarily suspended until American espionage against Norway is mapped out and the Parliament is informed in an appropriate manner.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals on how, within the framework of the Constitution, it can be ensured that the Norwegian Armed Forces are not used outside the country's borders except in cases of self-defense or in missions under UN leadership.

Ensure that Norwegian police personnel participating in international operations receive the same right to compensation for psychological injuries as personnel from the Armed Forces participating in international operations.
Ensure a living conditions survey for veterans from international military operations, conducted by an independent civilian research or investigation agency.

Calculate the cost of Norway's participation in the war in Afghanistan from 2001 to the present, using the same calculation method as that used for the years 2001 to 2014 in the Godal report (NOU 2016: 8), and report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner.

Investigate how many Norwegian veterans have become fully or partially disabled as a result of participation in international military operations, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Investigate and propose the introduction of a flexible cohabitation law that regulates the financial settlement between cohabitants, in order to ensure a fair distribution at the end of the cohabitation.
Investigate a deviable cohabitation law.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to incorporate children's participation and rights in all relevant parts of the Child Welfare Act, for example by including the wording "The child's rights according to Chapter 1 must be upheld" as the first part of each chapter.

Investigate the differentiation of the new competence requirements in relation to the type of institution and placement, as well as the various functions where a master's degree requirement is introduced in the municipal child welfare service, and return to the Parliament with a separate case.
Present the first part of a four-year ramp-up plan for a total of one thousand new positions in the municipal child welfare service.

Ensure that the new child welfare law is updated in accordance with the fundamental rights in the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child regarding children's right to information and to express themselves freely in all actions and decisions in child welfare, and how this should be weighed against other considerations.
Investigate a division of child welfare services.
Present a case regarding the use of recordings of conversations in child welfare cases.
Ensure that the parties in a child welfare case have the right to request a change of caseworker.
Ensure that service providers for child welfare are treated equally, and that in each case, the quality of the service is the most important factor.
Present a case for replacing the county boards with an administrative court.
Return to the Storting with a proposal for the introduction of a profession-specific authorization scheme for child welfare educators and social workers.
Ensure that non-profit organizations can still provide services for the target groups "care for children under 13 years" and "substance abuse treatment."
Facilitate greater transparency regarding the handling of cases in the county board, so that the press can more closely follow the proceedings without violating privacy regulations.

Come back to the Parliament with a new, revised proposal for the Child Welfare Act Chapter 10, after a thorough review and investigation of children's rights and the use of coercion in child welfare institutions.
To increase the share of non-profit providers of institutional placements in child welfare at the expense of commercial providers.
Not to limit the offerings of non-profit actors to specified groups of children/youth.
Investigate the requirements for authorization for those who will work with custody transfers.

Consider strengthening and restructuring the state offer for the target groups "acute" and "high behavior" among children with particularly extensive follow-up needs, and ensure that non-profit actors can continue to provide services for the target groups "care for children under 13 years" and substance abuse treatment.
Investigate and propose the introduction of a system for secondary assessment of urgent/expedited decisions.
Continue working on finding an alternative term for the concept of behavior in the Child Welfare Act.
Ensure that the elected representatives in the municipality receive a good introduction to their local child welfare services at the beginning of each term.
Promote a proposal that disabled foster parents do not have their disability benefits reduced as a result of their foster care duties.
Follow up on the recommendations of the Legal Security Committee in the child welfare area without unjustified delay.
Move the Norwegian embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

Norway, as a member of the UN Security Council, is promoting an initiative to establish an international criminal court to address members and sympathizers of ISIS in the region where criminal acts have been committed.

To ensure prison capacity in the region, so that members and sympathizers of ISIS who are sentenced by an international criminal court must serve their sentences in the area where they committed their crimes.
Ensure that Norway takes a leadership role in the international effort for a treaty that prohibits lethal autonomous weapon systems and preserves human control.
Present a case to the Storting regarding the regulation of autonomous weapon technology to ensure that Norwegian companies do not contribute to systems that can be considered unacceptable.

To establish clear conditions in the regulations for the cases in which municipalities can deviate from the pre-accepted solutions in the Building Technical Regulations (TEK17) § 11-17 and the Fire Prevention Regulations § 21 to the detriment of the developer when fire safety is designed with a tanker truck.
To prepare a circular on how the law regarding the rental of small electric vehicles on public grounds should be applied.
Promote proposals that allow municipalities to charge street ground rent for the rental of small electric vehicles on public land.
Plan to evaluate the law on the rental of small electric vehicles on public grounds once experiences with the practice have been gathered.
Relieve Greece and start the work of bringing an additional 750 refugees from the Greek islands for relocation in Norway.

Strengthen assistance to Bosnia and offer UNHCR, in collaboration with Bosnian authorities, the relocation of particularly vulnerable refugees to Norway for the processing of their asylum applications here.
Develop a classification of electric scooters as a type of vehicle, so that municipalities can regulate parking and other regulations for their use in line with other vehicles.
Assuming that the incurred costs for planning and competition for the new airport at Mo i Rana are included in the local contribution of 600 million kroner.
Ensure that the airports in Mosjøen, Sandnessjøen, and Brønnøysund remain operational after the construction of the new airport in Mo i Rana.
Ensure that there is a sufficient flight service to Stord Airport even after the current agreement expires in June 2021.
Assuming that a new airport in Mo i Rana will open in 2025.
Promote a proposal to promptly reverse the unsocial cuts in the physiotherapy scheme.
Promote a proposal to promptly reverse the cuts in funding for orthodontic treatment for children and young people, as well as dental check-ups for the elderly.
Promote proposals to reverse the anti-social cuts to necessary medical consumables.
Reverse the unsocial cuts to the Work Assessment Allowance (AAP) that have been implemented under the Solberg government and promote the necessary proposals for this.

Ensure an independent evaluation and investigation of the effects of the disability reform, both in terms of benefit levels, the relationship to other income-dependent benefits, and the relationship to occupational pensions, and promote proposals that can rectify any unreasonable outcomes caused by the reform.
Present a proposal for strengthened housing support so that it reaches more people, and that those who receive support cover an equal portion of their housing costs as in 2010.
Promote a proposal to reverse the cuts to the disability child allowance.
Promote a proposal to reverse the cut in the car support scheme for individuals in group 1 who need a car to break an isolated existence and improve daily living functions.
Evaluate the changes in the publicly funded physiotherapy services while implementing a scaling-up plan for habilitation/rehabilitation in the municipalities.
Evaluate changes in dental care services for children, youth, and the elderly so that dental care services can be improved for these groups.
Conduct a comprehensive review of the regulatory change that involved cuts in medical consumables to ensure that essential and fair needs are met.

Evaluate and investigate the effects of the disability reform, both in terms of benefit levels, the relationship to other income-dependent benefits, and the relationship to occupational pensions, and propose measures that can rectify unreasonable cuts.
Conduct a thorough evaluation of the scheme for work assessment allowance (AAP) and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Come back to the Storting with a review of how the unfair cuts implemented by the government and the parliamentary majority have weakened the living conditions for the most vulnerable in society and increased social inequality in Norway.

Promote necessary proposals for amendments to the National Insurance Act that ensure equal treatment of individuals admitted to psychiatric treatment institutions or addiction treatment facilities, and individuals admitted to somatic hospital departments, so that both patient groups are exempt from reductions in their benefits from the National Insurance scheme.
Investigate the legal basis for reducing social security benefits for individuals under criminal enforcement.

Investigate changes to the National Insurance Act's rules regarding the reduction of benefits during stays in institutions, including the difference between patients in somatic and psychiatric institutions, and return to the Parliament with proposals for changes that ensure equal treatment of patient groups.
Promote proposals for permanent improvements to the income security schemes, based on the measures from the Parliament, particularly in the unemployment benefit scheme in the spring of 2020.
Promote proposals for permanent changes that halve the minimum income requirement to qualify for unemployment benefits, effective from October 1, 2021.
To apply to agricultural businesses that employ workers residing in Norway.

Ensure that businesses hiring job seekers connected to Nav and providing work in agricultural enterprises have equal access, like other businesses, to utilize mentoring programs, wage subsidies, and other measures that help people return to work quickly.

Investigate a non-commercial housing sector with a housing supply for owner-occupied homes with prices shielded from market fluctuations, and return to the Parliament with proposals for the necessary legislative changes and financial allocations to establish such a scheme.
Present a proposal for legislative changes that allow municipalities to charge a lower property tax rate for primary residences compared to secondary and vacation homes.
Propose credit regulations that ensure that banks' total lending for housing is limited, while simultaneously increasing the share of first-time buyers in the total new home loans.

Investigate measures to change the composition of banks' credit over time, so that a smaller share goes to residential and commercial real estate and a larger share goes to other industries, and report back to the Parliament with proposals no later than in connection with the state budget for 2022.

Introduce a national housing plan that will address housing needs across the country. The Housing Bank will be strengthened as part of ensuring people's housing needs. Public land and development companies will be established to ensure consistent development in line with the plan and to secure counter-cyclical demand.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that allows the valuation discount for high-value primary residences to be reduced compared to other primary residences.

Investigate a reform for the taxation of housing and property in Norway that removes or drastically reduces net tax subsidies for housing and property. A basic deduction should be provided to shield a large proportion of primary residences from taxation, and different models for the gradual implementation of a more comprehensive and fair taxation of housing and property should be outlined.

Investigate and propose necessary amendments to the law on housing cooperatives that ensure that the managing director and central employees of housing cooperatives do not have the right to attend as delegates at the general assembly, and that employees of a housing cooperative cannot constitute more than 5 percent of the delegates to the general assembly.
Investigate and propose a model for a third non-commercial housing sector, including necessary legal changes to ensure that a significant proportion of new housing is non-commercial.

Propose amendments to the law on housing cooperatives that clarify that all members of housing cooperatives should receive sufficient information about participation in the general meeting and have a genuine opportunity to participate in it.

Ensure that it is not tax-wise beneficial to invest in secondary properties compared to other investment objects. This should be achieved through a tightening of the taxation of secondary properties and not a relaxation of other taxation.

Investigate how municipalities can be given the flexibility to tax secondary homes and other properties, such as privately owned rental apartments, differently from primary residences using property tax, and report back on this in connection with the state budget for 2022. Municipalities should be allowed to differentiate the basic deduction and tax rate between primary, secondary, and rental properties.
Promote a proposal for a phasing-out plan for the document fee in connection with the state budget for 2022.

Present a proposal to strengthen the BSU scheme by increasing the annual savings amount that provides a tax deduction, as well as the total savings amount, in connection with the state budget for 2022.
Increase housing development with a social profile, both at the state and municipal level.

Investigate and return to the Parliament with a long-term four-year phasing-out plan aimed at harmonizing the overall Norwegian owner taxation (corporate tax, dividend tax, and wealth tax) with the owner taxation in our neighboring countries and key trading partners such as the EU, the USA, and China.
Ensure that Norway's relations with other countries increasingly take into account the interests of Norwegian investors who invest globally, as well as access to foreign capital in Norway.
Return to the Parliament with a crime-reducing proposal to criminalize the media's publication of postcode-based listings in the tax records.

Investigate the possibility of making it easier for foreign actors to establish a Norwegian VPS account within the framework of a responsible compliance with international anti-money laundering and anti-corruption regulations, where Norway adopts the same practices as our competitor countries.
Promote a proposal to allow the stock savings account scheme to include unlisted companies.
Investigate and propose simplifications related to the conversion of sole proprietorships to limited companies.
Come back in the 2022 budget with a proposal for a scheme where smaller businesses can flag their tax returns for manual review for a lower deductible amount.
Ensure greater transparency regarding the distribution of value creation in Norway, among other things by removing access to who is searching in the tax lists.
Come back with a case related to how Argentum can be structured so that the fund's original objectives are better maintained.
Ensure increased coordination of inspections, so that the number of work hours in small businesses related to disruptive inspections is reduced.
Develop a strategy to ensure a more investment-friendly Norway leading up to 2030, with the goal of attracting both more Norwegian and foreign capital to invest in Norwegian companies.
Reallocate the funds from Rv. Hunndalen-Mjøsbrua to Rv. 4 Lunner-Gjelderåsen.
Dissolve all PPP projects as soon as it is practically and legally possible.
Let the E18 bypass Kristiansand city center.
Prioritize funds in the state budget for 2022 to ensure full state financing of the light rail in Bergen to Åsane without tolls.
Prioritize planning for the winter-open E134.
Prioritize the design of Fossumdiagonalen.
Prioritize environmental noise barriers over the E6 at Manglerud and Furuset.
Ensure that the transition to zero-emission ferries and fast boats is fully financed by the state, and allocate funds starting from 2022.

Ensure that all construction of roads, railways, and other infrastructure, including those built by the Norwegian Public Roads Administration, Nye Veier, and Bane Nord, is carried out with Norwegian wage and working conditions and without social dumping.
Ensure the establishment of a total of 10,000 fast chargers and rapid chargers along national and county roads by 2025.

Ensure clearer coordination responsibilities for the state and county municipalities to secure faster and more cost-effective development of charging infrastructure and electronic communication in connection with the upgrading, planning, and construction of roads and railways.

Expand the investment in charging stations at rest areas to include ferry terminals, bus stations, train stations, and other important traffic hubs along the roads that can function as energy hubs for trucks, buses, ferries, trains, and electric cars. Furthermore, the state, in collaboration with the transport industry, should take an active role in establishing the necessary infrastructure for emission-free freight transport as quickly as possible.

Ensure easy access to route information about international train connections and the ability to purchase train tickets that are valid across borders in the Nordic countries and to the continent, for example by expanding the national travel planner of Entur AS.

Reverse the separation of planning, construction, materials, and maintenance of the Norwegian railway, as well as evaluate the outsourcing of train operations, and consider reversing this as contracts expire, with the aim of consolidating train services into one state-owned company.

Investigate whether the state should cover a larger share of its expenses through loans in Norwegian kroner, and report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner. The investigation should include assessments of financial stability, room for maneuver in monetary policy, the effect on the exchange rate of the krone, as well as which expenditure purposes it may be appropriate to cover in this way, beyond those that currently apply.
Propose an initial grant for financing the dredging project at Borg harbor, considering the completed project with a cost estimate of 725 million kroner over the course of three annual budgets.
To investigate the possibility of introducing a ban on the sale and import of fossil fuel cars after 2025.
Propose to reduce the general speed limit in cities from 50 km/h to 30 km/h and to 20 km/h around schools and kindergartens.
Implement measures to increase profitability for the use of zero-emission fuels, particularly aimed at heavy transport and shipping.
Ensure that work is initiated on land accounting for natural types in individual transportation developments, including the impact of these developments on natural carbon stores.
Initiate a concept choice study for the further extension from Lørenskog center to Lillestrøm/Kjeller.
Prepare a concept choice study, alternatively a feasibility study, for a new, modern double-track railway between Oslo and Gothenburg in collaboration with Swedish authorities.
Prioritize the expansion of Rv. 4 with portfolio expansion up to Jaren, as well as the construction of the Hagantunnel, with a start no later than the second planning period.
Prioritize the construction of E134 Bakka-Solheim with a start in the first planning period.
Prioritize the construction of E 39 Astad-Bjerkeset with a start in the first planning period.
Prioritize the construction of E14 Stjørdal-Meråker with a start in the first planning period.
Prioritize the development of E6 Brandvollbakken with a start in the first planning period.
Prioritize the development of E39 Ring Road East (Vågsbotn-Klauvaneset) with commencement in the first planning period.
Prioritize the construction of E6 Helgeland Sør, including the two sections furthest south in Grane, with a start in the first planning period.
Prioritize the construction of E6 Ulvsvågskaret with a start in the first planning period.
Prioritize the development of E10 Lofoten with a start in the first planning period.

Make it clear from the Norwegian side that any potential replacement of the railway service from Arvika to Oslo must be linked to one of the existing railway routes in the region, either the Kongsvinger Line or the Indre Østfold Line.
Ensure that Alta Airport remains open and functional.
Prioritize the construction of E16 Fagernes south-Hande with a start in the first planning period.
Prioritize the construction of Rv.15 Strynefjellet with a start in the first planning period.
Prioritize the development of E39 segment improvements from Byrkjelo to Sandane, starting in the first planning period.
Prioritize the construction of the E6 new intersection solution at Olsborg, starting in the first planning period.
Prioritize the construction of E8 Lavangsdalen with a start in the first planning period.
Increase the funding for county roads by 4 billion kroner, from 15.3 billion kroner to 19.3 billion kroner.
Find solutions together with Agder County Municipality and Lindesnes Municipality to realize a new road between E39 and Spangereid.

Seek solutions in collaboration with Agder County Municipality and Arendal Municipality to realize a new access road from the E18 to Arendal Port, and assess whether the connection via County Road 415 to the port should be a national road.
Prioritize the improvement of the approach to Arendal city center through Galtesund, as well as expand the approach to Arendal harbor, with the aim of facilitating cruise traffic and larger vessels.
Prioritize the development of E6 Oslo East in the first six-year period and start the work on the state plan for the project.
Prioritize the E6 Oslo East project in the first six-year period, given local support for the project after 2023.
To strengthen the efforts regarding improvements on the E3 beyond the proposal in the National Transport Plan.
Prioritize the development of Furneset ferry quay.
Prioritize further improvements and the establishment of a median strip on E8 Lavangsdalen.
Prioritize the construction of pedestrian and bicycle paths along the existing E6 Tana Bru–Skipagurra.
Assign Nye Veier AS the responsibility for Rv. 4 Biri-Jaren.
Prioritize the Rv. 13 Vikafjell Tunnel project with state funding amounting to 500 million kroner in the first six-year period and 2.6 billion kroner in the second period.
Prioritize the Rv. 15 Strynefjellet project with state funding amounting to 1 billion kroner in the first six-year period and 3.4 billion kroner in the second six-year period.
Prioritize the E134 Bakka-Solheim project with full state funding and start in the first six-year period.
Prioritize the E8 Lavangsdalen project (improvement/traffic safety measures) with 500 million kroner in the first six-year period.
Prioritize the E14 Stjørdal-Storlien project with state funding amounting to 500 million kroner in the first six-year period and 4.5 billion kroner in the second six-year period.
Prioritize the E16 Fagernes South-Hande project with state funding amounting to 1 billion kroner in the first six-year period and 1.2 billion kroner in the second six-year period.
Take the initiative for further development of Notodden Airport in collaboration with the county municipality.
Prioritize the expansion of Leknes Airport in Lofoten.
Facilitate the development of the Haug-Seut section of the Østfold Line in the first six-year period.
Prioritize full state funding of Rv. 282 Holmenbrua with a total of 953 million kroner in the first six-year period.
Apply the same principles for the use of ferry replacement funds for both national and county roads, at least at the level of the current arrangement for county ferries.
Implement a critical review of the cost growth in the operating and maintenance budgets and submit proposals to the Parliament with concrete measures to streamline this part of the road sector.
Prioritize the construction of passing tracks at Fagerlia/Søsterbekk on the Ofot Line.
Prioritize the development of the Brønnøyle road.
Prioritize the development of Ballstad harbor.
Prioritize the development of Sørvær harbor.
Prioritize the development of Mehamn, elaboration.
Prioritize the development of E6 Vinteråpen Sennalandet/Saltfjellet/Bjørnfjell with a start in the first planning period.
Prioritize the construction of the Rv. 350 intersection with the exit to fv. 287, starting no later than the second planning period.
Initiate an independent concept choice study of the Nord-Norgebanen, where the goal of realization is established as a basis.

Ensure that the K5 project Arna–Stanghelle has a simultaneous start for both railway and road, no later than 2024, and that sufficient funds for this start are secured in the state budgets for 2022 and 2023.
Ensure the implementation of the planned crossing track in Fagerlia/Søsterbekk towards Bjørnfjell/Riksgrensen in the first planning period.
Ensure that Gulskogen station is developed in accordance with previous plans and agreements with Drammen municipality.

Develop a framework for a larger, long-term project within climate-neutral aviation, where the establishment of a testing center in Northern Norway will be central, and return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner, also with proposals for initial funding for this.
To initiate a pilot project for the use of trains with fuel cells powered by emission-free hydrogen on at least one of the non-electrified railway lines.
Ensure the construction of the E6 Narvik Tunnel is completed by 2027.

Ensure that requirements for universal design are set for all transportation projects, and that necessary funds are allocated so that universal design is integrated into the planning process of all individual projects.
Continue the planning of the connection between the Vestfold Line and the Sørland Line (Genistreken) with a view to starting construction midway through the planning period.

Take the initiative to develop a comprehensive and binding plan in collaboration with the county municipalities to reduce the maintenance backlog on county roads, and ensure that the county municipalities are equipped to follow this plan.
Take the initiative for an independent review and evaluation of the impact of the various reforms and reorganizations on the professional environments within the road sector.
Conduct an investigation into how road construction should be organized and carried out, so that it achieves the most efficient and appropriate organization possible.
Continue the environmental support scheme for freight by rail beyond 2021, and consider establishing it as a permanent scheme.
Initiate an external evaluation of the railway reform.
To start planning the reopening of the eastern line of the Østfold Line for both passenger traffic and freight transport in the first period of the National Transport Plan.

Assuming that the state is responsible for the maintenance and upgrading of the Tinnosbanen, so that the railway can be restored and Norway can fulfill its obligations for the World Heritage site in the Rjukan–Notodden industrial heritage.
Accelerate the project to grind and address the challenges posed by the Svinesund thresholds for the approach to Halden.
To develop a national charging strategy in 2022 to ensure coordination between public authorities and to secure sufficient charging infrastructure. The charging strategy must be consumer-friendly.

Make the necessary changes to ensure that universal design in the transport sector is incorporated as a primary goal in all transport planning to achieve that Norway becomes universally designed by 2035.
Ensure the interests of vintage vehicles by designing vehicle technical regulations and other regulations for the vehicle fleet.

Take the initiative to develop a national implementation plan for avalanche protection of all national and county roads with high and medium avalanche risk, in collaboration with the county municipalities.
Incorporate a new goal in all relevant decisions and documents, aiming for a 40% reduction in car traffic in all major cities by 2030.

Investigate a ban on the sale of new fossil fuel cars in 2025 if the goal set by the Parliament is not achieved through the tax system as a measure, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner, no later than the presentation of the state budget for 2022.
It should be clarified that the goal of increasing sales of zero-emission vehicles does not mean a ban on the sale of gasoline and diesel cars.
Facilitate the continued sale of gasoline and diesel cars in the Norwegian market even after 2025.
Promote proposals to abolish the zero growth target and facilitate the car as an attractive mode of transport for people in both urban and rural areas.

Change the current handbooks for standard requirements for the construction of bicycle and pedestrian paths, so that simpler and cheaper solutions are allowed. The Parliament expects that new simplified standard requirements will be introduced during 2021 and will be used particularly outside the major cities.
Investigate increased allowed speed for mopeds.
Introduce 120 km/h as the new upper speed limit on highways. The change will be implemented by July 1, 2021.
Increase the allowed speed for mopeds from 45 km/h to 60 km/h. The change will be implemented as soon as possible and no later than July 1, 2021.

Conduct a trial scheme to introduce a speed limit of 120 km/h on selected stretches of the newest and best four-lane motorways. It is natural for both the Norwegian Public Roads Administration and Nye Veier to be involved in the process of selecting trial stretches.

Change today's signage regulations so that it becomes easier for stakeholders along the road network to inform traffic participants about their businesses and where they are located. The Parliament requests the government to begin the work of revising the necessary handbooks and any proposals for changes to the Road Traffic Act so that these can be implemented as quickly as possible.
Increase the municipal sector's revenues by a minimum of 10-12 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in the Municipal Proposition 2022.
Introduce mitigating measures for municipalities and county municipalities with particularly high debt levels in response to the new repayment requirements in the Municipal Act.
Promote a proposal to abolish all financial incentive schemes for new municipal mergers.
Establish a scheme with state top funding for municipalities with extraordinarily high expenses for child welfare.
Change the income system so that municipalities receive funding for kindergarten operations based on the number of children and not the education level in the municipality.
Investigate a boat replacement scheme based on the principles of the ferry replacement scheme, and report back to the Storting in connection with the Municipal Proposition 2023.

Increase the municipal sector's revenues by a minimum of 3 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in the Municipal Proposition 2022, where approximately 700 million kroner is to be allocated to increase the county municipalities' framework.

Ensure that the income system committee's mandate is expanded to include the following: - Assess a maximum limit, either as a percentage of the municipal budget or in kroner per inhabitant, for expenses related to resource-intensive services - Evaluate a top financing scheme for municipalities with extraordinarily high expenses for child welfare - Consider whether the education criterion should be removed from the cost-sharing key for kindergartens - Examine compensation schemes for municipalities with high health costs related to residents from outside the municipality, for example, co-financing from the municipality where the service recipient pays taxes.
Provide a guarantee that all households will have internet access by 2025.
Present proposals for and funding of more pilot projects with low-threshold services within the fields of psychiatry and substance abuse in the municipal sector.
Increase the funding for the general practitioner scheme during 2022.
Promote proposals for increased income equalization in the income system for the municipal sector.

Conduct a review of the arrangement for resource-intensive services and ensure that all relevant costs incurred by the municipalities in the arrangement are included as the basis for the municipal co-payment.
Ensure that increased costs to municipalities as a result of the child welfare reform are covered by the state.
Establish a dedicated grant scheme to ensure the transition to zero-emission technology in regional public transport.
Increase the municipal sector's revenues by 3 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in the municipal proposition for 2022.
Investigate a framework for the maximum building permit fee and develop a guide for the use of self-cost to achieve a more cohesive practice and less variation between municipalities.
Consider a grant scheme for maintenance, upgrading, and investment in the county road network with a framework of at least 1 billion kroner.
Present a comprehensive report on property tax, including an assessment of a cap on property tax for ordinary homes and cabins, and return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Ensure that more projects are included in the ferry replacement scheme, that all projects receive a grant of at least 25 percent of interest costs, and that a minimum annual framework of 50 million kroner is established. At the same time, the Parliament requests the government to consider increasing this grant in connection with the annual state budgets.

Ensure that municipalities and county municipalities are compensated for the effects of tax shortfalls, loss of income, and additional expenses related to the coronavirus pandemic, both for 2021 and 2022.

Ensure that the county governor conducts an investigation in all municipalities in their region as soon as possible to clarify whether the COVID-19 compensation provided to each municipality covers the increased costs and loss of income that the pandemic has imposed on the municipalities.

Come back to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2022 with proposals that ensure predictable basic funding for the infrastructure and the work on facilitating the study offerings that take place through local study and education centers.
Present a proposal for the phasing out of the regional center grant in 2022.
Abolish the pilot scheme with state funding for care services.
Consider the legislation so that health services used outside the municipality of residence can be charged to a greater extent to the municipality where the service recipient pays taxes.
Extend the mandate of the working group on municipal finance related to the pandemic and its economic effects on the municipal sector.

Keep track of the new arrangement for additional compensation for small municipalities with high expenses for resource-intensive services and average tax revenues lower than 120 percent of the national average, and continuously assess whether this sufficiently helps municipalities that have disproportionately high expenses for resource-intensive services.

Establish a salary commission for public sector executive salaries and salaries in state-owned companies. The commission shall examine public executive salaries and bonus schemes in context and analyze why the salary development at the top level has continued, despite previously adopted guidelines. Furthermore, the commission shall conduct a thorough assessment of what constitutes genuine societal considerations in salary determination, and what cannot be justified by this. The commission shall have strong representation from the parties involved.
Introduce a salary freeze for high-paid executives in the state and establish a broadly composed low-income commission to investigate how real incomes are distributed in Norway.

"Establish a salary commission for state executive salaries, executive salaries in state-owned companies and companies where the state is the majority owner, as well as the salaries of politicians at the national and local levels and severance pay schemes. The commission shall examine state executive salaries, bonus schemes, and compensations in context and analyze why the salary development at the top level has continued, despite previously adopted guidelines. Furthermore, the commission shall conduct a thorough assessment of what constitutes genuine societal considerations in salary determination, and what cannot be justified by this. The commission shall have strong representation from the parties involved. The salaries of the Prime Minister, ministers, and members of parliament shall be nominally put on hold until the salary commission has presented its conclusions."
Conduct the wage settlement in the state so that there is one main collective agreement applicable to all employees in the state tariff area, regardless of organizational affiliation.
Promote a separate case for the Parliament regarding new guidelines for executive salaries and other types of compensation for leaders in the state, which contribute to reduced salary disparities.
Set a goal that the self-sufficiency rate, adjusted for imported feed ingredients, should be at least 50% by 2025 and 60% by 2030.

Investigate a pricing system for concentrated feed, where necessary concentrated feed is priced reasonably, while top consumption based on a feed sheet per livestock category and usage has a higher price.
Investigate how to transfer power, profits, and values from the large grocery corporations to the employees and producers.

Establish an independent commission to conduct a thorough and comprehensive review of animal welfare in all industries. The commission must, among other things, assess what constitutes good animal welfare, whether the laws and regulations ensure adequate animal welfare, and whether the Norwegian Food Safety Authority has the frameworks, tools, and resources necessary for supervision.

Stimulate more extensive animal husbandry with less use of concentrated feed and more use of roughage and pasture, by: - starting a gradual increase in the target price for grain without an increase in price reductions for concentrated feed - prioritizing increased support for pasture and meadow grazing that cannot be harvested mechanically - increasing support for investment in mountain farms through Innovation Norway.

Ensure a dispersed production structure by: - lowering the quota limit for cow's milk to 450,000 liters and goat's milk to 200,000 liters, so that no new productions exceed this - initiating a process to phase out the milk quota exchange and reintroducing state allocation of milk quotas, which should be based on local resource conditions - strengthening smaller livestock producers through an active subsidy ladder with the following subsidy limits: 70 dairy cows, 70 beef cows, 200 other cattle, 200 dairy goats, 300 sheep - setting the following limits for area subsidies: 800 daa of grain, 800 daa of grass, 500 daa of potatoes, 500 daa of vegetables, 100 daa of fruit, 100 daa of berries - removing the bottom deduction.

Increase the framework for this year's agricultural settlement by 1.6 billion kroner, to initiate an income increase for agriculture, strengthen the sector's ability to meet the goals set by the Storting for agriculture, as well as achieve the targets in the agricultural climate agreement.

Present a proposal to establish a commission for future food security. The mandate should be to identify the reasons for the agricultural sector's failure to achieve the goals set by the Parliament for agriculture and the abandonment of farmland, as well as to review the status and development of the economic, social, and ecological sustainability of agriculture, and to assess how the current agricultural policy impacts future food security.
Set a goal to close the income gap between agriculture and comparable groups within four years.

Increase efforts for greater self-sufficiency in Norwegian fruits, vegetables, and legumes by: - reviewing the tariff protection for potatoes, fruits, and vegetables, and considering proposing a change from specific tariffs to ad valorem tariffs for fruits and vegetables that can be grown in Norway, as well as for potatoes - reviewing and improving the subsidy zone system to encourage the production of food plants where the production conditions are adequate - making it more profitable for Norwegian farmers to produce grains, oilseeds, legumes, as well as fruits and vegetables, by prioritizing increased support and risk mitigation measures for these productions - increasing support for new vegetable producers through Innovation Norway.

Propose an animal welfare supplement with criteria that exceed the minimum requirements set by the animal husbandry regulations. Relevant criteria for the program include: - Access to pasture or outdoor areas for pigs. - Access to pasture or winter gardens for poultry. - Access to pasture for male cattle (uncastrated bulls are exempt from the pasture and exercise requirement). - Larger space per animal in the poultry and pig industries. - Greater environmental enrichment for broiler chickens (such as perches and hiding places). - Soft bedding for pigs (such as deep litter and lying mats). - Interaction between cows and calves. - Alternatives to surgical castration of male pigs.

Strengthen soil fertility, carbon sequestration, and biodiversity in agriculture by: - supporting regenerative grazing practices, including the use of virtual fencing - supporting regenerative cultivation methods in crop production - supporting mapping and rewarding of underground biodiversity - supporting management and production methods that enhance biodiversity, including meadows and measures that facilitate pollinating insects and birds - setting minimum requirements for biodiversity areas and crop rotation for the allocation of subsidies.

Ensure that during the summer, an extraordinary and extensive inspection campaign is conducted at Norwegian pig farms, with the aim of uncovering the extent of violations of animal welfare laws through unannounced inspections.
That a target for milk production is set at 7,500 kg/cow/year as the national average.
That a quality subsidy for sheep and cattle is established to promote the use of Norwegian feed.
Remove the bottom deduction.
Introduce a cap on area subsidies for: vegetables 200 acres; berries 80 acres; fruit 80 acres; potatoes 300 acres.
Provide higher subsidies for the first five decares of vegetables, berries, fruits, and potatoes.
Establish a goal that 20% of agriculture in Norway should be organic by 2030, and return to the Storting with a plan for how to achieve that goal.
Investigate how the introduction and design of subsidies for meat quality have affected the potential for utilizing grazing resources.
Implement the structural measures outlined in the agricultural requirements.

Facilitate that agriculture is ensured an annual monetary development that is significantly higher than the wage development in the rest of society in order to reach the same income level. The backlog must be addressed through a binding, time-scheduled escalation plan to close the income gap.
Establish a land conservation goal of a maximum of 2000 decares of cultivated land repurposed by 2026.
Present measures in the state budget to achieve the goal of a maximum reallocation of 2,000 decares by 2026.
Strengthen the relative competitiveness of roughage by reducing the price reduction from grain to compound feed. It is assumed that the change is made within the framework proposed by the government.
Increase the framework in this year's agricultural settlement by 1 billion kroner.
Implement measures to ensure sufficient labor, from both domestic and foreign sources, during this year's growth season.

Initiate new negotiations with agricultural organizations and present a new offer in accordance with the Storting's conditions. A new agreement will be presented to the Storting, and the current agreement will be extended until a new agreement is adopted.
Come back with a plan for decent wage and working conditions. The plan should be developed in collaboration with the parties in the labor market and trade unions.
Ensure that the statistics on the import of organic agricultural products are in place by the end of the year.

Come back with an investment package and a scaling plan for the renewal of loose housing barns in the state budget for 2022, ensuring that the approved loose housing requirement in cattle farming can be met by 2034. The investment program should ensure climate-friendly renewal of loose housing barns and be adapted for use with up to 30 cows, production based on Norwegian natural resources, and increased grazing use. This is important to ensure that the loose housing requirement does not lead to a reduction in the number of active farms.

Return to the Parliament in the state budget for 2022 with measures and instruments that contribute to following up the climate agreement between the state and agriculture, without undermining Norwegian food production based on Norwegian resources and the income of the agricultural sector as the Parliament has anticipated.
Introduce a cap on subsidies to ensure agriculture throughout the country.

Contribute to adjusting and lowering the milk production quota limits to a level that is suited to Norwegian nature, geography, resource base, and agriculture throughout the country. Those who have adapted to the current high level can retain their quotas or sell excess quotas back to the state at an agreed price.

Ensure that the agreement includes a provision from the Norwegian side stating: Norway reserves the right to adopt or maintain any measures regarding the provision of new services that are not included in the industry grouping of the United Nations Provisional Central Product Classification (CPC), 1991.

Conduct a impact assessment of the free trade agreement with the United Kingdom, specifically examining the use of negative lists, freeze and ratchet mechanisms, prohibitions on performance requirements, and national treatment for pre-establishment of investments, prohibitions on tariffs on digital services, and extensive regulatory cooperation. Once the assessment is completed, it must be subject to a public hearing before further consideration by the government and the Parliament. When the assessment is finished, there should be an opportunity to renegotiate parts or the entirety of the agreement.
Include 'new services' in the reservation list of the agreement, provided that this does not delay the entry into force of the agreement.
Ensure a real negotiation right for pensioners in the handling of the welfare settlement, effective from 2022. The Pensioners' Association/SAKO is responsible for the negotiations.

Include a ramp-up plan for the minimum pension in the annual pension settlements so that the level is increased by 7,500 kroner annually, effective from May 1 each year, until the minimum pension reaches the poverty target EU60.
Ensure that the pension settlement in 2021 provides a 3.83% annual growth for ongoing old-age pensions.

Change the regulation of pensions in payment for 2021 in accordance with the demand from LO, YS, FFO, and the Pensioners' Association. This means that the annual growth in ongoing old-age pensions in 2021 should be 3.83% instead of 3.58% as the government has proposed.
Facilitate enhanced training for the elderly councils by seeking to establish a collaboration between the Pensioners' Association, KS, and the Council for an Age-Friendly Norway.
Make assessments on whether the funds for the Cultural Walking Stick should be increased and/or earmarked in future budgets.

Consider whether an annual support of 3 million kroner should be introduced for the Economic Phone and Debt Assistance that the Pensioners' Association and Nav established in 2017, but which is now continued by the Pensioners' Association.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals on how to strengthen the protection of vulnerable elderly people in connection with the state budget for 2022.

Establish an expert committee to investigate issues and possible measures to improve the living conditions for children and young people living at secret addresses. The committee should include user representatives.
Ensure that public entities can also receive the same reimbursement as private actors for conducting testing for the corona certificate as described in Prop. 219 S (2020–2021).
Reintroduce full wage compensation for income up to 6 G for a minimum of 20 days for new layoffs until the end of 2021.

Establish a pay equity fund for salary increases in female-dominated professions in the public sector, which will be in addition to the regular collective bargaining agreements and distributed after negotiations between the parties in the labor market. The pay equity fund should be increased each year over a four-year period with the goal of achieving full pay equity.
Investigate various models to increase taxation of large companies engaged in the rental of commercial real estate, and present proposals for such increased taxation in the state budget for 2022.
Present a proposal for an increased tax on corporate profits in the state budget for 2022.

Present proposals for temporary or permanent changes to the tax system that will help finance the measures implemented in response to the coronavirus pandemic. The proposed changes should be progressive in nature and ensure that individuals with high incomes and/or large fortunes pay more in taxes.
Propose to ban private employment agencies for businesses that are not production companies, and reintroduce a comprehensive public employment service with the goal of full employment.
Propose a temporary reduction of 1 percentage point in the employer's contribution for the period from July to December 2021 in municipalities with unemployment above the national average.

Present a case for the establishment of a six-hour workday fund for the implementation of pilot projects with shorter working hours in municipal management as a measure for increased employment and better working conditions.

Ensure that individual companies and groups that have received government and/or municipal support during the coronavirus pandemic must disclose the grants they have received in the annual accounts of each individual company and summarized for the group where applicable.

Ensure that the whistleblowers from the Home Guard's operational units who have raised the issue of unlawful practices regarding holiday pay and the employment status of voluntary personnel in the Home Guard, and have been taken to court by the Ministry of Defence, receive compensation for their actual legal costs, including their own work and time spent.
Ensure that all individuals who received unemployment benefits in 2020 also receive holiday pay on unemployment benefits in 2021.

Implement the necessary changes to ensure that the work assessment allowance scheme operates in accordance with the National Insurance Act § 1-1 (Purpose), so that no one loses the right to work assessment allowance before they have been fully assessed for work or benefits.

Regulate that businesses receiving support from the compensation scheme for the business sector from the support month of March onwards are obligated not to pay out dividends in 2021 and 2022, unless the received support is first repaid. As part of the regulation, the government is requested to provide an opportunity for exceptions to this dividend prohibition in very special cases upon application.

Regulate that businesses receiving support from the compensation scheme for the business sector from the support month of March are obligated not to pay out bonuses, buy back their own shares, or increase executive salaries or board fees in 2021 and 2022, unless the received support is first repaid.
Explain the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on income and wealth distribution in Norway, including an assessment of how the design of various support measures has affected economic inequality.

Strengthen the control of the support schemes for businesses that were implemented during the coronavirus pandemic, and return to the Parliament as soon as possible with proposals for necessary budget increases for the regulatory authorities.
Do not earmark funds for the purchase of private specialist healthcare services, but rather ensure that these funds are used to strengthen the public healthcare system.
Ensure that the rights of undocumented pregnant women to necessary healthcare before and after childbirth are not billed, so that women do not receive invoices related to childbirth in hospitals.
Extend the temporary extensions of the benefit periods for recipients of work assessment allowance until the end of the year.
Ensure that municipalities exclude the entire child benefit from the income basis in the calculation of social assistance, and allocate funds for compensation for this in the state budget for 2022.
Continue the increased unemployment benefit rate of 80% for income up to 3 G until December 31, 2021.
Extend the reduced minimum income requirement to qualify for unemployment benefits until December 31, 2021.
Return to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2022 with proposals for permanent increases in the rates for social benefits and allowances from the National Insurance Scheme.
Ensure that all long-term recipients of unemployment benefits have their maximum benefit period extended to December 31, 2021.

Give the Tax Administration the authority to grant unemployment benefit amnesty by canceling all or part of the debt for individuals who have outstanding unemployment benefit debt after receiving an advance on unemployment benefits, based on a comprehensive assessment of each individual's financial situation, in order to prevent the collection of unemployment benefit debt from becoming an additional burden for those who have already borne the greatest cost of the coronavirus crisis.
Extend the duration of benefits for self-employed individuals and freelancers until the end of the year, as well as increase the compensation rate for income up to 3 G to 80%.
Extend the temporary compensation benefit for apprentices to include new cases for the rest of the year.
Change the conditions for unemployment benefits until December 31, 2021, so that unemployment benefits are only discontinued when the workload exceeds 80% of normal working hours.
Remove the waiting days in the unemployment benefit scheme until December 31, 2021.
Establish a new climate and nature percentage that will be in addition to the current aid initiatives, no later than in the state budget for 2022.
Convert all corona loans in the Norwegian State Educational Loan Fund to grants.
Create a cultural outreach program for preschool children, based on the model of The Cultural School Bag (DKS).
Incorporate online bullying into the curricula as early as elementary school.
To incorporate a provision in the mandate of the Export Strategy Council that they should work to promote exports from all sectors except for oil and gas.
Come back with a green aid boost, including prioritizing the guarantee scheme for investments in renewable energy in developing countries.
Abolish "Oil for Development" and transfer the resources to "Clean Energy for Development."
Suggest how media support can be used to promote editorial innovation against online harassment.
Present a proposal for a national ombudsman for vocational school students in connection with the state budget for 2022.
Extend the temporary AAP scheme until the end of 2021.
Continue unemployment benefits for apprentices until the end of 2021.
Engage in dialogue with the county municipalities to establish up to 1,000 additional vocational school places for the fall.
Extend the mandate of the working group between the government and KS that assesses the compensation needs of the municipal sector, from July 1, 2021, to January 1, 2022.
Calculate an interest supplement for compensation for lost inventory equivalent to the government's late payment interest from March 1, 2021, until the time the grant scheme opens for applications.
Establish a green state investment company that will invest in floating offshore wind, bioindustry, carbon capture and storage, battery production, hydrogen, and green shipping.

Initiate pilot projects with presence teams in primary schools based on the model from secondary schools. The project will examine whether this can contribute to better oversight and closer follow-up of vulnerable students. Participating municipalities will be compensated, and a follow-up evaluation of the pilot projects will be conducted.

Investigate a scheme for medical students who have obtained a Cand.med. degree in Denmark, which allows them to receive medical authorization after completing their education, so that they can apply for LIS1 in Norway without having completed KBU.
Extend the timeframe for the compensation and stimulation schemes for culture, volunteering, and sports until the end of 2021.
Ensure that the healthcare service at Trandum is placed under the public healthcare system.
Ensure that recipients of work assessment allowance who reach or have reached the maximum duration between November 30, 2020, and July 1, 2021, also have their benefit period extended.
Establish a trial arrangement with selected healthcare enterprises where all positions are advertised as full-time, but where it is possible, by agreement, to have a reduced position.

Review the arrangement of the schemes under chapter 325 item 88 to better address the diversity of cultural actors, including increasing the ceiling per organizer in the compensation scheme, ensuring support for cultural actors who are also registered in the Volunteer Register, and ensuring that applications for support can be submitted at the beginning of the period for which support is being sought.
Reverse the cuts in the order for children's glasses and ensure that all children in need of treatment glasses have their costs covered.
Introduce mandatory labeling schemes that inform about products' expected lifespan and reparability.

Return to the Parliament with a proposal for a legally guaranteed right to repair for consumers and an obligation for retailers to repair, along with proposals to ensure that requirements for durability, access to spare parts, and circular design are incorporated into the Consumer Purchase Act.
Investigate and implement targeted measures to ensure and create new vocational education programs for the circular economy.

Develop more deposit schemes and facilitate more reuse, including by encouraging the establishment of reuse and repair workshops, and return to the Storting in connection with the state budget for 2022.

Investigate a ban on environmentally and health-harmful substances that have significant known negative effects, in product categories such as textiles and leisure and sports equipment that are worn on the body. The ban should also include groups of harmful substances, not just individual substances.

Preserve Siva as an independent actor with ownership in innovation companies and responsibility for the incubation and business garden programs and the Norwegian Catapult, as well as transferring the cluster program from Innovation Norway to Siva.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to extend the complaint period to five years for several products during 2021.
Investigate opportunities to reduce the demolition of buildings and ensure that the reuse of building materials and furnishings is the main rule where buildings are demolished.

Develop a comprehensive national plan against littering. The plan should include measures to achieve zero plastic emissions into nature and for the cleanup of plastic waste and other litter throughout Norway.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals for measures to replace the use of fossil plastics with recycled and renewable plastics.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals for increased requirements for material recycling of plastic and for the use of recycled and renewable raw materials.
Investigate deposit on various types of plastic packaging.
Return to the Storting with a proposal to strengthen the support schemes for solar energy.
Investigate the possibility of full resource utilization for Nussir's mining project in Kvalsund and set requirements for increased resource utilization.
Ensure that reductions in ferry prices are targeted so that they benefit permanent residents.
Implement measures to prevent the trade of biofuels based on raw materials with a high deforestation risk, such as palm oil and soy.
Implement measures to reduce the consumption of raw materials with a high deforestation risk, such as soy for animal and fish feed.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals that remove the obstacles in the regulations for the installation of solar panels.

Establish a national employment strategy, including job creation programs, that maps the future labor needs in both the public and private sectors, and implements necessary measures to meet those needs. The strategy should include skills programs, collaboration across public agencies, and incentive schemes. The goal is to provide a guarantee of a job or training for all able-bodied individuals in the green transition.

Change the structure of the municipal compensation scheme so that the distribution key is based on actual unemployment figures, not population figures. All municipalities should be included in the scheme.

Ensure that Norway joins Important Projects of Common European Interest (IPCEI) in battery production, and initiate new establishments in floating offshore wind, bioindustry, zero-emission shipping, as well as carbon capture and storage.
Launch a large-scale recruitment campaign to attract young people to agriculture, fishing, and reindeer herding.
Investigate models for better permanent income security schemes for freelancers and self-employed individuals based on the experiences from the pandemic.

Investigate the introduction of requirements for the transfer of real estate, as well as restrictions or prohibitions on the use of blank transfer deeds, to prevent issues such as money laundering and tax evasion.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to prohibit dividend payments from businesses that have received support under the compensation schemes introduced during the COVID-19 pandemic. Businesses that have received support and paid out dividends must repay the support.
Introduce duty exemption for chrysanthemums, alstroemeria, and bridal veil from GSP+ countries.
Investigate a fee on land use based on the model from the Green Tax Commission to prevent unnecessary development of untouched nature.
Set the rate of the production tax on wind power to 2 øre/kWh when the tax is introduced.
Open to reduced delay interest in the repayment of deferred claims for companies that commit to significant emission reductions from their own operations.

Establish a support scheme for the event industry with the aim of facilitating the execution of more smaller events during the period when uncertainty related to the future infection situation hinders or complicates the organization of events with a large number of participants.
Let SIVA continue as an independent entity responsible for the incubation and business garden programs and Norwegian Catapult.
Continue SIVA's ownership in innovation companies as it is today.

Send out a supplementary consultation note regarding the proposed change in the resource rent tax on hydropower plants, where the consequences for the affected municipalities are specifically outlined both in the short and long term, while also extending the consultation deadline to three months after the issuance of the supplementary consultation note.

Take the initiative for Helse Sør-Øst RHF to review its model for the allocation and disbursement of investment funds from the health enterprises, and to conduct a new assessment of Sørlandet Hospital HF's finances in order to secure investment funds for a new women's clinic and children's and youth department in Kristiansand.

Ensure that Avinor's conclusion of the tender agreement for duty-free trade for the period 2023–2027 is postponed until after the parliamentary elections and the establishment of a new government, so that any changes in the framework conditions can be taken into account.
Transfer the management responsibility for the cluster program from Innovation Norway to SIVA.

Come back in the 2022 budget with a proposal to reduce or eliminate late payment interest for companies in particularly hard-hit regions or industries that have been granted deferrals for tax and duty claims.
Stop further intake of quota refugees to Norway in 2021.
Start working on establishing an asylum center in a third country, primarily by participating in the signed memorandum of understanding between Denmark and Rwanda.

Ensure that the Norwegian Railway Directorate follows up on the majority remark from the processing of the state budget for 2021 regarding the development of the terminal at Sørli. It is important, logical, rational, and economically beneficial for society to build sufficient track connections to the Sørli terminal at the same time as the double track is being constructed past the terminal.
Ensure that Kaftrio for the treatment of individuals with cystic fibrosis, and CAR-T therapy for lymphatic cancer, is implemented as soon as possible.
Ensure that all businesses with significant revenue declines are included in the compensation scheme for lost inventory, not just those that have been mandated to close.
Investigate and propose the abolition of the current tax amnesty scheme.

Change the wealth tax so that shares, operating assets, and commercial real estate (with assigned debt) are valued at 80%, the rate is increased to 1.1% with an additional rate for wealth over 20 million kroner of 1.3% (+0.2 percentage points), and so that the basic deduction is increased by 200,000 kroner effective from July 1, 2021.

Ensure sufficient presence and jobs in the three airlines with Norwegian operating licenses that have been operating in Norway over time. Government measures should contribute to securing permanent and direct employment with Norwegian wages and working conditions in aviation. State support should not go to the companies' creditors and shareholders.

Come back to the Parliament as soon as possible with a separate case regarding the introduction of a trial scheme for rolling maximum allowable biomass (MTB) that will contribute to increased processing and value creation.

Implement a pilot scheme where the state, county, and industry collaborate on sharing advanced equipment between multiple schools using a mobile unit that can serve several schools in a county/region.

Suspend the work at the Okla wind farm until the appeal case regarding the anchoring method for the wind turbines, which was submitted to the Ministry of Petroleum and Energy on May 26, 2021, has been fully processed.

Come back with an update of 'Meld. St. 36 Energy for Work - Long-term Value Creation from Norwegian Energy Resources' where the IEA's new report 'Net Zero by 2050' is used as a basis for assessments and proposals related to the petroleum sector and the power sector.

Investigate and return to the Parliament with a proposal for a legal basis for a concession fee, environmental fee, or similar in energy legislation so that such a fee can be established in the concession terms. It is essential that the fee represents a predictable value distribution from wind power developers to the affected host municipality. The organizations of the energy sector and the municipal sector must be involved in questions regarding the legal basis, design, and level. A fee should be designed in such a way that it does not hinder the realization of socio-economically profitable projects.

Present a proposal for a material fee for the beverage industry that rewards the use of renewable and recycled materials, as a replacement for the current packaging fee. The competitiveness of products that currently have an exemption from the fee must not be reduced, and the design must be done in dialogue with the affected industries.

Present a compensation scheme for the aviation industry as soon as possible, in line with the framework for a possible such compensation scheme as presented by the government in the proposal for the Revised National Budget 2021, and which helps to compensate for the significant losses the aviation sector has experienced during the pandemic.

Come back with a proposal for the introduction of a natural resource tax for wind power that bypasses the income equalization scheme for municipalities and county municipalities, in order to compensate affected local communities.

Ensure that the Planning and Building Agency has sufficient resources to increase supervision of illegal rentals of apartments that are not approved for permanent residence, as well as to investigate stricter sanctions against landlords who rent out illegally.

Establish a national industrial fund where a portion of the oil fund is allocated to make strategic investments in domestic industrial production with the aim of ensuring technological development, increased export of goods, more industrial jobs, increased value creation, and more processing in Norway.

Ensure increased resources and predictability for organizations that offer holiday activities to families in need, so that this service can be strengthened already this summer and expand the offerings, including on weekends, during autumn and winter breaks for the rest of the year.
Present proposals that give municipalities the opportunity to adjust kindergarten capacity locally, including distinguishing between non-profit and commercial private kindergartens.

Investigate and propose measures to prevent the export of decommissioned ships and ship hulls that create environmental problems in other countries, and instead ensure that these are dismantled and recycled in Norway under strict requirements for material reuse, handling of hazardous substances, and local emissions.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan to ensure the education of sufficient skilled workers in the industrial trades to guarantee that there is qualified labor available for the industry.

Come back to the Parliament with a plan to expand and utilize state ownership in Norwegian industry to retain and further develop industrial production in Norway, increase the level of processing and recycling, and ensure longer value chains in Norwegian industry.

Allocate funds for summer gift cards for families in need, which volunteer organizations can offer to those who cannot participate in organized holiday activities this year due to high demand. The gift cards should be usable for tickets to experiences such as water parks, zoos, cinemas, or other leisure activities that are not already free.

Ensure the necessary review of commercial kindergartens' payments in wages and dividends to owners and other transfers to related parties, ensure that funds not used in accordance with the Kindergarten Act's requirements that grants and parental payments benefit the children in the kindergarten are refunded, and return with necessary amendments to the Kindergarten Act so that the owner can no longer freely dispose of any surplus.

Investigate and propose to the Parliament the establishment of a production facility for ship hulls over 75 meters in connection with the existing shipbuilding industry at a suitable location, in order to facilitate greater maritime value creation in Norway.

Present proposals that ensure the introduction of a transfer and registration obligation for the purchase and sale of residential properties, as well as in cases of inheritance and division of estates, to ensure transparency regarding the actual ownership of all properties.

Establish a public staffing scheme for the shipbuilding industry and other industries that facilitates the lending of labor between production companies, replaces temporary hiring with permanent employment, and ensures working hours/conditions adapted to residents in Norway.

Ensure that companies only receive funds from the compensation scheme for lost income from legal activities, including that rental companies must document that the rental objects they are seeking compensation for are approved for rental by the Planning and Building Agency. If such documentation cannot be provided, any previously received support should also be reclaimed.
Abolish the loan scheme for private kindergartens in Husbanken, but ensure that non-profit kindergartens have access to loans in Husbanken for larger maintenance and rehabilitation projects.

Investigate and propose to the Parliament the establishment of industrial support schemes that provide increased and continuous operations and industrial jobs at Norwegian shipyards for the recycling of obsolete maritime tonnage.

Present a proposal for a pension model for private kindergartens that provides compensation for actual pension expenses, and consider similar subsidy schemes for other expenses, to ensure better alignment between actual costs and subsidy levels, so that subsidies and parental payments benefit the children in the kindergarten.

Investigate and propose the establishment of environmental stations for decommissioned oil installations in connection with the existing shipbuilding industry to carry out tasks related to remediation, dismantling, and material recycling of the oil installations.
