Investigate and propose measures that strengthen the acquisition and concession legislation to protect Norwegian industry from foreign takeovers.
Investigate and return to the Storting with a plan to stop the outsourcing of profitable industry in Norway and to pursue an active policy to bring back industry that has been previously outsourced.
Instruct Health North not to carry out UNN's plans to move the mental health and addiction clinic from Åsgård to Breivika in Tromsø.
Propose to incorporate the ILO's core conventions into the Human Rights Act.
Consider the establishment of an A-crime center in Troms and Finnmark, and return to the Storting in connection with the state budget for 2022.

To conduct an evaluation of the glasses support scheme to see if the changes made have had unintended consequences. The evaluation will also examine whether the various support schemes are well enough known to those in the target group. Additionally, the evaluation will assess whether the support schemes are properly designed so that those who actually have a need genuinely receive it.
Present an assessment of whether a compensation scheme for lost earnings should be introduced for volunteers who are requested by emergency services to assist in rescue operations.

Present a plan to ensure more nurses, social educators, specialized nurses, midwives, and health care workers in the coming years. The plan should include proposals for various measures that contribute to recruitment and ensure enough competent hands and minds in health and care services.
Consider whether and, if so, how the Commandant's Residence in Bergen can be transferred to the Bergen Military Society.
Ensure that private kindergartens' access to financing from the Norwegian State Housing Bank is reinstated until December 31, 2021, or until a new financing solution is adopted by the Parliament.

Investigate the consequences for patients of introducing tenders for medications financed by the National Insurance Scheme and the health economic benefits of the medications, and present the assessment to the Parliament in an appropriate manner. Tenders for medications financed by the National Insurance Scheme will not be implemented until the Parliament has addressed the matter.

Ensure that naprapaths and osteopaths are granted public authorization, and promote a legislative proposal for this as soon as possible over the summer and no later than September, as well as ensure that the temporary VAT exemption is extended until authorization is in place.

Present a package of measures to reduce electricity bills and electricity consumption in Norwegian households. The package should include increased housing support, a significant increase in funding for energy efficiency measures such as insulation of homes, and a substantial increase in support for the establishment of local energy production such as solar panels. The measures should be accessible to low-income households. The package must also include strong incentives for energy-saving measures that can lower electricity bills for people who rent their homes.
Investigate a top pricing system for electricity with the aim of creating a fairer electricity market that distinguishes between regular consumption and luxury consumption.
Present a green tax reform that makes it easier to live environmentally friendly in everyday life.
Introduce a climate percentage where Norway contributes at least 1 percent of GDP each year to climate initiatives in developing countries.

Increase the domestic emissions reduction target to 80 percent and report this as Norway's commitment under the Paris Agreement at the climate summit in Glasgow, to ensure that Norway has a commitment that is proportional to our historical emissions and our responsibility as an oil-producing country.
To cut the price of train and public transport tickets by at least 20 percent.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal for an enhanced night train service between the major cities in Norway and to foreign destinations.

Halt further planning of Hordfast, part of the ferry-free E39, and reallocate funds to a more frequent, emission-free ferry service between Os and Stord/Tysnes, as well as traffic safety measures along the existing E39.
Present a comprehensive analysis of climate and natural risks, including natural accounting, for all major transport projects in the National Transport Plan 2022-2033.
Conduct a power investigation with a particular focus on structures and the balance of power in the labor market.

Facilitate the civil service's ability to respond to questions about climate impact from the party groups in the Storting and provide calculations of the distribution effects of the parties' climate policies.

Initiate a process to hold advisory referendums in the counties of Vestland, Innlandet, and Vestfold and Telemark regarding whether to divide the counties again as the county structure was before January 1, 2020. Where the majority in one of the old counties wishes for this, the government should start a process for dissolution.

Initiate a process to hold an advisory referendum within the boundaries of the former municipality of Søgne, Haram, Verran, Flora, and Vågsøy regarding whether to revert to the municipal structure that existed before the municipal merger that took effect on January 1, 2020. Where the majority desires this, the government should initiate a process for dissolution.
Come to the Parliament with a proposal to establish a scheme where individuals with low income and high expenses can apply for coverage of heating costs.
Present a message to the Storting about living conditions in cities, where recommendations made by the Jenssen Committee are followed up.
Present a case to the Storting with proposals for sanctions to combat harassment in the fisheries.
Maintain Andøya Air Station as a base for our maritime surveillance aircraft.

Follow up on the EU Commission's initiative for a multilateral commitment not to allow further extraction of fossil energy resources in the Arctic or adjacent regions, and not to purchase such products if they are produced anyway.

Submit a proposal to the Storting no later than the spring of 2022 on how the Penal Code can be amended with the aim of defining rape as sexual intercourse without genuine consent, in accordance with international conventions.

Reject all requests for assistance to come to Norway from individuals who have joined the Islamic State (IS). Exceptions can be made for children, provided that their parents are not brought to Norway.
Conduct a comprehensive investigation into Ullevål Hospital as an expansion alternative to Gaustad.
Come back to the Parliament with concrete proposals for reduced electricity tax and VAT for 2022, no later than in the supplementary proposal to the state budget for 2022.
Present the announced new climate plan to the Storting no later than the end of February 2022.
Evaluate the effects of neutral value-added tax in healthcare enterprises and present this to the Parliament before any changes are made to the scheme.

Present a proposal for a temporary increase in housing support and social assistance to ensure that people with limited financial means have money to pay the high electricity bills that are on the way.
Come back with a scheme for a electricity grant for the winter of 2021/2022, as an additional grant for all full-time students to cover increased electricity costs this winter.
Ensure that extraordinary payments of housing support do not lead to deductions from other benefits.

Ensure equal treatment of all who need housing support in the fall of 2021, by ensuring that everyone who, for various reasons, does not qualify for housing support in November 2021, but who was granted it in October 2021, also receives an extraordinary payment.
Strengthen the housing support scheme so that more households with low income and high housing costs qualify for assistance.
Present a crisis package for ordinary people, where the tax burden is reduced so that more can live off their own income.
Expand the discretionary funds for distribution to housing expenses in the municipalities.
Present proposals to strengthen student benefits so that they can cover unexpectedly high electricity costs.
Ensure that minimum pensioners still have the right to receive increased housing support even if the minimum pension has increased.

Present a case to the Storting that ensures that electricity and heating costs are included in the basis for the payment of housing support for all groups, regardless of whether these costs are paid through rent or common expenses or are not included in these.

Ensure that Nav, when processing applications for social assistance to cover high heating costs in the upcoming winter months of 2021/2022, does not impose conditions regarding the sale of necessary assets such as housing, cars, or other valuable items, nor require the use of savings.

Ensure that the funds Enova was unable to distribute to private households in 2021 are earmarked for energy efficiency measures in existing municipal housing and other initiatives that target low-income groups.

Come back to the Parliament with the proposal for changes to the state budget for 2021, where student support is increased to a level equivalent to 1.5 G for the months of November and December. The entire increase shall be paid out as a grant.

Investigate and propose a cap on the income recognition of resource rent tax from the power industry. Resource rent tax revenues exceeding this cap are assumed to be distributed back to the people residing in Norway.

Use next year's extraordinary income from Statkraft and increased resource rent tax revenues from the power industry to pay out a cash amount equivalent to 2000 kroner per person. The amount is expected to be paid out as early as possible in January.
Investigate and propose a cap on state revenue from dividend payments from Statkraft. Dividends exceeding this cap should be distributed back to residents of Norway.

Disburse 4,000 kroner in cash support to all households in the country, to compensate for the very high electricity costs. This should also include separate rental units with their own electricity meters. This should be paid out as soon as possible, and no later than the end of 2021. The proposal for funding will be incorporated into the new budget for 2021.

Introduce a targeted and socially oriented financial support scheme for Norwegian households and students as compensation for abnormally high electricity prices, so that this can be disbursed as early as possible in 2022. The scheme should be aimed at those who are struggling the most. This could be achieved, for example, through a limitation based on household income and a support amount that increases with the size of the household. Students living away from home should have their grants increased by a minimum of 1,000 kroner.

Ensure that Enova, in light of the serious electricity situation, makes at least 300 million Norwegian kroner available for measures in households and for consumers, in accordance with the governance agreement on the management of funds from the climate and energy fund.

Come back to the Parliament with possible measures that can reduce the economic burden on households in the short term, and specifically look at measures that can assist groups that are particularly hard hit by extraordinarily high electricity prices.
Ensure that the proposed extraordinary housing support payment in December will not be deducted from other benefits one is already receiving, or from future housing support payments.
Assume a grant of 2,950 kroner for each household for December 2021, and that households consisting of multiple people receive an additional 120 kroner per person beyond the first.

Promote a proposal that removes the additional tax on wages in the financial sector while simultaneously increasing the tax on profits from financial institutions by an equivalent amount to cover the revenue loss.
Investigate how taxation on secondary homes can be increased.
Increase the maximum property tax rate for residential and vacation homes to 7 per mille.
Investigate the introduction of a socially redistributive inheritance tax with a high exemption threshold, and with an additional progressive rate for inheritances over 20 million kroner.

Investigate how the value-added tax system can be changed to ensure that the tax advantage of electric cars compared to fossil fuel cars at the time of purchase is replicated for car leasing, and report back to the Parliament with proposals in the revised national budget.
Investigate and propose the introduction of a CO2 tax on imported goods that are produced with high greenhouse gas emissions.

Investigate a fee for freight transport on roads in corridors where there is also railway. The investigation should assess different types of fees, including a toll fee, as well as the scope for this within the EEA Agreement. The investigation must also evaluate which routes the scheme may be suitable for.
Investigate tax exemptions for hybrid and fully electric ships based on the model of the electric car scheme.

Remove the possibility of taking tax-free dividends by eliminating the shielding deduction for stock dividends, and return to the Parliament with the necessary proposals regarding this in the state budget for 2023.
Investigate the introduction of a fair and progressive tax on luxury inheritances, to prevent the formation of dynasties where power and enormous fortunes are passed down tax-free.
Make a new assessment of whether the municipalities of Kvitsøy and Utsira should be moved from zone 2 in the differentiated employer's contribution scheme, and report back to the Storting on this.
Promote a proposal for an exemption from the CO2 tax for natural gas used as a raw material for hydrogen production where CO2 is permanently stored.
Not to reintroduce the totalisator tax. At the same time, it is requested that the exemption from tax benefits equestrian sports purposes, and not a private foundation.

Come back to the Parliament in connection with the revised national budget for 2022 with a proposal to change the VAT compensation scheme for sports, volunteer work, and culture so that it becomes rule-based instead of being granted as a block grant.
Maintain the gift enhancement scheme and evaluate it before any potential changes, increases, or discontinuation.
Return to the Parliament with a new legislative proposal on collaboration regarding e-health solutions.
Grant private actors exemptions from the costs associated with the operation and maintenance of government-mandated e-health solutions.
That the annual changes in costs for the municipal sector are discussed in the consultation scheme with KS.

Ensure that the growth in costs for management and operations, which is a consequence of investment decisions and measures in the national e-health portfolio, is made visible and addressed in the national governance model for e-health.

Ensure that the pricing models for the national e-health solutions are evaluated and adjusted based on experiences with the arrangements by 2024, and that the municipalities' share of cost growth is based on an assessment of the benefits for the municipal health and care services.

Utilize available means to ensure that Norwegian funds support education in Palestinian schools that is ethically sound and lays the foundation for peaceful coexistence and tolerance for future generations in the region.
To ensure that unused funds from Norway's military engagement in Afghanistan in 2022 are earmarked for strengthening the Cyber Defense.
Establish a Global Health Innovation Hub in Oslo.

Intensify efforts to ensure that pharmaceutical companies prioritize vaccine deliveries to Covax, as well as work towards the implementation of principles of transparency at all levels, particularly in contracts made with pharmaceutical companies.
Return to the Storting with a follow-up on NOU 2020: 5 Equality Before the Law no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2022.

Promote a proposal for a legal obligation so that all municipalities and county municipalities in the country must be connected to eInnsyn, and suggest how the financing of this should be carried out.
Introduce a support scheme for those who have high heating costs but do not qualify for housing support.
Look into the possibility of giving the county municipalities more responsibilities.
Ensure full funding for the user equipment at the Machine Laboratory and the Construction Laboratory at the Ocean Space Centre in the budgets for 2023 and 2024.

Provide the municipalities in the pilot project for state-funded elderly care with the funds they would have received if the project had continued as planned, against a corresponding reduction in the resident grant.
Ensure that the Norwegian State Housing Bank also includes municipal crisis centers in its arrangements.
Establish an expert committee for water and wastewater to address the significant backlog and investment needs in municipalities in a cost-effective and sustainable manner.
Establish a basis of 27 million kroner in annual funding within chapter 572 item 60.
Consider extending the mandate of the working group that is mapping the municipal sector's additional expenses and loss of income due to the coronavirus pandemic for the entirety of 2022.
Shield the regional health enterprises from the ABE reform.
Ensure that all health enterprises have arrangements for their own pool of temporary staff/recruitment units with permanently employed substitutes.
Ensure that the maternity department in Kristiansund is preserved, even after the new hospital in Hjelset is operational.
Abolish the system of neutral value-added tax in health enterprises and promote this in connection with the state budget for 2023.
Enter into national agreements on coronavirus vaccination and testing with private health actors.
Work to ensure that children referred by a school nurse or doctor to a local optician have the entire or part of the eye examination covered through public funding.
Ensure that the medication Kaftrio is used for the treatment of individuals with cystic fibrosis as soon as possible.
Allocate funds so that ALS patients in Norway can stay at the ALS house Rosenlund Park in Løten.
Initiate the planning of a fully equipped maternity ward in Alta municipality during 2022.
Ensure that the IT systems of the mammography program are updated so that women do not risk delayed breast cancer diagnosis.
Ensure that the public healthcare system is able to offer early ultrasound and that NIPT becomes available to all pregnant women.
To ensure that the construction of the new Stavanger University Hospital does not come to a halt.
Investigate a fund for large hospital investments.

Investigate the consequences for patients of introducing tenders for medications financed by the National Insurance Scheme and the health economic benefits of the medications, and present the assessment to the Parliament in an appropriate manner. Tenders for medications financed by the National Insurance Scheme will not be implemented until the Parliament has addressed the matter.

Implement measures that facilitate the ability of laid-off workers, students, disability pensioners, and retirees to work in municipalities and health enterprises with tasks that can quickly relieve the staff in health and care services. It must be ensured that the income limit for students and the deductions for benefits and pensions do not apply to those working in the healthcare sector during the pandemic, as long as there is a need for additional workforce due to the coronavirus pandemic.
Conduct a new assessment of how the COVID-19 crisis has affected municipal finances, and that municipalities are compensated for increased expenses and reduced revenues.

Ensure that tenders for publicly funded medications are organized in such a way that no patients are required to change treatment unless they wish to do so themselves. The Parliament requests the government to facilitate that tenders for publicly funded medications are limited to the initiation of new treatments and when the patient must change treatment for medical reasons.
Ensure that health enterprises offer more educational positions for nurses and midwives.
Establish as a principle in future concession processes that the development of onshore wind power should not lead to the degradation of nature or the weakening of indigenous rights.
Investigate and implement a nature tax on land use to limit the degradation of Norwegian nature, and return to the Storting with a proposal in connection with the state budget for 2023.
Require municipalities to make visible and assess the climate consequences in all relevant matters for political consideration.
Require municipalities to eliminate all fossil emissions from their operations by 2025.
Follow up on the Parliament's decision to ensure equal treatment of biogas vehicles with zero-emission vehicles on routes that are financed by tolls.
Consider restructuring the current tariff system with the aim of facilitating increased development of fast chargers in rural areas.

Postpone the regulation on performance-based tariffs, which is scheduled to come into effect on January 1, 2022, and return to the Parliament with a proposal for a grid fee model that is simpler for consumers and encourages increased energy efficiency.
Ensure more accurate climate statistics for the municipalities, which will be published in the following calendar year.

Follow up on the Parliament's decision to facilitate a faster application process for gas distributors applying for investment support for filling stations from Enova, as well as to immediately improve Enova's support scheme for filling stations and the purchase of heavier vehicles using biogas as fuel.

Demand that the charging industry provide more user-friendly solutions for electric vehicle drivers, such as better signage, clearer pricing, reduced downtime, simpler payment solutions, and fast charging stations with restroom facilities.

Assuming that the principal consequence of the Supreme Court's ruling on October 11, 2021, HR-2021-1975-S, is that the wind power plants at Storheia and Roan must be dismantled so that the rights of the Sámi reindeer herders to practice their culture can be fulfilled by restoring the reindeer grazing areas.

Develop a plan that demonstrates the potential for small-scale wind power production in ports, industrial areas, and other locations where wind power can be expanded without conflicting with environmental considerations and indigenous rights, including assessing adjusted distance requirements for shorter turbines in such areas, and report back to the Parliament no later than the end of 2022.
Ensure that all municipalities and county municipalities must have their own binding, politically adopted climate budget as a governance document.
Stop all ongoing and planned wind power development.
Ensure sufficient state support for Fortum Oslo Varme so that CCS at the Klemetsrud facility can start in 2023 and be implemented as quickly as possible.

Present a national natural accounting system with an accompanying natural budget, aiming for zero net loss of nature (measured in condition and extent) by 2025, nature positivity by 2030, and a 20% improvement by 2050.
Investigate and implement deposit systems for more types of single-use products, similar to what exists for cans and bottles today.
Present a plan for phasing out fossil gas for heating.
Investigate and propose a ban on the export of unsorted household waste.
Return to the Storting with a proposal for a ban on the degradation of wetlands.
Make Klimasats a permanent arrangement leading up to 2030, with annual increases.
Present a plan for how the goal of protecting 10% of Norwegian forests can be achieved by 2030.
Consider transferring the responsibility for the Directorate for Mineral Management from the Ministry of Trade and Fisheries to the Ministry of Petroleum and Energy.

Establish a compensation scheme for affected industries that have been severely impacted by the energy crisis, which compensates for the significantly increased electricity costs. The scheme will be presented to the Parliament at the beginning of January, with effect from the extraordinary costs incurred since November 2021.
Require the grid companies not to implement a new model for grid fees from January 1, 2022, which includes a peak hour charge for electricity usage during certain times of the day.

Utilize paragraph 12 in Statnett's concession terms for facilitating power exchange via the foreign cables NordLink and North Sea Link with the aim of limiting net power exports to improve the current power situation and ensure sufficient power reserves during the winter months.
To require Statnett to use alternative two (cable in trench) when renewing the connection between Hamang in Bærum and Smestad in Oslo, as part of the Oslo Network Plan.

Postpone the implementation of the new model for grid fees, which was announced to be introduced from January 1, 2022, until a new impact assessment of what this will mean for households and businesses has been conducted and presented to the Parliament.

Promote proposals that ensure that all companies with a significant state ownership stake set binding goals and develop plans to phase out all nature- and climate-damaging activities, as well as report on their contributions to achieving the Paris Agreement and a goal of a nature-neutral Norway.

Promote a proposal for funding to establish Bionova. The mandate should, in addition to Bionova being a financing mechanism to support climate initiatives in agriculture, also support systematic innovation and increased commercialization of all bio-based value creation in Norway.

Establish a grant scheme under Bionova where agricultural businesses and other companies that develop bio-based and sustainable value creation can apply for support for climate measures such as the purchase of emission-free tractors, installation of solar panels on operational buildings, biogas production, and other machinery, technologies, and methods that can contribute to more climate-friendly operations.

Propose the establishment of a center for circular economy linked to a university environment. The center will have the mandate to be a driving force for a circular Norwegian economy, including by investigating and proposing producer responsibility schemes for all relevant industries and products, industry standards for recycling raw materials, improved solutions for material recovery, and conducting research and development in the field of circular economy.

Adjust the production tax on salmon, trout, and rainbow trout in a way that provides host municipalities that focus on sustainable aquaculture (minimal escapes, lice, and environmental emissions) with a larger share of tax revenues than municipalities that facilitate conventional, open facilities.

Present a proposal for an investment support scheme for breeders transitioning to sustainable aquaculture technology with zero lice, zero escapes, and zero emissions. The maximum support rate is set at 40% of the investment.
Present a proposal for an investment support scheme for fish welfare measures in the aquaculture industry.
Establish a government center for alternatives to animal testing, for example based at the Norwegian Veterinary Institute and Norecopa.

Promote a proposal to increase support for Matsentralen Norway to enable them to redistribute more food and reduce food waste, in connection with the government's announcement of the introduction of a food waste law.
Establish a contingency stockpile for food grains.
Investigate and present a proposal for a grant scheme to increase the use of Norwegian timber, with the aim of enhancing the further processing of timber in Norway.

Report to the Parliament on how the temporary law has been applied and what experiences the parties have had with the use of the exception provisions, what consequences the application has had, including to what extent the county boards have used the exception provisions, and how many children have been moved to another institution.
Replace the toll portion in the revised Bømlopakke in Vestland with state funds.
Remove the requirement to reduce toll fees in order to access the funds through an additional agreement to the urban development agreements.
Come back to the Parliament with a comprehensive plan for the pricing and discount structure for ferry operations, both for national and county road ferries.

Consider how the competitive disadvantages for island communities that only have access to fast boat services can be mitigated in relation to island communities that are now experiencing reduced transportation costs in the form of lower ferry prices, and return to the Parliament with a proposal in the revised national budget for 2022.
Explain how county municipalities and national road connections will be compensated for the additional costs of ordering zero-emission vessels.
Return to the Storting with a proposal for further consideration of U-864 based on the professional assessment made by the appointed committee.
Engage in dialogue with the ferry companies with the aim of making the temporary ticketing system that has been in place during the pandemic permanent.
Take the initiative to repeal the decision on the incorporation of the legal acts included in the EU's Fourth Railway Package.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to introduce a prepayment-based compensation scheme for the victims of the welfare scandal, based on the model from the Netherlands.

Come back to the Storting with a proposal to change the legal aid scheme for the victims of the welfare scandal, so that those who believe they have been treated unfairly by Nav can receive legal aid regardless of whether the Labor and Welfare Administration has made a new decision in their case.

Promote necessary proposals for amendments to the National Insurance Act to ensure that when assessing whether the conditions for disability benefits are met, only the impact of the medical disability on future income opportunities can be considered.
Promote necessary proposals to introduce activity requirements for all age groups receiving social assistance.
Promote necessary legislative proposals to ensure the right to unemployment benefits and sick pay for all employees regardless of age.
Stop the demand for repayment of unemployment benefits for older workers who received these payments from Nav during the coronavirus pandemic.
Ensure that the company qualifies for support even if the company implements full or partial layoffs of other employees during the support period.
Work to strengthen the international legal protection of children held in armed conflict.
Investigate how our national legislation can strengthen the protection of children held in armed conflict, including provisions on repatriation.
Take the initiative in the Security Council to impose sanctions against Israel's violations of international law.
Take the initiative in the Security Council to impose sanctions against Turkey for its violations of international law.

Come back to the Parliament with an overview of the current licenses for the sale of A- and B-material and instances where the sale of equipment or weapons is used as a means to suppress one's own population or violate international law.
Investigate the consequences for businesses and effective export control of merging the lists of A- and B-material.
Ensure an immediate halt to all exports of strategic goods to countries participating in the civil war in Yemen.
Stop all exports of Norwegian strategic goods to countries where the military and security apparatus are instrumental in systematic and serious human rights violations.

The Storting shall be continuously updated on changes in exports to the countries in the Saudi-led coalition that is intervening in Yemen, and shall be informed immediately if there are changes in the export of strategic goods to these countries, based on the precautionary principle of avoiding Norwegian goods contributing to violations of international law.
The requirement for end-user documentation will become standard practice in all exports of strategic goods, including to NATO countries and close allies.
Publicize the justifications for the rejection and approval of license applications to countries outside NATO.

Strengthen the openness of the Norwegian export control regime and elaborate on the possibility of introducing a similar practice as that in the Netherlands, where Parliament is publicly informed about the approval of export licenses over a certain amount, except to the closest allies, with details on the assessment of the criteria against the application within two weeks after the application is approved.

Present a proposal for an amendment to the export control regulations to ensure that Norwegian digital surveillance technology is not exported to countries where there is a risk that the technology will be used in violation of human rights.

Strengthen the preventive work towards potential exporters of strategic goods and clarify to companies that export strategic goods that they are responsible for conducting independent risk assessments and reporting on the follow-up of this as part of the annual parliamentary report on the export of strategic goods.
Return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner with an overview of how the Netherlands has increased the level of parliamentary control over the export of A and B materials.
Ensure that the export of biometric surveillance technology falls under the Norwegian export control's definition of dual-use goods.

Establish a public committee to conduct a comprehensive review of the Norwegian export control regime, including both the regulations and the administrative aspects, to ensure real and verifiable compliance with the Parliament's decision from 1959 and the clarification from 1997, as well as with international obligations. Additionally, the committee should assess whether there is a need for further clarifications in line with Norway's obligations under international law, humanitarian law, and human rights law.

Ensure that an independent investigation is initiated into the export of strategic goods to countries involved in the Yemen war, with a mandate to examine the risk that Norwegian-produced strategic goods have been used in Yemen.

Interpret criterion 2 in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' guidelines for export control, regarding the human rights situation in recipient countries, more strictly than today, and ensure that Norway does not export strategic goods to regimes responsible for serious human rights violations.
The UN's Arms Trade Treaty (ATT) Articles 6 and 7 are included in law or regulation.

To develop control mechanisms that enable the verification of end-user declarations, for example through a sampling mechanism, and which are reported in the annual parliamentary report on the export of strategic goods.

Have the Paris Agreement and the Climate Goals Act, as well as considerations regarding climate risk for the Norwegian economy, as a framework for the further development of Norwegian petroleum activities and limit future license awards to expansions or extensions of already existing production in mature areas.
Stop all allocation of exploration licenses on the Norwegian continental shelf, both through numbered licensing rounds and through the TFO scheme.
Ensure that a plan for drainage of the high-risk area for large rockslides at Åkneset in Stranda municipality is quickly developed.
Come back to the Storting with a new and enhanced electricity package before the electricity bill for January is issued, based on preliminary experiences with electricity prices.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to temporarily raise the income limit for applying for housing support during the period from January 1 to March 31, 2022, so that even more people can qualify to receive housing support.
Ensure that recipients of disability benefits, work assessment allowance, and similar benefits who have low income and high housing costs are given the opportunity to apply for housing support.

Register the development of hiring from all staffing agencies and create statistics by industry and county, including the proportion from EU member states, and present proposals for measures that prevent the development seen in, among others, the construction industry from spreading to other sectors.

Introduce a ban on the hiring of labor from private companies that are not production companies at construction sites in the former counties of Oslo, Akershus, Østfold, Buskerud, and Vestfold, cf. the Working Environment Act § 14-12 (5).
Promote proposals that lead to increased basic staffing and strengthened public employment services, so that businesses are ensured the necessary workforce.
Promote a proposal for a ban on the hiring of labor from private companies that are not production companies.

Present a proposal for a piercing the corporate veil norm regarding circumventions of the Working Environment Act § 1-10, and that such a norm should be applicable by a low-threshold dispute mechanism, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Propose to clarify in the Working Environment Act § 14-2 first paragraph that "a group of enterprises connected through ownership interests or common management" also includes group-like enterprises, chains, and cooperatives.
Ensure that Aker Hospital is planned and developed based on the fact that Aker Hospital will become the local hospital for the entire Groruddalen.
Initiate a new investigation and review of the hospital options for the Oslo region, including the preservation of Ullevål Hospital.
Ensure that Aker Hospital quickly becomes a fully-fledged local hospital for all neighborhoods in Groruddalen.

Initiate an investigation into alternative development opportunities for Oslo University Hospital and return to the Parliament with proposals on how an investigation of the location alternatives can be structured.
To stop the closure of Ullevål Hospital and not to initiate the sale of the Ullevål site.
To demolish existing functional building stock at Oslo University Hospital.

At Gaustad Hospital is preserved as a treatment institution for patients within mental health care and interdisciplinary specialized substance abuse treatment, and that plans that prevent the use of the hospital and its areas for this patient group are halted.
To return in the revised national budget for 2022 with a proposal to introduce free dental care for individuals aged 19 to 21 and to implement half-price dental care for individuals aged 22 to 25.
That the grant follows price developments.

Present a dental health reform to the Parliament that includes a concrete plan for the phased implementation of a universally accessible dental health service within four years, where teeth are treated as part of the body and dental health services are equated with other health services, for example through a co-payment scheme.
Propose to expand the public dental health service by gradually including new groups and increasing the funding for dental treatment from the National Insurance Scheme.

Promote proposals to reverse the weakening of the coverage scheme for orthodontic expenses for children and young people, and ensure the strengthening of the support scheme for individuals in need of orthodontics.

Consider measures that can help prevent the centralization and closure of public dental health clinics, including examining the need for initiatives that can increase recruitment in professional and geographical areas where it is currently challenging to find qualified personnel. The Parliament requests the government to also implement measures related to larger chains' acquisitions of dental treatment clinics in this context.
Consider how the skills of dental hygienists can be utilized more effectively for prevention and to address dental health-related tasks, for example in nursing homes and assisted living facilities.

Ensure that the dental health reform aimed at equalizing dental health services with other health services includes measures that guarantee that increased public funding is fully directed towards the health services, including the consideration of a price cap on publicly funded dental care.

Ensure a temporary halt to all sales of hospital properties currently used for mental health care and interdisciplinary specialized substance abuse treatment, pending a public investigation related to the need for and future organization of hospital treatment for patients within mental health care and interdisciplinary specialized substance abuse treatment.
Investigate the need for long-term placements within mental health care, with particular attention to the need for hospital beds for patients who are sentenced to involuntary mental health care.

Evaluate the funding model for mental health care and interdisciplinary specialized substance abuse treatment, as well as the funding model for new hospital buildings, which makes it attractive for health enterprises to sell the plots currently used for mental health care in order to finance new hospital constructions.

Establish a public committee with a broad professional composition to investigate the advantages and disadvantages of a large-scale co-location of mental health care and interdisciplinary specialized substance abuse treatment with somatic care in the major hospitals.

Adopt a regulation to immediately extend changes to the unemployment benefit scheme that ensure those who qualify for unemployment benefits receive a compensation rate of 80% on income up to 3 G until further notice, or promptly return to the Parliament with a proposal for a legislative amendment to the same effect.
Promote a proposal to extend the temporary scheme for self-employed individuals and freelancers who lose income due to the coronavirus outbreak, with a compensation rate of 80%.

Promote a proposal to grant part-time working students receiving study support the right to unemployment benefits, on par with other employees. This is a temporary arrangement. The change will take effect immediately, and payments will be made as soon as Nav has implemented a technical solution.
Reduce the number of employer-funded sick days from 16 to three days for absences due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Ensure that freelancers are entitled to sickness benefits from the National Insurance Scheme from the fourth day of sick leave due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Ensure that self-employed individuals are entitled to sickness benefits from the National Insurance Scheme from the fourth day of sick leave due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Ensure that the electricity support scheme is based on a threshold set at 35 øre/kWh for consumption up to 2,000 kWh and 70 øre/kWh for consumption between 2,000 and 5,000 kWh. Furthermore, a tiered state coverage will be introduced with 100% compensation for consumption up to 2,000 kWh and 50% compensation for prices above 70 øre/kWh for consumption between 2,000 and 5,000 kWh, for the months of December 2021 and January, February, and March in 2022.

Introduce a maximum price for electricity of 50 øre per kWh excluding value-added tax from January 1 to March 31, 2022, which will apply to all electricity customers, from households and secondary residences to voluntary and non-profit organizations, as well as businesses and companies.
Calculate the average electricity price based on daily prices, to ensure that people receive support for their actual consumption.
Ensure that the extended electricity support scheme also applies to the electricity bill for December 2021.
Promote proposals to the Parliament for a suitable regulation of the electricity market in the long term, in order to counteract the extremely high electricity prices currently being observed.

Establish an application-based municipal compensation scheme to assist small businesses and voluntary associations and organizations that are currently struggling with high electricity prices. The scheme should be limited to municipalities in the pricing areas of Southern Norway, and support for businesses must be restricted to those where electricity costs represent a significant proportion of their revenue. The grant must comply with state aid regulations. Municipalities with significant additional income from ownership in power companies or power production should not be included in the scheme, but these municipalities are encouraged to create similar schemes within their own framework. The grant funds will be allocated as discretionary funds distributed through the county governor. The government is requested to propose an appropriate framework for the scheme, for example, 2 billion kroner. Funds that are not disbursed will be refunded to the state.
Consider how support for high electricity prices can be targeted towards households with low incomes based on data on electricity consumption and household income.

Come back with an evaluation of the support measures for electricity, including socio-economic consequences and distribution effects. The relationship between households' income and electricity consumption should be highlighted.

Introduce a maximum price for electricity at 35 øre/kWh, which will be imposed on the sale of power from Norwegian power producers to customers in Norway (households, businesses, etc.), in accordance with the law on price measures.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that combines a maximum price on electricity with a top price system for households through either VAT or electricity tax, where the maximum price applies to consumption up to a certain limit, while the price for luxury consumption is set higher.

Return to the Storting no later than autumn 2022 with a proposal for a long-term and redistributive model to manage high electricity prices. The proposal must include concrete and proactive investments in energy efficiency and local energy production aimed at households and businesses. It is assumed that the government, in a redistributive model, will also consider a system where the state's increased revenues from electricity sales are distributed back to Norwegian citizens.

Investigate the introduction of a maximum electricity price for households and businesses. The investigation must, among other things, examine the effect on household prices over time, distribution effects, incentives for energy efficiency, and limitations on consumption.
Introduce a maximum price for electricity of 0.50 NOK per kWh excluding VAT. This applies to everyone, both households and businesses.

Promote a case to the Storting with proposals for the necessary measures to ensure that Norwegian consumers and businesses have stable access to electricity at the prices that have been common in Norway, which are significantly lower than those that have been common in many other European countries.

Investigate the introduction of a two-tier pricing system where a lower electricity price is set and lower taxes are applied for consumption up to a certain level, with normal prices above this level. The distribution effects and the impact on energy efficiency must be considered.
Follow up and tighten requirements for energy efficiency in commercial buildings in line with the goals adopted by the Parliament to improve the energy efficiency of buildings by up to 10 TW.

Utilize the available private capacity to relieve the public healthcare system. This is especially important in light of an expected peak in infections in January/February, which will further burden hospitals, in addition to primary healthcare services and general practitioners. Also, ensure that as many planned surgeries and other procedures as possible can be carried out as scheduled by using the available private capacity that is ready.

Set a goal for the share of travelers using public transport and rail, walking, and cycling to return to the same level as before the pandemic and then continue to grow as a contribution to achieving climate goals.
Change the support schemes for the cultural sector so that more cultural institutions are included in the scheme, including large private venues that currently fall outside the scheme.
Ensure sufficient funding for public transport services so that the public transport offerings are at least as good after the pandemic as they were before the pandemic.
Return to the Storting in the revised national budget for 2022 with a proposal to increase corporate tax from the income year 2023.
Extend the stimulation scheme for cultural actors until August 1, 2022. After this, the Parliament will assess further extensions of the scheme in relation to other measures.
Ensure that outstanding interest debt on deferred tax and fee claims is waived for businesses in sectors affected by state or municipal infection control measures.
Ensure that the compensation scheme and the stimulation scheme for the cultural sector are governed by regulations.
Come back with a plan for the reconstruction and strengthening of the cultural sector after the pandemic.

Establish a public committee to assess how the coronavirus pandemic affects inequality in society, monitor economic disparities and the accumulation of wealth due to the crisis, and evaluate measures against inequality and unjust gains.
Introduce a national compensation scheme for employees in healthcare enterprises who work in hospital departments that have experienced an extra heavy burden due to COVID-19.
Ensure that organizations engaged in educational and knowledge journeys aimed at youth do not experience a reduction in their income base as a result of the pandemic.
Ensure that the upcoming tender takes into account national preparedness needs by weighting the award criteria and dividing the procurement in a way that considers small and medium-sized enterprises.
Investigate the possibility of entering into long-term preparedness agreements with Norwegian producers so that the country can be as well-prepared as possible for future crises.
Ensure that private healthcare providers with additional costs related to the pandemic receive compensation for these.
Ensure that companies donating food to charity due to the coronavirus situation are not required to pay taxes and value-added tax on this, by utilizing already established exemption provisions.

Present a motivation scheme with the aim of bringing back former intensive care nurses who are currently working in other professions, so that they can help alleviate the pressure on the healthcare system.
Change government support schemes for the cultural sector so that they are based on the same conditions as general grant schemes for business activities.
Ensure that the right to pay in installments under both schemes for temporary deferral of tax and fee payments does not cease even if the established payment deadlines are not met.
Come back with proposals for the reintroduction of the guarantee scheme for aviation or another similar compensation scheme to support the aviation industry.
Not calculating late payment interest on deferred tax and duty claims for the period from January 15 to March 31, 2022.

Ensure that operations at Norwegian airports are maintained during the pandemic, and that a case is presented to the Storting as soon as possible, including an assessment of the situation and necessary measures to ensure operations at both state-owned and non-state airports.
Present an analysis of the development in demand for public transport in 2022 and the economic consequences it has for the county municipalities and public transport companies.
Assess the passenger development and financial situation of the public transport companies and present proposals to compensate for the loss of ticket revenues and prevent route cuts.
Set a goal for the share of travelers using public transport and rail to return to pre-pandemic levels and then continue to grow as a contribution to achieving climate goals.
Compensate municipalities and county municipalities for additional expenses and reduced revenues resulting from national, regional, and local infection control measures.
Promote proposals to strengthen the rights of cohabitants in inheritance law.
Investigate a waivable cohabitation law.
Promote necessary proposals to ensure non-profit kindergarten operations.

Propose changes to the financial regulations for private kindergartens that ensure that tax money and parental payments are fully directed towards improving kindergartens and not to profit extraction for owners.

Introduce a reporting obligation and pre-emption right for the municipality in the sale of kindergartens, and promote any proposals for necessary legal amendments to establish such rights and obligations.
Promote the proposals necessary to change the pension subsidy for private kindergartens so that they correspond to the actual pension costs incurred by the kindergartens.

Follow up on the Storberget Committee's report and conduct necessary investigations with the aim of changing the funding system for private kindergartens. The new funding arrangement should ensure democratic governance of the entire kindergarten sector, require that each kindergarten be organized as its own legal entity, enable proper dimensioning of the sector, allow for targeted quality initiatives, ensure greater financial transparency and the possibility of financial oversight, and secure employees' salary, pension, and working conditions.
Present proposals that give municipalities the opportunity and obligation to adapt kindergarten capacity locally, including distinguishing between non-profit and commercial private kindergartens.

Ensure that municipalities are given the opportunity to impose the same requirements on private kindergartens as on public kindergartens, such as prioritizing children with a right to kindergarten placement, the intake of apprentices, and adhering to locally determined staffing norms.

Present a case for introducing stricter regulations on the buying and selling of kindergartens, and prevent short-term owners such as foreign investment funds from acquiring stakes in the kindergarten sector.

Propose to the Parliament to implement changes in the provisions of the Kindergarten Act and regulations regarding public funding for private kindergartens. Public funding must reflect the actual costs of operating kindergartens, based on requirements for staffing, competence, and quality.

Emphasize changes that will contribute to increasing students' motivation, learning, and well-being, and strengthen practical learning, and further that the government includes the sector closely in the work.

Contribute to increasing students' motivation, learning, and well-being by establishing a joint committee that will provide input for the reform. Emphasis will be placed on the participation of children and young people. The proposal for a lower secondary school reform is to be presented to the Parliament no later than the 2023–2024 session, with the aim of coming into effect on January 1, 2025.

Come up with a proposal to clarify the intrinsic value of animals in the penal code and the provisions regarding necessity, so that violence against animals is regarded as more serious than damage to property.
Introduce higher requirements for the transport of production animals in agriculture with the aim of improving animal welfare.
Tighten the requirements for animal welfare in the regulations on pig farming, including setting higher standards for space, bedding, and enrichment materials for slaughter and breeding pigs.

Tighten the requirements for animal welfare in the regulations on the keeping of hens and turkeys, including phasing out fast-growing breeds in favor of breeds where parent animals are not subjected to feeding restrictions, and where the animals do not experience abnormal growth as part of their development.

Include the following elements in the work on a new parliamentary report on animal welfare: To investigate and establish maximum limits for permitted mortality in salmon and smolt production that are significantly lower than current levels, based on updated scientific criteria for acceptable suffering and mortality in salmon populations in production. To identify the main causes of distress and death in salmon production and establish specific requirements and measures to reduce these factors to an ethically and scientifically acceptable level. This includes, among other things, density and other stress factors in cages, lice infestations, methods for lice removal, diseases, and more. To investigate and establish new requirements for acceptable animal welfare and mortality as conditions for retaining licenses and being awarded development licenses. Aquaculture facilities with excessive suffering and mortality should be warned and lose their license if welfare and mortality are not at an acceptable level in the next production cycle.
Investigate how farmers' economy, time use, and expertise affect animal welfare, and propose suggestions on how farmers can be compensated for increased animal welfare requirements.
Propose to increase the penalties for serious violations of the Animal Welfare Act, as well as to raise the fines for grossly negligent violations of the Animal Welfare Act.

Present an animal welfare report that is based on updated knowledge about animal welfare, grounded in professional and factual conditions. The report should address both professional and political issues related to animal husbandry and provide an overview of what we are doing well today, as well as what can be done differently and better in the future. There is a connection between human welfare and animal welfare, and the report should discuss this.

Look at incentives that will improve animal welfare in the pig industry, particularly regarding space, flooring, and environmental enrichment, and impose stricter requirements for animal welfare during upgrades of existing buildings or new constructions.

Present a comprehensive government white paper on animal welfare that includes both production animals in agriculture, pets, and fish farming, no later than the spring session of 2023. The government is requested to elaborate and propose specific measures in the report for improved animal welfare in general and for specific species/groups of animals, including the following topics: to elaborate on how economic instruments in agricultural policy can be designed in a way that rewards good animal welfare. to elaborate on how Norwegian regulations will need to change with the implementation of the EU's announced ban on keeping animals in cages and cramped enclosures. to elaborate on the Norwegian Food Safety Authority's control and guidance functions and the need for resources to ensure adequate follow-up of animal welfare in agriculture. to elaborate on labeling schemes that make it easier for consumers to choose animal-friendly products. Such a labeling scheme can be state-run or private. to elaborate on how pigs can be ensured better access to outdoor areas, for example through subsidy or labeling schemes, or possibly through changes in legislation.

Ensure that research is conducted on alternatives to CO2 stunning of animals in slaughterhouses and the maceration of chicks, with the aim of introducing better methods for euthanasia, and that a ban on current practices can be implemented in the long term.
Ensure that Enova contributes to land power facilities in the important cruise ports.
Come forward with a proposal to the Parliament on how to ensure sufficient power capacity for the Geirangerfjord area by 2026.
Come back to the Storting with a plan to contribute to financing the supply of necessary power capacity to Geiranger.

Come forward with a proposal to the Parliament on how to contribute to ensuring that the Parliament's decision to eliminate emissions from shipping traffic in the World Heritage fjords can increase value creation in the tourism industry in Geiranger and Hellesylt.

Assess the power needs that arise from the goal of business development in the UNESCO World Heritage areas of Geiranger and Nærøyfjorden and the ferry connections there, without greenhouse gas emissions, and return to the Parliament with a proposal on how the government can contribute to meeting the power needs.

Take the initiative for an external quality assurance of the calculations of the socio-economic consequences of cabling versus overhead lines on the planned 420 kV transmission line between Hamang in Bærum municipality and Smestad in Oslo municipality.

Establish a comprehensive socio-economic assessment that takes into account the considerations for development in areas with limited space, public utilization of the land, and the development of the areas, and that this is also done in the case of the planned 420 kV transmission line for power transfer between Hamang in Bærum municipality and Smestad in Oslo municipality.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for an application-based municipal compensation scheme, of at least 1 billion kroner, to compensate small and medium-sized enterprises struggling with high electricity prices.

Ensure that the electricity support scheme for the agricultural and greenhouse sector is based on the threshold for electricity support being set at 35 øre per kWh for consumption by the agricultural and horticultural sectors for the months of December 2021 and January, February, and March in 2022.

Ensure that the electricity support scheme for the agricultural and greenhouse sector is based on the threshold for electricity support being set at 50 øre per kWh for consumption for the agricultural and greenhouse sector for the months of December 2021 and January, February, and March in 2022.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal for electricity support for businesses based on the same model as for households.

Postpone the introduction of the CO2 tax for the greenhouse industry until at least 2023 and return to the Parliament with a proposal on this no later than in connection with the revised national budget.
Promote a proposal for an application-based support scheme for actors in the agriculture and greenhouse industry that use gas for heating.
Ensure that the funds transferred from the network tariff to Enova SF are made fully available for energy measures in households through Enova SF.

Renegotiate the governance agreement between the state and Enova SF. Energy efficiency and the utilization of renewable energy related to buildings (e.g., solar energy) for both businesses and households should be the cornerstone of a new agreement. A socially just profile – with free energy consulting – should guide the new agreement, ensuring that all households in the country can benefit from the support scheme. Housing cooperatives, tenant-owner associations, and sharehold apartments should be given special priority.

Renegotiate the agreement with Enova SF to include goals for reduced energy consumption in addition to goals for reduced greenhouse gas emissions, to expand the purpose to achieve emission reductions in industry and society beyond just supporting innovation, and to include the quota-regulated sector in its scope.
Ensure that the funds currently transferred from the network tariff to Enova SF are made fully available for energy measures in households.

Prioritize measures that prevent predator losses and can mitigate conflicts between predators and grazing, including increased support for herding, fencing, monitoring, and the use of breeds with natural defense instincts, as well as increased support for transitioning to other forms of land-based livelihoods in areas particularly affected by predators.
Abolish the current politically appointed large carnivore committees as they are organized today, and replace them with a professional, non-political arrangement.
Halt the planned hunt for 24 wolves in the wolf zone.
Consider transferring the management responsibility for large carnivores from the Ministry of Climate and Environment to the Ministry of Agriculture and Food.

Reassess and review the large carnivore agreement of 2011, and return to the Parliament with this, where especially the population targets for all four large carnivores, wolf, bear, lynx, and wolverine, as well as for the golden eagle, will be re-evaluated with a focus on ensuring that the population targets are maintained.

Come back to the Parliament with a new assessment of wildlife management in relation to grazing-prioritized and predator-prioritized areas, with a special focus on meeting population targets and using the Norwegian Nature Inspectorate more strategically in this work, as well as better organization and targeting of conflict-reducing measures.
Present a case for increasing the population target for wolves in Norway to 8–12 family groups, including border territories, of which at least 6 should be fully Norwegian breeding pairs.

Expand and specify the mandate of the Energy Commission to present measures that ensure reasonable and predictable electricity prices in Norway for both households and businesses, including various forms of price and tax determination/regulation, and if necessary, appoint additional members to ensure that this is addressed in the commission's work.
Come back to the Parliament with a review of the scope Norway has to regulate the export of electricity through the cables that go to the EU and the UK.

Start negotiations with the EU and the UK with specific demands to regulate the export of electricity on the new interconnectors North Sea Link (NSL) and NordLink, in consideration of electricity prices and power supply, and ensure that the planned capacity increase on NSL is held back until further clarification. The Parliament should be kept informed about developments in an appropriate manner.

Investigate new models for grid fees that take into account the need for a stronger grid to ensure the electrification of society, while also considering the needs of private households for a simple model that provides incentives for increased energy efficiency.
Develop and promote a proposal for a grid rental model that is adaptable for consumers, does not weaken the incentive for energy efficiency, and ensures minimal network expansion.
Withdraw the energy report's proposal to introduce peak hour charges on electricity (demand-based tariffs).
Require NVE/RME to demand that the grid companies immediately refund the debt they owe to their customers through reduced grid fees in 2022.
Investigate the consequences of placing the increased costs associated with network losses, upgrades, and maintenance of the power grid on the state instead of on consumers.
Reduce the grid rent by lowering the revenue cap for the grid companies.
Ensure that the interest rate that the grid companies receive on invested capital, the so-called reference rate, is reduced to a maximum of 2% from January 1, 2022.

Ensure that municipalities and county municipalities cannot take dividends from the grid companies to finance other tasks in the municipality, but that this money should be used to operate and expand the network or reduce people's electricity bills.
Ensure that the regulations governing allowed grid fees are amended so that the permitted return on capital follows the development of the general interest rate level on loans to such companies.

Investigate the consequences of the changes in the Penal Code in 2016 regarding the ruling on transfer to compulsory mental health care, and the introduction of the consent requirement in the Mental Health Care Act in 2017.
Develop proposals for amendments to the Mental Health Care Act and the Penal Code, to better address society's need for protection against and treatment of individuals with severe mental illness.

Propose the necessary amendments to the law to ensure societal protection by subjecting mentally ill individuals, who are assessed to pose a danger to themselves or others, to compulsory mental health care or otherwise depriving them of their liberty in a suitable manner. This is to safeguard the interests of the individual patient and the community's need for protection.
Promote a bill stating that municipalities cannot include cash support in the basis for calculating benefits under the Social Services Act and the Housing Support Act.
Promote a bill stating that municipalities cannot include child benefits in the basis for calculating benefits under the Housing Support Act.
Set the threshold for compensation in the compensation scheme for extraordinary electricity prices to 35 øre/kWh.
Set the threshold for compensation in the compensation scheme for extraordinary electricity prices to 50 øre/kWh.

Ensure that the electricity support scheme for voluntary organizations is based on a threshold for electricity support set at 50 øre per kWh for consumption during the months of November and December 2021, and January, February, and March 2022. The scheme should be designed to encompass all forms of volunteering, regardless of operational model. Additionally, all non-profit actors within, among others, addiction care, child welfare, hospitals, as well as folk high schools, independent schools, rehabilitation companies, and similar actors should be included.
Include sports facilities that are heated by energy sources other than electricity.
Ensure that the compensation scheme for extraordinary electricity prices is expanded to include increased costs for the use of all types of energy sources, including district heating and gas.
Ensure that all sports facilities, regardless of ownership structure, that have a significant element of voluntary activity qualify for compensation for extraordinary electricity prices.
Ensure that all organizational levels in voluntary organizations are included in the compensation scheme for extraordinary electricity prices.

Ensure that the compensation scheme for extraordinary electricity prices applies to all types of premises, buildings, and facilities where voluntary organizations are responsible for electricity/energy costs, regardless of the purpose of the premises. There is no requirement for the buildings or facilities to be open to the public.

Ensure increased allocations to individual municipalities that can document that they have not been granted sufficient funds to distribute support to voluntary organizations in their municipality, with a coverage rate approximately equivalent to the support scheme for private households, and return with proposals in the revised national budget for 2022 if there is a need for increased allocations.
Ensure that no representatives of the Norwegian government visit the Winter Olympics or the Paralympic Games in Beijing in 2022.
Develop a strategy that provides guidelines for Norway's use of diplomatic boycotts in connection with major international sporting events.

Set an ambition to enter into a separate partnership agreement with the EU to ensure full participation in the EU's Green Deal, as part of the ongoing dialogue with the European Commission on strengthened industrial cooperation.
Return to the Parliament with proposals to implement changes in Norwegian law and regulations to ensure full compliance with the EU's "Fit for 55" package.
Take the initiative for a green industrial partnership with the EU to ensure the best possible conditions for the export of Norwegian-produced zero and low-emission solutions.
Ensure Norwegian participation in the IPCEI program for batteries.

Consider taking the initiative to establish new IPCEI programs for floating offshore wind, bioeconomy, green shipping, and carbon capture for storage and utilization, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Ensure that all provisions of the EU's Fourth Railway Package continue to apply to Norway.
Ensure that any investigation of alternatives to the EEA Agreement also includes an assessment of what Norwegian EU membership would mean for Norwegian citizens and Norwegian businesses.
Assume that the announced investigation of alternatives to the EEA Agreement will be based on the premise that Norway's connection to the internal market shall remain unchanged.
Come back to the Storting with the results of the treatment of the "Fit for 55" package in the EU's institutions and the positions the government recommends Norway to adopt regarding this.

Inform the Storting in an appropriate manner about the progress and scope of Norway's participation in the financial agencies EBA, EIOPA, and ESMA, the European Union Agency for Railways (ERA), and the EU Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER).
Freeze disbursements of EEA funds that go directly to Polish authorities until the conditions of the rule of law in Poland improve significantly.
Continue payments to Polish civil society through the Batory Foundation.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to abolish the gambling monopoly and introduce a licensing system that ensures equal competitive conditions for Norwegian and international gambling companies. The system will uphold the three fundamental principles of gambling policy.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to amend the Marketing Act so that all licensed gambling companies can legally advertise their products.
Conduct a broad and external evaluation of Norwegian gambling policy, including the monopoly model (gambling monopoly).
Investigate an increase in the revenue cap for lotteries, merging of permits, and removal of expiration dates on lottery permits.

Closely monitor the gambling sector and the influence of international actors, and by 2024, return to the Storting with an evaluation of the Norwegian gambling monopoly, the so-called exclusive rights model.

Investigate the possibilities, within the framework of the monopoly model and EEA law, for raising the turnover limit of lotteries, merging licenses, and removing the expiration date on lottery licenses.

Return to the Parliament with a new assessment of the provisions related to the role of the Lottery Authority in connection with case processing and supervision, while the case regarding DNS blocking is presented.
Complete the work on the proposal for a mandate on DNS notification or DNS blocking.
To maintain the current board composition in Norsk Rikstoto.
Implement the necessary changes to the regulations for private lotteries to facilitate digital solutions for payment and distribution as soon as practically possible.
Expand the definition of horse gambling to also include digital and virtual horse betting.

Contribute to more municipalities making their multi-purpose halls and cultural venues accessible for data events and e-sports competitions, for example through the use of gaming funds and other grant schemes.
Introduce a regulatory framework for lottery mechanisms in video games in Norway, and possibly consider a ban on this.
Facilitate better conditions for the smart use of game-based learning in schools.
Facilitate for more high school students to choose e-sports on par with other elite sports programs.
Open to providing support for initiatives for international e-sports events in Norway.
Develop a national strategy for e-sports in Norway.

Follow up on the guide "Meeting Places for Video Games and Data Culture" and assess how we can further contribute to making it easier for municipalities and others who wish to develop attractive, accessible, and inclusive meeting places where children and youth interested in data culture feel seen and can feel safe.
Present an evaluation of the health mapping scheme within two years after it comes into effect.

Investigate whether the public sector should have an obligation to offer interdisciplinary health assessments when requested by the municipality, and promptly report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Develop a concrete and binding plan for how the professional community can be strengthened, without compromising teachers' own time for preparation and follow-up work, and return to the Parliament as soon as possible with such a plan.

Come back with a proposal for a career pathway arrangement for teachers in schools that builds on the teacher specialist scheme and can be continued from autumn 2022. The goal that all schools should have access to a teacher specialist in early education will be maintained. The arrangement should be anchored with the parties in the education sector.

Return to the Parliament with a binding escalation plan for more permanent adapted workplaces (VTA) in both sheltered and regular enterprises. The Parliament requests the government to report on the escalation plan in the annual budget proposals.
Investigate the need for more permanently adapted workplaces (VTA) in sheltered and regular enterprises, and report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner.

Ensure that better models for follow-up in VTA-O are developed, inspired by examples such as HELT MED, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner. Tailored follow-up for individuals with intellectual disabilities in regular employment must be of a permanent nature.

Investigate the need for more permanently adapted workplaces (VTA) in sheltered and regular businesses, and report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner, no later than the state budget for 2023.

Ensure that better models for follow-up in VTA-O are developed, where other actors besides Nav – for example, HELT MED – can also be responsible for follow-up, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner, no later than in the state budget for 2023. Tailored follow-up for individuals with intellectual disabilities in regular employment must be of a permanent nature and have a scope equivalent to what is practiced in the HELT MED model.

Map how many patients have had their surgeries or treatments in specialist healthcare postponed due to the pandemic, and as a result, have had to transition from sick leave benefits to work assessment allowance.
Review tax and duty regulations for unsold goods with the aim of making it more profitable to ensure the reuse of the goods rather than disposing of them.
Investigate a material fee for all plastic and return in the state budget for 2023 with a proposal for a fee on plastic packaging.

Investigate an extended producer responsibility scheme for textiles. It should be considered to hold clothing chains accountable for registering and being transparent about the volume of returned and surplus goods, and to work systematically to reduce this volume annually, as well as ensuring responsible disposal/donation of unsold clothing to second-hand stores and similar initiatives to extend the lifespan of garments by, among other things, offering resale and repair services in stores, continuously increasing the level of repair, reuse, redesign, and recycling.
Promote a proposal for the introduction of a repair index for selected consumer goods.
Assess whether the current VAT rules for goods to the voluntary sector are too rigid or create barriers to circular value chains, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Implement a salary freeze for leaders in the state under the State Leader Salary System (SLS) pending the presentation of the report from the committee reviewing leadership salaries in the state.
