Change the guidelines for salary and other compensation for senior executives in enterprises and companies with a state ownership stake, so that it is established that companies where the state is the majority owner must follow the state's guidelines for executive pay.

Ensure that the use of variable pay and bonus schemes is limited, and that the size of pension schemes and severance pay for senior executives in the State's salary system (SLS) in the state, enterprises, and companies with state ownership is reviewed with the aim of reducing total compensation.

Take the necessary initiatives to ensure that salaries and pensions for leaders and employees in the public administration, state-owned enterprises, wholly state-owned companies, and partially state-owned companies are not at a higher level than the arrangements that apply at any given time for the Prime Minister.
Introduce a salary cap for state leaders at 15 G and a salary freeze for current leaders with salaries above this level.
Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner once the committee tasked with reviewing the leadership salary system in the state has presented its report.
Ensure that allocations of business promotion funds in indigenous areas are made in such a way that the allocations do not conflict with the right to cultural practice.
Start a process to reestablish a crisis center service in the Sami areas.
Create a plan to further develop decentralized education in various subjects and societal areas in the different Sami regions and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Come back to the Parliament with a case regarding the authorization of speech therapists and possibly other professional groups.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal regarding the authorization of acupuncturists and any other relevant professions.
Consider a transitional arrangement that could allow ambulance workers and nurses with National Paramedic continuing education to become authorized as paramedics upon application.

Clarify which of the service providers registered in the Register of Practitioners of Alternative Treatment can be considered to provide health care, and return to the Parliament with a comprehensive review of the systems for authorization, licensing, and specialist approval of health personnel, including an assessment of which groups should be covered by these systems and receive exemptions from the Value Added Tax Act, as soon as possible.
Come back with a case to reduce electricity prices before the current electricity support scheme ends.
Consider how refugees with temporary collective residence living outside of asylum reception centers can be temporarily ensured support for their livelihood.

Promote a proposal to amend the wording of the Penal Code § 295 first paragraph letter c so that it includes the exploitation of a person under 18 years of age in a particularly vulnerable "situation."

Consider whether the word "livssituasjon" in the Penal Code § 295 first paragraph letter c should be changed to "situasjon," so that the provision addresses "exploiting a person under 18 years of age in a particularly vulnerable situation."
Ensure an updated knowledge base regarding the societal, law enforcement, and security implications of a potential general arming of the police.
Propose amendments to the Police Act to ensure general arming of the police.
Ensure a regular exam process as far as possible.
To prioritize the administration of written exams for graduating students in 10th grade and at Vg3, and to facilitate the administration of locally administered exams and oral exams.

Disburse the grant to X Games Norway / SAHR of 15 million kroner as decided during the processing of the state budget for 2022, so that this can be used to conduct qualification rounds and plan and execute a full-scale event when the pandemic restrictions allow it.

Disburse 2 million kroner of the approved grant in 2022 to X Games Norway / SAHR Productions for the planning of next year's event, and that the remaining 13 million of the allocated grant for 2022 be included in the state budget for 2023 for the implementation of a full-scale event in Lillehammer.
Ensure that a mandatory receipt system is introduced that guarantees a receipt is always issued to individuals who are subject to personal checks conducted by police and customs authorities.

Return to the Parliament with proposals for temporary changes to the Infection Control Act that ensure that all intrusive infection control measures are anchored in the Parliament, either before they are adopted, or immediately afterwards if prior anchoring is not possible due to an acute situation.

Establish a legislative committee to review existing laws and frameworks for combating pandemics, with particular attention to proportionality, infection control, and legal security when implementing infection control measures. The committee's mandate will be to examine how the government can be granted the necessary powers while ensuring democratic oversight and assessment of the nature, scope, and proportionality of the measures being introduced. The committee will provide recommendations on how authorities can facilitate public and democratic engagement, ensuring that affected interests are heard and involved in the development of restrictions, and contribute to generating new knowledge in crisis situations.

Present a bill that obligates health enterprises to follow the advice given to patients by the Expert Panel, so that the finances of individual hospitals do not determine whether patients have access to treatment.
Implement a salary increase in 2022 for nurses and healthcare workers of three percentage points beyond the regular wage growth.
Introduce a national compensation scheme for employees in healthcare enterprises who work in hospital departments that have experienced an extra heavy burden due to COVID-19.

Utilize the available private and non-profit capacity to relieve the public healthcare system and ensure that as many planned surgeries and other procedures as possible can be carried out as scheduled by using the available private and non-profit capacity that is ready.
Return to the Parliament with initial measures to secure more study places in medicine, health sciences, nursing, and psychology.
Update the professional report from 2019 to assess the current status, describe the challenges, and provide future perspectives on intensive care capacity in Norway.
Present a plan to increase intensive care capacity in hospitals in the short term.

Present a motivation scheme with the aim of bringing back former intensive care nurses who are currently working in other professions, so that they can help alleviate the pressure on the healthcare system.
Present a long-term escalation plan to increase the intensive care capacity in hospitals.
Implement a process to dissolve the county municipality as an administrative level.

Facilitate the opportunity for power companies to apply for the development of hydropower in protected waterways where they have identified that it is possible to increase power production without significantly compromising nature and environmental considerations.
Remove the limit of 1 megawatt installed capacity for small hydropower developments in protected waterways where the power plant is adapted to responsible environmental interventions.
Ensure that protected waterways receive permanent, legally binding, and cross-sectoral protection, and return to the Storting with a legislative proposal no later than during 2023.

Provide a temporary exception from certain intellectual property rights during the COVID-19 pandemic to increase the production and availability of vaccines, testing equipment, medicines, and medical devices – without conditions or requirements for compensation.
To improve global access to affordable COVID-related medical products and to address global production constraints and supply shortages.

Strengthened efforts for a solution to the enormous inequality in the world regarding access to vaccines, medicines, and medical equipment to combat the COVID-19 pandemic, with particular attention to increasing vaccine production and the geographical distribution of production capacity, and supported a revision of the global framework for intellectual property rights for future pandemics.

Present a case to the Storting that provides Norwegian farmers with the necessary clarifications regarding profitability, including guarantees for covering increased costs for electricity, fertilizer, and fuel.
Promote a proposal to remove the cap on the electricity support scheme for agricultural businesses of 20,000 kWh per enterprise per month.
Present a case to the Storting that provides Norwegian grain farmers with the necessary clarifications regarding profitability in food grain production before the seeds are sown.
Utilize § 2-4 of the main agreement for agriculture and immediately initiate supplementary negotiations for the agricultural settlement.
Take the initiative to conduct an evaluation in an appropriate form of Norway's contributions to the anti-ISIL coalition.
Conduct an evaluation of Norway's contribution to the anti-ISIL coalition in an appropriate form by the conclusion of the Norwegian military effort.

Present a report on the advantages and disadvantages of ratifying the Third Optional Protocol to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child of 1989, based on the cases that have already been addressed by the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child. The report should assess the consideration of the best interests of the child in the question of ratification and be submitted to the Parliament during 2022.

Promote a proposal for the ratification of the Third Optional Protocol to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child from 1989, thereby ensuring that Norway participates in the individual complaint mechanism under the Convention on the Rights of the Child.
Establish an independent assistance commission. A proposal for the commission's mandate and composition will be presented to the Parliament prior to its establishment.
Stop further electrification of oil and gas fields on the Norwegian continental shelf and demand that oil companies ensure zero emissions from platforms without power from land.
Demand that oil companies develop new solutions for stable power supply, so that fields being electrified do not require a cable to be brought ashore.
Stop all further electrification of the Norwegian continental shelf, including the Wisting field, with power from the mainland.
Ensure that the operators on the Norwegian continental shelf are required to electrify by developing offshore wind equivalent to what they will consume in electricity.
Stop further electrification of the Norwegian continental shelf with power from the mainland.
Not granting extraction permits for the development of the Krafla/NOA field and the Oscar Wisting field.

Each individual "power-from-land" project must be assessed on its own and considered in relation to power availability and project costs. New large power withdrawals, such as the electrification of petroleum installations with "power-from-land," should be linked to areas with a strong grid and good access to power.
Promote proposals for a permanent arrangement for income security for self-employed individuals and freelancers.

Extend the current improvements to the schemes for recipients of unemployment benefits from March 31 to June 30 and return to the Parliament with the necessary proposals for appropriations or amendments to the law.
Review the unemployment benefit scheme and assess permanent improvements based on the changes that were implemented on March 20, 2020.
Establish a committee to review and assess possible improvements in the social rights of self-employed individuals and freelancers, with a deadline no later than the revised national budget for 2023.
Investigate whether self-employed individuals and freelancers should gain stronger rights to income security, including improvements to the sick pay scheme and social benefits for the self-employed.

Promote proposals for changes to the withholding tax system that increase the number of days per year, abolish the income limit (currently 643,000 kroner), and set the tax rate equal to the ordinary tax rate (22% vs. 25% today).
Promote a proposal to reintroduce the scheme of standard deductions for foreign workers.

Investigate the possibility of making it easier for foreign actors to establish a Norwegian VPS account within the framework of a responsible compliance with international anti-money laundering and anti-corruption regulations, where Norway adopts the same practices as our competitor countries.

Make improvements to the tax deduction scheme for investments in startup companies, with the aim of encouraging more people to utilize the scheme and thereby increase investments in startup companies in Norway.
Develop a strategy to ensure a more investment-friendly Norway leading up to 2030, with the goal of attracting more both Norwegian and foreign capital to invest in Norwegian companies.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal for a separate visa program for researchers to give more professionals the opportunity to work in Norway.

Promote proposals that simplify application processes, reduce processing times, and ensure faster and easier access to D-numbers/personal identification numbers and high-security e-ID for labor immigrants, entrepreneurs, and students from non-EEA countries.

Promote a proposal for a consulting service for employers who wish to recruit skilled workers with sought-after technical, academic, or practical skills from countries outside the EEA, so that employers can relate to the advisory unit instead of having to gather information across Nav, municipalities, the Directorate of Immigration, and the Tax Administration.
Present a strategy to strengthen support services and growth opportunities for businesses established by international entrepreneurs in Norway.

Elaborate on regional pilot projects aimed at specific industries or regions that wish for entrepreneurs or individuals with specific expertise to move there for a period to 'try living', as has been done in Finland, for example.
Present a strategy to attract more international investors to Norwegian growth companies.

Develop a model for a startup visa or a similar scheme that makes it easier for entrepreneurs from non-EEA countries to start, finance, and operate a business in Norway, and return to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2023.
Look at how the continuous development of the Decision Forum for new methods can be incorporated into the National Health and Coordination Plan.
Ensure that the four pharmaceutical policy goals are followed and weighted equally in the New Methods system.
Initiate work on a new pharmaceutical message so that it can be processed in the Parliament during the current parliamentary term.
Promote a case to the Storting regarding the evaluation of the New Methods system.
Ensure increased user and clinician involvement in the New Methods system.
Present to the Storting, no later than in the state budget for 2023, how the evaluation of the Decision Forum for new methods has been followed up.

Strengthen the substance abuse prevention efforts, particularly aimed at youth, including by enhancing substance abuse education in schools, providing a wide range of recreational activities in the municipalities, and strengthening the work on attitude formation.

Implement a skills enhancement program regarding substance use for employees working with children and young people, including, among others, child welfare workers, teachers, caregivers, and school nurses.
Ensure a comprehensive offer in all municipalities to support young people who receive a deferred prosecution with conditions due to substance use or possession of narcotic drugs.
Come back with a proposal for a compensation scheme for those who have been subjected to illegal use of coercive measures in connection with drug searches.

Promote proposals for the exclusion of illegally obtained evidence in criminal cases with a penalty frame of less than one year, to ensure that the police do not use evidence that has been obtained unlawfully.
Ensure that the use of drug testing contracts for youth is discontinued until the government has evaluated the measure.
Ensure that harm reduction measures are treated equally with substance abuse prevention measures in the grant schemes for voluntary organizations in the field of substance use.
Promote a proposal that all possession of drugs for personal use that can be punished with a fine be consolidated into one common provision with a fine as the upper limit.
Ensure that the quantity is only given significance in sentencing for less serious drug cases if there is a qualified risk that the substance would have ended up in the wrong hands.
Promote a bill that protects individuals from prosecution for minor drug offenses when they contact emergency services for help for themselves or others.
Ensure that individuals with substance abuse issues who accumulate fines are given the option of serving their fines through community service, fine payment, or treatment.
Do not propose to decriminalize the use and possession of narcotic substances.
Strengthen the police's work related to the prevention and combat of drug crimes, including, among other things, when the trade occurs online.
Strengthen the drug program with court supervision.
Strengthen long-term treatment in addiction care through free choice of treatment facility, without the requirement that the person with addiction must have gone through short-term measures first.
Expand the use of the vaccine Naltrexone.

Return to the Parliament with a report on whether it would be beneficial for general practitioners and/or specialist healthcare services to have the authority to prescribe more medications to individuals with a severe substance use disorder in order to ensure better assistance on the path to sobriety and a better life.
Expand the use of Naloxone nasal spray to a national program for treating overdoses.
Increase the treatment capacity for individuals with substance dependence, ensuring they receive immediate healthcare and do not have to wait for necessary treatment.
Strengthen substance abuse care, including the capacity and competence related to treatment, rehabilitation, and aftercare.

Provide ideal treatment options for substance-dependent individuals with stable and long-term framework conditions, so that those with substance dependence can choose which program they wish to participate in.

Investigate possible changes in the driving instructor education, particularly how access, flexibility, and the scope of the education for heavy vehicle driving instructors in Norway can best meet the high demand.
"Consider an alternative educational pathway for vocational teacher education where heavy transport becomes its own basic education alongside passenger car education."

Consider how the tuition fee level of driving instructor education is perceived as an obstacle to recruitment, and if necessary, assess how funding or incentives can ensure that the cost for students does not become too high.
Investigate the extended possibilities of introducing a temporary usage ban for two-axle tractors when weather and road conditions during the winter period warrant it.
Promote proposals that impose a ban on the use of trucks that do not meet the requirements for chains during winter.

Ensure that necessary instructions are prepared for the Norwegian Public Roads Administration, the Customs Authority, and the police to ensure that the legal basis for the detention of trucks until the fee is paid and deficiencies are corrected is utilized in cases where inspections reveal that the vehicle does not have satisfactory winter equipment or is in a technical condition that poses a risk to traffic safety.
Introduce fast-track procedures for the detention of youth and gang criminals.

Introduce permanent area arming in vulnerable areas of Oslo a. where the police chief, in consultation with the GDE leaders, comprehensively assesses that arming is necessary to ensure the safety of residents b. as an extension of point arming, for example limited to neighborhoods or geographical operational units c. as a pilot project for possible similar measures in other parts of the country.

Introduce a reverse violence alarm for gang criminals with the aim of stopping disturbances of public peace and order, or when circumstances pose a risk of such disturbances, to ensure the safety of individuals and the public, and to prevent or stop criminal acts.

Shift the burden of proof by expanding the police and prosecution's ability to impose residence bans on multi-criminal gang members without legal process, but within the framework of Article 11 of the ECHR and Section 106 of the Constitution, if a. the relevant area serves as a place of residence for children and young people, such as schools, youth clubs, etc. b. the person's presence poses a risk of violence, recruitment to gang activities, or challenges the obligation to safeguard the best interests of the child.
Ensure that new funding for the police is used for personnel and prevention, rather than office spaces, to foster dialogue and trust in local communities.
Introduce a weapons amnesty, where individuals are exempt from punishment for possession of illegal weapons if they are surrendered to the relevant authorities within a specified period.
Prioritize resources for continuing education and skills enhancement for interdisciplinary teaching, including teaching about and for sustainable development and global citizenship.
Include a representative from the young civil society in the national forum for the Sustainable Development Goals.

Instruct relevant parts of the government apparatus that practical guidance for purchasers should showcase the diversity of opportunities available within the regulations regarding sustainable procurement.
Clarify to public purchasers that the regulations should be fully utilized to select suppliers who emphasize sustainability, climate, and the environment.
Incorporate the interdisciplinary theme of "sustainable development" into the curricula for English and Mathematics, in line with the curriculum group's proposal.

Strengthen the assessment of how Norwegian business, climate, and environmental policy can better facilitate green transition among small and medium-sized enterprises by presenting a package of measures that promotes green transition in the country's small and medium-sized businesses.
Investigate a model for a state-owned electricity company.
Include measures to reduce Norway's negative impact on other countries and ensure its own indicators to measure Norway's influence on the global achievement of the UN Sustainable Development Goals.
Review today's arrangements in the Norwegian State Educational Loan Fund (Lånekassen) so that they do not limit any group's opportunity for education.

Investigate a public job creation program that can provide opportunities for climate-friendly jobs, such as climate adaptation in municipalities or restoration of nature, and that is scalable according to the economic situation in the Norwegian economy.

Change the measurement point under sub-goal 9.2. to the following: Proportion of businesses with sustainability certification, energy management, or environmental certification (ISO 50001, 14064, and 14001, EMAS, or Eco-Lighthouse).
Include the following measurement point under sub-goal 9.4: The proportion of business actors that are third-party environmental certified with ISO 14001, EMAS, or Miljøfyrtårn.

Include the following measurement point under sub-goal 12.6: The number of companies that have implemented an environmental management system with associated climate and environmental reporting (ISO 14001, EMAS, or Eco-Lighthouse).

Ensure that the comprehensive national avalanche and landslide safety plan includes a scheduled implementation plan aimed at securing all registered landslide points on national and county roads with high and medium landslide risk factors.

Follow up on the work being carried out by the Norwegian Public Roads Administration in connection with the landslide factor model, and that all relevant projects are assessed based on two levels of protection with associated measures and cost analyses. Furthermore, the Parliament requests the government to ensure that the county municipalities are well involved in the work.

Develop an innovation program for avalanche protection. The program should support alternative solutions and levels of avalanche protection, both for county and national roads, and encompass everything from simple avalanche monitoring to heavy infrastructure measures.

Evaluate whether the current operational contracts for road maintenance are optimal in terms of early involvement and being open enough to allow for the use of innovative solutions. In this context, it should be considered whether it may be beneficial to increase the use of incentive schemes as part of the operational contracts.
Establish an incentive scheme for the investigation, installation, and operation of preventive avalanche control systems and warning systems.

Accelerate the work on developing comprehensive national avalanche and landslide safety plans that cover all landslide points with high and medium landslide risk, both for the national road network and for the county road network. The plans should be completed by the end of 2023.
Ensure that knowledge and awareness of the prioritization criteria are included in the curricula for education related to the healthcare system.
Conduct a review of how today's financing models influence prioritization decisions in the health and care services, as recommended in the Blankholm Committee's NOU.
Make a new assessment of the level of opportunity cost for prioritization decisions at the group level in health and care services.
Dismiss cases regarding revocation, and redirect resource use to other asylum and residence cases.

Investigate and propose a statute of limitations that, after a certain period, prevents the opportunity to revoke citizenship under the Citizenship Act § 26 second paragraph, with the exception of those who abuse a Norwegian citizenship obtained under false pretenses, or actively use different identities to commit serious crimes.

Investigate the introduction of a deadline for how long it can take from the issuance of a preliminary notice of revocation of citizenship until a decision is made by the immigration authorities in the first instance.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to introduce a requirement for dual citizenship in order to revoke citizenship.

Promote proposals for amendments to the Immigration Act that provide the legal basis for searches and examinations of mobile phones and other electronic storage devices in connection with asylum registration.
Lift the freeze decision for processing applications for approval as a private school with upper secondary education in vocational education programs or with a special profile.
Come back to the Parliament with a binding plan to tighten the implementation of procurement regulations regarding the business sector's compliance with international law in conflict areas.

Ensure that Norske tog AS does not exercise the option to purchase an additional 170 trains from Alstom as long as the latter is conducting business in violation of international law applicable in conflict areas.
Ensure that Norske tog AS does not enter into new contracts with companies that conduct business in violation of international law applicable in conflict areas.
Develop a separate Norwegian list of individuals and institutions to be subjected to Norwegian sanctions as a consequence of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
Investigate the possibility of promoting Norwegian contributions to the EU's sanctions lists in connection with Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

To introduce a maximum price for electricity for customers in Norway, which corresponds to three times the concession price for power, as calculated by the Ministry of Petroleum and Energy. For 2022, this is set at 11.57 øre per kWh. The Parliament requests the government to combine this with a requirement for coverage obligation for power producers and necessary regulation of electricity exports.

Introduce a maximum price for electricity that will apply to all electricity customers, from households and secondary residences to voluntary and non-profit organizations, as well as businesses and companies.

Propose in the revised national budget 2022 that all non-profit organizations, independent schools, folk high schools, and congregations in the Church of Norway, as well as sports clubs with sports facilities heated with gas, receive electricity support with 100% compensation for spot prices exceeding 50 øre per kWh on average per month from April 2022 to March 2023.
Ensure that garage associations, shared heating plants, and companies that supply heat to residential companies are included in the electricity support scheme.

Come back to the Storting with a proposal to include business activities and vacation properties in the established electricity support scheme, no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2022.

Investigate a solution that involves increasing housing support to compensate for extraordinary increases in electricity prices, which can be geographically targeted to the areas where electricity prices are exceptionally high.
Facilitate an application-based municipal compensation scheme for small businesses with particularly high electricity costs in the price areas of Southern Norway.
Evaluate the new proposal for the grid fee model that has come from Homeowners, environmental organizations, and Energy Norway.

Task the regional health authorities with creating a framework for cost-covering compensation for non-profit actors in the specialist health service during major unforeseen events. The framework should take into account their duty to act, ensure that any changes in the operation of their services are justifiable, and provide protection against such events leading to bankruptcy.
Ensure that the compensation schemes for the private hospitals are predictable and at the same level as for public hospitals regarding any COVID-related costs in the future.
Ensure that private healthcare providers with additional costs related to the pandemic receive compensation for these.

Ensure that children without legal residency are granted access to the general practitioner scheme, in order to secure their right to the highest attainable standard of health and to treatment services for illness and rehabilitation.
Ensure that individuals without permanent residence in the country are granted access to the general practitioner scheme.

Evaluate the regulation on the right to health and care services for individuals without permanent residence in the country, and make necessary changes so that the health services for vulnerable groups, such as children, persons with disabilities, pregnant women, and the elderly, are in line with the services provided to the general population.
Establish a funding scheme for practitioners, so that they can be reimbursed for expenses related to and medications provided to patients outside the National Insurance Scheme.

Amend § 5 letter a in the regulation on the right to health and care services for persons without permanent residence in the country, so that those who are already in the country receive primary health services on par with other citizens.

Ensure that the transfer capacity from the price areas NO4 and NO3 to the price areas NO1, NO2, and NO5 is not accelerated in today's power situation with unregulated power exports and speculation on high prices while the water reservoirs are being depleted.
To ensure Europe's transition to a renewable energy system, among other things by allowing hybrid cables during the development of Southern North Sea 2.
Take the initiative for a long-term binding energy cooperation with the EU to contribute to the EU's plans for a faster transition away from fossil energy.

To take the initiative to renegotiate the agreements for the cables North Sea Link, NorNed, and NordLink regarding the distribution of income from the cables and to allocate the profit to end users through the network tariff when applicable.
Investigate allocating a larger portion than today of domestic power production for regulating the consumption of its own use.
Investigate the introduction of an export tax on electricity, the consequences of this, and what the additional revenues will be used for.
Negotiate with the EU and the UK with the aim of ensuring that long periods of pure power exports are avoided during times of low reservoir filling.

Investigate the establishment of a separate pricing area around the controllable power cables, and regulate the price in this area upwards to match the prices abroad, in order to ensure that we do not export when prices in Norway are high and the reservoirs are too low, which would drive prices down in Norway.

Investigate an increased minimum requirement for the filling level in water reservoirs beyond the current requirements. The investigation should include an assessment of various filling level requirements with regard to the median for the different reservoirs, the impact on electricity prices throughout the year, effects on power production and flood protection, distribution effects of income between producers, and implications for supply security.
Investigate the possibilities within existing agreements on electricity exchange to limit power exports during periods when the reservoir levels are significantly lower than normal.

Investigate and return to the Parliament with a proposal for a ban on all use of loose rubber granulate, new grinding of tires, and all use of solid rubber granulate where there is a risk of exposure and leaching. The investigation should include an assessment of the structure of a compensation scheme for affected parties (municipalities, sports clubs, etc.), as well as mapping alternatives to rubber granulate and possible Norwegian business initiatives related to this.
Investigate a general proposal to ban all use of rubber granulate and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Include an exception to the current rule regarding the rehabilitation of sports surfaces only after ten years of use, in order to secure funding for facilities that prove to have a shorter lifespan, when this is a result of testing new solutions without loose rubber granulate.

Ensure that all students are offered participation in physical learning environments to the same extent as before the pandemic, while also considering additional measures that support higher quality in the sharing of academic content, new digital learning platforms, and the digitalization of teaching.

Consider measures to provide more high-quality teaching to recover lost study progression due to the pandemic. This must happen in dialogue with institutions of higher education. In this assessment and dialogue, one can specifically look at potentially increasing the number of teaching hours, extending the length of the academic year, facilitating closer academic support for students, and possibly providing task-solving assistance with support from student mentors.

Present a package of measures to make up for lost academic and social learning and to close knowledge gaps. This should follow up on key recommendations from the Parr report and set reinforced requirements and expectations for school owners to implement both short-term and long-term measures to assess and address the consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic for children and young people in schools. The government is requested to consider the financial implications and to return to the Parliament with a corresponding budget proposal in connection with the revised national budget for 2022.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals that facilitate the implementation of new and expanded summer school offerings in municipalities and county municipalities that have the need and desire for it, following the same model as in 2021.
Require school owners to assess students' reading and math skills before the start of school and provide intensive training in reading and math for students who need it.

Follow up on the completion reform by asking the county municipalities to offer introductory subjects in Norwegian, math, and English for students who have weak grades as they leave junior high school and are at risk of dropping out.
Implement a national reading initiative starting from the beginning of school in August 2022.

Commit school owners to ensure adequate systems for effective absence monitoring throughout the entire school journey, which guarantees attendance and a plan for following up on absences from the first hour, with special measures to reduce critically high absenteeism.
Consider introducing a national absence register for primary schools.
Introduce a follow-up obligation where all primary schools must have a duty to monitor absenteeism that exceeds 10 percent.

To have a dialogue with municipalities and county municipalities about measures to mitigate the negative consequences of the pandemic for students in Norwegian schools. In the dialogue, recommendations from the Parr report should be emphasized.
Come back to the Parliament with a package of measures to further develop the tourism industry after the pandemic, based on the national tourism strategy from 2021.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals on how the current differential treatment in the value-added tax system of food served at a restaurant and food taken out of the restaurant can be replaced with equal treatment, aiming for lower value-added tax on food served at the restaurant.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for measures to increase the recruitment of qualified labor to sectors that have been particularly affected by government infection control measures during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Prioritize industries that have particular challenges related to the aftermath of the pandemic, and where it takes time for the operational situation and revenue to return to normal levels.

Expand its offerings of tax and price reductions in relation to the wage settlement with the following measures: 1) The electricity support scheme is expanded to provide a coverage rate of 100% above 50 øre/kWh. 2) The special taxes on gasoline and diesel are abolished. 3) The value-added tax on food is halved from the current level.
Promote a proposal to postpone the requirement for payment of wealth tax on aquaculture licenses acquired before 1998, pending the investigation by the Tax Committee.
Consider a gradual phasing in of wealth tax on aquaculture licenses acquired before 1998.

Engage in dialogue with the Finnmarksløpet to continue and secure funding for the project 'Finnmarksløpet – A Tool for Promoting Norway' in 2022 and 2023, and return to the Storting with a proposal for this in the revised national budget for 2022.

Engage in dialogue with the Finnmarksløpet to assess the continuation of the project 'Finnmarksløpet - A Tool for Promoting Norway' in 2022 and 2023, and report back to the Parliament in the revised national budget for 2022.
Promote proposals with measures to avoid the dismantling or sale of infrastructure for storage and storage capacity for food grains, unless full-fledged alternatives are in place.
Consider a risk mitigation scheme so that farmers can sow food grains and maintain economic viability in production even if the harvests do not meet food quality standards.
Implement extraordinary measures to stimulate increased grain production in Norway, including an increase in grain prices for farmers and compensation for rising fertilizer and energy prices.

Come back to the Storting in an appropriate manner to inform about the government's handling of the very challenging situation in agriculture at the beginning of the growing season, with particular emphasis on preparedness, self-sufficiency, high fertilizer prices, and the profitability of grain production, as well as what measures the government is considering to address these challenges.
To have good dialogue with sports to strengthen collaboration for a healthier sports environment and to help prevent body dissatisfaction and eating disorders.

Include a broad equality perspective focusing on gender roles, norms, and diversity in the mandate for the interdisciplinary, coordinating competence group led by the Norwegian Sports Federation and in the action plan for a safer sports environment and the prevention of body dissatisfaction and eating disorders in sports.

Establish a cross-disciplinary, coordinating competence group where the Norwegian Sports Federation is invited to administratively lead the development of a proposal for an action plan for a safer sports environment and the prevention of body dissatisfaction and eating disorders in sports.

Present a proposal for an action plan for a safer sports environment and the prevention of body dissatisfaction and eating disorders in sports, based on the proposal developed by a multidisciplinary, coordinating competence group. This proposal for an action plan will be presented in collaboration between the Ministry of Culture, the Ministry of Health and Care Services, and the Ministry of Education.

Investigate an explicit exception from the duty of confidentiality in tax legislation for tax advisory services, and present such a proposal in connection with the expected proposal regarding the obligation to provide information for tax advisory services.
Investigate the issue of external ownership in law firms.
Develop regulations according to § 19 second paragraph, where insurance companies can offer legal assistance through legal aid insurance.

Ensure clear transition arrangements for enterprises affected by changes in the new Lawyer Act, which must provide them with sufficient time to reorganize, as allowed in Prop. 214 L (2020–2021) chapter 22.
Implement regulations for the affected insurance companies well in advance of the transitional rules that will be proposed in connection with the enactment of the Attorney Act, before they expire.
Proceed with the planning of the new Oslo prison on one of the alternative sites to Bredtvet as outlined in the report "Location Clarification for the New Oslo Prison" dated January 31, 2022.
Return to the Storting with a separate case regarding the placement of the new Oslo prison before a final decision is made.
Renovate the existing Oslo prison while awaiting a new prison.
Reject the preliminary plans for a new Oslo prison at Bredtvet.
Ensure that Statsbygg reassesses the relevant site alternatives for the new Oslo prison in light of a scaled-down option.
Reinforce Bredtveit women's prison while awaiting a new prison.

Promote a proposal to amend Section 44 of the Penal Code to include an exception provision that allows the courts to restrict the convicted person's right to petition for parole each year in cases where there are low prospects for improvement in the convicted individual.
Establish a forum to facilitate collaboration between public and private actors in the healthcare sector.
Establish a forum for collaboration and specialization within the healthcare industry.
Come back to the Storting in connection with the state budget for 2023 with a proposal to expand the Skattefunn scheme so that it reaches more large players within the health industry.
Return to the Storting with measures to reduce waiting times before approval and access to health data for private actors in the healthcare sector.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to remove the value-added tax on the repair of clothing and shoes.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to introduce VAT on clothes that are sent for destruction.
Investigate and return to the Parliament with a proposal for a law that prohibits the disposal of usable goods.
Investigate arrangements for lifetime labeling of clothing and return to the Parliament with proposals on this.
Come back to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2023 with measures that will make it more attractive to repair damaged textiles rather than buying new ones.

Participate in the work of developing a common European regulatory framework and measures within circular economy, and advocate for the PEF framework (Product Environmental Footprint) to take into account the total environmental impact throughout the entire life cycle of a product, including microplastic emissions.

Develop a plan for how the requirement for separate collection of textiles by 2025 will be met, including how textiles will be collected, sorted, and recycled, as well as what recycling solutions will be needed. The government is requested to report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Investigate and implement requirements for textile importers and textile producers to ensure traceability in the value chain of textile products and textile waste.

Support the work to further develop an environmental labeling scheme that includes circular aspects, functionality, quality requirements, warranty period, lifespan, product design, and opportunities for repair, among other things, by strengthening the Environmental Labeling Norway and the Nordic Swan Ecolabel.
Investigate a producer responsibility scheme for textiles.

Review the regulations and assess changes to ensure that the clothing industry reuses unsold textile goods to a greater extent instead of destroying them, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Open for connection with hybrid cables during the development of Southern North Sea II and future offshore wind projects.
Introduce requirements for the investigation of local CO2 capture and storage for new oil and gas projects on the Norwegian continental shelf.
Investigate local CO2 capture and storage from offshore gas power plants that aim to primarily produce power for new or existing oil and gas projects.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to establish and fund home visits after childbirth and discharge, so that the woman is offered follow-up by a midwife 3 days after discharge, and if necessary after 7 days, as well as a home visit by a public health nurse after 7 to 10 days for all first-time mothers.

Ensure that the comprehensive review of maternity, childbirth, and postpartum care includes proposals for measures to facilitate full-time and permanent positions in postpartum care, and that it supports the recruitment and hiring of a diverse range of healthcare personnel.

Return to the Parliament with a proposal to legislate the obligation of health trusts to offer accompaniment services for pregnant women, in order to create safe services and security for those giving birth.
Ensure that accessible maternity services are provided for families in need, also outside of normal working hours.
Ensure that healthcare personnel receive the necessary and updated knowledge about multiple births, and that national standardized guidelines for the care of multiple pregnancies are developed.
Review the leave and benefit schemes for parents of twins and multiples and return to the Parliament with a proposal for improved and expanded leave and benefit arrangements.
Replace the current system with performance-based funding for maternity departments with a designated scheme that ensures one-on-one support during active labor.

Introduce an offer of one hour with a physiotherapist after childbirth for all women who have given birth, to check pelvic/abdominal muscles or other physical challenges after pregnancy or childbirth.
Establish a national competence center for maternity and postpartum care, among other purposes, to prevent birth injuries.
Ensure that all postpartum women are offered the opportunity to stay in the maternity ward for the time it normally takes to establish breastfeeding. Early discharge should be the woman's own choice.
Ensure that women are offered a follow-up conversation with a midwife or obstetrician three weeks after giving birth.

Define breastfeeding guidance as necessary health care, and ensure that all maternity wards meet the requirements for Baby-Friendly standards, and that all health stations are certified as breastfeeding knowledgeable.
Develop a national escalation plan for midwifery services to ensure proper follow-up for pregnant women and safe maternity and postpartum care across the country.
Define breastfeeding guidance as necessary health care.
Instruct Helse Sør-Øst RHF to continue the ABC clinic at the current Oslo University Hospital and ensure that the clinic is strengthened in the new OUS.

Consider solutions to secure funding for childbirth processes, midwife-led units in hospitals across the country, and improve collaboration between health enterprises and municipalities, and return to the Parliament with a separate case.
Review and modify the funding model for municipal midwives so that municipalities do not incur losses by providing pregnancy follow-up by midwives.
Ensure that women receive necessary healthcare follow-up after childbirth, including home visits.
Promote a proposal to enshrine the right to have a support person of the mother's choice during pregnancy, childbirth, and postpartum.
Ensure better follow-up and support services related to pregnancy and the postpartum period to prevent and treat postpartum depression.
Investigate the need for a treatment center where mothers can be with their children in cases of severe postpartum depression.
Rights to home visits by a midwife within one week after birth.
Present a proposal to amend the National Insurance Act § 25-6 a to ensure that doctors cannot be imposed with fines for incorrect prescriptions of blue prescriptions.

Consider the adopted amendment to the National Insurance Act § 25-6 a regarding penalties to ensure that the provision does not have unintended consequences for either doctors or patients, and return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner with proposals for changes that address this.

Ensure that the Norwegian children and women who are in internment camps in Syria can come to Norway as quickly as possible. Those who have requested assistance to return to Norway should receive help with this.
Prepare a proposal for amendments to the Penal Code, so that the disqualification of voting rights is established for those convicted of violations of Chapter 18 of the Penal Code.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan to ensure full coverage of kindergarten services.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals for incentive schemes for kindergartens that accept children outside of regular admissions.

Promote a case for the introduction of a legally mandated system for continuous enrollment in kindergartens in Norway. The right to a kindergarten place should take effect no earlier than when the child turns one year old, or from the end of parental leave if it is taken for an extended period.

Ensure that teacher education programs and continuing education offerings for teachers provide increased understanding of sustainable development and professional and pedagogical work with sustainability in all subjects, in line with the introduction of sustainable development as a cross-disciplinary theme in the curricula through the curriculum renewal.
Consider how new construction machinery and equipment based on zero emissions can be integrated into educational programs.

Follow up on ensuring that the intentions in the curricula regarding sustainability, as well as circular economy and reuse in deconstruction and construction, are being implemented in vocational education and training.

Consider how to elevate and formalize the competence of professionals in dismantling and reuse within the construction and civil engineering sector in the education sector, and return to the Parliament with a plan for implementation. The plan should particularly address themes such as: how sustainability, circular economy, and reuse are made visible in the curriculum for modular structured vocational education and training, which is to be renewed in the summer of 2023, and how dismantling and reuse can fit into the vocational pathways.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals that ensure that the costs resulting from the war in Ukraine are covered in a fair manner, such as through increased taxes on corporate profits and dividend payouts, as well as more progressive taxation of high incomes and large fortunes.

Request the municipalities to establish temporary municipal or inter-municipal clinics to ensure that refugees have access to healthcare from the time of arrival until they are settled in the municipalities and assigned a general practitioner.
Implement the necessary changes to remove taxes and tariffs on goods imported from Ukraine, and if needed, quickly present the necessary proposals to the Parliament.
Promote proposals to finance humanitarian aid to Ukraine, or the reception of refugees from Ukraine, in ways other than by reducing other assistance to the world's poor.
Consider implementing the IEA's ten-point plan and return to the Storting in the revised national budget 2022 with concrete proposals on how to implement the plan.

Assign the Advisory Committee for Fiscal Policy Analysis the task of providing an independent statement on fiscal policy and the government's proposals in connection with the revised national budget for 2022.
Engage in dialogue with private healthcare providers to assist and relieve the municipal healthcare services and the general practitioner system.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to remove the road usage tax on biodiesel, bioethanol, LPG, and natural gas.
Return to the Storting with a proposal to remove the CO2 tax on LPG and natural gas.

Prepare a possible reduction of the rate, or a full exemption from value-added tax on gasoline and diesel, if fuel prices continue at today's level or above, and return to the Parliament with a proposal no later than in the revised national budget for 2022.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals for measures against high price growth that affects the economy of ordinary people, which can be approved before the summer.

Ensure that an investigation is conducted on how Norway can utilize the flexibility within the EEA Agreement by following Iceland's model of implementing EU/EEA legislation 'only to the extent that it is appropriate'.

Ensure that it is investigated whether the competence of ESA and the EFTA Court in the area of labor is an appropriate part of the EEA Agreement, or if this can be resolved in a better way, in line with the demands of the Confederation of Trade Unions.
Ensure that it is investigated how Norwegian collective agreements and Norwegian labor legislation take precedence over EU rules, in accordance with the demands of the LO Congress.

Come back to the Parliament with a plan for full broadband coverage by 2025, defined as 95% coverage of broadband with at least 1 Gbit/s and at least 100 Mbit/s for the remaining households/businesses.

Come back to the Parliament with a plan to maximize the societal and climate benefits of the broadband investment by, among other things, increasing efficiency in the public sector and enhancing value creation and climate reductions related to digitalization in both the private and public sectors.

Stop Avinor's bonus schemes for new long-haul routes and airlines that have passenger growth. The Parliament also asks the government to investigate whether this money can instead be used for the restructuring of aviation.
Set a goal for full electrification of the short-haul network by 2030.
Promote a case to the Parliament with a proposal for a green aviation program.
Ensure that requirements are included in the tenders for the use of low- and zero-emission technology on the short-haul network as soon as it is technologically feasible.
Investigate several measures to reduce emissions from domestic and international aviation and return to the Parliament with proposals for measures in connection with the aviation strategy.
Support the establishment of central research and development functions through a dedicated center for climate-neutral regional aviation in Norway.
Increase the fast ferry investment under Klimasats to strengthen the county municipality's efforts to promote zero and low-emission fast ferries, including hydrogen or ammonia-powered boats.

Facilitate the establishment of five hydrogen hubs for maritime transport in collaboration with private actors, with opportunities for the development of related land transport solutions based on hydrogen.

Facilitate the establishment of one to two industrial projects with associated production facilities for hydrogen in collaboration with private actors by 2025, with the aim of demonstrating value chains with global dissemination potential.

Facilitate the establishment of five to ten pilot projects in collaboration with private actors for the development and demonstration of new and more cost-effective hydrogen solutions and technologies.

Further develop the collaboration with the other Nordic countries on a full-scale infrastructure plan for hydrogen in the Nordics aimed at the maritime sector and land transport. The plan should include requirements for emission-free shipping between the Nordic countries.
Ensure that it is within Envoa's mandate to support projects that are relevant for the IPCEI Hydrogen scheme.
Facilitate further strengthening of the Research Council's research center for environmentally friendly energy (FME) in the field of hydrogen and ammonia.
Work to ensure Norway's participation and opportunities in EU processes regarding hydrogen development in Europe.
Contribute with government measures to establish a Norwegian hydrogen industry, rather than creating a new state-owned hydrogen company.
Consider new instruments that could trigger the initiation of projects using hydrogen or ammonia as energy carriers, including difference contracts.
Send all extensions of oil exploration areas, including TFO, to parliamentary consideration.
Announce the 26th numbered licensing round on the Norwegian continental shelf as soon as possible, and no later than the end of 2023.
Present a solution for the export of natural gas from the Barents Sea in connection with the announcement of the 26th licensing round.
Provide Statnett with funds that ensure a lower increase in grid fees in the future than what is currently planned.
Establish a national goal of saving 13 TWh in Norwegian buildings by 2030 and halving energy consumption in buildings by 2050.

Expand and strengthen support for energy saving and energy production, covering up to half of the investment costs for such measures in private single-family homes, small houses, housing cooperatives, and condominiums. The support should be paid in advance when possible, and favorable loan arrangements should be offered to those who need it for the remainder of the investment.

Move the support schemes for climate and energy measures for households from Enova to Husbanken and establish a program for free, proactive energy counseling for households in single-family homes, small houses, housing cooperatives, and condominiums. The program should be established as a collaboration between Husbanken and the municipalities.

Present an action plan for how at least half of all roof surfaces on residential blocks can be covered with solar panel systems, with the goal of at least 1 TWh of annual electricity production by 2030.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for measures to produce solar power with a total installed capacity of 5 GW on Norwegian buildings by 2030. Among other things, support for solar panels on existing buildings must be expanded, and support must be provided for solar panels on new buildings and building-integrated solar panels.

Develop a plan to extract the potential for energy efficiency improvements from commercial buildings amounting to 9 TWh by 2030, and ensure that the plan is detailed with annual goals and measures. The plan should be presented in connection with the state budget for 2023.

Enter into a three-year supplementary agreement with Enova, which provides special grants to ensure good support schemes for energy savings and local electricity production for both private customers and businesses.
Investigate and present to the Storting measures that make it possible to achieve at least 13 TWh of energy efficiency by 2030, in connection with or after the plan for 10 TWh has been presented.
Include heat pumps in an expanded and strengthened support for energy savings, in line with the other criteria described in Document 8:130 S (2021–2022).
Expand the support schemes for climate and energy measures in households to include more types of energy measures, including well-known energy measures with mature technology.
Establish targeted schemes with earmarked grants for energy savings in private rental properties.
Introduce a requirement for energy class A in all new public lease agreements.

Ensure that the energy requirements for new buildings are tightened to nearly zero energy levels, as defined in the EU's Energy Performance of Buildings Directive, in the next building technical regulations.

Return to the Parliament with proposals for amendments to the Planning and Building Act that enable requirements for power production from solar energy or green roofs on commercial, residential, and public buildings.

Introduce mandatory energy mapping of public buildings to ensure that profitable energy efficiency projects are implemented in all state, county, and municipal buildings where possible, within the next three years.

Consider how the Planning and Building Act and other means can provide stronger incentives for the development of waterborne energy from the sea to meet the heating and cooling needs of buildings in several Norwegian cities and towns.
Increase the efforts for energy measures in municipal housing and introduce a designated support and incentive scheme for municipalities until 2030.
Establish a set of measures for skills enhancement regarding energy saving in the construction industry.
Ensure that the new building technical regulations set clearer energy requirements for rehabilitation in order to unlock the significant energy savings potential in the existing building stock.
Promote a concrete plan for energy efficiency, as well as energy upgrades and rehabilitation of public commercial buildings, and propose to allocate funds for the implementation of this plan.

Introduce a requirement for energy audits of all commercial buildings with high energy consumption, or that have an energy label of E or lower, combined with skills enhancement for operational personnel.

Promote a proposal to allocate funds to counties and municipalities so that they are enabled to temporarily hire or engage energy advisors for individuals and businesses, who can help people plan and implement profitable investments to reduce energy consumption.
Remove regulatory barriers that hinder local energy production, local energy storage, and the trading of energy between buildings.
Stop the planning of the Ålesund city package and ensure that the plans for toll collection are scrapped, in accordance with the will of the people in the city.
Ensure full state funding for Lerstadvegen and initiate this project as soon as possible.

Ensure that the Norwegian Public Roads Administration accelerates the planning work for the new E39 Vegsund–Breivika as soon as possible, where especially the Veibust intersection must be planned, fully funded by the state, and implemented as a separate project as soon as possible.
Initiate the necessary planning work no later than within 2022–2023 and ensure the commencement of the project E16 Fagernes south–Hande during the period 2022–2027.
Initiate the necessary planning work no later than within 2022–2023 and ensure the commencement of the project rv. 13 Vikafjellet during the period 2022–2027.
Initiate the necessary planning work no later than 2022–2023 and ensure the commencement of the E39 Vågsbotn–Klauvaneset project during the period 2022–2027.
Initiate the necessary planning work no later than 2022–2023 and ensure the commencement of the E14 Stjørdal–Storlien project during the period 2022–2027.
Initiate the necessary planning work no later than within 2022–2023 and ensure the commencement of the E134 Bakka–Solheim project during the period 2022–2027.
Initiate the necessary planning work no later than within 2022–2023 and ensure the commencement of the new rv. 15 Strynefjellet during the period 2022–2027.
Ensure that a road to Geiranger as a year-round route is planned into the project for the new rv. 15 Strynefjellet, and that Møre og Romsdal County Municipality is included in this work.

Further develop the collaboration with the other Nordic countries on a full-scale infrastructure plan for hydrogen in the Nordics aimed at the distribution of hydrogen to rolling stock operating between the Nordic countries. The plan should include emission-free rail freight and passenger transport between the Nordic countries.
Strengthen the climate considerations in procurement processes that involve rail-based materials.

Provide an updated knowledge base for hydrogen as an energy carrier for trains. Here, one should differentiate between freight trains, passenger trains, and short and long distances, and consider this in relation to the establishment of hydrogen hubs.
Consider how to facilitate the integration of the business sector into hydrogen value chains for rail vehicles as part of an export market.
Ensure that the regulations for managing new energy carriers such as hydrogen and ammonia are also reviewed and updated for rail vehicles.

Evaluate which routes are best suited for deploying trains powered by hydrogen as an energy carrier. This should be assessed based on the entire value chain, including production, distribution, and consumption.

Prioritize the introduction of difference contracts for hydrogen that are also aimed at realization and integration in rail vehicles, where it is not possible or economically viable to use other zero-emission energy carriers.
Present a scheduled progress plan to transition the remaining diesel-powered railway lines to zero-emission technology.

Come back with proposals for necessary legal amendments that ensure that Nav uses the ordinary delay interest in cases where users have received too little payment due to an error by Nav and are therefore entitled to a back payment.
Carry out planning and construction of the stretch Ålesund–Tresfjord Bridge as the first sub-project of the new E39 Ålesund–Molde.
Ensure that a genuine impartial investigation of other crossing options over the Romsdalsfjord is conducted. This particularly concerns an overseas option at Romsdalsaksen.
Engage in dialogue with Vestland County Municipality with the aim of reaching an agreement where the toll fee portion in the Kvinnherad package is replaced with state funding.
Engage in dialogue with Vestland County Municipality with the aim of reaching an agreement where the toll portion of the Askøy package is replaced by state and county funds.
Ensure that Nordøyvegen receives a reduction in toll fees covered by state funds, equivalent to the ferry ticket calculated based on the rates as of January 1, 2021.

Make an assessment of whether the state's contribution through the ferry replacement funds for Nordøyvegen should be recalculated based on current ferry fares, and that any increased contribution should be used to reduce the toll rates for the project. Before the assessment is returned to the Parliament, toll collection can begin in accordance with the approved Prop. 93 S (2021-2022).

Amend the specialist regulation § 18 first paragraph to allow doctors who have completed practical training in another EU/EEA country, upon application and specific assessment of learning objectives, to have all or part of the practical training approved as LIS1 service.

Approve the learning objectives in LIS1 (doctor in specialization) based on the achieved competencies in KBU (clinical basic education). Doctors trained through KBU should be given the opportunity to apply directly for LIS2/3 and complete the missing learning objectives in LIS1 during their specialist training.

Approve newly graduated doctors who have obtained the cand.med. degree in Denmark, so that it becomes possible to receive medical authorization after completing their education and apply for LIS1 (doctor in specialization) in Norway without having completed KBU (clinical basic education).

Investigate the possibility of amending the Specialist Regulation § 18, first paragraph, to allow doctors who have completed practical training in another EU/EEA country, upon application and specific assessment of learning objectives, to have all or part of their practical training approved as LIS1 service, while ensuring that the LIS1 scheme is secured and maintained. The government is requested to return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner by the end of 2022.
Work to significantly reduce the quotas on mackerel tuna until the stock is at a substantially higher level than it is today.
Work with Danish authorities to ensure that there is no two-zone fishing for halibut in Norway's economic zone south of 62° north and in the Skagerrak between November 20 and March 31.
Introduce interest compensation schemes for necessary investments to implement free after-school care (SFO) nationwide.

Initiate a pilot project in collaboration with KS, where municipalities are invited to implement more full-time positions for employees working in after-school programs (SFO), in addition to strengthening the collaboration between schools and SFO. The project will examine whether this can help enhance the quality in both schools and SFO, as well as provide better working conditions for employees. The Parliament requests the government to introduce arrangements for rewarding municipalities that participate, and additionally to conduct a follow-up evaluation of the pilot projects.

Return to the Parliament with an assessment of whether oversight of quality in after-school programs (SFO) should be introduced, as well as whether guidelines for space, staffing, and competence in the provision should be established.

Facilitate increased collaboration between after-school programs and the cultural school, volunteer organizations, and local businesses and industries, which can support the school's broad view of knowledge and competence.
Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner by spring 2023 with a discussion of alternative final assessment methods.

Promote the necessary proposals to give counties that wish to do so the opportunity to implement local pilot schemes with alternative final assessment forms in lower secondary and upper secondary education, and to announce funding for conducting follow-up research on such trials.
Propose concrete measures to ensure increased freedom of expression, academic freedom, and research freedom at academic institutions.
Come back to the Parliament with a bill that implements the parts of the Kierulf Committee's proposal that are considered appropriate.
Specify and strengthen the importance of academic freedom as a cornerstone of education and research in existing governance documents for the higher education and research sector.
Report to the Storting on the work regarding international regulation of cryptocurrency, no later than in the state budget for 2023.
Investigate a transaction fee on cryptocurrency transferred from data centers that mine cryptocurrency.
Work for the regulation of cryptocurrency transactions through an international tax regime.
Work internationally in the UN, EU, and OECD for a ban on "proof of work" cryptocurrency mining.
Investigate a ban on large-scale commercial energy-intensive cryptocurrency mining.
Investigate how to achieve a reduction in large-scale energy-intensive cryptocurrency mining in Norway.

Investigate how energy-intensive cryptocurrency mining can be subject to full electricity tax. The investigation should take a broad approach and consider, but not necessarily be limited to, tax changes that specifically target data centers primarily engaged in cryptocurrency mining, as well as tax changes that affect all data centers where cryptocurrency mining occurs in their facilities, even on a smaller scale.
Task the Tax Committee with investigating the issue of taxation upon emigration.
Ensure that tax liability for latent gains on shares and similar assets arises immediately upon moving out of the country.

Strengthen the Ukrainian volunteer schools and educational programs so that Ukrainian children and youth can follow the Ukrainian curriculum and continue to receive language instruction in Ukrainian, including by providing assistance with facilities and funding for teachers and teaching materials.
Abolish the visa requirement for Ukrainian citizens without biometric passports, provided that they register upon arrival in Norway.
Consider accepting Ukrainian domestic ID cards secured with Ukrainian Bank-ID as a substitute for passports.
Initiate a municipal housing program where individuals who accommodate refugees in pre-approved homes receive payment for this.

Enter into agreements and provide support to serious, voluntary actors who can offer safe and secure transportation of refugees to Norway, including conducting thorough assessments to ensure that the actors have no other intentions than to help people in need.
Make it easier and faster to obtain authorization to work in Norway, among other things by increasing the capacity within the professional recognition authorities.
Assist in establishing streamlined systems in the municipalities/counties where refugees are settled, for the rapid assessment of refugees' skills, language abilities, and employability.

Prepare to provide transportation for Ukrainian citizens fleeing, including entering into agreements with airlines and other transport services, so that these can be implemented immediately when EU countries request assistance from Norwegian authorities to alleviate the refugee situation.
Ensure that privately housed refugees receive benefits for living expenses just like those in reception centers do.

Facilitate the establishment of systems by municipalities, county municipalities, Nav, and labor market actors to provide refugees with the quickest possible access to skills training/education to enter the local/regional labor market in sectors where there is a demand for skilled workers and other labor, for example, based on the experiences from the development of the "Gloppen model" in Vestland county.

Develop a plan for quickly responding to requests if Ukraine's neighboring countries ask for assistance in handling refugees with collective protection. The plan should include an agreement on transportation.

Ensure that healthcare services are prepared to receive Ukrainian refugees with temporary protection and provide those in need with medical assistance and psychological support, and guarantee that extraordinary costs related to this will be compensated.
Develop a reception plan to ensure that Ukrainian children and youth are warmly welcomed upon arrival, including provisions for their integration into schools and kindergartens.
Introduce an independent oversight system for asylum reception centers.

Ensure that the criteria for closing asylum reception centers emphasize quality over price, so that the best quality centers are retained when the number of residents in asylum reception centers decreases.

Look at measures to ensure that children do not have to be moved from asylum reception centers to asylum reception centers multiple times before they are settled, and ensure that the best interests of the child are a central criterion when assessing the closure of asylum reception centers.
Give asylum seekers temporary work permits while they wait for a response to their application, and ensure that the Tax Administration and other agencies do not become a bottleneck in the system.

Strengthen Norwegian language training and knowledge of rights and obligations in the workplace for all refugees with collective temporary protection, regardless of the length of the introduction program.

Establish a system where each refugee who has been granted legal residency can find housing on their own, without losing their right to the introduction program. It is assumed that the funding follows each individual, so that the municipality where the individual chooses to settle receives introduction support at regular rates.

Ensure that all refugees and asylum seekers arriving in the kingdom have access to information about their rights and opportunities early in the arrival phase, and that this information is also tailored to children of different ages.

Facilitate early assessment of children and families' needs and develop a plan for psychosocial support that begins upon arrival or at emergency reception centers and continues in the municipalities after resettlement. It is particularly important to develop a psychosocial offer for children and families who live privately and are not accommodated in reception centers.

Implement follow-up research on the measures that are now being introduced for Ukrainian refugees, to assess whether these measures can also facilitate the integration process for other asylum seekers and refugees coming to Norway.
Consider automatically granting work permits for registered Ukrainian refugees where there is no doubt about identity, for example, if the applicant has a biometric passport.

Ensure that Ukrainian refugees and their children have access to information about their rights and opportunities in Norway at an early stage of their arrival, regardless of whether they are staying in reception centers or are privately accommodated. The information must be tailored to children of different ages.
Encourage municipalities to establish cooperation agreements with voluntary organizations to strengthen local integration efforts.

Suspend immigration cases that affect children and their parents' residence in Norway, including cases with expulsion decisions, until the government returns to the Storting with concrete proposals for follow-up on the investigation submitted by an external working group to the Ministry of Justice and Public Security on January 24, 2022, in order to better safeguard the best interests of the child.

Promote a proposal that the main rule for violations of the Immigration Act should be other forms of sanctions than expulsion, such as fines, fees, or an extension of the residence period before obtaining permanent residency or citizenship, when the foreign national has children residing in Norway.

Ensure that the consideration of the child's best interests in deportation cases is given more weight than is currently practiced, by implementing changes similar to those made in the cases of long-term resident asylum-seeking children and unaccompanied minor asylum seekers.
