Ensure that, as a general rule, residence is granted on humanitarian grounds instead of referring to family immigration in cases involving children with residence permits and parents with rejected asylum applications.

Propose amendments to the law that ensure that asylum seekers who do not have approved travel documents or equivalent are also given the opportunity to work, and that they are allowed to have a work permit until a potential negative decision on their asylum application is implemented.

Promote a case to the Storting regarding access to healthcare for individuals without permanent residence permits in Norway, ensuring that those who are already in the country receive adequate primary healthcare services on par with other citizens.

Implement necessary measures to ensure that non-returnable asylum seekers and undocumented migrants have real access to essential healthcare, and request that the government, in this context, ensure that Norway's human rights obligations in this area are upheld, and if necessary, return to the Storting with proposals to ensure that these obligations are met.
Instruct the immigration authorities to halt all returns of people to Afghanistan and to extend the suspension of the obligation to leave for Afghanistan with immediate effect.

Consider the possibilities of structuring the natural disaster insurance scheme in a way that better addresses the need for prevention, while still ensuring that this does not come at the expense of the principle of a solidarity-based and uniform premium determination for insurance customers across the country.

Investigate environmental and climate aspects related to natural disaster insurance with the aim of incorporating it into the Natural Disaster Insurance Act and returning to the Parliament within a reasonable timeframe.

Promote a proposition to introduce an obligation for Norwegian service providers to report if they discover that their services are being used for the illegal storage or distribution of abusive material.

Engage in dialogue with relevant providers of digital payment services to raise awareness among parents and guardians about their ability to monitor transactions in and out of their children's payment accounts, as well as to find solutions to strengthen parental control.

Investigate the introduction of an obligation for Norwegian service providers to report if they discover that their services are being used for the illegal storage or distribution of abusive material.
Promote proposals for changing the conditions for the use of permanent restraining orders, so that the threshold is lowered and the consideration for victims is given greater weight.
Investigate changes to the conditions for the use of permanent restraining orders, so that the threshold is lowered and the consideration for victims is given greater weight.

Conduct a regulatory work on reporting from the correctional services, where the consideration for victims and the bereaved is emphasized more strongly than what is included in the current regulations.
Promote a proposal for the introduction of a system for electronic monitoring (so-called reverse violence alarm) in cases of violation of restraining orders.

Task the Criminal Law Council with conducting an additional investigation into the penalty levels for the provisions on sexual offenses in the Penal Code. The additional investigation is requested to be completed before the summer of 2023.

Establish a rape commission that is to deliver its report by September 2023. The commission should be broadly composed of various types of expertise in pedagogy, psychology, social work, police science, and law.
Return to the Storting with a review of the various municipal and county compensation and restitution schemes to gain an overview of potentially problematic discriminatory treatment.

Ensure that there is equal access to compensation for failures of the public sector towards a person who was a child when the failure occurred, regardless of where the person lives in the country, and if necessary, establish a national compensation scheme or a national framework for municipal schemes.

Return to the Parliament with a proposal to coordinate the regulations for compensation with the rules for statute of limitations in the Penal Code, so that claims for compensation do not expire before any potential prosecution.

Return to the Storting with a comprehensive review of public compensation schemes, which particularly examines which groups are not covered by the schemes, and assess how these should be included in or covered by other arrangements.
Engage in dialogue with KS to ensure more consistent practices for handling cases of compensation for failures of the public sector towards a person who was a child when the failure occurred.

Investigate an alternative where the perpetrator of violence is granted party status as in the proposal, but where the perpetrator cannot oppose the administrative process and thereby lead the case into the court system.

Do not implement the violence compensation law until alternative provisions regarding the non-accrual of late payment interest on compensation claims against inmates serving prison sentences have been investigated and prepared.

Ensure that victim compensation and factors relevant to reporting remain a prioritized area in the new law on support for legal aid, and conduct a comprehensive assessment of how the legal aid scheme in violence compensation cases can be strengthened.
Return to the budgetary consequences of the new violence compensation law in connection with the reallocation of the budget for 2022.

Ensure that the Office for Victims of Crime Compensation in Vardø is assigned additional tasks so that the staffing at the office is not reduced. The Parliament also asks the government to consider measures to strengthen the Office for Victims of Crime Compensation.

Establish in regulation that no late payment interest shall accrue on the state's recourse claims against the perpetrator in compensation cases for violence while the perpetrator is serving a regular prison sentence.
Propose the necessary legal amendments to dissolve the county boards for child welfare and social matters, and transfer the responsibilities of these boards to the ordinary courts.

Review today's crisis center offerings and return to the Parliament with a financing model that ensures strengthened, predictable frameworks and an equal, round-the-clock, year-round crisis center service throughout the country.
Reintroduce the earmarking of state funds for crisis centers in the proposal for the state budget for 2023, in order to secure the crisis center economy in the short term.
Ensure that the crisis center services for the Sámi indigenous population are improved, and inform the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Promote proposals for changes to laws and regulations so that it is up to each individual couple how they want to distribute parental leave between themselves.
Promote a proposal to abolish the division of parental leave and revert to the arrangement of 10 weeks reserved for each parent.
Propose to extend the total duration of the parental benefit period for childbirth by 4 weeks at a 100% coverage rate and 5 weeks at an 80% coverage rate.
Promote a proposal to introduce the possibility of transferring leave to the other parent when one is unable to take the leave.

Conduct a broad evaluation of the division of parental leave and the consequences it has for families and society, and report back to the Parliament with the results of the evaluation in an appropriate manner. The evaluation should include an assessment of whether there is a basis for adjusting the rules for transferring leave time between parents, as well as how it may be possible to provide families with increased flexibility in the disbursement of parental leave benefits, allowing them to take a lower percentage than 80 percent but have a longer leave period.

Conduct an evaluation of the parental leave scheme that came into effect on July 1, 2018. The evaluation should primarily focus on parents' experiences, the child's perspective, the pension consequences of many mothers taking unpaid leave, health implications for mothers, as well as experiences with breastfeeding as a result of the changes in the father and mother quotas.

Suspend the construction work of the mining company Nordic Mining by the Førdefjord until legal clarifications from the supervisory authority ESA are resolved and the ongoing lawsuit between Arctic Mineral Resources and Nordic Mining is settled.
Withdraw licenses for mining with sea disposal planned in Repparfjorden (Nussir ASA) and Førdefjorden (Nordic Mining AS).
Elaborate and return to the Parliament with a proposal for a deposit fee for unused surplus material from mineral extraction.

Discuss a system with an environmental appeals board, aimed at establishing a court-like body where one can easily challenge administrative decisions that have an impact on nature, the environment, and climate.

Elaborate and return to the Parliament with a proposal that ensures that lawsuits brought before the courts on behalf of nature, environmental, and climate interests, as a general rule, should be exempt from legal costs according to the Aarhus Convention.

Take a driving role for a binding agreement where the polluter pays and the precautionary principle is the basis in the negotiations for a new nature agreement under the UN Convention on Biological Diversity.
Discuss methods for best practices in effectively involving municipalities, local communities, and youth in the efforts to reverse the decline of red-listed species and natural habitats in Norway.
Come back to the Parliament with a concrete plan for which measures should be implemented for Norway to achieve its adopted goal of 30% protection of nature by 2030.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to expand the scope of the Nature Diversity Act to apply throughout Norway's economic zone.

Develop a national highway plan with the goal of building an efficient high-speed road network that connects the country by 2050. Continuous high-speed routes must be established from north to south and east to west, including E6 and E134.
Establish state full funding for all national road projects.
Establish the following standards for the development of the high-speed road network: 110 km/h on narrow four-lane roads and 130 km/h on full-standard four-lane roads.
Develop a financing plan to address the maintenance backlog on the railway and return to the Parliament with this in connection with the state budget for 2023.
Present a plan to phase out the practice of long-term summer closures of the railway in the central Eastern Norway region.
Come back to the Parliament with an evaluation of the consequences of the railway reform during 2022.

Review the corporate structure and organization of the railway sector, with the aim of ensuring an overarching organization that has control over train operations, workshops, maintenance, emergency preparedness, infrastructure, procurement, and property, and report back to the Parliament on this by the end of 2023.
Ensure that the train traffic in and around Oslo is not divided, and that the operations are assigned to Vy, which currently handles this service.

Promote a proposal to supplement the law on good trading practices in the grocery sector with provisions that: a. Prevent improper discrimination against the grocery chains' own brands and independent and competing brands. b. Ensure that a grocery chain selling its own brands cannot use competition-sensitive information received in negotiations with suppliers of independent and competing brands in the development of its own brands or in other ways that may affect competition between its own and independent brands.
Investigate a ban on private label products (PLP) in the grocery industry and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Create a digital sales data register for sales data of goods traded in the grocery market, and ensure access for all producers and suppliers.
Develop regulations and systems to ensure openness and transparency regarding how prices are set in the grocery market.

Introduce a requirement for equal purchasing terms in the grocery market from suppliers with significant market power, either through regulation or by presenting a legislative proposal to the Parliament on this matter. Suppliers with significant market power are to be understood as suppliers of groceries with more than 50% market share within one or more product categories in the grocery market. The legal content should include the following: A requirement that suppliers with significant market power must offer all grocery chains and wholesalers equal purchasing terms, unless the supplier can document a valid justification through differences in production or distribution costs or varying value of specific counter-performances. A requirement that suppliers with significant market power must provide grocery chains and wholesalers equal access to benefits and counter-performances such as bonuses, discounts, and rebate schemes, marketing and promotional support, or financial benefits for purchasing services. A requirement that suppliers with significant market power must operate with transparent terms towards grocery chains and wholesalers, so that informed decisions about purchases can be made.
Introduce a detailed regulation for the grocery industry to the Competition Act § 11, where a dominant position is defined as grocery chains with a market share of 30 percent or more.

Come back to the Storting with proposals for ownership restrictions in the food value chain in Norway, including how large a single actor can be at all levels and restrictions on vertical and horizontal integration.

Map the usage and pricing of private label products (PL) compared to corresponding prices for branded products from the industry. The government is requested to introduce requirements for justification from the grocery trade if significant differences in margin markups are discovered.
Provision in the regulation that the Grocery Supervision Authority is granted the authority to supervise the logistics area and the use of private label products (PLP) in the grocery market.

Investigate measures to ensure competition and greater transparency within the wholesale and distribution sector of the grocery trade, including oversight of the pricing calculations for distribution services.
Consider how actors without significant access to capital can gain entry into the grocery trade.
Consider measures that contribute to ensuring that food producers receive a fair share of the value creation in the food supply chain.

Send out for consultation a permanent regulation under the Competition Act § 14 regarding unjustified price discrimination, and possibly other provisions concerning unjustified price discrimination. The following considerations should be part of the consultation draft: a. An operational definition of significant market power b. An operational definition of what constitutes a product category c. An operational definition of different purchasing conditions d. That if suppliers with significant market power are to offer grocery chains and wholesalers different purchasing conditions, the supplier must be able to justify the difference objectively. Reference is made to decision 572 (cf. Innst. 185 S (2020–2021)) for the definition and consequences of differences in purchasing conditions that cannot be justified objectively. The government is requested to return to the Parliament by the end of 2022 with the results of the consultation and proposals for further follow-up. The Parliament asks the government to consider legislative changes to create increased competition in the grocery market and lower prices for consumers.
Develop and present a package of measures for the transport industry, aimed at assisting the sector in the acute situation it is facing due to the extraordinarily high fuel prices.
Ensure that flexibility regarding fuel costs is incorporated into public procurement of transport services, and that arrangements are made for such flexibility to be included in existing agreements.
Take the initiative with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to stop demands for payment of Ukrainian state debt and further cancel and restructure the debt.
Halve the ferry fares on national and county ferries in the revised national budget for 2022, compared to the ferry fares on October 1, 2021.
Ensure that island communities without a mainland connection, with fewer than 100,000 passengers annually, receive free ferry and/or boat services.
Cut further in ferry fares in the state budget for 2023, and in connection with the budget proposal, present a binding plan for further cuts in fares leading up to free ferry and boat connections.

Investigate a new and moderate alternative to the ferry-free E39. The alternative should ensure lower greenhouse gas emissions, less encroachment on nature and agricultural land, and reduced costs. The alternative should also free up funds for other purposes, such as increased landslide protection and maintaining existing roads.
Ensure that the entire E39 Ring Road East is planned as a cohesive project with a continuous four-lane motorway.
Develop a scaling-up plan with earmarked funds to increase staffing in the municipal child welfare services.

Investigate what constitutes professionally sound staffing in institutional child welfare services with regard to the therapeutic environment related to good care and treatment, as well as a safe living and working environment for both children, youth, and staff, with particular focus on the challenges associated with working alone.
Expand the Debt Register to include secured debt, such as mortgage and car loans, as soon as possible.

Expand the Debt Register so that it includes all types of debt, both secured and unsecured. The government must also conduct thorough investigations to ensure privacy and consider whether certain types of debt should therefore not be included.

Develop a national recruitment strategy for more teachers and other staff in schools and kindergartens, and anchor this in the Parliament within one year. This includes pilot projects with available funding to scale up and expand the team around the student with more professional groups, which will be followed by research and evaluation.

Strengthen the health stations and school health services by promoting proposals for a concrete escalation plan, which includes strengthening the nursing education for health nurses and treating it equally with corresponding educations.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how to increase the number of positions in the Educational-Psychological Service.
Take the initiative for a project for permanent, full-time positions in schools and kindergartens together with the parties in the labor market.
Establish a grant scheme for further education and training aimed at assistants employed in schools, kindergartens, and after-school programs.

Facilitate arrangements with permanent employees to cover substitute needs in schools and kindergartens, both with qualified personnel for teaching positions and other personnel for other positions, and return to the Parliament with a plan for this.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to strengthen the contact teacher resource with an additional contact teacher hour in middle school.

Promote a proposal to grant unqualified personnel in teaching positions the right to further education and training to become qualified, as well as to establish a searchable grant scheme through the county governor to facilitate further education and training.

Increase the funding category for teacher education programs, both for schools and kindergartens, so that teacher education programs are funded according to cost category C or higher, and come back with a proposal regarding this in connection with the state budget for 2023.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to increase the staffing and pedagogical standards for kindergartens to 50% kindergarten teachers and at least 25% child and youth workers.
Facilitate changes in the current funding of kindergartens so that more kindergartens can offer more flexible opening hours.
Promote a proposal to introduce a guarantee that all children will be offered a daycare place immediately after parental leave ends, regardless of the child's age.
Promote a proposal to introduce free core hours in daycare for children under 2 years old in low-income families.

Establish a committee to review the mental health services for children and adolescents and promote proposals for better collaboration, more equitable services across the country, as well as a funding scheme based on professional trust and patient pathways.
Ensure a greater focus on life skills in schools, and make sure that this receives more emphasis in several of the established subjects in schools.
Ensure to strengthen the mental health services for children and young people by securing more school psychologists.
Ensure that all mentally ill children and young people under the age of 13 who need it have access to round-the-clock treatment both on weekdays and weekends.
Conduct a comprehensive review of performance-based funding for maternity and childbirth services.

Provide an account of the status of hospital investments, how increased investment costs affect hospital development, and what plans are currently in place from the health enterprises and the government to ensure that rising expenses do not unnecessarily impact either operations or necessary investments.
Investigate a separation between operations and investments in healthcare enterprises, so that unexpected costs for construction and investments do not directly impact the operations of hospitals.
Increase the proportion of activity-based funding in specialist health services to 60 percent.
Review the system of activity-based financing in specialist health services, with the aim of phasing it out.

Replace activity-based funding with full block funding within outpatient mental health care and interdisciplinary specialized substance abuse treatment until a comprehensive change of the funding model has been made.
Replace activity-based funding with full block grant funding for maternity and childbirth care until a comprehensive change of the funding model has been made.
Conduct a comprehensive review of the current financing of specialist health services.

Ensure that the maternity and childbirth departments receive earmarked, fully framework-controlled funding, pending the comprehensive review of performance-based financing for maternity and childbirth services.
Ensure predictability in the dental care offer with a multi-year ramp-up plan to reduce waiting times, so that patients are guaranteed necessary dental health assistance.

Initiate work on the establishment of a new entry point in social security financing to ensure that victims of torture and abuse, as well as individuals with odontophobia, have a predictable right to necessary dental treatment.
Promote a proposal to extend the limit for self-determined abortion to the 18th week of pregnancy.

Return to the Parliament with a proposal to ensure women's right to self-determination regarding abortion, where the committees are abolished and the current limit for legal abortion is maintained, and where women are provided with necessary guidance and support.

Ensure that the government-appointed committee established to review the provisions of the abortion law investigates and proposes how the committees can be abolished, even after week 18, with an emphasis on safeguarding the woman's autonomy and her need for support and guidance.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a change in the law where § 2a of the Abortion Act is repealed and that the rules stating that abortion also applies to fetal reduction are clarified.
Ensure that the government-appointed committee that is to be established proposes how the boards can be dissolved, and how women's autonomy and need for support and guidance are safeguarded.

Ensure that all women who wish to have an abortion have a genuine opportunity to have it performed at the hospital if they desire, and that those who choose to do it at home are provided with close support from healthcare personnel throughout the process.

Strengthen the right to follow-up after an abortion, and enhance the services that provide qualified support, counseling, and follow-up for women who are considering, are about to have, or have undergone an abortion.

Promote the necessary legislative proposals to ensure control over which individuals are allowed to work with Ukrainian refugees on a voluntary basis, and to prevent individuals with a history of abuse from performing such work.

Strengthen the issuance of passports by establishing redundancy in production capacity beyond the current deliveries from the manufacturer Thales. This includes entering into agreements with alternative suppliers for Norwegian passports and national ID cards.

To take the initiative for countries within Schengen to accept publicly issued identification documents, which presumably confirm Norwegian citizenship, as travel documents during a transitional period. This includes police identification cards, military identification, etc.
Consider establishing a temporary arrangement for identification using combinations of expired documents and other documents, until the passport crisis is under control.
Consider issuing free national ID cards to encourage more people to choose them instead of passports.
Consider various methods for extending expired passports, such as simple processing and a stamp.
Consider a digital pass solution based on the architecture of the corona certificate or digital driver's license.
Create an easily accessible and updated overview of which Schengen countries Norwegians can travel to without a passport or ID card, and which countries still require such documents upon entry.
Look into the possibilities of temporarily extending the validity of expired passports, after discussions with other countries.
Ensure that the long queues for passport collection are reduced by creating separate queues or temporary offices for people who are only there to pick up their passports.
Facilitate that everyone has the opportunity to collect new passports at the passport office, so that they do not have to wait to receive the passport by mail.
Explore the possibilities of securing the necessary raw materials and components for producing passports through the EU or other channels, as the Solberg government did during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Look into the possibilities of establishing a contingency collaboration with other passport manufacturers so that in the future we are not dependent on just one passport producer.
Ensure that the price of ID cards is reduced, so that people have an incentive to choose ID cards when they do not need a passport.
Find solutions that increase the number of places that issue passports in Norway in the short and long term.
Engage in dialogue with the police districts to explore the possibility of offering mobile passport issuance in rural municipalities.

Ensure better passport preparedness for the future by entering into contracts for the production of Norwegian passports and national ID cards with multiple manufacturers rather than relying solely on the current supplier.
Investigate the possibilities for a national emergency stockpile of components for passport production.

Ensure that there are options available to produce passports in crisis situations nationally, so that there is preparedness in case the passport manufacturer that Norway purchases from encounters production issues.

Implement immediate measures aimed at reducing waiting times for obtaining a new passport, for example by extending opening hours in the evenings and on weekends, as well as increasing staffing at passport offices with high demand.
Introduce temporary border control.
Increase the number of conscripted personnel in the Civil Defense to 12,000.
Develop a plan for increased construction of public shelters to ensure sufficient national shelter capacity.

Present a plan for the rapid establishment of 50 new positions in the civil defense districts for the management of inspections and the increase of shelter capacity, based on the new threat landscape.
Present a long-term plan for the Civil Defense to ensure a sustainable development of capacity across the entire spectrum of Civil Defense preparedness.

Conduct a quick review of all shelters in the country to ensure that the shelters are in satisfactory condition and can be used by the population during critical events, in accordance with the requirements set out in the regulations on shelters.
Conduct a review of the implementation of the exemption provisions in the regulations on shelters, chapter VI.
Send the proposals in Document 8:213 S (2021–2022) regarding the strengthening of civil preparedness to the Total Preparedness Commission for a comprehensive assessment.

Look at how the authorities can take necessary measures to ensure protection and safety for people with disabilities in risk situations across the entire crisis spectrum, and ensure that organizations representing people with disabilities are heard in this regard.

Ensure that individuals who have been granted residence permits under the Immigration Act § 34 have the right and obligation to participate in an introduction program, but that these individuals should be able to do so on a part-time basis so that it can be more easily combined with any work and/or studies.

Ensure that individuals who have been granted residence permits under the Immigration Act § 28 have the right and obligation to participate in an introduction program, but that these individuals should be able to do so on a part-time basis so that it can be more easily combined with any work and/or studies.
Ensure increased flexibility by temporarily making exceptions to staffing and space standards in schools and kindergartens.
Consider establishing collaboration with private actors to expedite the skills mapping and career guidance for Ukrainian refugees.

Simplify the arrangement for agreed self-settlement, so that in a transitional phase it is sufficient for the municipality to approve self-settlement for displaced persons from Ukraine with a residence permit who are residing in the municipality through Alternative Reception Place (AMOT).

Request the municipalities to offer and facilitate kindergarten, school, and leisure activities for Ukrainian children while awaiting registration and/or settlement. The municipalities will be fully compensated for these costs.

Consider renegotiating the supplementary agreement between Norway and the USA on defense cooperation of April 16, 2021, if the international political situation and/or domestic political conditions in the USA warrant it, even before the expiration of the initial ten-year agreement period.

Ensure that Norwegian authorities at all times have access to and full insight into the operations in the agreed areas described in the supplementary agreement between Norway and the USA on defense cooperation dated April 16, 2021.

Ensure that no American use of the areas described in the supplementary agreement between Norway and the USA on defense cooperation dated April 16, 2021, related to activities in third countries, occurs without consultation with Norway.
Ensure that any extensions of the supplementary agreement between Norway and the USA on defense cooperation from April 16, 2021, to new areas are presented as proposals to the Storting.
Investigate the possibilities of allowing the establishment of allied bases on Norwegian soil even in peacetime, as a supplement to the development of our own defense.

Engage in discussions with Sweden and Finland regarding a coordinated approach to the supplemental agreement on defense cooperation with the USA that takes into account the new security political situation in the Nordic region.

Ensure that any potential supplementary agreement for defense cooperation with the USA does not allow the USA to commit violations of human rights and Norwegian law in areas where the USA may be granted exclusive usage rights in Norway.
Ensure that any additional agreement on defense cooperation with the USA does not prevent Norwegian authorities from prosecuting American personnel who commit offenses on Norwegian soil.

Investigate how public authorities can better collaborate across societal sectors to counter false news and disinformation that is spread or amplified by foreign threat actors. There is a need for a review of the various agencies' mandates, organization, and resources with the aim of achieving better collaboration and coordination, and thus a more effective and timely response.

Implement a systematic and long-term national effort against fake news and disinformation. The project should span at least five years, starting in 2022. It should include a larger, interdisciplinary project organized by Media City Bergen. The project should directly contribute to increasing knowledge and competence regarding fake news and disinformation, while also facilitating the development of new solutions and technologies that can be used in the fight against fake news and disinformation.
Initiate dialogue with the EU to explore the possibilities for Norway to become a full participant in the EU's Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP).
To communicate to China that Norway's negotiations for a free trade agreement with the country will be put on hold immediately if China supports Russia militarily in the invasion of Ukraine.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal for the ratification of the amendment to the Rome Statute on the crime of aggression (Kampala amendment).
Come back to the Storting with a proposal for a new provision in the Penal Code Chapter 16 that criminalizes acts of aggression, in line with the Kampala amendment to the Rome Statute.
Promote proposals to exempt households from grid fees.
Come back with a separate case assessing how the financing of the network expansion can be structured in a more geographically and socially equitable manner.

Come back with a case where the principles for the construction of the central grid are updated with criteria to better take into account considerations for nature, agricultural land protection, culture, and local participation in accordance with the purpose clause of the Energy Act.

Ensure that the underground and submarine cable is investigated as a real alternative on par with overhead lines in matters being processed by NVE, including the construction of the power line Blåfalli–Gismarvik.
Ensure that all approvals of plans for the development and operation of petroleum resources (PUD) granted after December 22, 2020, are revoked.

Implement an immediate moratorium on the processing of all new applications for the Plan for the Development and Operation of Petroleum Resources (PUD) until a system with clear, transparent criteria for climate assessments of combustion emissions is in place.

Establish clear, transparent criteria for climate assessments of combustion emissions in connection with PUD applications, in accordance with the recommendations of the Norwegian Institute for Human Rights.

Change the PUD guidelines to require that climate assessments of combustion emissions within the framework of the 1.5-degree target are subject to impact assessments and sent out for public consultation prior to the final decision.
Change the PUD guidelines to require that considerations for the best interests of children are assessed and sent for consultation prior to the final decision, in accordance with the Constitution.
Ensure that all municipal wastewater treatment plants discharging into water bodies where high nitrogen levels lead to a weakened ecological status implement nitrogen removal by no later than 2027.

Present a case to the Storting, no later than in connection with the state budget for 2023, regarding a national plan for the management and limitation of nutrient runoff to coastal waters. The plan should ensure that water quality everywhere is maintained or brought within the requirements for "good status" or better according to the Water Framework Directive § 4 by 2027.

Provide an update on the work with the Comprehensive Action Plan for a clean and rich Oslofjord with an active outdoor life, and suggest how efforts to improve water quality in the Oslofjord in particular and along the entire coast can be accelerated.

Develop a system for monitoring water quality in aquaculture fjords and create a plan for how to incorporate nutrient salt discharges into a traffic light system to prevent over-fertilization in fjords with open aquaculture facilities.

Propose amendments to the climate law, with a new goal of gradually phasing out and eliminating Norway's total contributions to CO2 emissions elsewhere in the world, including from Norwegian-produced oil and gas.
Investigate how an increased CO2 tax can be structured as a refund scheme or climate rebate, designed with a progressive social and geographical profile.
Promote a proposal to update the climate law with new targets and report the targets to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change.
Present an action plan for biogas and establish a goal of producing up to 10 TWh of biogas annually in Norway.

Establish public pilot projects for electric aircraft and other zero- and low-emission solutions in various parts of the country, with the goal that the first domestic scheduled flights with zero emissions should take place by 2030.
Investigate a tax on fossil plastics, implement a producer responsibility scheme, and track plastics, aiming to recycle half of plastic packaging in Norway by 2025.
Resume the work on establishing a new Swedish-Norwegian reindeer grazing convention.

Change the subsidy schemes for reindeer husbandry so that they more effectively encourage increased production, and actively use the subsidy schemes to favor reindeer owners who have reindeer husbandry as their main occupation.
Initiate a comprehensive revision of the reindeer herding law.
Make new assessments and reduce the upper livestock numbers so that they more closely align with the grazing resources.
Introduce an exemption from the road usage tax for operational vehicles in reindeer herding.
Promote a proposal to introduce a national moratorium on the repurposing of cultivated land until 2026.

Ensure that exemptions from the protection of agricultural land can only be granted by a national planning authority. Exemptions from the protection of agricultural land should include a goal that the loss of agricultural land is compensated with new equivalent areas of agricultural land, as long as this can be done without the loss of other valuable nature.
Set a goal that state transportation projects should not lead to the loss of cultivated land.

Present a plan to the Parliament for the fastest possible phase-out of biodiesel based on rapeseed and other agricultural crops in favor of advanced biofuels, no later than in connection with the state budget for 2023, in order to reduce Norway's contribution to the appropriation of arable land in other countries.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan to scale up the production of advanced biofuels in Norway.

Propose changes to the Agricultural Land Act that significantly tighten the possibilities for exemptions from the general requirement that arable land should not be used for purposes other than food production.
Secure an agricultural settlement that makes it profitable to utilize grain areas across the country.
Develop a strategy for economic equality between Norwegian and foreign ownership of Norwegian companies.
Create an overview of uniquely Norwegian taxes and fees, for both individuals and businesses, along with a plan for phasing them out over time.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for necessary changes to the law on the Government Pension Fund to enable the transfer of extraordinarily high revenues from oil and gas to a solidarity fund for assistance, reconstruction, and to counter the food and energy crisis resulting from Russia's invasion and destruction of Ukraine.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for the use of funds from a solidarity fund for assistance, reconstruction, and to counter the food and energy crisis resulting from Russia's invasion and destruction of Ukraine.
Promote a proposal for the establishment of a solidarity fund for assistance, reconstruction, and to counter the food and energy crisis resulting from Russia's invasion and destruction of Ukraine.
Use tax reductions to mitigate the price increase on airline tickets while simultaneously strengthening the competitiveness of the Norwegian aviation industry.

Investigate a progressive air passenger tax that increases with the number of flights taken in a year. Necessary flights within Norway, where there are no good alternatives to flying, should be exempt from the tax.

Propose a comprehensive vehicle tax system based on the following premises: The weight component of the one-time tax for passenger cars and vans/campers is removed. The volume component of the one-time tax for motorcycles is removed. The one-time tax is phased out over time. The registration fee is reduced to cost price. The traffic insurance fee should be technology-neutral. The traffic insurance fee for motorcycles is reduced to 50% of that for passenger cars. The low rate in the traffic insurance fee is abolished, so that vehicles such as vintage cars, snowmobiles, and tractors become tax-free. The road usage tax on fuel is abolished. Accumulated toll debt is erased by utilizing the infrastructure fund. New roads are built without tolls, and upcoming projects in the National Transport Plan should be publicly financed. User fees for ferries on national and county roads are removed. Road pricing as a system for tax collection is rejected.

Present a case for changes to the Police Register Act, or possibly implement changes to the Police Register Regulations, so that it becomes possible for volunteer teams and organizations to have a better police certificate system in line with the needs that the volunteer sector has clearly indicated.
Propose changes to the Police Register Act so that an updated police certificate can also be required for those working with children and young people in private enterprises.

Consider how the authorities can contribute to: the exchange of experiences between different sectors of society, including sports and volunteer organizations, regarding the prevention and handling of sexual harassment and abuse; sports-specific research on the extent and risk factors, similar to what has recently been conducted in the Armed Forces.

Promote a proposal to increase the state contribution to 80 percent for large public transport projects in connection with the state budget for 2023 and to reallocate funds from oversized highway projects.

Take the initiative for the state contribution to large collective projects to also cover cost increases that are beyond the control of local politicians, and report back to the Parliament during 2023.
Promote a proposal to increase the state contribution to 70 percent for large public transport projects in connection with the state budget for 2023.
Initiate a project to complete the Furuset lid on the E6 in Oslo without increasing car traffic.
Consider requiring that treatment seats in ambulances are tested and approved for transport.
Review the regulations for the approval of ambulances and ensure that they are unambiguous.

Review the framework agreement for the delivery of ambulances and ensure that the vehicles are delivered in accordance with the vehicle regulations and Norwegian Standards for ambulances and ambulance equipment, so that the safety of the ambulance personnel is maintained.
Consider introducing a requirement for signage indicating seats that are not approved for transport.
Ensure an arrangement where Norwegian-registered motorhomes can undergo approval for the Danish Tempo 100 scheme in Norway.

Amend the regulation on the one-time tax on motor vehicles § 2-5. The main rule for the definition of a camper van for the calculation of the one-time tax shall be that all vehicles delivered as camper vans from the factory and have EU type approval as camper vans shall be subject to this tax calculation. The current requirements for external height and the wording regarding camper vans with a liftable roof shall be removed.
Change the national regulations for ferry fares so that all recreational vehicles, such as motorhomes, pay fare group B2.
Change the AutoPASS regulations for ferry fares so that all recreational vehicles, such as motorhomes, pay fare group AP1.
Make the necessary changes so that vehicle group M1 is included in prepayment class 1 for the AutoPASS ferry account.

Facilitate the possibility for motorhomes to increase the permitted total weight through the retrofitting of parts carried out by entities other than the final manufacturer. Documentation from the equipment manufacturer and an independent body should be sufficient to approve the increased permitted total weight.
Work to allow driving a motorhome weighing up to 4,250 kg with a Class B driver's license.

Facilitate making it easier for those with a Class B driver's license to obtain a Class A1 license. A prerequisite for such a simplification should be that one has held a Class B driver's license for a minimum of 2 years and has also completed both theoretical and practical courses with practice at a driving school.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan for phasing out the one-time fee for motorcycles, and remove the volume component as soon as possible.
Return to the Storting with an adjustment to the principle that two wheels on a vehicle should result in half the traffic insurance fee.

Come back to the Parliament with a plan for the role of motorcycles in urban transport. The plan is expected to include measures for facilitation, safety, and the right to ride a light motorcycle with a class B driver's license.
Change the age limit for vintage vehicles from 30 years to 20 years with exemption from registration fees and traffic insurance fees.
Include all vehicles in the 50-year rule for EU inspections, as Sweden has done.
Introduce a guarantee that ethanol-free gasoline (98 octane E0) will be available throughout the country.

Facilitate that Møre og Romsdal County Municipality can use any potential underspending in the development of the project approved in Innst. 283 S (2021-2022), cf. Prop. 93 S (2021-2022), for reductions in toll fees.

Implement measures to ensure that age assessments of unaccompanied minor asylum seekers are only conducted in cases where there is doubt about their age, and that the threshold for when there is doubt is adjusted, in order to prevent testing from being carried out where it is not strictly necessary, in accordance with the principle of proportionality.
Initiate a research project to develop a method for psychosocial age assessments.

Develop clear guidelines for what informed consent for age assessment should entail, and ensure that the relevant authorities dealing with unaccompanied minor asylum seekers provide clear information so that informed consent can be obtained.

Review the practice from individual cases involving age assessments of unaccompanied minor asylum seekers, including examining whether the practice is in accordance with current regulations and guidelines, whether unnecessary assessments are conducted, and whether informed and voluntary consent has been obtained, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Assess the need for a new Hammersborg tunnel in light of established local political goals for traffic reduction, as well as conduct a standard analysis of the socio-economic profitability of the project.

Downscale the Hammersborg tunnel project on Ring 1 so that the tunnel is only made available for public transport and emergency vehicles, while also ensuring that safety considerations are taken into account.
Engage in dialogue with the City of Oslo with the aim of transferring the responsibility for national road 162 (Ring 1) from the state to the City of Oslo.
Consider permanent closure of the Hammersborg Tunnel, with the exception of public transport and emergency vehicles, in connection with the announced measures to reduce costs in the project.
Engage in dialogue with the City of Oslo about the downsizing of Ring 1 to ensure good solutions for pedestrians, cyclists, public transport, and emergency services.
Close the Hammersborg Tunnel on Ring 1.
Investigate the possibility of introducing rent caps on rental properties in high-demand areas.
Change the legislation so that municipalities are enabled to require housing with price and turnover control incorporated into zoning plans.

Review the Tenancy Act and propose changes to the legislation that make consumer complaint rights more accessible, strengthen the recognition that the home is the consumer's residence, clarify the landlord's obligation for regular maintenance, enhance predictability of rental prices, strengthen the consumer's right to privacy, secure the consumer's right to move, and significantly strengthen long-term housing security.
Take the initiative to establish a public land and development company to ensure consistent development in line with a national housing plan.
Increase housing development with a social profile, both at the state and municipal level.
Investigate and propose a model for a third non-commercial housing sector, including necessary legal changes to ensure that a significant proportion of new housing is non-commercial.
Introduce a national housing plan that will address the housing needs across the entire country.
Strengthen the Housing Bank as part of ensuring people's housing needs by expanding the loan framework and providing start-up loans to individuals with repayment capacity, but without equity.
Propose changes to the tenancy law that ensure the rental market is regulated more strictly and that tenants' rights are strengthened.
Set a goal of 30% national coverage rate for student housing.

Investigate the possibility of a differentiated production tax on wind power, where wind power developments that lead to significant environmental impacts are subject to a tax that goes to the state, while wind power developments that do not lead to new environmental impacts go to the municipalities.

Investigate the possibility of a differentiated production tax on wind power, where wind power developments that lead to significant environmental impacts are subject to a higher tax than wind power developments with low environmental consequences.

Have the Paris Agreement and the Climate Goals Act, as well as considerations regarding climate risk for the Norwegian economy, as a framework for the further development of Norwegian petroleum activities and limit future license awards to expansions or extensions of already existing production in mature areas.
Do not propose to include Norway in the fourth energy market package.

Present all concession applications for new power lines on the transmission network that connect different price areas, or upgrades of existing power lines on the transmission network that connect different price areas to higher voltage, to the Parliament.

Present a proposal that allows for a portion of the Government Pension Fund Global (SPU) to be used as a national climate industry fund that makes strategic investments in domestic industrial production, with the aim of ensuring technological development, increased export of goods, more industrial jobs, enhanced value creation, and more processing in Norway, in ways that also ensure emissions are reduced.
Increase funding for energy measures in households to at least 1 billion kroner.
Introduce a transition fee on all oil and gas production, which will be used, among other things, for the development of more renewable energy.
That the financing of energy measures aimed at low-income households through the Norwegian State Housing Bank should not be taken from Enova's allocations, but financed with its own earmarked funds.

Develop a customized concession process for local wind, smaller wind power projects in already established industrial areas or other developed areas, so that they can be established more quickly. In this regard, the Storting asks the government to consider whether this should be included as a simplified process under the Energy Act and the Planning and Building Act.
Take the initiative to collaborate with the EU and the UK on a joint energy agreement aimed at faster transition and increased exchange of renewable energy between Norway and Europe.
Investigate and establish a government entity aimed at purchasing electricity directly from producers to resell it through long-term contracts to households and businesses.
Develop offshore wind on the Norwegian continental shelf where hybrid cables can only be used if they contribute to a net power flow to Norway and a lower price for Norwegian consumers.
Ensure that Statnett receives all congestion revenues, shared with the associated countries' TSOs.
Assume that Statnett will act as the counterparty for the difference contract on behalf of the state, and request an investigation into how this can be done most effectively.
Establish a national testing center for battery production.
Present all EEA-relevant directives and directives relevant to Norway's climate agreement with the EU without delay, and no later than one year after the final decision in the EU.
Assign Enova the responsibility for establishing 30 publicly accessible hydrogen filling stations by 2026.
Postpone the increase of the grid companies' norm share from 60 to 70 percent until a comprehensive review of the Electricity Grid Committee's report.
Return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner with a concrete action plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from oil and gas production by 50% compared to 2005, by 2030.

Investigate a two-tier pricing system for household electricity purchases where a basic monthly consumption has a fixed price, and where any additional consumption is priced according to the market or in another way. Different methods for achieving such a two-tier pricing system must be explored, as well as what the threshold for basic consumption should be in order to still achieve sufficient energy efficiency.
Review the Energy Act to assess changes that ensure more political control and less market control in the energy sector.
Start the work of reversing Norway's inclusion in the EU's energy union Acer.
To reject the application for a license for the foreign cable 'NorthConnect' between Norway and the United Kingdom.
Investigate new minimum requirements for the filling level in water reservoirs. It is requested that different models be assessed in terms of their effects on power supply and water environment.

Do not renew the licenses for existing cables to the United Kingdom, Germany, Denmark, and the Netherlands, but rather initiate negotiations regarding these cables towards the end of the current license period.
Remove the application requirement under the Planning and Building Act for the installation of solar energy systems on apartment buildings.
Investigate the demand for increased public ownership of onshore wind power.

Investigate an increased resource rent tax on super profits from power production and assess how the increased tax revenue can be used for reimbursements to households and businesses to ensure distribution and maintenance of industry.
Register Norway in the international collaboration program ITER, which works on research into fusion energy.
Consider how Norway can contribute to supporting the development of safe and modern nuclear power to displace fossil energy and reduce greenhouse gas emissions in other countries.
Investigate the potential for utilizing deep geothermal energy associated with oil wells on the Norwegian continental shelf.
Demand for electrification of offshore installations through mobile wind turbines where suitable, in order to quickly initiate the development of offshore wind.

Clarify regulatory conditions in the Petroleum Act, the Ocean Energy Act, and the Energy Act, so that these do not hinder the establishment of offshore wind for direct electrification of petroleum installations.
Promote alternatives to land-based power in its owner dialogue with Equinor/Petoro, with particular emphasis on the use of gas with carbon capture and storage for stable and secure power supply.
Change the regulations so that municipalities and local communities have a real veto power against the construction of onshore wind power, through binding referendums and municipal council decisions.
Ensure equal framework conditions for the production of pure hydrogen and pure ammonia with natural gas on the mainland of Norway by applying the rules for mainland industry to all such production.

To implement the natural gas law in accordance with EU Directive 2009/73 for the transport of natural gas to the Norwegian mainland industry, so that the transport of gas to the Norwegian mainland industry is considered downstream.

Establish the goal that by 2030, 55% of Norway's greenhouse gas emissions should be reduced, measured against 1990 levels. This commitment applies to the entire economy, including the emissions trading sector.
To achieve the goal of a 55% reduction in emissions compared to 1990 levels by 2030.

To specify the mandate of the energy commission, so that they base their work on the goal of reducing 55% of Norway's greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, measured against 1990 levels. This commitment applies to the entire economy, including the emissions trading sector.
Give Enova the responsibility for establishing a national network of filling stations with liquid biogas by 2026.
Evaluate the structure of the electricity price areas.
Consider whether gas should be the main priority in exploration policy instead of oil.
Investigate the possibilities within existing agreements on electricity exchange to limit power exports during periods when the reservoir levels are significantly lower than normal.
Negotiate with the EU and the UK with the aim of ensuring that long periods of pure power exports are avoided during times of low reservoir filling.
Do not start the concession process for new wind power plants until the adopted amendment for processing under the Planning and Building Act is in place.
Ensure that a guarantee for cleanup is required before the start of wind power plants. No new licensed facilities can be built until such guarantees are in place.
Facilitate large-scale production facilities for blue and green hydrogen and ammonia.

Develop offshore wind on the Norwegian continental shelf in connection with and in collaboration with the countries around the North Sea, where hybrid cables are designed to contribute to a net increase in power flow to Norway and lower prices for Norwegian consumers, industry, and businesses over time.

Take into account important environmental values, fisheries, wild species, and seabirds. This is in addition to the 4.5 GW that has already been announced for Southern North Sea II and Utsira Nord, so that a minimum of 20 GW should be auctioned off by 2030.
Facilitate technology development and realization of CCS and CCU projects in Norwegian industry.
Increase the allocation for Enova's grants to industrial companies that need financial support to transition their production or invest in CCS to reduce emissions.

Establish a scheme with difference contracts that reduces market risk and makes it profitable for producers and users to switch from gray technology to hydrogen technology. The scheme should ensure that a large volume of hydrogen production and use is realized in the maritime sector and in industry, and must come into effect no later than 2023.
Allocate offshore wind licenses with qualitative requirements and ensure Norwegian content in the contracts.
That concessions for offshore wind are not granted piecemeal, but based on thorough comprehensive plans that take into account fish stocks, bird populations, and navigability at sea.
Introduce difference contracts for alternative fuels in the maritime sector to encourage increased use of climate-neutral alternatives.

Facilitate the possibility of applying for gentle development of hydropower in protected waterways where we can increase power production without significantly compromising nature and environmental considerations.
Announce the 26th licensing round and facilitate good area solutions for gas from the Barents Sea.
Strengthen research on seabed mineral extraction, including resource potential and environmental consequences of potential seabed mineral extraction.

Establish the following proposal: Investigate the energy impact of tightening the area requirements for energy-flexible heating in building regulations, including how much the area requirements should potentially be tightened. Explore and propose various schemes for energy saving certificates to effectively achieve goals for increased energy savings. Propose how the state's purchasing power can be used to promote environmentally friendly buildings and higher energy standards when leasing or purchasing new premises, including whether it is appropriate to introduce specific energy performance requirements when leasing office spaces. Ensure that the upcoming revision of the building technical regulations includes tailored requirements for energy efficiency in renovations.
Investigate the possibilities and consequences of accelerating tail gas production.

Consider alternative ways to compensate households, including evaluating proposals on how payments from the state to the population of extraordinary economic rent from high electricity prices can be designed without being linked to electricity consumption.
To establish marine spatial plans for offshore wind, as part of the integrated management plans for Norwegian sea areas, which will be updated in 2024.
Consider expanding the area concession to apply to facilities at higher voltage levels, in order to reduce the number of concession applications.
Ensure that the power grid is utilized more efficiently by establishing that all new electricity consumption that can be subject to disconnection as needed should be conditional.
Establish a production target for hydrogen, and measures to facilitate this target, and return to the Parliament no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2023.
Evaluate which railway stretch is best suited for hydrogen in Norway, and ask the government to return to the Storting in 2023 with a plan for a pilot project using hydrogen in trains.
Consider whether several stages in the concession process for obtaining network access can be conducted in parallel, rather than sequentially.

Contribute to the development of CBAM in line with the interests of Norwegian industry, with the aim of supporting the EU's carbon border adjustment mechanism to ensure the competitiveness of Norwegian and European industry within the framework of EU climate policy and to prevent carbon leakage from Europe to countries with less ambitious climate policies.
Create an action plan for how the 2030 goal for increased solar power production will be achieved.

Investigate a principle of nature neutrality/area neutrality in all power development projects so that the developer is required, through conditions in the concession, to restore natural qualities of equivalent value that are degraded or destroyed by the power development.
By 2030, there should be available storage capacity equivalent to Norway's annual greenhouse gas emissions.

Come back to the Parliament with measures to achieve the goals from the National Transport Plan 2018–2029: New passenger cars and light commercial vehicles should be zero-emission vehicles by 2025. City buses should be zero-emission vehicles or use biogas by 2025. New, heavier commercial vehicles, 75% of new long-distance buses, and 50% of new trucks should be zero-emission vehicles by 2030. Goods distribution in larger urban centers should be nearly zero-emission by 2030.
Open for 6,000 MW at Southern North Sea II, distributed as 3,000 MW in phase I and 3,000 MW in phase II.
Streamline the concession process for offshore wind, including submitting the concession application and detailed plan simultaneously and processing them in parallel.
Strengthen NVE's case processing capacity and introduce deadlines for case processing.

Ensure that smaller businesses with high electricity costs relative to their revenue also receive assistance in managing their electricity bills in the current situation with extraordinarily high prices.

Base the following proposal: Ensure that the funds transferred from the network tariff to Enova benefit households, and assess the need for and design of new energy efficiency programs in Enova aimed at households and consumers. Promote proposals for suitable and effective measures to support energy-saving initiatives in households, including housing cooperatives and condominiums.
Investigate and present to the Storting whether a reduction obligation should be introduced as an alternative to the blending requirement for biofuels for liquid fuels in the transport sector.
Set requirements in public procurement to ensure the rental of office spaces with energy rating A where possible.
Do not propose anything regarding a potential inclusion of the fourth energy market package that would result in us relinquishing more sovereignty in the energy sector to the EU.

That existing oil and gas installations are electrified using offshore wind or other emission-free solutions on the shelf, and that the need for stable power is addressed with batteries, hydrogen, CCS, or other emission-free technologies.
To conduct environmentally sustainable fishing practices.

Consider how the petroleum industry on the Norwegian continental shelf can best contribute to the investment in offshore wind in Norway in a way that facilitates the electrification of the shelf by designing requirements for zero-emission solutions for new petroleum installations and identify whether any regulatory conditions in the offshore energy act hinder the establishment of offshore wind for direct electrification of petroleum installations.

Investigate a separate fast-track process for power and grid development related to large industrial establishments and request the government to provide a report in connection with the revised national budget for 2023.
Assess the need for further regulation of the energy sector to achieve sufficient energy at reasonable prices for industry, other businesses, and households.

Ensure that the next allocation of offshore wind areas after Southern North Sea II and Utsira Nord in new areas takes place no later than 2025. The Parliament requests that this be a larger announcement that facilitates scaling, technology development, and new industrial opportunities, and that the announcement ensures good coexistence and takes into account important natural values.
Investigate various support schemes and instruments that can trigger the initiation of projects for floating offshore wind, including difference contracts.
Mapping the potential of small wind turbines on farms and what is needed to realize an investment in this.

Contribute to the realization of projects in the initial allocation rounds, among other things by establishing a suitable regime for risk alleviation and state aid if needed. Various models will be assessed in this context, including a model with difference contracts related to the electricity price for the development of offshore wind under the Offshore Energy Act in allocated areas. The goal is to choose a scheme that minimizes the costs of project realization.
Evaluate which of today's diesel-based rail lines is best suited for a pilot project with zero-emission technology and return to the Parliament with a plan for such a pilot project.
Consider measures to expedite the licensing process for small hydropower plants.

To follow up on the decision to change the use of the term zero emissions in all government objectives and plans to zero emissions and biogas, with the intention of equating biogas with electricity and hydrogen, and this should apply to both already adopted and future plans.
Ensure that future wind power developments lead to clear local ripple effects, including by facilitating municipal revenues.
Set deadlines for the administration's processing and appeal handling time in energy cases.

Consider measures that can help make direct air capture (DAC) of carbon profitable, including how the carbon tax and the flexibility within the emissions trading system can be structured to achieve this.

To gradually introduce requirements for sustainable production of batteries for electric transport purchased through public procurement. This should happen as quickly as possible in connection with the government's work on green procurement.
Investigate the energy effect and consequences for construction costs of tightening the requirement for energy-flexible heating, and assess how much the requirement can be tightened.
Investigate various schemes with energy saving certificates to achieve goals for increased energy savings with the greatest possible effect.
Facilitate a comprehensive value chain for carbon capture and storage that can serve large emission sources in Europe, with the goal of making CO2 storage commercially viable in the long term.
Continue the investment in the research center for environmentally friendly energy dedicated to CO2 management.
To include violence prevention and protection of women in the long-term reopening plans after the pandemic.
Make assessments of whether the measures are misaligned, and ensure that the measures do not exacerbate the economic and social disparities in society.
Incorporate the experiences from the COVID-19 pandemic in connection with the construction of new hospitals in Norway.
Not to implement the government regulatory plan for the New Oslo University Hospital, so that local democracy is not sidelined in the processing of the plan.

Initiate work to ensure that the total compensation/salary for employees in health enterprises, including any supplements and pensions, does not exceed the levels of the arrangements that are in effect for the Minister of Health and Care at any given time.
Review all agreements regarding severance pay and bonuses for leaders in healthcare enterprises with the aim of reducing wage disparities in society.

Strengthen established and well-known measures against loneliness, particularly ensuring municipal low-threshold initiatives and measures tailored to groups that are known to be especially vulnerable to loneliness.
Develop an action plan to reduce loneliness and establish tools to measure the prevalence of loneliness.
Strengthen research on loneliness and increase knowledge about measures that counteract loneliness.
Strengthen the collaboration between the public sector, businesses, the labor market, and voluntary groups and organizations to prevent loneliness.
Reorganize the Decision Forum for new methods according to the same model used in Denmark.

Remove the requirement that all new medicines must undergo health technology assessment, as well as investigate the possibility of introducing a "fast track" to ensure quicker access to new treatments.
Ensure full public access to the justifications provided by the Decision Forum for new methods, while the unit prices of medications can remain confidential.

Ensure that a maximum time limit is established from when the application for approval of new medications is received until the processing of the application is initiated. The Norwegian Medicines Agency shall commence the health technology assessment within a short timeframe, so that new medications can be quickly implemented in Norway.
Suggest alternative solutions for the procurement of pharmaceuticals that ensure transparency and access, and where the decision is detached from the budgets of the health enterprises.
Ensure that the health authorities' willingness to pay for a quality-adjusted life year is increased to be at the same level as in comparable countries in Europe.
Establish an appeal instance for decisions made by the Decision Forum for new methods, which evaluates the cases of denial.
Ensure that unit prices and total costs for new medications are made public. Any exceptions to the principle of transparency should be based on a specific assessment in each individual case.
Ensure that exceptionally confidential drug prices are made public after a limited time period.

Return to the Storting by the end of 2022 with proposals for changes in the practices related to method assessments based on the recommendations in Proba's evaluation report of the New Methods system.
Establish a quality assurance system for the method assessments of the Norwegian Medicines Agency to ensure the legitimacy of the decisions made in the Decision Forum for new methods.

Follow the recommendation from Proba to review the exemption scheme so that it aligns with the intention of Report St. 34 (2015–2016) and ensures exemptions until the medications are introduced into the healthcare system.

Follow the recommendation from Proba to review the implementation of the exemption scheme and to return to the Storting with a discussion of the exemption scheme and its implementation in the announced parliamentary report on prioritization.

Provide an account of how the evaluation of the New Methods system has been followed up, including measures to reduce processing times, ensure trust in the system, and give users and professionals a stronger voice.
Investigate the content and implementation of a five-year master's program in sign language.
Evaluate whether the current organization of the interpreting service is appropriate and, in close dialogue with users and Nav, assess possible alternative models.
Ensure that Nav tests new financing models for collaboration with social entrepreneurs and increases the use of outcome contracts.

Present a plan for how public procurement and tenders can prioritize social sustainability and inclusion to a greater extent, including considering the establishment of a national prequalification scheme for social entrepreneurs.
Increase the use of innovative procurement as a method, so that by 2024 it will be implemented in all of the country's Nav counties.
Increase the municipalities' and Nav's competence and capacity to collaborate with social entrepreneurs, including strengthening the focus on market contacts.
Promote a strategy to strengthen the role and offerings of the nonprofit sector in the labor and welfare field.

Conduct a comprehensive investigation into the military's outsourcing of tasks to private actors and the impact this has on security, preparedness, competence within the military, and the law of armed conflict.
Present proposals that ensure the Armed Forces procure equipment from Norwegian industry where this is appropriate.
Establishing emergency shelters for F-35.
Increase preparedness capacity for storing necessary emergency supplies, including the establishment of preparedness agreements with commercial actors.
Establish your own recruitment training for the Home Guard.
Accelerate the procurement of new helicopters for the Army.

Ensure permanent air defense for all major Norwegian cities as well as central defense installations, and guarantee that Kongsberg Gruppen can increase and expedite the production of Norwegian Advanced Surface to Air Missile Systems (NASAMS).
Reduce the lead time for NAMMO's ammunition production and ensure that NAMMO receives the financial support the company needs to increase production and storage capacity.
Promote a proposal to increase the funding for the Norwegian Shooting Association.
Establish emergency stockpiles for response materials.
Investigate whether there is a need for additional activities related to Andøya Air Station in light of the new security policy situation.
Increase combat power and operational capacity by strengthening the Home Guard – with the ambition of increasing the number of soldiers to a minimum of 60,000.
Increase the number of training days for soldiers in the Home Guard, and increase the soldiers' financial compensation to motivate and recruit more to participate in the Home Guard.
Include the major regional cities, possibly in collaboration with a unit in Tromsø.
Introduce a product-based criterion for autonomous weapons.

Change the behavioral criteria for the observation and exclusion of companies to ensure that the Government Pension Fund Global withdraws its investments from companies linked to unlawful occupation and other violations of international law.

Complaining that the Government Pension Fund Global raises privacy issues higher on the agenda in owner dialogues with companies, and that they demand more transparency about how algorithms affect users and control what content they are shown.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that outlines how the Government Pension Fund Global can achieve a deforestation-free portfolio by the end of 2025. The proposal should assess various models to reach this goal, including corporate engagement and exclusion criteria for companies that do not meet an acceptable standard.
Consider adding a goal to the mandate of the Government Pension Fund Global regarding net zero emissions in the investment portfolio by 2050.

Investigate and develop tools to best operationalize the net-zero target, including a reference index tailored to the unique characteristics of the Government Pension Fund Global, and specific sub-goals with emission pathways for all sectors across the entire portfolio.

Establish specific sub-goals for the portfolio's overall emissions reduction at the sector level from 2025, and Norges Bank is requested to report on this, to ensure consistency between the guidelines for the management of the fund and the ambitions of the net-zero target.
Ensure that the state's extraordinary revenues resulting from high energy prices benefit the population through tax reductions and investments in Norway.
Refrain from using the oil fund as a climate policy instrument.

Evaluate the effect of the crisis measures aimed at banks in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic and map how much of the banks' profits in 2020, 2021, and 2022 can be attributed to the crisis measures.
Ensure that Norway has preparedness in public financial institutions to immediately provide credit to businesses in an acute economic crisis.
Set a goal to reduce the share of private banks in the money supply.
Investigate the effects of a monetary system that adopts digital central bank currencies, combined with increased public credit intermediation through existing or new financial institutions.
Make climate transition a part of the purpose of Norges Bank.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to move the management of the Government Pension Fund Global out of the Central Bank of Norway.
