Return to the Parliament with proposals for amendments to the Central Bank Act, adding a general clause modeled after the Public Administration Act § 6 (2) that can address challenges related to impartiality that are not otherwise covered by the more specific impartiality provisions of the law.
Come back to the Storting with an assessment of who should be excluded from sitting on the governing bodies of Norges Bank, cf. the Central Bank Act § 2-3 fourth paragraph and § 2-6 third paragraph.
Encourage forcibly merged municipalities that wish to apply for division to do so by September 1, 2022, and to return to the Storting in an appropriate manner.
To keep public spending down, promote proposals to abolish county councils starting from the county council elections in 2023.
Initiate a process to dissolve the county municipality as an administrative level.
Facilitate for municipalities to take on more responsibilities.
Ensure that the measures supporting the municipal reform are continued.
Strengthen the municipal sector's economy by at least 9 billion kroner.
Propose changes to the regulations to allow municipalities to impose a higher tax rate on secondary and vacation homes than on primary residences.
Secure funding for the employment of general practitioners in municipal positions with fixed salaries in municipalities that lack general practitioners.
Present a plan to expand the top financing scheme for resource-intensive care and nursing services so that those who are in the scheme at the age of 67 are also included after they turn 67.

Increase the additional compensation for resource-intensive services in the proposed state budget for 2023 so that parts of this fund can also be allocated to municipalities with over 3,200 inhabitants.

Increase the municipal sector's revenues by nearly 6 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in the Municipal Proposition 2023, with an estimated 4 billion kroner for the municipalities and 2 billion kroner for the county municipalities.
Expand the scheme for particularly resource-intensive services to also include the age group 67 to 80 years.
Abolish the limit of 3,200 inhabitants for municipalities that receive additional compensation in the scheme for particularly resource-demanding services.

Conduct a review of the arrangement for resource-intensive services and ensure that all relevant costs incurred by the municipalities in the arrangement are included as the basis for the municipal co-payment.
Reduce the municipalities' own contribution in the scheme for particularly resource-intensive services.
Ensure enough positions in the municipal child welfare services so that municipalities are able to reduce the number of cases per caseworker from 2023.

Assess how the increased municipal contributions for the use of specialized foster homes, institutions, and emergency measures impact, especially for smaller municipalities, and return to the Parliament with an evaluation of the arrangement.

Engage in dialogue with the municipal sector to plan how to manage the significant costs associated with the large backlog in water and wastewater services, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Consider improving the arrangement for resource-intensive services for the municipalities.
Promote a proposal to further lower the property tax rate.
Reintroduce state-funded elderly care trials to improve the quality of elderly care.

Ensure that private kindergartens with higher pension expenses than what they receive covered by the pension supplement actually get reimbursed for the excess amount they are entitled to. The current regulations regarding the allocation of grants to private kindergartens must be changed so that municipalities can no longer deduct annual use of premium funds when calculating the municipality's pension expenses.

Promote proposals for the introduction of a challenge right so that private actors can challenge public monopoly operations of services in order to achieve greater diversity, better quality, and at the right cost for taxpayers.
Promote proposals for increased funding for elderly care/investment in more care homes/nursing home places.
Make it clear to the municipal sector that COVID-related expenses for the use of temporary staff, etc., will be covered in 2022.
Promote a proposal to make boat trips free for all routes to communities without alternative travel options.

Ensure that it remains the parents' choice of kindergarten that governs which kindergarten places are maintained in the municipalities. Users' wishes and needs should still be given great importance in the kindergarten admission process, and equal treatment of children and equal treatment of municipal and private kindergartens must be ensured through a coordinated admission process in the municipalities.

Present to the Storting a complete overview of all aspects and implications for fishing ports and county municipalities regarding the transfer of fishing ports from the counties to the state, including loan guarantee schemes, consequences for employees in the county municipal apparatus, consequences for the administration of the fishing ports, as well as costs associated with this transfer.

Come back in the state budget for 2023 with the status and plan for how to facilitate that all households and businesses in Norway will have access to a minimum of 100 Mbit/s download speed and 10 Mbit/s upload speed by 2025.

Come back in the state budget for 2023 with a status and plan for how to facilitate that all Norwegian emergency response centers, town halls, and other important public administration buildings, schools, and transport hubs will have access to at least 1 Gbit/s download speed and at least 100 Mbit/s upload speed by the end of 2025.
Facilitate the establishment of free municipality trials inspired by Denmark and present a case on this to the Storting no later than in connection with the state budget for 2023.

Investigate the possibility that the creditor must cover court fees in the collection of unsecured debt, the effects of halving the court fees for enforcement proceedings and forced sales, and the possibility of limiting the opportunity to claim previous court fees in a new enforcement request.
Present a proposal for the introduction of a cap on interest rates in Norway no later than in connection with the Financial Market Report 2023.
Investigate the possibility of limiting the use of external debt collectors in the collection of unsecured debt.

Ensure that municipal debt counseling and voluntary arrangements have sufficient capacity to provide advice to those in need of help in a timely manner, and that they have adequate expertise to assist people with debt problems when dealing with professional creditors.

Investigate the possibility of limiting or prohibiting the sale of overdue claims where the consumer is the debtor. The investigation should include the potential introduction of a right of first refusal for the debtor when the debt is resold.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to ban the marketing of consumer loans as part of a purchasing situation.

Return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner with a report on the coverage rate for debt advisors, the waiting time to get an appointment with a debt advisor, and the qualifications of the debt advisors.
Investigate the possibility of banning the sale of overdue claims where the consumer is the debtor.
Create a public solution that can be used for payments to Norwegian households.
Ensure that a public bank account is offered to all residents of Norway.
Propose to remove the surcharge in the shielding interest rate as the first step in phasing out the shielding deduction.
Present the necessary legal amendments to ensure that it is not tax advantageous to defer dividend taxation, for example by taking out loans to finance personal consumption secured by the company.
Propose changes to wealth taxation that ensure all shares are valued at their actual market value.
Propose to remove the valuation discount for unlisted shares in wealth tax.
Propose to increase the tax exemption for rental of cabins from 10,000 kroner to 50,000 kroner per year.

Propose a nature tax for the construction of new cabins. The tax rate should be structured to increase progressively based on the size of the cabin and the area that is being developed. The revenues from a nature tax should be earmarked for nature restoration.

Introduce guidelines that only allow cabin construction within already developed areas. Infrastructure such as water, electricity, sewage, and roads should not be permitted to be established in cabin areas where this would require new, harmful interventions in nature, or compromise important grazing land.
Present proposals for concrete measures that will encourage increased private cabin sharing and more public and voluntary sharing and lending schemes for cabins.
Investigate and propose a fee for the repurposing of agricultural land and other valuable areas.

Present a new land protection strategy in the spring of 2023. The strategy should include a new and stricter goal for the repurposing of agricultural land and new, concrete measures to achieve the goal.

To lower the quota limit for cow's milk to 450,000 liters and goat's milk to 200,000 liters, so that no new productions exceed this. The limits will be gradually reduced over a five-year period starting from the agricultural settlement for 2023.

To strengthen smaller livestock producers through an active subsidy ladder with the following subsidy caps: 70 dairy cows, 70 breeding cows, 200 other cattle, 200 dairy goats, 300 sheep. The scheme will be gradually implemented over five years.

To lower the ceilings for area subsidies to 800 acres for grain, 800 acres for grass, 500 acres for potatoes, 500 acres for vegetables, 100 acres for fruit, and 100 acres for berries. The ceilings will be gradually reduced to these levels over a five-year period.
Strengthen customs protection and propose changing from specific duties to ad valorem duties on all dairy products and meat from cattle, sheep, lamb, chicken, and pork.
Promote proposals that ensure that new lease agreements for milk quotas are not entered into after January 1, 2023.

Start the work on a new, comprehensive white paper on agriculture and food systems where health policy, climate and nature policy, and agricultural and food policy are interconnected, and the best professional environments in these areas are linked together. The overarching goal must be to outline a long-term strategy for the transition of Norwegian agriculture towards greater sustainability, faster reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, better public health, stricter animal welfare requirements, and improved economy/better working conditions for farmers. The work must be seen in connection with the EU's new food and agricultural strategy "Farm to Fork."
Implement changes to the fertilizer regulations based on proposals developed by the Agricultural Directorate in 2018.
Reintroduce a ban on autumn plowing.

Present and implement a scaling-up plan for food production based on Norwegian resources and set a target for the self-sufficiency rate for Norwegian agricultural products, adjusted for the import of feed raw materials, at 60%.
Investigate a new system for agricultural settlements that better adapts agriculture to the market and reduces political control over the industry.
Reallocate 1.2 billion kroner from item 50 LUF funds and from item 74.17 Area and cultural landscape grants to grant schemes that encourage increased food production through efficient management.
Postpone the requirement for loose housing for cattle for another year.

Adjust the grants so that they are structured to facilitate income development for those who derive the majority of their income from agriculture, in accordance with the guidelines from Meld. St. 11 (2016–2017).
Increase the quota limit in milk production to 1.2 million liters per farm.
Take the initiative for international cooperation to prevent future food crises resulting from crises or war.
Reduce subsidies that do not go to food production in future agricultural negotiations.

To make it more profitable for Norwegian farmers to produce grains, oilseeds, legumes, as well as fruits and vegetables, by prioritizing increased support and risk mitigation measures for these productions.

Propose an animal welfare grant with criteria that exceed the minimum requirements of the animal husbandry regulations, so that the grant scheme contributes to a real and significant improvement in animal welfare in Norwegian livestock farming. Relevant criteria in the scheme may include: Access to pasture or outdoor areas for pigs. Access to pasture or winter gardens for poultry. Access to pasture for male cattle (uncastrated bulls are exempt from the pasture and exercise requirement). Larger space per animal in the poultry and pig sectors. Greater environmental enrichment for broiler chickens (such as things to perch on and hide under). Soft bedding for pigs. Increased interaction between cows and calves. Alternatives to surgical castration of male pigs.

To work towards strengthening organic farming as a spearhead for a more sustainable circular agriculture, including by setting a goal that at least 20% of Norwegian food production should be organic by 2030.

The funds for temporary price reductions on imported feed raw materials amounting to 295.8 million kroner and the increase in the quality subsidy for beef amounting to 147.6 million kroner, totaling 443.4 million kroner, will be reallocated as follows: - The wild grazing subsidy for cattle and horses will be increased by 55 million kroner - The wild grazing subsidy for sheep, lambs, and goats will be increased by 68.4 million kroner - The livestock subsidy for sheep and suckling goats will be increased by 130 million kroner - The livestock subsidy for suckler cows will be increased by 110 million kroner - The grazing subsidy will be increased by 80 million kroner.
Increase the target price of milk by 45 cents.

Facilitate an increase in the planned average wholesale price of pork within the framework of the WTO agreement, for example through additional meetings between the parties and more frequent price setting.

Return to the Storting before next year's regular agricultural negotiations with a scheduled escalation plan for how Norway will achieve 50% self-sufficiency, adjusted for feed imports. The plan should also include how self-sufficiency in each individual region will be strengthened.
Set a goal to close the income gap between agriculture and comparable groups within four years.
To review and improve the arrangement of grant zones, so that it encourages the production of food plants where the production conditions are good enough for it.

To stimulate a more extensive livestock farming with less use of concentrated feed and more use of roughage and pasture by: starting a gradual increase in the target price for grain without an increase in price reductions for concentrated feed, prioritizing increased support for pasture and meadow grazing that cannot be harvested mechanically, and increasing support for farm investments through Innovation Norway.
To initiate a process for the dissolution of the milk quota exchange and to reintroduce state allocation of milk quotas, which will be based on local resource conditions.
Return to the Storting before next year's regular agricultural negotiations with a proposal to phase out rental quotas for cow's milk.

Lower the quota limit for cow's milk to 500,000 liters and goat's milk to 200,000 liters, so that no new productions exceed this. Producers who currently have a higher quota level can retain the quota or sell the surplus quota to the state at an agreed price.
That the target prices in the agricultural agreement are not increased from July 1, 2022.
To remove the bottom deduction for the right to subsidies under the agricultural agreement.

To strengthen soil fertility, carbon sequestration, and biodiversity in agriculture by: supporting regenerative grazing practices, including the use of virtual fencing; supporting regenerative cultivation methods in crop production; supporting mapping and rewarding of biodiversity below ground; supporting management and production methods that enhance biodiversity, including meadows and measures that facilitate pollinating insects and birds; setting minimum requirements for biodiversity areas and crop rotation for the allocation of subsidies.
Investigate a system with requirements for crop rotation in agriculture, aimed at reducing diseases and building up good and fertile soil that yields good harvests.

Promote a proposal for a multi-year investment plan earmarked for transitioning to loose housing by 2034. The plan should be aimed at small and medium-sized farms and be viewed in connection with closing the income gap.

Come back to the Storting in 2022 with a proposal to introduce binding and concrete goals for increased organic food production in Norway by setting quantified targets for production and public procurement of organic food by 2030, at least at the level of the EU and our Nordic neighbors.
Give a task to the Agricultural Directorate to urgently prepare comprehensive statistics on the trade of organic goods.
Investigate how to limit the prevalence of leased land in agriculture.

Implement the decision that zero-emission vehicles shall not pay more than a maximum of 50% of the rates for conventional vehicles regarding parking, and that the decision that zero-emission vehicles shall not pay more than a maximum of 50% of the rates for conventional vehicles regarding tolls and ferry fares shall be continued.
Continue working on the downsizing of Trondheimsveien between Sinsen and Grorud, and in the plan, make provisions for a tram to Tonsenhagen.
Consider deploying replacement vessels to ensure that the Coastal Route calls at the 34 ports daily.

Continue the grant scheme for smaller urban areas without urban growth agreements, and ensure state contributions to Bodø, Ålesund, Haugesund, Arendal/Grimstad, and Vestfoldbyen in accordance with the National Transport Plan 2022–2033.
Conduct a comprehensive review of the benefits of electric vehicles and assess changes in relation to the 2025 target, and report back to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2023.
To continue to base the assumptions for the increase to a 66% state share in large public transport projects on the national budget for 2020.

Propose to provide state funding for county road 353 Rugtvedt–Surtebogen in Bamble municipality in Vestfold and Telemark county, corresponding to the amount for toll financing mentioned in Prop. 117 S (2021–2022).
Contribute to ensuring that the process of Finnish and Swedish NATO membership does not result in yielding to Turkish pressure against Sweden or other NATO countries.

Promote legislation that ensures that the same requirements for hiring in municipal substitute pools are applied as those for hiring in the staffing industry, so that it guarantees that substitutes in the municipality have the same rights as employees in staffing agencies.
Review the procedures for residence permits for qualified healthcare professionals who wish to work in staffing agencies in the healthcare sector, with the aim of simplifying application processes.
Facilitate access for staffing agencies to provide staffing in the healthcare services in the municipalities.

Requesting municipalities not to opt out of using staffing agencies, in order to ensure adequate access to legally mandated services, necessary personnel availability, and flexibility in case of a need for increased staffing.

Ensure that municipalities wishing to opt out of using staffing agencies must be able to demonstrate that the reservation does not negatively impact the service offerings to the residents of the municipality.
Investigate changes in laws and regulations that lead to Nav using the income prior to the first instance of illness as the basis for calculating disability benefits.
Investigate legal and regulatory changes that lead to Nav using the income prior to the first illness as the basis for calculating rehabilitation benefits.
Investigate the possibility of reducing the requirements for reduced work capacity to be granted disability benefits to 20%.

Develop a regulation that ensures that individuals with disabilities from occupational groups with special age limits do not have large sums coordinated away from the special age limit until the age of 67.

Evaluate and investigate the effects of the disability reform, both in terms of benefit levels, the relationship to other income-dependent benefits, and the relationship to occupational pensions, and report back to the Parliament with proposals for necessary changes.

Conduct a review of the issue that workers who become ill but wish to continue in income-generating work beyond 50% receive a lower disability pension if they later have to apply for disability benefits due to a further reduction in work capacity, and return to the Storting in an appropriate manner.
Assess whether the regulation of Sunday-opening stores is being complied with and maintained, and verify and evaluate approvals under the exceptions in the Holiday Act § 5 second paragraph no. 4.
Propose to transfer the responsibility for approving exceptions to holidays and holiday rest § 5 second paragraph no. 4 from the county governor to the ministry to ensure consistent practice.

Promote a proposal to abolish the county governor's approval scheme for tourist municipalities and leave it to the municipality itself to decide whether Sunday opening of shops should be allowed in all or parts of the municipality.

Establish a committee to investigate and propose amendments to the law to strengthen employee protection against night and solitary work. It is particularly important to ensure that employees in retail are adequately protected by the provisions of the Working Environment Act regarding evening, weekend, and night work. Both parties must be represented in the committee.

Propose to repeal Section 16-1, second paragraph, of the Working Environment Act, so that Chapter 16 of the Working Environment Act, which grants employees rights in the event of business transfers, also applies to transfers from bankruptcy estates.
Review the bankruptcy legislation and propose changes to make it more effective, for example by tightening penalties and bankruptcy bans.

Establish a committee with a mandate to review the current bankruptcy regulations and propose measures that can more effectively prevent the abuse of the bankruptcy institution where actors evade their obligations towards employees under the Working Environment Act.

Promote a proposal for a new regulation in 2022 regarding ongoing old-age pensions, minimum pension levels, and guaranteed pensions in the National Insurance Scheme, as well as pensions from other statutory schemes that compensate for the deviation between estimated and actual wage and price growth in 2021.
Shield disability pensions completely from the effects of the life expectancy adjustment and provide accrual until the age of 67 in the new accrual model.
Increase the minimum pension level for singles by 4,000 kroner in the proposed state budget for 2023.
Increase the minimum pension level for married/cohabiting individuals by 4,000 kroner in the proposed state budget for 2023.
Increase the rates for guaranteed pension by 4,000 kroner in the proposed state budget for 2023.

Follow the tariff law principles of non-deviation and equal treatment, the conditions in the Employment Dispute Act regarding representativeness, and also the state's role in the government's income policy, and on this basis, implement the main collective agreements for LO Stat and YS for the unorganized from May 1, 2022, and in the current tariff period.
Establish a salary committee that examines the salary system in the state and presents its recommendations well in advance of the main negotiations in 2024.
Start a process to achieve similar main collective agreements for the main negotiations in 2024.
Ensure that the municipalities are compensated for coronavirus expenses.
Set a goal and establish a binding escalation plan that ensures a maximum waiting time of one week to schedule the first meeting between the patient and a specialist in mental health.
Take the initiative to establish a center for research and development of innovative treatment options for mental disorders and mental health.
Stop the expansion of the E18 West Corridor and use the released state funds to strengthen public transportation in the Oslo region.

Ensure that the Eating Disorder Counseling (ROS) receives sufficient funding to scale up its operations in order to provide a more comprehensive service to children and young people with eating disorders.
Secure funding for the new Viking Age museum.
Incorporate 70% state funding for the Fornebubanen and other major public transport projects in Oslo, Bergen, Trondheim, and Nord-Jæren.
Ensure that already allocated funds to compensate regional public transport for reduced revenues and increased costs are made available to the counties, at least until the end of 2022.
Develop a binding, cross-sectoral plan for how the goal of restoring 15% of degraded ecosystems can be achieved within a reasonable timeframe.

Set a goal and establish a binding escalation plan that ensures that children and young people with mental health issues and substance dependence do not have to wait more than 20 working days before receiving the necessary health care.

Expand the upper age limit for the exemption from co-payments for mental health care from 18 to 20 years and reduce the co-payments for assistance from specialist health services by 20%, so that more children and young people can receive the help they need.
Establish a transformation package to increase the attractiveness of the county municipal public transport.
Take the necessary measures to ensure a reduction in ticket prices for rail and county public transport by 20% from July 1, 2022.
Establish a restoration fund for bogs and wetlands to be able to plan and implement large projects with assurance of funding over several years.
Establish a government grant scheme that will cover 25% of the investment costs for nitrogen removal in municipal wastewater treatment plants around the Oslofjord.
Mandate the treatment of all major Norwegian point sources by 2030 and establish a fund to help finance this.
Include compensation for high electricity prices when renegotiating the traffic agreements with the train companies.
Maintain the VAT exemption for electric cars.
Base the calculation of the state's 70 percent share on updated cost estimates.
Conduct an additional investigation on VAT in the cultural sector, examining the three levels: zero rate, reduced rate, and full rate.
Return to the Storting in the state budget for 2023 with proposals for increased minimum rates for benefits such as AAP, disability pension, and old-age pension.

Investigate a scheme with a maximum price for electricity, imposed on the sale of power from Norwegian power producers to customers in Norway. The maximum price must be calculated in relation to the average production cost of electricity in Norway, and there must be a requirement for producers to cover their costs. The investigation must be presented to the Storting at the latest in the government's proposal for the state budget for 2023.

Ensure that the soldiers from the Home Guard's operational units who have reported and raised the issue of unlawful practices regarding holiday pay and the employment status of voluntary personnel in the Home Guard, and have been taken to court by the Ministry of Defence, receive compensation for their actual legal costs, including their own work and time spent.
Incorporate 70% state funding for the Fornebubanen and the other major local public transport projects.
Promote a proposal to include businesses in the electricity support scheme, with a coverage rate of 100% for consumption over 50 øre per kWh.
Increase the number of residency positions so that more doctors can complete their education and enter the workforce as general practitioners or in other medical positions.
Come back with concrete measures that ensure sufficient development of nursing home places to meet the needs for care and nursing services in the coming years.
Find a solution that provides Barnas Fysioterapisenter with the necessary predictability in light of the phasing out of free treatment choice.
Promote a proposal to continue the Elderly Ombudsman from 2023.
Promote a proposal for a maintenance and paving package that ensures necessary progress to catch up on the maintenance backlog for national and county roads.
Propose to allocate 5 million kroner to the Finnmarksløpet to unlock the value creation potential of the event.
Increase the pace of establishing a new police academy as soon as possible, cf. the request decision regarding this.
Ensure that all public procurements from the construction and transport sectors include flexibility regarding fuel costs, and that such flexibility is also incorporated into existing agreements.
Ensure that the construction of the Ocean Space Centre in Trondheim follows the original schedule.
Take the initiative to link student support to the basic amount in the National Insurance Scheme (G), which today corresponds to approximately 1.25 G, and in the long term increase it to 1.5 G.

Take the initiative to remove the degree regulation's limitation on educational institutions' ability to offer vocational training with protected titles, so that more educational institutions can provide medical education.

Promote proposals in the new budget adjustment for 2022 to compensate for additional expenses related to the pandemic in municipalities and county municipalities during the period from 2020 to the first half of 2022.

Introduce VAT on the purchase amount for electric cars over 500,000 kroner. The VAT exemption will remain unchanged until 2025. In connection with the introduction of purchase taxes for electric cars, it should be ensured that the competitive advantage of electric cars in all passenger car segments is maintained.
Ensure that Enova increases the support for electric vans from 30% to 40% of the additional cost.

Ensure that the healthcare service at the Police Immigration Detention Center, Trandum, is placed under the public healthcare system and that the decision regarding this is made during 2022 so that the transfer can be completed by July 1, 2023, at the latest.

Promote necessary legislative proposals that expand the statutory scope of the county municipalities' obligation to provide dental services to include 21- and 22-year-olds, as well as enshrine the right to reduced payment for these age groups in regulations.
Extend the temporary regulations for housing support according to recommendation 251 S (2021-2022) for the months of June, July, August, and September.

Ensure that 500 million kroner is disbursed through the grant scheme to the public transport companies established in connection with the RNB, distributed according to the expected decline in ticket revenues throughout 2022. The funds should facilitate restructuring and the development of new solutions.
Consider transitioning from specific duties to ad valorem duties, among other things for the customs lines for cattle, pigs, sheep, lambs, and potatoes.

Come back to the Storting with a model similar to Sweden's for Norway regarding advanced biofuels, and as soon as possible develop a reporting system for the use of sustainable biofuels beyond the blending requirement, which meets the sustainability criteria for biofuels and does not contain biofuels with deforestation risk. If Sweden does not succeed in the process with the EU Commission regarding the proposed model, the government is requested to return to the Storting with a proposal for a new model.

Ensure support for Norwegian organizations working on disarmament and contributing to public debate about nuclear weapons in Norway by earmarking organizational support of 2.5 million kroner to No to Nuclear Weapons, 3 million kroner to Norwegian Doctors Against Nuclear Weapons (which also administers ICAN in Norway), 1.8 million kroner to the Norwegian Peace Council, and 1.6 million kroner in project support to Norwegian People's Aid.
Continue the grant scheme for smaller towns without urban growth agreements as the scheme is described in the National Transport Plan (NTP).

Continue the project organization in the Ocean Space Centre in accordance with the assessment presented in the letter to the finance committee from the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans dated June 6, 2022, stating that it will be possible to commence parts of the project while the project is being revised and costs are being evaluated.

Exempt vessels with a fishing area of coastal fishing or smaller from the requirement to have a satellite subscription, so that these vessels only report position and catch messages over the mobile network.

Regulate requirements for zero emissions or biogas in all new ferry tenders and requirements for fossil-free in new fast ferry tenders, and return to the Parliament with proposals in the state budget for 2023.
Adjust the recommended rates for financial social assistance by 2.1 percent to 3.4 percent from July 1.

Evaluate and propose suggestions on how large projects can be scaled down to save nature and agricultural land, as well as to reduce costs and allow for a stronger focus on maintenance and upgrading of existing transportation infrastructure. The announced review will be conducted for projects in the Norwegian Public Roads Administration and New Roads. The Norwegian Public Roads Administration and New Roads will also be tasked with assessing the scaling down of projects that are currently in the planning phase.
Ensure that more children from low-income families are offered the opportunity to participate in free activities during the summer vacation of 2022.
Accelerate the implementation of the Action Plan for General Practitioner Services.
Ensure that the Children's Physiotherapy Center continues as it is today from January 1, 2023, so that they can continue the treatment of children from all over the country.
Strengthen the services for people with eating disorders through an enhancement of ROS - counseling on eating disorders.
Ensure Norwegian pharmaceutical and infection control preparedness through long-term and binding agreements with Norwegian suppliers of pharmaceuticals and infection control products.
To hire necessary and critical helicopter capacity.

Ensure that the lost education for children and young people during the pandemic and the recent prolonged teacher strike can be compensated for, and how they plan to follow up with the students who have faced specific challenges regarding knowledge gaps, mental health issues, or other concerns.
To ensure that the saved public funds resulting from the teachers' strike benefit children, young people, and the content of the school.
Stimulate growth in the private sector so that the public sector's share of GDP decreases during this parliamentary term.
Promote proposals for state funding to replace Tretten Bridge and other road bridges built in the same manner that require repairs due to construction defects.
Ensure that injured Ukrainian soldiers do not have to pay a deductible for medical treatment and follow-up in Norway.

Promote proposals to increase taxes on the petroleum industry as quickly as possible to prevent the oil tax package and high petroleum prices from contributing to strong inflation and an unhealthy petroleum dominance in the Norwegian economy in the coming years.

Review agricultural and land policies to identify new measures that can ensure that Norwegian farmland and arable land are used in a way that strengthens Norwegian self-sufficiency and food security. New measures must ensure that the intention of the Land Act, which states that agricultural land should be used for food production, is enforced and that farmland is not degraded. The measures must be implemented no later than during the winter to contribute to increased food security in 2023.
Ensure that all new development projects that involve interventions in nature reserves are halted.

Introduce a protection against petroleum activities by establishing petroleum-free areas in the marine areas outside Lofoten, Vesterålen, and Senja, the Møre fields, Jan Mayen, Skagerrak, coastal areas, as well as the scientifically defined ice edge zone.
To revise the Education Act, propose to the Parliament to enshrine students' right to qualified teachers in all their subjects, as well as a timeline for the implementation of this.
Map out what consequences the Fosendommen must have for other planned interventions in Sámi reindeer herding areas.
Remove access for vessels longer than 28 meters to fish with conventional gear within 4 nautical miles.
Promote a proposal for a fair inheritance tax, with a high exemption threshold.
Norway should join the UN's nuclear weapons ban.
Take the initiative with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to stop demands for payment of Ukrainian state debt and further to write off and restructure the debt.
Conduct a power investigation with a particular focus on structures and the balance of power in the labor market.
Strengthen the health professions in hospitals, and reduce health bureaucracy and the number of control and management levels.
Investigate the effect that the use of tenders has on working conditions and wage formation, both for employees and managers, especially in public transport and railways.
Investigate and propose changes to the Public Procurement Act, so that public purchases generally lead to increased activity and employment in Norway.

Report to the Parliament on the extent of tax evasion and tax losses for the state, with an update on the international efforts against tax flight and the government's initiatives to combat the problem.

Review Nav's preparedness and capacity to handle the increasing economic insecurity and engage in dialogue with the voluntary sector to gain an overview of the capacity for social activities, food distribution, and assistance services during Christmas, and report back to the Parliament in the reallocation of the state budget for 2022 with additional appropriations if necessary.

To scrap the trial scheme with receipts during police checks and instead ensure that police checks and other security measures are intensified to gain control over the development of violence in the capital.

Present the necessary legislative changes to the Storting to ensure that the Police Security Service has the same powers and access to means to prevent sabotage against the Norwegian continental shelf as they currently have under existing legislation to prevent terrorist attacks.
Promote a proposal to increase housing support.
Exempt fishermen born before 1962 from the requirement for electronic catch and position reporting for vessels under 11 meters.

Look at the simplifications of the systems for catch and position reporting for vessels between 11 and 15 meters and postpone the implementation of catch and position reporting for vessels under 11 meters until these simplifications are in place.

Scrap the requirement for satellite equipment for catch and position reporting for vessels with a fishing area of coastal fishing or smaller, and approve 4G-based equipment without Iridium for these vessels.
Utilize the existing frigate and coast guard helicopter (NH90) at the Maritime Helicopter Wing (MHV) in Bardufoss and Bergen in the extraordinary threat situation Norway is facing.
Ensure secure ideal treatment institutions and care services within substance abuse care.
Present solutions that allow general practitioners to be relieved from non-clinical tasks and how responsibilities can be distributed to other healthcare personnel.
Require all public buildings to establish solar energy production or green roofs.

Investigate and propose a more equitable electricity support model that does not allocate the most funds to those with the highest consumption, while also maintaining incentives to invest in energy efficiency measures. The following assumptions shall be the basis for the scheme: An equal amount will be paid to all individuals residing in price areas with higher electricity prices. The amount will vary between price areas depending on the price differences among them.

Consider how an additional allowance for households with only one member can be designed to account for the fact that single-person households have a somewhat higher average consumption than households with multiple members.

Ensure that a maximum price for electricity is introduced for all customers in Norway through regulations for power producers. This will be set at three times the concession price, which is approximately 35 øre/kWh. Until the necessary changes to laws and/or regulations are in place, the electricity support scheme will be strengthened for monthly consumption up to 3,500 kWh with 100% coverage when the electricity price exceeds 35 øre/kWh.

Immediately require producers to stop power production for export from reservoirs that can store water for the winter. If legal changes are necessary to implement this, the government is requested to present a proposal to the Storting by November 2022. If necessary to achieve this, the government must enter into negotiations regarding existing agreements that regulate electricity exports.
Provide an account of the dialogue with the United Kingdom and the EU regarding the import and export of electricity with respect to our national supply security, by the end of November 2022.
Facilitate an application-based municipal support scheme for small businesses with particularly high electricity costs in the price areas of Southern Norway.
Strengthen the electricity support scheme for voluntary organizations so that it will provide 100 percent compensation for prices above 50 øre/kWh.
Ensure that all forms of energy are included in the electricity support scheme for voluntary organizations.
Ensure that all folk high schools, independent schools, and similar institutions are included in the electricity support scheme for voluntary organizations.
Strengthen support for energy saving and energy production by ensuring that Enova covers up to half of the investment costs for such measures.
Promote a proposal for nearly zero energy levels for buildings in the building regulations in line with the climate agreement from 2012.
Promote proposals to increase housing support in areas with high electricity prices, so that low-income households receive assistance in managing their bills.
Increase the stipend for students with a residence address in areas with high electricity prices.
Promote a proposal to continue the increase in funding for Enova, with at least the same percentage increase as in the years 2013–2021.
Strengthen the Housing Bank's work on energy measures for low-income households without financing this by reallocating funds from Enova.

Investigate a top pricing model through electricity taxes. The government is requested, based on the investigation, to present a proposal that takes into account consumption, energy standards, household size, and geography.
Investigate the possibilities of introducing a tax on export power. The tax should be used to reduce domestic electricity prices and fees.
Remove the electricity tax from October 1, 2022.
Stop further electrification of the Norwegian continental shelf with power from land as a climate measure and reduce the emission target from 50% to 40%.
Assess the need for the procurement of new gas power plants to strengthen power preparedness and return to the Storting before the end of October 2022.
Ensure that larger district heating plants based on geothermal energy, sea heat, or energy wells receive electricity support.
Ensure equal treatment of folk high schools, so that no folk high schools are excluded from the electricity support scheme.
Continue and strengthen the scheme for electricity support to voluntary teams and organizations.
Facilitate a solution where consumers can order energy efficiency measures that are paid for through interest-free loans or grants with simultaneous disbursement.
Give Enova the opportunity to differentiate support schemes based on income, so that low-income households can have a larger share of their investments in energy savings covered.
Investigate how the incentives to implement energy efficiency measures in commercial buildings can be strengthened through changes in depreciation rates.
Impose on utility companies the responsibility to provide energy consulting to households and small businesses.
Set a goal to reduce gas consumption by 15%.
Facilitate Enova support for batteries.

Introduce a price for electricity of a maximum of 0.50 NOK per kWh including VAT. This applies to everyone, including households, vacation properties, non-profit organizations, and businesses, from September 1, 2022. The electricity support will then be set to 100% above 50 øre. The electricity support will last until electricity prices are normalized again.

Emphasize and prioritize national energy security in the system for electricity exchange between countries, and establish a system where net electricity exports are halted when reservoir filling levels are lower than normal for the season, taking into account future forecasts for electricity production and power reserves in the counterpart countries.

Start renegotiating the agreements regarding the power cables to Germany and England with the mentioned countries. The government is given the mandate to terminate the agreement if changes that reduce price spillover and lower the risk of power rationing are not granted.
Introduce a requirement for solar panels on all new residential buildings by 2029.
Give municipalities, through the Planning and Building Act, the opportunity to require solar panels on all new buildings from June 1, 2023.
Promote a proposal to amend relevant regulations to ensure stricter requirements for energy-flexible heating in new buildings and requirements for energy efficiency improvements during renovations.
Introduce a requirement for solar panels on all new public buildings and commercial buildings with a floor area greater than 250 square meters by 2026.
Introduce a requirement for solar panels on all existing public and commercial buildings with a usable floor area greater than 250 square meters by 2027.

Ensure that Enova, for a temporary period, is tasked with supporting mature technologies that reduce energy consumption for households and small businesses, such as heat pumps, insulation of parts of the building envelope, window replacement, batteries, geothermal energy, and similar solutions.
Set a goal to reduce electricity consumption during the hours of the day with the highest usage by 5%.
Set a goal and develop a plan for a reduction in electricity consumption of at least 10% by March 31, 2023.
Implement energy-saving measures in the public sector that have an immediate effect on electricity consumption.
Propose measures to support energy initiatives in rental properties.
Facilitate Enova support for solar panels in housing cooperatives and condominiums.
Assess whether the current revenue framework model for grid companies provides sufficient incentives to invest in digital solutions that increase capacity utilization in existing networks.
Halt the shutdown of the gas power plant at Mongstad and keep it for emergency purposes.

Utilize the gas power plant at Mongstad for regular power production in case of emergency and other needs, and assess whether other gas power plants in Norway can also be used in an emergency situation.

Raise the limit for power development in protected waterways from 1 MW to up to 10 MW, as long as this does not weaken the conservation values, so that production is governed by the actual effects on the conservation values, and that small-scale hydropower can have a greater flood mitigation effect.
Make the digital mapping of the remaining potential for small hydropower conducted by NVE available to improve access to information about potential small hydropower projects.

Consider establishing a competency program for craftsmen to assist homeowners with energy efficiency measures, ensure that a comprehensive national information campaign is conducted on opportunities for energy savings in households and commercial buildings, and create a guide for businesses and non-profit organizations on opportunities for energy efficiency and electricity savings, as well as the available support schemes.

Follow up on the introduction of requirements for waste heat utilization from industrial facilities and present a concrete plan by the end of 2022 on how this will be implemented for facilities with significant heat loss.

Establish a temporary or time-limited support scheme through Enova for the establishment of solar energy systems on commercial buildings and commercial areas within the framework of their mandate, which is not limited to companies with 3% energy intensity, and which also includes the installation of battery storage where relevant.
Ensure faster licensing processing by NVE for power production that can be in place during the fall of 2022 or in 2023, such as small-scale hydropower, hydropower, and solar power plants.

Evaluate whether the discount rate used to calculate the socio-economic profitability of small hydropower, hydropower, and solar power in concession processes is set at the correct level, in accordance with the Ministry of Finance's circular r-109.10.

Implement necessary measures that can significantly reduce case and concession processing times in the short term, and introduce fast tracks for simple cases and prioritized projects within networks and production.
Come up with a concrete plan for how several stages in the concession process can be conducted in parallel, not sequentially, by the end of 2022, with the aim of implementation from July 1, 2023.
Consider whether Statnett and the regional grid companies should be given greater opportunity to account for future needs when making investments in the networks.
Map the potential for solar energy production on agricultural land, while maintaining agricultural production, no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2023.

Map the potential for solar energy production on existing infrastructure where solar parks can be established without significant environmental impact, such as on parking lots, in industrial areas, and similar locations.

Consider imposing a clearer responsibility on Enova, NVE, or the grid companies to specifically offer energy consulting to households and small businesses, or otherwise ensure that a reasonable scheme for proactive energy consulting for households and businesses is established as quickly as possible, for example through site visits and the development of action plans.

Map which government buildings and infrastructure are suitable for the establishment of solar energy beyond Statsbygg's areas, and ensure that the state establishes solar energy production as quickly as possible where it is suitable, for example by making land available at a competitive price.

Map and implement energy efficiency measures in government buildings, as well as assess immediate actions to reduce energy consumption in public buildings and commercial buildings over the next year, including mandates for energy mapping and switching to energy-efficient lighting, rapid integration of heat pumps, and improvements in heat recovery and ventilation systems.

Set ambitious targets for installed solar energy by 2030 of at least 8 TWh, with interim goals already for 2023 and a concrete action plan that enables the realization of these targets. The plan should be presented to the Parliament along with the goals and action plan by the revised budget of 2023. The plan should include both public buildings, commercial buildings (including agriculture), as well as apartments, housing cooperatives, and single-family homes.

Consider whether electricity customers with their own solar energy production should pay electricity tax and VAT on net consumption, meaning they would receive a monthly net settlement for consumed and produced electricity instead of the gross settlement as it is today.

Consider strengthening the Housing Bank's work on energy measures for low-income households, for example by establishing a temporary loan scheme that can be used for the installation of heat pumps, insulation of buildings, and other relevant energy efficiency measures, in conjunction with existing energy efficiency programs.
Engage in dialogue with the municipalities to consider a temporary or time-limited arrangement where applications for building permits for energy upgrades are fee-free.
Consider a temporary or time-limited exemption from licensing requirements to establish low-voltage lines to neighboring buildings for the sale of electricity.
Consider removing the exemption limit of 500 kW for grid fees on electricity shared as neighborhood power, or possibly increasing the limit for shared solar installations to 4,000 m² or 1,000 kW.
Consider increasing the power limit for how large a solar energy facility can be before a permit requirement comes into effect.
Ensure that the grid companies adopt new technology that increases the utilization of existing network infrastructure, and that this work is prioritized.

Investigate how a power support scheme for district heating systems that supply household customers can be designed, and estimate the cost of such a scheme. The investigation should be carried out with the aim of completion by mid-November 2022.

Consider, in light of the current energy situation, giving Enova an additional mandate to help strengthen supply security by facilitating significantly more energy efficiency and flexible and effective energy and power use through targeted measures for businesses and households. Such an update must ensure that support for mature technologies that provide rapid reductions in electricity consumption becomes a central task for Enova, such as through heat pumps, retrofitting parts of building envelopes, window replacements, batteries, geothermal energy, and similar solutions.
Consider changing the current Enova grant "comprehensive upgrade of building structure" so that households can receive grants even when only parts of the building are upgraded.
Consider changing Enova's solution for payments to consumers so that payments are made simultaneously.

Consider temporarily or conditionally exempting smaller solar energy systems from the application requirement under the Planning and Building Act, with the exception of protected and heritage buildings, and removing the requirement for grid registration for systems under 7 kW.
Present the arms agreement with the USA to the Storting in accordance with the Constitution § 26.
The requirement for end-user documentation will be practiced for all exports of defense materials, including to NATO countries and close allies.

Establish a broad, composed public committee that will conduct a comprehensive review of the Norwegian export control regime, including both the regulations and the administrative aspects, to ensure real and verifiable compliance with the Parliament's 1959 decision and 1997 clarification, as well as with international obligations. Additionally, the committee should assess whether there is a need for further clarifications in line with Norway's obligations under international law, humanitarian law, and human rights law.

That defense materials and dual-use goods should not be exported to countries participating in warfare in Yemen, based on the precautionary principle of avoiding Norwegian goods contributing to violations of international law.
Establish a professional committee to deliver a NOU on the advantages and disadvantages of a potential Norwegian EU membership.

Investigate the possibility of increased joint procurement of materials for the Nordic countries as part of the work on a new long-term plan for the defense sector, in light of Sweden and Finland's applications for NATO membership.
Take the initiative to establish a Nordic deployable force as part of NATO's rapid response force.
Take the initiative to establish a joint Nordic air and land force for the defense of the northern regions.

Take the initiative for a joint Nordic collaboration to reduce the number of main weapon systems used in the Nordic region in connection with new acquisitions, with the aim of coordinating and reducing costs.
Initiate an investigation into a common Nordic education and training system for military personnel.
Take the initiative for coordination and sharing of Nordic shooting and training areas.
Explain how Norway's current commitment to defend Sweden and Finland has been operationalized and followed up in defense planning as far as possible.
Expand Norway's independent obligation to assist Sweden and Finland with all necessary means, so that it does not lapse when these countries become members of NATO.
Take the initiative to establish joint defense operational plans for the Nordic region.
Promote a proposal for an amendment to the law on the Government Pension Fund to allow the use of part of the fund's assets outside the country's borders.
Ensure that the electricity support scheme for voluntary organizations is changed so that the scheme can provide monthly payments.
Come back to the Storting with proposals for improvements to the electricity support scheme for businesses.

Assess whether the energy subsidy scheme is functioning as intended, whether there is a need for energy subsidies or similar schemes for businesses in 2023, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Promote a bill for the establishment of asylum reception centers abroad, similar to the Danish bill L 226 (2021–2022), passed by the Folketing on June 3, 2021, or the recently proposed British model.
Enter into a collaboration with Denmark and/or the United Kingdom with the aim of establishing a joint solution for asylum reception abroad.
Engage in negotiations aimed at entering into agreements with third countries that ensure protection for individuals with a genuine need for protection.
Investigate a system where Norway provides protection to vulnerable individuals with protection needs by funding their relocation to safe third countries.
Suspend the reception of quota refugees as long as the conflict in Ukraine persists, so that all available capacity is used to receive and assist Ukrainian refugees.
Come back to the Parliament with a clarification of the relationship between the provisions of the National Insurance Act and EEA law.
Review the use of compulsory wage arbitration. The review should be conducted regularly.
Promote proposals that ensure the right to be heard, so that both parties are listened to and can express their opinions before a conflict is halted by compulsory wage arbitration.

Review the use of compulsory wage arbitration and propose measures to ensure that compulsory wage arbitration cannot be used in a way that undermines the right to strike. The goal is that ongoing conflicts are not halted unless absolutely necessary.

Review proposals on how to ensure that compulsory wage arbitration does not become the outcome of a labor conflict, and how to use exemptions so that the parties have the opportunity to negotiate with progress when there is a conflict, and return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Promote necessary proposals for a gradual phasing out of the reduction in pensions based on marital status.
That tolls will not be collected on the side roads to E39 between Bjørnafjorden and Bergen.
Introduce an approval system for general practitioner offices that includes a registration scheme, and that establishment cannot take place if it undermines the public service.
Ensure that the absence scheme for upper secondary school does not burden the healthcare system with administrative tasks that are not based on a genuine health need.
Allow municipalities to grant applications for sales permits for alcoholic beverages of class 1, even when the application comes from service trade businesses.
Investigate how the service trade can compete on equal terms with grocery retail without leading to increased availability of alcohol.
Revoke the decision to tighten the rules for obtaining and retaining individual reimbursement (blue prescription) for CGRP inhibitors for migraine patients.
Make a new assessment of the need, and possibly the time interval, for treatment breaks for CGRP inhibitors.
Ensure that the National Health and Coordination Plan includes a comprehensive plan for pediatric palliative care.

Propose measures to strengthen municipalities' duty and ability to follow up on illegal activities in accordance with the Planning and Building Act and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Propose a change in the law that clarifies that municipalities have the "right" and not the "duty" under the Planning and Building Act to follow up on measures that are illegal.
Ensure that the county governor places more emphasis on discretion than is currently done in cases of illegal construction.

Investigate a legislative proposal to amend the municipality's obligation to follow up on measures that have been implemented in violation of the Planning and Building Act, and send this proposal out for consultation.

Investigate the costs of establishing a medical education program at the University of Stavanger, where the university is more effectively involved, and return to the Parliament with a more precise cost basis.
Assess the need for changes in the degree regulations to potentially allow for medical education in more locations across the country.
Establish medical education in Stavanger.

Implement measures and promote proposals that ensure adults who have not completed upper secondary education are given a real right to complete high school. Emphasis should be placed on better collaboration between the state, county, and business sector, increased flexibility in the offerings, improved accessibility, and greater capacity.
Investigate the possibilities of establishing a joint Norwegian-Taiwanese semiconductor manufacturing facility in Norway.
Come back to the Storting with a message about alternative ways to strengthen Norway's bilateral relations with the Republic of China (Taiwan).
Reestablish a Norwegian representation office in Taipei.
Take the initiative for free trade negotiations between EFTA and the Republic of China (Taiwan).
Take the initiative for a bilateral tax agreement with the Republic of China (Taiwan).
Remove the general exemption for Russian fishing vessels from the Norwegian port ban, so that it also includes Russian fishing vessels that are covered by SOLAS, MARPOL, or the Load Lines Convention.
Make the Students at Risk program a permanent arrangement.
Increase the cap on the number of students who can come through the Students at Risk program from 20 to at least 40 per year starting from 2023.
Enter into a new dialogue with the sellers of AS Meraker Brug to achieve a price that provides Statskog SF with a business-like real return on the investment.
Present sufficient information so that the Storting can make an informed decision regarding the purchase of AS Meraker Brug.

Require Statskog SF to use the property of AS Meraker Brug to develop management methods that will help maintain a diversity of ecosystems in good ecological condition, and to contribute to improving the ecological status of Norwegian forests to "good."
Notify that Norway will maintain its contributions to ESA's voluntary programs at the current level, i.e., a minimum of 161 million euros in new commitments for the program period until 2030.
Propose to increase the funding for the Norwegian Geological Survey (NGU) to map the mineral resources in Norway.
Present a proposal for the establishment of a state mineral fund based on the Finnish model.

Evaluate reimbursement schemes for exploration companies within the mineral industry and examine whether the principles from the exploration reimbursement scheme within the petroleum tax regime can be transferable.
Propose necessary funding of 100 million NOK for research and development regarding the management of waste material in mineral extraction.
Contribute to creating an economy in circular mining by increasing the demand for mining waste in construction and infrastructure projects.

To conduct a thorough assessment of the potential for increased metal recovery from existing waste streams, from old landfills, from slag heaps, and other sources, with the aim of minimizing the need for new mineral extraction.

Investigate and propose a fee for the disposal of waste materials from the mining industry, with the aim of encouraging increased reuse of waste materials, and report back to the Parliament no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2023.

It should be established that in future concession processes, no concessions for mineral extraction shall be granted without requirements for zero emissions for waste, strict requirements for the return of materials, and requirements that waste management should not occur in open landfills. No permits shall be granted for sea disposal.

Investigate how municipalities can retain a larger share of the value creation associated with mineral activities, and assess whether a production fee could be appropriate for municipalities to have an incentive to facilitate more business activities.
Introduce a ten-year moratorium on seabed mineral extraction with the aim of gathering more knowledge about environmental consequences before potentially initiating such activities.

Consider a requirement that mining companies must establish an individual environmental fund. Allocated funds should be deposited into a blocked account to ensure coverage and replanting of the deposit site during and after mining operations have ceased.
Ensure a simpler and more coordinated licensing process for mineral extraction in mainland Norway.
Consider strengthening the guidance function of the Directorate for Mineral Management with the Mining Inspector for Svalbard (DMF).
Look at the possibilities for increased Nordic cooperation in the extraction and processing of minerals, as well as research and development to mitigate environmental challenges.
Review the exceptions in the VAT regulations that apply to the cultural industries, and consider proposing a common low VAT rate for cultural industries.
Investigate multiple funding sources for the development of the creative industry, including improved loan and guarantee schemes.

Consider how the authorities can better facilitate the retention of copyright in Norwegian hands to preserve Norwegian culture, language, and history, as well as to ensure a well-functioning ecosystem within creative industries.

Develop and promote proposals for a growth strategy within the creative industry. The strategy should aim to increase value creation and contribute to growth in the number of businesses, sustainable jobs, and exports.

Review the entire support system for cultural industries and assess how to ensure better coordination, including whether it may be appropriate to consolidate several support measures for cultural industries within Innovation Norway, as well as ensuring that Innovation Norway's expertise in cultural industries is strengthened.
Open up for the possibility that the fishing industry in the north can be granted up to 4 licenses for the capture of snow crab, so that they can utilize this resource in their production.
Present a proposal on what percentage of future snow crab quotas should be delivered as live-caught to land facilities in Northern Norway.
Regulate the snow crab fishery so that it contributes to the greatest possible growth and development for Norwegian coastal communities.

Ensure that the Norwegian Directorate of Health promptly initiates the revision of the national guidelines for investigation, diagnosis, treatment, rehabilitation, care, and support for CFS/ME as soon as possible in 2023, so that patients being assessed for CFS/ME receive the best possible treatment as quickly as possible.
Maintain the level of current research on CFS/ME.
Investigate the rights and treatment options for CFS/ME patients with the aim of gaining better insight into how patients are met by Nav and the healthcare services.

Review regulations and practices to ensure that the rights of individuals with CFS/ME to equal treatment are upheld regarding the requirement for appropriate treatment when applying for disability benefits.

Review regulations and practices to ensure that individuals with CFS/ME undergoing assessment are not subjected to treatment requirements that are unavailable or that they are denied in the public healthcare system.
Raise the upper limit for the imposition of fines and ensure that serious labor market crime is routinely reported to the police.

Promote proposals for guidelines that ensure the most vulnerable users are guaranteed an accessible and open Nav, including national requirements for opening hours for drop-in visits. Such guidelines should be developed in collaboration with the employees in accordance with the principles behind the government's trust reform. The Parliament requests the government to ensure that the Labor and Welfare Administration has sufficient resources to implement these changes.

Promote proposals that require municipalities to establish local emergency hotlines that allow for contact with the Labour and Welfare Administration. The Parliament requests the government to ensure that municipalities have the necessary resources to implement these changes.
Ensure that all of the country's Nav offices have opening hours and availability that accommodate users who cannot or are not comfortable using digital and self-service solutions.

Draft a regulation that ensures that individuals who have been subjected to illegal use of coercive measures in minor drug cases are granted compensation in these cases without a reasonableness assessment.

Establish a public committee to investigate how the Norwegian police and prosecution have misinterpreted the law regarding searches of individuals in less serious drug cases for years, and propose changes to prevent similar mistakes from occurring in the future.

Promote a legislative proposal that ensures that if someone complains to a department about a rejection of a request for access to information, it shall not prevent a similar complaint from another party from being processed by the Parliamentary Ombudsman.
Investigate the establishment of an independent complaints body for access requests under the Freedom of Information Act.

Promote the necessary legislative proposals to ensure control over which individuals are allowed to work with Ukrainian refugees on a voluntary basis, and to prevent individuals with a history of abuse from performing such work.
Ensure that all police districts have dedicated investigation teams against human trafficking.
Create a new and binding action plan against human trafficking.

Come back to the Parliament with a new legislative proposal that includes a more thorough review with an emphasis on the housing social aspects. In particular, the residents' viewpoints must be taken into account in the assessments. In the preparation of a new legislative proposal, alternative ways to assist municipalities with issues related to housing foundations should also be explored. This includes examining requirements for the number of members on the boards of the foundations, proposals for frameworks for transition funds for universal design and energy efficiency, and the reintroduction and improvement of economic and legal frameworks that make the foundation model more suitable for carrying out municipal tasks.

Develop social and environmental requirements that must be established before a municipality can proceed with the dissolution of housing foundations under the current legislative proposal, including neglect of maintenance, poor housing social conditions, default on capital, and lack of compliance with energy efficiency and universal design, provided that satisfactory support schemes in these areas are available for each housing foundation.

Ensure that the proposed § 55 c in the Foundations Act, cf. Prop. 135 L (2021–2022), requires municipalities to assess the consequences for tenants/users of the foundation's housing before making decisions under the proposed § 55 b.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal on how the legal basis for the dissolution of foundations established by municipalities or county municipalities together with housing cooperatives can be formulated.
Propose amendments to the law that require private schools to be self-owned and not part of a corporate group.
Propose amendments to the law so that schools receiving government funding must have a non-commercial purpose clause.
Investigate new organizational forms for operating private schools that facilitate non-profit activities while ensuring public transparency in the use of public funds.

Propose amendments to the law that ensure municipalities and county municipalities gain increased authority over the school structure, so that the interests of the public school offering are safeguarded when establishing and expanding private school offerings.

Review the legislation for private schools to ensure that the intention that all state funding benefits students is better upheld than it is today. Such a review should aim to reduce the need for oversight, introduce stricter sanctions for violations, and prevent the resale of schools and colleges receiving state funding from enabling the extraction of private profit from school operations.
Promote proposals that ensure a regulatory framework requiring private schools to report in cases of sale, merger, demerger, and closure.
Propose amendments to the law that clarify that the prohibition on transferring values to the school's owners also applies in the case of a sale.

Propose amendments to the law that ensure that members of the school board cannot serve on the boards of companies that conduct business with the school, in order to counteract trade with related companies and prevent the possibility of profiting from school operations, based on the model from Denmark.
Ensure that national tests are conducted as sample tests.
Ensure that the results from the national tests are not published at the school, municipality, and county levels.
Consider which regulatory changes are necessary to allow for the operation of autonomous vehicles in normal traffic and at normal speeds on selected parts of the regular road network.
Consider how the regulations for testing autonomous vehicles can better contribute to technology and industry development in Norway.
Ensure that, in collaboration with the industry, varied routes are proposed that can be pre-approved for autonomous driving.
Consider how the complexity of testing autonomous vehicles can be increased, and adapt the approval procedure for the tests.

Investigate a separate fee on fossil-fueled private jets to promote the transition to zero-emission aircraft and create a larger market for this. The fee should exempt flights justified by life, health, and safety. Exceptions should also be made for small aircraft clubs, skydiving clubs, veteran aircraft communities, and similar organizations.

Investigate and present a proposal for a ban on private flights, including charter flights with one or few passengers. The ban must make exceptions for flights justified by life, health, and safety. It should also make exceptions for small aircraft clubs, skydiving clubs, vintage aircraft communities, and similar organizations.

Set a reduction target for aviation of 5% annually based on the 2022 level. Avinor shall primarily work to ensure that the reduction occurs in international flights, as well as in air traffic between cities where the rail connection is good.

Investigate a progressive air passenger tax that increases with the number of flights taken in a year. Necessary flights within Norway, where there are no good alternatives to flying, should be exempt from the tax.
Say no to the splitting of the railway by instructing the Norwegian Railway Authority not to divide the train services in Eastern Norway.
Merge Vy and Flytoget.

Ensure that a temporary bridge is established at Tretten as soon as possible, including ensuring that the relevant state agencies expedite the processing of applications for the necessary permits and approvals.
Change the proposal that zero-emission vehicles may have to pay up to 70% of the normal rate when passing a toll, and set it to the current limit, which is 50% of the normal rate.
Prioritize the planning work and financing of the state highway projects E39 Fløyfjelltunnelen in combination with the tunnel safety upgrade project in Fløyfjelltunnelen.
Ensure that it becomes possible for the county municipalities to finance the operation of public transport with toll revenues through the urban growth agreements.
Allow a pilot project with a lower speed limit on the national road 4 between Sinsen and Grorud in Oslo year-round and reduce the number of lanes to protect the population along the road.
End all exploration for new oil and gas fields on the Norwegian continental shelf.
Cancel the allocation of extraction permits through TFO 2022, which is planned for the first quarter of 2023.

Compensate the private kindergartens for the cost of implementing the recently adopted requirement by the Parliament that each private kindergarten must be transformed into an independent legal entity.
Abolish the current toll system and establish state full financing of infrastructure.
Create a separate item in the national budget for the Police National Preparedness Center (PNB).

Conduct an evaluation of the consequences for activity and jobs in the measure zones with reduced employer contributions as a result of changed conditions introduced in 2010, including requirements for the registered location of companies' headquarters.
Come back to the Storting with a plan for stem cell treatment in Norway and/or assistance to purchase this abroad.

Come back to the Parliament in connection with the revised national budget for 2023 with a proposal to change the VAT compensation scheme for sports, volunteer work, and culture so that it becomes rule-based instead of being granted as a block grant.
Continue the approval scheme for free treatment choice.
Investigate and send for consultation any potential changes to the emigration tax before it is presented to the Parliament for consideration.
Promote measures to strengthen the public general practitioner service, including developing a legal basis to regulate the establishment of fully private commercial general practitioner offices.

To ensure that non-profit organizations in child welfare have long-term agreements with the public sector, and to present a plan for phasing out large commercial actors from child welfare in connection with the revised national budget for 2023.
