Send out proposals for consultation in 2023 that provide municipalities with new and stronger tools to regulate and dimension the overall kindergarten offerings in the municipality for the benefit of children and parents. The government will investigate and send proposals for consultation on this, such as setting conditions for grants to private kindergartens, the possibility of imposing the same requirements on private kindergartens as on public kindergartens, and time-limiting grants to private kindergartens.
Investigate and propose a departure tax that ensures that unrealized gains accrued in Norway up to the time of departure are actually taxed here.
Promote a proposal for a municipal/state tourist tax no later than in connection with the state budget for 2024.

Make the necessary legal and regulatory changes to reintroduce the obligation to be affiliated with a taxi central and the duty to operate and limit the number of taxis in the taxi industry during 2023.

Send out for consultation a proposal for new rules stating that fishing for cod with vessels over 21 meters must take place outside the baseline, and that vessels over 28 meters must fish outside 4 nautical miles from the baseline. The proposal will entail a ban on cod fishing with the specified vessel groups within these limits. The purpose of the change being sent for consultation is to implement a significant tightening compared to current practices.

Promote a proposal to amend the dental health law so that individuals aged 23-26 are granted the right to treatment in the public dental health service, as well as to establish by regulation the right to a 50 percent reduced payment for these age groups.

Ensure that students who receive an offer of 12 hours of free after-school care (SFO) from the school year 2023-2024 have the opportunity to participate on all weekdays when the school offers SFO services, as far as it is practically possible.

Establish a Rent Law Committee to review the Rent Act to assess how it can strengthen tenants' rights, ensure basic housing security, and align the law better with the current situation in the rental market. The committee will be established in the spring of 2023, and a new law will be considered during the current parliamentary term.

Investigate alternatives to the current compensation rates in the parental benefit scheme. The investigation should include an assessment of introducing a 90 percent compensation rate and a revenue-neutral restructuring. Proposals for possible alternatives will be presented in the state budget for 2024.

Implement trials and testing of alternatives to the current examination system in upper secondary school and lower secondary school. The trials and testing will be monitored with assistance and experience gathering.
Investigate the one-time fee on fossil fuel trucks, buses, and other heavy vehicles in connection with the state budget for 2024.

Continue the Ringeriksbanen and E16 Skaret-Høgkastet-Hønefoss as a joint project and assess the progress and economic sustainability of the project leading up to the new National Transport Plan (NTP).
Ensure that the maximum toll rate for light zero-emission vehicles of up to 70 percent of the regular rate is maintained during the current parliamentary term.
Come up with a plan to introduce a system for contracts for difference for hydrogen by the end of 2023.
Aim to initiate negotiations for a city growth agreement with the Kristiansand region and Nedre Glomma as soon as possible.

Present a proposal for a ban on the conversion of wetlands for development purposes during 2023. Possible exemptions from the ban will be investigated to preserve other areas of high value and for the development of critical infrastructure. The goal is for the ban to effectively reduce the conversion of wetlands.
Return to the Storting in the 2024 state budget with a proposal for government funding to finance production schools.

Facilitate the continuation of the preliminary project work for a new building for the Grieg Academy in Bergen, where the Ministry of Education and Research still has the role of project commissioner.
Propose phasing out the weight deduction for plug-in hybrid cars by no later than 2025.
Investigate whether and how medical costs related to the deductible limit can be distributed throughout the calendar year.
Ensure that the Police Directorate and the Attorney General implement measures to increase the clearance rate and ensure a short processing time for cases of violence in close relationships.
Ensure that the Police Directorate secures knowledge about SARA in the police districts.
Ensure that the Police Directorate secures knowledge in the police districts about PATRIARK and about honor-related violence, forced marriage, and female genital mutilation.

Follow up on the recommendations in Document 3:8 (2021–2022), the National Audit Office's investigation of the authorities' efforts against violence in close relationships, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Establish a permanent partner homicide commission.
Develop a national prevention program for a coordinated effort against partner violence and partner homicide.
Ensure that the municipalities, either on their own or in inter-municipal cooperation, have adopted an action plan against violence in close relationships.
Ensure a good and updated knowledge base on violence in close relationships.

Facilitate that the police and other support services routinely offer users individual conversations, and that such conversations are mandatory in parts of the support system, in line with the recommendations of the partner homicide committee.

Facilitate better documentation routines and strengthen the competence on the rules regarding information exchange between the police and other support services, in accordance with the recommendations of the partner homicide committee.
Strengthen the emergency services for individuals who are exposed to violence in close relationships.

Ensure that the regulations regarding the child welfare service's duty to report to the police about children at hidden and blocked addresses are clarified, and that necessary routines for information exchange are established.

Ensure access to impose conditions for electronic monitoring with a GPS ankle bracelet for those sentenced to preventive detention during their leave from serving their sentence, and if necessary, propose the necessary legislative changes to achieve this goal.

Develop a national minimum standard for the alternative to the system of state-funded parole, including a maximum cap on the number of individuals per unit, minimum requirements for the number of staff per unit, minimum requirements for the professional qualifications of staff, minimum requirements for outdoor and recreational areas, and minimum requirements for eight hours of meaningful activity per day, in accordance with the recommendations from the CPT.

Investigate the need for changes to the law on the establishment and implementation of mental health care (the Mental Health Care Act), provided that the alternative to the arrangement of state-funded probation is assigned to the specialist health service.

Implement appropriate measures to improve the quality of and standardize personal investigations according to the Criminal Procedure Act § 161, so that they can serve as tools for identifying cognitive impairments, including considering the inclusion of control questions that form the basis for assessing whether to proceed with, for example, HASI (screening for intellectual disabilities in adults).

Come back to the Storting with a proposal to amend the Criminal Procedure Act § 239 so that it also includes suspected or charged individuals, as well as making the necessary changes to the regulations regarding the questioning of children and other particularly vulnerable victims and witnesses (adapted interviews).

Consider establishing a system with more active support for particularly vulnerable individuals during police interrogations, for example, following the British model, where there is a formal requirement for an "Appropriate Adult" (AA) in criminal cases involving individuals with intellectual disabilities, and also consider whether the State Child Welfare Services can be assigned such a responsibility.

Introduce routines where the preparatory judge takes on the role of a reporting point to ensure the transfer of knowledge about cognitive impairments from the police, prosecution, defense attorney, and victim's counsel to the court.

Implement appropriate measures to raise the basic knowledge of cognitive impairments among students and staff in all relevant professional groups within the justice system, as well as ensure that training in simple communication is provided within the respective student and professional groups.
Ensure that adapted written materials are developed for individuals with reading and writing difficulties at all stages of the judicial process.
Conduct a comprehensive evaluation of the system of state-funded parole.

Investigate alternatives to the arrangement of state-funded parole, including a new form of special reaction aimed at individuals who have been sentenced to preventive detention and attempted rehabilitation, but who, due to poor mental functioning, will have a permanent need for boundary-setting care; a new type of institution for individuals sentenced to this form of special reaction, as well as how such an organization should be structured and financed.

Conduct a comprehensive evaluation of the special reactions of preventive detention, sentences to compulsory mental health care, and sentences to compulsory care, including assessing whether these special reactions are appropriate for those sentenced under special reactions without further rehabilitation potential.

Initiate an independent review of the Special Unit for Police Cases, including a review of the quality of investigations and prosecutorial decisions, including dismissals, a review of internal culture and independence in relation to the police, an examination of how many of the employees do not have a background in the police, and assess whether more should be done to hire people with more diverse backgrounds, as well as an evaluation of whether dependence on resources and expertise affects practical independence and what changes may need to be made in this area.
Promote a case for incorporating the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities into the Human Rights Act.
Promote a case for ratifying the additional protocols to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

To require the Norwegian Food Safety Authority to tighten enforcement and sanctions against dog breeders in accordance with the Animal Welfare Act § 25 regarding robust animals with good function and health.
Ensure that the upcoming regulation on dog breeding includes a ban on breeding that negatively affects animals' physical or mental functions.
Introduce a requirement for a general health examination from a veterinarian for both parent animals to be used in breeding.
Take the initiative to establish a searchable database of breeding values for dogs.

Consider whether parts of the costs for ensuring animal welfare in dog breeding can be placed on breeders or breed clubs, since the revenue in this sector is significant, and since dog breeding is generally not subject to taxation.
Ensure that all health history about the dog and its parent animals is made available in an understandable format for all dog buyers.
Return to the Parliament with a proposal for the establishment of a health register for seafarers.
Ensure that substance analysis is offered to prevent the risk of harm and overdoses in the municipalities, for example through the municipal advisory units for substance issues.
Ensure that harm reduction measures are treated equally with substance abuse prevention measures in the grant schemes for voluntary organizations in the field of substance use.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a compensation scheme for individuals who have been subjected to illegal use of coercive measures in connection with drug searches.
Ensure that the quantity is only given significance in sentencing for less serious drug cases if there is a qualified risk that the substance would have ended up in the wrong hands.

Change the mandate of the municipal substance abuse units so that their work is solely focused on health care and support for coping, and does not serve as a part of a sentencing process or to avoid punishment. The mandate must be developed in a way that allows the units to utilize their health and social expertise in the best and most effective manner.
Ensure that all possession of drugs for personal use that can be punished with a fine is gathered in one common provision with a fine as the maximum penalty.
Ensure that the upcoming prevention and treatment reform in the substance abuse field also includes harm reduction measures.
Promote a bill that protects individuals from prosecution for minor drug offenses when they contact emergency services for help for themselves or others.

Present a case stating that the use and possession of drugs remain punishable, but that individuals with severe substance dependence should be met with tailored responses such as dismissal of charges and health assistance.
Ensure that the police continue to prioritize combating illegal drug use among youth.

Promote proposals for necessary clarifications of legislation to ensure that the police have the necessary tools in their work to combat drug-related crime, including specifying the conditions that must be met to decide on a search in cases of suspected use and possession, and to secure evidence of use that holds up in court.

Strengthen the treatment services and healthcare for individuals with substance abuse issues, including enhancing the municipalities' preventive services, the capacity in interdisciplinary specialized substance abuse treatment, and measures to improve the quality of life for those with substance dependence, and return to the Parliament with a plan for this as soon as possible.

Ensure systematic documentation of the effects of drug contracts and clarify the legal basis for their use. The government is requested to return to the Storting with a case on this matter. Until that happens, the Storting asks the government to ensure that the use of drug contracts for youth ceases.
Present a proposal for a boundary adjustment between the municipalities of Sandnes and Strand, so that the Forsand part of the new Sandnes becomes a part of Strand municipality.

Ensure that the employee organizations in the Armed Forces receive the necessary ongoing insight into the Armed Forces' use of contracts for service obligations, in order to safeguard personnel with such contracts in the best possible way.

Ensure that the soldiers from the Home Guard's operational units who have reported and raised the issue of unlawful practices regarding holiday pay and the employment status of voluntary personnel in the Home Guard, and have been taken to court by the Ministry of Defence, receive compensation for their actual legal costs, including their own work and time spent.

Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner by the end of 2023 and by the end of 2024, for example in the budget proposals for 2024 and 2025, and report on the experiences and consequences of the changes in the Defense Act, as adopted during the consideration of Innst. 74 L (2022-2023), for personnel in the Armed Forces, including the extent of the use of contracts for service obligations and which personnel in which functions will receive contracts for service obligations.
Present a plan to halt all trade in food, feed, and feed raw materials with Russia as long as Russia's war against Ukraine continues.
Promote a proposal for a compensation scheme for fish reception facilities and coastal communities affected by the exclusion of Russian fishing vessels from Norwegian ports.
Extend the port ban for Russian vessels to include fishing vessels.

Take the initiative, either unilaterally or in consultation with other countries, to ensure that Russian individuals and companies involved in fishing in the Norwegian economic zone, and with ties to Russian authorities, are subject to economic sanctions.
Ensure that the EEA Agreement strengthens free trade with the EEA area, with the aim of promoting Norwegian interests.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to amend the EEA Act § 2 to ensure the scope for action, by allowing national laws and regulations to take precedence when necessary for the sake of important societal interests.
Reject all requests for assistance to bring adult Norwegian citizens from the camps in Syria to Norway.
Introduce a support scheme for district heating customers and return to the Parliament with proposals for funding for this if necessary.
Investigate a more accurate calculation of the electricity support, reflecting both electricity prices and consumption patterns.

Ensure that electricity support can be granted to households connected to smaller, private power grids on par with other households, and return to the Storting with proposals for funding for this if necessary.

Consider how households connected to smaller, private power grids can receive electricity support similar to others, and report back to the Storting as soon as possible on whether it is possible to adjust the electricity support scheme to take such households into account, aiming for the end of January 2023.

Consider how households that receive their heating from district heating systems can be included in the electricity support scheme, and report back to the Parliament as soon as possible on whether it is possible to adjust the electricity support scheme to take such households into account by the end of 2022.

Consider how households that actually have their permanent residence in a property registered as a holiday home – and do not own or have access to another property – can be included in the electricity support scheme, and report back to the Parliament as soon as possible on whether it is possible to adjust the electricity support scheme to take such households into account with a view to the end of 2022.

Ensure that the funds Enova is to make available for energy measures in households and for consumers are at least 520 million kroner, in order to compensate for cuts in the Housing Bank's allocation in Innst. 16 S (2022-2023) and to follow up on the Parliament's decision in the processing of Innst. 25 S (2022-2023).

Promote a proposal to strengthen the electricity support for households so that it will provide 100% compensation for consumption over 50 øre/kWh. This should apply from January 2023 to December 2023.
Propose amendments to the law that establish a ban on large point source emissions of greenhouse gases in Norway starting from 2030.
Present a plan for how Norway can become land-neutral by 2025.
To present the "Green Book" as a separate parliamentary report alongside the budget to ensure a genuine debate on the instruments of climate policy.
Propose to allocate at least one billion kroner for forest conservation annually.
Promote a proposal to reestablish the grant scheme for livestock farmers who have struggled with predator damage for an extended period.
Propose a scheme where the state covers half of the salary for new climate and environmental advisors hired by municipalities in 2023.
Review the management of state properties suitable for cabins and holiday resorts, and facilitate the accessibility of more of these locations to the public.
Not approving new plans for the development and operation of new petroleum fields on the Norwegian continental shelf.
Discontinue the work on geological mapping of petroleum resources on the shelf.
Present an updated version of the "Climate Plan for 2021–2030" by the end of 2023 that outlines how Norway will meet its national and international commitments towards 2030 and 2050.
Allocate 1.0 million kroner to the Norwegian Nature Heritage's work within the framework of chapter 1400 item 70.
Allocate 0.7 million kroner to the National Center for Sustainable Transition within the framework of chapter 1400 item 70.
Allocate 0.8 million kroner to the National Center for Sustainable Transition within the framework of chapter 1400 item 70.
Ensure Norwegian parks receive increased support in the state budget for 2023.
Introduce a time-limited support for energy efficiency measures in existing commercial buildings through Enova.
Promote proposals for securing project funds for the Urnes World Heritage Center.
Ensure that the scheme for selected cultural landscapes is expanded to at least 100 selected cultural landscapes by 2025.
Keep the Storting informed about the progress of the work on natural accounts as announced in the Hurdal platform, and report on this no later than in the revised national budget for 2023.

Take the initiative to create a Nature Plan 2030 report modeled after the Climate Plan 2030. The report should include five proposals for cost-calculated measures, instruments, and mechanisms that demonstrate how Norway can achieve land neutrality by 2030.
Restore at least 15% of degraded peatlands and wetlands by 2030.
Maintain December 31, 2025, as the deadline for the use of peat in garden soil, and prohibit the opening of new peat extraction sites as soon as possible.
Ensure that the carbon capture project at Norcem's cement factory in Porsgrunn is realized.
Promote a proposal that all Norwegian municipalities should have a climate and environmental advisor.
Propose that the state should cover 25% of the municipalities' costs for reducing their emissions.

Present a proposal for a binding escalation plan for Norway's international climate financing that ensures Norway covers a fair share of the costs for emission reductions, climate adaptation, and loss and damage in developing countries as a result of climate change.
Take the initiative for a new global financing scheme to fund measures aimed at protecting and restoring marine life.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal for a scheme with difference contracts for hydrogen, no later than the revised budget for 2023.
Introduce requirements for the investigation of local CO2 capture and storage for new oil and gas projects on the Norwegian continental shelf.
Set climate requirements for companies receiving CO2 compensation.

Ensure that the funds Enova makes available for energy measures in households and for consumers are at least 480 million kroner, in addition to the 200 million kroner transferred to the Norwegian State Housing Bank.
Inform the Storting about how it will follow up on the decisions made in connection with the consideration of Innst. 25 S (2022–2023), no later than the end of January 2023.
Complete the investigation of measures for the commercialization of DAC and inform the Storting no later than in the proposal for the state budget for 2024.
Investigate local CO2 capture and storage from offshore gas power plants that aim to primarily produce power for new or existing oil and gas projects.
Utilize the IPCEI PV collaboration to secure a strong Norwegian position in the European value chain for the solar cell industry.
Ensure that authorities still have the opportunity to demand access to source codes in ongoing negotiations regarding free trade agreements.
Establish a separate algorithm oversight under the Data Protection Authority.
Promote proposals to introduce stricter requirements for privacy and principles for data protection in connection with public procurement of digital tools and services.
Investigate with a view to introducing a ban on advertising based on mass surveillance, tracking, and profiling of individuals.
Impose stricter requirements for standardization, conciseness, and plain language in privacy policies on social media platforms operating in Norway.
Promote a proposal to introduce a right to use digital services without having to agree to the collected data being shared across platforms owned by the same company.
Promote proposals to introduce stricter privacy requirements in connection with public procurement involving social media platforms.
Advocate for public advertising funds not to be used for marketing solutions that misuse personal data.
Promote a proposal to introduce a ban on large technology companies favoring their own products and services over those of other companies through their social media platforms.

Assess the scope of action Norway has to regulate digital services beyond the regulations in the Digital Services Act and Digital Markets Act, considering the consequences of a Norwegian ban on advertising based on mass collection of personal data, tracking, and profiling of individuals on digital platforms. The assessment should include both the collection, use, and potential sale/disclosure of personal data.
Investigate the extent of and challenges surrounding the storage of biometric data from Norwegian consumers on social media platforms.
Postpone the entry into force of the law on compensation from the state to victims of violence (the Violence Compensation Act) until January 1, 2024.

To return to the Parliament with a scaling-up plan for targeted assistance for the inclusion of persons with disabilities to a minimum of 1 percent of aid funds by 2025, as well as a strengthening of inclusion in all Norwegian aid, including humanitarian assistance.
To return to the Storting with a concrete implementation plan with annual targets for the strategy "Equality for All."
Report annually in the budget proposal on what proportion of the total research allocation goes to European policy research, and which projects receive research funding.
Consider injecting capital into NAMMO AS on market terms.
Introduce a one-year duty-free period for goods from Ukraine, and within the current quotas for agricultural products.
Promote a proposal to abolish the increased resource rent tax on power by the end of 2024 at the latest.
Investigate and propose to the Parliament a resource rent tax for offshore wind.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a temporary results-based tax for power producers. The tax should be set at a level that generates revenue equivalent to the proposed high-price contribution as well as a five percentage point increase in the resource rent tax, with quarterly payments and without the right to deduct investment costs.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a resource rent tax for wind power, where it is designed as a real cash flow tax.
Return to the Storting with proposals for changes to the resource rent tax for wind power, suggesting a transitional arrangement for already existing power plants.
Limit the exemption from value-added tax for electronic news services to apply to news services that are specifically aimed at Norwegian conditions or a Norwegian audience.

Develop a plan for the gradual increase of the financial tax on profits with the aim of reducing the tax expenditure due to the VAT exemption for financial services, and return to the Parliament with a proposal for the first increase in the state budget for 2024.
Remove the sailing requirement related to the shipping tax scheme.
Ensure to extend the duration of the temporary oil tax package by 3 months, from December 31, 2022, to March 31, 2023.

Assuming that the new resource rent tax for land-based wind power can take effect no earlier than the time the final proposals are presented to the Storting, or that transitional arrangements are made to provide sufficient predictability.
Ensure that the revenues from power production are calculated over the year instead of per month when determining the high-price contribution.
Assess whether the high-price contribution has negative consequences for power production, and suggest necessary adjustments if needed.
Clarify that the principle of market price in the calculation of tax on aquaculture shall not apply from January 1, 2023.

Assuming that new taxes for the aquaculture industry can take effect no earlier than the time the final proposals are presented to the Storting, or that transitional arrangements are made to provide sufficient predictability.
Ensure that the high price contribution (tax on electricity production) is abolished as quickly as possible and no later than by the end of 2024.
Introduce duty-free status for goods from Ukraine.
Allocate funds set aside for the regional research funds in accordance with previous practices among all counties.
Ensure the continuation of the program for maritime competence.
Mapping the extent to which students are in study-relevant work six months after completing their studies.

Follow up on minimum requirements for learning materials for students with disabilities to ensure universal design and a clearer regulatory framework with greater distribution of responsibilities than what exists today.
Support the excellent work of Teknisk Senter AS in Flekkefjord, as an outstanding example of how children and youth can be helped to better master, among other things, science and technical subjects.

Ensure that the maximum amount that private kindergartens can apply to each municipality for reimbursement of their actual pension expenses beyond the pension subsidy is calculated based on the respective municipality's actual pension expenses for their municipal kindergartens, including the portion of pension expenses that may be paid out through premium funds.

Ensure the continued operation of the French School in Oslo (Lycée Français d'Oslo) and the Norwegian Section at Lycée International St. Germain en Laye, until a solution is found that can guarantee predictable ongoing operation of the schools.

Ensure that the operations of Kongshaug Music High School, Oslo City Steiner School, and Kristen VGS Vennesla can continue unchanged until a new, fairer funding rate for these students is implemented.
Ensure that no inpatient psychiatric beds are closed in 2023.
Ensure that the investment plans at Oslo University Hospital do not result in the postponement or cancellation of other necessary investment projects in the health region.
Abolish the system of neutral value-added tax in healthcare enterprises and propose this in connection with the state budget for 2024.

Ensure that all health enterprises have arrangements with their own pool of temporary staff/recruitment units with permanently employed substitutes, aimed at meeting the staffing needs of the health enterprise.
Expand the "Men in Health" program to include people of all genders.
Expand the Men in Health program or a similar initiative to include the recruitment of individuals who are not unemployed but are working as unskilled laborers in the healthcare sector.
Return to the Storting with a proposal to implement state-funded elderly care.
Ensure to clarify the division of responsibilities for the mentally ill between the police and the healthcare system.
Make a regulatory change that allows for tobacco-free snus.
Accelerate the process of simplifying the rules for marketing vaccination, so that as many people as possible can access information about vaccination.
Propose a system that allows for the sale of more over-the-counter medications in stores.
Investigate a fund for large hospital investments.
Reintroduce the VAT exemption for acupuncture treatment temporarily from January 1, 2023, pending the government's response to request resolutions no. 328 (2020–2021) and no. 417 (2021–2022).

Allocate the grant of 25 million kroner for the recruitment of healthcare personnel in Nordmøre and Romsdal to the maternity department in Kristiansund and ensure that the maternity department is permanently reopened.
Initiate the planning of a fully equipped maternity ward in Alta municipality during 2023.
Initiate the planning of a geriatric ward in Alta municipality during 2023.
Consider solutions to stop patient overload during patient travel.
Present a case for the initiation and implementation of a nutrition reform in elderly care.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal on how to reduce the number of patients who are waiting in hospitals.
Initiate the project for the modernization of Ålesund Hospital as soon as possible.
Reintroduce the "Golden Rule" that ensures that mental health care and addiction treatment each grow at a greater rate than somatic care in hospitals.
Ensure continued earmarking of funds for Lukas Hospice.
Remove the age limit for companion certificates.
Enter into contracts with Norwegian pharmaceutical manufacturers instead of foreign ones to ensure Norwegian emergency production.
Ensure that there are no cuts to inpatient beds in psychiatry at Oslo University Hospital.
Establish the positions of national chief nurse and national chief midwife.
Ensure that the hospital in Kirkenes is defined as intensive activity level 2 also in 2023.
Ensure that the activity-based funding in hospitals is maintained at 50% to ensure efficiency and the shortest possible waiting times for patients.

Ensure that businesses providing specialist health services through agreements with the regional health authorities are compensated for the increased employer's contribution on income over 750,000 kroner, in the same way as the public health enterprises.
Investigate whether clinical pharmacists in pharmacies should be tasked with conducting regular medication reviews for patients, in close collaboration with the patients' general practitioners.

Consider the need for a habilitation and rehabilitation reform that contributes to improving the services in, and the collaboration between, primary healthcare and specialist healthcare. The Parliament requests the government to return with a suitable proposal.
Present a comprehensive overview of the consequences that the postponement of investment projects has for specialist health services.

Ensure that up to 20 million kroner granted for 2022 is transferred to 2023 for the purpose of completing ongoing activities related to the finalization, quality assurance, and anchoring of the governance document for the Joint Municipal Journal (FKJ) in the municipal sector.
Ensure that the work on creating national guidelines for the investigation, treatment, and follow-up of endometriosis and adenomyosis is prioritized in 2023.

Create a comprehensive plan to reclaim privatized services in-house within the public sector, as well as to mandate state enterprises to reduce the use of private providers in areas that the enterprises can perform with their own employees.
Investigate how all municipalities and county municipalities in the country will be connected to eInnsyn, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Prepare criteria and present a plan for full funding of the free ferry scheme.
Reintroduce grants for elevators and condition assessments from 2024.

Maintain the structure of subsidies for rental housing and trials with new housing models that were in effect until 2022, so that those in difficult housing situations do not compete with district-targeted housing initiatives.
Initiate a consequence assessment with the aim of including users over 67 years old in the scheme for resource-demanding services.
Come back to the Parliament with a calculation of what it will cost to fully finance the child welfare reform, both in terms of measures in child welfare services and preventive measures.

Map the municipalities' needs for planning and environmental expertise with the aim of establishing a system to enhance this expertise in the municipalities, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Provide an account to the Storting on how the government envisions realizing the joint building at Dokken in Bergen for the Institute of Marine Research and the Directorate of Fisheries.
Consider incorporating boat routes to island communities without detour roads into the free ferry scheme.
Assess the situation for small shops in light of the electricity price situation and consider strengthening and expanding the Merkur scheme in connection with the revised national budget for 2023.
Consider whether kiosks and gas stations should also be included in the Merkur program, and report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner.
Consider providing electricity support to cultural historical properties and return to the Storting in an appropriate manner.
Accelerate the presentation of the announced parliamentary report on a comprehensive housing policy to no later than summer 2023.
Conduct a review to present proposals for changes to the funding model for the police, as a replacement for the current distribution model.
To prepare a proposal for negotiation rights for the Norwegian Bar Association for the establishment of fee rates and piecework pricing arrangements.
Draft a proposal for a legislative amendment that grants both parties in a child custody case free legal aid if one party receives free legal aid, with a maximum income limit of NOK 1,500,000 gross.
Conduct a review of the police education program, focusing on increasing the practical elements in the training.
Introduce fast-track procedures for the incarceration of youth and gang criminals.
Investigate how to develop more respite services for single parents based on the model from Rødhette and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Consider whether stricter requirements should be imposed on the information that electricity companies provide to consumers about various agreements, so that consumers can better assess the risks and consequences associated with the agreements. The government is also asked to consider whether there is a need for stricter regulations, or possibly a ban, on the sale of variable electricity agreements. The government is requested to return to the Storting in an appropriate manner no later than the end of January 2023.
Suggest a letter of commitment for the project The Whale in Andenes, starting in 2024.
Implement a revenue-neutral reform of child benefits, within the proposed framework, where child benefits are increased and taxed.
Present a case for restructuring the incentive scheme for attracting foreign film productions to Norway into a rule-based system.

Ensure that volunteer organizations with a license to sell scratch cards can do so digitally, on par with Norsk Tipping. The Parliament also asks the government to ensure that clubs and associations can operate bingo activities.
Reintroduce the gift matching scheme.
Ensure local radio stations predictability for their distribution and any potential public support.
Present a case for actively reducing the backlog in the financing of sports facilities through gaming funds and that the VAT compensation scheme in chapter 315 item 82 is enshrined in rights.

Come back to the Parliament in connection with the revised national budget for 2023 with a proposal to change the VAT compensation scheme for sports, volunteer work, and culture so that it becomes rule-based instead of being granted as a block grant.
Investigate a legal requirement for subtitling all films shown in cinemas.

Establish a scheme for established performing arts companies, no later than in connection with the state budget for 2024, and that this is seen in conjunction with the establishment of regional cultural funds.
To come back with an assessment of making the Arctic Philharmonic a national orchestra on par with the Oslo Philharmonic and the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra.
Come back with an assessment of the project The Whale and possible government contributions to the project in connection with the revised national budget for 2023.
Explain to the Storting how the 1,000-year anniversary of Christian law will be commemorated.

Investigate the possibilities, within the framework of the monopoly model and EEA law, for raising the revenue cap on lotteries, merging licenses, and removing the expiration date on lottery licenses.
Implement the necessary changes to the regulations for private lotteries to facilitate digital solutions for payment and distribution as soon as practically possible.
Ensure that a larger share of Norsk Tipping's revenue goes to the purpose recipients by reducing administrative operating costs for advertising, consultants, and profiling.

Implement trials for the municipalization of work assessment allowance (AAP). Where a portion of the state welfare budget is transferred to selected municipalities that take on the responsibility of financing part of the welfare benefits together with the state, and are allowed to keep the savings if they succeed in helping vulnerable groups enter the labor market.

Investigate the legal establishment of leave rights for employees who wish to take leave from work to start their own business, including examining the possibility of gradating the leave and considering whether it is feasible to establish specific arrangements to compensate for the loss of income during the period of starting their own business.
Investigate what barriers exist in the Working Environment Act to facilitate a location-flexible working life and remote work outside of Norway.
That a separate unit is established to handle whistleblowers at the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority in order to strengthen the work that the authority currently does to assist whistleblowers.
Clarify and strengthen NAV's obligation to follow up on individuals who are unable to meet deadlines in order to identify their need for assistance and support.

To expand the discretionary margins for the assessment of social assistance, in order to avoid further pressure on individuals who are currently facing a difficult economic situation due to the extraordinary circumstances we are in, and to ensure that NAV has the necessary leeway to provide the required support.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to halve the reduction of pensions in the State Pension Fund, effective from July 1, 2023.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to halve the reduction of disability pensions, effective from July 1, 2023.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to halve the reduction of the old-age pension effective from July 1, 2023.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to halve the reduction of survivor's pension effective from July 1, 2023.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to increase the minimum pension by 7,500 kroner for minimum pensioners, effective from July 1, 2023.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to increase the number of VTA positions by 400, of which 200 positions in sheltered employment and 200 positions in regular employment.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to initiate the establishment of the Nav Ombudsman.

Ensure the payment of a one-time amount of 3,000 Norwegian kroner as soon as possible for all who receive a minimum rate of disability benefits in January 2023. The payment should not be taxable, pensionable, reportable, or subject to deductions.
Present a parliamentary report on how private ownership in Norway can be strengthened during 2023.

Continue the maximum limit for eligible consumption in the temporary electricity support scheme for primary producers in agriculture at 60,000 kWh per month per enterprise until the end of the second quarter of 2023.

Return to the Parliament as quickly as possible with an assessment of possible expanded electricity support measures to assist industries that are critical for the Norwegian and European renewable transition and energy and raw material independence, and that fall within the framework of such measures implemented in other EU/EEA countries.

Present a case as quickly as possible in the new year with proposals for more flexible models for fixed-price electricity contracts for businesses, taking into account that many companies have significant variations in electricity consumption throughout the day and the year.
Present a case as quickly as possible in the new year regarding a municipal support scheme for small businesses with high electricity costs, as a supplement to the fixed price agreement scheme.

Promote a proposal to structure the resource rent tax on aquaculture in a way that rewards emission-free facilities, for example by imposing a low resource rent tax on emission-free facilities that benefits the municipalities, while conventional facilities are subject to a high resource rent tax that goes to the state.
Investigate and propose a resource rent tax on fisheries, with a basic deduction that ensures the coastal fleet falls below the taxable threshold.
Transfer the responsibility for the management of harvestable wildlife resources to the Ministry of Climate and Environment.
Promote proposals to give municipal and inter-municipal actors the opportunity to apply for schemes managed by Innovation Norway.
Promote proposals to allow non-profit organizations to apply for programs managed by Innovation Norway.

Clarify with ESA, and propose to the Parliament, electricity support measures to assist energy-intensive industries that are critical for the European renewable transition and European energy and raw material independence, through, for example, a technology-based electricity support or short-term fixed-price agreements.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a compensation scheme for fur farms and feed suppliers affected by the ban on fur farming, based on the valuation of machinery and equipment, so that the values are fully covered, in connection with the consideration of the revised national budget 2023.
Make the Norwegian solar cell industry a particular focus area in the Green Industrial Initiative.
Make the Norwegian solar cell industry a particular focus area in the initiative "Whole Norway Exports."

To ensure that the financial framework for Norecopa is maintained at least at the same level as in 2022, and that within the framework of the government's proposed budget, it is assumed that sufficient funds are still secured for a full position for the Norecopa secretariat in addition to operating funds of 500,000 kroner.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for the arrangement of emergency storage of food grains and estimated costs as soon as this is completed, and no later than in connection with the presentation of the revised national budget in the spring of 2023.

Present a concrete plan for the introduction of difference contracts to increase production and use of alternative fuels in the maritime sector, no later than the revised national budget for 2023, with the goal of establishment by the end of 2023.
Conduct an analysis of the consequences of a temporarily increased employer's contribution and report back to the Parliament with the analysis in an appropriate manner.

Prioritize the development of specific export strategies for new industries where Norway is advanced, including the health industry, agritech, and creative industries, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Consolidate the responsibility for drowning prevention work in one department.

The grant for Young Entrepreneurship shall be earmarked for efforts to increase the number of students and pupils throughout the entire education system who receive practical and reality-based teaching with a focus on innovative solutions and entrepreneurship methods.
Map the margins across the entire value chain for groceries through a comprehensive margin study and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Adopt a vision that there should be no accidents resulting in fatalities or lifelong injuries due to drowning (a zero vision).
Develop a national action plan to reduce and prevent drowning accidents, based on the zero vision principle.
Facilitate a public drowning statistics initiative that enables the collection and coordination of statistics on drowning accidents.
Present a parliamentary report on industry.
Present a separate case to the Storting regarding border trade, where measures are discussed and proposed to reduce border trade and ensure the competitiveness of Norwegian businesses.
Present a parliamentary report on small and medium-sized enterprises.

Ensure that the quota basis for the coastal fishing scheme is increased from the current 0.9% of the total quota for cod to 1.5% of the total quota starting from 2024, and that the quota basis for the trawler fleet is simultaneously reduced accordingly.
Review the tax, fee, and support system for the action zone and assess enhanced economic incentives for increased settlement and business activity in Finnmark.

Engage in dialogue with the Finnmarksløpet to explore financial measures that can help better utilize the economic potential associated with and around the Finnmarksløpet, and how the Finnmarksløpet can contribute more significantly to promoting Finnmark as a travel destination.

Change the direction of the differentiated employer's contribution so that it works as intended, and so that a lower employer rate cannot be used where the main business is located and the employee has their permanent residence.
Stimulate the development of the aquaculture industry in Finnmark.
Follow up on relevant recommendations from the Tveiterås Committee for increased value creation from fish processing.
Investigate possible areas for the development of offshore wind in Finnmark.
Investigate rapid rearmament and improvements of ports in Finnmark.
Evaluate the support measures for East Finnmark adopted during the consideration of Prop. 78 S (2021–2022), and inform the Storting in an appropriate manner, no later than spring 2023.
Develop a strategy for feed ingredients, with the aim of making the aquaculture industry more sustainable and independent of imports.
Strengthen efforts to develop and promote Finnmark as a travel destination.
Consider relocating and locating suitable government jobs to Finnmark.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan to phase out the maximum caps in the subsidy scheme for the employment of seafarers.
Promote a proposal to enshrine the substance of the current subsidy scheme for the employment of seafarers in law to ensure the necessary predictability, as the Holmefjord Committee assumes.
Take the initiative with the parties to continue the work initiated by the Holmefjord Committee to simplify and find necessary adjustments in the grant scheme for the employment of seafarers.

Return to the Parliament with a plan to phase out the maximum caps in the subsidy scheme for the employment of seafarers, as soon as the law on Norwegian wage and working conditions on ships in Norwegian waters and on the Norwegian continental shelf is completed.

Ensure rapid progress on the supplementary agreement to the urban development agreement in the Bergen area and that all necessary decisions are made by the end of 2023. It is assumed that the state funding contribution to the Light Rail to Åsane constitutes a minimum of 70% of the total cost, cf. the commitment in the Hurdal platform.
Abolish the uniquely Norwegian standard for the development of two/three-lane roads and establish the development of a narrow four-lane road as the new standard.
Designate funds allocated for county roads under chapter 1320 for road purposes.
Further develop the grant scheme for the five smaller urban areas, with the aim of ensuring more predictability than what one-time payments provide.

Ensure that the state regulatory plan for the Joint Project Ringeriksbanen and the new E16 (FRE16) must serve as the basis for further work and development, regardless of the developer, to avoid further delays.
Ensure that the Joint Project Ringeriksbanen and the new E16 (FRE16) is carried out in accordance with the approved plans under the auspices of Nye Veier AS.

Promote a proposal for the establishment of a solidarity fund for: assistance and reconstruction of Ukraine, to support European renewable energy initiatives, including a fund to reduce the consumption of natural gas and other fossil energy sources and the accompanying dependence on Russia, as well as aid to developing countries that are severely affected by rising food and energy prices as a result of the war.
Promote a proposal for an additional solidarity tax on the revenue from oil and gas from the Norwegian continental shelf.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for necessary amendments to the law on the Government Pension Fund to enable the transfer of extraordinarily high revenues from oil and gas to a solidarity fund for assistance, reconstruction, and to counteract the food and energy crisis resulting from Russia's invasion and destruction of Ukraine.

Conduct a review of the fiscal rule and propose a new anchor for economic policy based on the following premises: 1. The state budget shall undergo the following changes: - A distinction will be established between operating expenses and investments in the state budget. - Socio-economically profitable investments in infrastructure, central buildings, and other significant real capital such as defense materials will be activated as "asset reallocation." - The fiscal rule may still include operating expenses and investments that do not meet profitability requirements, but their use must be accounted for in the state budget. - A system for maintaining completed investments and addressing the significant maintenance backlog in infrastructure will be introduced. 2. The Oil Fund shall not be used for climate policy speculation but shall continue to aim for the highest possible return. 3. The oil wealth should benefit current generations to a greater extent through lower taxes and fees, as well as prioritizing the core tasks of the welfare state. 4. The use of oil wealth for symbolic climate measures, immigration and integration, as well as aid, shall be reduced. 5. The criteria for calculating socio-economic benefits will be reviewed. The project's ability to solve capacity problems in the short and long term will be given significant weight, and the discount rates used will be reassessed. 6. The oil and gas industry shall be further developed and provided with framework conditions that encourage more actors to engage in exploration based on the premises of the current petroleum tax regime.

Investigate the establishment of separate transition institutions or departments between youth units and adult prisons for young inmates aged 18 to 24, which ensures a more comprehensive and interdisciplinary follow-up and treatment pathway.
Implement measures to comply with the recommendation from the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child to end the detention of children.
Investigate the entire range of penal responses for minors and young inmates up to 24 years old, particularly focusing on the experiences of children and young people with the various responses.
Gather more knowledge about the effects and impacts of alternative sanctions to imprisonment for children.
Implement measures to ensure that detention in youth units only occurs in extraordinary cases and as a last resort.

Investigate how the rehabilitation purpose and the rights of young inmates can best be fulfilled in accordance with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, Articles 37 and 40, as well as the Norwegian Penal Execution Act § 2.
Take a closer look at today's practices regarding forensic psychiatric assessments in serious criminal cases involving children.

Investigate the conciliation board system with a view to strengthening and improving it. The investigation should specifically consider: whether the current system safeguards the legal rights of citizens, any need for formal legal competence among one or more members of the conciliation board, the competence needs of conciliation board members, including mediation skills and legal expertise, how the long processing times can be reduced, whether Section 6-11, fourth paragraph of the Dispute Act should be amended, whether there should be a requirement to maintain annual statistics on the decisions of the conciliation board to facilitate easier oversight, whether the current organization of the conciliation board should be changed, whether a conciliation board with potentially enhanced legal competence should be allowed to handle more types of cases than it does today, whether the rulings of the conciliation board uphold the rights under the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), any need for a system that ensures parties are notified that they are involved in a case before the conciliation board, whether there is a need for annual statistical reporting, and whether the right to access information about the activities of the conciliation boards should be strengthened to ensure better oversight.
Conduct an evaluation of the entire co-payment system with the aim of examining how the system affects different patient groups, so that the arrangement does not exacerbate social health disparities.
Promote proposals that ensure children's exemption from co-payments in healthcare services is extended to include the age group 16 to 18 years.
Come back with an assessment of extended exemptions from user fees in the healthcare service for the age group 16-18 years in the state budget for 2024.
Present a proposal to the Storting to introduce a third legal gender category when the initiated investigation into a third legal gender is available.

Review the treatment options for individuals with gender incongruence, ensuring that it also accommodates individuals with non-binary gender identities, with the aim of strengthening the services and rights of each individual, decentralizing the offerings, and reporting back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Ensure that the national professional guidelines for gender incongruence from 2020 are followed up in all health regions, with the aim of strengthening and decentralizing healthcare services for all individuals with gender incongruence and providing the same basic services throughout the country.

Ensure that general practitioners and general practitioner offices have access to sufficient continuing education and competence in gender incongruence, so that they can provide healthcare in accordance with the principle of the lowest effective level of care.

Promote a proposal to reduce the value-added tax rate to zero on the reuse and repair of consumer electronics, sports and outdoor equipment, white and brown goods, furniture, clothing and shoes, as well as on parts needed for repairs.
Introduce a requirement for a maximum amount of waste generated per square meter at construction sites.
To develop circular economy incentives, including developing ENOVA's mandate to involve circular economy measures, and to report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Introduce a recycling target for critical raw materials, supported by a landfill ban for critical raw materials and measures to develop and implement new recycling technology.
Amend the procurement regulations to specify that environmental considerations should be weighted at least 30% in public tenders where relevant.
Implement changes to the regulations regarding the document fee with the aim of enhancing the economic value of preserving rather than demolishing existing buildings.
Ensure that public project owners have a strategy for reusing building components in their rehabilitation and new construction projects.
To develop a comprehensive plan with clear objectives and associated measures for significantly increased reuse and rehabilitation of buildings instead of demolition and new construction.
Expand Chapter 2b of the product regulation to include more unnecessary plastic products with a high risk of littering.

Introduce an extended producer responsibility scheme for plastic equipment used in fisheries, aquaculture, and agriculture, including financial responsibility for cleanup efforts, and set targets for material recycling.

Introduce an extended producer responsibility scheme for agricultural plastics and set a target for material recycling. The scheme should also require industry actors to finance the cleanup of plastic products that have strayed from their own operations.
Present an action plan through a parliamentary report that outlines how Norway will reduce food waste by 30% by 2025 and 59% by 2030.

Ensure that a research program for circular critical minerals is established under the green platform, which maps the value chain and the opportunities for circular economy to meet the demand for critical minerals for the green transition, and supports research on innovative circular mineral solutions.
Establish as a principle for state enterprises and actors that buildings should not be demolished to construct new ones when rehabilitation is possible.

Investigate and propose the introduction of a tax on virgin materials, in order to make it more profitable for buyers in companies to demand products with a high content of recycled raw materials in procurement processes.

Investigate how the waste regulations can be used as a tool to reduce the material footprint and decrease the use of virgin raw materials, through active stimulation of technology development and more targeted recycling.

Introduce a requirement that at least 75% of non-hazardous construction and demolition waste must be sorted at source, and begin the implementation of requirements for material recycling. The government is requested to consider what the material recycling requirement should be, and to report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner, no later than the revised national budget for 2023.
Regulate the producer responsibility for all single-use plastic products.

To follow several countries in implementing landfill taxes for residual materials from the mineral industry and a ban on sea disposal of mineral waste and other environmentally harmful disposal methods that also hinder the utilization of materials.
Present a parliamentary report by the end of 2024 with answers on how we will achieve the goal of reducing Norway's footprint to levels within the planet's tolerance limits.
Amend the investigation instruction and the accompanying guidelines to include requirements for assessing the environmental and climate footprint in all government initiatives and investigations.
Investigate a ban on the disposal of rare earth elements and minerals.
Present proposals on how the tax and fee system can contribute to a comprehensive circular economy transition of society and the reduction of our footprint.
Give Enova the responsibility for establishing a national network of filling stations with liquid biogas by 2026.
Set a goal of 10 TWh of biogas production by 2035, and create a plan to achieve this goal.
Map the need for, and access to, minerals and rare earth elements in Norway and introduce requirements for the recycling industry to recycle rare earth elements and minerals.
Notify the Parliament when a reporting obligation for the extraction of mineral materials in construction and civil engineering projects may be introduced.
Return to the Parliament with measures to ensure that public project owners have a strategy for reused building components in their rehabilitation and new construction projects.
Take the initiative to establish environmental agreements with relevant industry stakeholders to reduce single-use plastic products such as drinking cups and food containers.

Ensure that the waste definitions in the Pollution Control Act are harmonized with EU regulations, so that the definitions do not differentiate between household waste and commercial waste that fall under the same category.
Come back to the Parliament with measures to ensure that more public procurers require the inclusion of recycled resources in the products they procure.
Enforce the landfill ban more strictly, including reviewing and removing exceptions to the landfill ban for fractions where there are available industrial recycling solutions.

Start the implementation of requirements for material recycling of non-hazardous construction and demolition waste. The government is requested to consider how high the requirement for material recycling should be set and to report back to the Parliament no later than in the revised budget for 2023.
Phase in requirements for reduced greenhouse gas emissions from material use in commercial and residential buildings starting in 2024.

Phase in requirements for the proportion of reused, recycled, and renewable materials in new construction and renovation starting in 2025. The government is requested to assess the extent and areas for this phasing in and to return to the Storting in an appropriate manner, no later than the revised national budget for 2023.
Consider introducing energy requirements for rehabilitation to encourage increased use of the existing building stock.
Develop national targets and progress plans for circularity for the entire economy.
Consider a restructuring of the base fee for beverage packaging to a material fee and phase in requirements for the use of recycled material in all beverage packaging.
To gather updated knowledge about the competence needs associated with new, circular business models, and to establish more tripartite industry programs.
Mapping how the support system can be organized to better support parts of or entire value chains that contribute to a transition to a more circular economy.
Facilitate the establishment of material banks for the reuse of building materials, in collaboration with industry stakeholders and other Nordic countries.
Streamline and digitize the reporting of waste quantities from the construction and civil engineering industry.
Review relevant regulations and develop a cross-sectoral strategy for mass handling in collaboration with the construction industry.
Facilitate the establishment of a digital marketplace for surplus materials, based on the model of Bærum Resource Bank.

Send out for consultation a proposal for changes to the building technical regulations and the building application regulations that require greenhouse gas accounting for buildings, effective no later than January 1, 2024. The accounting must cover the entire life cycle of the construction process (including work on the construction site, assembly, and execution) and apply to the entire building.

Send out for consultation a proposal for changes to the building technical regulations and the building application regulations that set maximum requirements for greenhouse gas emissions for all new buildings, effective no later than January 1, 2024, with gradually stricter requirements leading up to 2030.

Send out for consultation a proposal for changes to the building technical regulations and the building application regulations that increase the requirement for waste sorting on construction sites from 70% to at least 80% starting January 1, 2024, and notify about a gradual further increase in the percentage requirement in the years to come.

Investigate possible requirements for counties and municipalities that area plans and development plans at various levels include a goal for emission reduction through less development and more reuse, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Investigate measures that strengthen the incentives for reusing materials and aggregates in construction projects, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Gather experiences from municipalities that have succeeded in reusing materials and resources, as well as explore the possibility of strengthening this work throughout the country.
Promote legislation that requires contactless card payment ("tapping") to be offered directly at all publicly available fast and rapid chargers.
Require the retrofitting of contactless card payment on existing charging infrastructure by the end of 2025.

Ensure that county road 760 via Snåsa is improved in specific areas where needed, so that the road is equipped to handle the extra load imposed on it due to its use as a detour for E6 Langnesberga. The improvements must be prioritized within the financial framework of the Norwegian Public Roads Administration.
Ensure that the Norwegian Public Roads Administration prioritizes permanent avalanche protection measures at E6 Langnesberga (Snåsakroa).
Promote a proposal to abolish the system of environmental speed limits on national roads.
Prioritize ongoing road maintenance and winter operations, including washing the roads to reduce airborne dust.

Conduct a thorough evaluation of the pilot project with variable signage of environmental speed limits to assess whether this is a measure that can be used to ensure greater respect for signage, while also ensuring optimal driving conditions for motorists and the best possible air quality for residents.
Abolish the regulation on fees for the use of studded tires and additional fees, and propose to amend the Road Traffic Act § 13 so that a studded tire fee cannot be introduced.
Increase support for capacity-building projects aimed at improving Georgia's and Bosnia's ability to maintain security and their political independence.
Consider taking the initiative to suspend Russia from international organizations until they withdraw from Ukraine and end the war.
Take a leading political and financial role in the coordinated European effort for the reconstruction of Ukraine.

Acquire and donate advanced air defense systems, such as NASAMS, and anti-ship missiles, such as NSM missiles, to Ukraine, as well as engage in dialogue with NATO countries and Ukraine to identify additional weapon systems and necessary basic materials that Ukraine will need, and procure these, for example through the British "International Fund for Ukraine" and the "European Peace Facility."
Allocate more police resources to the Section for International Crimes in Kripos, which (among other things) investigates war crimes against Ukrainians who are now refugees in Norway.
Support Ukraine's neighboring countries in managing the social consequences of the war in Ukraine, such as the increased number of refugees.
Contribute to building medical rehabilitation centers in Ukraine with Norwegian expertise.
Take the initiative with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to stop demands for payment of Ukrainian state debt and further cancel and restructure the debt.

Take a leading role in the international efforts to identify, investigate, and prosecute war crimes in Ukraine, for example through increased funding to the International Criminal Court, the International Court of Justice, and the International Commission on Missing Persons, as well as to non-governmental organizations that contribute to the documentation of war crimes.

Promote proposals for changes to the Water Resources Act and the Water Regulation Act that improve the legitimate interests of local communities and landowners through the alteration and revision of old concessions.

There is a call for a new review of the entire Røldal–Suldal power plant and the watercourse from the high mountains to Suldalsvatnet, with the aim of reconstructing and upgrading the facility to utilize the water in a more sustainable manner, with much better consideration for nature and the environment in accordance with the requirements of the host municipalities Ullensvang and Suldal.
Complaining that the maneuvering regulations for the Røldal–Suldal power plant are updated in accordance with the input from the municipal councils in Ullensvang and Suldal.

It should be assumed that the new terms for the host municipalities for the Røldal–Suldal power plant will be based on the premises and promises made through the decision on reversion after 60 years, as the Parliament did in 1962.

Complaining about the coordination of the audit for the Røldal-Suldal power plant and the Ulla-Førre facilities. Especially with regard to whether there are synergies that allow for the restoration and rehabilitation of nature in Røldal and Valldalen.

Complaining that the strict environmental requirements that apply to new hydropower developments today are being used as a basis when the concession conditions for the Røldal–Suldal facility are revised.
Expand the scheme for the cancellation of student loans for teachers to also include preschool teachers and all others with an approved teaching degree.
Increase the efforts in the further education and training of teachers, so that more applications approved by the school owner can be granted.

Follow up on the recommendations in NOU 2022:13 related to the right to a guidance year for newly hired teachers and career paths for teachers in schools, and present the proposal to the Storting by the end of 2023.
Present a proposal for the certification of teachers, aiming to introduce protected titles for teaching positions.
Introduce a right to further education and training for teachers. This should be done without any personal contribution.

Investigate the expansion of the scheme for the cancellation of student loans for teachers to also include preschool teachers and other groups, and return to the Storting with a proposal in an appropriate manner.
Make the arrangements for public sector PhDs and industry PhDs better known in the municipalities' child welfare units.

Facilitate more varied practice in teacher education programs and ensure better support and guidance for new teachers at the beginning of their careers, and return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Present a strategy to strengthen the team around the teacher and the student so that the teacher has more time for their core tasks and the student receives closer support, including increasing the number of staff and enhancing collaboration between professional agencies, as well as bringing more professionals with health and social science expertise into the school.
Promote a proposal to introduce a national ban on the use of hijabs for children in kindergartens and primary schools.
Introduce a requirement for zero emissions for all cruise ships in Norwegian waters by 2026.
Introduce requirements for zero emissions for cruise-related bus operations by 2026.

Promote necessary proposals to give municipal councils the direct opportunity to regulate cruise traffic. These proposals should, at a minimum, include the ability to regulate the number of arrivals and the number of passengers both per day and per season, as well as the ability to regulate the minimum docking time and maximum size of the ships.

Promote necessary proposals to give municipal councils the direct opportunity to set environmental and climate requirements for cruise traffic. These proposals should, at a minimum, include the possibility to require connection to shore power as well as the possibility to demand low or zero-emission ships.
Return to the Storting with measures to limit cabotage driving for foreign tour buses in Norway, based on the model from Denmark.
Implement a government venture capital reform aimed at closing the capital gap by strengthening the available capital access for early-stage companies.
To expand the option scheme so that more newly established growth companies can use options as a tool to recruit and retain talent.

Make it easier for small businesses and startups to recruit labor from countries outside the EEA area, including through simpler, more coordinated, and streamlined processing in the Directorate of Immigration, and initiate the development of a common Nordic strategy to attract international labor.

Ensure that Norway has a strategy to secure that Norwegian entrepreneurs and small businesses gain increased access to international capital to scale their solutions, including by ensuring that the public support system has sufficient resources and expertise to assist Norwegian small businesses and entrepreneurs in mobilization and application processes for EU investment programs aimed at entrepreneurship and new industries.

Facilitate the strengthening of first-line services for entrepreneurs, and ensure a clear objective to provide a seamless support system for entrepreneurs across different levels of government to the greatest extent possible.

Present a case to the Storting with an assessment of whether the requirements for personal guarantees and equity can be reduced in state financing schemes for companies in the startup and growth phases, based on the completed evaluation of Innovation Norway's startup instruments.

Investigate how to better facilitate opportunities for individuals with low income and/or unstable employment connections to start their own businesses, and how self-employment can be more widely used as a tool for labor inclusion.

Investigate the legal establishment of leave rights for employees who wish to take leave from work to start their own business, including examining the possibility of gradating the leave, and consider investigating whether specific arrangements can be established to compensate for the loss of income during the period of starting one's own business.
Conduct a comprehensive review of the rights and legislation related to freelancers in 2023 to ensure a safe and decent working environment.

Investigate the establishment of an entrepreneurial panel based on the Danish model. The panel should promote proposals and recommendations on how to make it easier and more attractive for entrepreneurs to start new businesses, and how more new businesses can grow larger.
Investigate the effect of expanding the scheme that provides tax deductions for investors who invest in start-up companies.

Facilitate easier access for small businesses and startups to contracts in the public sector, including through increased use of innovative procurement in the state, county municipalities, and municipalities, and to set targets for the share of public procurement.
Resume the work of simplifying existing regulations initiated by the simplification committee, with the aim of ensuring that businesses are not subjected to unnecessary burdens.

Obtain a better map and data basis to determine the correct number of kilometers of the standardized county road network and bicycle network along county roads in Oslo, and return to the Storting in an appropriate manner with proposals for a more accurate financing of this.
Transfer the responsibility for the section of rv. 4 that lies within Oslo municipality, and rv. 162 to Oslo municipality, including funds for the operation and maintenance of the roads.

That in the follow-up to the Long-Term Plan for Research and Higher Education 2023–2032, measures are implemented to use research and higher education to promote competitive industries throughout the country.
That in the follow-up to the Long-Term Plan for Research and Higher Education 2023–2032, measures are implemented to utilize research to facilitate increased value creation and more jobs.
To increase the focus on research that can contribute to the development and facilitation of petroleum activities in Norway.
To facilitate and invest in research on nuclear power.
Engage in dialogue with the other Nordic countries about a common admission system for universities and colleges in the Nordics.
Investigate a scheme for a researcher visa to provide more researchers the opportunity to work in Norway.
Review the regulations with the aim of making it easier for foreign students to remain in work in Norway after completing their studies.
Review the regulations with the aim of making it easier for foreign students who are pursuing a full degree in Norway to go on shorter exchange stays.
