To particularly prioritize professional subjects that are important for the personnel challenges in health and care services, especially within mental health and addiction, as well as advanced clinical nursing (AKS) and midwifery education.

Present a binding financial escalation plan for the funding of the long-term plan for research and higher education 2023–2032, with clear priorities in connection with the consideration of the revised national budget in the spring of 2023.
To continue the goal of developing research environments of outstanding quality in the Long-Term Plan for Research and Higher Education 2023–2032.

Consider requiring collaboration in industry-oriented research funded by the public sector where relevant, with the aim of strengthening the impact and dissemination of research for larger segments of the business community and society as a whole.
Come back to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2024 with a predictable and sufficient framework for Return-EU.

Follow up on Meld. St. 7 (2020–2021) A World of Opportunities – International Student Mobility in Higher Education, and return to the Parliament with concrete proposals for measures to increase internationalization of, and in, higher education and research.
Follow up on the work regarding academic freedom of expression in the development agreements with the public universities and colleges.
Continue and strengthen the SFU scheme to ensure access to high-quality education throughout the country.

Ensure that the Research Council of Norway is responsible for following up on the Climate Cure 2030 and other relevant adopted plans for emission reductions and transition, including by identifying areas where Norwegian research can contribute to reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

Change the targeted societal mission of sustainable feed to "Green Transition and Growth." The targeted societal mission must include renewable energy, digitalization, and sustainable animal feed for the blue and green sectors.
Present a plan for the further development of higher vocational education that discusses, among other things, financing, the credit system, capacity, and accreditation.

Follow up on the legislative change regarding the collection of information without consent in patient injury cases to ensure that it contributes to a simpler and more efficient case handling process. The Parliament requests the government to return to the matter in an appropriate manner.

Present a parliamentary report on the prevention of negative consequences resulting from parental ill health during the first 1,001 days of a child's life, from pregnancy until the child turns two years old, for the entire family.

Ensure that the specialist health service strengthens the follow-up for postpartum psychosis, including preemptive support for individuals who are particularly vulnerable, as well as follow-up afterwards that facilitates safe interactions with children.
Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner to ensure better communication and continuity in healthcare services for parents and children.

Investigate whether a letter c should be added to § 3 of the Division Act, which allows for one part of a municipal or county division to retain its status as a legal entity, while the other part becomes a new entity.
Ensure that Ålesund municipality is given the opportunity to retain its existing municipality number in the ongoing division from Haram.
Revise the regulations for the approval of higher education from third countries with the aim of better integration and increased staffing.
Introduce a fast-track scheme for highly skilled foreign labor from outside the EEA, inspired by the Danish model.

Consider changes that ensure the early work start scheme is made available and improved, including exploring the possibility of utilizing service centers for foreign workers more for faster processing of cases.
Facilitate the adoption of new technology for faster case processing in the immigration administration.
Follow up on recommendations for simplifications in the processing of cases for individuals applying for the renewal of work permits, and return to the Parliament if necessary.

Investigate what barriers exist in the Working Environment Act to facilitate a location-flexible working life, including reviewing the current Working Environment Act with the aim of enabling employees to work in shared spaces, compiling guidelines for work outside the workplace, and finding new opportunities for flexibility based on the individual needs and life situations of the staff.
Investigate how to facilitate remote work outside of Norway.
Promote necessary legislative proposals to ensure a location-neutral occupational injury legislation.
Implement state projects that aim to identify the obstacles to place neutrality in the public sector, both in terms of administrative procedures and competence.
Implement measures to ensure that neighborhoods, cities, and towns have good offerings for remote workers in their local communities.
Investigate what barriers exist in today's legislation to facilitate a flexible working life and location-independent workplaces.
Facilitate location-independent workplaces and develop solutions where state employees can work in local office communities with other state employees.
Clarify the coverage area for occupational injury compensation and ensure a clear regulatory framework for a location-neutral occupational injury insurance.

Come back to the Parliament, at an appropriate time, with a summary of the knowledge gathering and the development trends for home offices and location-independent workplaces in the labor market, as well as an assessment of the need for further measures in light of this.
Come back with a plan to increase the guideline rates for social assistance by 12,000 kroner during 2023.

Investigate a tax-free allowance in social assistance that ensures that benefits for social assistance recipients are not reduced if they take on small jobs or receive moderate gifts and contributions from others.

Develop rules that ensure that no extraordinary social contributions approved by the Storting are deducted from the municipal social assistance, such as one-time payments during holidays, as well as extraordinary housing and electricity support. The Storting also requests that the government develop rules to ensure that extraordinary social contributions approved by the Storting for cohabiting partners are not deducted from the municipal social assistance.
Conduct a mapping of how the new guidelines for social assistance are used by the local Nav offices, to ensure that the goals in the guidelines are being followed up.
Update the social support guidelines to clarify that expenses for internet and phone, as well as moderate transportation costs and more, should be included in the social benefits.
Reintroduce the simplified guide for the receipt of social assistance, which was used during the COVID-19 pandemic, until July 1, 2023.
Look at the need for a simplified guide for the receipt of social assistance, and whether it should be extended or terminated.
Promote a proposal to legislate the access to disregard transactions that involve evasion of the Working Environment Act, in accordance with the recommendations of the Fougner Committee.
Review the changes in the Working Environment Act and investigate whether they are functioning effectively and as intended, two years after they come into force.
Give the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority the authority to issue orders in cases concerning misclassification of employees.

Ensure that the legislation designed to prevent misclassification of workers is actually enforced, and consider whether disputes regarding the form of employment should be brought before the Dispute Resolution Board, or whether trade unions with members in a business that employs so-called independent contractors should be able to file lawsuits in their own name to determine whether the worker should have been a permanent and directly employed staff member, similar to how collective action rights function in disputes over illegal hiring.

Review the Working Environment Act § 10-5 on average calculation of ordinary working hours. The aim of the review is to strengthen organized labor and prevent average calculations from undermining the normal working day.
Raise the access to agree on average calculation of the regular working hours for businesses that are bound by a collective agreement entered into with a trade union with the right to negotiate.
Conduct a more detailed investigation into how a provision that enshrines arrangements for discussions and information within a group can affect contractually established rights.

Investigate a legislative proposal to grant the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority the power to issue orders regarding the employee concept defined in § 1-8 and report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner.

Present a proposal that eliminates the coordination trap in public service pensions, also with retroactive effect, by ensuring that ratio and division factors lower than 1 and 13.42 are not used in the calculation of coordination deductions.

Conduct a review of the regulations that lead to the coordination trap, and return to the Parliament with proposals for changes that will prevent the occupational pension for public employees born between 1944 and 1962 from decreasing if they continue to work after reaching the age of 67, in the processing of the announced parliamentary report on pensions.
Ensure that public pension funds better inform their members about the consequences for their occupational pension of staying in work for a long time.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for changes to the National Insurance Act and make changes to the unemployment benefit regulations to remove the exception from the ordinary layoff rules, such as the law on wage obligations during layoffs, for fish processing of salmon, trout, and rainbow trout.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to extend the period of entitlement to layoff in the fishing industry from 26 to 52 weeks.
Reverse the current layoff rules for the fishing and aquaculture industry, so that the number of layoff weeks becomes 52 weeks over an 18-month period instead of 26 weeks in the same period.

Promote a proposal to amend the Second-Hand Trade Act § 1 so that it explicitly states that the purpose of the law is to promote reuse and circular economy, to prevent the sale of stolen or illegally received items, and to facilitate the police's work in tracking down such items.

Propose changes to the second-hand trade law that ensure that businesses find it practical and profitable to choose second-hand trade as part of their business solution, and that facilitate the development of business models that increase the reuse of products. The changes should include the following simplifications of the legislation: The approval period for operating a second-hand trade is extended from 1 year to a minimum of 3 years. The requirement that items must be stored for 14 days before they can be sold, for goods with a value below a certain minimum amount, is abolished. The requirements for listing are simplified, especially for clothing, equipment, and other items with low sales value, for example by introducing exceptions at the product group level in the law's regulations, or possibly by introducing a price or turnover-based threshold value. The requirement for manual listing, special licensing requirements, and other rules that create higher administrative costs for second-hand trade than for trade in new products are abolished.

Place the child welfare houses at level 2 in the organizational police structure within the police districts, so that the child welfare house leaders are included in the police chief's management team and are given responsibility for their own budget.
Implement measures to ensure stable operation of the State's Child Welfare Centers across the country.

Establish a permanent sub-department of the State Child House in Harstad that will provide a comprehensive service to meet the needs in Midtre Hålogaland, administered by the State Child House in Tromsø. It is assumed that funding for establishment and operation will be secured in connection with the revised national budget for 2023.
Expand the target group for children's houses to include suspected children, within the types of offenses that apply to vulnerable individuals.
Expand the target group for children's houses to include children and young people who engage in harmful sexual behavior (HSB).
Expand the target group for children's houses so that children between the ages of 16 and 18 can also receive adapted interviews, just like other children.
Promote proposals for legal changes that clarify that health care and psychosocial support must become a right for those who use the children's houses.
Implement measures or promote proposals for a clearer regulation of the follow-up work in the State Child House, in order to ensure a more uniform service across the country.
Evaluate the services provided by the children's houses to adults with intellectual disabilities, and possibly return to the Parliament with proposals for measures based on the evaluation.
To promote the necessary legislative changes for the dissolution of the commission in its current form, and to replace it with a new system for handling requests for the reopening of criminal cases.
Promote a proposal to remove the possibility of municipal bans on begging.
Establish a national anti-drone service at the Police National Preparedness Center.
Instruct the Civil Aviation Authority to ensure the requirement for identity verification for foreign citizens when registering in the drone operator registry.
Establish a national anti-drone service.

Return to the Parliament with a cost estimate and a proposal for a timeline for establishing a function that receives and analyzes data on drone activity related to relevant infrastructure, installations, and objects in order to establish a baseline and subsequently identify deviations, in connection with the revised national budget for 2023.
Promote the necessary legislative amendments to ensure legislation that clarifies the responsibility of owners of critical infrastructure for self-protection against unlawful drone activity.
Promote the necessary legislative amendments to ensure a legal basis for halting unlawful drone activity using enforcement measures.
Shut down Nye Veier AS.
Develop a roadmap and a prioritization sequence to ensure 100% public ownership of Equinor, Hydro, Telenor, Yara, and DNB by 2030.
Investigate the consolidation of Nysnø, Argentum, and Investinor under a green mandate for the revised national budget for 2023, where Nysnø will be the coordinating entity.
Introduce routines to refrain from supporting or participating in share buyback programs if it comes at the expense of necessary investments in Norway's green and just transition.
Introduce a regular strategic review of state ownership in addition to ownership reports, and return to the Storting in an appropriate manner.
Propose that Statkraft AS should have as its main purpose to ensure supply security in Norway and to provide Norwegian households and businesses with affordable, renewable energy.
Establish a shadow council for Norfund consisting of labor unions, indigenous organizations, and development organizations, based on the model of the OECD's contact point.

Ensure that state infrastructure owners such as Telenor and Statnett are subject to the same rules as public procurers regarding apprenticeship positions with suppliers, and that suppliers must be approved as training companies.
Come back with guidelines that ensure that executive salaries and board fees in state-owned companies do not exceed the salary of the Prime Minister.
Present a plan for how the state-owned companies within Norwegian railways can be gathered, consolidated, and/or co-located to provide more predictable and profitable operations for train users.
Reverse the separation of Norske tog AS, Mantena AS, and Entur AS from Vygruppen (formerly NSB Group).

It is suggested that companies in which the state has ownership are expected to publish country-by-country reports that show the companies' economic activities distributed across all the countries where they have a presence.
Investigate how to ensure procedural rules for energy policy that guarantee energy developments do not conflict with international law, human rights, and the rights of indigenous peoples.
Gather the state's ownership management of all companies in the Ministry of Trade and Fisheries.

Assume that the goal for companies with a state ownership stake in category 1 should be to achieve the highest possible return over time within sustainable frameworks, as well as to contribute to fulfilling the goals of the Paris Agreement and the biodiversity agreement.

Ensure through voting at the companies' general meetings that the articles of association of all state-owned companies include provisions stating that the company aims to fulfill the goals of the Paris Agreement and the new nature agreement.

Use their ownership power to ensure that all state-owned companies adhere to principles for setting science-based targets and reduce emissions from their own operations and value chains in line with the 1.5-degree limit, as well as having credible plans for emission reductions towards both 2030 and 2050.
Ensure that Statskog SF achieves the national environmental goal of good ecological status in Norwegian forests on its properties by 2030.

Present a binding plan for how the goal of 11 billion kroner in reduced administrative costs for businesses, related to imposed regulations and bureaucratic burdens from the government, will be achieved.

Consider how Norway can ensure control over strategically important value chains in light of the new geopolitical situation, and assess whether this has implications for state ownership. The Parliament requests the government to present a white paper on this, or in another suitable manner return to Parliament during 2023.
Contribute to a broader geographical distribution and diversity among owner-elected board representatives in companies where the state has ownership stakes.

Ensure that the new committee tasked with examining how electricity prices are set is given a mandate to explore pricing models for power that change the current distribution, where customers incur enormous expenses while power companies receive enormous revenues.

Ensure that the new committee tasked with examining how electricity prices are set is given the mandate to explore how the use of foreign cables can be changed to uphold the goal of making affordable, renewable energy a competitive advantage for customers in Norway.

Ensure that the new committee tasked with examining how electricity prices are set is given the mandate to consider how limitations can be placed on what power companies can charge for renewable energy, for example through a maximum price for electricity. Furthermore, they should look into how this could work in combination with a progressive tax on high consumption, a so-called top price system.

Investigate models where separate price points are established for suitable interconnectors to separate and alleviate the southern Norwegian electricity market from price contagion from the European electricity market, and present this no later than in connection with the state budget for 2024.

Investigate how the exchange through the interconnectors can be arranged so that price spillover from surrounding power systems to the Norwegian system does not override Norwegian energy policy objectives.

Introduce models where specific price points are established for suitable inter-country connections to separate and alleviate the southern Norwegian electricity market from price spillover from the European electricity market.

Give Statnett the mandate and resources to operate interconnectors through new pricing points, with the aims of achieving normal electricity prices in Norway (in a historical context), ensuring high supply security in Norway, and managing the import and export of electricity. Surplus electricity that Norway does not need can be sold through the interconnectors at European prices in quantities that do not affect Norwegian prices.
Establish an expanded investment program for biogas through Enova and/or Bionova, with a quantified goal for increased production.
Create a plan with measures for the establishment of a national network of filling stations with liquefied biogas. The plan must prioritize longer, particularly busy road sections.
Introduce toll reductions equivalent to zero-emission vehicles for biogas vehicles on routes financed by tolls, also outside urban areas.
To change Enova's mandate so that it includes energy efficiency for all sectors by spring 2023.

Ensure that Enova has available support schemes for energy efficiency with mature technology in accordance with Decision 21 (2022–2023) no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2023.

Give Enova an additional mandate to ensure increased supply security by contributing to significantly more energy efficiency and local energy production in households. This must be done through support for mature technologies that provide rapid reductions in the use of electricity from the grid, such as heat pumps, insulation of parts of the building envelope, window replacements, batteries, geothermal energy, and similar solutions. Support must be provided with simultaneous disbursement. The additional mandate for Enova must be in place by March 2023.
Facilitate the adaptation and modification of existing infrastructure in established fields, especially Troll and Snøhvit, to utilize and increase production and export capacity.
Announce the 26th licensing round.
Expand the predefined areas (TFO) and open more blocks for exploration and extraction.
Facilitate increased exploration for oil and gas near areas with existing infrastructure.
Facilitate the prompt initiation of existing commercially viable discoveries, such as the Linnorm field and similar projects.
Challenge the companies to present plans to increase production and export capacity in existing fields on the Norwegian continental shelf.
Accelerate the work on developing an export solution for gas from the Barents Sea to facilitate increased gas exports from the area.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a special law prohibiting the export of goods, technology, and services that can be used for surveillance and eavesdropping on opposition members in Iran.
Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner with measures to prevent surveillance and threats against citizens in Norway from the Iranian regime.
Exercise ownership power in the arms company Nammo to close down Nammo's export office in Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates, which is participating in the war against Yemen.
Suspend the issuance of new export permits for A-material, B-material, and dual-use goods with Qatar as the buyer.
Stop the export of A-material, B-material, and dual-use goods to Qatar covered by existing permits.
Present an assessment of human rights and democratic conditions before new permits are granted for the export of A-material, B-material, and dual-use goods to Qatar.
Support the Sámi Parliament's work to investigate a Sámi language ombudsman.

Consider how to best comply with the Sámi Parliament's demand that Sámi klinikk should be managed according to its own budget with a board appointed by the Sámi Parliament, and report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner.

Review all permits for wind power plants, mining activities, and other major interventions in nature with negative effects on reindeer husbandry, and reassess these permits in light of the Supreme Court ruling on October 11, 2021.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals to clarify, through legislation or other regulations, the relevant assessment themes according to Article 27 of the UN Convention on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) in order to contribute to good human rights assessments in the administration.

Investigate and return to the Storting with proposals for amendments to the law that can abolish the arrangement for advance entry in expropriation cases for developments in reindeer grazing areas, and ensure that the legal status of reindeer herding in development cases is clarified before any natural interventions are permitted.
Report to the Parliament on the progress of the follow-up to the Fosen ruling.
Emphasize rectifying the ongoing human rights violations confirmed in the Fosen ruling, rather than other considerations.
Facilitate the establishment of a separate sub-ombudsman by the Equality and Anti-Discrimination Ombud that works on harassment against Sámi people and national minorities.

Develop a guide and take the initiative for municipalities to create plans with concrete, binding, and measurable actions to prevent and combat hate speech/harassment against Sámi people and national minorities.
Develop an accessible online tool where individuals can report experienced or observed hate speech/hate incidents, regardless of whether the specific events have been reported to the police.

Initiate a national competence boost on Sami people and national minorities for all teachers and teacher education programs. The Sámi Parliament and national minority organizations must be partners to ensure the quality of the content.

Strengthen efforts to prevent and combat racism, hate speech, and harassment against Sámi people and national minorities through concrete, binding, and measurable actions developed in collaboration with the organizations and institutions of these groups.

Ensure that all police districts in Norway develop professional environments that can collect and publish statistics on the specific groups that are exposed to hate speech and hate crime, including Sámi and national minorities, according to clear national guidelines based on the methodology already used by the Oslo Police District.
Investigate the possibility of introducing a rent cap on rental properties in high-demand areas, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Look into the possibility of introducing a cap on annual rent price increases based on the model from Denmark, and return to the Parliament as soon as possible.

Promote proposals for necessary legislative changes where the system of market rent as a basis for rental prices for municipal rental properties and care homes is abolished and replaced by a system where the tenant's financial ability is the basis for rent determination.
Ensure that the review of the Tenancy Act safeguards the rights and challenges faced by residents in municipal housing and care homes.
Promote a proposal to amend the Planning and Building Act so that municipalities can require a certain percentage of non-commercial housing, with price and turnover control, in zoning plans.
Develop and present a national plan for a large-scale municipal development of rental housing.
Look at models for establishing a separate rental supervision for the housing sector and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Strengthen tenants' right of first refusal in cases where rental properties are sold.
Prepare and present to the Storting a proposal to introduce penal provisions in the law on municipal pre-emption rights to rental properties.

Set a goal to make Norway area-neutral by the end of 2025, and set a new goal for a significant improvement in the condition of Norwegian ecosystems by 2035 and a 20% improvement in condition by 2050.

Investigate and present proposals for legal amendments that ensure the goal of area neutrality, both on land and at sea, is incorporated into Norwegian legislation and becomes legally binding for land use policy, including plans and individual case processing at all levels of government and in all sectors.

Require that all municipalities present annual nature and land accounts and nature and land budgets that provide a complete overview of completed, approved, and planned reallocation and changes to the land in the municipality.
Come back to the Parliament with a concrete plan for how we will achieve the goals in LULUCF according to the climate agreement with the EU.
Strengthen the funding for the development of methodology and technology for nature mapping, as well as the funding for the actual nature mapping itself.

Develop and present a land account and a land budget for the Parliament each year that shows the development of Norwegian land use from year to year and projections for how Norway will achieve its nature goals.

Present a proposal for a reform of land use policy in municipalities, which provides each municipality with the necessary knowledge base, management tools, and legal frameworks to make the municipality land-neutral.
Halt planned interventions at the Nordre Tyrifjorden nature reserve and associated protected areas and natural values, and quickly assess an alternative route option for the Ringeriksbanen.
Strengthen the county governor's authority and capacity to object in environmental matters.
Conduct a comprehensive review of current practices regarding dispensations for interventions in protected areas and take measures to ensure that conservation decisions are respected.
Ensure that the Hordfast project, E39 Stord–Os, is not realized as it is currently planned.

Conduct a comprehensive review of planned natural interventions in Norway with the aim of reducing the degradation of nature in line with the ambitions of the global nature agreement reached in December 2022.
Say no to the plans for the Davvi wind farm, which will affect Sámi reindeer herding areas and involve a significant intrusion into Norway's second largest untouched area.
Withdraw the permit for the development of the planned area for Eidfjord Resort with a ski facility in Eidfjord municipality.

Reduce the capacity of the planned E6 Moelv–Lillehammer–Øyer, and do not change the conservation regulations for the Lågendeltaet nature reserve, so that the E6 is not routed through the nature reserve.
Implement measures to protect productive forests, with a goal of 7% by 2025 and 10% by 2030.
Introduce a moratorium on clear-cutting in the remaining old-growth forests and in forests that have never been clear-cut, until the forest conservation goal is achieved.
Implement measures that ensure independent, professional biological registrations of all old-growth forests and forests in Norway that are over 100 years old.
Mapping forests that serve as important protection against landslides, floods, and avalanches.
Stop all subsidies for logging in steep terrain and for forest roads into areas that have not been clear-cut before.

Present a proposal for necessary amendments to the law and changes to regulations to introduce an application requirement for all clear-cutting, so that it can be assessed under the Biodiversity Act Chapter II regarding biological conservation values.
Initiate a larger public inquiry aimed at shaping a new sustainable forest management based on new knowledge about greenhouse gas emissions, biodiversity, and alternative logging methods.

Amend § 5, first paragraph of the regulation on sustainable forestry so that it has a practical and legal content that implies that violations of the environmental requirements in the regulation may result in sanctions.

Change the current method for collecting, registering, and controlling important natural values in Norwegian forests, and implement measures that ensure that environmental registration is carried out by independent professionals.
Introduce a reporting obligation for all logging in old-growth forests that have not been clear-cut before.
Present a scaling-up plan for financing forest conservation to achieve the goal of 10% forest protection by 2030.
Conduct a survey of the oldest forest so that we can ensure proper management of it.

Review the current method for collecting, registering, and controlling important natural values in Norwegian forests, and assess measures to ensure that the intention of environmental registration is upheld, and that the environmental registration has sufficient quality.
Present a plan to decouple Norwegian electricity prices from European gas prices.
Establish a pricing system for electricity used in Norway, with a cost-based maximum price for regular consumption and a higher price for luxury consumption by private households.
Change Statnett's mandate in accordance with a new organization of the Norwegian electricity market.

Take political control over the power flow in the foreign cables with stricter requirements for environmental and supply security as a condition for export, and renegotiate relevant agreements to achieve this if necessary.
Present a plan for government regulation of domestic electricity trading, where the state takes over domestic electricity sales and electricity sales companies are phased out.
Initiate a process to ensure public ownership of the exchange for trading physical power in Norway.
Reject the license application from NorthConnect, in accordance with the Hurdal platform's statement that no new foreign cables should be approved during this period.
Ensure that the expert committee tasked with evaluating electricity pricing delivers its report by September 1st.
Promote the necessary legislative amendments to ensure that the residence requirement for permanent residency is increased from five years to eight years.

Ensure that women who have come to Norway through family reunification and who report or notify about partner violence are exempt from the residence requirement and are granted residency in Norway on an independent basis.

Come back with the necessary proposals for amendments to the law so that women who come for family reunification with Norwegian men or men who have lived in Norway for more than five years, or women who obtain residence as labor immigrants, are granted the right and obligation to training according to the Integration Act § 8.

Instruct the immigration authorities to place greater emphasis on other forms of violence and abuse besides physical violence in future cases covered by the Immigration Act § 53 first paragraph letter b.

Promote a proposal for a separate provision in the Immigration Act § 53 that ensures that individuals who have been granted permission under the law's § 42, and who can no longer live with the reference person due to abuse or neglect, shall be granted a new residence permit on an independent basis, and return to the Parliament with this within a reasonable time.
Promote a proposal to reverse the residence requirement for permanent residence permits from five years to three years.

Conduct a comprehensive review of the application of the Immigration Act § 53 first paragraph letter b, among other things in light of the preparatory works of the provision, and ensure in an appropriate manner that the exception clause is not interpreted too strictly.
Ensure that the ongoing work on the development of public cloud services includes solutions for the municipal sector.
Implement measures for increased transparency regarding ownership, organization, and finances of private actors providing welfare services with public funding.

Subject private enterprises that provide publicly funded welfare services to the same requirements to comply with the Archives Act, the Freedom of Information Act, and the Public Administration Act as public entities, and return to the Parliament with any necessary proposals to ensure this.

Propose legislative changes that ensure public access to all information, including financial and employment-related data, necessary to monitor commercial actors providing publicly funded welfare services.

Promote necessary legislative proposals that ensure transparency and access to accounts, quality indicators, staffing situations, and cash flows of private commercial actors providing welfare services with public funding, as well as ensuring that the changes in key parts of the legislation necessary for genuine insight into public operations also apply to these actors.
Ensure that information about ownership in commercial companies providing welfare services with public funding is available, so that it is clear who is responsible for the welfare service.
Facilitate collaboration between humanitarian efforts, long-term development initiatives, and peacebuilding in the Nansen program.
Implement a review of the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority to assess appropriate organization, resources, functions, and competencies.

Come back to the Parliament, at the latest in the revised national budget for 2023, with a proposal to establish more labor crime centers where the Labor Inspection Authority, NAV, the police, and the Tax Administration are co-located to more effectively uncover labor market crime.

Start the work on a trust reform in the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority, with the goal of eliminating unnecessary measurement and control, and ensuring increased participation and involvement from the employees.
Come back with a proposal for the state budget for 2024 that includes a plan to increase the number of inspector positions in the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority.

Investigate a proposal for a legal basis to seize relevant documents that companies do not wish to present during the Labor Inspection Authority's inspections, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Investigate proposals that ensure the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority has access to retrieve information from multiple actors, a so-called third party, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Review and assess the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority's powers for supervision, access to information, and sanctioning options under the Working Environment Act.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals that ensure that disabled individuals who return to work will not face unreasonable repayment demands for already disbursed disability benefits. The change must not result in a weakening or removal of the current income threshold.
Address the unreasonable practice of the Norwegian Directorate of Health, where establishments that use emojis associated with alcohol are fined for illegal alcohol advertising.

Clean up the Norwegian Directorate of Health's practice of penalizing breweries that are tagged by private individuals on social media, which can result in warnings and fines for illegal alcohol advertising.
Review Chapter 9 of the Alcohol Act along with Chapter 14 of the Alcohol Regulations and propose changes that ensure a more effective enforcement of the advertising ban adapted to new media.
Promote a case with a proposal to expand the access that local producers of alcoholic beverages have to sell their own products with an alcohol content of over 4.7 percent.
Exempt pocket ashtrays from the prohibition on display in the Tobacco Damage Act.
Evaluate the healthcare service's "no-show" fees and do not increase the fees until this has been completed.
Ensure that health enterprises and health actors providing services under agreement with them do not use external collection agencies for the recovery of overdue monetary claims.

Ensure that in connection with the evaluation of the "no-show" fees, it is also considered what other measures the health enterprises should be required to implement in order to ensure better communication and facilitation for patients, so that missed appointments are reduced, and that, to the extent possible, arrangements are made to accommodate the patient's needs.
Ensure that patients are not charged a fee when missed appointments are due to weather and road conditions.

Initiate a process to describe clear guidelines for the handling of exceptions related to the "no-show" fee, which contributes to more consistent practices in healthcare institutions for protecting patients with health challenges or financial difficulties.
Promote a parliamentary report on women's health and health from a gender perspective.
Establish a national center for competence, diagnosis, and treatment of women's health diseases, specifically endometriosis and adenomyosis.

Promote a proposal for the financing of maternity care that safeguards and rewards good maternity care, ensuring that healthcare enterprises do not lose out on births with minimal intervention, and that maternity care does not receive lower DRG points than comparable procedures. Furthermore, the government is requested to consider how activity-based financing in maternity care can be completely phased out and replaced with block funding or pathway financing.

Present a proposal for a new financing model for maternity care that rewards professional quality and ensures that healthcare institutions do not lose money by preventing complications and interventions.

Present a concrete plan to address the acute shortage of midwives, both in specialist healthcare services and in municipalities. The government is also requested to consider basic staffing, workload, and other conditions that lead to midwives not wanting to remain in their positions today.
Develop a more varied maternity service with more separate birthing units in hospitals and continuity in midwifery services across the country.
Ensure that the ABC unit is maintained as a separate midwife-led unit at Oslo University Hospital throughout the entire operating year.
Ensure clear responsibilities regarding the handling of information influence in public debate.

Initiate a mapping of unwanted information influence from foreign actors in connection with the municipal and county council elections in 2023 and the parliamentary elections in 2025. The mapping should, among other things, capture attempts to influence Norwegians' perception of reality, values, and trust over time.

Investigate and present proposals to harmonize the penalty framework for violations of the sanctions law with the penalty framework for violations of the export control law and similar provisions in other comparable countries.
Ensure clear responsibilities in matters related to the handling of information influence, including the responsibility to continuously map and analyze the information environment across sectors.
Promote a proposal to criminalize collaboration with foreign intelligence services to conduct influence operations.

Initiate a process to revise the provisions of the Penal Code Chapter 17, with the aim of adapting the provisions to the security policy situation and ensuring stronger protection of fundamental national interests and Norway's independence.

Ensure that the police and other agencies are given the necessary authority to effectively respond to the illegal use of drones. This includes, among other things, the proposal to grant the police access to frequencies to neutralize dangerous objects.
Implement the necessary changes to the export control regulations to achieve more targeted control of knowledge with military applications that is transferred to foreign citizens and entities.

Facilitate the opportunity for power companies to apply for the development of hydropower in protected waterways where they have identified that it is possible to increase power production without significantly compromising nature and environmental considerations.
Present a case for supplementing the protection plans for protected watercourses with the Gjengedalsvassdraget, Garbergelva, Hovda, Vinda, and Skurvedalsåna.

Map the quality of and develop a system for regular monitoring of school buildings and the physical learning environment for all Norwegian students in primary and secondary education, and report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner by the end of 2023 with the results and proposals for measures, including how the right in the Education Act § 9 A-7 second paragraph can be ensured, and a strategy for improving school buildings and the physical learning environment. Universal design should be a fundamental consideration in the strategy.

Engage in dialogue with municipalities and county municipalities to gain a better overview of maintenance backlogs and the condition of Norwegian school buildings, and ensure that municipalities and county municipalities have systems in place for mapping and monitoring the quality of school buildings.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to reintroduce the scheme of interest-free loans for the maintenance of school buildings.
Ensure that sex education contributes to knowledge/training, and that special care is taken with the younger age groups (elementary schools and kindergartens).
Develop goals for a national competence boost for sexuality education in kindergartens and schools, which also includes gender, relationship, and sexuality minorities.

Develop common guidelines for good sexuality education for the entire upbringing sector – from kindergarten to high school, including adult education. The guidelines should include recommendations on when sexuality education should take place, how much time is recommended to allocate per grade, as well as which topics should be covered.
Implement a national competence boost in sexual education, including increased awareness of sexual abuse and similar issues.

Engage in dialogue with educational institutions to integrate sexuality education as a larger part of the educational pathway for professions that work closely with children and young people. The framework plans for the relevant programs must be reviewed so that staff in kindergartens and schools are equipped to provide their students with good and comprehensive sexuality education.
Consider establishing more study places for health nurses.

Consider strengthening the school health service with earmarked funds for full-time positions for school nurses, so that all municipalities and counties can at least meet the standard ratios for school nurses.

Intensify efforts to ensure transparency regarding hidden ownership in the Norwegian economy and return to the Storting with proposals for increased appropriations beyond the announced wage and price adjustments to relevant oversight bodies in the revised national budget for 2023.

Present an overview with estimates of the scope over time of conducted control activities and lost tax revenues that can be attributed to the lack of control capacity at the Tax Administration and other supervisory authorities.

Make a new assessment of whether the chosen threshold value for registration as a real right holder is in line with the conditions formulated by a unanimous finance committee in Innst. 143 L (2018–2019), in light of the international development where many countries have opted for a lower threshold value.

Make a new assessment of whether the current exemptions from the registration requirement in the Norwegian register of beneficial owners for certain company forms are in line with the conditions formulated by a unanimous finance committee in Innst. 143 L (2018–2019).
Propose a legislative change to remove access to information about searches conducted on one's own person in the tax lists.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals for necessary legal changes that ensure that tax lists from previous years are made available to the public for a longer period than they are today.

Investigate the possibilities for ensuring increased transparency and better access to tax lists for the public. The investigation should be viewed in light of the developments in the area of privacy since access was restricted in 2014.
Promote necessary proposals to include gross income before deductions and net wealth before valuation discounts in the tax lists.

Clarify whether the scope for donating surplus food for charitable purposes from cruise lines and ship suppliers, etc., is actually limited by EU/EEA regulations, and align the regulations in Norway with EU countries, provided that Norwegian veterinary authorities consider this to be safe.
Introduce mandatory cargo securing courses in the driver training for driver's license class B.

Abolish the requirement in the driver's license regulations for a driver's license in class BE or community code 96 for driving with a trailer with a permissible total weight of up to 3,500 kg, provided that the permissible "combination weight," meaning the total permissible weight of the vehicle and trailer, is not exceeded.

Consider whether it is appropriate to simplify the regulations for driver's licenses class B96 and BE, and whether the scope of training should be the same for these driver's license classes. The government is requested to return to the Storting with an assessment of this in connection with the state budget for 2024.

Consider whether, from a traffic safety perspective, a single load securing course is sufficient to be classified for driver's license class B96 and BE, and report back to the Parliament with the assessment in connection with the state budget for 2024.

Change the driver's license regulations so that individuals with glaucoma, stroke survivors, and possibly those with hereditary diseases, who are automatically denied the right to keep their driver's license, can have the opportunity to use a simulator and/or practical test to receive a new assessment of whether they can regain their driver's license.
Implement the Storting's resolution 960 (2020–2021) and present a case on this no later than the end of March 2023.

Change the driver's license regulations so that individuals with glaucoma, individuals who have suffered a stroke, and other individuals with a hereditary condition that automatically revokes their right to drive, should be given the opportunity to use a driving simulator or take a practical test to receive a new assessment of their driving skills and suitability. In cases where driving ability is deemed satisfactory, exemptions from the regulations should be allowed, and the right to drive should be restored.
Investigate how to make simplified fines more progressive, and consider linking the fine to the offender's income and/or wealth.

Consider removing the condition of special need, so that the first paragraph of the regulation's § 3 reads: a. driver of a motor vehicle who needs parking concessions because they cannot walk or have significant difficulties moving over any distance. b. passenger who regularly needs assistance from the driver outside the motor vehicle because they cannot walk or have significant difficulties moving over any distance.
Consider changing § 1 Purpose, so that it states that the purpose is to provide people in need of parking assistance the opportunity to live full and equal lives on par with others.
Ensure that the national guidelines for the implementation of the regulations on parking permits for the disabled are updated and published shortly, and no later than during 2023.

Ensure that the implementation of the regulations regarding parking permits for the mobility impaired facilitates that those who need a parking permit for the mobility impaired receive it, regardless of which municipality they live in, and how many parking spaces the municipality may have.

Ensure that the regulations regarding parking permits for the mobility impaired facilitate that individuals with chronic physical disabilities only need to apply for a parking permit for the mobility impaired once.

Ensure that the regulations regarding parking permits for the mobility impaired facilitate that the HC card is valid whether the person in need of it is a passenger or a driver, so that it becomes possible for the holder of the HC card to be dropped off and picked up.
Ensure that the regulations regarding parking permits for the mobility impaired facilitate that there are no requirements for regularity or frequency of use of the HC card.

Investigate Norway's legal scope to prohibit the import and trade of agricultural products that Norwegian law does not allow to be produced, including products from fur farming, as well as to assess the likelihood of any trade policy consequences of introducing such prohibitions.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a ban on the import and trade of fur products that originate from animal husbandry where the animals or their offspring are kept solely or primarily for the exploitation of their fur, when such import or trade occurs as part of a business activity.

Strengthen the trainee candidate scheme, including ensuring that it is clarified and made clear who the right target group for the trainee candidate scheme is, and who might benefit more from alternative arrangements such as the practice certificate scheme.
Investigate whether to introduce a professional title level between skilled workers with vocational or journeyman certificates and unskilled workers.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal for the introduction of a flexible school start age, with school starting no later than at the age of seven.

To propose to the Storting to postpone the start of first grade until the age of seven and to introduce preschool for six-year-olds. The preschool should be based on learning through play and kindergarten pedagogy and be free of homework.

Come back with proposals for the state budget for 2024 that include a plan to ensure more inspections to comply with regulations against social dumping. The plan should include increased funding for the Labor Inspection Authority and for conducting more inspections in the road sector.
Accelerate and expand the driving and rest time regulations to also apply to national transport and courier and delivery vehicles down to 2.5 tons.
Establish a regulatory framework that holds transport buyers accountable for using unreliable subcontractors.
Promote proposals to limit cabotage in the coach industry, including developing a clear definition of "temporary" operations in the coach market by the end of 2023.
Introduce HSE cards in the light commercial vehicle sector during 2024.
Ensure that the train companies reintroduce a consistent minimum price as before the privatization of the railway.

Come back to the Storting with a proposal to abolish the gambling monopoly and introduce a licensing system that ensures equal competitive conditions for Norwegian and international gambling companies. The system will uphold the three fundamental principles of gambling policy.

Return to the Parliament in the revised national budget for 2023 with a proposal to make the value-added tax compensation scheme for voluntary organizations rule-based, with ongoing application deadlines and compensation payments throughout the year.

Closely monitor the gambling sector and the influence of international actors, and by 2024, return to the Storting with an evaluation of the Norwegian gambling monopoly, the so-called exclusive rights model.

Adjust the gambling regulations so that the loss limits for bingo games are set at the same level for all operators, 20,000 kroner per game per month. At the same time, private land lotteries will be allowed to conduct their games digitally.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to raise the turnover limit for charitable lotteries and to allow the lotteries to distribute income to multiple organizations beyond those that hold the lottery license.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for tax schemes that value and encourage generosity towards the voluntary sector, both from individuals and businesses. This could include increased tax deductions for donations and/or gift matching schemes.

Strengthen and expand the work with the Volunteer Register, including ensuring that information from the register forms the basis for all application schemes administered at the national level. The work will be carried out in consultation with the voluntary sector.
Ensure that a unified definition of "voluntary organization" is used to a greater extent in the public administration, based on the registration rights in the Voluntary Register.

Initiate work to harmonize and simplify the many searchable schemes managed by the ministry, directorate, and state sector, including assessing more coordinated systems for applications and reporting for state grant schemes, synchronized application deadlines and response/payment times, and implementing faster processing of grants and rules for transferring grants to the next budget year when allocations are made late, as well as facilitating that grants are more often provided as multi-year grants and operational grants. The work will be carried out in consultation with the voluntary sector.
Promote a proposal for an economic support package for the voluntary sector.
Investigate how the state can intervene with municipalities that systematically violate children's rights, for example based on the model of ROBEK.
Expand the mandate of the National Commission for Health and Care Services so that it also takes responsibility for investigating the municipal child welfare services.
Regulate the purpose of the child welfare service's status reporting, as well as some essential points that all child welfare services must report on, and how they should report.

Implement a project to ensure children's national complaint opportunities and improve information for children and young people about their right to complain in individual cases and the complaint rights that exist.
Return to the Parliament with proposals for improvements to the cost-sharing key for child welfare, based on the recommendations in NOU 2022:10, with the aim of making it more accurate.

Bring a case to the Storting regarding the continuation of the energy subsidy scheme for businesses until the first quarter of 2023, through an adjusted version of the current scheme: The threshold for electricity intensity is reduced to 2.5 percent, based on electricity consumption in the second half of 2022. Payments are increased beyond 25 percent over 70 øre/kWh for step 1 of the model, up to a maximum of 30 percent. It will be allowed to distribute dividends to cover wealth tax even if one receives electricity support. A framework of 2 billion kroner is set for the scheme. The cap per company is maintained (3.5 million kroner).

Implement measures under the Price Measures Act, or other types of price-regulating tools, if the investigations currently being conducted by the Ministry of Trade and Fisheries reveal that the prices set for consumers by grocery retailers on February 1, 2023, are unreasonable.
Present a new Myanmar strategy aimed at supporting the people of Myanmar and their struggle for democracy, human rights, and justice, inspired by the US Burma Act of 2022.

Establish an external committee to clarify whether there is a legal basis to determine that the Soviet Union's treatment of the population in the then Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic between 1932 and 1933, known as the Holodomor, constitutes a violation of the genocide convention.
Recognize the Holodomor as a genocide against the Ukrainian people.

Consider issuing student visas and scholarships to Afghan women whose education has been interrupted due to the Taliban's decision to deny girls and women access to universities, so that they can gain access to higher education.

Consider providing aid funds so that Afghan women whose education has been interrupted due to the Taliban's decision to deny girls and women access to universities can still complete their education at institutions in the surrounding areas.

Present a plan for when a sufficient number of Bell 412 helicopters will be moved to Bardufoss, and how many will be moved, in order to strengthen the Army's helicopter capacity while awaiting the procurement of new helicopters.
Move a sufficient number of Bell 412 helicopters to Bardufoss to strengthen the Army's helicopter capacity while awaiting the purchase of new helicopters.
Ensure that the National Security Authority develops new guidelines for mobile usage, which will replace the National Security Authority's 13 recommendations on security for mobile devices.
Develop a binding long-term plan for the operations at the Norwegian Centre for Information Security.
Ensure a new review of the residence permit applications for the 23 women from Iran who are living in Norwegian asylum reception centers and have been denied.
Ensure that those who are granted residence permits are given the same rights as Norwegian citizens.
Establish a committee to evaluate the handling of the one-time solution for long-term elderly asylum seekers from 2019.
Ensure that all who applied for the one-time solution for long-term elderly asylum seekers in 2019 and were denied are given a new assessment of their applications.

To return to the Storting within a reasonable time with a proposal for a new one-time solution for long-term asylum seekers regardless of age, where those who have been in Norway for more than five years are given the opportunity to apply.

Follow up on the specific recommendations from the UN High Commissioner for Refugees from 2015, including incorporating a definition of stateless persons into national legislation, so that the administration can better assess whether a person is stateless or not.

Ensure that those who have been granted residence permits under the one-time solution for long-term asylum seekers from 2019, as well as those who are now being granted it under the new one-time solution proposed in Document 8:85 (2022-2023), are given the opportunity to apply for family reunification, and that arrangements are made for this.

Ensure that those who have not been granted residency in Norway, but are still residing here, are provided access to healthcare services, dental care, and mental health support. Furthermore, that opportunities for obtaining work permits and study rights, as well as access to public transportation, are provided.

Amend the Immigration Regulations to emphasize the lack of opportunities for same-sex couples to enter into marriage/partnership in their home country or in nearby areas when processing applications for residence permits to marry.
Include "sexual orientation" as an assessment topic in cases that, as a general rule, should be handled in a committee meeting with personal attendance.

Amend the immigration regulations so that same-sex couples who have been in a relationship in a country where there are limited opportunities to enter into same-sex marriages or live together in stable and established cohabitation relationships are given the opportunity to apply for a residence permit for cohabitation based on a substantiated prior relationship.

Investigate how refugees in same-sex relationships can be ensured the right to family reunification with their spouse/partner, for example, by allowing documentation requirements to be replaced with proof of likelihood for countries that restrict the ability to live in same-sex relationships.

Investigate and implement a regulatory framework that ensures existing vacation homes can be purchased by the state when they are put up for sale. The acquisition of properties in coastal areas and in urban-adjacent mountain regions, especially properties over 200 m2 and/or with large plots, should be prioritized. National and local outdoor recreation associations and similar organizations should then be given the opportunity to offer affordable short-term rentals of these properties, following the model of, for example, the coastal cabin scheme and the Norwegian Trekking Association.
Investigate and present a proposal for a maximum allowable size for new vacation homes, set at 200 m2.
Ensure that passenger car traffic to and from vacation homes counts less than other traffic, or is even excluded, in assessments of socio-economic profitability for large national road projects.

Investigate and present proposals to significantly restrict the construction of vacation homes in the following areas: in the mountains above the tree line, in coastal zones, in the habitats of wild reindeer, in wetland areas, in untouched natural areas, and in other vulnerable areas.
Investigate and present a proposal that new vacation homes should be built in existing areas designated for vacation homes with already established infrastructure.

Ensure that the deduction in the framework grant due to high concession power revenues aligns with the assumptions presented by the government on September 28, 2022, and which the Parliament approved during the consideration of the state budget for 2023. The deduction should correspond to less than one third of the estimated value above 70 øre/kWh of the concession power in 2023.
Investigate an improved arrangement for additional costs related to the settlement of refugees with disabilities beyond the current system.
Investigate a scheme for direct settlement in the municipalities from the National Arrival Center in Råde.

Change the criteria for settlement regarding the size of municipalities, and allow all municipalities in Norway, regardless of the number of inhabitants, to settle refugees based on their capacity and the desire they express.

Change the weighting of the criteria set for the settlement of refugees, so that the labor market and results from the introduction program and integration work are given greater importance than the number of residents in the municipality.
Return to the Parliament with measures that ensure all children living in asylum reception centers have access to preschool places.
Work to ensure that settlement in the municipalities happens quickly, so that each refugee spends less time in reception centers.

Present a proposal that entails that everyone on minimum benefits should receive a one-time support payment of 10,000 kroner as soon as possible. The proposal should at least apply to all minimum pensioners and recipients of disability benefits and work assessment allowance at the minimum level. The one-time support payment should also be prorated for those who would have received increased benefits if they were at the minimum level. A proposal for financing should also be presented, if necessary with increased use of oil revenues.

Present new measures to address the inequality crisis no later than in the revised national budget for 2023, and among the measures to be considered are one-time payments to vulnerable groups, increasing the minimum rates in welfare benefits, raising social assistance rates, reducing taxes, fees, and co-payments including municipal co-payments, strengthening the housing support scheme, and enhancing services such as health and social services.
Suggest a compensation scheme for retirees for the price increase in 2022.
Come back to the Storting with measures that will compensate for the price developments in food, electricity, and fuel.

Consider how Nav can be enabled to make extraordinary payments and change the level of existing benefits more quickly than today, and report back to the Storting on the work no later than in the state budget for 2024.

Present a status report to the Parliament indicating the extent to which the principles for sharing and using data presented in Meld. St. 22 (2020–2021) Data as a Resource have been implemented in the public and private sectors.
Establish arenas where the business community can provide advice and recommendations on which data should be prioritized for data sharing.

Establish a digitalization panel consisting of business actors who continuously identify the need for legislative changes in order to realize technological potential and increase the level of innovation in Norwegian enterprises.
Ensure that public enterprises support activities in Digital Norway and other business arenas where collaboration on skills enhancement in digitalization and data sharing takes place.
Establish a guide for public and private organizations focusing on cybersecurity and privacy in connection with data sharing through open APIs.
Revise the national strategy for digital security.

Initiate the establishment of a marine data bank as a public-private partnership between established actors who are working on data sharing platforms for marine-specific data. The platform should ensure the sharing of marine data in the SMB segment and the industry.
Ensure that more qualified technologists are trained.
Expand the number of study places for further education in ICT.
Ensure increased digitalization competence among public actors, so that greater use of innovative procurement can become an important tool for business growth.

Facilitate regulatory sandboxes where businesses and authorities have the opportunity to test new technologies and services with insufficient regulation, where the legal framework requires more testing and experimentation before it is comprehensively changed.
Ensure that the Norwegian Mapping Authority becomes a public data provider that enables the development of digital twins and forward-looking services, particularly within the transport sector.
Ensure Norwegian participation in pan-European digital initiatives through national mobilization funds.
Let the development of the emergency network be a pioneering area for how 5G technology can enable services and communication solutions, such as the use of remote operations via the network.
Facilitate programs that connect the digital skills of youth involved in gaming and programming with the increasing demand for digital competence in the business sector.
Ensure that knowledge of artificial intelligence and the Internet of Things is integrated into more educational programs.
Require that data be made available upon the conclusion of public contracts, where deemed appropriate.
Consider which types of data have such significant societal value that the authorities should mandate data sharing.
Establish a national memorial day for the victims of the Holocaust on November 26.
Promote proposals for state-funded development of road and bridge projects from the urban package proposal for Nedre Glomma phase 2. It should be based on shorter travel times for motorists.
Promote a proposal to maintain the environmental support scheme for rail freight beyond 2023.
Promote a proposal to make the environmental support scheme for rail freight a five-year program to ensure predictability and profitability in the industry.

Ensure a new ferry connection between Aure and Hitra as a research and development project, focusing on floating ferry terminals and possible trials with autonomous ferries, and that this is taken into account in the revenue system of Møre og Romsdal County Municipality and Trøndelag County Municipality as soon as the project is ready.
Stop the plans for the new E6 between Moelv and Øyer over the Lågendeltaet nature reserve and initiate work to find alternative solutions that do not conflict with the conservation regulations.

Reverse the decision of the Norwegian Environment Agency regarding the rejection under the Nature Diversity Act, maintain the previous decision on exemption, and thereby ensure the construction of the new E6 with a four-lane standard through the Lågendeltaet as planned and approved by the Parliament.

Investigate the necessary maintenance on the railway that can significantly reduce train delays, and return with proposals for funding in line with this in connection with the national budget for 2024.
Reduce the maintenance backlog on the railway and come back with proposals regarding this in connection with the state budget for 2024.
Reject and halt the proposed electrification of Hammerfest LNG at Melkøya with power from the mainland.
Stop and postpone the electrification project Hammerfest LNG at Melkøya.
Consider introducing a fee for being in the connection queue for electricity.

Ensure that the electrification of the shelf is postponed until new power sources and reinforcements of the power grid in the area are established, so that electrification does not hinder the establishment of other industries. Available replacement power is a prerequisite before approval for electrification is granted.

Ensure that the electrification of land-based petroleum industry facilities in Norway is postponed until new power sources and reinforcements of the power grid in the area are established. Available replacement power is a prerequisite before approval for electrification is allowed.
Ensure that all petroleum-related projects that have reserved capacity on the central grid are reassessed. If there is no available replacement power, the project should be rejected.
Require Equinor to investigate CCS at Melkøya.
Require Statnett to investigate underwater cables as an alternative to overhead lines.

Present the case regarding the revised plan for development and operation (PUD) and the plan for facilities and operation (PAD) for the Snøhvit field and Hammerfest LNG to the Parliament and do not approve the applications without the revised plans being considered by the Parliament.
Ensure that the operators of LNG Hammerfest and Snøhvit implement measures to reduce CO2 emissions at the facilities with CCS solutions without using large amounts of power from the shore.

Ensure that a new assessment of the use of carbon capture and storage as an alternative to electrification of LNG Hammerfest and Snøhvit is conducted, as a measure to reduce CO2 emissions from the facility.

Ensure that the regulations regarding delivery obligation and connection obligation are revised, so that greater consideration can be given to available power and grid access, as well as the socio-economic effects of a project.
Create a plan for how to increase power production, including what is needed to realize offshore wind projects in connection with petroleum installations.

Make your own assessment of whether carbon capture and storage could be an alternative to electrification of Melkøya with power from the mainland that can be realized by 2029 and implemented without reducing future gas production.

Come back to the Parliament with an assessment of the legal acts in the energy sector that have not yet been incorporated into the EEA Agreement, such as the Energy Performance of Buildings Directives and the Energy Efficiency Directives, and how corresponding national regulations can be implemented outside the EEA Agreement. The assessment must take into account that the rules need to be adapted to Norwegian conditions and be socially equitable.

Initiate the work to reverse the changes in internal legislation resulting from the decision to incorporate the legal acts of the third energy market package, along with the accompanying commission regulations, into the EEA Agreement, and to withdraw Norway from the EU's Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER).
Veto the introduction of the EU's fourth energy market package into the EEA Agreement, and communicate this to the EEA Committee in accordance with Article 102 of the EEA Agreement.
Stop all transfer of power over the energy sector to the EU and begin the work of increasing Norwegian sovereignty in the area again.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a scheme that allows for studying while receiving work assessment allowance (AAP) – based on the same principles as for employees.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals on how to ensure that the protection against dismissal during long-term illness is maintained with an extended sick leave period.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a system where the sick leave period for long-term sick individuals is converted into a time account.
Ensure a practice that strengthens dialogue and collaboration between parties in the follow-up of employees on sick leave.
Propose necessary legislative changes that temporarily raise the income limit for disability benefits to 1 G until the end of 2023.

Review how welfare benefits are affected by recipients having earned income, and provide suggestions for legislative changes that simplify income reporting for benefit recipients, and ensure that users can retain more of their wages and benefits. The review should not be limited to, but must at a minimum consider the following topics: 

- Increase in the income threshold for disability benefits
- Whether elected positions and fees for roles in clubs and associations should be deducted in the same way as other income
- Introduction of an income threshold for social assistance recipients
- Introduction of an income threshold for recipients of work assessment allowance
- Raising the income level prior to disability for those on minimum disability benefits
- Raising the income limit for receiving child supplements in social benefits
- Changing the regulations for the coordination of unemployment benefits and other social benefits so that, for example, disabled individuals receive the same unemployment benefits as healthy individuals in the same situation.
Implement measures to ensure that the processing of complaints regarding sick pay at Nav does not exceed 12 weeks.

Promote legislation that involves user-controlled personal assistance being removed from health legislation and enshrined as an individual right to accommodation based on equality and non-discrimination.

Promote a bill that individuals with practical assistance needs are entitled to user-controlled personal assistance even after reaching the age of 67, regardless of whether they have been granted this right before turning 67.
Promote a proposal to place user-controlled personal assistance under a different administrative body than the municipal health service, such as Nav.
Promote a proposal for a scheme of interest-free loans for municipalities that are upgrading or building new schools to ensure that the requirement for universal design is met.

Present a proposal on how a decision support system can uphold the autonomy of individuals with intellectual disabilities, and submit a draft law that regulates a decision support system for people with intellectual disabilities.

Provide municipalities with state guidelines for housing social mapping that ensures the initiation of planning for independent living for young people with developmental disabilities starts early enough.
Investigate the possibility of alternative and augmentative communication (AAC) being equated with other languages in Norway, and present a separate case to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Ensure necessary regulatory changes to provide individuals with intellectual disabilities in VTA-O with permanent support, regardless of which county they live in, and with a scope similar to what is practiced in HELT MED. The support should also be provided by entities other than Nav, such as HELT MED or vocational rehabilitation companies, preferably by replacing the current subsidies with permanent support for both employees and employers. The government is requested to follow up on this in connection with the state budget for 2024.
Come back in connection with the state budget for 2024 with a long-term and binding plan for how to ensure a significant increase in the number of VTA positions.

Establish a public committee to prepare a report on the economic living conditions of individuals with disabilities and their immediate families, as well as to propose measures to improve the economic living conditions for this group. The report should be completed by July 1, 2024.
