Make an assessment of the economic living conditions and measures for persons with disabilities and their immediate families, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Create a scheduled plan for the cleanup of all closed polluting mines and, before the presentation of the revised national budget for 2024, report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Consider which public authority is best suited to take responsibility for the cleanup of closed and polluting mines where the responsibility is not clarified, within 5 years after the cessation of operations in cases of severe pollution and within 10 years after the cessation of operations in cases of moderate pollution.

Clarify the pollution responsibility for the closed mines where the pollution responsibility is currently not established, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner. In the assessment of who holds the pollution responsibility, the financial responsibility of the companies that have extracted value from the mining activities shall be emphasized.

Gather a comprehensive overview of old abandoned mines in Norway and the pollution risks they pose based on the local qualities of water and soil occurrences, and by the end of the spring session in 2024, report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Ensure a maximum processing time for cases in the Norwegian Patient Injury Compensation.

Review the legislation that allows the Norwegian Patient Injury Compensation to reduce compensation because the patient's expected lifespan is shorter than what was assumed when the compensation was awarded.
Ensure a practice in the Norwegian Patient Injury Compensation that safeguards patient safety and ensures patient contact in cases where it is deemed necessary.
Conduct a comprehensive review of the Norwegian Patient Injury Compensation and present this as a case for the Parliament.

Conduct an evaluation of the Norwegian Patient Injury Compensation where procedures for case handling and processing time are central. The Parliament also requests that the evaluation includes recommendations. The Parliament asks the government to return to the matter in an appropriate manner.

Establish specialist approval for specialized nurses with a 120-credit master's degree in ABIKO nursing and health nursing, and for specialized nurses in mental health, substance abuse, and addiction.
Strengthen efforts against involuntary part-time work caused by excessive workload in full-time positions, especially in female-dominated professions.
Strengthen the efforts to make healthcare services a health-promoting workplace that gives nurse leaders the authority and framework to lead their own profession and nursing services.

Require health enterprises to set clear targets for the proportion of full-time and permanent positions, as well as to develop concrete plans and strategies, and to report annually on how the work of recruiting and retaining employees is carried out.

Develop a program to recruit and retain employees in municipal health and care services. The program must include measures such as leadership support, guidance on how to create good working time arrangements, and how to facilitate increased basic staffing, more full-time and permanent positions, competency measures, and reduced reliance on hiring from commercial actors.

Suggest a change in the funding category for nursing education that ensures educational capacity through adequate funding for enough teachers at educational institutions, skills enhancement for teachers, practice supervisors, sufficient practice placements, and advanced simulation centers.

Investigate how special arrangements are ensured for nurses specializing in critical competencies and legally mandated tasks in services such as anesthesia, pediatric, intensive care, oncology, and surgical nursing, as well as nurses with a master's degree in mental health, substance abuse and addiction, public health nursing, midwifery, and advanced clinical general nursing.
Consider targeted measures such as increased staffing levels to retain seniors in the healthcare services for a longer period.

Ensure good training programs and continuing education opportunities for healthcare workers, as well as their inclusion in teams with nurses to take responsibility for tasks that do not require nursing competence.

Ensure progress in the ambitions to increase the basic staffing levels in healthcare services and secure the necessary conditions to raise the basic staffing levels for each leader in the healthcare services.
Present a long-term plan for nursing education and further education. The plan must help ensure educational capacity that meets society's need for competence in healthcare services.
Consider pilots that can test the economic potential of increasing the base staffing in healthcare services to save on hiring costs in the long term.

To address habilitation in the specialist health service and in the municipal health and care services, as well as the collaboration between the levels, as a specific part of the National Health and Coordination Plan.

Ensure that a national model for guidance in the home and daily life of children with disabilities is developed, and provide recommendations on how municipalities and specialist health services can ensure that relatives receive the support they need.

Come back to the Parliament with concrete measures to strengthen the collaboration between municipal and specialist health services to ensure a good habilitation and rehabilitation service throughout the country.

Return to the Storting with a proposal that ensures the implementation of the "Project for the Development of Rehabilitation Services in Møre and Romsdal," which is a collaboration between the municipalities in Møre and Romsdal, Helse Møre og Romsdal HF, and Helse Midt-Norge RHF, so that the rehabilitation service at Mork is continued.
Ensure that Mork Rehabilitation Center in Health Møre and Romsdal continues with specialized rehabilitation.
Ensure that a multi-year rehabilitation plan for the building stock at Mork is presented, so that the services can be continued in the long term.

Investigate and propose ways to further limit how much a party can claim for the coverage of their own legal costs from the opposing party in civil cases. It should be assessed how other countries limit the losing party's obligation to cover the winning party's legal costs, and whether it would be reasonable to tie the claim to established rates such as the public fee or to set an absolute upper limit.

Come back to the Storting with a proposal to add a new third paragraph to the Dispute Act § 3-8 stating that the court, at the conclusion of the main or appeal hearing, shall inform the parties about the right to request the court's determination of the compensation.

Send out for consultation proposals for further amendments to the Dispute Act to ensure that concealed or blocked addresses are not disclosed as a result of witnesses' obligation to provide names and personal information, and return to the Parliament as soon as possible in an appropriate manner.
Consider changes to the Dispute Act Chapter 6 for cases that must be dismissed due to the proceedings not being completed within the deadline in § 6-11 fourth paragraph.
Consider changes to/exceptions from the absolute ten-year deadline for reopening civil cases that have been adjudicated as part of a criminal case, according to the Dispute Act § 31-6.
Investigate how the parties' legal costs in civil cases can be reduced, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Investigate whether the condition in the Criminal Procedure Act § 456 regarding "general considerations" functions according to the legislator's intent, and whether it should be changed, for example, based on the model from Sweden.
Propose amendments to the law that ensure a significant increase in penalties for violence and threats against public officials.
To establish a legislative committee to review and propose changes to regulations aimed at protecting children and young people in digital spaces.

Return to the Parliament with a proposal for a ban on behavior-based marketing directed at children and consider whether the ban should also apply to special categories of personal data that are derived from data that was not sensitive at the time of collection, such as location data that, when combined, can reveal political or religious affiliation.
Return to the Storting with a proposal for a ban on the use of children's personal data for behavioral marketing, regardless of whether the marketing is aimed at children or adults.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a new paragraph in the Child Act that clarifies the child's independent right to protection of their privacy, in relation to the parents' competence to consent.

Consider various approaches to strengthen the understanding of children's right to privacy in family relationships, including whether mandatory guidance for parents or the distribution of a guide for parents in connection with health station check-ups could be an appropriate method.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a ban on parents publishing children's personal information, including pictures, for commercial purposes online.
Consider how to strengthen education on privacy as a fundamental human right in school teaching.
Investigate the establishment of a research environment for children and digital media, including the consideration of creating a research center for children and digital media.
Consider various approaches to strengthen the understanding of children's right to privacy in family relationships.
Come back to the Parliament with an assessment of how to best regulate that parents do not publish children's personal information, including pictures, for commercial purposes online.
Ensure continued Norwegian participation in the international research project EU Kids Online.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals on how to strengthen the teacher's position in schools, including through increased authority, expanded powers for expelling students, the ability to intervene and protect themselves and others in dangerous situations, and similar measures. The proposals should also include strengthening the school leadership's ability and tools to handle and respond to violence and threats occurring in schools. If necessary for the implementation of the measures, the government is requested to propose specific legislative changes.

Consider the introduction of follow-up teams at heavily burdened schools, evaluate the implementation of fixed routines for police reporting from the school's side in cases of serious violence and threats, and assess what reactions can be imposed on individuals who commit violence and threats in schools.
Ensure increased focus on classroom management in teacher education.
Ensure increased involvement of parents and guardians in cases of serious violations of the school's code of conduct.
To report on statistics and developments regarding violence and threats in Norwegian schools.
Introduce free school choice throughout the country.
Conduct an evaluation of the system for sick leave based on electronic consultations, no later than four years from now.

Ensure that the new overview of waiting lists for round-the-clock care facilities includes information on how many applicants are denied, the reasons for the denials, and the average time individuals spend on the waiting list before receiving a placement.
Ensure equal criteria for qualifying for round-the-clock care placements in all municipalities.
Continue the arrangement with a public overview of waiting lists for round-the-clock care placements until the new system from the Norwegian Directorate of Health is in place.
Investigate and propose a quality- and competence-based staffing standard for round-the-clock care services. The standard should encompass all relevant professional groups.
Facilitate that the Working Environment Act does not hinder flexibility and individual adaptation in the labor market.
Facilitate more flexible working time arrangements, such as the North Sea rotation schedule.

Implement a national multi-year program to recruit and retain personnel in the care and nursing sector by improving the conditions under which employees work. Among the areas that need to be addressed are the work environment, professional leadership, absenteeism, competence development, educational needs in both county and higher education, peer guidance, salary and working conditions, and the assessment of various shift arrangements.
Take the initiative with the member states of the International Criminal Court to remove the specific jurisdictional limitations for the crime of aggression in Article 15 bis of the Rome Statute.
Support the establishment of a special tribunal to investigate and prosecute the crime of aggression against Ukraine.
Promote a case to the Storting regarding the ratification of the Rome Statute's amendment on crimes of aggression (Kampala amendment).
Promote a proposal for a new provision in Chapter 16 of the Penal Code that criminalizes acts of aggression, in line with the Kampala amendment to the Rome Statute.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan to abolish the tax-free scheme. This plan must include a strategy for how Avinor and private airports will be compensated with grants from the state budget.

Set a specific target for emissions reduction from aviation, based on what is necessary to cut in aviation in order to collectively achieve the goal of at least a 55 percent reduction by 2030. The government is requested to investigate and present the necessary measures to achieve this to the Parliament.

Set a goal to transfer at least half of the air passenger traffic to rail, supplemented by other modes of transport, by 2030 on the following routes: Oslo-Bergen, Oslo-Trondheim, Oslo-Stavanger, Oslo-Kristiansand, Oslo-Stockholm, Oslo-Copenhagen. The government is requested to investigate and present the necessary measures to achieve this to the Parliament.
Stop Avinor's goal and efforts to increase the number of pure cargo flights to and from Norwegian airports.
Propose to change the air passenger tax to a seat fee.
Investigate a minimum price for flight routes with good alternative public transport options.
Investigate several solutions to reduce the price of the short-distance network, such as through tickets and resident passes.

Investigate how to change the takeoff fees and terminal fees for aircraft so that the fees are reduced for the short-haul network, for example for light aircraft or specific airports, and increased for other or heavier aircraft.
Test the scope of action in the EEA Agreement, so that it is possible to increase the air passenger tax on international travel, while shielding the regional airport network from tax increases.
Increase the sales requirement for biofuels in aviation to at least 15 percent by 2030.
Consider notifying a gradual reduction in the number of fossil fuel departures in aviation starting from 2030.
To return to the Storting with a proposal to abolish the tax-free scheme and a restructuring of Avinor's financing model.
Review the tax and fee levels for Norwegian aviation and propose reductions that bring Norway in line with neighboring countries, in connection with the national budget for 2024.
Promote a proposal to abolish the air passenger tax no later than in connection with the state budget for 2024.
Promote a proposal to reintroduce a full tax-free scheme in connection with the state budget for 2024.
Facilitate a diversity of ownership of airports through stable framework conditions and a lower tax and fee level for aviation.
Promote necessary proposals to abolish unique Norwegian requirements for technology and fuel that weaken the competitive position of Norwegian aviation.
Facilitate Norway's position as an attractive country for international aviation.

Conduct a review of the economic consequences of the changes made to the tax-free scheme in the state budget for 2023, consider repealing the change, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Conduct a comprehensive review of the tax system and the blending requirement for aviation, with the aim of ensuring that the aviation sector both meets emission targets and has the financial capacity to transition.

Revise the drone strategy to take into account the technological developments that have occurred since 2018, as well as the expected developments moving forward. The revision must be cross-departmental so that an updated strategy addresses how drones challenge aviation safety and public safety, while also covering potential areas of use.
Consider how to facilitate increased competition for the FOT routes, and whether adjustments to the infrastructure are necessary to achieve this.

Investigate how Avinor can be given better incentives to operate more efficiently and under competitive conditions moving forward. Areas where services can be put out to competition should be considered. The Parliament requests the government to return to the Parliament with a plan for this.
Facilitate realistic and predictable frameworks for the operation of non-state airports.
Investigate how Norwegian airlines can strengthen their position in international competition.
Consider how the competitive conditions for Norwegian aviation can be strengthened in bilateral and multilateral air transport agreements.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a startup grant for a green aviation center in connection with the state budget for 2024.

Ensure that the contract for the next tender for the FOT routes, which will be announced in 2024, is structured to allow for the gradual introduction of zero-emission and low-emission aircraft if they become available during the contract period.

Establish a climate partnership with the aviation industry, which can, among other things, review the use of measures to find concrete and comprehensive solutions for the green transition, in order to ensure that we achieve Norway's climate goals.
Facilitate a voluntary scheme for the use of biofuels in aviation.

Present a plan for how Norway can achieve a leading position in the production of sustainable fuel, so that Norway is well positioned through an industrial environment when blending requirements are introduced in the EU, and return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Present a plan to increase the production of advanced biofuels in Norway.
Create a plan for how the FOT routes should be managed if it becomes impossible to replace the current scheduled flights.

Return to the Storting with a specific plan for the prompt realization of E39 Veibust–Blindheim–Moa in Sula municipality and Ålesund municipality. A separate financing plan for the development will also be presented once planning and design are finalized.
Come back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner with a proposal for a plan on how to include children and young people in sports and outdoor activities.
Promote sports and outdoor activities as a focus in its work with the area investment program until 2024, with the goal of increasing operational grants to sports clubs in disadvantaged areas.

Present a plan for how the state will contribute to including all children who wish to participate in local sports clubs and outdoor activities, so that high costs do not hinder individual participation.
Resume regular numbered licensing rounds to ensure predictability and development on the Norwegian continental shelf.
Consider measures that can strengthen the infrastructure for gas and facilitate more exploration for gas in the Barents Sea.
Close the Barents Sea to further oil and gas activities and not grant new exploration licenses there.
Take the initiative for an international agreement to halt new exploration for oil and gas in the Arctic.

Facilitate leadership development in innovation and business development, including ensuring that this is addressed in the new executive program for leaders in specialist health services and municipal health and care services.
Further develop the Health and Care 21 strategy and create an action plan to follow up on Report No. St. 18 (2018–2019) with a focus on innovation activities in municipal health and care services.
Ensure that Husbanken treats public and private developers equally who wish to develop various models for smart homes.
Mapping the potential for increased collaboration with the health industry in relevant parts of the university and research sector.

Identify one or more test municipalities that will serve as a regulatory sandbox to test various new welfare technologies and other solutions that provide better information and improved services to residents.
Facilitate a catapult scheme within the health industry in collaboration with relevant stakeholders and clusters.
Ensure Innovation Norway has a clear mission for business development within health technology and life sciences.

Design public procurement competitions in a way that allows small and medium-sized enterprises to participate, as well as contribute to better utilization of the flexibility in procurement schemes, thereby ensuring predictability, long-term commitment, and innovation.

Facilitate private initiatives for the establishment and scaling of Norwegian companies, such as start-up labs, regulatory sandboxes (controlled testing environments for better understanding of regulatory requirements in relation to the understanding of technological possibilities), and testing centers.
Make public data available to facilitate digital entrepreneurs and businesses, and allow aggregated anonymous data to be used to improve the quality of public services.

Consider whether there is a basis for conducting a new review of the regulations regarding dangerous goods on Norwegian ships, to assess whether the limitation on the number of passengers allowed to transport dangerous goods on ferries in regular ferry routes is appropriately aligned with the safety level.
Work to significantly reduce the quotas on mackerel tuna until the stock is at a substantially higher level than it is today.
Promote a proposal to standardize the expiration time for all gift cards, including digital ones, including considering a minimum duration of 3 years, but consider exceptions for product gift cards.
Promote proposals for necessary changes in laws or regulations that prohibit gift card issuers from deducting fees from the card after it has been sold and handed over to the customer.
Promote proposals for necessary changes in law or regulation to introduce a requirement that the contractual principles applicable to the gift card are made visible on the card itself.

Consider strengthening consumer rights regarding the acquisition and use of gift cards. Furthermore, the government is requested to consider introducing a ban on gift card issuers from deducting fees from the card after it has been sold and handed over to the customer, as well as to introduce an obligation for the contractual principles applicable to the gift card to be clearly displayed on the card itself. It is requested that the government report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Facilitate Norwegian research environments to contribute to the realization of small nuclear power plants for power systems and as an energy source in the transport sector to provide sufficient energy.

Propose the establishment of a dedicated nuclear power authority under the Ministry of Petroleum and Energy, which is allocated sufficient resources to build expertise in the field and processing capacity to handle nuclear power-related matters.

Investigate the need for nuclear power in Norway and the possibilities for expanding nuclear power of the SMR and MSR types, especially in areas where there is a significant future power demand, where grid reinforcement or local power production is needed, and where this can serve as a socially beneficial substitute or supplement to grid development.
Seek collaboration with Sweden, which is now set to begin a large-scale expansion of nuclear power.
Establish a selection that prepares the groundwork for regulations, expertise, and licensing authorities to be clarified in order to start nuclear power production in Norway.
Consider applying for associate partnership in the Euratom Treaty, including EUROfusion, to ensure access to European research funding for Norwegian actors.
Strengthen Norway's research collaboration with Sweden and Finland on the development of new nuclear power technology.
Update the mapping of thorium deposits in Norway and present an analysis of whether thorium can be extracted profitably in Norway, along with suggestions on how it can be implemented.
Ensure that Norway takes an active role in the international research and development of new nuclear power technology, including related to thorium.
Investigate the prerequisites and needs Norway has for nuclear power as part of the energy mix leading up to 2050.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that all construction sites should be emission-free by 2030.
Give municipalities the authority to impose climate requirements on construction sites, for example through a new regulation under the Pollution Control Act.
Ensure that all public procurements require emission-free construction sites that do not contribute to direct or indirect greenhouse gas emissions.
Develop a plan for how all construction sites can become emission-free by 2030, in consultation with the industry, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Ensure that there is sufficient personnel in the Directorate of Immigration as well as in the police districts to reduce the processing time for family reunification cases.
Withdraw instructions given after 2015 that require the immigration authorities to review the residence permits of groups with the aim of revoking citizenship.
Come back with a proposal regarding the statute of limitations for the revocation of citizenship.
Accommodate the Directorate of Immigration's proposal to dismiss revocation cases that were initiated more than 3 years ago.
Prioritize family reunification higher in the allocation letter to the Norwegian Directorate of Immigration from 2024.
Provide an account of the follow-up to decision 383 (2022-2023).
Establish a stronger collaboration between PST and Norwegian educational institutions to uncover espionage from foreign powers.

Terminate research collaboration with countries that Norway does not have security policy cooperation with, and that Norwegian security services believe may pose a particular intelligence threat to Norway.
Prepare a parliamentary report on women's incarceration conditions.

Present a parliamentary report on the future of corrections and the execution of sentences. The report should include measures to improve women's incarceration conditions, strengthen reintegration efforts, prevent isolation and mental health issues, as well as enhance consideration for the victims of crime.
Investigate the overall needs and assess necessary measures to ensure equal prison conditions for female and male inmates.
Propose a legislative amendment that prohibits marriage between cousins by December 31, 2023.
Promote proposals that ensure the Labor Inspection Authority can impose fines on leading individuals in a business that has committed serious violations of the Working Environment Act.
Not to equate larger cities and urban areas with Oslo when it comes to where new and relocated government jobs and enterprises should be located.

Reverse the increase in fine rates for traffic cases decided under the regulation on simplified summons in road traffic cases, so that the rates are reduced to the same level as before February 1, 2023.
Present a case to the Storting regarding a national standard for ferry services that provides predictability for both the public and businesses along the coast.
Better organize the FOT route services to reduce detours and lower travel time and travel expenses to and from the country's airports outside the major cities.
Adjust compensation amounts and fee structures to achieve a better environmental and climate-oriented design of FOT routes.
Come back with a case that assesses how the flight routes through the FOT route offer can be made cheaper for consumers.
Include Bardufoss Airport in the next FOT route agreement.
Halt the work on the closure of Ullevål Hospital and the construction of a new hospital at Gaustad.

Present a comprehensive risk analysis related to the New Aker and New National Hospital project, which also highlights the financial implications for the investment projects at the other hospitals in Health South-East.

Present a case that thoroughly investigates an alternative to the current hospital plans for Oslo, with a phased development of Ullevål Hospital as a complete regional hospital and the establishment of Aker Hospital as a local hospital in Oslo.
Take the initiative to make changes to the EU's Professional Qualifications Directive to allow for the use of simulation as part of the practical training in nursing education.
Explore the scope available within the current Professional Qualifications Directive, so that arrangements can be made for equal and increased use of simulation in Norwegian educational institutions.

Present a science strategy with a ten-year horizon and a five-year rolling plan to promote the development of science competence and the recruitment of science candidates to education and the workforce.
Propose an investment in printed textbooks in the state budget for 2024 to ensure that printed textbooks have a larger role as the central teaching resource in schools.
Require that municipalities purchase printed textbooks as the central teaching material in schools.
Propose an investment in educational resources in the state budget for 2024, to ensure that all students have access to updated learning materials in line with the curriculum renewal.
Propose a significant strengthening of school libraries no later than the state budget for 2024.
Present a plan for how more teachers can have the opportunity to undertake further education and training in the use of digital teaching resources in their instruction.

Present a parliamentary report on the use of digital learning resources in Norwegian schools to provide an overview of their usage, assess the results, and establish a basis for better targeting their use as a supplement to printed learning materials.
Develop and present a binding plan to provide training for teachers on the use of digital teaching materials as well as learning resources and platforms in education.
Promote a proposal to introduce a land use fee for environmental impacts.
Ensure that natural interventions are limited when developing new road facilities, and require compensation areas in case of loss of nature.
Investigate a land use fee for environmental impacts.
Consider introducing a government reward scheme for municipalities that succeed with area-neutral development.
Facilitate more local protection of natural areas by supporting the establishment of boundary regulations where municipalities advocate for this.
Investigate the introduction of a government nature and environmental appeals board for land use decisions that affect natural areas, based on similar arrangements in Sweden and Denmark.
Require land accounting for all new construction and infrastructure projects.
Promote a proposal to ban all drainage of wetlands.
Investigate and implement Nature Investment based on the model of Climate Investment to provide municipalities with a new tool in their efforts to protect nature.
Continue the Enova support for the purchase of light electric vans, and ensure that we achieve the goal that all new light electric vans sold are zero-emission by 2025.
Continue the Enova support for the purchase of biogas trucks.
Introduce a government-controlled registration scheme for biofuels used beyond the blending mandate.
Exclude biofuels with high deforestation risk by 2023.
Grant biogas vehicles exemption from tolls.
Investigate a reduction obligation in the maritime sector, where all renewable fuels are assessed.
Present a plan to increase the production of advanced biofuels in Norway.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a scaling-up plan for biofuels in aviation, aiming for at least a 15% advanced biofuel blend by 2030.

Facilitate a voluntary scheme for the use of biofuels in aviation beyond the blending mandate. Such a scheme could enable companies and individuals to purchase sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). The scheme should allow for collaboration between airlines, fuel producers, and the business community.
Give Enova and/or Bionova the mandate and resources to support the scaling up of biogas production in Norway to 10 TWh by 2035.
Give Bionova an additional mandate to support an increase in biogas production by 1 TWh annually starting from 2024.
Present a plan for increased production of and demand for biogas, and return to the Storting in an appropriate manner no later than in connection with the revised national budget for 2024.
Investigate whether some of the public ferry routes can be operated on biogas.
Investigate and return to the Storting with a proposal for a scheme to ensure public ownership of wind power plants when existing concessions expire and may need to be renewed.
Propose changes to the concession legislation for wind power, so that the same requirements for public ownership apply to wind power as for hydropower.

Investigate and propose measures that require wind power concessionaires to make an annual allocation that is sufficiently large to cover future costs related to the cleanup of the wind power area when the concession expires.

Require Norwegian wind power companies to disclose details about ownership structures as a condition of their licenses and in connection with changes in ownership/financing. These details must include the actual beneficiaries (with a threshold of 5% ownership), the ownership chain linking the company to the actual beneficiaries, the complete corporate structure back through the ownership chain, and detailed information about financing.
Propose to raise the penalty limits in the Penal Code §§ 257 and 258 on human trafficking to a maximum of 10 years and a maximum of 15 years in prison, respectively.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for legal regulation of currently unregulated covert investigation methods.
Delegate the authority to carry out ADR inspections of vehicles to approved workshops.
Look at options such as the obligation to serve as a lay judge, increased fees for lay judges, and ongoing recruitment to the program.
Come back with a plan to gradually increase the fees for lay judges.
Investigate and propose changes to the current lay judge system so that lay judges more accurately reflect the population.
Develop guidelines for how to ensure adequate representation in the selection of lay judges.
Consider the addition of an exception for student housing in the property tax law § 5.
Investigate an exception for climate and environmentally friendly buildings in the property tax law § 7 or § 12.
Promote a bill to remove the cap on maximum property tax.
Come back to the Parliament with the necessary legislative proposals to exempt all residential and vacation properties from property tax starting January 1, 2024.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan for the abolition of property tax on commercial properties, including power plants and networks.
Investigate an adjustment of the fiscal rule.

Implement targeted measures to recruit more boys into teacher education programs, particularly focusing on boys from minority language backgrounds, such as piloting role model schemes and internship programs that allow boys in school to become familiar with the professions. These measures must be followed up with research and evaluation.

Expand the scheme for recruitment scholarships to qualify applicants for teaching positions and the scheme for education scholarships for already employed individuals, through PPU, PPU-Y, or vocational teacher education, to also include primary school teacher education for grades 1-7 and primary school teacher education for grades 5-10.

Establish a new arrangement for individuals who drop out of the five-year primary school teacher education programs and the secondary school teacher education program to qualify for employment in schools, as the current arrangement will expire in 2025.
Take the initiative for a project for permanent, full-time positions in schools and kindergartens together with the parties in the labor market.

Facilitate arrangements with permanent employees to meet substitute needs in schools and kindergartens, both with qualified personnel for teaching positions and other personnel for other positions, and return to the Parliament with a plan for this.
Regulate the system for guidance for newly hired teachers in kindergartens and at all levels of primary and secondary schools by the end of spring 2024.
Create a task-sharing guide for the school, clarifying the various professional groups' areas of responsibility within the school, in collaboration with the relevant parties in the school.
Strengthen the contact teacher resource to give teachers time for their contact teacher duties in addition to their other teaching responsibilities.

Investigate and come back with a plan to increase enrollment in teacher education programs, including better arrangements to offer teacher education outside of the study locations for employees and applicants who wish to qualify.

Initiate knowledge gathering that includes: an investigation into the reasons why teachers, with a particular focus on newly qualified teachers, leave the teaching profession; a risk analysis of the teacher shortage, assessing the consequences of the extensive use of staff in teaching positions without teacher education and the use of unqualified staff in kindergartens; an investigation into teachers' physical and psychosocial working conditions and workload in the school system. Based on the results of the knowledge gathering, the government is to present measures to retain teachers in the school system, improve teachers' working conditions, and strengthen the entire team in schools with relevant competencies.

Develop a strategy for increased recruitment of teachers and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner regarding the strategy. The strategy must be viewed in connection with the arrangements for mentoring newly graduated teachers, the continuing education offerings, new career paths for teachers in schools, and the announced professional report.

Freeze all transactions that involve changes in ownership of property in the childcare sector until the announced comprehensive review of the Childcare Act has been adopted and come into effect, and return to the Parliament with proposals if necessary.
Allocate a separate traffic agreement to Flytoget that lasts at least until 2033, ensuring better capacity utilization at a lower cost to the state.

Clarify that Flytoget will continue as an independent train company, thereby ensuring that the company has the opportunity to be a provider of train services even after the current concession period expires.
Conduct a test closure of the Hammersborg Tunnel.
Abolish the uniquely Norwegian standard of developing a 2/3-lane road and establish the development of a narrow four-lane road as the new standard.
Stop the plans for Møreaksen and instead improve the current road.

Investigate targeted adjustments to import protection that can be made on certain goods by the end of 2024, within the framework of agricultural policy objectives, with the aim of reducing the price of certain goods.

Initiate a parliamentary report that reviews customs protection and should investigate the connections between customs protection, agriculture, and the grocery sector – including examining the consequences of reducing or adjusting customs protection.
Review customs tariffs with the aim of increasing flexibility for prepared food products.
Review the structure and financing of the market regulation schemes so that they operate effectively and contribute to increased competition.

Conduct a comprehensive investigation of the price equalization scheme for milk that can help ensure long-term and predictable competition in the dairy sector, and return to the Storting with a proposal or white paper on this by spring 2024 at the latest.
Ensure that the Competition Authority has the necessary tools and enforces the Competition Act, so that consumers are not harmed by a lack of competition.
Ensure that market data showing the development of market shares at the chain level in the grocery retail sector is published regularly.
Consider measures that can more effectively ensure openness and transparency throughout the entire value chain for grocery products.
Include mortality in the sea phase in the traffic light system for aquaculture. The threshold for qualifying for a green light should be set at a maximum of 10 percent.
Establish an investment grant for fish farmers who want to transition to closed systems or a technology with equivalent environmental standards.
Present measures to the Parliament to increase the production of new sustainable feed ingredients that do not have a negative impact on the environment for aquaculture.
Promote a scheduled escalation plan for agriculture during the spring session of 2023.
Promote proposals to make negligent violations of the Animal Welfare Act punishable.
Propose to increase the upper penalty limit for serious animal crime to six years.
Promote a bill to include the Animal Welfare Act § 37 in the listing in the Criminal Procedure Act § 216 b first paragraph letter b.

Ensure that animal owners who do not comply with orders from the Norwegian Food Safety Authority after serious and repeated violations of the Animal Welfare Act are more easily deprived of the right to engage in livestock farming.
Ensure that the Norwegian Food Safety Authority reports serious violations of the Animal Welfare Act to a greater extent.

Do not renew existing cables to Denmark when they reach their technical lifespan. If Denmark wishes for renewal, the government can take the opportunity to renegotiate the management of foreign cables with the EU.
The application from Statnett for foreign connections to Denmark is submitted for consideration by the Storting.
Ensure that data centers for cryptocurrency mining do not get connected to the power grid by establishing this as a clear criterion in the processing of applications for grid connection.
Present a plan to eliminate all major point emissions by 2030, and return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Quiet plans for the electrification of Norwegian oil and gas production are on hold, and instead, a binding plan for alternatives to electrification that can contribute to emission reductions on the shelf should be presented.

Instruct the oil industry to develop as much offshore wind power as they need for electrification, and to pay for these investments. Electrification should not be used to maintain oil production that is in conflict with the 1.5-degree target.
Require the oil and gas sector to reduce their own emissions through their own offshore power production or CCS.
Stop the electrification of oil and gas installations with power from land and ensure that emission reduction requirements are met with other zero-emission solutions.

Investigate alternative models for connection obligations to the power grid and prioritization of projects, where societal benefits through contributions to emission reductions, nature and environmental considerations, and employment are prioritized. The government is requested to present proposals for necessary legislative changes to the Parliament.
Ensure that a requirement for connection to the power grid for data centers and battery factories is to have a plan for the use of surplus heat.
Present a plan for extensive reductions in point source emissions in Norwegian industry.
Set "rarity" as a separate criterion and in this way ensure that the distinctive characteristics of rare diagnoses are captured.
Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner with a plan for how to ensure quick access to new and available medications for patients with rare diagnoses.

Establish a public committee to provide an updated knowledge base on prioritization in the healthcare system, and assess changes so that the new prioritization report can best address today's and future challenges.

Return to the Storting with a proposal for a change in the financing responsibility for hospitals in the treatment of rare diseases through a national scheme, for example, a fund for rare diseases or a nationally funded prescription.
Establish a dedicated development company responsible for investments in the construction, operation, and maintenance of hospitals, modeled after Nye Veier AS.

In connection with the national health and hospital plan 2024–2027, a financing model for hospitals is proposed that distinguishes between operations and investments, and ensures adequate funding for hospital development, so that hospitals are built that are efficient and have the capacity to meet the needs.

Promote the necessary legislative amendments to ensure the requirement of self-sufficiency in secondary relocation, so that refugees must reside in the first settlement municipality until they are self-sufficient.
Present a plan for implementation and a model for financing marine base maps in the coastal zone in connection with the state budget for 2024.
Accelerate the work of creating marine base maps for all Norwegian fjords and coastal areas within the baseline.

Discuss how the arrangement for impact assessments of plans and measures can be carried out independently, so that the ties between the developer and the assessor are broken, while ensuring that it does not lead to increased costs for the state or municipalities.
Initiate an investigation into how hundreds of unaccompanied minor asylum seekers have been able to disappear from asylum reception centers and care facilities since 2015.

Promote a bill stating that unaccompanied minor asylum seekers should be under the responsibility of the child welfare services until they turn 18, with accompanying aftercare services until they turn 25.
Promote legislation that requires unaccompanied minor asylum seekers to be quickly settled in municipalities after arriving in Norway, regardless of the status of their asylum application.

Ensure that the best interests of the child are always the basis for the housing arrangements of unaccompanied minor asylum seekers, and that there is encouragement for the use of foster homes, family homes, and smaller housing communities.
Demand follow-up after health assessments of unaccompanied minor asylum seekers, with particular emphasis on mental health support.

Amend the prosecution instruction § 7-4 in accordance with parliamentary resolution no. 129 (2015–2016), so that it explicitly states that investigations into cases of missing children from asylum reception centers shall always be initiated.
Amend the prosecution instruction § 7-4 to explicitly state that investigations into cases of missing children from care centers must always be initiated.
Promote a proposal to introduce a two-party process in the Immigration Appeals Board.
Lower the threshold in the immigration regulations so that more asylum seekers have the opportunity to explain themselves verbally.
Come back with proposals for more legal assistance for asylum seekers in line with the recommendations from the Legal Aid Committee.
Ensure that relevant competence requirements are established as a condition for being a member of the UNE.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a tax reform for the aquaculture industry that takes into account the need to extract a larger share of the industry's super profits while also introducing an environmental tax to address the industry's environmental issues.
Promote a proposal for an environmental tax to replace the current tax on fish production. The environmental tax is expected to decrease as environmental challenges at a given facility diminish.

Consider a revised arrangement for the allocation of revenues from the resource rent tax between the state and municipalities if an environmental tax is introduced simultaneously with the implementation of a resource rent tax for aquaculture.
Return to the Storting with an assessment of alternative models and recommendations for the taxation regime for aquaculture. It is assumed that the industry will be involved.

Return to the Storting with proposals for changes to the aquaculture tax that can provide a more moderate, competitive, and sustainable tax level, and that facilitates sustainable growth, development, and innovation. An income-graded production fee and an increased ordinary corporate tax must, in this context, be further investigated and considered as alternatives to the model that the government has based its proposals on.

Ensure that environmental indicators for the traffic light system are in place from the auction round in 2024. Indicators will be investigated and assessed, including impacts on sea trout, emissions, and mortality, until the state budget for 2024 investigates proposals to introduce a resource rent tax on offshore aquaculture. The investigation must clarify whether there is a basis for resource rent on offshore aquaculture. Introduce a scheme that allows for reduced production due to the traffic light system to be produced using closed technology. Present a proposal for an environmental technology scheme during 2023. In the spring of 2024, present a case for better organization of cooperation between authorities and the aquaculture industry to ensure more holistic management, better sustainability, and improved fish welfare. In the spring of 2024, present measures for increased processing of seafood in Norway. Ensure that the Aquaculture Fund is allocated funds as if the production fee had been increased from 56 cents to 90 cents from January 1, 2023.

Investigate other changes in the regulations for free policies that clearly benefit customers, including that life insurance companies and the state collaborate to manage the free policies as a pension service company, and that the state takes over the free policies and guarantees better regulation, for example in line with the development of the National Insurance Scheme's basic amount.
Investigate other changes in the regulations for free policies that clearly benefit customers, including the possibility of transferring more types of pensions to their own pension account.
Investigate changes in the regulations for free policies that are clearly in favor of customers, including the possibility of transferring multiple types of pensions to a personal pension account.
Establish a fast-working committee with representation from affected parties, with a mandate to examine possible regulatory changes to further secure the values in and regulations of free policies.

Establish a fast-working committee with a mandate to propose alternatives to and changes in the shareholder model and the exemption method that can ensure that all owners are taxed on the same basis as wage earners.
Investigate how the Tax Committee's proposals for changes in the taxation of housing and real estate may affect the rental market and the availability of rental properties.
Investigate how the Tax Committee's proposals for changes in the taxation of housing and real estate may affect the housing market and the ability of different income groups to own their own homes.

Establish a committee to investigate an updated mandate for monetary policy in light of the economic challenges we face now and in the coming years. The inflation target should be assessed against other relevant considerations, such as employment, financial stability, the exchange rate, and green transition.
Make the transition to a zero-emission society part of the purpose of Norges Bank.
Consider whether the level of, and/or the emphasis on, the inflation target in monetary policy should be changed, and report back to the Storting during 2023.
Clarify to the Central Bank of Norway that the consideration for employment and production is on par with the consideration for stable monetary value in the current purpose clause.
Bring a proposal to the Storting that gives municipalities that wish to do so the opportunity to conduct trials with local drug reforms.
Ensure that no new private hospitals are established or expanded until the shortage of healthcare personnel is under control.
Ensure that the available capacity of private healthcare providers is utilized to reduce waiting times and ensure faster treatment for Norwegian patients.

Return to the Parliament with a proposal for an approval scheme that ensures that private health institutions and private health services within specialist healthcare that wish to establish operations must apply through an approval scheme where patient safety, public safety, and preparedness are assessed, and where rejections can be given if the establishment may threaten access to healthcare personnel for public health services.
Ensure an approval scheme where private health institutions and healthcare services within the specialist health service that wish to expand or change their operations must apply for new approval.

Introduce requirements for private general practitioner services, hospitals, and other actors providing healthcare services to report their operations and activities to national registers, so that we can, among other things, gain an overview of the number of full-time equivalents and services, as well as their use of blue prescriptions, referrals, and sick leave.

Promote a proposal to amend the user room law and the associated regulations so that individuals with a long-term substance addiction cannot be denied access to user rooms, even if they do not have or have not had a harmful injection practice.
Facilitate increased research on the causes and aftereffects of abortion.
Introduce monthly payments of the one-time grant, with a total level of at least 2 G from July 1, 2023.

Investigate how the parental leave scheme can be changed so that the money follows the child rather than the parents' connection to the labor market, and return to the Storting in an appropriate manner.
Ensure that free long-acting contraception is available for everyone over 16 years old, and for those under 26 years old starting from January 1, 2024.

Strengthen and enhance the information offerings and access to information regarding hormonal contraception, and ensure that the information is also made available through various channels and media platforms.

Strengthen teachers' opportunities for regular professional development so that they are confident adults when interacting with students in sex education, as well as to explore the possibility of enhanced collaboration with the school nurse in the implementation of the teaching.
Ensure more research on contraception for men.

Strengthen Amathea's framework for and ability to provide information and guidance services, as well as ensure that Amathea has the financial resources to maintain physical offices located near all university hospitals, and return to the Parliament in the revised national budget for 2023 or at the latest in the state budget for 2024.
Ensure that a new action plan for continued reduction in the number of abortions is ready when the current plan's period ends in 2024.
Reintroduce a comprehensive strategy against labor market crime across all relevant ministries, including economic crime.

Initiate a follow-up evaluation of the new provisions for information sharing and use between the agencies in the labor crime collaboration, so that they can be quickly improved if necessary, as well as assess the need for common provisions in connection with joint operations.

Clarify the collaboration between the National Cross-Agency Analysis and Intelligence Center (NTAES) and the labor crime centers, including assessing whether NTAES should be given a larger role in analysis, reporting, and knowledge building in the field of labor crime.
Ensure that the a-crime centers prioritize operational controls, sanctions, and investigations, as well as that the knowledge gathering is organized to support this.
Ensure that the a-crime collaboration prioritizes the use of arrest and seizure from criminal actors.

Ensure that the police have clear legal grounds for participation in the control group and knowledge building at the a-crime centers, and if necessary, return to the Parliament with proposals for updated legal provisions.

Ensure that the a-crime centers have a plan for collaboration with non-governmental actors who are closely connected to the victims of labor market crime, as well as establishing a contact point / a tip solution.

Promote the proposal that the right to education in Kven and Finnish at primary schools in Troms and Finnmark depends on meeting a certain minimum requirement for the number of students, in accordance with current legislation.

Promote proposals that take into account the interests of the Training Offices as currently formulated in the regulations to the Education Act, § 11-2. Training Office and training ring, "A training office is an organization for companies that collaborate on training for apprentices, practice letter candidates, and/or training candidates. A training contract or training agreement is then signed between the apprentice, practice letter candidate, or training candidate and the training office."

To propose an amendment to the Education Act regarding the introduction of preschool for six-year-olds based on play, kindergarten pedagogy, and no homework, and that children start in 1st grade at the age of seven.

To propose changes to the Education Act § 9-a in dialogue with the parties in the school, ensuring that both students' and teachers' legal rights are better protected in the work towards a safe school environment.
To propose changes to the Education Act that ensure printed teaching materials are the primary teaching resource in schools, while digital teaching materials serve as a supplement.
To propose a mobile phone ban in primary schools.
Ensure that all acquired competencies are given a designation, including competencies other than educational and vocational competencies.
Conduct a pilot project with SMS notifications to parents regarding absences at school.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to introduce optional second language in schools.
Ensure that mother tongue instruction is no longer a public task to finance or organize.

Return to the Parliament with a proposal to transform the bullying ombudsmen into a bullying supervision authority, transfer the current supervisory tasks from the county governor to the bullying supervision authority, propose additional sanction options and measures for the bullying supervision authority, and make the entire change revenue-neutral for the public sector by ensuring that resources follow the transfer of responsibilities.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to introduce objective responsibility for the students' school environment for the schools.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that the municipality shall have an obligation to consult the bullying supervision authority, and that a statement shall be issued by the supervision authority in cases where municipalities see reason to report a child's family to child welfare services when the school/municipality has received a report of a bullying case from the child or their family.

Come back with a new proposal regarding the right to complete upper secondary education, which prevents a possible unintended consequence where more students choose to take breaks in their upper secondary education instead of completing it within the standard time, as well as preventing more students from dropping out.

In the fall of 2023, a plan of action against violence and threats in schools will be presented. The action plan will include both preventive measures and responses to those who commit serious acts, and relevant stakeholders should be involved in the work.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal where the opportunity to mark Norwegian traditions, including the holding of school services, is anchored in the Education Act.
Establish in regulation that students participating in adult education shall have a contact teacher.
Establish in regulations that adult education must have a principal with pedagogical competence, on par with primary education.

Develop a new and more flexible follow-up regulation without penalties related to specific percentage thresholds, which includes a follow-up guarantee for students with concerning levels of absenteeism, as well as access to self-reporting and parental reporting in case of illness.
Investigate and return to the Storting with a proposal to enshrine Statped as a national special education support system.
Investigate and propose a guiding standard for staffing and competence in the Educational Psychological Service (PP-service) and its sizing.
Promote a proposal to amend the Education Act to include requirements for other professional groups and competencies in schools, such as health and social care competencies.

Promote a proposal to amend the Education Act, where the after-school program (SFO) receives its own chapter in the law. Elements in this chapter should include that students in grades 1-4 have a legal right to SFO, SFO must have staff with the competence to provide a responsible service in accordance with the goals of the framework plan, and who have practical-pedagogical competence regarding issues related to the students, work on the social environment, and injury prevention. The leader of SFO should not be counted as part of the basic staffing of SFO, and the resources that follow children with decisions on special adaptations during school hours should also follow the child into SFO.

Present a proposal for an amendment to the Education Act, ensuring that vocational students have a genuine right to an apprenticeship, where the county municipality is obligated to initiate a process to place students in apprenticeships starting from the beginning of their third school year if the student has not already secured an apprenticeship.
Come back to the Parliament with concrete proposals on how to increase the teacher density in first grade of primary school.

Come back to the Parliament with a separate legislative proposal to follow up on the work, include the parties in the school in the efforts, and propose amendments to the Education Act that establish requirements for school owners to hire teachers with approved teacher education for teaching positions, as well as a legal basis for regulations that specify this further, including that exemptions can be granted if there are no qualified applicants with approved teacher education, and a condition that the person hired must complete a qualification program.

Promote a proposal for legislation stating that only the teacher can have the academic responsibility for the education. It should be emphasized that the academic responsibility includes preparing and following up on the education and, as a general rule, being present with the student during the education. Other staff may assist with the education.
Abolish the absence limit in upper secondary education.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal on how to ensure individual rights to Kven education, based on the model of Sami education in the Education Act.
Present to the Storting a proposal to amend the Education Act regarding the legal right to Sami educational materials.
Promote a proposal to clarify the procedural rules of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child in the Education Act.

Investigate and return to the Storting with a proposal to amend the Education Act to enshrine students' right to good, green outdoor areas, as well as to include larger area standards for schoolyards in regulations or guidelines.
Consider whether a requirement for intensive training in basic skills should be introduced in secondary schools.
Address the various candidate types within vocational education and training, such as practice letter candidates and apprenticeship candidates, in the work of following up on the new education law.
Consider opening up the possibility of offering the International Baccalaureate (IB) both in primary and secondary schools, and return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Clarify and increase the scope of action that school leaders, parents, and students have to utilize alternative learning arenas.

Conduct a knowledge gathering on the extent of the use of learning support resources in education that are not available in both language forms, and report back to the Parliament with an assessment of the degree to which this affects particularly the rights of Nynorsk students to education in their own language.
Consider expanding the target group of the follow-up service to also include students in 10th grade.

Come back to the Parliament with an assessment of how the implementation of decisions regarding individual adjustments to education can be ensured and appealed. Pending this, the Parliament requests the government to assume that the lack of implementation of individual adjustments to education can still be appealed to the county governor.

Review and assess the experiences of replacing homework with schoolwork, as well as facilitating for municipalities and schools that wish to do this, in close dialogue with teachers, students, and municipalities.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that achieved employment after completing education becomes one of the indicators in the funding system for higher education, in accordance with the majority decision in the "Competence Report" Meld. St. 14 (2019-2020) Innst. 370 S (2019-2020).
To return to the Storting with an incentive scheme aimed at institutions that strengthens their prioritization of education for the green transition.

Investigate the structure of the funding categories for the performance-based allocation, and allow the sector to be consulted further before a final implementation of changes to the funding categories.

Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner with a financing model for further and continuing education that does not constitute an additional expansion of the current regulations regarding self-funding for public higher education.
Investigate a scheme that requires the public sector to take in apprentices.
Maintain a results-based indicator for external revenues from the EU in the funding system, and return with proposals on this to the Storting in connection with the state budget for 2024.
Establish a fast-working committee that examines occupational health from a gender perspective.
Evaluate and present measures that reduce the impact of racism on health.
Set aside the proposed tightening of the smoking law.
Not introducing a 16-year age limit for the purchase of energy drinks in Norway. This is being handled well by the Food Industry's Professional Committee.

Ensure that established services for relatives, such as the Norwegian Women's Public Health Association's guidance service, are continued. The government is also requested to ensure low-threshold services that can assist relatives of individuals with substance abuse and psychiatric issues.
Ensure that ROS (Counseling on Eating Disorders) continues to provide its low-threshold services to individuals struggling with eating disorders.
Promote a proposal to remove VAT on fruits and vegetables, so that economics does not become a barrier to eating environmentally friendly and healthy.
Present a separate case on the prevention and treatment of obesity during the spring of 2024.
To work towards ensuring that economics does not become a barrier to the opportunity for a healthy diet, starting by removing VAT on Norwegian-produced fruits and vegetables.
Ensure that free HPV vaccination is provided to particularly vulnerable groups.
Ensure an expanded screening offer for women under 30 by providing HPV testing alongside vaccination, and to a greater extent offer self-testing/home testing.
Ensure tailored and close follow-up of HPV-positive women.
To clarify the requirements for the psychosocial working environment in the working environment regulations in order to strengthen preventive workplace efforts.
To develop a plan for more effective health, safety, and environment (HSE) work in the health and care sector.
Establish a funding scheme for sports clubs nationally, with the condition of low participation fees and integration based on the same model as the neighborhood club project in Oslo.

Ensure the security of supply of critical medicines in Norway by splitting contracts for the procurement of medicines into two parts, with one of these parts reserved for Norwegian actors. This is to ensure emergency production.

Establish a state-owned company, StatMed, which will ensure national self-production of pharmaceuticals in Norway and collaborate with the rest of the pharmaceutical industry and the public healthcare system on national development and production of medicines.
Take the initiative to develop a global antibiotic convention, or a similar binding legal instrument, to ensure that the world's population has access to effective antibiotics in the future.
To ensure that the escalation plan against violence in close relationships is followed up with necessary resources and includes a power perspective.

Follow up on the requirements in the regulations regarding environment and health in kindergartens, schools, and after-school programs with a program initiative focused on upgrading outdoor areas for varied physical activity for children and youth through a program initiative in the national plan for sports facilities.
Develop a strategy for the use of nature experiences and outdoor activities as prevention, treatment, and rehabilitation measures in public health work.
Follow up the transportation route project with a program initiative for trails and hiking routes in the national plan for sports facilities.
Establish a grant scheme to set up more kitchens in nursing homes and care centers with round-the-clock care services.
Ensure that free HPV vaccination is provided to all men and women under 30 years old.

Include dental services and facilitate good communication and collaboration between dental services and the rest of the healthcare system, and ensure that financial issues do not hinder access to healthcare.
To strengthen the funding of school health services and health stations.
Strengthen the prevention work aimed at children and young people by enhancing the school health service.
Ensure that all new mothers have access to necessary breastfeeding support and the opportunity for extended hospital stay if needed.
To ensure lower out-of-pocket maximums and expand free healthcare services up to 18 years old, so that financial constraints do not hinder the right to health.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals that can ensure more varied housing options for individuals who are lonely, insecure, and/or have other needs, in addition to the current nursing homes and care facilities.
Establish more psychiatric ambulances in Norway.
Ensure that individuals who are actively using substances also have the opportunity to access crisis center services.
Halt the reduction of inpatient beds in psychiatry, and ensure that the round-the-clock services are strengthened.
Ensure to strengthen early intervention in psychiatry and that the low-threshold services in the municipalities are enhanced.
Introduce a requirement that healthcare personnel with patient contact have relevant vaccinations. The Parliament requests the government to return in an appropriate manner.
Open for the sale of tobacco-free snus in Norway.

Conduct a comprehensive review and modernization of the alcohol advertising ban in the Alcohol Act with the aim of eliminating gray areas and ambiguities. The Parliament requests the government to return in an appropriate manner.
Contribute to increasing knowledge about vaccines to ensure the highest possible vaccination coverage in the population.
Establish a new national antibiotic strategy.
Continue the collaboration with the food industry to facilitate healthy products in grocery stores and ensure clear labeling of healthy alternatives.
Ensure that the referral to Pusterom, or another tailored training program, is included in the care pathways for cancer at the time of diagnosis.
Take the initiative for a broad Nordic collaboration on the production and storage of pharmaceuticals and infection control equipment in the Nordic region.

Establish arrangements that help reduce loneliness among the elderly by involving volunteer organizations, as well as strengthening volunteer centers so that they can create meeting places and arenas for lonely seniors.
Revise the National Strategy for Voluntary Work in the Health and Care Sector in collaboration with Voluntary Norway and KS.

Promote a proposal to introduce an adult vaccination program and establish an automatic reminder system for vaccine renewals on helsenorge.no in accordance with what the Parliament has already decided. The Parliament requests the government to return in an appropriate manner.
Not to introduce a ban on online sales of tobacco products.

Ensure that there are enough institutional places within mental health and substance abuse services, and that both private/non-profit and public offerings are facilitated to ensure patients have the freedom of choice and access to help when they need it.
Follow up on the Parliament's decision to develop a national action plan to combat loneliness during 2024.

Present a parliamentary report on the scheme for user-controlled personal assistance (BPA) based on NOU 2021:11 Self-managed is well-managed. The Parliament requests the government to return in an appropriate manner.

Clarify in the regulations for value-added tax that swimming pools operated by municipalities, including inter-municipal companies, on a non-commercial basis, are entitled to compensation for value-added tax.
To continue and develop the model development program for clinical nutritionists as a resource for the care services.
Regulate a ban on the marketing of unhealthy food and drinks aimed at children and young people under 18 years old.
Promote a proposal to introduce a 16-year age limit for the purchase and sale of energy drinks.

Facilitate increased use of green prescriptions and request the government to investigate new follow-up models for green prescriptions, for example with more guided activities and diet. The Parliament requests the government to return in an appropriate manner.
Ensure that suicide prevention measures are strengthened.

Ensure that the ongoing work on complementary education for healthcare personnel from non-EEA countries includes proposals on how the education can be made free of charge with a binding period in the public healthcare service.

Ensure that healthcare professionals who have received their education outside the EEA but are residing in Norway can enter a fast-track program where they can complete the necessary education and training to obtain authorization to work as healthcare professionals in Norway – in order to address the staffing challenges we face in the healthcare system.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for the introduction of a national travel card, so that passengers can use all trains and all public transport with one travel card, at a monthly price of 499 kroner for adults and 249 kroner for children and young people up to 18 years old.
Ensure that the state covers at least 70% of the development costs for large public transport projects and public transport hubs.

Establish a public committee with a mandate to examine the organization of Norway's entire transport sector, with the aim of potentially creating a unified overarching transport directorate that can consider all transport solutions and needs as a whole.
Promote proposals to establish more vocational driver education programs for various types of public transport in high schools to ensure sufficient recruitment for future transportation needs.
Strengthen the urban growth agreements with increased state funding to 80% in connection with the proposal for the national budget for 2024.

Present a proposal for a system that financially rewards county municipalities and municipalities that effectively reduce car traffic, with increased operational and investment funds for public transport, cycling, and walking.
Establish and secure funding for express bus routes where there is no train service, but high demand for express lines.
Create a plan to open and renovate partially and completely closed or unused railway routes, where there is currently a real need for train transport.

Ensure that all long-distance trains can offer bicycle storage for travelers where such an option is not currently available, and increase the capacity for bicycle storage where it is available today.
Investigate a national travel card in Norway that applies to travel throughout the country, on buses and railways, and report back to the Storting in connection with the state budget for 2024.
Increase the government funding for student discounts on public transport from 40% to 50%.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a strengthened focus on maintenance within the train and railway sector to reduce the number of delays and cancellations and to increase punctuality and reliability.
Follow up on the ambition to strengthen the focus on public transport, cycling, and walking in smaller urban areas from the National Transport Plan 2022–2033.
Strengthen the requirements for universal design related to public transport, so that it becomes a real option for everyone.
Abolish the current system of city packages financed by tolls.

Promote a proposal to establish a scheme with state funding for public transport and larger transportation projects, which requires that the county municipalities/municipalities do not use revenue from tolls in the local part of the financing. This should apply to both investment and operation.

Promote a proposal to amend the Road Act § 27 so that revenues from tolls cannot be used for bicycle paths, public transport, urban development, and other purposes that are not directly related to roads and improved or increased accessibility for motorists and other road traffic.

Propose a program to reduce the maintenance backlog on the county road network. The program should outline a ramp-up plan for maintenance that reduces the backlog for roads, bridges, and tunnels. A binding financing model will be established without the use of tolls.

Investigate and present proposals for regulations regarding the state's road budgets within the national budget for 2024, which should ensure that maintenance is prioritized higher and that the maintenance backlog is reduced.
