Calculate the socio-economic profitability of reducing the maintenance backlog on national and county roads and use this as a basis for prioritization in the National Transport Plan.

Develop a comprehensive and binding plan to reduce the maintenance backlog on national roads and county roads in collaboration with the county municipalities, and return with proposals to the Parliament as part of the National Transport Plan.

Look at how the role of pharmacies in vaccination efforts can be strengthened, among other things to increase the vaccination rate in the population and ensure proper medication use. The Parliament requests the government to return in an appropriate manner.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal on how to strengthen Sami education by making Sami after-school programs free and lowering the prices for Sami kindergartens.

Come back to the Parliament with a plan, developed in collaboration with the parties in the labor market and the Sámi Parliament, on how to recruit more teachers and skilled workers with Sámi backgrounds, as well as measures to include and retain Sámi-speaking employees with informal qualifications, for example through further education in the workplace.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan for a national network for schools with Sami students.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how to strengthen the system of Sámi guides.

Consider measures that can help strengthen the scope and quality of the offerings in the Sámi kindergartens, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner. The assessment should include both existing practices, the framework plan for kindergartens, and the kindergarten law. The Sámi Parliament should be involved in the work.
Investigate and implement a turnover requirement for recycled phosphorus in fertilizers.
Investigate and establish a scheme that rewards farmers for using fertilizers based on recycled raw materials that are currently underutilized, such as fish sludge and sewage sludge.
Investigate and implement a system that mandates or ensures that sludge from the aquaculture industry is collected, recycled, and utilized as a resource for business development and production.
Send proposals for the revised fertilizer regulation out for consultation, no later than the fall of 2023.

Ensure that measures with action levels 1 and 2, as referred to in the Norwegian Environment Agency's report "Green Transition: Climate Action Analysis for Petroleum, Industry, and Energy Supply," are implemented through necessary requirements and support schemes.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals for concrete measures that will reduce emissions in the capped sector by at least 55% by 2030.

Follow up on the ownership message's requirement that state-owned companies invest in accordance with the Paris Agreement by demanding that Equinor halt investments in new fossil projects and shift its investments towards renewable energy.

Assume that the CO2 tax will be increased to 3,000 kroner by 2030, and implement a green people's bonus, also known as climate reward, as a principle for returning part of the increased revenue from higher environmental taxes to the people.
Come back to the Storting with an action plan for energy efficiency in all parts of the Norwegian economy no later than when the state budget for 2024 is presented.
Return to the Parliament with a proposal for a requirement for zero emissions for all service vessels in the aquaculture industry. The requirement will come into effect from July 1, 2024.

Give Enova an additional mandate to follow up on the implementation of a program for point emissions and further request the government to introduce carbon contracts for difference for emission reductions in industry, particularly prioritized towards biocarbon.
Ensure that Equinor ends new investments in oil and gas, and reallocates investments to other projects that contribute to emission reductions.
Prepare and present an updated "Climate Action Plan" with measures and instruments that can achieve the climate target for the non-ETS sector by 2030 compared to 2005.
Set a sub-goal for new solar energy of 8 TWh by 2030.

Amend the regulation on emission requirements for vehicles in public procurement for road transport, so that it also regulates the procurement of transport and can require that emission-free freight (electricity, hydrogen, or biogas) is ordered where three or more providers can offer this.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal for the introduction of VAT exemption for electric leisure boats.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a separate toll class for electric vans, which ensures exemption from tolls for electric vans.

Come up with suggestions for additional measures that increase the incentives for using electric cars in car sharing, such as removing VAT or introducing VAT compensation for short-term rentals of electric cars.
Create a specific goal and a strategy to increase natural carbon uptake and storage in Norwegian ecosystems.
Mapping the deep sea as a carbon reservoir and safeguarding these reserves, which are important carbon stores and habitats for a variety of species.
Ensure that stored carbon also becomes a conservation criterion in the further development of marine protection in Norwegian waters in accordance with the commitments of the nature agreement.

Set ambitious targets for installed solar energy by 2030 of at least 8 TWh, with interim goals already for 2025 and a concrete action plan that enables the realization of these targets. The government should return to the Parliament with the goals and action plan by the revised budget in 2024. The plan should include both public buildings, commercial buildings (including agriculture), and apartments, housing cooperatives, and single-family homes.
Set requirements for zero emissions in the next bidding period for the Coastal Route from 2030.
Present an updated Climate Plan to the Storting with specific measures that demonstrate how the climate goals for 2030 will be achieved.
Ensure that the electrification of Yggdrasil with power from land is not carried out until new power sources and reinforcements of the power grid in the area are established.

Present all plans for development and operation (PUD) as well as all plans for the construction and operation of facilities for the transport and utilization of petroleum (PAD) that are a result of the oil tax package, for consideration in the Storting, regardless of size.
Reject the applications for the development and operation plan for the Yggdrasil area and Fenris, as well as the further development of Valhall.

To update the guidelines for the plan for development and operation (PUD guidelines) where it is specified that combustion emissions should be assessed for each individual project in relation to the remaining carbon budget for the 1.5-degree target, in accordance with the Supreme Court ruling in 2020 and the recommendations of the Norwegian Institute for Human Rights.
Ensure that impact assessments are conducted by independent actors, and that the assessments are based on the premise that Norway will adhere to its obligations under the Paris Agreement.
To stress test the socio-economic climate risk for all areas covered by the oil tax package based on oil and gas prices that will result from the world achieving the 1.5-degree target.

Return to the Storting with a separate proposal on CO2 storage that ensures that the impact on the climate and rapid climate gains are prioritized in future allocations related to CO2 storage, in the same way that considerations for safe and secure storage are taken into account.
Ensure that the impact on climate and rapid climate gains are emphasized in future allocations related to CO2 storage, along with considerations for safe and secure storage.
Consider raising the concession limit for wind power production in and near commercial buildings.
Consider raising the limit on the number of wind turbines in and near commercial buildings that trigger the requirement for a license under the Energy Act regulations § 3-1.
Present a plan with measures and instruments that ensure the development of at least 10 TWh of renewable local energy in already developed areas by 2030.
Raise the concession limit for wind power production in and near commercial buildings.
Raise the limit for how many wind turbines in and near commercial buildings that trigger the requirement for a license according to the Energy Act regulations § 3-1.

Present proposals for changes that allow for area solutions and sharing of locally produced electricity and energy storage between buildings with different property and usage numbers, and return to the Storting in an appropriate manner during the spring of 2024.

Present a plan with goals and measures to promote the development of renewable energy production in industrial areas, along highways, and in other developed areas, with the aim of achieving at least 5 TWh of production by 2030.
Review and remove regulatory barriers for energy production on commercial areas and other developed land.
Raise the limit on how much self-produced renewable energy can be shared from commercial buildings, in a way that does not hinder the rational development of the grid.
Facilitate that more positions advertised in the public administration are location-independent.

Ensure that good models for knowledge sharing between various state agencies regarding decentralized job structures in a new digital everyday life are established, and that clear expectations are set for all state agencies to facilitate this.
Review and promote necessary proposals for changes to the concession law to facilitate that more of the existing homes in the country become subject to permanent residency.
Investigate relevant immediate measures in response to the rising rental prices and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Ensure that the requirements for housing layout, based on the Housing Bank's previous recommendations and current guidelines for universal design, are incorporated into the building technical regulations.
Ensure that the requirements for good outdoor spaces with sufficient area and sunlight for communal gathering/meeting/playing are incorporated into the building technical regulations.
Consider a provision for municipalities to impose higher property taxes on uninhabited homes.
Ensure that the alcohol prices in the Armed Forces' messes follow the prevailing market price.
Facilitate unannounced alcohol serving inspections and supervision of the Armed Forces' messes.

Ensure an independent investigation of sexual harassment, abuse, and other instances of unacceptable behavior in the Armed Forces, as well as the handling of whistleblower cases in the defense sector. The investigation should be completed by the end of 2023.
Present immediate measures to upgrade Norway's air defense.
Promote a proposal to reestablish the Coastal Home Guard.
Consider reestablishing a one-year officer training school in the branches of the armed forces and locating some of this officer education in Northern Norway.

Ensure that in the work on the new long-term plan for the Armed Forces (LTP), it is assessed how the Armed Forces' readiness, operational capability, endurance, and volume can be increased through greater use of reservists.

Ensure that in the work on the new long-term plan for the Armed Forces, consideration is given to accelerating the expansion and upgrading of existing air defense systems, as well as the procurement of long-range air defense, in relation to the current procurement plan (FAF) 2022–2029.

Ensure that in the work on the new long-term plan for the Armed Forces, a comprehensive assessment is made of how the defense capability in Norway's coastal domain can be strengthened across the branches of the military.
Come back to the Storting with additional measures to improve the retention of employees and recruitment in the Armed Forces.
Return to the Parliament with a comprehensive action plan against bullying and sexual harassment in the Armed Forces.
Accelerate an evaluation of the education reform in the Armed Forces and the arrangement for military personnel.
Conduct a comprehensive assessment of the proportion of substance-dependent individuals who are victims of violence, and the need for crisis centers for people in active substance use.
Develop national guidelines and quality requirements for crisis center services for individuals in active substance use.
Ensure that there is an updated overview of which crisis centers accept individuals in active substance use, which is made available to relevant support agencies.

Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how more municipalities can be included in the TryggEst project, so that healthcare personnel in primary care receive training in identifying individuals in active substance abuse who are victims of violence.
Update the guidelines for the crisis center law so that it more clearly addresses the crisis center services for vulnerable groups.
Promote proposals for changes to the crisis center law, where the municipality's responsibility for crisis center services for vulnerable groups is clarified.

Update the guidelines for the crisis center law so that it more clearly addresses the crisis center services for vulnerable groups. This work is expected to commence as soon as changes to the crisis center law are adopted.

Establish an external committee to clarify whether there is a legal basis to assert that the treatment of Uighurs and other minorities in the Xinjiang province by the Chinese authorities violates international law.
Take the initiative to ensure that individuals on the Anti-Corruption Foundation's list of accomplices in Russia's invasion of Ukraine are included in the EU's sanctions lists.
Take the initiative in the UN to establish binding guidelines for responsible lending for states, international financial institutions, and private creditors.
Take the initiative in the UN to establish a public register for government debt.
Take the initiative in the UN to establish a new international debt management mechanism.
Take the initiative to include UNDP as a negotiating partner in the G20-initiated Global Debt Roundtable.

Conduct a consequence assessment of the proposed changes to the environmental regulations for Svalbard and document the impact these changes will have on the areas of business activities, settlement, utilization of Svalbard, use of nature, and specific environmental effects/benefits.
Coordinate proposals for a new intrusive environmental regulation for Svalbard with the processing of the parliamentary report on Svalbard that is expected to be released in 2024.
Assume that the main road network will be developed with grade-separated four-lane roads where the annual average daily traffic exceeds 6,000 vehicles.
Promote a proposal that county roads with high traffic volumes and industrial roads be reclassified as national roads.
Promote proposals for more resources for the improvement and modernization of sections of the national and county road network.
Promote a proposal for a road safety package in connection with the state budget for 2024.
Ensure a binding timeline for addressing the maintenance backlog on the national road network.
Prioritize that national and county roads with oncoming traffic receive enhanced markings with both center and edge lines, along with a binding timeline for implementation.
Ensure that the handbooks for the development of pedestrian and bicycle paths are simplified, so that more pedestrian and bicycle paths can be built for the money.
Consider introducing a temporary obligation for license holders to be affiliated with taxi dispatch centers.
Consider implementing a temporary halt in the issuance of additional taxi licenses.
Strengthen the efforts to ensure that all actors in the taxi market, including so-called platform companies, report complete figures to the Tax Administration.
Ensure that the state health enterprises set requirements when announcing tenders that guarantee drivers a minimum wage per hour for the time they spend on patient transportation.
Ensure that the state contribution for large public transport projects covered by urban growth agreements is increased to 70%.
Investigate the possibilities of using landowner contributions to finance the operation of public transport.
Expand the zero growth target by including freight transport in the basis for the zero growth goal.
Resume the work of establishing more urban growth agreements, without compromising the existing ones.
Expand the zero growth target to also apply outside the largest urban areas.
Promote a proposal to abolish the zero growth target in road traffic.
Facilitate the car as a transportation option throughout the country.
Come back with proposals for changes to the book law that continue the current rule where the e-book format of a work receives free pricing when the pocket format of the work is launched.
Come back with suggestions for changes to the book law that continue the current rule allowing publishers to adjust the binding resale price during the fixed price period.

Come back with proposals for changes to the book law that continue the current rule allowing a discount of up to 12.5% on the retail price chosen by the supplier at any time during the fixed price period.
Ensure that public libraries have the right to purchase and lend e-books and e-audiobooks.
Come back with proposals for changes to the book law that ensure non-discrimination of content providers for streaming services for literature.
Investigate universal design of audiobooks.

Investigate how the streaming market can be regulated in the Book Act, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner. The investigation should include, among other things, an amendment to the Book Act that ensures non-discrimination of content providers of streaming services for literature, as well as a thorough assessment of establishing a special independent committee to evaluate possible violations of the Book Act, either for advisory opinions or also with decision-making authority.

Consider whether it would be easier to include textbooks for higher education and professional books for the professional market in digital learning services during the fixed price period, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner. The consequences of amending the Book Act should be assessed, so that sales beyond copy sales are also permitted during the fixed price period for textbooks for higher education, and that professional books for the professional market either receive optional fixed pricing or a fixed pricing scheme that only applies to print format for six months, or that the fixed price period for this book group can be regulated by regulation.
Assess the impact of the book law in the market, including how the book definition works and the delineation between books, learning resources, and other types of digital products.
Investigate whether it is possible to establish regulations for public libraries regarding the digital lending of digital works.
Conduct an external review of the margin regulation, as announced, to reconcile the various inputs from the book industry before the provision for such regulation comes into effect.
Present a plan to reduce the backlog in funding for sports facilities through gaming funds, so that the queue of sports facilities waiting for grants is reduced.

Consider various solutions that will ensure that sports clubs and municipalities avoid costs for interim financing during the period they are waiting for the disbursement of gaming funds, including considering the establishment of a government interim financing scheme that can disburse the gaming funds once the construction of the facility has commenced.
Come back with a case regarding the regulatory management of VAT compensation for sports facilities.

Ensure that patients with mental health issues who, according to the regulation on benefits for covering dental treatment expenses § 1 point 14, have the right to benefits for dental treatment, retain their rights for 6 months after their significantly reduced ability for self-care has been restored.

Ensure that patients with mental health issues that fall under the Dental Health Services Act § 1-3 first paragraph letter c, retain access to services from the dental health services in the county municipalities for up to 6 months after the patient has been discharged, declared healthy, or transferred to follow-up in an ACT/FACT team or similar.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for measures that strengthen the collaboration between primary and secondary mental health services for children and adolescents, also considering the necessary financial incentives for enhanced cooperation between child and adolescent psychiatric services (BUP), schools/kindergartens, educational psychology services (PPT), child welfare services, and other relevant services.

Promote targeted measures to ensure that parents' socioeconomic situation and competence regarding health information do not determine whether children or adolescents receive the necessary mental health support.

Ensure that parents of children who have been or are undergoing treatment in the specialist health service receive the necessary guidance on their rights, and provide access to guidance if applications are denied or if the municipality does not fulfill its legal obligations.
Facilitate that child and adolescent psychiatry (BUP) can provide necessary assistance and assessment in settings other than an office, if that is the most effective treatment.

Come back with concrete solutions to address the practice of discharging children and young people with permanent problems or lifelong diagnoses from specialized services, so that they become dependent on a comprehensive re-referral process if new needs for assistance arise.
Ensure that mental health services for children and adolescents in specialist health care are not further weakened, but instead secured for continued development and strengthening.
Extend the pilot project for primary health teams until the end of 2024.

Abolish the system of payment for patients ready for discharge, and in the planned hospital and collaboration plan, propose measures that ensure better transitions between municipalities and hospitals and fewer readmissions.
Ensure that the processes for prescribing medical cannabis are simplified, and that the cost of prescriptions is economically viable.
Investigate various models for strictly regulated production and sale of cannabis products in Norway, including a state monopoly system.
Ensure that all municipalities systematically conduct user and relative surveys in health and care services, and that there is transparency regarding the results of these surveys.

Promote a proposal for a legal requirement that municipal councils must annually review a report on the state of health and care services, where both user and relative surveys, objective quality indicators, and user satisfaction are measured.
Promote a proposal to amend the alcohol law so that municipalities can regulate the consumption of alcohol in public places themselves.

Take the initiative for new negotiations with the parties, aiming to downscale the existing road project and not initiate new road projects that contradict the zero growth target for passenger cars in the urban development agreement, so that the use of tolls can also be reduced.

Introduce a regulated maximum price for electricity sold in Norway. The maximum price should reflect production costs and concession prices, as well as the historical price level in Norway, which is around 35 øre per kWh.
Investigate measures that prevent overconsumption and waste of electricity, such as a tiered pricing system through taxes for households and stricter energy requirements for businesses.

Introduce a support rate of 100% for electricity over 0.50 kroner per kWh. This applies to everyone, including households, vacation properties, non-profit organizations, and businesses, starting from June 1, 2023. The electricity support will last until electricity prices are normalized again.
Consider how the electricity support scheme can be limited so that households purchasing reasonably priced concession power from the municipality do not receive support.
Investigate how the access to pre-emption in expropriation cases for developments in reindeer grazing areas can be abolished.

Develop a wind power regulation that includes procedural rules, criteria for allocation, criteria for early rejection, considerations for nature, cultural, and outdoor values, guidelines for location, and guidelines for coordination between authorities, sector legislation, and international directives and conventions.

Consider changes to the EIA regulations to allow for coordination between the concession process and the planning process for land-based wind power through joint hearings and approval of the EIA program, as well as joint hearings of the concession application and planning proposal.
Promote a proposal for how ground-mounted solar energy systems can be included in the Planning and Building Act, no later than the end of 2023.
Require NBIM to implement the following sub-targets for the fund's portfolio: 22–32% emissions reduction by 2025 and 40–60% emissions reduction by 2030.

Establish in the mandate for the Government Pension Fund Global specific forward-looking sub-goals for the portfolio's total emissions reduction at the sector level from 2025 that are consistent with membership in the Net-Zero Asset Owners Alliance (NZAOA). Norges Bank is requested to report annually on progress towards these goals.

Make changes to the "Guidelines for Observation and Exclusion of Companies from the Government Pension Fund Global" so that § 3 second paragraph reads: (2) Observation or exclusion may be decided for mining companies and power producers that themselves or consolidated with entities they control either: a) receive 10 percent or more of their revenues from thermal coal, b) base 10 percent or more of their operations on thermal coal, c) extract more than 10 million tons of thermal coal per year, or d) have a power capacity of more than 5,000 MW from thermal coal.
Promote a proposal that NBIM is not allowed to invest in, and is expected to divest from, companies that expand or make new investments in coal-related activities.

Change the behavioral criteria for observation and exclusion of companies to ensure that the Government Pension Fund Global withdraws its investments from companies linked to unlawful occupation and other violations of international law.

Consider whether the current regulations and practices need to be tightened to ensure that the Government Pension Fund Global does not invest in nuclear weapons. The results of the review should be presented to the Parliament no later than in the next parliamentary report on the Government Pension Fund.
Require NBIM to implement a specific target for net zero emissions across the entire portfolio of the fund.
Consider adding a goal to the mandate of the Government Pension Fund Global regarding net zero emissions in the investment portfolio by 2050.
Initiate work on the development of a climate risk-adjusted reference index.
Investigate the effects of a monetary system that adopts digital central bank currencies, combined with increased public credit intermediation through existing or new financial institutions.

Investigate to what extent the banks' lending is economically beneficial for society, and assess how credit regulation can make the allocation of credit more efficient with the aim of particularly achieving the goals of the Paris Agreement and otherwise supporting the real economy.
Propose credit regulations that ensure that banks' total lending for housing is limited, while simultaneously increasing the share of first-time buyers in the total new home loans.
Require banks to report average mortgage rates and publish data that forms the basis for decisions on pricing and loan allocation.
Evaluate the effect of the crisis measures aimed at the banks and map out how much of the banks' profits in 2020, 2021, and 2022 can be attributed to the crisis measures.
Ensure that Norway has preparedness in public financial institutions to immediately provide credit to businesses in an acute economic crisis.
Investigate the establishment of a state green investment bank.
Set a goal to reduce the share of private banks in the money supply.
Create a public solution that can be used for cash payments to individuals or households in Norway.
Take the initiative for an international collaboration on the taxation of currency transactions and financial transactions involving securities.
Take the initiative to start the work on an international ownership register.
Report on climate risk and natural risk in the Norwegian economy in each national budget.
Task the Financial Supervisory Authority with regularly conducting stress tests on natural risks in addition to climate risks in Norwegian financial institutions.

Investigate how the framework conditions and regulation of the financial industry can be changed to promote restructuring and climate cuts, and how climate and climate risk can be given more weight in the credit process.

Present measures to reduce the systemic risk associated with bank financing through covered bonds (OMF), the underlying dependence on developments in the housing market, as well as cross-ownership of OMF in the banking sector.
Promote proposals that further reduce banks' access to take risks outside their core business.

Establish a committee to assess how to increase the market shares of banks and financial institutions based in Norway, and report back to the Parliament in connection with the Financial Market Report 2024.

Investigate measures to change the composition of banks' credit over time, so that a smaller share goes to residential and commercial real estate and a larger share goes to other industries, and report back to the Parliament with proposals on this in the Financial Market Report 2024.
Consider measures that facilitate increased use of fixed interest rates on home loans.
Tighten the oversight of competition in the banking market with the aim of ensuring that banking operations benefit consumers to a greater extent.
Investigate the causes of the increased margins in the Norwegian banking sector and report back to the Storting with measures to limit them in the Financial Market Report 2024.

Investigate measures that can contribute to more affordable banking services for customers, including asking the Competition Authority to present an updated review and proposals that can improve the competitive situation in the Norwegian banking market.

Promote the necessary legislative amendments to ensure a system of individual approval of credit assessments, where the central responsibility for the scheme is organized under the Brønnøysund Register Centre.

Change the subsidy schemes for the reindeer husbandry industry so that they more effectively encourage increased production, and actively use the subsidy schemes to favor reindeer owners who have reindeer husbandry as their main occupation.

Initiate a comprehensive revision of the reindeer herding law and, in this context, make new assessments and establish an upper limit on the reindeer population so that it more closely aligns with the grazing resources.
Review the established population targets for large carnivores in reindeer husbandry areas with the aim of reducing the target numbers and decreasing the populations down to the new population goals.
Introduce an exemption from the road usage tax for operational vehicles in reindeer herding.
Expand the Merkur scheme to allow for investment grants for digital solutions in local stores in rural areas, including self-service checkouts.

Investigate models that reward municipalities that achieve emission reductions and preserve biodiversity through the income system, and return to the Storting with proposals on this in connection with the Municipal Proposition for 2025.

To return to the Parliament in the state budget for 2024 with a proposal to strengthen the climate policy instruments that allow for sufficient support for low- and zero-emission fast ferries in the coming years, so that the removal of the "standardized boat cost" criterion does not lead to a halt in the renewal of the fast ferry fleet.
Ensure that fast boats to island communities without mainland connections and ferry connections are treated equally in national schemes for ticket price reductions.
Ensure that the improvement of living conditions is emphasized in connection with the update of criteria in the income system for the counties during the next evaluation of the income system.

To evaluate the implementation of a new common cost key for bus, boat, and train, in order to ensure that the restructuring does not have significant unintended consequences for local communities that currently rely on fast boats as a functioning public transport solution, and for those living in cities with many public transport users.
Promote a proposal to strengthen the financial framework of the municipal sector by at least 9 billion kroner beyond what the government has proposed in the Municipal Proposition 2024.

Replace the extra compensation for municipalities with fewer than 3,200 inhabitants with a scheme for extra compensation distributed to municipalities with a high proportion of expenses per inhabitant for resource-demanding services.
Secure additional funding for the hiring of general practitioners in municipal positions with fixed salaries in municipalities that lack general practitioners.
Ensure enough positions in the municipal child welfare services so that municipalities are able to reduce the number of cases per caseworker nationwide starting in 2024.
Investigate how to best protect residents from increased fees resulting from the new requirements for the water and wastewater sector.

Increase the municipal sector's revenues by 5.719 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in the Municipal Proposition 2023, with an estimated 3.019 billion kroner for the municipalities and 2.3 billion kroner for the county municipalities, as well as an increase of 400 million kroner for resource-intensive services.
Propose changes to the regulations to allow municipalities to set a higher tax rate for secondary and vacation homes than for primary residences.
Evaluate the county municipalities' income system within three years after the new county structure has come into effect.
Closely monitor the impact of the income system on the county municipalities' upper secondary education offerings and the significance the system has for socioeconomic differences.
Investigate an incentive scheme for CO2 reductions in the counties' public transport services that provides the counties with predictability for cost compensation.
Investigate the arrangement for resource-intensive services with the aim of finding solutions that ensure equal quality and access to services regardless of the municipality of residence.
Propose to further lower the property tax rate from 4 per mille.

Promote proposals for the introduction of a right to challenge, so that private actors can challenge public monopoly operations of services in order to achieve greater diversity and better quality at the right cost for taxpayers.
Reintroduce trials with state-funded elderly care to improve the quality of elderly care.
Ensure that the connections that are allowed to use the 2017 key as a starting point will also be able to benefit from the other improvements to the scheme from 2017 to today.
Present a model for a support scheme for investments in nitrogen removal from wastewater in areas that are subject to new treatment requirements.
Promote proposals for increased funding for elderly care and investments in more care homes and nursing home places.
Promote a proposal to include fast boats to island communities without mainland connections in the free ferry scheme.
Facilitate the inclusion of gas stations and kiosks in rural Norway into the Merkur scheme.
Reintroduce grants for rental housing and grants for elevators and condition assessments.
Increase the loan limits of the Housing Bank.
Consider improving the arrangement for resource-intensive services for the municipalities.
Emphasize municipal self-governance as a fundamental value in planning, land use, and building matters more strongly than current practice.

Ensure that ferry replacement projects completed between 2022 and 2027 are included in the interest compensation scheme in accordance with decision no. 1251 (2020–2021), cf. Prop. 192 S (2020–2021) the Municipal Proposition 2022 and Innst. 660 S (2020–2021).
Ensure the intention of an income system for municipalities that is more redistributive than the current one.
Come back with an evaluation of the income system for county municipalities in connection with the presentation of the municipal proposition in the spring of 2027.
Consider whether the municipalities in Namdalen should still be classified under the district grant for Northern Norway.
Come back with an evaluation of the free municipality trial at an appropriate time.
Come back to the Parliament with an overview of the status of the water and sewage situation in Municipal Norway.
Consider increasing the threshold amount to enter the Merkur scheme.
To create an external report with updated costs for the implementation of zero-emission ferries and fast boats in collaboration with the ferry and boat counties.

Account for the implementation and effects of today's temporary solution for the tariff regulation of wages for state employees who are not members of a trade union, and for alternative solutions to the current arrangement.

Withdraw Prop. 93 S (2022–2023), and as soon as possible, present a new case to the Storting that facilitates the rapid development of the entire Southern North Sea II with hybrid cables to one or more countries.
Cancel the planned announcement of offshore wind areas in Southern North Sea II and Utsira Nord due to significant cost increases and lack of knowledge about environmental consequences.
Investigate proposals on how the electrification of oil installations can be carried out in connection with the development of offshore wind and replace power sourced from land.
Ensure that mapping of the marine environment and seabirds is integrated into the decision-making basis leading up to the licensing process for offshore power production facilities.
Present a comprehensive plan for environmental mapping for the areas that will be relevant for offshore wind development.
Consider increasing the weighting of sustainability criteria and positive local ripple effects in future offshore wind developments and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Facilitate the implementation of follow-up research during the construction and operational phases of Southern North Sea II. Emphasis should be placed on the offshore wind farm's impact on nature and the environment, and this knowledge should be actively utilized and integrated into the ongoing work to promote good coexistence and sustainability in offshore wind.

Consider other and more appropriate funding solutions for differential contracts than the OPS framework, which ensures that the allocations are spread over several budget years rather than just the construction phase, and report back to the Parliament no later than in the state budget for 2025.

Develop a scaling-up plan during the current parliamentary term to improve the staffing situation in the correctional services. The scaling-up plan should be developed in close collaboration with employee organizations, relevant professional environments, and relevant voluntary organizations.

Initiate a research project to map the prevalence of PTSD and other psychological burdens among prison officers and police officers in Norway, similar to the Danish report "Psychological Stress Reactions among Police Officers and Prison Guards" from 2020.
Develop a plan for the escalation of healthcare services in Norwegian prisons that strengthens both somatic services, addiction treatment, and mental health care, particularly for long-term inmates.
Develop a concrete action plan for the prevention of violence against employees in the correctional services, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner within a reasonable timeframe.
Introduce a real occupational injury compensation scheme for employees in the correctional services, similar to the one that has been implemented for police employees.
Start a pilot project with a legal aid scheme for inmates based on the proposal in NOU 2020:5.
Present a proposal for the introduction of a rent cap in Norway.
Propose that the borrower has a right of first refusal for the claim on the same terms that the lender is willing to sell to a third party.

To review existing relevant regulations and make changes that will prohibit the sale of claims for unsecured debt that is granted after a simplified credit assessment, in accordance with the intention of the majority decision from Innst. 373 S (2021–2022).
Submit a proposal for debt collection law within the state budget for 2024.
To set the fee levels for all collection claims so low that they do not fully cover the collection costs.
Present a proposal for the introduction of a rent cap in Norway during 2024.
Return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner with a proposal to limit the use of external debt collectors in the collection of unsecured debt.
Reduce the fees on larger collection claims.
Propose to increase the minimum benefits in the National Insurance Scheme by 12,000 kroner in the state budget for 2024.
Present a proposal to reintroduce the shielding supplement for pensioners born between 1954 and 1962 in the national budget for 2024.

Investigate and report back to the Parliament, no later than the end of 2023, with a proposal for a hardship scheme that ensures a decent pension for those who are unable to continue working, and where the disabled are given earning rights up to the age of 67 in a new earning model.

Present a proposal for 2.2 billion kroner for pensioners in the balanced budget for 2023 or the state budget for 2024, which will cover the discrepancy between estimated and actual wage growth in 2021, and that the funds should be used to raise the lowest pensions after discussions with pensioners' organizations.
Present a proposal for a scaling plan for the minimum benefits in the National Insurance Scheme up to the poverty line.

Consider whether disability pensioners and other relevant groups should have their benefits adjusted according to price growth or the average of price and wage growth this year, given the decline in real wages.

Develop a plan for the annual increase of the minimum pension level towards the EU poverty threshold (EU60), where the first step in the escalation plan is implemented in the 2024 national budget with an increase of 7,500 kroner.

Implement the Storting's decision that organizations in connection with the annual welfare negotiations should be able to negotiate other issues of significance for pensioners, as well as investigate what real negotiation rights should entail beyond this.
To introduce an operational difficulty grant to ensure that heavily farmed agricultural areas are kept in operation.
To investigate and implement a plot-based area subsidy.
Strengthen customs protection by transitioning from kroner to percentage tariffs on tariff lines where percentage tariffs provide the best protection, effective from January 1, 2024.
Remove milk from the aggregated market price support ("Green Box"), so that milk is not regulated according to target price.
Not to increase the target prices for milk, potatoes, fruit, and vegetables from July 1, 2023.
To raise the quota limit on cow's milk to 1,200,000 liters.
Present a phasing-out plan for price reductions of grain for feed and in this year's agricultural settlement reduce the price reduction by 500 million kroner.
Reduce grazing/area subsidies in area zone 1 and 2.

Engage in dialogue with the professional associations and market regulators regarding a proposal for production regulation of sheep, cattle, and eggs, and present this well in advance of the agricultural negotiations in 2024.
Present a plan to increase the share of organic agricultural land in Norway to 15% by 2030.

Engage in dialogue with professional organizations to develop a new plot-based grant system with data mapping to ensure higher precision in the allocation of grant funds and simpler administration. Such a system must, among other things, be able to target grants towards areas that are fallow.

Develop a mapping database that defines agricultural land at the parcel level, with the aim of a more targeted area subsidy that promotes efficient resource use and better achievement of the goals for agricultural policy.
Present a package of measures aimed at, and associated instruments for, reducing agricultural land that is out of operation to a minimum.

Come back to the Parliament in connection with the state budget for 2024 with a ramp-up plan to achieve the goal of 50% self-sufficiency adjusted for the import of feed raw materials. The ramp-up plan should include guidelines on how to strengthen the exchange ratio between concentrated feed and roughage in favor of roughage.
Ensure that there is a requirement for at least 10% procurement of Norwegian agricultural products in the public sector.
Investigate the introduction of a CO2 tax for Norwegian agriculture.
Ensure that strengthening welfare schemes for farmers is specifically targeted at young farmers.
Start work on a new parliamentary report on the future of agricultural and food systems, based on the EU's food and agricultural strategy "Farm to Fork."

Follow up on its commitments under the agricultural climate agreement to contribute to changing food consumption in the Norwegian population so that food consumption aligns as much as possible with the Norwegian dietary guidelines.

Propose an animal welfare grant with criteria that exceed the minimum requirements of the animal husbandry regulations, so that the grant scheme contributes to a real and significant improvement in animal welfare in Norwegian livestock farming.
Reduce the transfers in chapter 1150 by 1.2 billion kroner.

Investigate and present a proposal to establish a pilot project for a mobile grazing service that can utilize outdoor resources, generate income for farmers, and provide sustainable clearing services.
Ensure follow-up on the Food Nation Norway and assess necessary measures to strengthen the focus on local food.
Suggest removing subsidies on the import of food grains.
Start a phase-out of the price reduction subsidy for compound feed and other subsidies that help lower the price of compound feed.
Consider measures to ensure increased grazing in the outfields.
Strengthen the focus on the production of plant crops for food to increase self-sufficiency.
Implement necessary measures to significantly increase Norwegian production of grains, fruits, and vegetables.

Establish a pilot project for farmers struggling with mental health, and that this is set up within one of the established organizations. It is assumed that the necessary funds will be taken within the budget framework.
Present a strategy for increased self-sufficiency and secure food production based on Norwegian resources, and return to the Storting no later than in connection with the national budget.

Investigate how the use of data maps can ensure higher precision in the allocation of grant funds and target area subsidies towards land that is fallow, such as a plot-based subsidy. The investigation should be completed before the regular agricultural negotiations in 2024.

Ensure Norwegian food preparedness and Norwegian food production through a well-functioning customs protection, and that the government in the state budget for 2024 shifts from a fixed tariff to a percentage tariff for individual products to secure this.
To remove the temporary increase in employer's contribution in the national budget for 2024.
To ensure that non-profit organizations are compensated for the temporary increase in employer contributions in the same way as corresponding public enterprises.
Promote a proposal for a significant increase in the compensation subsidy for farmers in connection with maternity leave.
Investigate the introduction of an electricity tax for the continental shelf.
Establish a committee to ensure that regulations, expertise, and licensing authorities are clarified in order to initiate nuclear power production in Norway.
Ensure that there is an opportunity to apply for funding for research on modern nuclear power within the funds allocated for research on "environmentally friendly energy."

To ensure that non-profit and private enterprises with agreements with regional health enterprises receive the same compensation for wage and price increases as public enterprises do at 5.2%, in accordance with the intention of wage and price adjustments in the current agreements.
Promote a proposal for a ramp-up plan for pensions for single minimum pensioners. The first increase must be included in the state budget for 2024.
Propose a new climate and nature percentage that should be added to the current aid initiatives, no later than in the state budget for 2024.
Introduce a ban on the use of disposable grills.
Investigate models for removing the value-added tax on electric bicycles.
Present a concrete plan for phasing out the temporary increase in employer's contributions for salaries over 750,000 kroner. The phase-out must take effect no later than the budget year 2024.
To clarify how much defense capability in general and documented operational capability in particular Norway derives from its budget compared to other countries.
Present a parliamentary report on the choices Norway faces in development policy, as recommended in the government-appointed expert committee's report "Investing in a Common Future."
Limit the exemption from value-added tax for electronic news services to apply to news services that are specifically aimed at Norwegian conditions or a Norwegian audience.
Ensure that the municipalities calculate new grants for private kindergartens for 2023 due to the fact that the grant calculations for 2023 are based on too low wage and price growth.

Clarify that kindergartens that follow the collective agreement PBL has with the Trade Union, the Education Union, and Delta, have the right to have costs for pensions covered beyond what is covered by the pension surcharge, upon application to the municipality.

Postpone any potential transfer of responsibility for the Cancer Registry to the Norwegian Institute of Public Health until a consequence assessment of such a transfer has been conducted and the relevant professional environments have been consulted.
Present a proposal for a support scheme under the Ministry of Children and Families for voluntary organizations that provide food distribution.
Engage in dialogue with the operators for the three railway packages up for tender, with the aim of terminating the contracts and then directly awarding the routes to Vy by December 25, 2023.

Ensure that benefits and allowances set outside the social security settlement are proposed to be adjusted upwards annually in the revised national budget if the inflation forecast in the revised national budget increases compared to what was used for adjustments in the state budget, so that they at least keep pace with wage and price growth.

Come up with suggestions on how the regulations for housing support can be changed so that extraordinary increases in benefits, such as one-time payments to those on minimum disability benefits and Christmas bonuses in social assistance, do not lead to a reduction in housing support.
Ensure that no one has their housing support reduced as a result of the increase in benefits in the revised national budget 2023.

Expand the support schemes for energy efficiency for households through Enova and ensure that support is provided for mature technologies that deliver rapid reductions in electricity consumption, and that it can be disbursed with simultaneous payment. The schemes must be updated accordingly by October 2023.
Contribute to ensuring that all school students visit a human rights center during their school years.
Ensure that no one has their housing allowance reduced as a result of the increase in benefits following the 2023 social security settlement.

Investigate the increased case processing capacity at the Norwegian Environment Agency due to increased activity on the Norwegian continental shelf related to industries such as offshore wind, seabed minerals, and oil.
Introduce a ban on new peat extraction from wetlands by the end of 2023, including extractions that have already been granted permits.
Set requirements for municipalities to report planned peatland degradation, degraded peatland, and restored peatland through KOSTRA by the end of 2023.
Stop the work on planning the new Hammersborg tunnel and instead engage in dialogue with the City of Oslo about testing the closure of the road section.
Consider removing tuition fees for international students in Norway.

Ensure that the food distribution centers have enough capacity and resources to meet the needs until the Parliament convenes in October, and return to Parliament with proposals for necessary budget increases in connection with the newly adjusted budget for 2023.

Come back with suggestions for limitations and design of an electricity support scheme for business customers. The scheme should compensate for domestic competition distortion and be based on the pricing regime for household customers with the necessary adjustments.
Come back to the Parliament in the state budget for 2024 with proposals for necessary changes to increase the income limit for disability benefits from 0.4 G to 0.8 G.
Consider an adjustment of guardians' compensation in line with the development of the National Insurance Scheme's basic amount in connection with the state budget for 2024.
To return in the state budget for 2024 to how the number of LIS1 positions can be increased by 100 positions for the application round this autumn.
Return to the Storting with a plan for stem cell treatment in Norway and/or assistance in purchasing this abroad.
Continue the preparatory work for the construction of the Stad ship tunnel.

Establish that private kindergartens with PBL's pension agreement have the right to be compensated for their pension expenses beyond the standard amount in the pension subsidy from their host municipalities.
Present a case for restructuring the incentive scheme to attract foreign film productions to Norway into a rule-based system, and for removing the application deadline.
Consider how the consequences of the loss of contracts due to sanctions, for companies and shipyards that have had Russian vessels in their client portfolio, can be mitigated.

Propose to amend the Value Added Tax Act so that § 6-2 is reintroduced effective from November 1, 2023, and that the law or regulation is changed so that VAT exemption is contingent upon the content being aimed at the general public in Norway. The criterion should be negatively defined in the sense that it is clarified that internationally produced news services that are broadcast with the same content in several countries will not be considered sufficiently aimed at the general public in Norway.
Facilitate contracts for pharmaceuticals with Norwegian pharmaceutical manufacturers to ensure Norwegian emergency production of essential medicines.
Abolish the temporary increased rate of the employer's contribution effective from the state budget for 2024.
Present measures to electrify offshore installations using offshore wind to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Promote a proposal to increase the blending requirement for biofuels for road traffic and to introduce a separate sub-requirement for advanced biofuels based on A-feedstock for consultation, with the aim of implementation from January 1, 2024. The following proposal for an increased blending requirement is sent for consultation: The blending requirement for biofuels for road traffic is increased from 17% to 19%. The sub-requirement for advanced biofuels is increased from 12.5% to 14.5%. A sub-requirement for advanced biofuels from A-feedstock of 1%, 2%, or 3.5% is introduced.
Promote a proposal to increase the turnover requirement for biofuels in aviation to 2% with effect from January 1, 2024. At the same time, the 2024 national budget should indicate future escalation.

Promote a proposal for a requirement of zero emissions for all new service vessels in the aquaculture industry starting from July 1, 2024. It must be taken into account that local conditions related to energy supply may complicate achieving zero emissions.
Send out for consultation a proposal requiring the establishment of solar panels and/or locally produced energy on all new commercial buildings over 500 m2 outside of LNF areas.

Come back with suggestions for criteria to establish automatic traffic control for speed in areas where the speed limit has been reduced due to concerns about air or noise pollution. At the same time, work will be initiated to develop the necessary legal basis.
Propose a scheme that supports the expansion and structural upgrading of crisis centers based on the model of the Housing Bank's scheme for investment grants for care homes and nursing home places.

Come back with an assessment of a revision of the income threshold in disability benefits, including an evaluation of an increase of the threshold up to 1 G and other changes aimed at allowing disabled individuals with residual work capacity to a greater extent than under the current regulations to combine earned income with disability benefits.

Ensure that patients with mental health issues that fall under the Dental Health Services Act § 1-3 first paragraph letter c, retain access to services from the dental health services in the county municipalities for up to six months after the patient has been discharged, declared healthy, or transferred to follow-up in an ACT/FACT team or similar.

Investigate differentiated valuation of non-listed shares in wealth tax based on the characteristics of the individual shares, e.g., different voting and dividend rights, so that the valuation of the individual shares more closely corresponds to their actual market value.
Promote a case as the basis for a broad elderly agreement.

Publish the professional advice and input the government has received from the Police Directorate and the police districts in connection with the process of establishing 20 new police service locations.
Promote a proposal that involves a halt to the establishment of new cabin areas.

Introduce a ban on surveillance-based marketing for consumer loans and unsecured credit, so that advertising for consumer loans and unsecured credit, which is based on mass surveillance, tracking, and/or profiling of individuals, is prohibited.

Review and assess the experiences of replacing homework with schoolwork, as well as facilitating for municipalities and schools that wish to do this, in close dialogue with teachers, students, and municipalities.
Conduct an independent investigation into the possibilities for CCS at the Melkøya facility.

Come back with suggestions on how the pension subsidy for kindergarten staff can be covered krone for krone. This is in contrast to the current standardized coverage, which leads to both over- and under-financing. The pension subsidy should ensure that kindergarten staff have the best possible pension and not be a source of profit for the owners.
Propose changes to the kindergarten law that prevent commercial owners from acquiring more and more kindergartens.

Review the regulations related to employees' salary and working conditions in connection with outsourcing and come back with a proposal that ensures that municipalities cannot outsource publicly funded welfare unless the level and development of salary, working, and pension conditions remain at the same level as the public sector.

To clarify the framework for the outsourcing of publicly funded welfare services and to return to the Parliament with a proposal that only long-term contracts be entered into with non-profit organizations, while simultaneously introducing a maximum limit of four years for contracts with commercial actors.
Present a guideline that ensures municipalities can set collectively agreed wage rates as a condition for liquor licenses.

Send for consultation and present proposals for amendments to the law regarding the obligation of ministers and state secretaries to register their previous clients and the content of assignments where they have worked to promote political or business interests in the two years prior to taking office.
Investigate and propose a tax on trading in stocks, derivatives, and other securities.
Increase the guideline rates for social assistance by 1,000 kroner and 1,000 kroner per child, until the New Year, and present a proposal for financing this in the balanced budget for 2023.
Conduct a power investigation focusing on structures and power balance, particularly in the labor market and between the public, elected officials, and the government.
Ensure that volunteer organizations have sufficient funds to help the poor during Christmas, and present proposals for financing this in the balanced budget for 2023.

Present legislative and regulatory changes that require digital storage and real-time accessibility of the shareholder register, in order to facilitate a shareholder register that is open to the public.

Investigate proposals for amending the party law to ensure that actual contributors of donations exceeding the amounts set by the law are reported and made public. The government is requested to return to the Storting in an appropriate manner after the investigation has been completed.

Inform the Parliament about all security-relevant information related to Equinor's contract for the procurement of floating rigs from the state-owned Chinese company COSL, as well as explain what control mechanisms have been established to ensure that the companies fulfill their mandated responsibility to ensure that procurements are conducted in accordance with the Security Act.
Start the work of utilizing the current road bridge as a replacement for the Randklev bridge so that the Dovre Line can be reopened.
Create a plan for the annual increase of the minimum pension level up to the EU poverty line (EU60), with the first step in the escalation plan to be implemented in 2024.
Utilize available private and non-profit hospital capacity to reduce hospital waiting lists.
Ensure that all new development projects that involve interventions in nature reserves are halted.
Promote a proposal to introduce a production tax on the petroleum industry to mitigate the negative effects of the oil tax package on inflation and interest rates.
Stop all allocation of exploration licenses on the Norwegian continental shelf, both through numbered licensing rounds and through the TFO scheme.

Ensure that women's health becomes a central part of the national health and collaboration plan, and that concrete proposals for measures and a plan are presented so that women's health is addressed in the Parliament.

Make the necessary proposals to initiate the phasing out of the health enterprise model, so that we can return to hospitals being politically governed, where operations and investments do not fall under the same budget, and where the placement of hospital services is decided through political processes.
Mapping out what is needed to implement continuous kindergarten admissions.
Return to the Storting in a suitable manner by January 2025, with a model that allows for a minimum of two kindergarten intakes per year.
Present a binding plan to the Parliament aimed at ensuring that all children are offered a kindergarten place immediately after parental leave ends, regardless of the child's age.

Develop an alternative subject and time distribution for upper secondary education that takes into account that teaching can be organized in modules, where students have the opportunity to focus on fewer subjects at the same time, in shorter terms, and with final assessments.

Develop a nationally established structure for modular training, so that school owners and schools can easily choose to implement modular training in their upper secondary schools, allowing students to focus on fewer subjects at the same time, in shorter terms, and with final assessments.

Strengthen the opportunities to take subjects across different study programs and consider removing the distinction between general studies and vocational education, so that the final qualifications are determined by the student's combination of subjects.
Initiate work to increase the number of hours for program subjects in the general studies program in upper secondary education.
Change the rules for elective subjects so that students can choose elective subjects to specialize in outside of the program areas.
Ensure that students in the general studies program have the opportunity to take elective subjects starting from Vg1.
Consider whether the ex.phil. education can be offered as an elective subject in the specialized study program.
Present a strategy for a strengthened follow-up service for young people outside of education and employment across the country.
Consider how increased academic depth and concentration, through the organization of subjects and hours in shorter terms or modules, can contribute to enhanced learning and relevance for students.

Present a separate parliamentary report on how the Follow-up Service in the counties can play a larger role by including more individuals in upper secondary education and work, with the aim of increasing the completion rate of upper secondary education.

Return to the Parliament with legislative changes so that nurses who receive old-age pensions under Chapter 4 or service pension-calculated AFP under Section 7, third paragraph, shall not be re-registered in the scheme, unless the individual has worked at least 168 hours during the quarter.

Facilitate that retired nurses have good incentives to work in part-time positions in the public sector, including considering exceptions for enrollment in the pension scheme for nurses. This should be done in consultation with the parties, and the government will return to the Parliament before the amendment comes into effect.
Investigate whether publicly approved nurses employed by staffing agencies and leased to institutions under the Nurses' Pension Act should also be members of the pension scheme for nurses.
Propose to temporarily increase the income limit for disability benefits to up to 1 G until the end of 2023.

Review how welfare benefits are affected by recipients having earned income, and provide suggestions for legislative changes that simplify income reporting for benefit recipients and ensure that they retain more of their wages and benefits. The review should not be limited to, but must at a minimum consider, the following topics: a. Whether elected work and fees for positions in clubs and associations should be reduced in the same way as other income b. Introduction of a free allowance for social assistance recipients c. Introduction of a free allowance for recipients of work assessment allowance d. Increasing the income threshold before disability for disability pensioners on minimum benefits e. Raising the income limit for receiving child supplements in social benefits f. Changing the regulations for the coordination of unemployment benefits and other social benefits so that, for example, disabled individuals receive the same unemployment benefits as healthy individuals in the same situation.
Ensure that individuals who receive a salary increase are not deducted from their disability benefits by Nav.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to increase the income limit for disability benefits.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a simplified disability system where all remaining work capacity can more easily be combined with a graded disability pension, so that individuals with reduced work capacity are not forced onto 100% disability pension.
Investigate how to prevent residents in sparsely populated municipalities with large areas from incurring disproportionately high expenses due to improvements in the water and sewage sector.
Present a financing solution for the water and wastewater sector and a model for how the sector can be organized to operate more efficiently.
Ensure that all Norwegian municipalities are connected to a knowledge-sharing portal for municipal water and wastewater by 2026.
Ensure that common fee rates for self-cost areas are established across municipal borders where binding inter-municipal cooperation has been agreed upon in the water and wastewater sector.
Promote necessary proposals to ensure water competence in the coming years.

Create a national action plan to address the challenges in the water and wastewater sector. The goal is to coordinate efforts for the benefit of the environment and people. Both the preservation of the water cycle and the avoidance of misinvestments or overinvestments are necessary.

Allocate sufficient resources to follow up on the proposals in NOU 2015:16, including investigating the issue of liability for damages, and promote the necessary proposals to modernize the legal and regulatory framework for water and wastewater fees.
Present a model for a joint investment scheme for nitrogen treatment of wastewater in areas that are subject to new treatment requirements.
Ensure that there are no requirements for treatment plants for communities with few residents and already good treatment levels.
Ensure that the implementation of the revised wastewater directive is adapted to Norwegian conditions to spare Norwegian citizens from unnecessary expenses.
Investigate a interest compensation scheme for water and sewage, and return to the Parliament with a proposal for this in the state budget for 2025.
Ensure that the new wastewater directive is adapted to specific Norwegian conditions.
Ensure the harmonization of the maximum depreciation periods in the accounting rules of the Local Government Act with those of the self-cost regulations in the water and wastewater sector.
Start the work of establishing a national benchmarking model for municipal water and wastewater, based on an objective national overview.
Develop an objective national overview of maintenance and investment needs in the water and wastewater sector.
To take the initiative to establish a cross-political working group with the aim of creating an economic escalation plan for the Armed Forces.
Ensure coal mining in Svalbard beyond 2025 and, if necessary, scale up operations, with the goal that the coal will primarily be used as a factor of production in industry.

Provide relevant stakeholders in Svalbard, such as Store Norske AS, with the mandate and resources for further exploration of gold and mineral deposits north of Longyearbyen and potentially other geologically promising locations.

Present comprehensive plans for Svalbard regarding strengthened Norwegian presence, assertion of sovereignty, employment, as well as mining for coal, gold, and minerals in a new Svalbard report by the first quarter of 2024.
Consider further strengthening communication and preparedness in Svalbard, especially in the energy sector, possibly through an additional submarine cable or other redundant solutions.

Investigate the possibility of using nuclear power or LNG and LBG (liquefied natural gas and biogas) as a future energy solution for Svalbard in connection with the work on the final energy plan for Svalbard.
Investigate the possibility of building infrastructure for charging facilities for ships powered by nuclear power plants or gas power plants (LNG and LBG) and/or bunkering solutions for LNG and LBG.
The requirement for end-user documentation will be practiced for all exports of defense materials, including to NATO countries and close allies.

Guidelines for how Norwegian export authorities conduct forward-looking risk assessments to ensure that Norwegian defense material is not used in violation of international humanitarian law and international human rights, in accordance with Article 7 of the Arms Trade Treaty and the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises.
Establish that the joint declaration between Norway and China from December 2016, also known as the normalization agreement, has no political validity.
Present a parliamentary report on how Norway, through international cooperation, can reduce its dependence on supplies from authoritarian regimes for further industrial and technological development.

Actively support initiatives to institutionalize international cooperation on freedom-promoting trade policy among liberal democracies and other countries seeking alternatives to Chinese supply chains.
Consider requesting observer status for Norway in the EU-US Trade and Technology Council.

Present to the Storting the ongoing assessment of the extent and manner in which Norwegian value creation depends on imports from China, and the vulnerabilities associated with this, with particular focus on green technology and technology that collects large amounts of data about Norwegian citizens.

Present a parliamentary report that maps Norway's dependence on Chinese technology that collects large amounts of data about Norwegian citizens, and presents a plan for how Norway will collaborate internationally to reduce this dependence.
Develop a strategy for a freedom-promoting trade policy.
Conclude negotiations with China on a free trade agreement.
Consider requesting observer status for Norway in the EU-India Trade and Technology Council.
Initiate dialogue with the EU regarding the possibilities for a framework agreement for Norway's association with the EU's common foreign, defense, and security policy.
Condemn Israel's failure to protect healthcare personnel and patients and demand guarantees that ambulances transporting patients will not be attacked.
Work to ensure that the International Criminal Court is granted access to Israel and Gaza as soon as possible to investigate war crimes on both sides of the conflict.

To assert that Israel's treatment of and violations of international law against the Palestinians constitute apartheid and are in violation of international law according to the Rome Statute and the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.
Prepare the recognition of Palestine as an independent state.
To recognize Palestine as a separate state at a time when such recognition could have a positive impact on a peace process and without any conditions regarding a final peace agreement.
Promote a case to the Storting regarding Norway's accession to the UN's apartheid convention (The International Convention on the Suppression and Punishment of the Crime of Apartheid).
Ensure a Norwegian ban on goods and services from companies and enterprises on occupied land produced in violation of international law.

Review the circular "H-4/21 Establishment of charging points and charging stations for electric vehicles (EVs) and vessels with battery-electric propulsion – the relationship to the Planning and Building Act, etc.", where the purpose is to list the measures that are exempt from application requirements, so that this becomes clearer for the municipalities. Charging facilities for vessels and vehicles must be explicitly mentioned as a measure exempt from application requirements in the Building Application Regulations (SAK 10), in order to ensure consistent interpretation and application of the regulations in all municipalities.
Develop guidelines that clarify the scope of action municipalities have to enter into lease agreements where the municipality is the landowner, in the next update of the guidelines.

Consider whether there should be requirements that new residential and commercial projects established in the coastal zone should facilitate shore power and charging for electric boats where dock facilities are also being established.

Discuss the possibility of imposing requirements for charging infrastructure for new marinas of a certain size, as well as the renovation of existing marinas, so that electric charging infrastructure is made available for a minimum number of electric recreational boats.
Intensify the efforts to develop shore power and other infrastructure necessary to achieve the goal of zero emissions from the offshore fleet by 2030.

Intensify the work on expanding shore power and charging infrastructure in relevant fishing ports and ports that are frequently used by the fishing fleet. The development of shore power should, where possible, also accommodate other users, such as other vessels, electric cars, etc.

Initiate a project to assess how and in what ways land infrastructure for established electric ferries or other maritime vessels can be made accessible for other sea and land transport, preferably through commercial charging and shore power operators.

Ensure that for upcoming public tenders for commercial ferries and fast boats, the accessibility of the electric infrastructure for other users is considered, and require this in the upcoming tenders.

Promote a proposal to give Norske tog the flexibility to order new long-distance trains for the Røros Line. The order is linked to the procurement that Norske tog is carrying out for several of the other long-distance train routes. Furthermore, the government is requested to ensure universal design of all trains ordered for Norwegian railway lines.
Take the initiative with Avinor to contribute to the reopening of civil air traffic from Moss Airport, Rygge, by leasing capacity as a relief for traffic at Oslo Airport.
Give a preliminary assurance that when a concession application to resume civil air traffic is received, it will be processed positively and quickly.
Ensure that 120–200 million kroner of the Research Council's announced research funds for environmentally friendly energy, amounting to 1.2 billion kroner, is allocated to an FME for nuclear power.

Ensure that the funds for the FME for nuclear power are announced as soon as possible, with new application deadlines that give relevant stakeholders the opportunity to prepare strong applications for FMEs on nuclear power.
Remove the restriction in the Research Council's announcement of FME funds, where it currently states: "Applications for FME within nuclear power will not be accepted."
Review and assess the removal of existing barriers to research on nuclear power and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Present a national strategy for transitioning away from the use of rubber granulate in Norway, including a financing plan that provides predictability for affected sports clubs.
Ensure that the funding scheme allows for new support after five years, in cases where the tested alternative to rubber granulate on sports fields proves to be ineffective.
