Present an action plan for the transition away from the use of rubber granulate in Norway, which ensures our compliance with the approved sales ban on rubber granulate from the REACH regulation in the EU starting in October 2031.

Ensure that the discharge of wash water from the marinas in the Oslofjord is regulated through individual permits with treatment requirements until the work on a potential regulation is completed. The Parliament also asks the government to consider whether it is reasonable for the county governors to be delegated the authority and responsibility to regulate the marinas in the Oslofjord through individual permits.
Investigate a local regulation for larger boat storage areas in the Oslofjord with requirements for significantly reduced emissions from washing recreational boats.

Ensure that measures are implemented to make those responsible for marinas aware that they have an obligation to take action under the Pollution Control Act § 7 second paragraph, and what this obligation entails.

Investigate the establishment of an independent, professionally grounded climate commission with a mandate to assess goal achievement and propose necessary measures and instruments to meet the climate targets under the Climate Act, as well as to conduct independent oversight to ensure compliance with these targets.

Investigate and report to the UN Climate Convention – the Paris Agreement – a climate target for Norway, based on scientific advice for 90–95% emission reductions in collaboration with the EU by 2040 compared to 1990 levels.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for changes to the Climate Act that commits to sector-specific, annual climate targets and budgets that contribute to achieving the objectives of the Climate Act.

Come back to the Storting with a proposal for a climate target for emission reductions on Norwegian territory that contributes to Norway fulfilling its obligations under the Paris Agreement to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees, no later than in connection with the government report on climate that is expected to be released in 2024.

Present a parliamentary report on a plan for Norway's contribution to international climate financing. The plan should address what level Norwegian climate financing should be at moving forward, what proportion should be public or private, which sectors should be prioritized, and which countries Norway wishes to collaborate with. There should be a distinction between funds that are primarily aimed at poverty reduction and have other main objectives, and funds for emission reductions, adaptation, and loss and damage.
Ensure that market cooperation under the Paris Agreement Article 6 is not utilized outside of Europe to achieve Norway's climate goals under the Paris Agreement.
Come back with suggestions for changes to the Climate Act § 4 that clarify that the 1.5-degree target is the basis for Norwegian climate policy.
Return to the Storting in the spring of 2024 with a parliamentary report that outlines how Norway will reduce emissions in the period leading up to 2030 in line with Norway's climate goals.
Give municipalities the opportunity to implement local drug reforms, where the use and possession of small amounts of illegal drugs for personal use does not result in punishment.
Evaluate all substance abuse prevention measures aimed at children and youth in Norway and investigate whether they align with international standards for drug prevention.

Create low-threshold services for individuals with opioid addiction who do not receive the necessary assistance through LAR and/or ensure that municipalities are equipped to establish such low-threshold services.
Instruct the administration to immediately ensure a bureaucratic solution that does not require financial expenses for individuals who depend on oxygen treatment while traveling abroad.

Investigate whether the administration in other areas has tightened practices where people have to pay on behalf of the state instead of it being done through direct settlements, and instruct the administration to initiate the necessary processes to ensure that as many as possible have the opportunity to utilize arrangements with direct settlements.

Investigate whether it is necessary to amend laws or regulations to ensure that there are no unreasonable outcomes from the current regulations that severely impact individuals, and return to the Parliament with the necessary proposals for changes.

Come back to the Storting with proposals for necessary legislative changes to allow businesses involved in and producers of alcoholic beverages to inform about their own operations and products on their social media pages, as well as to grant Norwegian producers the freedom to provide sober product information about their own produced beverages on their own websites as they see fit.
Make it easier for Norwegian producers of beer and cider to offer their products in grocery stores, including items with an alcohol content over 4.7%.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals for necessary legal amendments to allow labeling of alcohol packaging with any awards and/or prizes.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals for necessary legal changes to allow the marketing of non-alcoholic beer with the brewery's/producer's logo and trademarks.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to allow distilleries and breweries to sell all their own produced goods in their own production facilities.
Initiate work to revise and modernize the alcohol regulations and the advertising ban.
Explain how welfare properties can be returned to their home municipalities after buyback.

Consider whether profits from the sale of childcare properties can be regarded as illegal state aid to a commercial real estate business, rather than support for a non-economic childcare operation. Furthermore, the Parliament requests the government to clarify how any illegal state aid can be reclaimed within the context of a purchase of welfare properties.
Promote proposals for improved coastal zone protection.
Propose suggestions on how municipalities' enforcement of illegal activities in the coastal zone can be strengthened.
Map the municipalities' efforts to remove illegal barriers in the coastal zone and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Investigate whether the Data Protection Authority should have the right to sue regarding the decisions of the Privacy Board in cases of particular importance or principle questions, similar to what the Competition Authority has for decisions from its appeal body.
Increase the current guideline social assistance rates by 1,000 kroner per month starting from January 2024, pending SIFO's investigation of new rates.

Propose changes to this year's national budget so that municipalities can quickly ensure the payment of a one-time amount of 1,000 kroner to recipients of social assistance, plus 1,000 kroner per child.
Propose changes to this year's national budget so that voluntary organizations that help the poor before Christmas receive an extraordinary support of 30 million kroner.
Investigate a guideline holiday supplement for social assistance.

Ensure that Nav clearly communicates that, in general, there are no requirements to sell assets in order to receive social assistance, and that asset sale requirements will only be directed at long-term recipients of social assistance and are not applicable to new recipients. Among other things, this should be clearly stated on Nav's website regarding social assistance.

Propose guidelines that ensure the most vulnerable users are guaranteed access to an available and open Nav, including national requirements for opening hours for drop-in visits that at least match the opening hours of the municipal town hall. Such guidelines should be developed in collaboration with the employees in accordance with the principles behind the government's trust reform. The Parliament requests the government to ensure that the Labor and Welfare Administration has sufficient resources to implement these changes.
Investigate how a guiding income allowance can be introduced without reducing social assistance.

Review the use of the terms "collective agreement" and "union representative" in the Working Environment Act. "Collective agreement" should consistently refer to a collective agreement with a trade union that has the right to negotiate, and "union representative" should refer to union representatives with real rights according to main agreements.
Specify in the guidelines regarding the hiring of labor that only union representatives with real rights under the main agreements can enter into agreements for hiring with the company.

Consider the need for a comprehensive review of the use of the terms "union representative" and "collective agreement" in the Working Environment Act. If it turns out that there is a need for changes, clarifications, or both in this context, the Parliament requests the government to return to the Parliament with proposals for legislative amendments.

Come back to the Parliament with the necessary legislative changes to reverse the amendments made in connection with the Parliament's consideration of Innst. 108 L (2022–2023), cf. Prop. 131 L (2021–2022) Amendments to the Working Environment Act, etc. (in- and out-leasing from staffing agencies).

Engage in dialogue with the parties in the labor market and initiate the process of expanding the ban on hiring from staffing companies to also include the ISO area in the petroleum industry, and report back to the Parliament with a proposal on this by the end of 2024.

Present a plan for how public procurement and tenders can prioritize social sustainability and inclusion to a greater extent, including considering the establishment of a national prequalification scheme for social entrepreneurs.
Ensure that Nav increases the use of innovative procurement as a method, so that it is implemented in all counties of the country.
Ensure that Nav tests new financing models for collaboration with social entrepreneurs and increases the use of outcome contracts.
Increase the municipalities' and Nav's competence and capacity to collaborate with social entrepreneurs, including prioritizing the market contact apparatus.
Promote a strategy to strengthen the role and offerings of the nonprofit sector in the labor and welfare field.

Necessary improvement measures must be implemented quickly to protect these from dangerous incidents and accidents related to lack of maintenance, insufficient height, or incorrect design. Facilitate more goods and freight delivery in the centers of the largest cities through cargo bikes and lighter electric vehicles by establishing government support schemes for urban transshipment centers.
Ensure that the network for sustainable regional cities has the opportunity to enter into a binding partnership with the state in connection with the new national transport plan for 2025-2036.
Present a legislative proposal for national minimum standards for snow removal and salting requirements for infrastructure for pedestrians and cyclists during winter.
Ensure that the responsibility for signage and warnings on county roads is transferred to the county municipalities.

Propose to legislate broader control and sanction powers that municipalities and county municipalities can use against illegal obstacles and incorrect implementation of work notifications on roads, sidewalks, and bike lanes.
Create a guide for the development of walking and cycling strategies for use by municipalities and county municipalities.
Investigate the possibility of establishing 20 km/h as a new speed limit that all levels of government can adopt.
Investigate the possibility of implementing automatic traffic control (ATK) at lower speed limits and for more purposes than currently used.
Revoke the previous approval to impose a fee on toll tag subscriptions.
Ensure that the Norwegian State Educational Loan Fund temporarily halts the submission of new claims to collections.
Propose a ban on the use of external, commercial debt collection agencies for public entities.

Review existing relevant regulations and make changes that will prohibit the sale of claims for unsecured debt that is granted after a simplified credit assessment, in line with the intention of the majority decision from Innst. 373 S (2021–2022).
Promote a proposal for a new debt collection law within the state budget for 2025.
Propose that the borrower has a right of first refusal for the claim on the same terms that the lender is willing to sell to a third party.
Return to the Parliament in an appropriate manner with a proposal to limit the use of external debt collectors in the collection of unsecured debt.

Suggest rules and procedures that ensure that individuals with disabilities (cognitive disabilities) who are suspected of committing crimes are identified and receive better-adapted police interrogations.

Here are some suggested guidelines for how individuals with disabilities (with and without diagnoses) in Norwegian prisons should be assessed:

1. **Initial Screening**: Upon admission, conduct a comprehensive initial screening to identify any disabilities or special needs. This should include a questionnaire and interviews with the individual.

2. **Multidisciplinary Team**: Involve a multidisciplinary team, including medical professionals, psychologists, social workers, and rehabilitation specialists, to assess the individual's needs holistically.

3. **Individualized Assessment**: Tailor the assessment process to the individual's specific circumstances, taking into account both physical and mental health, as well as any learning disabilities.

4. **Confidentiality and Consent**: Ensure that all assessments are conducted with respect for the individual's privacy and that informed consent is obtained before sharing any personal information.

5. **Regular Reviews**: Implement a system for regular reviews of the individual's needs and progress, allowing for adjustments to support and accommodations as necessary.

6. **Accessibility**: Ensure that the assessment process is accessible to all individuals, including those with communication difficulties or other barriers to participation.

7. **Training for Staff**: Provide training for prison staff on how to recognize and support individuals with disabilities, ensuring they understand the importance of sensitivity and appropriate accommodations.

8. **Collaboration with External Organizations**: Work with external organizations that specialize in disability rights and support to enhance the assessment process and provide additional resources.

9. **Documentation and Follow-Up**: Maintain thorough documentation of assessments and follow-up actions taken to support individuals with disabilities, ensuring continuity of care.

10. **Feedback Mechanism**: Establish a feedback mechanism for individuals to express their experiences and suggest improvements to the assessment process.

By implementing these guidelines, Norwegian prisons can better support individuals with disabilities, ensuring their rights and needs are recognized and addressed.

Propose legislative changes and other measures that clarify the conditions of imprisonment for individuals with disabilities, provide guidelines for how the imprisonment should be adapted for this group, and improve the current conditions of imprisonment.

Develop a plan to strengthen the recruitment of healthcare personnel in elderly care, while also considering measures for flexible shift arrangements and increased wages to make it more attractive to work in health and care.

Consider measures and appropriately return to the Storting to prioritize preventive health work for the elderly, including physical activity, healthy nutrition, and early access to healthcare services for disease prevention and early treatment.

Come back to the Parliament with support measures for relatives who care for elderly family members, including counseling, training, and access to respite services to avoid caregiver burnout. Additionally, the possibility of strengthening the compensation scheme for lost income should be considered.
Come back with a specification on safe housing, and propose funding for the program no later than in the state budget for 2025.

Facilitate more and better collaboration between the Norwegian State Housing Bank and private initiatives, making it easier to build more social housing forms with, for example, access to shared spaces.
Develop a national standard for how individuals can better adapt their daily lives and homes to be more age-friendly.
Facilitate that all elderly individuals living at home who wish to do so have the opportunity to participate in an activity or community on a weekly basis.
Strengthen the Housing Bank and expand the support schemes so that they contribute to better planning of one's housing situation for seniors.
Establish a grant scheme to build more safe housing for the elderly in the district. The Parliament requests the government to return with a suitable proposal.
Ensure that the Housing Bank's loan and grant schemes for adapting and upgrading one's own home become better known to municipalities and the elderly.

Reintroduce the approval model for free user choice so that municipalities can more easily open up for options within home services and home nursing. The Parliament requests the government to return in an appropriate manner.
Reintroduce national collection of waiting time statistics for municipalities to nursing homes.
Ensure that all municipalities systematically conduct user and relative surveys in health and care services, and that there is transparency regarding the results of these surveys.

Promote a proposal for a legal requirement that municipal councils must annually review a report on the state of health and care services, where both user and relative surveys, objective quality indicators, and user satisfaction are measured.
Revise the National Strategy for Voluntary Work in the Health and Care Sector in collaboration with Voluntary Norway and KS.
Set the goal and work towards ensuring that all municipalities offer preventive home visits during the reform period.
Place greater emphasis on ensuring that future living situations are also assessed as part of the preventive home visits conducted in the municipalities.
Ensure that mental health is taken care of in the health professional education programs.
Strengthen the systematic nutritional work and ensure that food, meals, and nutrition are part of all preventive, therapeutic, habilitative, and rehabilitative efforts for the elderly.
To increase knowledge and competence about food, meals, and nutrition in the municipalities.
Develop your own quality indicators for medication use in nursing homes and ensure that the requirement for regular and systematic medication reviews is followed up.

Review and improve the regulations for family leave options in the workplace to ensure equality and enhance the ability to combine work and caregiving without incurring financial difficulties or falling out of the labor market.
Contribute to ensuring that municipalities create better conditions for establishing a more dementia-friendly society, and that the municipalities have a plan for how this should be done.
Ensure that a grant scheme is established to encourage the construction of more sheltered housing for the elderly in rural municipalities.
Develop a specific housing program for people with dementia that will make it easier to adapt their own homes, as well as to acquire a more suitable living space.
Ensure that all municipalities have a relative strategy and provide relatives with more flexible respite care options.
Investigate and implement a care pathway for dementia that ensures better diagnosis and follow-up.
Facilitate more low-threshold services in municipalities for people with dementia and their relatives, such as more memory teams, dementia schools, and respite care services for relatives.

Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how seriously ill patients who fall outside the RAM-MS study can be offered stem cell treatment through the exception scheme when national medical expertise recommends such treatment.

Ensure that stem cell treatment for MS patients is implemented in Norwegian hospitals in accordance with professional recommendations from national medical expertise for patients who cannot be included in the RAM-MS study.

Inform the Parliament about the progress and financing of the national RAM-MS study on stem cell treatment, in accordance with the Parliament's decision during the consideration of Representative Proposal 221 S (2020–2021) (decision no. 991 (2020–2021)).
Establish a national 3R center for research on alternatives to animal testing based on the model of similar centers in Sweden and other European countries.
Promote the necessary legislative amendments to ensure a legal basis for revoking a ship's right to sail under the Norwegian flag, in consideration of national interests.
Come back with suggestions for the registration of positions and financial interests also for government members' household members, including spouses and partners.
Ensure that the requirements for the registration of government members' positions and financial interests are at all times at least as strict as the requirements for parliamentary representatives.

Investigate proposals for the registration of positions and financial interests for government politicians' household members, including spouses and partners, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Investigate the possibility of formalizing the arrangement for the Coordination of Local Substance Abuse and Crime Prevention Measures (SLT) and making it nationwide, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Investigate the possibility of enshrining in law or otherwise clarifying the municipalities' responsibility for crime prevention, including assessing the model in the Swedish law regarding municipalities' responsibility for crime prevention, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Initiate a pilot project in Oslo and Kristiansand municipalities with the establishment of an interdisciplinary action group focused on children and young people who are at high risk of committing serious offenses, based on a model from Denmark.
Establish dedicated seizure teams in each police district. The team should consist of a lawyer, an investigator, and an auditor.

Ensure that the work on organized crime and gangs is prioritized and provided with resources in the police districts where this is required as a result of the crime situation, and that this is secured for the long term and with predictability.
Ensure a buffer capacity within mental health services for mapping the mental and physical health of children and young people at high risk of committing serious offenses.
Consider the practical and principled aspects of a potential introduction of search zones for weapon control in Norway.

Promote proposals on how to ensure that youth sentences have real content regardless of where one lives. Such regulation can occur through law or regulation with a minimum standard for what types of measures should be available in all municipalities and health enterprises.
Promote the necessary legislative amendments to make it easier for the prosecution to confiscate assets obtained through criminal activities.
Propose amendments to the law that authorize the imposition of bans on staying in certain areas during specific time periods for those convicted of gang-related crime.
Promote the necessary legislative amendments to ensure a significant increase in the penalty level for illegal possession of firearms.

Consider whether the court should have a more active role in the execution of sentences, both in terms of setting conditions for the punishment and in order to be able to monitor the implementation of it, following the model of drug programs with court oversight.
Consider changes in the relevant legislation regarding the right to appointed counsel in youth planning meetings, both in youth follow-up and in youth sentencing.

Promote the necessary legislative amendments to ensure the establishment of a fast track for the swift adjudication of offenses committed by perpetrators who were under 18 years of age at the time of the act.

Conduct a legal review of relevant legislation related to confidentiality and information obligations for all relevant entities working with children and young people at high risk of committing serious offenses, with particular emphasis on the possibilities for information flow.

Investigate proposals that uphold the intentions of the legislative changes outlined in the letter from the Justice Committee dated November 28, 2023, to the Ministry of Justice and Public Security, and submit proposals for legislative amendments during the spring of 2024.
Promote a proposal to extend the sulfur tax to include coal, coke, and emissions from refining.
Investigate equal treatment of intangible assets in wealth assessment, so that technology is exempted in the same way as other intangible assets such as patents, know-how, and business value.
Investigate a scheme that allows for the calculation of wealth tax as an average over the last three years.

Investigate alternative models for taxing emissions in the waste sector that reduce the incentives to export waste to Sweden and maintain the incentives to implement emission-reducing measures at Norwegian incineration plants, and report back to the Storting no later than in the revised national budget for 2024.
Investigate the landfill fee for gypsum waste and report back to the Storting no later than in the revised national budget for 2024.

Create a comprehensive plan to reclaim privatized services in-house within the public sector, as well as to mandate state enterprises to reduce the use of private providers in areas where the enterprises can perform tasks with their own employees.
Initiate a consequence assessment with the aim of including users over 67 years old in the scheme for resource-demanding services.

Map the municipalities' needs for revising the land use planning framework and report back to the Parliament with proposals on how municipalities can strengthen their competence and processing capacity regarding land management, nature, and outdoor recreation.
Come back to the Storting with an evaluation of the child welfare reform and how the reform has affected the economy of Norwegian municipalities and the provision of services.
Consider providing electricity support to cultural historical properties and return to the Storting in an appropriate manner.
Expand the Merkur scheme to include service trade.
Assess the situation for small shops in light of the electricity price situation and consider strengthening and expanding the Merkur scheme in connection with the revised national budget for 2024.
Consider incorporating boat routes to island communities without detour roads into the free ferry scheme.

Present an action plan to ensure that the settlement rate is maintained, for example through a proposal to increase funding for chapter 581 Housing and Living Environment Measures, item 76 Rental Housing, and trials with new housing models.
Stop the reception of quota refugees as long as the war in Ukraine continues.
Present a plan for a gradual phase-out of CO2 compensation for the fishing fleet, with the goal of complete phase-out by 2030 at the latest.
Propose the establishment of a CO2 fund for the fishing fleet.

Clarifying that the main principle that projects receiving support through the business-oriented support system should have a place on the path towards the transition goal for 2030, and that Norway should be a low-emission society by 2050, means that no support will be given to oil and gas projects through Innovation Norway.
Exclude mineral activities on the seabed as eligible under chapter 2421, item 75 Green platform, until sustainable methods for the extraction of seabed minerals can be documented.
Clarify through the allocation letter that Export Financing Norway shall not provide new loans and guarantees for oil and gas projects.
Promote proposals to allow non-profit organizations to apply for programs managed by Innovation Norway.
Prioritize the allocation in chapter 904 item 45 for the establishment of a real-time shareholder register in accordance with request resolution no. 496, dated June 16, 2014.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal for an environmental technology scheme and follow-up on the work of the Aquaculture Committee.

Make the necessary changes to the regulations so that volumes taken during reductions due to red traffic lights can be produced using technology that has minimal impact on lice infestation on migrating wild salmon smolt.
To initiate a survey of the actual equipment needs of the country's students.

Ensure that the operations of Kongshaug Music High School, Oslo City Steiner School, and Kristen VGS Vennesla can continue unchanged until a new, fairer funding rate for these students is implemented.

Follow up on the majority's remarks in Innst. 378 L (2022–2023) regarding tuition fees for students from countries outside the EU and EEA, as well as transitional arrangements for the institutions, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Present the announced review of the practice and use of the vocational certificate scheme at work to the Storting in an appropriate manner, and no later than in connection with the revised national budget in the spring of 2024.

Ensure that the intention of the regulation regarding the allocation of pension grants to private kindergartens is upheld, so that private kindergartens, upon application, receive coverage for actual and documented pension costs.

Postpone the proposal for a new funding model for private primary schools until the announced working group has submitted its report, which must be based on a broad factual basis and involve good participation from the independent school organizations.

Ensure that the operations of Kongshaug Music High School, Oslo Steinerschool, and Kristen VGS Vennesla can continue unchanged until a new and fairer funding rate for these students can be implemented, and that this assessment is made in connection with the announced review of private schools.
Present a proposal for a national student ombudsman for vocational school students.
Ensure that the state contributes its share so that World Skills has stable conditions to organize the school national championships and other vocational competitions.
Revise the support scheme for organizations working against poverty, so that it becomes possible to receive funding for projects that help people navigate the Nav system.
Come back to the Parliament with a scheme so that organizations that assist people in their dealings with Nav receive the necessary financial support until the Nav Ombudsman is established.

Come to the Parliament with a simplification of Nav's programs for getting into work, turning it into a service where one can customize a path for each individual, with the goal of securing permanent employment.
Start a preliminary project for the procurement of long-range ground-based air defense with the capability to combat tactical ballistic missiles.
Present a new national strategy for antibiotic resistance before the UN's planned high-level meeting on antibiotic resistance in the autumn of 2024.
Strengthen Amathea's framework conditions and facilitate the establishment of more offices.

Ensure that all health enterprises have arrangements with their own pool of temporary staff/recruitment units, with permanently employed substitutes, aimed at meeting the staffing needs of the health enterprise.
Include enhanced influenza vaccines for particularly care-dependent elderly individuals over 65 years old in the adult vaccination program.
Ensure that the activity-based funding in hospitals is increased to at least 50% to ensure efficiency and the shortest possible waiting times for patients.
Implement a municipal pilot project in 2024, where elderly individuals living at home can order food delivered to their door at cost price.

Continue the item in the state budget with funding for the net increase of new round-the-clock care places, so that there will be more places, and that municipalities are enabled to meet the increased demand.
Lift the cap on the number of changes of general practitioners.
Accelerate the process of simplifying the rules for marketing vaccination, so that as many people as possible can access information about vaccination.
Allow snus without tobacco and other similar less harmful products.
Present a scheme that allows for the sale of more over-the-counter medications in stores.
Initiate the design of a geriatric ward in Alta municipality during 2024.
Facilitate that also approved 'Inn på tunet' farms that are not members of Inn på tunet Norge SA can receive grants upon application.

Conduct an independent follow-up evaluation of the introduction of tenders for blue prescriptions, involving patients and professional environments. The evaluation should take place over a period of three years. The government is requested to present the evaluation to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Ensure that doctors still have the authority to prescribe the medication they consider best for each individual patient, without unnecessary bureaucracy.
Ensure that no patients are forced to switch medications to the tender winner.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal on how to reduce the number of patients who are waiting in hospitals.
Scrap the proposal to introduce tenders in the blue prescription area as a permanent arrangement from 2024.
Initiate the planning of a fully equipped maternity ward in Alta municipality during 2024.
Provide an assessment of the need for improvements to the landing sites at emergency hospitals to ensure that the new rescue helicopters can utilize them.
Ensure that more 'inn på tunet' services are established to provide various types of offerings for individuals with dementia, mental health issues, and/or substance abuse problems.

Transfer the funding responsibility for continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) for individuals with type 2 diabetes who use insulin, from the specialist healthcare service to the blue prescription scheme, effective from January 1, 2024.
To earmark 10 million kroner for Livslosen and the work to strengthen the preventive efforts against suicide.
Come back to the Parliament with a concrete plan for the establishment of an adult vaccination program in 2025.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to reduce the deductible limit.
Ensure that there are no cuts to inpatient beds in psychiatry at Oslo University Hospital.

Continue the requirement that part of the investment grant for round-the-clock care facilities in institutions and care homes should go towards the net increase of round-the-clock care places in the municipalities.

Consider expanding the Model Development Program for clinical nutritionists as a resource for the care services to also include other parts of the municipal health and care services. The Parliament requests the government to return with a suitable proposal.
Establish a separate grant scheme for Ønsketransporten at the Norwegian Directorate of Health, based on the grant scheme for Fontenehus and Fontenehus Norway.
Allow patients to keep their original medications if a tender in the blue prescription area is unexpectedly implemented.
Enter into contracts with Norwegian pharmaceutical manufacturers instead of foreign ones to ensure Norwegian emergency production.
Ensure that none of the current emergency units or maternity services are closed during the planned restructuring process in Health North.
Ensure that elderly individuals receiving home care receive the dental treatment they are entitled to.

Evaluate the entire deductible system with the aim of examining how the system affects different patient groups, and return to the Parliament with proposals for changes that ensure the scheme does not exacerbate social health disparities.

Halt further implementation of the Health Platform in Health Møre and Romsdal and Health Nord-Trøndelag until St. Olav's Hospital is at normal activity and staffing levels and corrections in accordance with the Health Inspectorate's report have been completed.

Start the work of transitioning the BPA scheme from a municipal responsibility to a state scheme under Nav. This must happen without anyone losing or being at risk of losing their place in the scheme.
Reintroduce 'The Golden Rule' which ensures that mental health care and addiction treatment each have greater growth than somatic care in hospitals.
Establish positions as national chief nurse and national chief midwife.
Ensure that assessments of alternatives for the dissolution of the Health Platform are made if St. Olav cannot reach normal activity and staffing levels within a reasonable time.
Ensure that the activity-based funding in hospitals is maintained at 50% to ensure efficiency and the shortest possible waiting times for patients.
Investigate whether clinical pharmacists in pharmacies should be tasked with conducting regular medication reviews for patients, in close collaboration with the patients' general practitioners.
Utilize available private treatment capacity to reduce the long healthcare queues.

Ensure that patients who are part of the transitional arrangement following the phasing out of free treatment choice, and who require longer treatment time, receive good follow-up from their health enterprise.
Ensure that the competence and experience from the primary care teams contribute to the further development of an interdisciplinary general practitioner service for the benefit of the patients.

Consider the need for a habilitation and rehabilitation reform that contributes to improving the services in, and the collaboration between, primary healthcare and specialist healthcare. The Parliament requests the government to return with a suitable proposal.

Investigate the extension of the right to dental treatment for individuals who have previously been addicted to substances, so that dental health issues resulting from past substance addiction are addressed and an acceptable dental health condition is restored. The Parliament requests the government to report back in an appropriate manner, and no later than in the budget for 2025.
That a thorough investigation and open hearing are conducted before the introduction of tendering for blue prescriptions is established as a permanent arrangement.
Investigate how to develop more respite services for single parents based on the model from Rødhette and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Follow up on the recommendations in the report "A Childhood for Life" from the expert group on children in poor families, by increasing child benefits, taxing them, and equalizing the rates to 31,535 kroner per child.
Investigate whether child benefits should be included in the income basis for recipients of social security benefits.
Ensure that the father's right to parental benefits is not affected by the mother's activity requirements.
Come back with an assessment of making the Arctic Philharmonic a national orchestra, on par with the Oslo Philharmonic and the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra.

Propose to amend the Value Added Tax Act so that § 6-2 is reintroduced, and that the law or regulation is changed so that VAT exemption for electronic news services is contingent upon the content being aimed at the general public in Norway. The criterion should be negatively defined in the sense that it is clarified that internationally produced news services that are broadcast with the same content in several countries will not be considered sufficiently aimed at the general public in Norway.

Start the process of assessing whether the state should take over the financing of the Norwegian Horse Center, as well as tasks related to doping control, stable inspections, and preventive doping work. The government is also requested to amend the regulations regarding the distribution of profits from horse betting, so that the share for those who are providers of the game, namely harness racing and thoroughbred racing, is maintained and increased.
Present a proposal for the legal establishment of interdisciplinary health assessments in health legislation.
Ensure that the film incentive scheme has multiple application deadlines each year, until the scheme is converted to a rule-based system.

Return to the Storting with a binding escalation plan for the film incentive scheme. When the escalation plan is fulfilled, the government is requested to propose a transition of the film incentive scheme to a rule-based system.
Reintroduce the gift matching scheme.

Investigate the possibilities, within the framework of the monopoly model and EEA law, for raising the revenue cap on lotteries, merging licenses, and removing the expiration date on lottery licenses.
Adjust the revenue threshold for large lotteries with a turnover of up to 360 million kroner.
Ensure the necessary changes to the regulations for private lotteries to facilitate digital solutions for payment and distribution as soon as practically possible, in line with Norsk Tipping.
Investigate what effect an expansion of the tax deduction limit, for example a doubling, will have on the independent income of voluntary clubs and organizations.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for an adjustment of the child benefit for children between 6 and 18 years old, to the same level as for children between 0 and 6 years old.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for amendments to the law that prevent the reduction of other benefits, such as advance maintenance payments and support for residents in asylum reception centers, against child benefits.
Present a plan for the further increase of child benefits for all children.
Present a proposal that will ensure an annual adjustment of child benefits linked to price growth.
Ensure sufficient progress in the projects related to the "death roads" E16 Skaret–Hønefoss and E39 Veibust–Blindheim–Moa.
Ensure sufficient progress in the road project rv. 15 Strynefjellet with the branch to Geiranger.
Maintain the planned progress with preparatory work and construction start for the Stad ship tunnel.

Ensure that the Numedalsbanen, including the stretch from Flesberg to Rødberg, remains part of the national railway network and that provisions are made for the operation of heritage trains on the line.

Ensure that all municipalities revise their land use and zoning plans by 2027 to ensure that the plans comply with current regulations for nature, and that planned development of nature is reduced by at least 50%.
Propose that the state should cover 25% of the municipalities' costs for reducing their emissions.
Allocate at least 1 billion kroner to forest conservation annually.
Establish a grant scheme for the cleanup of lead ammunition at shooting ranges.

Ensure that Norwegian forests are managed in such a way that Norway is not dependent on purchasing forest credits to meet requirements under the EU's climate regulations in the forestry and land use sector starting from 2025.

Present an estimate of the cost to upgrade all wastewater treatment plants that require increased treatment in connection with the Oslofjord, no later than in conjunction with the revised national budget for 2024.
Ensure stable and predictable funding for Runde Environmental Center through the national budget.

Enter into an additional agreement with Enova that gives them greater responsibility for ensuring that the goals of Norway's climate agreement with the EU are met, including the sub-goals established for the transport sector. Enova must be given the responsibility for establishing a national network of filling stations for liquid biogas and at least 30 filling stations for hydrogen by 2028.

Present an improved Climate Status and Plan for 2024 that includes a binding escalation plan with scheduled measures and instruments to ensure that Norway meets its climate goals submitted to the UN under the Paris Agreement. The document should include emission budgets for the non-ETS sector for each year from 2024 onwards, sector-specific targets for emission reductions in Norway, and an emission budget that demonstrates how Norway fulfills its climate commitments in the forestry and land use sector.
That priorities and the actual allocation of funds for initiatives and measures are presented in a clear manner in future budget proposals.
Initiate work to designate many more prioritized species and selected natural types under the Nature Diversity Act, in line with the Parliament's stated ambitions in this area.
Present a plan for how the goal of 10% protection of productive forests can be achieved by 2030 at the latest.
Create a plan for how 30% of Norway's marine areas can be protected by 2030.
Ensure that the scheme for selected cultural landscapes is expanded to at least 100 selected cultural landscapes by 2027.
Prohibit the use of fossil fuels in industry starting from 2030.
That electricity consumption in buildings should not exceed 54 TWh in 2030.
Implement the work on a supplementary national park plan that will ensure a representative protection of Norwegian nature.

Initiate a Nature Plan 2030 report based on the model of the Climate Plan 2030. The report should include proposals for cost-calculated measures, instruments, and mechanisms that demonstrate how we can make Norway area-neutral by 2030 and meet the goals of the Nature Agreement.

Consider measures that enable the petroleum industry to a greater extent to apply for funding from research programs that are currently limited to research institutes, including programs that focus on early-stage technologies.

Investigate carbon differential contracts or other suitable instruments that can effectively scale emission-reducing measures in the industry, and report back to the Parliament no later than in the revised national budget for 2024.
Change the Enova support for solar energy to include battery storage and systems for smart management of electricity from solar panels.
Set requirements for the recovery of waste heat from processes that emit a lot of heat, such as industrial plants, waste incineration, data centers, and hydrogen production.

Investigate the introduction of flexible energy requirements for rehabilitation in the building technical regulations, so that more property owners choose to rehabilitate buildings with efficient energy solutions instead of demolishing them.
Ensure an independent evaluation of the efforts against pink salmon in general and in the Tana River system in particular.

Investigate various models with energy savings certificates, including whether energy savings certificates can be a more effective tool for reducing energy consumption than current support schemes, and report back to the Parliament no later than in the revised national budget in 2024.
Instruct NVE to prioritize faster processing of small hydropower concessions to strengthen the power balance in the short term.
Ensure that measures to develop commercial value chains for the development and use of blue hydrogen are treated equally with green hydrogen in the policy framework.
Present a plan for increased local energy production and energy production on gray areas in connection with the revised budget in 2024.

Investigate the possibility of expanding the current ban on the use of mineral oil for permanent heating to include fossil gas, with a view to implementation from 2028. The consequences for safety, preparedness, and self-sufficiency should be given special emphasis in the impact assessment of the change.
Implement electrification of Melkøya with alternatives other than power from the mainland.
Withdraw the permit concerning the amended development plans (amended PUD/PAD) for the Snøhvit field and Hammerfest LNG.
Require Equinor to eliminate greenhouse gas emissions from the gas facility at Melkøya without using power from the mainland by 2030.
Propose rule changes to introduce a maximum interest rate differential between deposit and loan rates.
Explain the competitive situation and prices of banking services in Norway, and assess measures that can strengthen competition and contribute to more affordable services.

Consider various measures to limit the banks' record-high profitability, including whether to introduce extraordinary taxation, and return to the Storting with proposals on this no later than in the revised national budget for 2024.

Make an assessment of whether the level of the financial tax is sufficiently high to fulfill the purpose of being a substitute for the lack of value-added tax on financial services, and return to the Storting with proposals that ensure the industry pays as much tax as other businesses no later than in the revised national budget for 2024.
Demand that the bank demonstrates greater social responsibility and offers its customers better interest rates than today.
To investigate a public banking alternative, either by expanding the role of the Norwegian State Housing Bank in the Norwegian banking market or by establishing a completely new bank.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals that ensure Norwegian banks must increase deposit rates at least as much as lending rates, and that they cannot raise lending rates faster than deposit rates following an interest rate increase from the Norges Bank.
Consider whether SSB should be tasked with regularly publishing the margins of individual banks.
Conduct an updated assessment of whether the introduction of account number portability can help improve the competitive situation in the Norwegian banking market.
Present necessary proposals to reduce the unnecessarily long processing time for car support at Nav, such as pre-approval, pre-ordering, and long-term planning.

Review the regulations and organization of the car support in Nav to ensure that case processing, orders, and logistics are streamlined, so that people who rely on the car as an aid in their daily lives do not risk being without a car.

Conduct a legal review with the aim of abolishing language that describes disabled individuals or persons with disabilities using outdated, discriminatory, and stigmatizing terms, and return to the Parliament with proposals for necessary legal amendments to ensure this.
Propose to introduce mandatory ID tagging of cats.
Ensure that the introduction of mandatory ID marking of dogs comes into effect as soon as possible.

Ensure that the Norwegian Railway Authority immediately initiates an investigation into the consequences for operational stability and preparedness if heavy maintenance of rolling stock is no longer located in Norway. The investigation must be conducted in collaboration with relevant stakeholders.
Take the initiative for stronger protection of marine areas in the Arctic.
Take the initiative for an international agreement that no country shall open new maritime areas in the Arctic for petroleum activities or the extraction of seabed minerals.
Halt the ongoing opening process on the Norwegian continental shelf and introduce a moratorium of at least 10 years for mineral activities on the Norwegian shelf.

Work actively internationally, particularly within the International Seabed Authority (ISA), for a moratorium on mineral extraction from the seabed until it is proven that such activities can occur without loss of biodiversity, important habitats, and the natural functions of ecosystems.
Clarify that considerations of national security will be a criterion in the allocation of extraction permits.
Present the initial plans for the extraction of seabed minerals to the Parliament as a proposal before the department approves the extraction plan according to the Seabed Minerals Act § 4-4.

Ensure that the Norwegian Petroleum Directorate gathers input from other relevant government agencies, including the Norwegian Environment Agency and the Institute of Marine Research, in connection with the preparation of its proposal for a work program to the ministry.
Instruct Statkraft to offer better fixed-price agreements.

Facilitate even better for publicly owned power companies to offer more affordable fixed-price agreements, for example with a maximum price around 35 øre/kWh, by establishing that such a price level is not in conflict with the regulations on standard fixed-price agreements.

Lower the compensation threshold for local grid companies to 35 øre/kWh and distribute the extraordinary revenues to Statnett to a greater extent, so that the congestion revenues benefit electricity customers more.
Ensure that parts of Statnett's congestion income from 2023 and 2024 are used to reduce grid fees in areas with high electricity prices, also for the first quarter of 2024.

Come back to the Parliament with extraordinary measures that can be implemented in NO2 to compensate for the extraordinarily high electricity prices in this price area, pending more structural changes in the electricity market.

"Develop a regulation that ensures that congestion revenues are used to compensate for high electricity prices, beyond the current compensation for increased grid loss costs. It is requested that the scheme ensures that congestion revenues are used where they occur."
Negotiate with the EU to use bottleneck revenues from trade with EU countries for payments that can compensate for the consequences of increased electricity prices.
Make the standard fixed-price contracts more flexible by removing the limitation that the contracts must have a fixed amount of electricity.
Remove the time limit on standard fixed-price electricity contracts that require the agreements to last for 3.5 or 7 years.
Set clear expectations in the ownership dialogue with Statkraft that the company should be among the market leaders in fixed-price agreements.

Consider which measures can be quickly implemented to prevent and mitigate a situation with large price differences between a price area and adjacent price areas, including measures in the electricity grids, use of congestion revenues, structuring of price areas, and other relevant and applicable measures.
Do not grant permits for new wind power projects in Sámi reindeer grazing areas until the ongoing human rights violations in Fosen have ceased.

Suspend the processing of all wind power projects in Sámi reindeer grazing areas until an agreement is reached with the affected reindeer herding districts regarding the remedy for the human rights violations in Fosen.
Present a bill that gives NVE the authority to issue early rejections of concession applications that clearly conflict with reindeer husbandry and natural interests.
Include a multi-year funding plan that ensures rapid scaling of efforts against flooding and landslides in accordance with the recommendations from NVE and the Gjerdrum Committee.
To ensure that DSB receives the necessary funds as quickly as possible to prioritize the operation and further development of the Knowledge Bank.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for amended regulations that require municipalities to revise land use plans every ten years, in order to ensure that these are adapted to updated knowledge about the consequences of climate change and the risk of flooding and landslides.
Suggest how municipalities can be compensated for expenses related to climate adaptation during the spring of 2024.

Come back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner with a proposal for a national fund for the municipalities' water and sewage upgrades, which will finance a water and sewage network adapted to future climate changes.

Present a plan for scaling up efforts to strengthen municipalities' expertise in nature and climate, as well as a plan for how the grant scheme for climate adaptation should be increased to reach a level that enables municipalities to effectively implement good climate adaptation measures.
Develop updated climate adaptation plans every four years.
Present a proposal for a ban on the extraction of peat from wetlands, as well as a ban on the import of peat products to the private market.
Present specific measures to strengthen the use of forests as protective measures against flooding and landslides, including measures under § 12 of the Forestry Act.
Ensure that no government grants are allocated for forest road construction aimed at logging in areas particularly prone to landslides.
Consider appointing a coordinating national stormwater authority.
Allow municipalities to use organizational measures instead of permanent protection to safeguard new buildings against flooding, in accordance with the recommendations from NVE.

Consider measures to strengthen municipal preparedness for extreme weather and subsequent events, including supporting increased training frequency, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Consider the establishment of shorter modular competence programs for the municipal sector to strengthen professional expertise in climate adaptation.
Harvest experiences from the pilot project on the establishment and operation of regional climate adaptation networks, and consider expanding the scheme to all counties.

Develop a consumption-based climate account for emissions abroad resulting from Norwegian economic activity. A consumption-based climate account should be in addition to the emissions statistics that Norway already maintains.
Come up with a proposal for a specific emissions target for consumption-based emissions no later than in connection with the state budget for 2025.

Prepare a parliamentary report that includes a goal for emission reductions from emissions abroad resulting from Norwegian economic activity, along with an action plan outlining measures to achieve this goal.
Report to the Storting on the government's work regarding issues related to artificial intelligence.

Establish regulations for the introduction and use of artificial intelligence for various applications before a large-scale rollout of commercially developed artificial intelligence in the public sector takes place.
Establish public AI registers to document how algorithms are used to deliver services to citizens based on knowledge and experiences from comparable countries.

Develop a licensing scheme for the collection, use, and storage of both public data and personal data for commercial actors. Such a licensing scheme must establish requirements regarding which data can be used, for what types of purposes, where and how they are stored, and whether and how they can be shared with various third parties.
Present a parliamentary report on artificial intelligence that outlines how work is being done with artificial intelligence at all levels in all sectors.
Scale up the number of study places in educational areas that are important for understanding and applying artificial intelligence, such as STEM subjects, law, philosophy, and ethics.

Initiate a project to investigate how relevant aspects of Norwegian regulations should be interpreted and applied in light of the use of artificial intelligence, including, among other things, copyright rules, criminal procedure rules, competition law, and administrative regulations.
Establish an independent algorithm oversight.

Present a plan for strengthening research on artificial intelligence and the significance of the use of artificial intelligence in society, as part of the follow-up to the long-term plan for research and higher education.
Prepare for the implementation of the European Union's Artificial Intelligence Act, with the aim of it coming into effect in Norway at the same time as it comes into effect in the EU.
Investigate a requirement for salmon slaughterhouses to notify the next stage in the production line or the buyer upon detection of Listeria monocytogenes in their own monitoring.
Take the initiative, together with the aquaculture industry and the Food Safety Authority, to develop industry guidelines for Listeria monocytogenes in the aquaculture sector.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal that ensures an exception in the Mountain Act for the disposal of commercial property on state common land in cases where there is local agreement on this.
Review Statskog's guidelines for setting lease fees so that they align with the consumer price index, and assess whether the valuation should be determined by an independent third party.
Present a plan of action to the Storting for the care and support of veterans.

Return to the Storting no later than Friday, February 16, 2024, with a proposal for a significant increase in core support for UNRWA to counteract a further deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Gaza.
To increase the funding for UNRWA and work together with other countries to close the funding gap that arose after 12 countries froze their aid to the organization.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal for a multi-year program for support for humanitarian aid and reconstruction of Gaza.
Refer the situation in Palestine to the International Criminal Court.

Take a leading role in the international effort to identify, investigate, and prosecute any war crimes in Gaza, the West Bank, and Israel, and provide resources to the International Criminal Court and non-governmental organizations that contribute to the documentation of war crimes.
Press Israel to allow the International Criminal Court (ICC) access to Gaza, the West Bank, and Israel to investigate potential war crimes.
Ensure that Norwegians evacuated from the war in Gaza are systematically interviewed so that Kripos can map out any witnesses and/or victims of war crimes.
Work to freeze the free trade agreement between EFTA and Israel from 1992.
Freeze the free trade agreement on agricultural products between Israel and Norway that was signed in 1992.

Introduce a ban on all research collaboration and other cooperation with Israeli universities and other research institutions that are involved in military research and/or otherwise contribute to enabling the Israeli military to maintain the occupation.

To take the initiative with allies and like-minded countries to consider the possibility of sanctions against individuals and institutions in Israel that contribute to violations of international law and human rights.
Investigate whether the current behavior-based exclusion criteria for the Government Pension Fund Global adequately capture violations of individual rights resulting from a prolonged occupation.

Consider necessary measures to prevent the Government Pension Fund Global from being invested in companies linked to illegal occupation and other serious violations of individual rights in war and conflict situations.
Change the mandate of the Government Pension Fund Global (SPU) with the aim of halting further investments in Israeli companies and divesting from existing investments in Israeli companies.
Report back to the Storting on how the government has worked to promote international sanctions.
To take the initiative for the EU to impose sanctions on individuals, companies, and institutions that are directly responsible for violations of international law in Gaza and the West Bank.

To initiate that the UN Security Council imposes sanctions against individuals, companies, and institutions that are directly responsible for violations of international law in Gaza and the West Bank.
Advise Norwegian businesses to refrain from trading with Israeli companies as long as the war against Gaza continues.

Ask educational and research institutions to reduce collaboration with Israeli institutions that contribute to maintaining the occupation to a minimum. Collaboration with individual researchers can continue.
Take the initiative for a travel ban on violent Israeli settlers in the Schengen cooperation.

Develop ethical guidelines for Norwegian businesses that discourage economic interactions that support illegal settlements and other violations of international law and human rights in the occupied Palestinian territories.
Work to have Israel listed in the UN Secretary-General's annual report on Children and Armed Conflict (CAAC) for the killing, abuse, and mistreatment of Palestinian children.

Prevent Norway from importing goods from illegal settlements, occupied land, and companies that contribute to violations of international law and human rights in illegally occupied areas, as well as to assess whether this requires a change in legislation.
Not in accordance with the interests of the Palestinians and therefore may contribute to violations of international law.
Support a European initiative to impose visa restrictions against violent Israeli settlers.
Consider necessary measures to ensure that the Norwegian defense industry does not directly or indirectly sell weapons or weapon components to Israel.

Regulate that exceptions can be made from the requirements for Norwegian language skills in the regulations on admission to higher education § 2-2 second paragraph for admission to educational programs where Sami is the language of instruction and studies in Sami languages.

Investigate various models for financing salary costs between projects for permanent employees at state universities and colleges with external funding, for example by changing the regulations for the structure and use of unused appropriations at state universities and colleges (cf. circular F-05-20), so that institutions can use allocations beyond 5% to invest in their employees.

Ensure that any decisions regarding expulsion under the rules of the University and University College Act Chapter 12 are not implemented before students have had their complaints regarding the decisions addressed, if the student wishes to do so.

Come back to the Parliament in the spring of 2024 with an assessment of proposals on how students who wish to do so can have the implementation of decisions regarding expulsion postponed until any appeals against the decisions have been resolved.
Present a plan for how to ensure a good continuing education program for school counselors.
Investigate the need for and organization of diversity advisors so that there is sufficient coverage, and that the service becomes a natural part of the school system.

Consider whether career guidance counselors should be a separate job category in schools, and clarify the requirements for relevant education and competence to be a counselor in schools, for example, in accordance with the recommendations developed by the Norwegian Directorate for Education and Training.

Investigate how the responsibility for the counseling and career guidance service for the entire school journey can be better centralized and coordinated, and how the collaboration between career guidance, Nav, and the labor and business sectors can be strengthened.

Develop a binding escalation plan for improvements in staffing standards that ensures better and more stable coverage of personnel in kindergartens. The goal for the improvement should be a coverage of at least 50% kindergarten teachers and 25% skilled workers. The plan must include, among other things, better financing of the staffing standards, requirements for the use of substitutes, reduction of administrative tasks, and compensation for the time employees spend on necessary work tasks outside of their department or base.
Promote a proposal for a national mobile phone ban in primary schools.
Introduce a national regulation for mobile-free education in Norwegian schools.
Implement a consequence assessment of the fisheries subsidy agreement.
Put the fisheries subsidy agreement out for consultation before it is potentially sent to the Storting for ratification.
Establish an external committee to clarify whether there is a legal basis to determine that ISIS's attacks on the Yazidis violate international law in such a way that it constitutes genocide.
Return to the Parliament with a proposal to legislate the right to be disconnected after office hours.

Promote necessary legislative proposals to ensure that the regulations governing working hours are better aligned with today's and tomorrow's labor market and do not create unnecessary obstacles to entering into individual agreements on flexible working hours.

"Introduce access to agree on a partially independent type of position in line with the Working Hours Committee's proposal from 2016. The positions should have stronger protection than today's independent positions."

Establish a committee tasked with investigating the scope and arrangements of flexible working time solutions in Norwegian working life and gathering experiences from the legislation of other comparable countries regarding the regulation of flexible working hours.
Investigate a scheme that grants parents who have lost children, and other groups who may need it, the right to bereavement leave.
Investigate changes to the care benefit regulations that ensure that more groups are entitled to care benefits, including students and recipients of work assessment allowance.
Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that ensures that everyone who loses a child while covered by the care benefit scheme receives the same right to care benefits if the child dies.

Promote necessary legislative proposals that ensure transparency and access to accounts, quality indicators, staffing situations, and cash flows of private commercial actors providing welfare services with public funding, as well as ensuring that the changes in key parts of the legislation required for genuine insight into public operations also apply to these actors.
Ensure that information about ownership in commercial companies providing welfare services with public funding is available, so that it is clear who is responsible for the welfare service.
Establish a publicly accessible register of all private and non-profit organizations that provide publicly funded welfare services.

Investigate which measures can be implemented to achieve greater transparency among private and non-profit actors providing welfare services, including accounting separation, in sectors that do not already have such or similar regulations.

Investigate what scope Norway has to impose strict requirements regarding employees' salary and working conditions on actors providing publicly funded welfare services. The investigation must include a clarification on whether it is possible to require that the actors must offer salary and working conditions equivalent to the nationwide collective agreements that municipalities and private and non-profit actors have, as well as the collective agreement of the City of Oslo.
Investigate how it can be required that user-oriented work is primarily carried out by employees rather than contractors within publicly funded welfare services.
Gather more knowledge about the differences in sick leave and other aspects of employment conditions between private, non-profit, and public enterprises within publicly funded welfare services.

Develop a guide on how user involvement can and should be utilized in the planning of a procurement, in the design of the contract, and in the evaluation of bids when a welfare service is to be procured.
Ensure that regular user and relative surveys are conducted in all welfare services, regardless of whether the service is provided in private, non-profit, or public management.
Develop standard surveys for each individual welfare service where they do not already exist, so that the results can be compared nationally, and the quality of the survey is as high as possible.
Focus on how the state can contribute to the development of health and care services in the north, as well as ensuring the population's safety and preparedness.

Ensure a hospital structure in Northern Norway that addresses the need for preparedness and comprehensive community development. The analyses and recommendations of the Total Preparedness Commission and the Defense Commission should be actively utilized in the work.
Come back to the Parliament with a case regarding the hospital structure in Health North, so that a final decision on the new structure can be made by the Parliament.
Ensure that the daily capacity at the DPS in Helse Nord is not weakened, and that great emphasis is placed on preserving existing services in the ongoing process.

Follow up on decision 742 (2022-2023) regarding a parliamentary report on user-controlled personal assistance as soon as possible, and request that the report be presented no later than the end of 2024.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for necessary legislative changes, as well as a proposal to transfer the responsibility for user-controlled personal assistance (BPA) from the municipalities to a state scheme in order to ensure equality and fairness for individuals who need BPA.

Promote necessary proposals to transfer the responsibility for the user-controlled personal assistance (BPA) scheme for students to a state scheme. The BPA scheme for students must include all the assistance needs that the student may have, including during their leisure time.
Return to the Storting with a more comprehensive review of the benefits for refugees, ensuring that they are at most on par with those in Sweden and Denmark.

Return to the Parliament with a comprehensive review of the introduction program and employment related to Ukrainians in Norway, Sweden, and Denmark, with the aim of increasing employment towards the levels in Denmark and Sweden, where the goal is to get people into work as quickly as possible and to have language/community training take place in the evenings/weekends.
Investigate the underlying reasons why unaccompanied minor asylum seekers go missing from care centers or reception facilities.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for changes to laws and regulations that ensure that the care responsibility for unaccompanied minor asylum seekers between the ages of 15 and 18 is transferred to child welfare services.

Draft a law and regulation proposal to ensure that unaccompanied minor asylum seekers over the age of 15 living in asylum reception centers receive a care offer that has both quality and rights equivalent to those provided to other children under public care.
To give the police a clear instruction that the disappearance of unaccompanied minor asylum seekers should be investigated and taken as seriously as the disappearance of Norwegian children.

To provide the right conditions and resources for reception centers for unaccompanied minor asylum seekers to have guidelines that prevent disappearances, sufficient child welfare qualified personnel, and good care.
Promote a proposal to transfer the responsibility for Housing Adaptation Grants back to the Norwegian State Housing Bank to ensure equal treatment for all citizens.
Promote a proposal to reopen the grant scheme for elevators in the draft budget proposal for 2025.

Propose an amendment to the tenancy law where index regulation is set as a maximum limit for annual rent increases, even when changing tenants. Significant upgrades to the property that improve living conditions for the tenant should provide an exception to the price cap.

Establish a loan scheme where the state acts as an owner or guarantor in home purchases for individuals who have the ability to pay but do not have sufficient equity for a mortgage, or where construction costs exceed the mortgage value.
Establish a refinancing scheme for financially vulnerable homeowners to ensure that those in financial distress have the opportunity to retain their homes during times of high costs.

Propose amendments to the Tenancy Act that ensure municipalities cannot demand market rent or "usual rent" for social housing or care homes owned by the municipality, as well as investigate a new mechanism for long-term and predictable price setting, based either on property value or individual income.
Investigate and propose a model for a third non-commercial housing sector, including suggestions for necessary legal changes to ensure that a significant proportion of new housing is non-commercial.
Adjust the Housing Bank's loan frameworks so that they are expanded to include a scheme that encourages the construction of non-commercial rental housing in the municipalities.

Reestablish a dedicated grant scheme in the Norwegian State Housing Bank that offers start loans to young first-time homebuyers who have the ability to pay but do not have sufficient equity for a private mortgage.

Change the rules for housing support so that the income of children living at home up to 20 years old is not included in the income basis for housing support, compared to the current limit of 18 years.
Change the rules regarding housing support so that the rule stating that one loses the right to housing support if a cohabitant becomes a student is abolished.

Change the rules for housing support so that the support is fixed for six months at a time for families with children, in line with the recommendations in the report from the expert group on children in poor families.
Update Enova's mandate so that offshore wind projects in need of support can receive funding beyond the justification for the introduction of new technology.
Investigate how actors in the development of floating offshore wind are ensured conditions that make them competitive against offshore wind projects developed by the petroleum industry.

Ensure that Statnett has a clear mandate to develop a comprehensive plan for the construction of a North Sea grid for offshore wind, including a mandate to collaborate with other countries in the North Sea region to consider future offshore wind development and grid development in context.
Plan for a predictable allocation of new offshore wind area of at least 3 GW annually starting from 2025.

Create a comprehensive plan for how a future offshore power grid should be developed. The plan must consider future offshore wind development, expected future power demand, Statnett's grid development plan on land, and the electrification of major point emissions in conjunction.

Streamline the licensing process for offshore wind, including by considering whether the license application and detailed plan can be processed in parallel, and by setting deadlines for case processing in the ministry. In particular, smaller offshore wind projects related to the electrification of petroleum facilities should be simplified and prioritized.
Include Northwest A for the impact assessment for offshore wind, with a possible announcement in 2025.
Task NVE with including more areas for impact assessments for offshore wind, with a possible announcement in 2025, of which at least one of the fields is located north of Stad.

Start a review of the labor rights of pilots and cabin crew in collaboration with the parties in the labor market and return to the Parliament with proposals that will provide cabin crew with regulations similar to the Working Environment Act's rules for working hours and breaks.

Investigate and return to the Storting with a proposal to introduce requirements in line with the French regulation Decree 2006, stating that foreign airlines operating in Norway must comply with Norwegian labor regulations.
