Come back to the Parliament no later than in connection with the state budget for 2025 with an assessment of the Civil Aviation Authority's capacity to conduct adequate inspections.
Put all applications for status as a 'typical tourist destination' on hold while this work is ongoing and until any new criteria are presented.
Consider the possibility of introducing a time limit on how long a place can hold the status of 'typical tourist destination' before it must reapply.

Review the regulations for being classified as a "typical tourist destination" and present a separate case to the Parliament with proposals for restrictions that prevent the number of stores open on Sundays from increasing.
Present a proposal to allow stores to open on Sundays.
Propose to allow the country's cinemas to have screenings before 1 PM on Sundays.
To ensure a ban on behavior-based marketing targeted at children and young people.

Stop the electrification of oil and gas installations with power from land, and require the oil and gas sector to eliminate all its greenhouse gas emissions through its own offshore power production, CCS, etc.

Present comprehensive climate and energy plans in the form of a parliamentary report each year. The report should include the government's policies for achieving long-term and short-term goals, how this relates to other policy areas, and how scarce resources should be prioritized. The first parliamentary report on this should be presented in the spring of 2024.
Reject new applications for electrification of oil and gas installations with power from land.
Ensure that there are requirements for available backup power before applications for electrification of oil and gas installations with power from land can be approved.
Develop binding, comprehensive plans for marine spatial planning in connection with the update of the management plans for Norwegian sea areas to be presented to the Parliament in 2024.

Develop principles for stricter prioritization of scarce biomass resources. The principles must ensure that short-term emission reductions do not come at the expense of global and long-term climate goals, and that resources are prioritized where there are no good alternative zero-emission solutions and where it is not desirable to cease the activities that generate emissions. The government is requested to report back to the Parliament on this no later than in connection with the state budget for 2025.
Develop a strategy for the final phase of Norwegian petroleum activities, and present this to the Storting no later than in connection with the state budget for 2025.

Not to grant any further exploration licenses and extraction permits, or approve new plans for extraction and operation (PUD), or facilities and operation (PAD) under the Petroleum Act, until a strategy for the final phase of Norwegian petroleum activities has been addressed by the Storting.
Ensure that proposals for the new national transport plan are based on transport demand and the transport system in a low-emission society in 2050.

Carry out a "climate wash" of relevant laws with the aim of strengthening climate considerations. This should not be at the expense of nature. The government is requested to report back to the Parliament on this no later than in connection with the state budget for 2025.

Investigate the effects on recycling, waste production, and greenhouse gas emissions of the current tax on waste incineration, and report back to the Storting with the results no later than in the state budget for 2025.

Investigate alternative arrangements for the tax on waste incineration, including that the tax is imposed on waste holders and applies to all types of waste, including waste that is exported, and return to the Parliament with proposals for improving the current waste incineration tax no later than in the state budget for 2025.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal that levels out the differences in CO2 costs between different waste facilities as a result of some of the facilities currently being included in the EU's emissions trading system. The proposal is expected to be presented no later than in connection with the state budget for 2025.
Investigate and return to the Storting in connection with the revised national budget for 2024 with a proposal for a tax on all residual waste, including that which is sent out of the country.

Evaluate the current fee on waste incineration and how to ensure more equal competitive conditions between Norwegian and foreign facilities, investigate how pricing of waste can most effectively contribute to reducing global emissions, assess the consequences for district heating, recycling, and emission-reducing measures at incineration plants in Norway as well as costs for consumers, and report back to the Parliament no later than in the government's proposal for the state budget for 2025.

Implement an external evaluation of Norway's handling of the evacuation of military forces and civilians from Afghanistan in April 2021, where criteria and responsibilities and authority relationships are specified.
Publish the Armed Forces' evaluation of its efforts during the evacuation from Afghanistan in 2021.

Establish a committee to conduct an independent and comprehensive evaluation of and draw lessons from Norway's military and civilian efforts in Afghanistan during the period 2015–2021, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' engagement with the Taliban leadership since 2005, the coordination between these efforts, as well as the treatment of Afghans who have worked for Norwegian forces.
Develop and promote proposals for a comprehensive chapter in the Criminal Procedure Act, with specific rules for children in conflict with the law.
Promote proposals for changes to the Criminal Procedure Act so that suspected children have the right to police interviews at children's houses.

Develop a separate regulation on the questioning of children and particularly vulnerable individuals who are suspected in criminal cases, based on the model of the regulation on facilitated questioning.
Present a proposal for an amendment to the Criminal Procedure Act that ensures that suspected children have an unconditional right to a publicly appointed defender.
Complete the work on an expanded register of beneficial owners.
Establish an updated shareholder register in real-time.

Promote a legislative proposal that ensures that if someone complains to a department about a rejection of a request for access to information, it will not prevent a similar complaint from another party from being processed by the Parliamentary Ombudsman.
Investigate the establishment of an independent complaints body for access to information cases and refusals of access under the Freedom of Information Act.
Investigate proposals for sanction options for violations of the Public Access to Information Act.

Conduct a comprehensive review of the Freedom of Information Act with a view to increasing transparency, taking into account not only the evaluation from 2016 but also addressing the issues raised in the National Audit Office's reports on access to information and archiving, the proposals from the Archives Act Committee and the Freedom of Expression Commission, as well as expanding the scope of the law to ensure that recent developments in the application of the access rules in the Freedom of Information Act are captured.

Establish a broadly composed committee to further investigate public access to documents in criminal cases, based on the Aarli report on the same topic. This should include a specific assessment of the privacy implications.

Promote the necessary legislative amendments to ensure that municipalities are given a clear legal basis to halt businesses and recreational activities aimed at children and young people that are deemed to have a clearly integration-hindering effect.
Return to the Storting with a legislative proposal as a follow-up to decision 498 (April 14, 2020) by the end of 2024.
Initiate measures and develop an action plan to combat transnational oppression of Eritreans in Norway.
Investigate the applications for residence permits for Eritreans in Norway and revoke the residence permits of those who support the Eritrean regime.
Ensure that revocation cases are initiated for citizenship granted to individuals who have come to Norway from Eritrea but support the Eritrean regime.
Develop an action plan against transnational oppression of diaspora communities in Norway.
Map the extent of transnational oppression of diaspora communities in Norway and implement measures to combat this based on such mapping.
Implement measures to stop money transfers from Norway to Eritrean authorities and organizations controlled by them.

Follow up on Proba report 2020-3 "Pressure and Control – a study of economic, ideological, or religious pressure originating from countries of origin, directed at individuals with immigrant backgrounds in Norway" and Proba report 2023-10 "Transnational Oppression – Concept Clarification and Sector Responsibility" and implement measures to prevent transnational oppression of individuals in Norway, for example through an action plan against transnational oppression.
Establish a professorship in Jewish studies at the Faculty of Theology at the University of Oslo.
Ensure that Jewish life and culture are included in the curriculum for elementary schools, for example through cultural presentations.
Promote a proposal to increase the funding for the Jewish Guides program organized by the Mosaic Religious Community in the revised national budget for 2024.

Promote a proposal to increase the funding for Dembra in the teacher education program in the revised national budget for 2024, so that knowledge about antisemitism reaches all teacher students. The increase should not affect Dembra's other work.
Make antisemitism a separate topic in the school curriculum, so that all students receive education about antisemitism.

Ensure that explicit guidelines and criteria for dissemination activities are established in the announcement and allocation of research funds regarding antisemitism and Judaism. The guidelines must include the dissemination of research findings to professional groups such as teachers, police, journalists, etc.
Present a new action plan against antisemitism.
Ensure that the police prioritize hate crime, including antisemitism.
Ensure that the police receive increased training on antisemitism.
Increase the focus on Dembra, including Dembra in teacher education programs.

Come back to the Parliament with a report and proposals for a water reform aimed at more efficient organization, less water leakage, and lower fees for users, inspired by Denmark's water reform from 2007.
Conduct an evaluation of how the full cost recovery model as a financing model for the water and wastewater sector functions, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Come back to the Parliament in connection with the revised national budget for 2024 with an incentive scheme to encourage regional organization based on the model recommended in the Opportunity Study for the water and wastewater sector, along with the socio-economic analyses presented in the spring of 2022.

Revise the regulation on the calculation of total self-cost for municipal and county fees (the self-cost regulation) with the aim of extending the period for when future surpluses must be returned or deficits can be carried forward.

Extend the maximum depreciation period for treatment plants, pumping stations, elevated tanks, and pipeline networks in the regulations on financial plans, annual budgets, annual accounts, and annual reports for municipalities and county municipalities, etc.
Consider the consequences of allowing municipalities the option to choose between using a calculated interest rate or a real interest rate in budgeting for investments in the self-financing area.
Establish platforms where the business community can provide advice and recommendations on how to utilize data internally within industries and share across them.

Establish a council for artificial intelligence that will serve as an advisory and independent body to monitor the development of artificial intelligence, provide guidance on principled questions related to the technology, and advise on its responsible use.
Facilitate regulatory sandboxes for digital technologies such as artificial intelligence and establish a separate regulatory sandbox for health technology.

Assess the suitability of the EU's Artificial Intelligence Act for safeguarding Norwegian interests, the challenges that will be encountered in implementing the regulation if it is deemed EEA-relevant, and how Norway can swiftly adopt the regulation once it is enacted.
Present a strategy to ensure that Norway gets the most out of its participation in Digital Europe.

Investigate approval methods for artificial intelligence systems that have potentially very serious consequences in case of misuse, but which can still have particularly significant societal benefits.

Conduct a digital legal review, mapping out which parts of the legislation are unclear in the context of new technologies such as artificial intelligence. The mapping should particularly focus on transparency and oversight, legal security, privacy, and consumer rights. The results of the mapping should be made known to the Parliament.
Work closely with the EU to ensure that Norway's interests are best represented in the development of standards for high-risk systems with artificial intelligence as defined by the EU.
Return to the Parliament with measures to ensure sufficient cooperation between supervisory bodies in the face of artificial intelligence.

Develop national guidelines for the use of artificial intelligence in schools that ensure learning benefits, constructive and critical use of the technology, and a clear distinction between when artificial intelligence can and cannot be used in teaching.
Ensure that the security authorities make cybersecurity training available to small and medium-sized enterprises.
Take the initiative for a Nordic summit on artificial intelligence.
Ensure sufficient breadth and specialized expertise in digital technologies such as artificial intelligence in response to upcoming competency needs.
Strengthen continuing education and opportunities for skills enhancement in the development and use of artificial intelligence.
Initiate work to strengthen the competence verification for real competence and micro-certification.
Conduct a ripple effect analysis for the data center industry and its impacts on value creation, sustainability, and green transition in traditional industries.
Promote collaboration on Nordic language models for generative artificial intelligence in the Nordic Council of Ministers.
Investigate joint municipal procurement schemes for advanced digital technologies such as artificial intelligence based on the Danish model KOMBIT.

Prepare a NOU on the consequences that generative artificial intelligence has for copyright, media, culture, democracy, and public discourse, as well as possible measures to address these consequences.
Propose to extend the unemployment benefit period to 52 weeks within an 18-month period.
Promote proposals that ensure those who are laid off can participate in skills-enhancing measures as soon as they are laid off.
Promote proposals that strengthen the Norwegian State Housing Bank (Husbanken) to ensure that a sufficient number of new homes are built in the coming years.
Promote proposals that in the coming years increase maintenance and rehabilitation of the public property portfolio, as well as ramp up efforts on energy efficiency.

Present a package of measures for the rapid upgrading of residential and commercial buildings. The package should include higher support amounts for measures such as window replacement and additional insulation of exterior walls.
Facilitate increased activity in the construction industry by initiating maintenance, renovation, and new construction projects in the public sector.
Conduct an analysis of the development in the construction industry to identify what measures may be necessary to increase activity in the sector.

Implement changes in the organization of the interpreting service for sign language users with the aim of moving the interpreting service out of Nav assistive devices or completely out of Nav to other appropriate organizations based on the Roadmap to a new national interpreting service.

Equalize sign language interpreters with other language interpreters, including that freelance interpreters receive rates corresponding to their competence based on the rates in the National Interpreter Register.
Ensure that freelance interpreters' fees also reflect the interpreters' competence and experience.

Implement the necessary strengthening of the interpreting service for individuals with hearing impairments, the deaf, and the deafblind to ensure an effective and professionally competent interpreting service that continues to be funded under the National Insurance Act, including ensuring an adequate level of authority within Nav Assistance and Adaptation to ensure that the interpreting service provides the right interpreter at the right time, whether it concerns sign language interpreting, written interpreting, or interpreting-guiding for the deafblind according to the National Insurance Act.
Equalize sign language interpreters, written interpreters, and interpreting guides, regardless of whether they are employed by Nav or are freelancers, in terms of salary and working conditions.

Ensure adequate funding in the national budget so that the right to sign language interpreters, written interpreters, and interpreter escorts is secured in accordance with the intentions of the National Insurance Act.
Ensure that artist grants paid out by public actors are disbursed as salaries with full social rights.

Introduce a system where artist grants are regulated so that they receive at least the same increase as the framework in the state wage settlement. State artist grants should always be at least 50% of the median annual income.
Establish a goal to increase the number of artist grant positions by 100 each year over the next four years.
Look at how a collective agreement for the Cultural School Bag can be introduced in all counties and return to the Storting in an appropriate manner.
Ensure a review of the scheme for state grants and guaranteed income for artists with a view to phasing out the scheme.
Ensure the continuation of the Musician Alliance.
Ensure a good development for the Sami scholarships, on par with the other artist scholarships.

Promote a proposal to amend the Working Environment Act § 14-9 second paragraph so that agreements on temporary employment can be made with artistic personnel and leaders within the cultural sector in connection with the performance of artistic work.
Consider establishing a specialized Nav unit with expertise in combination incomes and the specific challenges of the artist economy.
Come back to the Parliament with a review of how the Working Environment Act aligns with the needs of the cultural sector and what consequences arise from the government's tightening of the law.
Continue the current arrangement where the final decision on the allocation of scholarship quotas related to the State Artist Grant is made by the Ministry of Culture and Equality.

To involve the Data Protection Authority in the work on the regulation regarding DNS blocking, as well as to give particular weight to the Data Protection Authority's concerns related to privacy and freedom of information, which should be addressed in the final regulation.

Come back to the Parliament in the revised national budget for 2024 with a proposal to make the value-added tax compensation scheme for voluntary organizations rule-based, with ongoing application deadlines and compensation payments throughout the year.

Ensure a swift consultation process regarding the regulatory framework for the VAT compensation scheme for voluntary organizations, with the aim of implementing the regulatory framework in the state budget for 2025. The Parliament requests the government to follow up on other adjustments to the scheme, including the follow-up of the EY report, in a separate process.
Ensure necessary changes to the VAT regulations and propose rule-based VAT compensation for the voluntary sector in connection with the state budget for 2025.

Prohibit all logging of remaining old-growth forest/natural forest in Norway, map all old-growth forest/natural forest by 2025, and ensure that all old-growth forest/natural forest in Norway is formally protected by 2030. The definition of old-growth forest/natural forest used must correspond to the EU's Commission Guidelines for Defining, Mapping, Monitoring, and Strictly Protecting EU Primary and Old-Growth Forests.

Prohibit all clear-cutting of remaining old-growth forests in Norway, defined as forests that have not been clear-cut, and ensure that the most important old-growth forests for biodiversity are formally protected by 2030.
Engage in dialogue with the forestry sector to establish a system to prevent logging in valuable natural forests while the mapping of natural forests is ongoing.

Promote proposals for necessary legislative changes and amend regulations to introduce an application requirement for all clear-cutting, so that this can be assessed under the Nature Diversity Act Chapter II.

Present measures that ensure that the management of at least 30% of Norwegian forests is in accordance with the goals of the Kunming-Montreal agreement regarding the effective conservation of at least 30% of Norwegian forest nature.

Set requirements through the extraction and production permits for operators on the continental shelf to reduce emissions by 70% by 2030 through changes in activity levels or the use of carbon capture and storage.
Not renewing the extraction licenses for the oil fields Draugen, Brage, Ula, and Statfjord.
Present a plan with the goal of shutting down the Brage field as soon as possible, and no later than the end of 2027.
Present a plan with the goal of shutting down the Draugen field as soon as possible, and no later than the end of 2027.
Present a plan with the goal of shutting down the Statfjord field as soon as possible, and no later than the end of 2027.
Present a plan with the goal of shutting down the Ula field as soon as possible, and no later than the end of 2027.
Increase the threshold for the use of four-lane highways from an annual average daily traffic (AADT) of 12,000 vehicles to 15,000 vehicles.
Revoke the approval of the Norwegian Public Roads Administration's proposal for a revised road standard.
Promote a proposal to abolish the offset rule for married and cohabiting pensioners.
Promote a proposal that retirees should be able to choose to withdraw the portion of their accumulated pension wealth that exceeds the guaranteed pension level as a lump sum payment.
Promote a proposal to remove the age limit of 75 years for earning pension rights.
Promote a proposal for a separate hardship arrangement in the pension system.
Promote a proposal that the minimum benefits of the pension system should be at the level of the EU's poverty line (EU60).
Promote a proposal that the minimum benefits of the pension system should be adjusted according to wage development and not be specific to each cohort.
Promote a proposal for full protection of disability pensions from the effects of life expectancy adjustments.
Promote proposals for better framework conditions for individual pension savings.
Conduct an evaluation of the pension system every parliamentary term in connection with the perspective report.
Investigate and present proposals for special regulations that provide a tax exemption for the sale of surplus electricity from private homes.
Include the work against violence in close relationships and the protection of women in emergency plans, ensuring that this has a central place in future crisis management.
Expand the use of local emergency stockpiles, including ensuring that all hospitals, both existing and new constructions, have space to maintain emergency stockpiles.

Establish a state-owned company, StatMed, that will contribute to the production of pharmaceuticals in Norway and collaborate with the rest of the pharmaceutical industry and the public healthcare system on national development and production of medications.

Establish R&D collaboration with the pharmaceutical industry, where the public healthcare system can access medications at acceptable prices when the drugs are developed based on publicly funded studies.
Promote proposals for a ban on parallel exports of pharmaceuticals and medical equipment from emergency stockpiles.

Investigate new incentive schemes for the development and production of antibiotics, based on experiences with such schemes in Sweden and the United Kingdom, and present proposals for these incentive schemes to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Follow up on decisions 963 and 964 from the 2020–2021 session and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Ensure that the hiring from commercial staffing agencies in healthcare institutions is replaced with strengthened core staffing, and that all healthcare institutions implement arrangements with their own pool of temporary staff/staffing units, with permanently employed temporary workers, aimed at meeting the staffing needs of the healthcare institution.
Increase the educational capacity for healthcare personnel, including doctors, nurses, and other essential staff, to meet future health challenges.
Intensify efforts on preventive measures, including information campaigns, vaccination programs, and measures to reduce the spread of infection.
Increase investments in research and development in health preparedness, including research on new treatment methods and the development of better diagnostic tools.

Strengthen the collaboration and coordination between various actors in the healthcare system, such as hospitals, municipalities, general practitioners, and other health services, for better interaction and effective response in emergency situations.
Develop and maintain updated and realistic emergency plans at the national, regional, and local levels, with clear divisions of responsibility and communication routines.

Establish and strengthen national arrangements to ensure the production of protective equipment and necessary medications in Norway, in order to reduce dependence on international supply chains and ensure stable access in times of crisis.
To ensure adequate staffing and resources in the healthcare system, including recruiting and hiring more healthcare personnel and increasing capacity in hospitals and health clinics.

Intensify and formalize collaboration with voluntary health preparedness organizations such as the Red Cross, Norwegian People's Aid, and the Norwegian Women's Public Health Association to expand and strengthen national health preparedness.
Introduce a national escalation plan to increase intensive care capacity in healthcare institutions.

Revise the National Strategy for Voluntary Work in the Health and Care Sector (2015–2020) in collaboration with Voluntary Norway and KS. The contribution of volunteering during health crises must also be part of the revision.
Establish a new national antibiotic strategy.
To increase the number of intensive care beds across the country to strengthen emergency preparedness and ensure that the healthcare system is better equipped to handle major health crises.
Ensure that the role of volunteers in health preparedness is strengthened, and that volunteer organizations are integrated into planning and exercises.
Strengthen and expand Nordic cooperation on the production and storage of pharmaceuticals and infection control equipment in the Nordic region.
Abolish the use of private health insurance in state-owned companies, and actively use ownership to prevent a two-tier healthcare system.
Introduce a sales tax on private health insurance to strengthen the public healthcare system.

Promote a bill for the establishment of asylum reception centers abroad similar to the Danish bill L 226 (2021–2022), passed in the Folketing on June 3, 2021, or similar models from other European countries.
Enter into a collaboration with Denmark, the United Kingdom, and/or Italy with the aim of establishing a joint solution for asylum reception abroad.
Come back to the Parliament with concrete proposals for tightening immigration policies, including proposals for restrictions on family reunification, which can be implemented quickly if necessary.
Engage in negotiations aimed at reaching agreements with third countries that ensure protection for individuals with a genuine need for protection.
Investigate a system where Norway provides protection to vulnerable individuals in need of protection by funding their relocation to safe third countries.

Conduct a review of the areas in immigration that differ from other comparable countries, such as those in the Nordic region and Europe, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner. Both the conditions for residence in the individual countries as well as benefits or other factors that may make Norway more attractive than other countries should be examined.
Prepare a public evaluation of the consequences of the Schengen Agreement.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to raise the income limit for individuals receiving care benefits, before the care benefits are reduced, to correspond to the current income limit for disability benefits, which is currently 0.4 G. The income limit applies for each calendar year and is adjusted based on changes in the basic amount of the National Insurance Scheme.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to amend the National Insurance Act so that everyone who receives care benefits in cases where a child dies can retain the care benefits for up to three months, regardless of how long they have received care benefits, instead of some only being able to retain care benefits for up to 30 benefit days as is the case today.

Make the necessary changes to the rules for the care allowance scheme for individuals with developmental disabilities over 18 years old, so that parents can receive care allowance without the child being terminally ill, if the municipalities do not have a good care offer to provide.

Ensure that war sailors who receive war pensions and who were subjected by the Norwegian state during World War II to activities that posed a direct threat to their own lives and health are provided with the necessary assistance to secure a dignified old age, regardless of whether they are currently Norwegian citizens residing in Norway or have emigrated to other countries.
Abolish the regulation on emission requirements for vehicles in public procurement for road transport.

Promote a case with the following points for a simpler structure and more competition in addressing the railway's tasks: a. An investigation into whether the tasks of the Norwegian Railway Directorate can be transferred to the Ministry of Transport. b. The establishment of an infrastructure competitor to Bane Nor, including the assessment of creating a permanent railway structure at Nye Veier AS. c. Norwegian trains are given greater financial freedom to procure customer-adapted equipment tailored to the operating concepts of the train companies.
Contribute to ensuring that the master's program in speech therapy at NTNU receives basic funding from the Ministry of Education and Research, as other speech therapy programs do.

Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how to ensure and strengthen the future education of speech therapists. This involves: ensuring equal funding for speech therapy education at educational institutions, placing the education in the correct funding category (2), and assessing the need for a five-year education in speech therapy.

Give Statped a special assignment so that the collaboration between the specialist health service and Statped can be maintained for the voice disorder field. Statped must also be able to receive referrals regarding adults with acquired language and speech difficulties, not only from the school system (PPT or adult education) but also from the healthcare system (including private practicing speech therapists).
To include speech therapists in the authorization scheme.
Come back to the Parliament with a plan for how to ensure and strengthen the future education of speech therapists.
Promote a case to the Parliament regarding measures to strengthen speech therapy services in municipalities, and consider speech therapy as a core competence and a legally mandated service.
Make a new assessment of the level of opportunity cost for prioritization decisions at the group level in health and care services.
Price-adjust the current opportunity cost for prioritization decisions in health and care services.

Propose necessary regulatory changes that lower the threshold for transferring students who have engaged in severe and prolonged bullying to another school, and request that the government obtain an annual report on the use of this measure in schools' efforts to combat bullying and improve safety in the school environment.
To establish a legal right for school staff to access information about students who have a known history of violence or who may otherwise pose a security risk.

Implement preventive measures based on the model from the social agent project in Oslo in schools with specific violence and threat challenges to assist them in their efforts to combat the dramatic situation that some schools are experiencing.

Suggest changes to the provisions of the Education Act regarding the violation of students (current § 9 A-5) and possibly other necessary changes, so that the legislation does not hinder addressing incidents of violence, bullying, and other unwanted behavior in schools.

Change the regulations so that students with very problematic behavior can be placed in their own educational programs for the sake of themselves and the learning environment of their peers, similar to the "skolakuten" project in Sweden, and request the government to begin the work of developing such a tailored educational offer.

Consider whether the Penal Code § 265 and § 286, which provide selected professional groups with special protection in their workplace, should be extended to other professional groups in the same workplace, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Develop an action plan with the goal of making the school a safe workplace for teachers and others. The plan should emphasize both prevention and management of situations involving violence and threats.

Investigate and return to the Storting with a proposal to amend the Nature Diversity Act § 35 regarding national parks to include urban national parks, which are unique or representative ecosystems or landscapes, even if significant natural interventions have occurred in the form of urban development.
Remove value-added tax on Norwegian-produced fruits and vegetables.

Present an overview of the total cost of ensuring income equalization between farmers and other professional groups under different assumptions, including not using a standardization factor before comparison, including investments in land in the calculation of allocations for investments in depreciable capital, and assuming that one full-time equivalent in agriculture amounts to 1,700 hours.
Develop a scaling instruction to increase the proportion of Norwegian-sourced food in the Armed Forces' procurement.
Conduct a comprehensive review of the agricultural agreement system and present it to the Storting before the consideration of the agricultural agreement in 2026.

Come back to the Parliament with a step-by-step plan to reduce the price reduction scheme for grain, while simultaneously strengthening subsidies that enhance self-sufficiency through drainage, restoration of soil, and agriculture across the country.
Investigate and return to the Parliament with proposals for changes to the main agreement for agriculture to introduce agricultural negotiations for the current year.
Propose to lower the quota limit for cow's milk and goat's milk in the agricultural negotiations.

Ensure that the escalation of agricultural income opportunities is carried out without increasing the price reduction on grain, and that a professional investigation is conducted to determine the level at which the scheme should be set to achieve the goal of production balance between grain and grass areas.
Suggest new production-regulating measures for eggs, pigs, sheep, and cattle to avoid overproduction in the agricultural negotiations of 2024.

Add a category for "Norwegian standard" in public procurement with criteria that suppliers must be able to document that the products are produced to a certain quality, for example, equivalent to the Quality System in Agriculture (KSL) standard, to make it easier for buyers to write tenders that facilitate Norwegian-produced goods.
Remove all coordination of the replacement subsidy with other income.

Make the following changes to the calculation of average agricultural income proposed in Meld. St.11 (2023–2024): A standardization factor of 20% will not be added in the calculation of average agricultural income for level comparison. For the calculation of average agricultural income for level comparison, it shall be assumed that one full-time equivalent in agriculture is 1,700 hours. For the calculation of average agricultural income for level comparison, the total budget shall include an average return on all equity invested in agriculture that is higher than the interest rate on debt.
Include investments in land in the calculation of allocations for investments in depreciable capital.

Establish the following income target: "The income gap between agriculture and other groups shall be closed by 2027. The income gap shall be addressed in future agricultural negotiations based on the model for measuring income levels where one full-time equivalent is 1,700 hours, the standardization factor is set at 5 percent, and the allocation for depreciable capital shall be calculated based on invested value and not book value, along with the other conditions outlined in Report No. St. 11 (2023–2024)."
Assume 1,700 hours per full-time equivalent in agriculture when comparing income with other professions.
Develop a normalization factor based on the model from the Grytten committee.
Continue to use wages for industrial workers as a benchmark for future calculations of income opportunities in agriculture.
Stimulate increased use of roughage and pasture use, and that this should be a guiding principle for the state in agricultural negotiations.
Propose a soil package to increase plant production where subsidies for drainage, ditching, and sustainable land use are increased.
Introduce requirements for origin labeling in large-scale catering and restaurants (HoReCa).
Not using a normalization factor when comparing income in agriculture and other professions.
Ensure that Norway's offensive trade policy interests are given equal weight as agricultural interests in trade policy.
Come back to the Storting with a consequence analysis of how trade policy for agricultural products affects trade in other goods.

Change the calculation model for self-sufficiency and food security so that Norwegian seafood is also included, including the possibility that imports of input factors for feed in a crisis can be replaced by Norwegian-produced input factors.
Promote a plan in 2024 to increase the share of Norwegian fruits and vegetables in public procurement, and report back to the Storting in an appropriate manner.
Expand origin labeling to enable consumers to make informed choices.

Conduct a review of the grain price reduction scheme to assess how the scheme can best encourage less use of concentrated feed and more use of domestically produced roughage, as well as contribute to Norwegian self-sufficiency.

Follow up on its commitments under the agricultural climate agreement to contribute to changing food consumption in the Norwegian population so that this consumption aligns as closely as possible with dietary guidelines.
Conduct future agricultural settlements based on the model for measuring income levels, with assumptions, limitations, and conditions, as outlined in Meld. St. 11 (2023–2024).

Start the work on a public inquiry that can lay the foundation for a parliamentary report on the future food systems, where public health, climate, nature, and agricultural and food policy are interconnected.
Develop concrete emergency plans for a crisis situation that ensures all Norwegians have enough food.
Take the initiative to develop a joint Nordic risk and vulnerability analysis for food supply security.

Return to the Storting in the spring of 2025 with a plan for more plant-based food, with the goal of strengthening the overall Norwegian plant-based production and increasing the connection between the various links in the value chain.
Review the subsidy system to assess whether the transfers to agriculture lead to a strengthening of Norwegian self-sufficiency and whether more land in Norway is being utilized for food production.
Revise the strategy for organic farming in 2024.
Investigate and test a plot-based system, or similar, that will contribute to the management of demanding areas.
Work towards a goal of achieving 50% self-sufficiency, adjusted for feed imports, by 2030.
Establish the following income goal: The income gap between agriculture and other groups should be closed by 2027.
Ensure that the number of hours per full-time equivalent in agriculture is gradually reduced in equal parts to 1750 hours by 2027.
Emphasize Norway's preparedness potential in the further follow-up of the Total Preparedness Commission's report NOU 2023: 17.
Ensure that critical societal functions are prioritized during crises so that, among other things, trade and food production can continue as normally as possible during a crisis.
Promote a proposal to allocate the entire remaining budget for the Nansen program for the current year.

Take a leading role in the international diplomatic efforts to facilitate a fair and lasting peace in Ukraine in accordance with the UN Charter and the principle that Ukraine should determine its own future.

Take the initiative with the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, and other creditor associations to halt demands for payment of Ukrainian state debt and further cancel and restructure the debt.

Ear marked at least 10% of the Nansen program for an application-based grant scheme for the Ukrainian civil society. The grant scheme will provide Ukrainian organizations with opportunities for long-term and predictable frameworks. The projects must have financial frameworks that are large and flexible enough to provide a basis for capacity building and a certain freedom to choose their own priorities.

Ensure that local civil society organizations, including trade unions, women's organizations, and human rights organizations, are included in the civil support of the Nansen program, and that their interests are safeguarded.
Maintain the customs protection at the current level for the import of Ukrainian agricultural products.

Establish partnerships with local organizations as a condition for the allocation of humanitarian aid to Ukraine. The partnership should be based on equality, and the local organization should be involved in governance and management. The local partner organization should always be allocated overhead in the same way as the international organization.
Increase the total budget for the Nansen program.
Ensure a significant improvement in the production capacity of the parts of the Norwegian defense industry that produce equipment that Ukraine is in great need of.
Work for full funding of the Czech ammunition initiative.
Accelerate the military support in the Nansen program in connection with the revised national budget for 2024.
Promote a proposal to amend the Education Act, so that the law establishes that printed textbooks are the central teaching resource in schools, while digital teaching materials are a supplement.
A significant increase in funding for printed textbooks is proposed in the state budget for 2025.
Propose a significant increase in funding for school libraries in the state budget for 2025 to strengthen the role of printed books in education.

The regulations of the Education Act state that school libraries shall contribute to the students' development of information, language, and reading skills, and help to bridge social, cultural, and digital disparities.
Present a binding plan for the training of teachers in the use of digital teaching materials in education, both for teacher training programs and further education.

Impose requirements on kindergarten and school owners to enter into data processing agreements and install Kripos' blocking filter and other filters that effectively block access to games and social media, and that protect children from seriously harmful content and advertising, and prevent the misuse of personal data, on digital devices for children in kindergarten and students in primary school.
Strengthen the work of providing guidance to kindergarten and school owners on compliance with privacy regulations to prevent the misuse of children's and young people's personal data.

Recommend and follow up that kindergarten and school owners install Kripos' blocking filter or consider other filters that effectively block access to unwanted media and content on digital devices used by children in kindergartens and students in primary schools.
Strengthen oversight and control of hawala operations, with the aim of preventing and reducing the likelihood of violations related to the transfer of cash abroad.

Initiate a process to simplify the regulations surrounding recreational drone flying, with the aim of limiting the regulations to what is practical, as well as enhancing the understanding of the remaining regulations.

The announced parliamentary report on drones is cross-departmental and cross-sectoral, so that an updated strategy addresses how drones challenge aviation safety and public safety while facilitating the development of unmanned aviation in Norway. Such development of unmanned aviation should include the entire value chain from research and production of drones, appropriate regulatory development, and safe aviation across both military and civilian sectors.

Come back in the revised state budget for 2024 with a funding proposal for the improvement of the Veibust intersection on E39 in Sula municipality, with the aim of ensuring the fastest possible start of construction for the project.

Ensure that the district policy intentions of the Marine Resources Act and the Participant Act are implemented in practice, and promote necessary proposals to allocate a certain percentage of the total allowable catch (TAC) of all fish species to non-marketable district quotas, which are allocated by the Directorate of Fisheries and managed by the fishing-dependent municipalities. The government submits an annual accounting and budget report to the Parliament regarding the results of the quota distribution in accordance with the purpose of the Marine Resources Act.
Ensure that the allocation to third country quotas is taken from the deep-sea fishing fleet, not from the top.
Ensure that the third country quota is distributed in accordance with the current quota distribution among the vessel groups.
Ensure that the open group is allocated a minimum of 6.62% of the Norwegian cod quota.
Phase out the CO2 compensation scheme for the deep-sea fishing fleet by 2030.

Reintroduce the meter limit between the coastal and deep-sea fishing fleets, where the actual length of 28 meters is the starting point, and return to the Parliament with a specification of the consequences for, among other things, quota rights and allocation of fishing areas.

Present a plan with binding goals and measures to make the fishing industry, including vessels in the aquaculture sector, a part of the national effort to reduce national greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030.

Present a message to the Storting regarding a precautionary-based Norwegian fisheries management in light of ongoing ecosystem changes due to global warming and the altered security political conditions in the Arctic.
Ensure that Enova's program "Battery in Zero-Emission Vessels" is adapted for fishing vessels under 15 meters in length, or establish a corresponding program for this group of vessels.

Introduce ownership restrictions in coastal fishing for cod, haddock, and saithe north of 62 degrees north, so that an owner and minority owner through a person, company, or association can own a maximum of 1.5% of the relevant group quota.
Reintroduce the length of entitlement as a grouping of the quota basis for the coastal fishing fleet.

Distribute the structural gain that occurs when time-limited structural quotas expire with full effect on basic quotas and half effect on remaining structural quotas (model X), according to the original duration of the entitlement.

Prioritize affected fleet groups according to the agreement of April 19, 2024, between the Labour Party, the Conservative Party, the Centre Party, the Progress Party, the Liberal Party, and the Christian Democratic Party this year, where unused third-country quotas are returned to the national quota.
Introduce ownership restrictions in coastal fishing for species other than cod, haddock, and saithe north of 62 degrees north in accordance with Meld. St. 7 (2023–2024).

Develop specific rules in connection with the introduction of ownership restrictions for the coastal group, which among other things ensures that those who exceeded the deadline for the submission of Meld. St. 7 (2023–2024) can retain their ownership share with necessary flexibility. The rules should also include time limits on how long one can have a reduced share before it is applied as a new maximum limit.
Reintroduce the dynamic trawl ladder in the distribution of the quota for cod north of 62 degrees north.

Conduct a review of the purpose of the open group in fisheries, and assess the structure and measures that contribute more effectively to ensuring that the open group functions as intended, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Reintroduce the dynamic quota allocation mechanism (the herring ladder) for Norwegian spring-spawning herring.

Conduct a new assessment of the charter vessel scheme with the aim of making it better and simpler in order to promote the development and construction of new and more environmentally friendly vessels, including taking into account different vessel classes.

Consider whether the current structure quota system should be changed or adapted to facilitate value creation and green transition, and to ensure that it takes into account the importance of the fishing fleet for employment and settlement in coastal communities.

Establish a merger scheme for vessels under 11 meters in length, where the owner of two vessels that fish for cod, haddock, and saithe north of 62 degrees north is granted permission to merge the quota basis for the two vessels and fish the combined quota on one vessel, and develop further regulations for the use of the scheme, including activity requirements.
Investigate and assess the introduction of a merger scheme that also includes vessels fishing in pelagic fisheries under 11 meters in length (13 meters for mackerel fishing with coastal nets).
Ensure that the open group’s share of cod is taken from the top as an allocation of the Norwegian total quota, and that the share is set at 6.62%.

Request the sales teams to make their boards more representative and include a broader range of expertise to take into account the interests of the entire value chain, and that such members should constitute at least 25% of the board.
Introduce annual expectation letters in the dialogue with the fish sales associations.

Promote a proposal to introduce an environmental flexibility scheme that allows for an increase in production within existing aquaculture licenses if the increase occurs through the conversion of open cages to production technology that ensures zero escapes, zero discharge of salmon lice eggs and/or salmon lice larvae, and waste collection.
Establish scientifically based upper limits for mortality in the sea phase that ensure compliance with animal welfare legislation for all farmed fish.
Introduce a requirement for the aquaculture industry to reduce the maximum allowed biomass (MTB) when mortality in the sea phase exceeds 5%.

Promote proposals to change the structure of the production tax on fish in a way that rewards more sustainable practices, for example by converting parts of the tax into a graded environmental tax that rewards low emissions, zero escape rates, and zero discharge of lice eggs/larvae.

Investigate and implement a system that ensures that sludge from the aquaculture industry is collected and utilized as a resource for business development and production, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Promote proposals to only allow land-based aquaculture on already developed areas to avoid land-based aquaculture leading to the destruction of nature.

Promote a proposal for a moratorium on cod farming until it is clarified whether cod farming is ecologically acceptable in areas with local wild cod, and until technology that genuinely guarantees against escape, spawning in cages, and the exchange of parasites and diseases with wild cod is potentially implemented.

Promote proposals to structure the Aquaculture Fund in a way that provides municipalities with income from aquaculture, while simultaneously ensuring a swift transition to sustainable operating practices with the goal of zero lice, zero escapes, and zero emissions.
Consider whether it is appropriate to set a scientifically based limit for mortality in the marine phase given the industry's complex biology and vulnerable locations.

Promote a proposal for a technology-neutral environmental flexibility scheme that addresses the recommendations from the Aquaculture Committee (NOU 2023:23). The Parliament requests the government to base the work on a technology-neutral environmental flexibility scheme for aquaculture on the following principles: The scheme must be technology-neutral to ensure development and innovation. The scheme must contribute to reducing the industry's environmental footprint. The scheme must help reduce the lice pressure on both farmed and wild fish. The scheme should, through incentives, ensure the use of low- and zero-emission technology in areas where it is necessary to reduce emissions. The scheme should encompass all existing and future permits. The scheme should be applicable to the production volume that has been withdrawn due to a red traffic light in a production area. In such cases, it will not be possible to convert back to traditional technology until this volume has been reallocated as a result of a green traffic light. This must be done in accordance with the intention behind the traffic light system.

Promote proposals for necessary changes so that the arrangement with a market regulator in agriculture is abolished, and that existing target price models are removed in a way that ensures trust in the value chain and fair competition conditions.
Review and evaluate existing regulations related to market regulators to ensure that competition is not unnecessarily restricted, or that it does not hinder new entrants from entering the market.
Ensure a more independent market regulation by transferring the expertise for market regulation that TINE, Felleskjøpet, and Nortura currently have to the Agricultural Directorate.
Dismantle the market regulation on eggs and instead facilitate a transition to contract production similar to that of chicken.

Change the tendering process and awarding of contracts for the operation of asylum reception centers to better facilitate private non-profit actors and municipal operators instead of private commercial actors.

Promote a proposal for a compensation scheme that covers all additional costs incurred by municipalities acting as host municipalities for asylum reception centers, so that municipalities do not suffer financial losses.
Ensure that each municipality, through political processes, has the right to veto questions regarding the establishment of asylum reception centers within its borders.

Introduce a proportionality assessment in cases concerning the revocation of residence permits under the Immigration Act § 63, so that residence permits should, as a general rule, not be revoked in cases where the foreign national was a child at the time the incorrect information was provided by the child's caregivers.

Promote a proposal to amend the Immigration Act § 70 regarding the requirement for proportionality in cases of expulsion under §§ 66-68, so that a foreign national shall, as a general rule, not be expelled on the grounds that incorrect or misleading information has been provided about the person's stay in the kingdom, if the foreign national was a child at the time this information was given by the child's caregivers.

Promote a proposal to introduce a provision in the Immigration Act Chapter 1 regarding the best interests of the child, stating that children, as a general rule, should not be held accountable for what their parents/adult caregivers have informed the immigration authorities in their case. This will also apply in cases where the information has been repeated after the child has become an adult, which could have consequences for the caregiver who provided the information the first time when the foreign national was a child and under their care.

Promote a proposal to postpone the implementation of decisions that require a foreigner to leave the country, if the individual came to Norway as a child, has lived in the country for more than 15 years, and the reason for expulsion is based on a false statement made by a caregiver. The decision should be put on hold pending a regulatory change that will allow for the application for the lifting of entry bans for individuals who came to Norway as children and have lived in the country for more than 15 years, if the entry ban arises from a false statement made by a caregiver.
Introduce a proportionality assessment in cases concerning the revocation of residence permits under the Immigration Act § 63.

Introduce a list of factors to be considered when revoking residence permits and citizenship, where aspects such as the best interests of the child, the provision of incorrect information as a child, and whether the individual has cooperated in identity clarification should be taken into account.
Introduce a ten-year statute of limitations for the revocation of residence permits and citizenship.

Introduce a processing deadline for the immigration administration in revocation cases under the Immigration Act § 63 and revocation of citizenship under the Citizenship Act § 26, preferably set at 15 months.

Instruct the Norwegian Directorate of Immigration through guidelines for the basis on when to initiate revocation cases under the Immigration Act § 63 and the Nationality Act § 26, where the current threshold is raised.

Increase legal assistance in revocation cases under the Immigration Act § 63 and the Nationality Act § 26, cf. the unit price regulation § 5 second paragraph 1a, and ensure that legal assistance is provided during the investigation phase, including in connection with administrative interviews, so that the person concerned has a genuine opportunity for contradiction.
Establish a national monitoring body for human trafficking.
Come back to the Storting with proposals for changes to the Crime Victim Compensation Act, following up on the recommendations of the Rape Committee.
Present a case to the Storting that follows up on the evaluation of the State Child House from 2021.
Strengthen family protection.
Strengthen the police's work in investigating online abuse.
Ensure that children and young people with disabilities and chronic illnesses are explicitly emphasized as important target groups for sex education.
Ensure that children and young people who break with norms of sexuality are explicitly emphasized as an important target group for sex education.
Implement concrete measures to ensure comprehensive and inclusive sex education for all children and young people.
Ensure that gender and sexuality diversity, as well as violence and abuse, are secured as areas of knowledge in the framework plan for teacher education.

Ensure that qualified kindergarten and primary school teachers, as well as other professional groups in kindergartens and schools, are offered further education and/or courses in gender and sexuality diversity, norm criticism, as well as violence and abuse from an LGBTQ+ perspective.
Deliver annual parliamentary reports on the government's work to ensure a comprehensive protection against violence.
Ensure the implementation of reliable incidence studies on violence and abuse, covering the life course from childhood to adulthood and into old age, and also including various minorities.
Ensure that research is prioritized to improve the knowledge base on living conditions and the protection of the rights of children who break with norms of gender and sexuality.
Return to the Storting with more targeted measures aimed at several vulnerable groups, including people with disabilities and women in active substance abuse.
Promote proposals to change the conditions for the use of permanent restraining orders, so that the threshold is lowered and the consideration for victims is given greater weight.

Promote a proposal to legislate an action plan against violence and abuse in municipalities, which will be updated regularly, with the aim of systematizing and coordinating the municipalities' work to prevent, uncover, and assist individuals who are victims of violence and abuse. The proposal will be sent out for consultation by spring 2025.
Investigate changes in mandatory visitation and mandatory mediation in cases involving violence or suspicion of violence.

Map how many foreign nationals have been convicted of violence in close relationships, who are not deported from the country, and where the decision not to deport is justified by the consideration that the convicted person's children should be able to have contact with the convicted individual.
Return to the Parliament with a proposal to ensure emergency healthcare services for children who have been victims of sexual assault.

Consider measures that can strengthen the child's right to protection against violence and sexual abuse in cases of visitation and custody, and report back to the Parliament in connection with the announced changes to the Child Act.
Ensure that children who have been subjected to abuse are given the right to an emergency service and an equivalent healthcare service offer as adult victims of abuse.
Investigate proposals for the legal establishment of municipal action plans against violence in close relationships and send a draft law for consultation by spring 2025.
Investigate and propose sufficient legal provisions to ensure that costs related to travel to and from crisis centers are covered.

Initiate a pilot project in at least ten municipalities of varying sizes, with the aim of implementing a universal intervention program aimed at first-time parents during the first half of the planning period. The government is requested to provide further details on the funding in connection with the state budget for 2025.
Expand the target group for children's houses to include suspected children, within the types of offenses that apply to vulnerable individuals.

Investigate and return to the Storting with a proposal to expand the target group for children's houses, so that children between the ages of 16 and 18 can also receive facilitated interviews on par with other children.
Review the regulations regarding death scene investigations when children die suddenly and unexpectedly, and assess the need for legislative changes.
Ensure that support measures, institutions, and all others working with victims of violence can provide assistance, services, and information in multiple languages other than Norwegian when needed.
Ensure that all police districts have sufficient resources for investigating cases of violence in close relationships, and that these resources are earmarked for this purpose.
Work to ensure that all municipalities can offer transitional housing or other suitable temporary accommodation for victims of violence.

Promote proposals for a better offer for victims of violence and a fast track for financial support, health follow-up, and housing options for victims of violence who wish to leave an abusive relationship.

Promote proposals for a binding national prevention strategy for a coordinated effort against partner murder and violence, in line with the recommendations from the Partner Murder Committee in NOU 2020: 17.
Initiate a comprehensive review of the police's work related to violence in close relationships and partner homicides, as part of a national prevention strategy.
Take the initiative to review the judicial system's handling of cases involving domestic violence, restraining orders, and the use of violence alarms and reverse violence alarms.
Promote a proposal to strengthen the funding for Jewish guides organized by the Mosaic Religious Community in the 2025 state budget.
Ensure updated teaching plans on antisemitism in the curriculum for primary schools.
Ensure increased competence in police education regarding the handling of hate crimes, including antisemitism.

Promote proposals on how to ensure that all Norwegian school students have the opportunity to visit former concentration camps, such as Auschwitz and Sachsenhausen, during their schooling, for example through White Buses, Active Peace Travels, and other organizations.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals on how to ensure that more school students from all over the country have the opportunity to visit former prisoner and concentration camps, such as the Falstad Center and Falstad Prison Camp, Grini Prison Camp, Auschwitz, and Sachsenhausen, within the budgetary frameworks approved each year.
Ensure control and mapping of antisemitism in Norwegian mosques and other arenas that influence Muslims' attitudes towards Jews.
Ensure that mosques and other actors that spread antisemitic attitudes are deprived of state funding.

Expand the mandate of the Rent Law Committee to allow the committee to also assess the need to introduce rules for democratic control over rental prices, as well as the need for separate non-commercial segments in the rental market.
Implement the law on price measures to set the maximum allowed rent increase in existing housing leases lower than the consumer price index in 2024 and 2025.

Map the actual composition of the rental market by gathering information about, among other things, what proportion of the rental market consists of properties owned by companies, as well as how the composition has developed over time.
Investigate how properties that are currently not anyone's primary residence, but instead used for short-term rentals and similar purposes, can be transitioned into the regular rental market.
Investigate how tenants can receive tax deductions for housing expenses, similar to how homeowners with loans receive tax deductions for interest expenses.

Discuss how the arrangement for impact assessments of natural interventions in development plans and measures can be made in an independent manner, so that the connection between the developer and the assessor is broken, while also ensuring that it does not lead to increased costs for the state or municipality.

Reestablish a goal that five percent of new hires in the public sector should be individuals with gaps in their CV or disabilities, as well as a requirement for annual reporting on the achievement of this goal.

Investigate how municipalities can eventually implement a goal that five percent of new hires should be individuals with gaps in their CVs or disabilities, which will be followed up with annual reporting.

Initiate work to investigate further and stronger measures to include more people with disabilities and more people with gaps in their CVs in the labor market in the public sector, including measures in the state's employer policy as well as measures to dismantle socially constructed barriers and discrimination, and report back to the Parliament with proposals by the end of the spring session in 2025.
Regulate a ban on logging and other forestry measures during the breeding season in forests with a high density of nesting birds.

Revise the regulation on sustainable forestry with the aim of ensuring that the regulation independently establishes all necessary main requirements for environmental considerations expected of the forestry sector, and that the regulation explicitly facilitates prosecution for serious violations.
Regulate a ban on logging during the breeding season.
Propose to include a general reporting obligation for logging in the Forestry Act § 11.

Promote a proposal for an amendment to the Forestry Act § 11 that explicitly states that all municipalities are free to introduce a notification requirement for logging and other forestry measures on the areas and for the purposes that the municipality itself desires.
Assume that forest areas owned by Statskog SF that are suitable for protection shall be protected without compensation.
Reduce the dividend from Statskog SF this year as the company protects new forest areas.
Come back to the Storting with a proposal to make commercial forestry in Norway an active contributor to fulfilling the commitments of the nature agreement.
Review the Norwegian PEFC Forest Standard to ensure that the standards collectively ensure the conservation and enhancement of biodiversity in commercially managed forests.

Review the grant schemes under value creation and development measures in agriculture and the Agricultural Development Fund (LUF), with the aim of phasing out subsidies for forestry that contribute to weakened natural conditions in production forests, including subsidies for operations in difficult terrain, subsidies for forest roads, subsidies for denser planting, and subsidies for fertilization.
Start the process of considering terminating the contract with Epic.
Halt further rollout of the Health Platform.
Instruct Health Mid-Norway RHF to quickly assess temporary alternatives to the Health Platform.
Come back to the Storting with an alternative solution to the Health Platform.
Ensure sufficient funding and resources for training and involvement when new hospitals or municipalities in Helse Midt-Norge RHF implement the Health Platform.

Ensure that the Health Platform is not implemented in more hospitals in Helse Midt-Norge RHF until the errors and deficiencies identified during the implementation at St. Olavs hospital HF are corrected.
Inform the Storting about the status and the way forward for the Health Platform.
Send the contract, with full transparency, between Helse Midt-Norge RHF and the supplier of Helseplattformen, Epic, to the Parliament.
Send the contract, with full transparency, between Helse Midt-Norge RHF and the supplier of the Health Platform, Epic, to the Parliament.
Inform the Storting about the status and the way forward for the Health Platform.
Promote proposals for changes in the legislation regarding consent competence in substance abuse treatment.
Expand the number of inpatient places within interdisciplinary specialized substance abuse treatment.

Strengthen the aftercare in addiction treatment through collaboration with private and non-profit actors, social entrepreneurs, and municipalities so that more people have the opportunity for work training and other activities after addiction treatment and rehabilitation.
Ensure that a service with integrated aftercare, including user-controlled placements, is developed as soon as possible in collaboration with the municipalities.
Ensure that capacity in the treatment services for women who are victims of violence and have substance abuse issues is built up as soon as possible in the specialist health service.
Ensure that follow-up research is initiated in connection with the further development of interdisciplinary specialized substance abuse treatment (TSB) and integrated aftercare.
Halt the reduction of inpatient beds within interdisciplinary specialized substance abuse treatment (TSB).

Conduct a comprehensive professional review of the overall treatment offerings in interdisciplinary specialized substance abuse treatment and present a projection of the need for day and inpatient treatment leading up to 2040.
Ensure that individuals with substance use disorders are offered treatment options of sufficient duration.
Ensure that patients with substance use disorders have the opportunity to choose medication-free and/or recovery-based treatment options.
Ensure that there are specific treatment options for female patients with substance use disorders.
Investigate the regulation of non-commercial surrogacy in Norway.
Promote proposals to allow simultaneous egg and sperm donation for singles and couples.
Review the availability of infertility treatment to ensure that it is genuine, equitable, and accessible.
Review the legal protection of children born to surrogate mothers abroad, with the aim of strengthening children's rights.
Promote measures that can help restrict the opportunities Norwegians have to use surrogacy services abroad, and continue the national ban on surrogacy.
Ensure that the recommendations in the report "Investigation and establishment of increased operational capacity at Klinikk Alta" are followed up.
Ensure that the day surgery activity at Klinikk Alta continues without downsizing or transferring surgery to Hammerfest and Kirkenes hospitals.
Ensure a systematic development of the service offerings at Alta Clinic, as well as the continuation of ear-nose-throat day surgery and dental treatment under anesthesia.

Come back with a new proposal for changes to the Airport Operations Act § 2. In the work on a new proposal, affected parties must be involved, with the aim of avoiding negative consequences for professional groups working at airports.
Ensure that police students who complete their education at the Police University College are guaranteed a job as police officers after graduation.
Propose to increase the police budget framework by up to 1.15 billion kroner, of which 150 million kroner is earmarked for combating youth and gang crime.
Remove the cash support and replace it with a waiting support that will provide compensation to those who lack a daycare place after the child turns one year old.
Follow up on the evaluation of the use of risk tools in the police with measures that ensure that all police districts implement PATRIARK.

Combat social control and honor culture by expanding the scheme for minority advisors, strengthening multicultural competence in the public sector, enhancing efforts against female genital mutilation and forced marriages, and supporting women's organizations that work for the inclusion of women in work and society.

Focus on areas with disadvantaged living conditions that need better housing environments and living standards. The Groruddalen initiative and other area-focused efforts are good examples that should be continued and expanded to other cities, neighborhoods, and localities where there is a need.
Establish an honor crime commission.
Establish psychiatric groups in several police districts, based on the model from the Oslo police district.

Start the work on a long-term plan for the digital infrastructure, based on similar plans from, for example, transportation, defense, or research. The plan should include long-term goals for the expansion and development of the digital infrastructure, clear political priorities, and targeted public measures to ensure that long-term goals and sub-goals/milestones are achieved.
Establish a national organization for the county bullying ombudsmen, in consultation with the ombudsmen and relevant directorates.
Develop a plan for strengthening the team around the student and returning to the Parliament by the end of the spring session in 2025.
Prepare a parliamentary report on a safe school environment and present it to the Parliament by the end of the spring session in 2025.

Promote proposals to strengthen the legislation for preschool children, ensuring that preschool children have a legally guaranteed right to a safe and good preschool environment, and that establishes an enforcement system allowing parents to bring the matter before the County Governor.
Ensure that Udir can conduct financial oversight of the parent companies of private kindergartens.
Ensure that resources are secured and prioritized for conducting financial oversight of kindergarten corporations that have spun off and sold properties to foreign owners.

Establish a continuing education and professional development strategy for vocational teachers at technical colleges, so that all vocational teachers have the right to continuing education and professional development without any personal contribution.

Change the regulations for the subject vocational specialization (YFF) so that the annual teaching hours for the subject are allocated to the subject teacher, in order to ensure that the subject teacher can take responsibility for the academic content and coordination of the education, as well as for the follow-up of the students and ongoing and final assessments in the subject.

Consider a regulatory requirement for relevant competence for vocational teachers in the subject of vocational specialization (YFF), in line with other subjects in upper secondary education, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Regulate that the school and the subject teacher are responsible for the education of students in the subject of vocational specialization (YFF).

Ensure that the announced review of the YFF subject includes a concrete assessment of the need for a resource norm, and evaluate to what extent the annual teaching hours allocated to the subject teacher are sufficient to provide quality support for the students.

Consider measures to ensure that mentors in businesses where students complete their placements have sufficient time and resources to support the students, for example through grant schemes or arrangements for relieving mentors from regular work tasks.
Consider measures that facilitate skill enhancement for supervisors in businesses that have students in internships as part of the vocational specialization subject (YFF).

Present a proposal for an amendment to the Education Act that ensures vocational students have a real right to an apprenticeship, and where the county municipality is obligated to initiate a process to get students into apprenticeships starting from the beginning of their third school year if they have not already secured an apprenticeship.
