Follow up on the letter to the Presidency of the Storting from the Parliamentary Ombudsman dated April 20, 2023, regarding – Follow-up on Document 21 (2020–2021) – evidence regarding information subject to confidentiality at the Parliamentary Ombudsman – and return to the Storting with a legislative proposal that safeguards the intention of the letter.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal on how the management of the Enlightenment Fund can be further developed, based on the premise that access to uncultivated land, good management, and cooperation and dialogue with municipalities and state agencies that are large tenants ensure good conditions, and where clear requirements are set for nature and environmental management.
Ensure that the company's goals, articles of association, or strategy contribute to the public's genuine access to hunting and fishing on the company's properties.
Present a strengthened action plan against forced marriages and inform the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Return to the Parliament with the necessary amendments regarding the follow-up of women who are subjected to violence but are afraid to ask for help due to concerns about being sent back to their home country. The matter must include an assessment of the Immigration Act § 53 b, which currently regulates the right to remain after a separation due to violence.

Evaluate how the interest limitation rules have functioned, in accordance with the recommendations of the Tax Committee. The evaluation should include the tax authorities' experiences and administrative costs related to the practical enforcement of the exemption provision.
Promote proposals to improve the regulations to ensure that foreign shareholders do not pay less withholding tax than they should.
Take the lead in a strong framework convention on tax at the UN and use its role in the ongoing working group to support the perspectives of developing countries.
Investigate the possibility of leveling the valuation of startups over 3 to 5 years after the company is registered.

Investigate the introduction of a weighted average of the value for companies in the first years after the company is listed on the stock exchange, for example, that the company is set to the weighted average of the company's value over the last five years for three years after the IPO.

Investigate and propose changes to the wealth tax to better facilitate entrepreneurs and startups, including whether all technologies should be treated equally in the exemption for intangible assets and what the current law and practice are regarding today's exemptions.

Propose changes to the option tax regulations so that the conditions for utilizing the scheme are expanded to include companies with up to 150 employees, that are no older than 12 years, and that have a balance sheet total of up to 200 million Norwegian kroner.

Investigate simplifications in the regulations for Norwegian companies that want to recruit highly qualified workers from third countries, assess whether the regulations for self-employed individuals should be adjusted, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Come back with proposals for increased tax deductions that benefit ordinary working people, such as the agricultural, seafarer, and fisherman deductions, as well as commuter and travel deductions.

Investigate how to facilitate the spread of ownership, for example, whether it could be allowed for capital owners to pay wealth tax wholly or partially by transferring ownership shares to employees or to the state.
Establish a new tax committee with a mandate to investigate changes in the tax system that reduce inequalities and ensure that the majority of people retain more of the value they create.
Present a proposal for a more progressive wealth tax with an increased basic deduction and new brackets with higher rates for large fortunes.

Present an annual report on the overall impact of the policies implemented by the government on various groups, including estimated effects of changes in taxes, fees, co-payments, benefits, and welfare schemes.
Come back with a proposal to lower the tax rates on regular and low incomes.
Come back with a proposal to raise the exemption limit.
Set an annual goal to reduce deforestation to a maximum of 6,000 acres by 2027 and to achieve net zero deforestation in Norway by 2030.
Set a goal to halt the negative development in all 24 wild reindeer areas by 2028, achieve at least medium quality in all areas by 2035, and good quality by 2050.
Ensure that municipalities within the reindeer grazing areas review their zoning plans and halt development projects in the reindeer habitats that have not yet been initiated.
Ensure that no new licenses for power production are granted in wild reindeer areas.
Introduce a ban on the construction of new cabins in the habitats of wild reindeer, including in existing cabin areas.
Introduce a ban on all new interventions in the habitats of wild reindeer.
Set a goal that at least half of the wild reindeer areas should have good quality by 2050, and that all wild reindeer areas should have at least medium quality or better by 2050.
Set a goal that all national wild reindeer areas will have good quality by 2065.

Set requirements for municipalities in wild reindeer areas and in buffer zones around wild reindeer areas when revising the land use section of the municipal master plan to take into account new knowledge about wild reindeer habitat use and regional plans for wild reindeer. The revision should include an assessment of unrealized areas for vacation homes.
Ensure that the action plans for the wild reindeer areas include measures that reestablish migration routes for wild reindeer that are currently fragmented by roads and railway lines.
To return to the Storting with an assessment of which road and railway sections can be placed in tunnels or otherwise effectively contribute to restoring the habitats of wild reindeer.
Come back with suggestions for a reduction in the use of motorized vehicles in the habitats of wild reindeer, as well as increased control of motorized traffic in these areas.
Come back to the Parliament with proposals for new protected areas and an expansion of existing protected areas in the habitats of wild reindeer.
Ensure further process for the expansion of Rondane National Park and Forollhogna National Park.

Ensure that all wild reindeer areas receive management tools equivalent to the regional plans, either through municipal land use plans, regional plans, or in another suitable way, including appropriate provisions for wild reindeer mountains in the existing planning system that the municipalities control.
Ensure effective mitigation measures for the voluntary sector in cases where marked trails or tourist cabins need to be closed or relocated.
Proceed to place 'The Wild Reindeer Capture on Dovre' on Norway's tentative list for World Heritage Sites.

Reestablish wild reindeer in Nordfjella in zone 1 with wild reindeer from zone 2 when this source population is declared healthy at the population level, so that the risk of reinfection is managed at an acceptable level.
Ensure that Norway contributes to achieving the Kunming-Montreal Agreement on 30% marine protection by 2030 by protecting at least 30% of Norwegian marine areas.
That petroleum activities, including exploration and seismic shooting, are not initiated in areas defined as particularly valuable and vulnerable (PVV).

Prohibit bottom trawling in marine protected areas and develop a plan to protect new areas from bottom trawling within particularly vulnerable and valuable regions. The Parliament requests the government to develop a plan to transition the fishing industry away from bottom trawling in these areas.

Investigate areas that are defined as particularly valuable and vulnerable areas (SVOs) for marine protection and ensure that such an investigation is conducted before permission is granted for new industrial activities in an area.

Adopt a marine spatial plan for Norwegian sea areas during the next parliamentary term. This plan should then be updated regularly as part of the management plan system. The spatial plan must set area-specific frameworks for all types of activities in Norwegian sea areas. The responsibility for such a marine spatial plan will be assigned to the existing steering group for the integrated management plans for Norwegian sea areas.
To define the SVO Ice Edge Zone in accordance with the scientific basis from the Professional Forum, with a southern boundary at maximum ice extent, i.e., 0.5 percent ice frequency.

Develop operational and measurable goals in marine management related to ecosystem impact and the preservation of biological diversity, as well as the structure, dynamics, and productivity of ecosystems, which together operationalize ecological sustainability in the use of marine ecosystems and resources.
Present a national action plan for seabirds by the end of 2024.
Reopen the licenses in Nordland VI that have previously been awarded.
Facilitate area solutions for gas evacuation from the Barents Sea, in collaboration with the industry.
Start the process of developing a licensing scheme, announcing areas, and holding a competition for preliminary commitments for new offshore aquaculture areas by the end of 2024.
Investigate how marine spatial plans can contribute to strengthening Norwegian ocean management, and report back to the Storting well before the summer of 2025.
Present a plan and propose measures to systematically restore Norwegian kelp forests along the coast to improve the marine environment.
Clarify the management system that will ensure coordination and implementation of nature restoration on land and at sea in Norway, in line with the objectives of the nature agreement.

Investigate and propose how nature can be restored on private land, and how restored nature can be protected against new destruction, and present proposals for necessary legal amendments to the Parliament.
Come back to the Storting with an action plan for the restoration of Norwegian nature on land and at sea, in line with the goals of the nature agreement.
Establish a nature restoration fund that will contribute to planning, implementing, and financing restoration projects in line with the goals of the nature agreement.
Create a system for use in all Norwegian municipalities for mapping which nature areas are suitable for restoration.

Consider measures for Oslomarka as a pioneer area for the restoration of wilder and richer nature, the restoration of deciduous forests in Eastern and Southern Norway, and the continuation of the project for the restoration of the coastal cod stock in Porsangerfjord.
Present a scaling-up plan for increasing the number of prioritized species and natural habitats, and follow up with action plans to ensure cross-sectoral coordination in the work.
Investigate a system for the valuation and payment for ecosystem services where both landowners, municipalities, and other relevant actors are compensated for restoration measures.
Show how Norway will follow up the goal of 30% restoration of degraded nature by 2030 with concrete measures.
Require all hydropower plants to conduct an assessment of the negative consequences the facility has for fish.
Impose measures on all power plants to prevent fish mortality and to reestablish free migration routes for fish where the power plant obstructs this.
Present a plan for the complete phase-out of peat in garden soil and growing media by 2030.
Investigate and return to the Storting with a condemnation scheme for shrimp trawlers that makes it easier to transition to a more environmentally friendly mode of operation.

Investigate and return to the Storting in connection with the state budget for 2025 with a plan to clean all the sediment that arises in connection with the dredging at Borg harbor on land, and reuse it for various purposes on land.
Introduce year-round protection for halibut and other deep-sea fish in a significant part of the Skagerrak.

Take the initiative to establish new bottom trawl-free zones in the Oslofjord and Inner Skagerrak, including a trawling ban in the Inner Oslofjord, in the national parks, and in parts of the Outer Oslofjord and Inner Skagerrak.
Total protection of cod in all types of fisheries in today's protected area for cod from the Swedish border to Agder.
Present enhanced measures to reduce nitrogen runoff and nutrient loading from streams, rivers, and watercourses, including the restoration of riparian vegetation.

Tighten measures to reduce nitrogen emissions from wastewater in the Oslofjord watershed, including setting stricter deadlines for the establishment of treatment plants and providing significantly larger state grants to affected municipalities.
Establish a registration system for saltwater recreational fishermen following the same pattern as for fishing for anadromous salmonids and lobster fishing.

Establish a compensation scheme for fishermen who need to adapt or pause their operations due to new environmental regulations. The scheme should include support for the development of new sustainable fishing methods, such as shrimp traps.

Establish a network of no-fishing areas in the Oslofjord and Inner Skagerrak that also includes recreational fishing and encompasses important historical spawning and nursery areas, as well as corridors for spawning migrations.
Establish a network of protected areas for seagrass, kelp, eelgrass, and other important habitats that serve as nursery and feeding grounds for fish in the Oslofjord and Inner Skagerrak.

Investigate the significance of the sprat for the ecosystem in the Oslofjord and quickly implement measures to strengthen the sprat population, including necessary adjustments to fishing quotas and the introduction of fjord lines.
Introduce maximum catch limits for important fish species, such as large and long-lived top predators.
Investigate a general ban on non-biodegradable fishing gear, so that lost fishing gear does not continue to 'ghost fish'.
Ensure that the work on preserving the Oslofjord is accompanied by follow-up research that provides the best possible knowledge base for the successful restoration of the ecosystems over time.
Conduct a practice review to ensure that children's rights are adequately assessed and considered in decisions made under the Integration Act.

Come back to the Parliament with a proposal to enshrine the principle of the best interests of the child according to the Convention on the Rights of the Child Article 3, the child's right to be heard according to Article 12, and the child's right to play and leisure according to Article 31.
Ensure that all adult asylum seekers living in reception centers can obtain a work permit while waiting for a response to their asylum application.
Facilitate free language training and a tailored introduction program for immigrants between the ages of 55 and 60.

Review the law on supplementary benefits for individuals with short residence in Norway and return to the Storting with a proposal for changes that provide better and more predictable income security for individuals who have a short residence in Norway and who have reduced work capacity, or are over 67 years old and do not have full rights in the National Insurance Scheme.

Transfer the care responsibility for all unaccompanied minor asylum seekers, both before and after settlement, to the child welfare services. The care responsibility should be anchored in the Child Welfare Act.
Transfer the care responsibility for unaccompanied minor asylum seekers aged 15 to 18 to child welfare services.
Introduce a general obligation for child welfare services to open an investigation and assess the child's care situation if a child is living privately with someone other than their parents.
Come up with a proposal for a legal amendment that grants children in asylum reception centers the right to a kindergarten place.
Clarify the settlement criteria so that refugees, as a general rule, should not be settled in areas with an immigrant share higher than 25 percent.
Investigate and implement national tests for Norwegian language training in the introduction program, with the aim of achieving better quality in education across the country.
Expand the requirement for activity for social assistance recipients, initially up to 40 years old.
Make clearer demands for participation in Norwegian language training for parents who receive free kindergarten and who are not engaged in work, education, or qualification.

Investigate and gradually implement a scheme granting the right and obligation to 200 hours of Norwegian language training and training in social studies for individuals with family immigration permits who do not have the right or obligation to participate in the introduction program.
Ensure an increase in the number of diversity advisors in the proposed state budget for 2025.
Follow up on Fafo report 2024:04 to ensure that more immigrants have the opportunity to complete upper secondary education.
Promote a proposal to increase the number of places in Jobbsjansen in the state budget for 2025.
Further develop the industry programs by creating new programs and ensuring the availability of job-oriented Norwegian language training.
Ensure that the skills policy measures for adults are well adapted to individuals with an immigrant background, with the aim of increasing workforce participation.
Develop an action plan against hate crime.
Require municipalities to conduct labor market assessments before the settlement of refugees.
Change the settlement criteria to set clearer requirements for the municipalities' integration results if they are to receive refugees.
Further develop and improve the integration contract system and ensure that municipalities utilize the arrangement.

Ensure that the system of parental guidance is improved, and that special guidance is provided related to the themes of children's rights in Norway and the responsibilities and duties that come with parental responsibility in Norway.
Ensure increased competence in preventing negative social control in municipal service offerings.
Improve aftercare for women who have been subjected to female genital mutilation.

Elaborate and return to the Parliament with proposals on how voluntary non-profit nationwide organizations engaged in integration work can receive more predictable conditions, where grants are provided for three or five years, so that evaluation and new applications with potential new agreements can be clarified well in advance of the current agreement expiring.

Return to the Storting with proposals for measures to ensure that municipalities are adequately compensated for the additional costs of receiving refugees, and measures to ensure that the elderly and others who flee to Norway, and who for various reasons are not able to work, have a predictable and dignified income security throughout their lives.
Ensure that a fast track is established to get foreign education approved in Norway.

Initiate trials with job-oriented integration packages that include workplace integration, where business actors can receive parts of the integration grant when they provide training and paid work to refugees in the introduction program.

Come back to the Parliament with proposals for incentives to make it more attractive for refugees to remain in the municipality where they are settled during the implementation of the introduction program.
Reintroduce the Housing Bank's grant scheme for rental housing and related measures to make it easier to access housing in settlement work.

Propose changes to the option tax regulations so that the conditions for utilizing the scheme are expanded to include companies with up to 150 employees, that are no older than 12 years, and that have a balance sheet total of up to 200 million Norwegian kroner.

Investigate simplifications in the regulations for Norwegian companies that want to recruit highly qualified workers from third countries, assess whether the regulations for self-employed individuals should be adjusted, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Task the Financial Supervisory Authority with establishing its own innovation center or similar, based on the model from the Swedish Financial Supervisory Authority.
Abolish the lending regulation.

Establish a committee to assess how to increase the market shares of banks and financial institutions based in Norway, and report back to the Parliament in connection with the Financial Market Report 2025.

Present measures to reduce the systemic risk associated with bank financing through covered bonds (OMF), the underlying dependence on developments in the housing market, as well as cross-ownership of OMF in the banking sector.
Ensure that Norway has preparedness in public financial institutions to immediately provide credit to businesses in an acute economic crisis.
Set a goal to reduce the share of private banks in the money supply.
Create a public solution that can be used for cash payments to individuals or households in Norway.

Promote the necessary legislative amendments to ensure a system of individual approval of credit assessments, where the central responsibility for the scheme is organized under the Brønnøysund Register Centre.
Promote proposals that further reduce banks' access to take risks outside their core business.
Promote a proposal to allow the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG) to invest in unlisted shares on a general basis.

Investigate the basis for withdrawing the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG) from gambling companies with the aim of promoting a proposal in connection with next year's management report on the fund.

Change the behavior criterion regarding the sale of weapons so that it reads: "sale of weapons to states that use the weapons in a manner that constitutes serious violations of human rights or international humanitarian law."

Change the behavioral criteria for observation and exclusion of companies to ensure that the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG) withdraws its investments from companies linked to unlawful occupation and other violations of international law.

Establish in the "Guidelines for the observation and exclusion of companies from the Government Pension Fund Global" that the fund's investments shall not undermine Norway's international legal obligations, including conventions to which Norway is a party.

Ensure that Norges Bank regularly reports on how the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG) operates in accordance with Norway's international legal obligations, including our commitments to prevent violations of the laws of war.
Ensure that Norges Bank divests from companies in the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG) portfolio that contribute to the hostilities in the Gaza Strip.

Ensure that all investments from the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG) in financial instruments issued by Israeli companies are frozen with immediate effect, and that the GPFG divests from the same companies.

Intensify efforts to avoid investments in deforestation so that the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG) achieves the goal of a deforestation-free portfolio by 2025, and if necessary, adopt plans for how this goal will be reached.
Establish a goal for NBIM's investment portfolio to achieve net zero emissions by 2050.

Start the work on establishing a climate-adjusted reference index for the oil fund and present it to the Parliament no later than in connection with next year's parliamentary report on the Government Pension Fund.
Require NBIM to demand emission pathways from the companies they are invested in by 2026.

Make changes to the "Guidelines for the observation and exclusion of companies from the Government Pension Fund Global" so that § 3 second paragraph reads: (2) Observation or exclusion may be decided for mining companies and power producers that themselves or consolidated with entities they control either: a) receive 10 percent or more of their revenues from thermal coal, b) base 10 percent or more of their operations on thermal coal, c) extract more than 10 million tons of thermal coal per year, or d) have a power capacity of more than 5,000 MW from thermal coal.
Promote a proposal that NBIM is not allowed to invest in, and is expected to withdraw from, companies that expand or make new investments in coal-related activities, both thermal and metallurgical.
Adjust the guidelines for the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG) to withdraw the fund from investments that do not meet Norwegian animal welfare standards.

Ensure that all investments from the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG) in companies that have business ties to illegal Israeli settlements in the West Bank are frozen with immediate effect, and that the GPFG divests from the same companies.

Change the criteria for observation and exclusion of companies to ensure that the Government Pension Fund Global withdraws its investments from companies that violate fundamental labor rights and deny their employees collective agreements.
Amend the regulation on the lending practices of financial institutions (the lending regulation) so that the maximum loan-to-value ratio for first-time buyers is set to 95%.

Amend the regulation on the lending practices of financial institutions (the lending regulation) so that the banks' special flexibility quota for Oslo is abolished and that there will be a common national quota of 10 percent.
Veto the inclusion of the EU's fourth energy market package in the EEA Agreement, and communicate this to the EEA Committee in accordance with Article 102 of the EEA Agreement.

Take the initiative to negotiate with the EU on a proposal for an agreement regarding the terms of Norwegian membership. The process should be transparent and ensure that the public is kept informed. A final draft of the agreement should be presented for a referendum.

Come up with suggestions on how the public debate about the EU and EEA can be revitalized, including by increasing financial support for the member-based, grassroots organizations' information work on the topic.
To investigate the advantages and disadvantages of Norwegian EU membership compared to the current EEA membership.
To join Belgium's initiative for EU sanctions against goods produced in Israel's illegal settlements.
Take the initiative to restore the UN Special Committee against Apartheid.
Join Belgium's initiative for economic sanctions against Israel.
Deliver an intervention statement in the case South Africa brought against Israel before the International Court of Justice, clarifying Norway's view on how the genocide convention should be applied.
Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner with a report on Norway's obligations under the genocide convention as they are relevant to Norwegian cooperation with Israel.
Take the initiative for the USA and other NATO member countries to stop all deliveries of weapons, weapon components, and dual-use goods that could contribute to war crimes.
Investigate which grants and schemes can be changed or introduced with the aim of rewarding municipalities for preserving nature.
Promote a proposal for an increase in free revenues to the municipal sector of at least 8 billion kroner.

Consider an additional compensation in connection with the new income system for municipalities for municipalities with low tax revenues, which will be in addition to the 1.5 billion kroner in the Municipal Proposition 2025, where the fund is distributed at a uniform rate per inhabitant. The funds will be allocated to municipalities with an average tax revenue per inhabitant – according to the definition of income equalization – that is lower than the national average for the period 2021–2023, and where tax revenue, including natural resource revenues, does not exceed 105% of the national average level.
Investigate the maximum number of years a municipality should be allowed to remain on the ROBEK list.
Reintroduce a specific capital grant.

Increase the municipal sector's revenues by 6.035 billion kroner beyond the government's proposal in the Municipal Proposition 2025, with an estimated 3.335 billion kroner for the municipalities and 2.7 billion kroner for the county municipalities.

Extend the implementation of the tax reform and the symmetrical income equalization from two to three years, so that municipalities experiencing significant cuts in their revenues are given time to adjust their welfare services accordingly.
Promote a proposal to further lower the maximum rate for property tax from 4 per mille.
Reintroduce trials with state-funded elderly care to improve the quality of elderly care.

Promote proposals for the introduction of a challenge right so that private actors can challenge public monopoly operations of services in order to achieve greater diversity and better quality at the right cost for taxpayers.
Ensure that the connections that are allowed to use the 2017 key as a starting point will also be able to benefit from the other improvements to the scheme from 2017 to today.
Establish a common rate for municipal wealth tax for all municipalities.
Look into the possibility of further strengthening the loan framework of the Housing Bank.

Consider changes and return to the Parliament with proposals on how the expenditure equalization in the income system for municipalities can place greater emphasis on and compensate for the municipalities' involuntary costs related to living conditions challenges.

Take the initiative to research which socioeconomic criteria are relevant for explaining the resource needs of municipalities, also using methods other than those typically used as the basis for cost keys in the municipal revenue system.
Look into further strengthening the compensation to municipalities for the child welfare reform, for example through an increase in the general grant.

Ensure that the arrangement for free ferries is fully funded by the state, and return to the proposal for the state budget for 2025 with a scheme that does not incur additional costs for the operators of the ferry service.
Consider returning to the Storting with a solution for the establishment of a National Avalanche Center located in Lyngen municipality.
Consider an additional transitional arrangement for the municipalities that are hardest hit by the reduction of the PU criterion in the new income system for municipalities.
Promote a proposal to include fast ferries to island communities without a mainland connection in the free ferry scheme.

Consider a longer transition period and/or additional compensation during a transition phase for municipalities that experience extraordinarily large revenue losses due to the introduction of a new income system for municipalities.

Investigate a change in the income system where municipalities that are above 140% of the national average in income per inhabitant, including the same income that the government has based its extended income concept for district grants in Southern Norway on, should not be compensated through income equalization.
That a financing scheme will be established in connection with the state budget for 2025 to alleviate the financial burden on the former host municipalities following the HVPU reform.
Abolish the upper age limit for the top financing scheme for resource-intensive services.
Promote proposals for increased funding for elderly care and investments in more care homes and nursing home places through the Housing Bank's investment grants.
Raise the age limit to 70 years for top funding of particularly resource-intensive services starting in 2025.
Consider improving the top financing scheme for resource-intensive services in municipalities.
Present a model for a support scheme for investments in nitrogen removal from wastewater in areas that are subject to new treatment requirements.

Facilitate the opportunity for kiosks and gas stations to participate in the Merkur program on the same terms as actors in the grocery industry, as Menon suggests in the report prepared for the Ministry of Local Government and Modernization (Menon publication no. 131/2021).
Investigate a settlement arrangement so that health services used outside the municipality of residence can be charged to a greater extent to the municipality where the service recipient pays taxes.

Monitor the development of the restructuring of the PU criterion in the expenditure equalization closely and ensure that municipalities have the resources to provide good and legally mandated services for people with disabilities, and keep an eye on ensuring that the service offerings in the municipalities are not reduced as a result of the restructuring.
Evaluate experiences with the down-weighted PU criterion.
Emphasize municipal self-governance as a fundamental value in planning, land use, and building matters more strongly than in current practice.

Investigate how a transitional arrangement of five years for income equalization, including for owner income, under the new income system should be implemented, and report back to the Parliament with a proposal no later than in connection with the state budget for 2025.
That changes to the income system for municipalities are postponed and further investigated.
Investigate one or more factors that better address the specific situation of growth municipalities.

Investigate a model for capital city grants, including how it can be introduced and structured. The government is requested to present a proposal on this to the Storting no later than in connection with the state budget for 2025.

Investigate a regional political grant for municipalities with significant living condition challenges, including how the grant can be structured and implemented. The government is requested to present a proposal to the Parliament no later than in connection with the state budget for 2025.

Investigate grants and schemes that can be changed or introduced to better address the living conditions challenges in the municipalities. The government is requested to present proposals to the Parliament no later than in connection with the state budget for 2025.
Investigate changes in the regulations so that municipalities can set different tax rates for secondary, vacation, and primary residences.
Evaluate the new income system for municipalities by 2029.

Change the name of the PU criterion in the expenditure equalization in the income system for municipalities by removing the term "mental." The diagnoses that fall under the criterion remain unchanged.
Evaluate the restructuring of the top financing scheme for resource-intensive services and assess the entry point for resource-intensive services in connection with regular budget processes.

Come back to the Storting with an assessment of compensation for the municipalities that stand out with the largest negative first-year impact per inhabitant as a result of the changes in the income system for municipalities.

Change the subsidy schemes so that they more effectively stimulate increased production, and actively use the subsidy schemes to favor reindeer owners who have reindeer herding as their main livelihood.
Initiate a comprehensive revision of the reindeer herding law, and in this context, make new assessments and establish upper reindeer numbers so that they more closely align with grazing resources.
Review the established population targets for large carnivores in reindeer husbandry areas with the aim of reducing the target numbers and decreasing the populations to the new population goals.
Introduce an exemption from the road usage tax for operational vehicles in reindeer herding.
Continue the subsidy scheme for seal hunting in line with price increases to ensure ongoing population regulation and the maintenance of traditions in coastal communities.
Come back to the Parliament with a five-year plan to contribute to increased catch of seals, whales, and other marine mammals.
Promote a proposal to remove subsidies from the state budget for seal hunting.
Prioritize the start of tunnel work on E45, Natoveien between Altafjorden and Finland, in the spring of 2025.
Commit to maintaining and securing county roads that are used for detours when national roads are closed.
Increase the annual support for county roads by 1 billion NOK per year, so that the support over the planning period is increased by a total of 12 billion NOK.

Make an assessment of which county roads can be returned to the state based on the criteria of state-regulated emergency roads, high maintenance backlog, and strategic national road sections, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.

Continue the focus on traffic safety for children and young people by maintaining the framework of the Children's Transport Plan from the previous National Transport Plan with a similar allocation and support scheme.

Establish a grant scheme for the counties for landslide, avalanche, and flood protection, where the state and the county municipality commit to a 50/50 distribution for the protection routes, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner.
Ensure that increased funding is allocated in the National Transport Plan specifically for the establishment of more express bus routes across the country.
Increase the government share of larger public transport projects from 66% to 80% starting in 2025.
Terminate all projects in the road development portfolio, except for Rv. 19 Moss, which will be prioritized with funding in the transport plan.
To rebuild the Ålgård Line in the first six-year period.

Shut down Nye Veier and discontinue E6 Moelv-Øyer, E16 Skaret - Hønefoss, E6 Ulsberg - Melhus, E18 Arendal-Grimstad, E18 Tvedestrand - Bamble, E16 Kongsvinger - E6, E39 Lyngdal - Ålgård, E18 Ytre Ringvei, Rv 4 Hunndalen - Mjøsbrua, Rv 26 Hamar - Løten, E6 Øyer - Otta, E39 Mandal - Lyngdal. Remaining projects will be transferred to the Norwegian Public Roads Administration.
Ensure that municipalities that wish to establish night train connections to foreign countries on their own have the opportunity to do so.

Introduce a new scheme for new toll-financed road projects, where tolls are increased by 25%, which will be allocated to a fund for the maintenance of nearby roads, better solutions for cyclists and pedestrians, and to improve public transport services in the region where the toll-financed roads are being built.

Follow up on the recommendations from the Norwegian Railway Directorate regarding double-decker trains and proceed with the procurement of these so that double-decker trains can be in place in Eastern Norway before 2030.
Establish an annual fund for difference contracts aimed at emission-free fuel for shipping.
Improve the current E16 route to Ringerike so that the road capacity is not increased, but necessary upgrades are made to accident-prone sections to enhance traffic safety.

Transfer funds from new highway projects to a pool for improving and renewing existing national roads with measures such as more median barriers, wider road shoulders, and landslide and avalanche protection.

To investigate an alternative route for the Ringeriksbanen that has fewer negative consequences for nature and agricultural land, and that ensures significantly shorter travel time between Oslo and Bergen.
Move more of the funds aimed at maintenance and renewal of the railway to the first six-year period, and increase the total amount allocated for maintenance and renewal of the railway.
Register Norway in the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) as part of the TEN-T cooperation, so that Norway can apply for EU funds for the development of future transport projects.

Ensure that more funds are allocated for environmentally friendly improvements of shipping routes, so that projects like the dredging at Borg harbor can be carried out in a more sustainable and circular manner.
Demand fossil-free construction sites by 2025 and emission-free construction sites by 2030 for all state transportation projects.
Start negotiations on the urban growth agreement for Grenland as soon as possible. Negotiations with Buskerudbyen will commence as soon as local decisions on toll financing are approved.
Instruct the Norwegian Public Roads Administration to terminate all further planning related to phases 2 and 3 of the E18 West Corridor and E6 Oslo East.

Require area neutrality for all state transportation projects so that the total amount of nature restored equals the amount lost due to development. Preferably, the restoration of nature should be carried out in the same municipality where the nature is lost.
Demand the use of nitrogen and environmentally friendly explosives in all transportation projects as soon as it is feasible.
Deliver a climate account for all calculable climate effects in the short and long term from the finally adopted National Transport Plan (NTP).
Create a plan to initiate the process of phasing out tender operations and consolidating the railway into a fully integrated organization.
Set the reduction of noise and air pollution from state transportation infrastructure in urban areas as a separate priority criterion in the next revision of the National Transport Plan.

Ensure that all construction of roads, railways, and other infrastructure, including that which is built by the Norwegian Public Roads Administration, Nye Veier, and Bane Nor, is carried out with Norwegian wage and working conditions and without social dumping.
Set an annual target for Avinor regarding reduced air traffic, where the reduction should occur in flights between the major cities and in international traffic.
Initiate a KVU for the railway line Oslo-Stockholm, in accordance with the recommendation in the Norwegian Railway Directorate's feasibility study of September 30, 2022.
Incorporate a plan for the improvement of the Sørlandsbanen in the next iteration of the National Transport Plan.

Investigate and return to the Storting with proposals on how infrastructure contributions from large private landowners can be used to co-finance future railway development, based on the model of how this is done for large local public transport projects.
Set specific targets for emission reductions for the various transport sectors leading up to 2030, in line with what is necessary to collectively meet national goals and international commitments.

Review the construction portfolios of the Norwegian Public Roads Administration and Nye Veier to downscale projects planned with motorway standards and four-lane solutions, with the aim of reducing environmental impact, greenhouse gas emissions, and costs.
Map out and present to the Parliament an overview of the rehabilitation needs for bridges, both on national roads, county roads, and railways.
Incorporate a plan to catch up on maintenance backlog for railways in the next iteration of the National Transport Plan.
Increase the state share for larger public transport projects to 80% starting from the renegotiation of existing urban development agreements.
Ensure that the annual grant to urban areas without urban growth agreements is strengthened.
Planning for the reopening of the Ålgård Line.
Follow up on the recommendations from the Railway Directorate regarding double-decker trains.

Make the following changes to the project portfolio for the National Transport Plan 2025–2036: Projects to be prioritized: E18 Ramstadsletta–Nesbru Ringeriksbanen Vestfold Line, double track Stokke–Torp–Sandefjord Vestfold Line, double track Sandefjord–Larvik, planning funds Rv. 15 Strynefjellet E16 Fagernes–Hande, planning funds Rv. 19 Moss Rv. 4 Nittedal–Gjelleråsen, planning funds Trønderbanen, electrification and two trains per hour to Steinkjer Ofotbanen Double-decker trains by 2030 Increased maintenance of the railway Freight terminal Eina Nord, planning funds The port in Longyearbyen Majorstuen station Increased framework for urban growth agreements and reward schemes for smaller urban areas Increased cycling framework Wildlife crossings. Projects to be deprioritized in the National Transport Plan 2025–2036: E18 Retvet–Vinterbro E16 Nymoen–Eggemoen E6 Moelv–Øyer (New Roads AS) Østfold Line, double track Råde–Seut Dovre Line, double track Hamar–Åkersvika Free ferry.
Assign Enova the responsibility for establishing 30 publicly accessible hydrogen filling stations by 2027.
Secure a minimum of 200 million kroner in planning funds for the further planning of the double track between Sandefjord and Larvik.
Ensure that the annual grant to urban areas without urban growth agreements is continued with at least 150 million kroner in annual average.
Give Enova the responsibility for establishing a national network of filling stations with liquid biogas by 2027.
Ensure that the maintenance backlog on the railway is reduced by at least one third during the National Transport Plan period.
Facilitate the construction of the planned double track Sandnes–Nærbø, and that the planning of the stretch further to Egersund continues.
Ensure assistance in the planning of the new rail-based public transport service in Nord-Jæren and ensure that construction can take place in the final part of the planning period.
Ensure that the subway extension to Skårer in Lørenskog becomes part of the next urban growth agreement between the state and the Oslo area, and that the project is financed as a 70/30 project.
Ensure service improvement on the Jæren Line by facilitating increased frequency between Stavanger and Skeiane station as soon as possible.
Ensure further planning of the double track between Sandefjord and Larvik.
Ensure progress in the process of the Northern Norway railway and follow up the KVU with a KS1 and KS2 in the National Transport Plan period.

Introduce a GPS-based system for road pricing of heavy vehicles based on the initiated investigation in the area. This will be actively used as a tool to achieve the goal that all new trucks should be zero-emission vehicles or run on biogas by 2030.
Dissolve Nye Veier AS and transfer ongoing projects to the Norwegian Public Roads Administration.
Scrap the plans for the new E18 between Nesbru and Ramstadsletta.
Ensure that municipalities can set their own fine levels for parking violations so that there is also the possibility for increased fines for repeated offenses.
Ensure that universal design is set as an absolute requirement in all tender processes in the transport sector.
Allocate sufficient funds to halve the current child and student ticket prices for trains throughout the entire National Transport Plan period.
Ensure that the toll rate for zero-emission vehicles can be set to a maximum of 70% of the rates for fossil fuel-powered passenger cars, and ensure that this rule is maintained until at least 2030.
Open for municipalities to establish geographically limited zero-emission zones.
Initiate the work to electrify the remaining diesel lines on the railway in the first six-year period of the National Transport Plan 2025–2036.
Stop the plans for the E6 between Moelv and Øyer over the Lågendelta nature reserve.
Focus on wildlife crossings for railways and roads.
Come up with a new investigation of high-speed trains in the first six-year period of the National Transport Plan 2025–2036.
Investigate section-wise high-speed railways between the largest cities in Norway, as well as between Oslo–Gothenburg and Oslo–Stockholm.
Open for differentiated rates for new fossil cars registered after January 1, 2026.
Continue the goal that 30% of all goods transported over distances greater than 300 km should be transferred from road to sea and rail by 2030.
Develop a national plan for the transfer of goods from road to rail and sea, which coordinates the agencies in the area, with the aim of transferring all transferable goods.

Intensify the work on a comprehensive universal design of the transport sector, including platforms and boarding and alighting from the means of transport, to ensure that everyone can use public transport, including on railway lines, regardless of ability, and continue the goal of universal design in the transport sector by 2035.

Explain the work on harnessing the potential for local energy production on developed areas in connection with transportation infrastructure through requirements and goals for transportation agencies.
Present a separate county road plan to the Parliament.
Present a county road plan to the Parliament, with proposals for structural measures that can better enable the public sector to catch up on the maintenance backlog of county roads.
Scrap the plans for a third runway at Oslo Airport Gardermoen and a second runway at Bergen Airport Flesland.
Include the Bybanen to Åsane in the National Transport Plan 2025–2036 with a start in the first six-year period.

Commit to contributing to the extension of the Light Rail to Åsane, including the new Fløyfjell Tunnel, in the first six-year period, with at least 70% state funding for the rail portion of the project and that negotiations are held regarding a possible toll contribution for the Fløyfjell Tunnel. The Storting requests that the government primarily bases this on the valid zoning plan, and secondarily requests that the government will help ensure that the work on the Light Rail and Fløyfjell Tunnel begins in Eidsvåg/Åsane in the first six-year period, pending Bergen municipality's completion of its supplementary study related to section 1 in Bergen city center.
Ensure that the train service on the Trønderbanen is strengthened, and that the schedule of two trains per hour between Trondheim and Steinkjer becomes a reality by no later than 2027.

Prioritize RV 15 Strynefjellet with the branch to Geiranger in the National Transport Plan's first six-year period, with start and implementation during this part of the planning period. The branch to Geiranger is co-financed by the state in a project that is a collaboration with Møre and Romsdal County Municipality. The state finances and carries out planning and design.
Prioritize E39 Smiene–Harestad for Nye Veier AS's portfolio.
Prioritize E39 Figgjo–Ålgård for Nye Veier AS's portfolio.
Prioritize E39 Osli–Figgjo for Nye Veier AS's portfolio.
Assign the project E39 Solevågseidet–Veibust/Blindheim–Moa to Nye Veier AS's portfolio.
Create a new urban transport program that equalizes the modes of transport and aims for a simpler and more efficient daily travel experience.
Prioritize the initiation of dredging in Leirpollen in Tana.
Facilitate the reclassification of county roads with high traffic volumes or a high proportion of commercial traffic to national roads.
Prioritize further development of the E70 road.
Maintain earmarking of state funds for county roads.
Prioritize the construction of E6 Sørelva–Borkamo in the first six-year period of the National Transport Plan 2025–2036.
Prioritize contributions to the financing of a new subway tunnel in Oslo as part of the urban transport program.

Investigate how new technology can be used to detect if an avalanche occurs on the road, prevent cars from entering the avalanche area, and detect if there are cars or people inside the area, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner by spring 2025.
To ensure preparedness for air ambulance services at Haugesund Airport and to compensate the airports for the associated costs.
To ensure the start of convoy driving for heavy vehicles over E134 Haukeli in the upcoming winter 2024–2025.
Prioritize the expansion of double track on the Ofot Line.
Prioritize the development of a new intersection solution for Kopstad Freight Terminal at E18 Vestfold.
Prioritize comprehensive improvement of the Meråker Line.
Prioritize the development from E18, Batteriveien Arendal.
Prioritize the development of Ballstad fishing harbor.

Make the following changes to the project portfolio for the National Transport Plan 2025–2036: Projects to be prioritized: E18 Ramstadsletta–Nesbru Ringeriksbanen E39 Hordfast Vestfold Line, double track Stokke–Sandefjord E39 Vik–Molde E10 Nappstraumen–Å E18 Retvet–Vinterbro E39 Smiene–Harestad E134 Dagslett–E18 Rv. 15 Strynefjellet E6 Narviktunnelen Rv. 19 Moss. Projects that are not ready and therefore deprioritized: Østfold Line, double track Råde–Seut E6 Høybukta–Hesseng, Finnmark Rv. 4 Grua–Roa, Innlandet E16 Nymoen–Eggemoen, Buskerud E39 Klakegg–Byrkjelo, Vestland.
Prioritize the construction of E39 Vik–Molde in the first six-year period of the National Transport Plan 2025–2036.
Prioritize the construction of E39 Smiene–Harestad in the first six-year period of the National Transport Plan 2025–2036.
Report the status of the maintenance backlog in the road sector when the national budget is presented.
Specify goals for automated transport for all modes of transport in both the short and long term. The goals should also be considered across different modes of transport.

Review alternative energy carriers for the railway lines that have not yet been electrified, in light of the technological developments that have occurred since KVU Green presented its report, with the aim of finding more optimal and cost-effective solutions to ensure zero emissions in the transport sector. The work should also be viewed in the context of value chains that can be established and the business development of new energy carriers.
Report Norway into the EU's Union Database for Sustainable Fuels.
That zero and low-emission solutions are ensured in upcoming tenders.

Facilitate locally produced energy on developed areas and buildings in connection with all transport infrastructure such as roads, railways, airports, port facilities, and parking lots, and quantify a target for such production for the transport sector.
Demand zero emissions on the Coastal Route by 2030.
Facilitate more heart zones around schools.

Provide a progress report regarding the status of the implementation of the findings from the National Audit Office in Document 3:10 (2023–2024) Seamless Public Transport and the government's work on the conclusions presented in the report, in connection with the state budget for 2025.
Promote your own case to the Parliament with proposals for measures to catch up on the backlog of county roads.

Prioritize comprehensive development to a four-lane standard for the E18 Oslo–Riksgrensen project, including the sub-project Retvet–Vinterbro. It is assumed that the start will take place in the first six-year period of the National Transport Plan 2025–2036.
Prioritize the construction of E134 Dagslett–E18, Viker in the first six-year period of the National Transport Plan 2025–2036.
Prioritize the construction of E18 Ramstadsletta–Nesbru. It is assumed that the project will start in the first six-year period of the National Transport Plan 2025–2036.
Prioritize the construction of E39 Ring Road East, starting in the first six-year period of the National Transport Plan 2025–2036.
Prioritize the development of E39 Hordfast.
Initiate an external evaluation of the National Transport Plan as a tool for further developing the transport system.
Prioritize the construction of the E6 Narvik Tunnel.

Investigate how Avinor can be given better incentives to operate more efficiently and under competitive conditions moving forward. Areas where services can be put out to competition should be considered. The Parliament requests the government to return with a suitable approach.
Maintain the arrangement with ferry replacement funds, so that these can be used in calculations for national and county roads in ferry replacement projects.
Ensure that commercial operators in passenger and freight transport have access to publicly owned or publicly supported charging infrastructure during times of the day when there is capacity.
Prioritize the development of E10 Nappstraumen–Å in the first six-year period of the National Transport Plan 2025–2036.
Accelerate the RV 15 Strynefjellet, including the branch to Geiranger in the National Transport Plan 2025–2036, and ensure commencement in the first six-year period.
Continue the Ringeriksbanen and the new E16 Skaret–Hønefoss (FRE16) as a joint project to ensure the economic benefits and sustainability of the project.

Ensure that the charging infrastructure at larger charging stations along the national roads is designed to allow for the maintenance of rest and break times without having to move the car after charging is completed.
Remove RV. 19 Moss from the development portfolio and ensure the project starts during the planning period.
Strengthen the funding for county roads with a focus on traffic safety, business and emergency roads, and continue the earmarked grant scheme for the maintenance of county roads.
Ensure further planning and initiation of capacity-increasing measures for the Trønderbanen that enable two trains per hour between Trondheim and Steinkjer during the planning period.
Start the double track project Stokke–Torp–Sandefjord on the Vestfold Line in the first six-year period of the National Transport Plan 2025–2036.
Accelerate the capacity-increasing work on the Ofot Line in the National Transport Plan 2025–2036, and ensure the start of the project within the planning period.
Include the state contribution of 500 million kroner for Majorstuen station in the National Transport Plan 2025–2036, in the first six-year period.

Investigate how new technology can be used to detect if an avalanche occurs on the road, prevent cars from entering the avalanche area, and detect if there are cars or people inside the area, and report back to the Parliament in an appropriate manner by spring 2025.
Evaluate the new schedules for the FOT routes and the consequences of half price on full fare tickets, and find improved solutions within the tender period.
Present a case that incorporates the projects for which there is now a majority decision in the Storting into the NTP portfolio, no later than in connection with the RNB 2025.

Promote a case for the further development of the road reform that includes the following points: a) The Norwegian Public Roads Administration, along with the Road Directorate, will be dissolved and replaced by a new administrative body for the road sector. b) The Ministry of Transport shall have a greater direct responsibility for the management of the road sector. c) Vehicle technical services will be increasingly performed in the private sector to ensure better accessibility across the country. d) The former construction division of the Norwegian Public Roads Administration shall have the same framework conditions as Nye Veier AS. e) Nye Veier AS shall be treated equally with the new administrative body for road matters as a premise provider for the development of the road sector. f) Road standards and speed limit criteria shall be modernized to align with practices in Norway's neighboring countries.

Provide a more detailed account of the specific measures that will be implemented to clarify responsibilities and improve collaboration between the ministry, county municipalities, and subordinate agencies within the road sector.

Conduct a comprehensive review of the Road Act (veglova) with the aim of updating the law so that it better reflects societal needs, technological development, and other considerations that the law should address.
Promote a proposal for a scheme with senior policy measures to be negotiated between the pensioners' organizations and the government.
Return to the Parliament in the state budget for 2025 with a permanent increase of at least the minimum rates for disability benefits and work assessment allowance by 0.05 G.

Investigate a scheme that grants a monetary supplement to pensioners and disabled individuals with low income to equalize increased income disparities. For old-age pensioners, the increase should ensure that everyone receives a minimum of two-thirds of the adjustment for individuals with low-wage supplements in the front sector negotiations. For disability pensioners, the increase should ensure that everyone receives at least in line with the low-wage profile in the front sector.

Create a plan for the annual increase of the minimum pension and guaranteed pension for singles in relation to the EU poverty threshold (EU60), where the first step in the escalation plan is implemented in the state budget for 2025 with an increase of 10,000 kroner.
Establish a new standard in line with SIFO's reference budget.
Ensure that the survivor's pension is regulated in the same way as the rest of the pension and that this is implemented in connection with the state budget for 2025.
Implement the Storting's previous decision that organizations in connection with the annual welfare negotiations should be able to negotiate other issues of significance for pensioners.
Develop a plan for the annual increase of the minimum pension level towards the EU poverty threshold (EU60), with the first step in the escalation plan to be implemented in the state budget for 2025.
Ensure that sole proprietorships and limited companies with the owner as the only employee are approved as staffing agencies.
Consider a limited exception to the Working Environment Act so that independent IT consultants and advisors with specialized expertise can continue to deliver work and assignments.

Follow up on the conclusions from NOU 2022:19 Oil Pioneers – a compensation scheme, so that the recommended compensation scheme for those who were exposed to chemicals in the early period of the oil industry can be established.
Follow up on the work with the oil pioneers and return to the Storting in an appropriate manner as soon as possible.
Stop the possibility of granting exemptions from the nationality requirement for captains on ships in the NIS register from countries that pose a significant security risk to Norway.
Review all permits and arrangements for individuals from countries that pose a significant security risk to Norway, across all sectors, with the aim of closing vulnerabilities.
Suspend the issuance of navigation certificates to citizens of countries that pose a significant security risk to Norway.
Make a revision of the regulations regarding qualifications and certificates for seafarers, taking into account the current security policy circumstances.

Return to the Storting in an appropriate manner with an assessment of the current system for issuing certificates for foreign seafarers. The assessment should include a review of the risk landscape, the practice of granting exemptions, and the consequences of any potential changes.
To introduce a grant scheme for outdoor pig farming.
Ensure that Norway takes on a leadership role in removing agriculture as part of the WTO agreement, to secure Norway and other nations' sovereignty over their own food production.
Strengthen the Information Office for fruits and vegetables, and investigate a model for an independent information office for sustainable and health-promoting food.
Strengthen customs protection by transitioning from kroner to percentage tariffs on tariff lines where percentage tariffs provide the best protection, effective from January 1, 2025.
Not using a normalization factor when comparing income in agriculture and other professions.
To investigate the removal of the coordination of the relief grant with other income.
Establish a normalization factor for calculating the farmer's income equivalent to 5 percent.
Remove the percentage standardization used for calculating income in agriculture by 2027.
Continue to use wages for industrial workers as a benchmark for future calculations of income opportunities in agriculture.

Of the 250 million kroner from the funds in chapter 1150, item 73.13 in the budget for 2025, milk price subsidies will be reallocated as follows: - Grain price subsidies, item 73.19, will be increased by 100 million kroner - Vegetable price subsidies, item 73.17, will be increased by 150 million kroner.

10 million kroner of the funds for livestock grants, chapter 1150 and item 74.14, in the budget for 2025, will be reallocated as follows: - The market measures for green initiatives, item 70.11, will be increased by 2.6 million kroner earmarked for the Information Office for Green - A new item will be established under direct grants, item 74.21, Operating grants for vertical green production, with an allocation of 6.4 million kroner.

The 30 million kroner in chapter 1150, item 73.15 meat price support in the budget for 2025, is reallocated as follows: - Support for advisory services, item 77.13 is increased by 10 million kroner - Support for joint facilities for fruit, item 77.17 is increased by 10 million kroner - Support for the Agricultural Development Fund, item 50, and measures for regional facilitation funds earmarked for county-specific initiatives with Food Nation Norway, is increased by 4 million kroner - Support for the Agricultural Development Fund, item 50, the funds for MetanHUB, is increased by 6 million kroner.
The subsidy for livestock, chapter 1150 item 74.14, in the budget for 2025, is reduced by 50 million kroner.
The operating grant for milk and meat, chapter 1150 item 74.11, in the budget for 2025, is reduced by 50 million kroner.

Present a plan to increase the share of organic agricultural land in Norway to 15% by 2030, and follow up the plan with concrete measures and adjustments to support schemes in the upcoming agricultural negotiations.

Establish arrangements that encourage increased use of market gardens and community-supported agriculture for fruits and vegetables, which are not based on the amount of land in use, but rather on production, diversity, and quality.
Link Norwegian agricultural policy more closely to the EU's agricultural policy by first investigating the most important opportunities in a common European market, compared to the current situation.
Introduce CO2 labeling of groceries.
To strengthen the focus on climate measures in agriculture to a level that ensures the agricultural sector meets the goals of the climate agreement between the state and agriculture.
Ensure follow-up on the Food Nation Norway, and assess necessary measures to strengthen the focus on local food.
Use coverage rate as a measure of how well-equipped Norway is to ensure food for the population in a crisis situation.
Follow up on the agricultural climate agreement to contribute to changing the food consumption of the Norwegian population so that food consumption aligns as much as possible with dietary guidelines.
Adjust production support so that it is more profitable to produce food with low emissions and the use of local resources.
Facilitate the cultivation of more legumes such as peas and field beans.
Facilitate the use of climate-friendly and sustainable feeding practices.
Strengthen the focus on the production of plant crops for food, in order to increase self-sufficiency.
Develop a national soil health strategy.
Work to ensure that Norwegian products, such as fruits and vegetables, can have greater variations in shape for consumers.
Increase information to consumers about food, healthy diets, and proper nutrition.
Facilitate increased area-independent production such as urban agriculture and vertical farming.

Ensure that the new market scheme for milk has been in operation for at least one year before considering the reduction of the competition-enhancing measures in the price equalization scheme for milk.

Come back with a separate case proposing principles for calculating income in agriculture and comparing it with other groups, to ensure democratic anchoring of the data used in agricultural settlements and legitimacy for the negotiation institution.
Investigate a package of measures to reduce agricultural land that is out of operation.
Stimulate less use of concentrated feed and more use of Norwegian-produced roughage.

Ensure that the fast ferry connections announced in 2024 with requirements for emission-free technology, prior to the government's announced requirement for zero emissions for new ferries and fast boats, are included in the compensation scheme provided in connection with the requirement.
Promote a proposal to introduce a tax on fast fashion products in connection with the state budget for 2025.

Promote a proposal to amend § 5 of the law on the Government Pension Fund to allow direct transfers from the fund to a fund for the restructuring of the Norwegian economy and a solidarity fund to cover expenses related to the wars in Ukraine and Gaza.
Develop a financing scheme for green investments based on the same model as SDØE, including for offshore wind.
Consider a ban on the export of textile waste to countries that are poorly equipped to handle the reception of this waste.
Halt the rollout of the Health Platform and replace it with other, well-functioning solutions.
Announce areas for offshore wind in 2025 that allow for at least 5 - 10 TWh of new production.
Announce the offshore wind areas in Vestavind B and Vestavind F in 2025.
Ensure that electric vans have access to bus lanes, both during and outside of rush hours, without requiring passengers.
Review the fee structure under the Norwegian Environment Agency to ensure that it is not designed in a way and does not have a size that counteracts green transition and technology development.

Expand charging stations for electric vehicles at state workplaces and reserve these spaces for electric vans at night. The government should appropriately encourage municipalities and county municipalities to do the same for their employee parking spaces.
Promote a proposal to equalize the tax deduction opportunities related to pension savings between self-employed individuals and regular employers.
Enter into an additional agreement with Enova that ensures the goals of Norway's climate agreement with the EU are met, for example, by achieving the interim targets set for the transport sector.
Facilitate the continued development of the National Salmon Center foundation, located in Lyngdal, Lærdal, Namsos, and Tana, through core funding in the state budget.

Establish regulations on energy and environmental requirements for public procurement of maritime transport in accordance with the consultation proposal of May 4, 2023, to introduce zero-emission requirements for new tenders for fast ferries, and present guidelines and a plan for compensation to county municipalities for additional costs resulting from this in connection with the state budget for 2025.
Propose ways to ensure that the regional public transport system receives adequate operational funding without cuts to service offerings or increased ticket prices.
Give a national directive that electric vans should be exempt from tolls throughout the country until 2027.

Follow up on the agreement with the EU regarding the strategic industrial partnership on sustainable value chains for land-based raw materials and batteries by actively facilitating the participation of Norwegian companies in the qualification for strategic projects under the CRMA (Critical Raw Material Acts).

Propose amendments to the Tax Act § 14-41 so that investments in rental properties are covered by the regulations for declining balance depreciation, for example, similar to the rate for hotels, buildings and construction, or the rate for commercial properties.
Present a plan for upgrading existing shelters and expanding the total capacity of shelters in Norway.

Return to the Storting with proposals for increased appropriations if the need for ammunition, spare parts, and maintenance during 2024 exceeds the government's proposed increases in the revised national budget.
Increase the framework for the Nansen program.

Take the initiative for a common European collaboration to increase the production of weapons and military equipment. Such an initiative could be part of the EU's Act in Support of Ammunition Production (ASAP), the UK's International Fund for Ukraine (IFU), and the initiatives from the Czech Republic and Estonia for the procurement of ammunition for Ukraine, but could also directly support weapon production in Ukraine and/or other similar programs or initiatives. A Norwegian financial contribution to such a collaboration must be in addition to the Nansen program.
Ensure that a price index is developed that better reflects the consumption of recipients of social assistance and other low-income individuals.

Ensure that benefits and allowances set outside the social security settlement are proposed to be adjusted upwards annually in the revised national budget if the inflation forecast in the revised national budget increases compared to what was used for adjustments in the state budget, so that these at least keep pace with inflation.

Come up with suggestions on how the regulations for housing support can be changed so that extraordinary increases in benefits, such as one-time payments to those on minimum disability benefits and Christmas bonuses in social assistance, do not lead to a reduction in housing support.
Set a goal that electricity consumption in the building stock should be a maximum of 56 TWh by 2030, in line with the recommendations from NVE.
Develop an action plan with new and existing measures to ensure that electricity consumption in the building stock does not exceed 56 TWh by 2030.

Change the criteria for which nonprofit organizations are eligible to provide donors with tax deductions, so that organizations that only receive value-added compensation for volunteer organizations in public support can be included on the list.
Change the rules for value-added tax compensation for voluntary organizations, so that renovations of premises, new buildings, and pure donations once again qualify for compensation.
Restore the Elderly Ombudsman from January 1, 2025.
Investigate a fund for large hospital investments.
Start the winding down of Nysnø Climate Investments and complete it by 2025.

Follow up on previous decisions made by the Storting regarding the establishment of a Nav ombud, and ensure necessary funding for the Foundation for Justice and their service "Help with Nav" until the approved Nav ombud is established and operational.
Promote proposals to allow tobacco-free snus.
Instruct the regional health authorities to purchase available private hospital capacity to reduce waiting times.
Clarify the responsibility relationship between the police and the healthcare system for seriously mentally ill individuals.
Ensure that the budget for the new police station project in Bergen is increased in accordance with the application from the Police Directorate.

Ensure the advance funding, pending later co-financing from Møre og Romsdal County Municipality, for the quickest possible securing and opening of Fv.63 Trollstigen so that it can fulfill its crucial role for the entire tourism industry in the region this summer season.

To map the staffing situation in the SFO (School's After School Program) offerings in collaboration with the parties involved. This will outline new measures to improve staffing and the quality of the SFO offerings. The mapping will also gather information about the extent of transportation related to SFO, school holiday programs, and accommodations for children with special needs, and identify relevant measures related to these.

Adjust the grant scheme for increased pedagogical density in kindergartens in areas with challenging living conditions, while simultaneously strengthening it, so that it becomes a grant scheme for increased pedagogical density and increased basic staffing.

Promote a proposal to amend the dental health law so that individuals aged 25 and 26 are granted the right to treatment in the public dental health service on par with young adults up to 25 years old.

Send out for consultation revised guidelines for the allocation of Housing Bank loans for student housing, so that non-profit foundations are also eligible for Housing Bank loans for the construction of student housing.

Continue the dialogue and specify the content of an energy partnership with the oil and gas industry, established in connection with the oil tax package, in line with the description in the Revised National Budget 2024, with the aim of continuing emission reductions in the industry to help achieve the climate goal for 2030. An important premise for the partnership is that the oil and gas industry, within the framework of fiscal policy, should contribute more to the financing of floating offshore wind than they do today, by increasing the CO2 tax on the continental shelf leading up to 2030.

The government in the state budget for 2025 proposes an ambitious support program for floating offshore wind areas in Vestavind B and Vestavind F. The commitment authority will be based on updated cost estimates. The support program will amount to at least 35 billion kroner and will significantly contribute to the development of floating offshore wind and the electrification of petroleum installations, while also maintaining the power balance on the mainland.

Investigate the introduction of new restrictions on bottom trawling and seine nets to ensure that the coastal fleet has increased priority in coastal fishing, especially in areas with high natural value.
Investigate an extension of the withholding tax to also apply to payments to countries that are not considered low-tax countries.
Send out for consultation a proposal for a ban on new peat extraction, with the ban coming into effect as soon as possible and before October 1, 2025.
Provide an assessment of a potential subsidy scheme for long-distance buses on routes without trains and similar commercial offerings.

Ensure that the Norwegian Public Roads Administration participates in the ongoing work on the tram to Bjerke/Tonsenhagen, in dialogue with Ruter, within the framework of the locally revised agreement on Oslopakke 3, and maintain progress in following up on the recommendations from the collaboration project between the City of Oslo and the Norwegian Public Roads Administration regarding rv. 4. This is subject to approval through local political processing and decisions regarding Oslopakke 3 in the City of Oslo and Akershus County Municipality.
Include the tax authorities' experiences and administrative costs related to implementing the exemption provision in practice.
Propose to exempt light electric vans from the traffic insurance fee, subject to notification and approval by ESA.

Investigate and return to the Storting during the spring session of 2026 with a proposal for consumer legislation regarding the rental of goods, in order to ensure comprehensive consumer protection for rental, leasing, and sharing services.

Remove the licensing requirement for solar parks up to 10 MW located on industrial sites, commercial areas, airstrips, or similar, so that permits are granted by the municipalities according to the Planning and Building Act.
Set a goal of reducing electricity consumption by 10 TWh in the total building stock by 2030 compared to 2015, and report back to the Parliament on this in connection with the state budget for 2025.
Establish a traffic start no later than 2030 for direct night trains from Oslo to Copenhagen and/or Hamburg, and engage in dialogue with the necessary authorities and operators during 2024.
